Up to 12 people were diagnosed with viral meningitis, relatively common illness, all caused by an enterovirus, and were hospitalized as a result.\n\nDirector Public Health, Curtis Gregory, said the 1st person became unwell in late March [2018] and the others in early April [2018].\n\n'There have been no indications of common links between the cases other than 2 patients who were from the same family,' Dr Gregory said. 'We have interviewed the patients and examined medical records to look for any common source of the infection. Further laboratory testing is also being carried out to identify which type of enterovirus has caused these illnesses.\n\n'All of the patients have now been discharged from hospital after making a full recovery.' Symptoms of viral meningitis can include fever, headache, sensitivity to light, lethargy or tiredness, stiff neck, nausea and vomiting. It is important that all people with symptoms of meningitis are seen by a doctor immediately. Viral meningitis can sometimes cause serious illness on its own and symptoms are very similar to those of bacterial meningitis, which requires urgent medical treatment.\n\nViral meningitis is the most common type of meningitis, which is an inflammation of the lining of the brain and spinal cord. It is usually much less severe than bacterial meningitis, and most people get better without treatment within 7 to 10 days.\n\nEnteroviruses are spread from person to person through respiratory droplets, saliva, feces or contact with contaminated items or water.\n\nThe best means of protecting yourself from infection and stopping transmission is through effective hand washing and good hygiene practice. This is particularly important prior to eating, after using the toilet, changing a nappy or helping care for a sick person. There is no specific treatment for most cases, with rest and plenty of fluids recommended and medication to manage any pain and headaches.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Illawarra is a coastal region in the Australian state of New South Wales, located immediately south of Sydney and north of the Shoalhaven. The coastal city of Shoalhaven is approximately 200 km (120 mi) south of Sydney (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_of_Shoalhaven). A map of Shoalhaven can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Shoalhaven,+NSW,+Australia.\n\nWe are told in the news report above that there are 12 cases of enteroviral meningitis in Illawarra, but we are not told how an enterovirus was established as the cause. Testing the cerebrospinal fluid, rectal or throat swabs for enteroviruses by cell culture or reverse transcriptase PCR can be used. We are also told that no common links exist between the 12 cases, other than 2 patients were from the same family, and that further laboratory testing is being carried out to identify which type of enterovirus has caused these illnesses.\n\nThe enteroviruses include coxsackievirus, echovirus, enterovirus, and poliovirus. Enteroviruses are common causes of viral meningitis, especially in children, during the summer and fall months (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2174764/). Summer months in New South Wales span December to February and fall months, March to May. Most people who get infected with enteroviruses are asymptomatic or have only a non-specific febrile illness. Enteroviruses are most often spread via the fecal-oral route from person to person, through fecal contamination of water or food, or contact with contaminated inanimate objects. Enteroviruses can also be spread through the respiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus) of an infected person.\n\nMaps of Illawarra, New South Wales, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5004 and\nShoalhaven Shire, New South Wales, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/45053. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nViral meningitis is the most common type of meningitis, which is an inflammation of the lining of the brain and spinal cord. This was revealed by the Minister for Health and Medical Services Rosy Akbar in Parliament yesterday [Tue 17 Apr 2018].\n\nMs. Akbar said the ministry declared a national outbreak of meningococcal C on [20 Mar 2018], after a review was made on the evidence and recommendations by health experts on the National Meningococcal Taskforce.\n\nShe added that there have been 46 cases from [1 Jan to 12 Apr 2018]; 22 cases were laboratory confirmed and 24 were either suspected or probable cases with similar symptoms, but not diagnosed by laboratory.\n\nAccording to her, the Central Division reported 27 cases, Western Division 16 cases, Eastern Division 1 case and Northern Division had 2 cases.\n\n'There have been 4 confirmed meningococcal disease related deaths and 2 suspected from [1 Jan to 12 Apr 2018],' she said. And of these, males account for 63 per cent of cases while females for 37 per cent.'\n\nShe said the current case number for 2018 includes a cluster of cases reported from Navesau Adventist High School in Ra. In 2017 there were 48 cases with a total of 7 deaths reported -- including an outbreak at St John's College in Cawaci, Ovalau --, and were reported from January to June 2017 with up to 2 students getting sick within a month. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n MENINGITIS, UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - NIGERIA (03): FATAL, SCHOOLCHILDREN\n*********************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2017-12-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Katsina", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5735431", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Fiji (02): fatal, children", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5735431", "date": "2018-04-09 13:45:10", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - FIJI (02): FATAL, CHILDREN\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Apr 2018\nSource: Fiji Centre for Communicable Disease Control, Ministry of Health and Medical Services [edited]\nhttps://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/_Fiji%20Meningococcal%20C%20Weekly%20SITREP%20V2_060418.pdf\n\n\nFiji meningococcal C outbreak situation report; volume 2, 2018\nNational Update (1 Jan-5 Apr 2018)\nFiji Centre for Communicable Disease Control, Ministry of Health and Medical Services\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nOverview\n--------\nThe Fiji Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MoHMS) declared an outbreak of meningococcal [serogroup] C on [Tue 20 Mar 2018]. The Ministry, through the National Meningococcal Disease Taskforce, continues to coordinate the response to the outbreak, including strengthening surveillance, laboratory diagnostics, clinical management, public health interventions, and risk communications.\n\nSurveillance\n------------\nNational surveillance is coordinated by the Fiji Centre for Communicable Disease Control (FCCDC) through weekly indicator based surveillance for meningococcal disease via 34 EWARS [Early Warning, Alert and Response System] sites; EWARS event-based surveillance reporting of suspected cases; laboratory based surveillance for _Neisseria meningitidis_; and active case investigation reports.\n\nNational update (1 Jan-5 Apr 2018)\n----------------------------------\nMoHMS is reporting both confirmed and suspected cases. Therefore, there have been a total of 38 cases from [1 Jan-5 Apr 2018]. Of these, 22 cases are laboratory-confirmed, and 16 are either suspected or probable cases (WHO case definitions). There has been an average of 2.5 cases per week in the last 4 weeks.\n\nAs of [5 Apr 2018], all cases were in the 19 years or younger age group:\n- 39.5 percent of cases: younger than 5 years old\n- 18.4 percent of cases: 5-9 years old\n- 26.3 percent of cases: 10-14 years old\n- 15.8 percent of cases: 15-19 years old\n\nMales account for 63.2 percent of cases and females, 36.8 percent. 4 confirmed and 2 suspected meningococcal deaths.\n\nA cluster of 6 cases was reported from Navesau Adventist High School (boarding school) in Ra from [28 Feb to 28 Mar 2018]. No deaths reported.\n\n*The current national incidence for 2018 is 4.1 per 100 000 population (38 cases). The Central Division has the highest incidence of 6.0 per 100 000 (23 cases), followed by Western at 3.3/100 000 (12 cases), Eastern at 2.6/100 000 (1 case), and Northern at 1.5/100 000 (2 cases).\n\n*The 6 Navesau Adventist High School cases were reclassified from Central Division to Western Division in week 13 [week ending 30 Mar 2018].\n\nInterventions\n-------------\nClinical case management:\n- Clinicians have been alerted and have access to the new Meningococcal Public Health Management Guidelines.\n- A nationwide training on the guidelines from [9 Apr 2018] covering all 4 divisions.\n- Deployment of ceftriaxone to subdivisions completed.\n- Ensuring access to rifampicin for prophylaxis of high-risk contacts.\n\nPublic health response:\n- Nationwide training on use of the new guidelines to start [9 Apr 2018].\n- Case investigation, education, rifampicin prophylaxis, commenced from notification of 1st case from Navesau Adventist High School. Active case finding at the school daily.\n- Vaccination of students at Navesau Adventist School began [5 Apr 2018].\n- Strengthening of infection and prevention control measures has been emphasized to all divisional and subdivisional officers.\n- Involvement of the Infection Prevention and Control officers in the rollout of the guidelines.\n\nRisk communication:\nImplementation of the Meningococcal Disease Risk Communication plan, including dissemination of key messaging, mass media and school campaigns. Production of risk communication packages targeting the general public and specific focal groups.\n\nContact:\nDr Aalisha Sahukhan, National Advisor Communicable Disease <aalisha@gmail.com>\nDr Daniel Faktaufon, Medical Officer\n<dbfaktaufon@gmail.com>\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As pointed out by Kathleen Harriman, PhD, MPH, RN (Chief, Vaccine Preventable Diseases Epidemiology Section California Department of Public Health Richmond, CA, <kathleen.harriman@cdph.ca.gov>), the CDC recently updated their meningococcal disease outbreak guidance and no longer recommends the use of an absolute outbreak threshold. The new guidance can be found at: https://www.cdc.gov/meningococcal/downloads/meningococcal-outbreak-guidance.pdf. The relevant portion of the guidance is extracted below:\n\n8.3 Outbreak thresholds\n-----------------------\n'The purpose of declaring an outbreak is to determine when appropriate public health interventions should be considered. In contrast to previous guidance in which a threshold of 3 cases of the same serogroup with an attack rate of more than 10 cases per 100 000 population during a 3- month period was used to define both organization- and community-based outbreaks, the current guidance does not recommend the use of an absolute threshold. However, the following thresholds can be considered as guidance, with considerable flexibility to account for the unique nature of each meningococcal disease outbreak.\n\nFor organizations, 2-3 outbreak-associated cases within a 3-month period is considered to be an outbreak (Box 4 -- see below). In most situations, 2 cases within an organization constitute an outbreak. However, in some situations, such as an outbreak within a large university (for example one with more than 20 000 undergraduate students) where no identifiable subgroup at risk within the population can be identified, it may be reasonable to declare an outbreak after 3 cases.\n\n'For communities, an outbreak is defined as multiple outbreak-associated cases with an incidence of meningococcal disease that is above the expected incidence in a community during a 3-month period (Box 4). Several strategies may be considered to determine whether incidence is above expected in a community. For instance, incidence during the current 3-month period can be compared with the incidence during a similar time period in previous years, or in the setting of very low or unstable monthly incidence, annual incidence in the 3-5 years prior. If community incidence has historically been very low or zero, comparisons against state or national incidence can be made. Additional supportive evidence of an outbreak should be solicited, such as similarity of the strains by molecular typing and common epidemiologic or social characteristics of cases. Consultation with CDC is encouraged if an outbreak is suspected.\n\n'Box 4. Outbreak thresholds\nThresholds by outbreak type\nOrganization-based: 2-3 outbreak-associated cases within an organization during a 3-month period.\nCommunity-based: multiple outbreak-associated cases with an incidence of meningococcal disease that is above the expected incidence in a community during a 3-month period.\n\n'Although an absolute outbreak threshold is no longer used, calculating an outbreak attack rate may still be useful in determining the magnitude of an outbreak and comparing against a historical baseline. An outbreak attack rate per 100 000 population is calculated as follows: [(number of outbreak-associated meningococcal disease cases during a 3-month period) / (population at risk)] x 100 000. The epidemiology of the cases should be used to determine the appropriate denominator for attack rate calculations and should include the population of the smallest geographic area that contains the cases and be limited to the sub-populations in which cases were reported (such as among certain age-groups or social networks). For some populations, such as MSM [men who have sex with men], determining the denominator can be very challenging. Results of local or statewide surveys (such as proportion of adult male population that is MSM, proportion of population with HIV) along with census data can be helpful in estimating population sizes.\n\n'Previous versions of the outbreak guidance do not define the term 'cluster' of meningococcal disease, though this term is used informally by public health officials. In this updated guidance, the term cluster can be used to describe a grouping of cases thought to be epidemiologically related that are still under investigation or that do not meet the definition of an outbreak.\n\n9. Vaccination\n--------------\n9.1 Decision to vaccinate\n'Vaccination is the preferred control measure for meningococcal disease outbreaks of all serogroups commonly seen in the United States (B, C, W, and Y). However, many factors should be taken into consideration when determining the need for vaccination. While the number of cases is important, other factors to consider include the population size, ability to define a target group for vaccination, whether ongoing transmission is likely, feasibility of a vaccination campaign, and timing of potential vaccination in relation to cases. In situations where ongoing transmission is unlikely (such as cases limited to household members, roommates, or boyfriend/girlfriend), a vaccination campaign is not necessarily indicated as long as antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis of close contacts is implemented to prevent further transmission.\n\n'The guidance above suggests thresholds for considering vaccination, but decisions to vaccinate should be made on a case-by-case basis in consultation with the local/state health department and CDC taking into account all circumstances and epidemiology specific to the outbreak.'\n\nIn terms of an organization-based outbreak, a cluster of 6 cases was reported from Navesau Adventist High School (boarding school) from [28 Feb to 28 Mar 2018], that is, more than the CDC definition of an outbreak of 2-3 outbreak-associated cases within an organization during a 3-month period. Vaccination, presumably with a conjugate meningococcal vaccine that covers meningococcus serogroup C, of students at Navesau Adventist School began [5 Apr 2018].\n\nIn terms of a community-based outbreak, with a total of 38 cases in the 1st 3 months of 2018 and the population of Fiji being 920 938 (July 2017 est.) (https://www.indexmundi.com/fiji/demographics_profile.html), the national attack rate is 4.1/100 000, as reported above. However, all cases in 2018 were less than 19 years of age and almost 85 percent of cases (32 cases) were less than 15 years of age. This age group represents the population at greatest risk; with 27.7 percent of the Fiji population or about 255 100 people in this age group (https://www.indexmundi.com/fiji/demographics_profile.html), their attack rate is 32 cases/255 100 (that is, 12.5/100 000) in the 1st 3 months of 2018, which is much more than the only 1 to 10 cases, or 0.11 - 1.1 cases/100 000 reported annually in years prior to 2016 (see prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Fiji: fatal 20180321.5701022). However, we don't have a breakdown by age for cases before 2016; but, assuming all the cases (1 to 10 cases) were 14 years of age or less, with about 30 percent of the population being 14 years of age or less, or about 270 000 children, the annual attack rate for children 14 years of age or less would be 1 to 10/270 000 or 0.37 to 3.7/100 000.\n\nWe are told in the report above that Fiji's Central Division has the highest meningococcal meningitis incidence of 6.0/100 000 (23 cases/383 333 population). However, assuming 30 percent of the Central Division population is under 15 years of age, this group has an attack rate of 20/100 000 (23/115 000).\n\nNevertheless, no mention is made about vaccinating all Fiji children less than 15 years of age or vaccinating this age group in the Central Division. Also, genotyping of meningococcal isolated would help establish an outbreak strain.\n\nFiji is an island nation of more than 330 islands in Melanesia in the South Pacific Ocean about 2000 km (1300 miles) north east of New Zealand's North Island (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiji). Fiji is divided into 4 major divisions, Central, Eastern, Northern, and Western, and 14 provinces. For a map of Fiji's divisions, see http://www.geographicguide.com/pictures/map-fiji.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Fiji is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/167 - Mod.ML]", "summary": "As of [5 Apr 2018], all cases were in the 19 years or younger age group:\n- 39.5 percent of cases: younger than 5 years old\n- 18.4 percent of cases: 5-9 years old\n- 26.3 percent of cases: 10-14 years old\n- 15.8 percent of cases: 15-19 years old\n\n Dr Daniel Faktaufon, Medical Officer\n<dbfaktaufon@gmail.com>\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As pointed out by Kathleen Harriman, PhD, MPH, RN (Chief, Vaccine Preventable Diseases Epidemiology Section California Department of Public Health Richmond, CA, <kathleen.harriman@cdph.ca.gov>), the CDC recently updated their meningococcal disease outbreak guidance and no longer recommends the use of an absolute outbreak threshold. However, we don't have a breakdown by age for cases before 2016; but, assuming all the cases (1 to 10 cases) were 14 years of age or less, with about 30 percent of the population being 14 years of age or less, or about 270 000 children, the annual attack rate for children 14 years of age or less would be 1 to 10/270 000 or 0.37 to 3.7/100 000. In terms of an organization-based outbreak, a cluster of 6 cases was reported from Navesau Adventist High School (boarding school) from [28 Feb to 28 Mar 2018], that is, more than the CDC definition of an outbreak of 2-3 outbreak-associated cases within an organization during a 3-month period. This age group represents the population at greatest risk; with 27.7 percent of the Fiji population or about 255 100 people in this age group (https://www.indexmundi.com/fiji/demographics_profile.html), their attack rate is 32 cases/255 100 (that is, 12.5/100 000) in the 1st 3 months of 2018, which is much more than the only 1 to 10 cases, or 0.11 - 1.1 cases/100 000 reported annually in years prior to 2016 (see prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Fiji: fatal 20180321.5701022). An outbreak attack rate per 100 000 population is calculated as follows: [(number of outbreak-associated meningococcal disease cases during a 3-month period) / (population at risk)] x 100 000. The Central Division has the highest incidence of 6.0 per 100 000 (23 cases), followed by Western at 3.3/100 000 (12 cases), Eastern at 2.6/100 000 (1 case), and Northern at 1.5/100 000 (2 cases). In contrast to previous guidance in which a threshold of 3 cases of the same serogroup with an attack rate of more than 10 cases per 100 000 population during a 3- month period was used to define both organization- and community-based outbreaks, the current guidance does not recommend the use of an absolute threshold. \n\n'For communities, an outbreak is defined as multiple outbreak-associated cases with an incidence of meningococcal disease that is above the expected incidence in a community during a 3-month period (Box 4). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n However, all cases in 2018 were less than 19 years of age and almost 85 percent of cases (32 cases) were less than 15 years of age. The epidemiology of the cases should be used to determine the appropriate denominator for attack rate calculations and should include the population of the smallest geographic area that contains the cases and be limited to the sub-populations in which cases were reported (such as among certain age-groups or social networks). In terms of a community-based outbreak, with a total of 38 cases in the 1st 3 months of 2018 and the population of Fiji being 920 938 (July 2017 est.) (https://www.indexmundi.com/fiji/demographics_profile.html), the national attack rate is 4.1/100 000, as reported above. Community-based: multiple outbreak-associated cases with an incidence of meningococcal disease that is above the expected incidence in a community during a 3-month period. For organizations, 2-3 outbreak-associated cases within a 3-month period is considered to be an outbreak (Box 4 -- see below). However, in some situations, such as an outbreak within a large university (for example one with more than 20 000 undergraduate students) where no identifiable subgroup at risk within the population can be identified, it may be reasonable to declare an outbreak after 3 cases. For instance, incidence during the current 3-month period can be compared with the incidence during a similar time period in previous years, or in the setting of very low or unstable monthly incidence, annual incidence in the 3-5 years prior. \n\n'Although an absolute outbreak threshold is no longer used, calculating an outbreak attack rate may still be useful in determining the magnitude of an outbreak and comparing against a historical baseline. While the number of cases is important, other factors to consider include the population size, ability to define a target group for vaccination, whether ongoing transmission is likely, feasibility of a vaccination campaign, and timing of potential vaccination in relation to cases. Organization-based: 2-3 outbreak-associated cases within an organization during a 3-month period. \nClinical case management:\n- Clinicians have been alerted and have access to the new Meningococcal Public Health Management Guidelines. --------------\n9.1 Decision to vaccinate\n'Vaccination is the preferred control measure for meningococcal disease outbreaks of all serogroups commonly seen in the United States (B, C, W, and Y). The current national incidence for 2018 is 4.1 per 100 000 population (38 cases). https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/_Fiji%20Meningococcal%20C%20Weekly%20SITREP%20V2_060418.pdf\n\n\nFiji meningococcal C outbreak situation report; volume 2, 2018\n The relevant portion of the guidance is extracted below:\n\n8.3 Outbreak thresholds\n However, assuming 30 percent of the Central Division population is under 15 years of age, this group has an attack rate of 20/100 000 (23/115 000). \n\nA cluster of 6 cases was reported from Navesau Adventist High School (boarding school) in Ra from [28 Feb to 28 Mar 2018]. \n\nPublic health response:\n- Nationwide training on use of the new guidelines to start [9 Apr 2018]. \n\n'The guidance above suggests thresholds for considering vaccination, but decisions to vaccinate should be made on a case-by-case basis in consultation with the local/state health department and CDC taking into account all circumstances and epidemiology specific to the outbreak.' \n\n'Previous versions of the outbreak guidance do not define the term 'cluster' of meningococcal disease, though this term is used informally by public health officials. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - FIJI (02): FATAL, CHILDREN\n******************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-07-26 00:00:00", "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Melanesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand 's", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5736191", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: sg.B, ciprofloxacin-resistant, military, 2017", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5736191", "date": "2018-04-09 23:51:54", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - TAIWAN: SEROGROUP B, CIPROFLOXACIN-RESISTANT, MILITARY BASE, 2017\n*********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Apr 2018\nSource: Taiwan Epidemiological Bulletin Volume 34, Number 7 [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov.tw/english/info.aspx?preview=true&treeid=3847719104BE0678&nowtreeid=5125C5DE158A5D51&tid=A5A0321FF0CAD68D\n\n\nAn Outbreak of Ciprofloxacin-Resistant Serogroup B Meningococcal Disease in a Military Base, 2017\n--------------------------\nHsueh-Mei Chiang, Chien-Shun Chiou, Chuen-Sheue Chiang, Shu-Man Yao,Hao-Hsin Wu, Yu-Ning Fan, Hsin-Yi Wei\n\nOn 23 Jul 2017, a hospital in Taoyuan reported a suspected case of meningococcal disease, who was a soldier in a military base, to Taoyuan Department of Health. After investigation, another 2 soldiers who served in the same base with the index case developed symptoms of meningitis and were reported subsequently. Blood cultures from all 3 cases yielded serogroup B _Neisseria meningitidis_ with indistinguishable pulsed-field gel electrophoresis patterns. A total of 114 contacts received chemoprophylaxis with rifampin or ciprofloxacin. Nevertheless, the hospital laboratory found that the isolate from the index case was resistant to ciprofloxacin. Of the 98 contacts receiving ciprofloxacin as initial chemoprophylaxis, 54 contacts were offered azithromycin, while the rest 44 contacts declined. No secondary cases were identified in the contacts during the one-month follow-up period. The outbreak underscores the importance of antimicrobial surveillance of _Neisseria meningitidis_. The antimicrobial profiles of isolates from the cases should be reviewed and taken into consideration in terms of chemoprophylaxis for contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Angela Song-En Huang\n\n[Household and other close contacts of persons with invasive meningococcal disease have a higher risk for carriage and invasive disease, for which they should receive antibiotic chemoprophylaxis to eliminate nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ as soon as possible. Ciprofloxacin has been an effective single-dose oral chemoprophylaxis agent. However, sporadic isolates ciprofloxacin-resistant meningococci disease began to appear in the Americas, Europe, Australia, China, and India. As a result, in 2008, the U.S. CDC recommended ciprofloxacin should no longer be used for chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal disease in communities where fiprofloxacin-resistant strains have been identified (selected U.S. counties in North Dakota and Minnesota). Ceftriaxone and rifampin are alternative agents (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm). Azithromycin is also recommended in communities where ciprofloxacin resistance has been detected (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/surv-manual/chpt08-mening.html).\n\nMaps of Taiwan can be seen at http://www.mapsofworld.com/taiwan/taiwan-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/193. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Angela Song-En Huang\n\n[Household and other close contacts of persons with invasive meningococcal disease have a higher risk for carriage and invasive disease, for which they should receive antibiotic chemoprophylaxis to eliminate nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ as soon as possible. '[According to] our records, 51 cases were recorded in 14 Local Government Areas; 14 of them died.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project member\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 24 Mar 2018\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\nThere is a suspected outbreak of cerebrospinal meningitis (CSM) in Majiya town, Taura Local Government Area of Jigawa state. Victims started with complaints of fever and numbness in their legs. There are 51 suspected cases in 10 Local Government Areas of the state, with 15 deaths.\n\nIn Niger state, there are 4 dead in Katcha Local Government Area from the C strain of cerebrospinal meningitis. 31 cases have so far been reported; 9 have been confirmed positive for serotype C. Cases and deaths recorded remain confined to 2 Local Government Areas: Magama and Katcha.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project member\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Sat 24 Mar 2018\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\nI have also heard the same report from the head of the department and from other colleagues in my healthcare facility. From their reports, meningitis was the suspected illness due to the symptoms that were observed and the season in which it occurred (hot season). It is a known fact that during the hot season in the north, especially the extreme northeast and northwest, the temperature can be as high as 45 C [113 F], and meningitis is usually the common illness.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project member\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Many thanks to the EpiCore Global Surveillance Project members for their responses.\n\nFrom the above responses, there are likely multiple local outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis, some of which have been confirmed to be due to serogroup C.\n\nA map of Nigeria that shows the location of its states can be found at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNigeria: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62]", "summary": "[According to] our records, 51 cases were recorded in 14 Local Government Areas; 14 of them died.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project member\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n 31 cases have so far been reported; 9 have been confirmed positive for serotype C. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNigeria: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62]", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Majiya village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5724160", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Sudan: Darfur region", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5724160", "date": "2018-04-02 18:21:28", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - SUDAN: DARFUR REGION\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Apr 2018\nSource: All Africa [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201804020088.html\n\n\nTests have confirmed 14 cases of meningitis in Central Darfur, with reports of other cases in South, North, and East Darfur. Medical sources told Radio Dabanga that 14 meningitis (cerebro-spinal fever) cases have been confirmed through lab tests in Central Darfur.\n\nThe sources pointed to the presence of cases in South Darfur, denied by the Ministry of Health and the state government.\n\nOn Wednesday [28 Mar 2018], Nyala witnessed the overcrowding of large numbers of patients in the private clinic and health centres after the hospital was completely free of any medical staff after the withdrawal of deputy specialists working in the hospital.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sudan is a country in the Nile Valley of North Africa. It is divided into 18 states or wilayat (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudan). Five states (Central, East, North, South, and West Darfur) compose the Darfur region in western Sudan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darfur). Nyala, with a population of 565 734 (2007), is capital of South Darfur (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyala,_Sudan). For a map of Sudan showing the location of Nyala, see https://www.google.com/maps/@12.0521585,24.909482,6z.\n\nThe African 'meningitis belt', which stretches from Senegal in West Africa to the Horn of Africa in the east and includes Sudan, has been plagued yearly by large epidemics of meningococcal meningitis (http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm). The meningitis outbreaks occur in the dry season (December to April) and end at the onset of the rainy season (May to June). Larger outbreaks occur every 8-12 years. A map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif.\n\nThe predominant pathogen had been meningococcus serogroup A. However, after preventive mass vaccination of the population with conjugate meningococcal meningitis serogroup A vaccine (MenA) was introduced in 2010, the epidemiology of meningitis in the African meningitis belt changed. As of November 2017, more than 280 million people have been vaccinated in 21 African belt countries (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). In Sudan, the vaccination campaign against meningococcal A meningitis was launched in 2012, targeting 16.9 million children and adults in the 5 Darfur states (Central, East, North, South, and West Darfur), Blue Nile, Khartoum, Gezira, Sennar and Gedaref.\n\nSubsequently, in the African meningitis belt, serogroup A meningococcus has been replaced by other meningococcal serogroups and other bacterial species. However, the above news report fails to specify what pathogen is causing meningitis in the Darfur region. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSudan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n However, after preventive mass vaccination of the population with conjugate meningococcal meningitis serogroup A vaccine (MenA) was introduced in 2010, the epidemiology of meningitis in the African meningitis belt changed. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sudan is a country in the Nile Valley of North Africa. He said that the ministry received the information about the outbreak of a strange disease and dispatched its Rapid Response Team to the area. 'The team reported that the 1st case was reported on 15 Mar [2018] in the area, and the victims died instantly before reaching a health facility,' he said. He said some other cases were recorded in the area but were not reported early to the hospitals.\n\nMr Getso further revealed that the patients had a high fever and convulsions, as well as vomiting, and it was later confirmed to be cerebrospinal meningitis type A. The state, he said, had already strengthened surveillance to fish out unreported cases and had also set up a special team to deal with the people identified with the disease.\n\nHe said, in addition, that the ministry had also embarked on a massive mobilization on the disease because of its fast spreading and contagious nature.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nOlutayo Babalobi\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\nDepartment of Veterinary Public Health & Preventive Medicine,\nUniversty of Ibabadan, Nigeria\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Olutayo Babalobi for this news report, which clarifies the location of the meningococcal serogroup A meningitis outbreak to Dungurawa village of Dawakin Tofa Local Government Area in Kano state, Nigeria.\n\nDawakin Tofa has a population of 247 875 in the 2006 census (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawakin_Tofa). A map showing the location of Dungurawa village can be found at http://1worldmap.com/Nigeria/Kano-State/Dungurawa/2592511.\n\nA map of Nigeria that shows the location of its states can be found at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nKano State, Nigeria: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/887]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Olutayo Babalobi for this news report, which clarifies the location of the meningococcal serogroup A meningitis outbreak to Dungurawa village of Dawakin Tofa Local Government Area in Kano state, Nigeria. 'The team reported that the 1st case was reported on [Thu 15 Mar 2018] in the area and the victims died instantly before reaching a health facility,' he said. Getso gave further details saying that the patients had a high fever and convulsion as well as vomiting and was later confirmed to be cerebrospinal meningitis type A [_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A?].\n\nHe said surveillance has been strengthened to fish out unreported cases and has also set up a special team to tackle the people identified with the disease. In addition, he said, the ministry has also embarked on massive mobilization of people affected with the disease because of its nature of being contagious.\n\n[Byline: Okponyia Onyedikachi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\npromed@promedmail.org\n\n[The exact location of the 8-person outbreak of meningitis type A [presumably _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A] is not specified in the news report from Kano, Nigeria. Kano is the state capital of Kano State in northwest Nigeria (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kano). Kano State is located between Katsina State, where ProMED-mail recently reported the deaths of 8 students from an undiagnosed illness and Jigawa State, where ProMED-mail also recently reported the deaths of 8 students from meningitis, the type not being specified at the time (see prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, undiagnosed illness - Nigeria: (KT) fatal, schoolchildren, RFI 20180324.5707401.) It could be a previously unreported outbreak in Kano State, or perhaps it is referring to the outbreaks in neighboring Katsina or Jigawa States. More information is required concerning these outbreaks in northern Nigeria.\n\nA map of Nigeria that shows the location of its states can be found at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Kano State is located between Katsina State, where ProMED-mail recently reported the deaths of 8 students from an undiagnosed illness and Jigawa State, where ProMED-mail also recently reported the deaths of 8 students from meningitis, the type not being specified at the time (see prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, undiagnosed illness - Nigeria: (KT) fatal, schoolchildren, RFI 20180324.5707401.) Contacted, the State Commissioner of Health, Dr. Abba Zakari, confirmed the outbreak of the disease, and promised further details today [7 Mar 2018].\n\n[Byline: Aliyu M. Hamagam]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jigawa, with a population of 4.3 million residents, located in north-central Nigeria, is one of 36 states that constitute the Federal Republic of Nigeria state; its capital is Dutse (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jigawa_State).\n\nNorthern Nigeria lies within the African meningitis belt, the semi-arid areas of sub-Saharan Africa where epidemics of meningococcal meningitis recur each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June. _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A has been the main cause of epidemic meningococcal disease in this region (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf). However, since the introduction of the meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt, beginning in 2010, WHO has noted a decrease in the number of cases of meningitis; in fact, the number of cases in 2013 was the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years (http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/), and _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was noted to be no longer the predominant pathogen, having been replaced by other serogroups, notably serogroup C, and other bacterial species.\n\nAlthough the organism causing the current meningitis outbreak in Jigawa state is not given, it may very well be meningococcus serogroup C, which caused an outbreak in Nigeria in 2017 (see also's below). We await further updates on the outbreak from Nigerian officials.\n\nMaps of Nigeria can be seen at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/617. A map of the African meningitis belt can be found at http://img.static.reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/A592137EAFA85677C1256F2D0047FD68-af_menen.jpg. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "However, since the introduction of the meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt, beginning in 2010, WHO has noted a decrease in the number of cases of meningitis; in fact, the number of cases in 2013 was the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years (http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/), and _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was noted to be no longer the predominant pathogen, having been replaced by other serogroups, notably serogroup C, and other bacterial species. MENINGITIS - NIGERIA: FATAL\n Date: Wed 7 Mar 2018\n _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A has been the main cause of epidemic meningococcal disease in this region (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Majia", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "the Federal Republic of Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Jigawa State", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5701022", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Fiji: fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5701022", "date": "2018-03-21 13:20:37", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - FIJI: FATAL\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 2018 10:22 FJT\nSource: FBC (Fiji Broadcasting Corporation) [edited]\nhttp://www.fbc.com.fj/fiji/61292/health-ministry-declares-meningococcal-disease-outbreak-\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has declared an outbreak of meningococcal disease in Fiji. Over recent years Fiji has had an increase in cases of meningococcal disease. Prior to 2016, there were 1 to 10 cases per year reported. In 2016 there were 29 cases, and in 2017 there were 48 cases. In 2018, there have been 18 cases as of [21 Feb 2018].\n\nEven with the recent increase in cases, meningococcal disease remains uncommon in Fiji; however, this disease has a high death rate. According to WHO, without appropriate medical treatment, up to 5 per cent of people who get the disease will die. Most people who get the disease, and are treated appropriately, will recover fully; however 10-15 per cent will still die, and around 2 per cent will have permanent disabilities, including severe brain damage.\n\nIn 2017, 14.4 per cent of all people who had meningococcal disease in Fiji died. To put this in context, the death rate for dengue fever in Fiji is 0.4-0.6 per cent annually, even during outbreaks. This is why the Ministry of Health and Medical Services is taking nationwide action.\n\nThe meningococcal disease bacteria are not easily transmitted but are spread from person to person via transfer of saliva or spit. This can happen when a person with the bacteria coughs on an uninfected person, or deeply kisses an uninfected person on the mouth. It may also be spread through sharing of drinks from the same glass/cup, water bottle or bowl, such as kava or taki alcohol at a nightclub. Babies and children under the age of 5 frequently put things into their mouths, therefore they are also at risk of getting the bacteria.\n\n[byline: Akosita Talei]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above fails to characterize the patients with invasive meningococcal disease; for example, were they part of the population at increased risk for meningococcal disease because of age; a medical condition (complement component deficiencies), HIV infection, or absent spleen; travel or residence in countries in which the disease is common; or being a college student or military recruit living in a residence hall. We are also not told the meningococcal serogroups involved.\n\nHowever, ProMED-mail reported in 2017 that a total of 8 cases, including 1 fatal case, of meningococcal serogroup C meningitis occurred on the campus of St John's College, a Roman Catholic secondary school located on the Fiji island of Ovalau (see alsos below). In 2015, 590 students were enrolled at the school, the majority coming to Fiji from Papua New Guinea (http://www.sjcawaci.school.fj).\n\nIn Fiji, infant, childhood, adolescent immunization schedules do not include a meningococcal vaccine: http://www.health.gov.fj/PDFs/policy/EPI%20Policy%202013-2016.pdf.\n\nFiji is an island nation of more than 330 islands in Melanesia in the South Pacific Ocean about 2000 km (1300 miles) north east of New Zealand's North Island (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiji). Fiji is divided into 4 major divisions, Central, Eastern, Northern, and Western, and 14 provinces. For a map of Fiji's divisions, see http://www.geographicguide.com/pictures/map-fiji.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Fiji is available at <http://healthmap.org/promed/p/167 - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Akosita Talei]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above fails to characterize the patients with invasive meningococcal disease; for example, were they part of the population at increased risk for meningococcal disease because of age; a medical condition (complement component deficiencies), HIV infection, or absent spleen; travel or residence in countries in which the disease is common; or being a college student or military recruit living in a residence hall. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nEven with the recent increase in cases, meningococcal disease remains uncommon in Fiji; however, this disease has a high death rate. \n\nThe meningococcal disease bacteria are not easily transmitted but are spread from person to person via transfer of saliva or spit. However, ProMED-mail reported in 2017 that a total of 8 cases, including 1 fatal case, of meningococcal serogroup C meningitis occurred on the campus of St John's College, a Roman Catholic secondary school located on the Fiji island of Ovalau (see alsos below). Most people who get the disease, and are treated appropriately, will recover fully; however 10-15 per cent will still die, and around 2 per cent will have permanent disabilities, including severe brain damage. In 2017, 14.4 per cent of all people who had meningococcal disease in Fiji died. [The father], whose son, a 13 year old, was among the 8 that died, said, 'We are being kept in the dark as to what was wrong before the death. I have reached out to the authorities and doctors to know the cause to no avail.'\n\n[The father] said although the dead could not be returned to life, knowing the cause of death could check future occurrences and calm the tensed atmosphere especially with parents whose children were in the affected school. 'It's worrisome that we are still being kept in the dark. I have another child in the school,' he said. Speaking of the late [son], [the father] said, 'My son took ill overnight. He had severe body temperature and was rushed to the hospital the next day. I was with him as he kept holding his stomach. A doctor examined him and prescribed some drugs which were sent for. Before the medicines came, my son died in my presence.'\n\nUp till press time, the executive secretary of the Science Schools Management Board, Lawal Bosa, under whose purview the school is, had failed to respond to enquiries made to him. It could be recalled that an outbreak of a strange disease at the Government Science Secondary School Kurfi killed 8 students, prompting a closure of the school [Is this a separate event? - Mod.SH].\n\n[byline: Habibu Umar Aminu]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 20 Mar 2018\nSource: Independent [edited]\nhttps://independent.ng/strange-disease-surfaces-in-katsina-school-kills-8-students/\n\n\nA strange disease described, as 'mysterious epidemic' on [Mon 19 Mar 2018], struck Government Science Secondary School, Kurfi, in Katsina State and killed about 8 students of the school. The development was said to have forced the State Board for Science and Technical Education to shut down the school indefinitely and send its students home.\n\nA senior government appointee of the board, who preferred to be anonymous confirmed the outbreak in the school, said the board closed the school to avoid the spreading of the epidemic to other students. 'We have closed down the school indefinitely to avoid the spreading of the epidemic to other students. Measures are on top gear to vaccinate students of other schools to stop similar incident,' the source said.\n\nThis is even as the State Assembly slammed the Board for the closure of the school, saying the action of the Board was capable of spreading the epidemic. Kabiru Lawal, a lawmaker representing Kurfi constituency at the Katsina House of Assembly, who confirmed the incident to his colleagues during plenary on [Mon 19 Mar 2018], under Matters of Public Importance, called for urgent attention by government. He said, 'I am urging the House to step in. The epidemic has now forced the school authority to close the school down and send students back home.'\n\nOther lawmakers in the Assembly also claimed that similar epidemic occurred in their constituencies. Garba Useini, representing Kafur Constituency and Bishir Mamman of Dutsin-ma constituency, informed the House that the epidemic has broken down in their respective constituencies, but they could not ascertained the numbers of casualties recorded.\n\nPresiding over the plenary, Abubakar Kusada, the speaker of the assembly, directed the House Committees on Education and that of Health to conduct a thorough investigation on the incident and report back to the House for urgent action.\n\n[byline: Sardauna Francis]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Sun 18 Mar 2018 2:00AM\nSource: Daily Trust [edited]\nhttps://www.dailytrust.com.ng/8-more-persons-die-of-meningitis-in-katsina.html\n\n\nA total of 8 more deaths have been recorded as the meningitis outbreak spreads in Jibia Local Government Area of Katsina State. Up to 2 weeks ago, 7 persons died in the same council just as several others were hospitalised.\n\nSources said the recent deaths were recorded between [Mon 12 Mar 2018] and [Thu 15 Mar 2018] this week. The permanent secretary in the Ministry of Health, Dr Kabir Mustapha, confirmed the deaths, saying 7 persons died at home and that only one death was recorded at the hospital. He said a planned vaccination is on the way for people of the area.\n\n[byline: Habibu Umar Aminu]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Katsina State is located in north west Nigeria (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsina_State). Kurfi, where the 8 students died of an undiagnosed disease, is one of 34 Local Government Areas (LGAs) in Katsina State, with a population of 117 581 in 2006 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurfi). Kafur and Dutsin-Ma are other LGAs in Katsina State, where lawmakers (see news report #2 above) in the State Assembly also say 'the epidemic has broken down in their respective constituencies'. Jibia is another LGA in Katsina State, where 8 died of meningitis, the type not being specified in the news report (see news report #3 above). A map showing the location of LGAs in Katsina State and the location of Katsina State on Nigeria can be found at https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Map-of-Katsina-State-Showing-the-Location-of-Dutsin-Ma_fig1_263809397.\n\nEarlier this month [March 2018], ProMED-mail reported a meningitis outbreak in the adjacent Jigawa State (ProMED-mail post Meningitis - Nigeria: fatal 20180307.5672461).\n\nNorthern Nigeria lies within the African meningitis belt, the semi-arid areas of sub-Saharan Africa where epidemics of meningococcal meningitis recur each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June. _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A has been the main cause of epidemic meningococcal disease in this region (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf). However, since the introduction of the meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt, beginning in 2010, WHO has noted a decrease in the number of cases of meningitis; in fact, the number of cases in 2013 was the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years (http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/), and _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was noted to be no longer the predominant pathogen, having been replaced by other serogroups, notably serogroup C, and other bacterial species.\n\nAlthough the organisms causing the current meningitis outbreaks in Jigawa State or in Jibia LGA in Katsina State are not given, it may very well be meningococcus serogroup C, which caused an outbreak in Nigeria in 2017 (see also's below). ProMed-mail would appreciate more details concerning the meningitis outbreaks in Jigawa State or in Jibia LGA in Katsina State and the undiagnosed outbreaks in Kurfi, Kafur and Dutsin-Ma LGAs in Katsina State from knowledgeable sources.\n\nMaps of Nigeria can be seen at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/617. A map of the African meningitis belt can be found at http://img.static.reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/A592137EAFA85677C1256F2D0047FD68-af_menen.jpg. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n[byline: Habibu Umar Aminu]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n[byline: Sardauna Francis]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n[byline: Habibu Umar Aminu]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nA senior government appointee of the board, who preferred to be anonymous confirmed the outbreak in the school, said the board closed the school to avoid the spreading of the epidemic to other students. ' However, since the introduction of the meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt, beginning in 2010, WHO has noted a decrease in the number of cases of meningitis; in fact, the number of cases in 2013 was the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years (http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/), and _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was noted to be no longer the predominant pathogen, having been replaced by other serogroups, notably serogroup C, and other bacterial species. A strange disease described, as 'mysterious epidemic' on [Mon 19 Mar 2018], struck Government Science Secondary School, Kurfi, in Katsina State and killed about 8 students of the school. MENINGITIS, UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - NIGERIA: (KATSINA) FATAL, SCHOOLCHILDREN, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************************************\n \n\nNorthern Nigeria lies within the African meningitis belt, the semi-arid areas of sub-Saharan Africa where epidemics of meningococcal meningitis recur each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June. It could be recalled that an outbreak of a strange disease at the Government Science Secondary School Kurfi killed 8 students, prompting a closure of the school \n\nThis is even as the State Assembly slammed the Board for the closure of the school, saying the action of the Board was capable of spreading the epidemic. [March 2018], ProMED-mail reported a meningitis outbreak in the adjacent Jigawa State (ProMED-mail post Meningitis - Nigeria: fatal 20180307.5672461). The epidemic has now forced the school authority to close the school down and send students back home.' \n\nSources said the recent deaths were recorded between [Mon 12 Mar 2018] and promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n [The father] said although the dead could not be returned to life, knowing the cause of death could check future occurrences and calm the tensed atmosphere especially with parents whose children were in the affected school. ' https://www.dailytrust.com.ng/kurfi-school-deaths-parent-demands-explanation.html\n\n\nA parent whose child was among those killed by yet to be identified disease that broke out at Government Science Secondary School [SS] in Kurfi has demanded explanation for the cause of his son's death. \n\nUp till press time, the executive secretary of the Science Schools Management Board, Lawal Bosa, under whose purview the school is, had failed to respond to enquiries made to him. [The father], whose son, a 13 year old, was among the 8 that died, said, 'We are being kept in the dark as to what was wrong before the death. The development was said to have forced the State Board for Science and Technical Education to shut down the school indefinitely and send its students home.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jigawa State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Habibu", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Kurfi", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Kafur", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Katsina State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Jibia", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/katsina_state", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5662466", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - South Sudan: (Imatong) fatal, susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5662466", "date": "2018-03-03 16:59:11", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - SOUTH SUDAN: (IMATONG) FATAL, SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 1 Mar 2018\nSource: Radio Tamazuj [edited]\nhttps://radiotamazuj.org/en/news/article/18-people-die-meningitis-suspected-in-imatong-state\n\n\nAt least 18 people became ill and died in 2 counties in South Sudan's Imatong State recently, and government officials believe meningitis is to blame. Imatong governor Tobolio Alberio told Radio Tamazuj on [Wed 28 Feb 2018] that 18 people died after being afflicted by a disease in Ayachi and Torit East Counties in February [2018], which he said the local doctors have been unable to diagnose.\n\nThe top state official further said 7 [fatal] cases were 1st reported in Ayachi County on [Sun 18 Feb 2018], while 11 others were recorded 2 days later in Torit East County. Alberio said the state hasn't confirmed the disease, and that lab tests should soon reveal whether those who died contracted meningitis or not. He added that 18 people died of suspected meningitis but samples have been taken to the laboratory to ascertain the actual cause. 'It's still under investigation,' he said, continuing 'We're not sure yet if the cases are meningitis but the symptoms of the unknown diseases are similar to the symptoms of meningitis.' The governor revealed that several people have been admitted to health facilities due to the unknown disease in the state.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[South Sudan became an independent country on 9 Jul 2011. Imatong State, with an estimated population of almost 600 000 residents, is one of the 28 states of South Sudan and is located on South Sudan's southern border with Uganda; Ayachi and Torit East are 2 of Imatong's 12 counties (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imatong_State).\n\nSouth Sudan is one of the countries in the African 'meningitis belt' that stretches from Senegal in West Africa to the Horn of Africa in the east. This region has been plagued yearly by large epidemics of meningococcal meningitis (http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm). The meningitis outbreaks occur in the dry season (Dec to Apr) and end at the onset of the rainy season (May to Jun). Larger outbreaks occur every 8-12 years (http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx). Attack rates during these cyclic epidemics of meningitis have ranged from 100 to 800 per 100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates as high as 1000 per 100 000 (http://www.bioline.org.br/request?ms03017).\n\nHowever, the epidemiology of meningitis in the African meningitis belt changed after preventive mass vaccination of the population with conjugate meningococcal meningitis serogroup A vaccine (MenA) was introduced in 2010. Prevention consisted of vaccinating all those aged one to 29 years in the African meningitis belt with the MenA conjugate vaccine. As of November 2017, more than 280 million people have been vaccinated in 21 African belt countries (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). Subsequently, serogroup A meningococcus has been replaced by other meningococcal serogroups and other bacterial species. A map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif.\n\nDuring 2016, preventive campaigns with MenA were conducted for the first time in South Sudan, which covered 37 counties in 6 states (Central Equatoria, Eastern Equatoria, Lakes, Northern Bahr el Ghazal, Warrap and Western Bahr el Ghazal) (http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/254901/1/WER9213.pdf?ua=1). A total of about 4 million people were vaccinated, giving overall administrative coverage of 92 per cent. Imatong was apparently not included.\n\nAlthough meningitis is suspected on clinical grounds in the Imatong outbreak, laboratory confirmation of the diagnosis and its microbial etiology are still pending. More information from knowledgeable sources on this outbreak would be appreciated.\n\nA map of Imatong, South Sudan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63845. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "However, the epidemiology of meningitis in the African meningitis belt changed after preventive mass vaccination of the population with conjugate meningococcal meningitis serogroup A vaccine (MenA) was introduced in 2010. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Attack rates during these cyclic epidemics of meningitis have ranged from 100 to 800 per 100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates as high as 1000 per 100 000 (http://www.bioline.org.br/request?ms03017). It's still under investigation,' he said, continuing 'We're not sure yet if the cases are meningitis but the symptoms of the unknown diseases are similar to the symptoms of meningitis.' \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n\nAt least 18 people became ill and died in 2 counties in South Sudan's Imatong State recently, and government officials believe meningitis is to blame. Imatong governor Tobolio Alberio told Radio Tamazuj on [Wed 28 Feb 2018] that 18 people died after being afflicted by a disease in Ayachi and Torit East Counties in February [2018], which he said the local doctors have been unable to diagnose. \n\nThe top state official further said 7 [fatal] cases were 1st reported in Ayachi County on [Sun 18 Feb 2018], while 11 others were recorded 2 days later in Torit East County. He added that 18 people died of suspected meningitis but samples have been taken to the laboratory to ascertain the actual cause. ' \n\nAlthough meningitis is suspected on clinical grounds in the Imatong outbreak, laboratory confirmation of the diagnosis and its microbial etiology are still pending. Alberio said the state hasn't confirmed the disease, and that lab tests should soon reveal whether those who died contracted meningitis or not.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-11-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-02-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Ayachi County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "South Sudan 's", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Ghazal", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Imatong State", "country": "South Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5568890", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) middle school student", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5568890", "date": "2018-01-18 18:25:11", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA: (OREGON) MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENT\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 17 Jan 2018\nFrom: Hannah Carey <careyhan@oregonstate.edu> [edited]\n\n\nI am reporting an additional case of meningococcal disease in Corvallis, OR, this time in a middle school student. The strain identity has not yet been released to the public. In a Gazette Times article from earlier today, [Wed 17 Jan 2018], it states, 'A student at Linus Pauling Middle School in Corvallis has been hospitalized with meningococcal disease, public health officials announced on [Wed 17 Jan 2018]. The student was admitted to the hospital on [Sun 14 Jan 2018], health officials said, and testing is being done to determine which strain of the potentially deadly disease is involved.'\n\nPlease see the link to the article from the Gazette Times below.\n\n--\nHannah Carey, MPH\n<hannah.carey@valleyaidsinfo.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 17 Jan 2018\nSource: Gazette Times [edited]\nhttp://www.gazettetimes.com/news/local/article_7d4304ea-4012-59a3-86b7-fd3d9f328a62.html\n\n\nA student at Linus Pauling Middle School in Corvallis [Oregon] has been hospitalized with meningococcal disease, public health officials announced on [Wed 17 Jan 2018]. The student was admitted to the hospital on [Sun 14 Jan 2018], health officials said, and testing is being done to determine which strain of the potentially deadly disease is involved.\n\nUp to 6 undergraduates at Oregon State University [OSU] have been infected with meningococcus [serogroup] B since the fall of 2016, but so far there is no indication of a connection between the Linus Pauling case and the OSU outbreak, according to Charlie Fautin, deputy director of the Benton County Health Department. However, he added, 'If the laboratory work indicates serotype [serogroup] B, we'll go back and revisit everything.'\n\nHealth Department and school officials have declined to release the name of the infected middle schooler, citing federal privacy laws. They also have declined to give the student's age, grade or gender. However, a spokeswoman for the Corvallis School District said [Wed 17 Jan 2018] that the child is doing better. 'As of this morning, the student is recovering,' Brenda Downum told the Gazette-Times.\n\nFautin said parents should make sure their children have all age-appropriate vaccinations, including the quadrivalent meningococcal vaccine that is recommended for young people between the ages of 11 and 21. Parents should seek immediate medical attention if their child shows signs of meningococcal disease, which can be fatal or cause life-altering complications including brain damage, loss of hearing or vision, and amputation of limbs.\n\nIn the case of the Linus Pauling student, Fautin said, 'that was an alert parent who saw a stiff neck and rash and got this kiddo into emergency care promptly.'\n\nWhile the disease can strike people of any age, it mainly afflicts young people between the ages of 18 and 24 and is relatively rare in children of middle school age. It is not highly contagious but can be spread through prolonged, face-to-face exposure to an infected person.\n\nThe disease spreads via body fluids and can be passed from one person to another by sharing eating and drinking utensils or smoking paraphernalia or through kissing, coughing or sneezing. People who may have been exposed can be treated with antibiotics as a precaution. County health workers are in the process of contacting people who may have been exposed to the infected student, Fautin said. The Corvallis School District sent an email to Linus Pauling parents about the situation on [Wed 17 Jan 2018] morning, Downum said, and is mailing letters to families who don't have email.\n\n'We are sharing information with all the families at the school to make sure they know the signs' of meningococcal disease, she said. 'We're just allowing the Health Department to do their work and reminding families to watch for signs.'\n\n[Byline: Bennett Hall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHannah Carey, MPH\n<hannah.carey@valleyaidsinfo.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Hannah Carey for submission of the above news report.\n\n- In November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319).\n- In March 2017, we posted a report of a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus was reported with IMD due to serogroup B meningitis (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298).\n- In October 2017, we posted a report of a 4th OSU student on the Corvallis campus with IMD that was subsequently confirmed to be also serogroup B (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497).\n- In November 2017, we posted a report of a 5th OSU student with IMD due to serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532); and - In Dec 2017, we posted a report of a 6th OSU student with IMD, that is now said in the news report above to be serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (07): (OR) college, sg B 20171222.5520017).\n\nMany of these cases occurred despite campus-wide vaccination programs with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y. The news reports have not given the vaccination status of the OSU students with IMD.\n\nHumans are the only reservoir for the organisms that cause IMD. Colonization of the nasopharynx of asymptomatic carriers or persons with IMD provides the source from which an outbreak clone is spread among people. The news report above says that a middle school student without known contacts with OSU has developed IMD, which if due to the OSU outbreak strain, suggests that nasopharyngeal carriage of the outbreak clone has spread from the OSU campus into the general population.\n\nOSU is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). OSU has a total student enrollment of 30 354. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nOregon State University, Oregon: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733\nOregon county map: http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "In November 2017, we posted a report of a 5th OSU student with IMD due to serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532); and - In Dec 2017, we posted a report of a 6th OSU student with IMD, that is now said in the news report above to be serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (07): (OR) college, sg B 20171222.5520017). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n In November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319).
