The news report above says that a middle school student without known contacts with OSU has developed IMD, which if due to the OSU outbreak strain, suggests that nasopharyngeal carriage of the outbreak clone has spread from the OSU campus into the general population.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2018-01-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-12-26 00:00:00", "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-11-26 00:00:00", "2016-11-26 00:00:00", "2017-10-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oregon", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5620563", "headline": "PRO>  Meningitis - Spain (02): (MD) foodborne, raw cheese, recall, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5620563", "date": "2018-02-10 18:12:13", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - SPAIN (02): (MADRID) FOODBORNE, RAW CHEESE, COMMENT\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 10 Feb 2018\nFrom: Steve Berger <steve@gideononline.com> [edited]\n\nRe: ProMED-mail post Meningitis - Spain: (MD) foodborne, raw cheese, recall, alert, RFI Archive Number: 20180209.5618781\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nRates of listeriosis in Spain have been increasing since 2000, and are currently more than 15-fold those reported in the United States. [1] Regarding the recent case posted on ProMED, Listeria is identified in 12.1 percent to 16.5 percent of community-acquired bacterial meningitis cases among Spanish adults. [2] The following chart was produced using a multi-graph tool in Gideon. [3] (See graphs at https://www.gideononline.com/2018/02/10/listeriosis-in-spain/.)\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger S. Listeriosis: Global Status, 2018. 122 pages, 107 graphs, 1,039 references. Gideon ebooks, https://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/listeriosis-global-status/.\n2. Berger S. Infectious Diseases of Spain, 2018. 535 pages, 195 graphs, 2,871 references. Gideon ebooks, https://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-spain/.\n3. Gideon multigraph tool, https://www.gideononline.com/cases/multi-graphs/.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr. Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nTel Aviv, Israel\n<steve@gideononline.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Steve Berger for providing this contribution.\n\nA map of (Madrid, Autonomous Region of Madrid, Spain): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2506. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Gideon multigraph tool, https://www.gideononline.com/cases/multi-graphs/.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr. Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\n MENINGITIS - SPAIN (02): (MADRID) FOODBORNE, RAW CHEESE, COMMENT\n*****************************************************************\n Tel Aviv, Israel\n<steve@gideononline.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Steve Berger for providing this contribution. [3] (See graphs at https://www.gideononline.com/2018/02/10/listeriosis-in-spain/.)\n\nReferences:\n --------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nRates of listeriosis in Spain have been increasing since 2000, and are currently more than 15-fold those reported in the United States.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madrid", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gideon", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "ProMED", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tel Aviv", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5621382", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Meningitis - Spain (03): listeriosis, raw soft ewe cheese, Portugal, recall, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5621382", "date": "2018-02-11 12:22:57", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - SPAIN (03): LISTERIOSIS, RAW SOFT EWE CHEESE, PORTUGAL, RECALL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n****************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate Thu 8 Feb 2018\nSource: Spanish Agency for Consumer Affairs, Food Safety and Nutrition (AECONSAN) [in Spanish, trans., edited]\nhttp://www.aecosan.msssi.gob.es/AECOSAN/web/seguridad_alimentaria/ampliacion/quesos.htm\n\n\nOn [5 Feb 2018] the Spanish Agency for Consumer Affairs, Food Safety and Nutrition, through the Coordinated System of Rapid Information Exchange (SCIRI), learned of the existence of [a 39-year-old man; see 20180209.5618781] in the Community of Madrid affected by meningitis as a result of food intoxication by _Listeria monocytogenes_, presumably associated with the consumption of soft milk sheep cheese made by the company Ohian Txiki Koop located in the Basque Country. The affected [person is recovering] favorably.\n\nThe allegedly involved cheeses are the following: Gutizia, a raw sheep milk cheese; Txuria, a soft cheese from raw sheep milk; and Beltza, a lactic cheese-curl of raw sheep's milk.\n\nThe manufacturer has distributed these products to the autonomous communities of Madrid, Catalonia, and the Basque Country. As of [7 Feb 2018] there is evidence that there has been a small redistribution of a few units from Madrid to Andalusia, Castile-La Mancha, Castile and Leon, Extremadura, Galicia, Valencia, and Portugal.\n\nThe removal of all batches of raw soft-ewe sheep milk cheese is being carried out.\n\nThis information has been communicated through the national alert network to the competent authorities in the autonomous communities who are carrying out the appropriate actions, as well as to the competent Portuguese authorities through the European Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed.\n\nAs a precautionary measure, people who have any of these products at home are advised to refrain from consuming them. If they have consumed them and present any unusual symptoms, it is recommended that they go to a health center.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Irene Lai\nInternational SOS\n<irene.lai@internationalsos.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 10 Feb 2018\nFrom: Allen Lenoir <alenoir165@aol.com> [edited]\n\n\nHas the cause of the meningitis in the 39-year-old in Spain been determined, and is more known about the patient? _Listeria_ would seem to be less likely in a patient this age unless they were immunocompromised. A more likely cause of meningitis related to the consumption of unpasteurized cheese in an immunocompetent 39 year old would be _Brucella_.\n\n--\nAllen Lenoir, MD\nMiami, Florida\n<alenoir165@aol.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Irene Lai and Allen Lenoir for providing their contributions.\n\nDr Lenoir is correct. As I stated in my moderator comments (see 20180209.5618781), listeriosis affects mainly pregnant women, newborns, the elderly, and adults with impaired immune systems. Invasive disease, like meningitis, due to _Listeria monocytogenes_ would be uncommon in an immune competent 39-year-old man, but certainly invasive disease in apparently immunocompetent non-elderly adults has been reported (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6428282, https://ojs.library.dal.ca/DMJ/article/download/3793/3465, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5771898/, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22760149, https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/0b1e/3e311e79f55e4e80c82eee5a4c9512cea0a1.pdf).\n\nMore information on the 39-year old man in Madrid who developed _Listeria_ meningitis would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nA map of Spain can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43 and of Portugal at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n--\nAllen Lenoir, MD\nMiami, Florida\n<alenoir165@aol.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Irene Lai and Allen Lenoir for providing their contributions. Dr Irene Lai\nInternational SOS\n<irene.lai@internationalsos.com>\n\n******\n The allegedly involved cheeses are the following: Gutizia, a raw sheep milk cheese; Txuria, a soft cheese from raw sheep milk; and Beltza, a lactic cheese-curl of raw sheep's milk. On [5 Feb 2018] the Spanish Agency for Consumer Affairs, Food Safety and Nutrition, through the Coordinated System of Rapid Information Exchange (SCIRI), learned of the existence of [a 39-year-old man; see 20180209.5618781] in the Community of Madrid affected by meningitis as a result of food intoxication by _Listeria monocytogenes_, presumably associated with the consumption of soft milk sheep cheese made by the company Ohian Txiki Koop located in the Basque Country. Invasive disease, like meningitis, due to _Listeria monocytogenes_ would be uncommon in an immune competent 39-year-old man, but certainly invasive disease in apparently immunocompetent non-elderly adults has been reported (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6428282, https://ojs.library.dal.ca/DMJ/article/download/3793/3465, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5771898/, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22760149, https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/0b1e/3e311e79f55e4e80c82eee5a4c9512cea0a1.pdf). MENINGITIS - SPAIN (03): LISTERIOSIS, RAW SOFT EWE CHEESE, PORTUGAL, RECALL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n \n\nMore information on the 39-year old man in Madrid who developed _Listeria_ meningitis would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources. \n\nThis information has been communicated through the national alert network to the competent authorities in the autonomous communities who are carrying out the appropriate actions, as well as to the competent Portuguese authorities through the European Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed. A more likely cause of meningitis related to the consumption of unpasteurized cheese in an immunocompetent 39 year old would be _Brucella_. \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2018-02-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22760149", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Galicia", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Txuria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "Leon", "country": "Nicaragua"}, {"location": "Andalusia", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Miami", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5598770", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Cryptococcus neoformans - USA: (CA) meningitis, immunocompet., marijuana smoker", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5598770", "date": "2018-02-01 09:56:01", "main_text": "CRYPTOCOCCUS NEOFORMANS - USA: (CALIFORNIA) MENINGITIS, IMMUNOCOMPETENT, MARIJUANA SMOKER\n*****************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 30 Jan 2018\nSource: Mail Online [edited]\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-5327367/California-woman-caught-meningitis-CANNABIS.html\n\n\nA 48-year-old woman in California contracted a potentially deadly meningitis infection in 2016 from smoking her favorite medical marijuana strain 3 to 6 times a day, according to a British Medical Journal case study report published last month [December 2017; [1]. The infection came from a fungus, called _Cryptococcus_, that most people contract from inhaling contaminated dust or eating food that mouse feces have touched [sic, see below].\n\nMeningitis is the most common illness to develop from exposure to _Cryptococcus_, and causes potentially fatal inflammation in the brain and spinal cord.\n\nDr Bryan Shapiro, who treated the woman, says that cannabis smokers in California should be sure to know where their marijuana came from, especially if their immune systems are compromised in any way, as meningitis could be lethal for them.\n\nThe unnamed woman's sister brought her to the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center (CSMC) in Los Angeles, California. She had 'strange symptoms,' Dr Shapiro said, including being dizzy, tired, struggling to recall even her own name, and behaving aggressively. In fact, her behavior had become so erratic that she was fired from her job as an administrative assistant before being admitted to the hospital.\n\nAt CSMC, the emergency room team could not figure out what was ailing the otherwise healthy patient. When she assaulted a nurse, the team called in the psychiatric department. 'We thought it might be catatonia [abnormal movement triggered by mental issues], and it took us some time to rule out a psychiatric illness,' Dr Shapiro said.\n\nStill unable to diagnose her, they took a sample of her brain fluid [cerebrospinal fluid or CSF], which tested positive for _Cryptococcus neoformans_, 'a rare fungal infection usually only seen in people with late stage HIV or transplant patients,' Dr Shapiro explained.\n\nBut the woman was otherwise in reasonably good health. The only things that stood out in her medical history were high blood pressure and a significant marijuana habit. 'She said she had smoked between 3 and 6 marijuana blunts about daily since her teenage years,' Shapiro said, 'I've never known a patient who smokes that heavily and wondered if there could be a link between her heavy cannabis use for a lifetime.'\n\nThey treated the woman for meningitis, but if they hadn't done so 'prudently...there is a strong possibility she would have died, she was very, very severe at the time we saw her,' he says.\n\nAs she was recovering, Dr Shapiro and his team investigated her favorite medical marijuana dispensary in Bakersfield where she always purchased one of the shop's cheaper strains, which was grown locally outdoors. DNA sequencing of 9 samples revealed small amounts of the rare fungus. 'That lent credibility to the idea that the _Cryptococcus_ in the cannabis may have caused the woman's systemic malfunction, and smoking might actually predispose someone to invasive fungal infection,' Dr Shapiro said.\n\nFungus spores are actually grown on cannabis quite commonly. A study conducted last year [2017] identified evidence of mold, pesticides, and other contaminants on much of the weed grown in the state [2]. More than 90 percent of the marijuana plants tested were contaminated with pesticides, and crops from 20 farms were positive for mold.\n\nThe soil in Bakersfield and the surrounding Central Valley area is known to be a breeding ground for another fungus called _Coccidioides immitis_, which is to blame for a slew of cases of an infection, dubbed 'valley fever' [aka, coccidioidomycosis].\n\nValley fever is a potentially severe lung infection and its symptoms can mirror those of the flu that has killed nearly 100 people in California since the start of the year [2017 ?]. The prevalence of the valley fever fungus -- which causes infection when it is inhaled -- in the area 'raised suspicions' for Dr Shapiro and his team that the soil could harbor _Cryptococcus_ as well. The spores of these fungi are very heat resistant, so they survive even as the weed they are attached to is smoked.\n\nEven so, it is rare for someone with an otherwise healthy immune system to get such an infection, and Dr Shapiro points to other research that has suggested that THC [tetrahydrocannabinol] -- the psychoactive component of weed -- may itself suppress the immune system. 'So, the more you smoke, the greater the exposure [to the fungus and] the more likely it is that your body is unable to fight off the infection,' he says.\n\nDr Shapiro was unable to disclose the name of the particular dispensary that the contaminated marijuana came from, but said that it is under investigation.\n\nThis case was the 1st of its kind that Dr Shapiro or his team had seen, so it's too early to make formal recommendations, he says, but advises: 'Make sure you know where your marijuana is coming from. 'I recommend buying indoor-grown strains and, for people who are immuno-compromised like those with HIV or other infections, I would recommend avoiding inhaled marijuana products,' he says. Edible products, on the other hand are probably safer for consumption.\n\n[Byline: Natalie Rahhal]\n\n[References\n-----------\n1. Shapiro BB, Hedrick R, Vanle BC, et al. Cryptococcal meningitis in a daily cannabis smoker without evidence of immunodeficiency. BMJ Case Rep 2018; pii: bcr-2017-221435. doi: 10.1136/bcr-2017-221435; available at: http://casereports.bmj.com/content/2018/bcr-2017-221435.short.\n2. Thompson GR 3rd, Tuscano JM, Dennis M, et al. A microbiome assessment of medical marijuana. Clin Microbiol Infect. 2017; 23(4): 269-70. doi: 10.1016/j.cmi.2016.12.001; available at: https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/shl.website.assets/pdf/uploads/whitepapers/e5bbb9cf596ac31a585081b24e047c00.pdf. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cryptococcosis is a fungal disease caused by the encapsulated yeast _Cryptococcus neoformans_ or _C. gattii_. These 2 species have 5 serotypes based on antigenic specificity of the capsular polysaccharide; these include serotypes A, D, and AD (_C. neoformans_) and serotypes B and C (_C. gattii_). The ecologic niches for _C. neoformans_ and _C. gattii_ appear to be distinct. _C. gattii_ lives in the soil and areas on or around trees, such as the eucalyptus. _C. gattii_ is not associated with birds, whereas _C. neoformans_ is found in the accumulated droppings around roosting and nesting sites of birds, especially pigeons. Pigeons are not known to acquire symptomatic disease but can carry cryptococci on feathers, skin, in the crop and cloaca [common cavity into which the intestinal, genital, and urinary tracts open]. _Cryptococcus neoformans_ was the cryptococcal species isolated from the patient's cerebrospinal fluid in the above news report.\n\nCryptococci can become aerosolized when dried bird droppings or contaminated soil are stirred up. People can become infected when they inhale aerosolized cryptococci, which primarily infect the lung, but may subsequently spread systemically via the bloodstream, especially to the central nervous system where the organisms cause a basilar meningoencephalitis. Mice and their feces are not involved with this disease.\n\nA University of California (UC) Davis group had previously reported that one of their immunocompromised patients developed a fungal infection after using aerosolized marijuana (https://www.eastcountymagazine.org/tainted-marijuana-kills-california-man-contaminated-plants-found-statewide). The patient had been told by the dispensary that the marijuana product, which consisted of raw, blended marijuana that was inhaled as a mist, was a safer alternative to smoking (https://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/publish/news/newsroom/11791). This prompted the UC Davis group testing 20 medical marijuana samples statewide. The following is extracted from this report, which is the 2nd article referenced in the news report above [full article including references and appendices available at the URL cited]:\n\n'20 cannabis samples from different dispensaries in northern California were collected by Steep Hill Labs, cataloged, and DNA was extracted using the PowerSoil DNA Isolation Kit (Mo Bio). The fungal communities (assessed by ITS gene sequence analysis) and the bacterial communities (from 16S sRNA gene) were analyzed using published methods. More specific whole metagenome (WMGS) analyses were used to better understand the presence of distinct species within the microbiome. ITS analysis resulted in about 4000 total fungal taxonomic classifications. Of the 20 fungal genera observed at more than 0.1 percent frequency, many are genera that contain opportunistic pathogens (such as, _Cryptococcus_ [species not specified], _Mucor_, _Aspergillus_) (Appendix 1).'\n\nThe abstract of the 1st article referenced in the news report above is extracted below:\n\n'Cryptococcal meningitis is a life-threatening condition most commonly observed in immunocompromised individuals. We describe a daily cannabis smoker without evidence of immunodeficiency presenting with confirmed _Cryptococcus neoformans_ meningitis. An investigation of cannabis samples from the patient's preferred dispensary demonstrated contamination with several varieties of _Cryptococcus_, including _C. neoformans_, and other opportunistic fungi. These findings raise concern regarding the safety of dispensary-grade cannabis, even in immunocompetent users.'\n\nMolecular typing was apparently not done to see if the clinical isolate of _C. neoformans_ and the _C. neoformans_ identified in the marijuana obtained from the patient's dispensary matched. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nBakersfield, California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12227]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nStill unable to diagnose her, they took a sample of her brain fluid [cerebrospinal fluid or CSF], which tested positive for _Cryptococcus neoformans_, 'a rare fungal infection usually only seen in people with late stage HIV or transplant patients,' Dr Shapiro explained. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cryptococcosis is a fungal disease caused by the encapsulated yeast _Cryptococcus neoformans_ or _C. gattii_. \n\nDr Bryan Shapiro, who treated the woman, says that cannabis smokers in California should be sure to know where their marijuana came from, especially if their immune systems are compromised in any way, as meningitis could be lethal for them. She said she had smoked between 3 and 6 marijuana blunts about daily since her teenage years,' Shapiro said, 'I've never known a patient who smokes that heavily and wondered if there could be a link between her heavy cannabis use for a lifetime.' The abstract of the 1st article referenced in the news report above is extracted below:\n\n'Cryptococcal meningitis is a life-threatening condition most commonly observed in immunocompromised individuals. The patient had been told by the dispensary that the marijuana product, which consisted of raw, blended marijuana that was inhaled as a mist, was a safer alternative to smoking (https://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/publish/news/newsroom/11791). That lent credibility to the idea that the _Cryptococcus_ in the cannabis may have caused the woman's systemic malfunction, and smoking might actually predispose someone to invasive fungal infection,' Dr Shapiro said. \n\nMeningitis is the most common illness to develop from exposure to _Cryptococcus_, and causes potentially fatal inflammation in the brain and spinal cord. \n\nFungus spores are actually grown on cannabis quite commonly. CRYPTOCOCCUS NEOFORMANS - USA: (CALIFORNIA) MENINGITIS, IMMUNOCOMPETENT, MARIJUANA SMOKER\n**************************************************************************************** An investigation of cannabis samples from the patient's preferred dispensary demonstrated contamination with several varieties of _Cryptococcus_, including _C. neoformans_, and other opportunistic fungi. Even so, it is rare for someone with an otherwise healthy immune system to get such an infection, and Dr Shapiro points to other research that has suggested that THC [tetrahydrocannabinol] -- the psychoactive component of weed -- may itself suppress the immune system. ' I recommend buying indoor-grown strains and, for people who are immuno-compromised like those with HIV or other infections, I would recommend avoiding inhaled marijuana products,' he says. ML]\n\n--\n ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\n The soil in Bakersfield and the surrounding Central Valley area is known to be a breeding ground for another fungus called _Coccidioides immitis_, which is to blame for a slew of cases of an infection, dubbed 'valley fever' [aka, coccidioidomycosis].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "cryptococcosis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:16", "2017-12-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-01-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UC", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Bakersfield", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cryptococcus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CRYPTOCOCCUS", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5520017", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (07): (OR) college, sg B", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5520017", "date": "2017-12-22 14:13:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (07): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017 06:01 PM PST\nSource: Bend Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://www.bendbulletin.com/exports/newsletters/main/5858299-151/osu-requires-vaccine-amid-meningococcal-outbreak\n\n\nA 6th case in a meningococcal disease outbreak on the Corvallis campus of Oregon State University [OSU] prompted school officials to require all students under age 25 be vaccinated for meningococcal B disease by [15 Feb 2018]. School officials did not detail how they would enforce the vaccination requirement but indicated they would have rules that could not be easily circumvented. 'If you are not vaccinated against this disease and you are a student on that campus, you are at risk for meningococcal infection,' said Dr Paul Cieslak, medical director for communicable diseases and immunizations at the Oregon Health Authority Public Health Division. 'We do feel that now, because there is a break between classes, that this is the best time for students to get vaccinated.'\n\nMeningococcal disease is not a highly contagious disease, but it has a 100 percent fatality rate without antibiotic treatment. Even with antibiotics, some 15 percent of those infected will die. Another 15 to 20 percent will incur long-term consequences such as brain damage or the loss of fingers or limbs. 'This disease can progress from sort of feeling like you have the flu and feeling crummy to being catastrophic very quickly,' said Charlie Fautin, deputy director of the Benton County Health Department. 'We've been very fortunate in this outbreak. The 5 previous students all made full recoveries.'\n\nThe outbreak began in November 2016 when 2 students were hospitalized with meningococcal B disease in less than a week. A 3rd student was diagnosed in March [2017], prompting a formal declaration of an outbreak.\n\nSchool officials organized 2 mass vaccination clinics in the spring and 3 more this fall [2017]. Vaccination efforts mainly targeted students with frequent close contact, including those living in residences and group housing, and on athletic teams. The school already had a requirement to get a meningococcal vaccine that protects against the A, C, Y, and W strains of the disease. But that vaccine offers no protection against the B strain that is currently circulating on the Corvallis campus. The school revised its vaccination guidelines for the current school year, requiring all incoming freshmen and transfer students to be vaccinated specifically for meningococcal B disease by the 1st week of November [2017] in order to register for winter term classes.\n\nBut a 4th student was diagnosed in October and a 5th in November [2017] while home for Thanksgiving [23 Nov 2017] outside of Corvallis. The 6th case was a 21-year-old student hospitalized [17 Dec 2017] while visiting family. Testing to confirm the strain has not been completed.\n\n'We realize now, with this case which involves an older student not living in congregate housing, like residence halls or group living, that we need to up our requirements,' said Steve Clark, OSU vice president for university relations and marketing, who has spearheaded the school's response to the outbreak.\n\nThe standard approach with a single case of meningococcal disease is to provide antibiotics to those in close contact with the infected person. But as the outbreak spread across the campus, with no obvious link between the 6 cases, officials had to broaden the scope of their interventions. 'The problem is the cat's out of the bag. It's spread completely through the campus,' Cieslak said. 'It's not like it's in one dorm, one fraternity or one athletic team. Therefore the only way to protect people is to get them all immune.'\n\nMeningococcal disease can include meningitis, an infection of the fluids that line the brain and spinal cord. Meningitis symptoms can include fever, headache, stiff neck, nausea and confusion. The bacteria can also cause a blood infection, known as meningococcemia, with symptoms such as fever, shaking chills, rash, fatigue, severe aches and pains and rapid breathing. The disease is spread when a healthy person comes in close contact with an infected person's nose or throat fluids, such as droplets from a sneeze, spit or saliva. It occurs most often among large groups of people living in close quarters, such as in university residences, group housing or fraternities or sororities. The bacteria are being spread from student to student on campus with most infections not causing recognizable symptoms. 'We don't know who they are, and we don't know who it's going to strike next,' Cieslak said.\n\nPublic health officials urged families and friends to be on the lookout for symptoms of meningococcal disease, and recommend that doctors have a low threshold for suspecting the condition, particularly in OSU students.\n\nIn 2015, the University of Oregon had a meningococcal B outbreak affecting 6 students, one of whom died. The university held 4 mass vaccination clinics with the goal of immunizing all undergraduate students, but according to public health officials, only an estimated 6 percent of students were fully vaccinated.\n\n'The best prevention is vaccination,' Fautin said. 'This is the proven way to disrupt these kinds of outbreaks and our uptake unfortunately has not been as great as we would like.' 2 brands of meningococcal vaccine are licensed for use in the United States from age 10 to 25. Bexsoro requires 2 doses given at least one month apart for full coverage. Trumemba requires 3 doses, with follow-up doses one month and 6 months after the 1st. Cieslak said a single dose of either vaccine is likely to provide only 40 to 60 percent effectiveness, compared to 80 to 90 percent effectiveness for the full series. The vaccines are not interchangeable so follow-up doses should be of the same brand.\n\nDoctors and county health officials in Central Oregon have been on alert for cases, particularly those involving college students. Deschutes County Health Services offers the vaccine and is compiling a list of pharmacies that offer it, including Rite Aid, Walgreens, Fred Meyer, and Safeway on Century Drive. St Charles Health System offers the vaccines in its family care and school-based clinics. The vaccine costs about USD 300 but is covered by insurance plans. Some university students, however, had trouble getting insurance coverage for the vaccine on campus because the providers were out-of-network. The Oregon Legislature passed House Bill 3276 to address that issue during outbreaks, and the governor signs the bill into law in August [2017].\n\nThe holiday break, however, often brings students back to their familiar doctors and pharmacists, or back home where parents can ensure their children get vaccinated. Cieslak stressed the importance of prevention as well as timely treatment if symptoms arise. 'It's a nasty virulent bacterium that can affect even perfectly healthy people,' he said. 'And if you have it in your spinal fluid and you don't get antibiotics promptly, you are going to die.'\n\n[Byline: Markian Hawryluk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319) and in March 2017, meningococcal serogroup B meningitis was reported in a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298).\n\nIn October 2017, we posted a report of a 4th OSU student on the Corvallis campus with IMD; although we were not told at that time what the serogroup of the pathogen was, it apparently was also serogroup B (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497) and in Nov 2017 we were told of a 5th OSU student has developed IMD due to serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532). Now there is a 6th OSU student with IMD, but confirmation of the serogroup is still pending.\n\nThese cases occurred despite campus-wide vaccination programs with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y. The news report above does not give the vaccination status of the latest OSU student with IMD.\n\nOSU is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). OSU has a total student enrollment of 30 354. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nOregon State University, Oregon: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733\nOregon county map: http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319) and in March 2017, meningococcal serogroup B meningitis was reported in a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298). \n\nIn October 2017, we posted a report of a 4th OSU student on the Corvallis campus with IMD; although we were not told at that time what the serogroup of the pathogen was, it apparently was also serogroup B (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497) and in Nov 2017 we were told of a 5th OSU student has developed IMD due to serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532). \n\nThese cases occurred despite campus-wide vaccination programs with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y. The news report above does not give the vaccination status of the latest OSU student with IMD. \n\n\nA 6th case in a meningococcal disease outbreak on the Corvallis campus of Oregon State University [OSU] prompted school officials to require all students under age 25 be vaccinated for meningococcal B disease by [15 Feb 2018]. The school revised its vaccination guidelines for the current school year, requiring all incoming freshmen and transfer students to be vaccinated specifically for meningococcal B disease by the 1st week of November [2017] in order to register for winter term classes. \n\nPublic health officials urged families and friends to be on the lookout for symptoms of meningococcal disease, and recommend that doctors have a low threshold for suspecting the condition, particularly in OSU students. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n If you are not vaccinated against this disease and you are a student on that campus, you are at risk for meningococcal infection,' said Dr Paul Cieslak, medical director for communicable diseases and immunizations at the Oregon Health Authority Public Health Division. \n\nThe outbreak began in November 2016 when 2 students were hospitalized with meningococcal B disease in less than a week. The university held 4 mass vaccination clinics with the goal of immunizing all undergraduate students, but according to public health officials, only an estimated 6 percent of students were fully vaccinated. \n\nMeningococcal disease is not a highly contagious disease, but it has a 100 percent fatality rate without antibiotic treatment. We realize now, with this case which involves an older student not living in congregate housing, like residence halls or group living, that we need to up our requirements,' said Steve Clark, OSU vice president for university relations and marketing, who has spearheaded the school's response to the outbreak. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nOregon State University, Oregon: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733\nOregon county map: http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif] \n\nMeningococcal disease can include meningitis, an infection of the fluids that line the brain and spinal cord. \n\nBut a 4th student was diagnosed in October and a 5th in November [2017] while home for Thanksgiving [23 Nov 2017] outside of Corvallis. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (07): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n*******************************************************************\n \n\nDoctors and county health officials in Central Oregon have been on alert for cases, particularly those involving college students. The standard approach with a single case of meningococcal disease is to provide antibiotics to those in close contact with the infected person. This is the proven way to disrupt these kinds of outbreaks and our uptake unfortunately has not been as great as we would like.' 2 brands of meningococcal vaccine are licensed for use in the United States from age 10 to 25. \n\nThe holiday break, however, often brings students back to their familiar doctors and pharmacists, or back home where parents can ensure their children get vaccinated. \n\n[Byline: Markian Hawryluk]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-11-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-10-26 00:00:00", "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-08-26 00:00:00", "2016-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2017-10-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oregon", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5618781", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Meningitis - Spain: (MD) foodborne, raw cheese, recall, alert, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5618781", "date": "2018-02-09 20:36:40", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - SPAIN: (MADRID) FOODBORNE, RAW CHEESE, RECALL, ALERT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 7 Feb 2018 20:18\nSource: Euro Weekly News [edited]\nhttps://www.euroweeklynews.com/3.0.15/news/on-euro-weekly-news/spain-news-in-english/1471517-cheese-withdrawn-from-sale-in-spain-following-meningitis-case\n\n\nA total of 3 different cheeses manufactured in Spain have been withdrawn from store shelves after a reported case of meningitis in Madrid. The warning follows a case of a 39-year-old man being diagnosed with the disease after consuming raw sheep's cheese.\n\nThe Beltza, Txuria and Gutizia raw sheep's milk cheeses are made by the Oihan Txiki Koop group in San Sebastian. The General Directorate of Public Health has recommended that if you have bought any of the products to get rid of them. In addition, if you have eaten any of the named cheeses recently, you should visit a health centre if you present any of the symptoms of the disease.\n\nIt is believed the affected products were mainly distributed in the capital, Cataluna and the Basque Country.\n\nMeningitis is an inflammation of the membranes that cover the whole central nervous system. Its symptoms are characterized by high fever, drowsiness, headache, loss of consciousness, stiffness in the neck, agitation, delirium, convulsions, red spots on the skin and vomiting.\n\n[Byline: Karl Smallman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above news report fails to specify the microbial cause of meningitis in a 39-year-old man that developed after consuming cheese made from raw sheep's milk, but the most likely pathogen is _Listeria moncytogenes_. More information on this infection would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely distributed in nature. The organism can be found in soil, water, silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw milk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans. Most human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission can occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery through an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can occur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals.\n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, e.g., raw vegetables contaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk by infected cows, or contamination can occur following cooking or other processing.\n\nBecause _Listeria_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures listeriosis is commonly associated with ingestion of contaminated food that have been held at refrigeration temperatures and then eaten without further cooking, e.g. ready-to-eat deli meats and cole slaw. The sources of human infection can be pinpointed by DNA identification techniques matching _Listeria_ isolated from a possible source with isolates recovered from a patient.\n\nListeriosis affects mainly pregnant women, newborns, the elderly, and adults with impaired immune systems. Infection can cause diarrhea and in some patients invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Invasive listeriosis is rare (about 2500 cases occur annually in the US), but the disease has an overall case fatality rate of 20 to 30 percent.\n\nMadrid is the capital city of Spain and, with a population of about 3.1 million and a metropolitan population of about 6.5 million, is the largest municipality in both the Community of Madrid and Spain as a whole (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid). Catalonia is an autonomous community located on the northeastern corner of Spain and consists of 4 provinces: Barcelona, Girona, Lleida, and Tarragona; the capital and largest city is Barcelona (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catalonia). The Basque Country is located in the western Pyrenees, on the border between France and Spain on the coast of the Bay of Biscay (A map of Basque Country can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Basque+Country,+Spain.) San Sebasti\u00e1n is a coastal city located in the Basque Autonomous Community (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Sebasti\u00e1n).\n\nA map of (Madrid, Spain): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53751. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above news report fails to specify the microbial cause of meningitis in a 39-year-old man that developed after consuming cheese made from raw sheep's milk, but the most likely pathogen is _Listeria moncytogenes_. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, e.g., raw vegetables contaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk by infected cows, or contamination can occur following cooking or other processing. The organism can be found in soil, water, silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw milk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans. Most human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission can occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery through an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can occur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals. \n\nMadrid is the capital city of Spain and, with a population of about 3.1 million and a metropolitan population of about 6.5 million, is the largest municipality in both the Community of Madrid and Spain as a whole (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid). The warning follows a case of a 39-year-old man being diagnosed with the disease after consuming raw sheep's cheese. Infection can cause diarrhea and in some patients invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Because _Listeria_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures listeriosis is commonly associated with ingestion of contaminated food that have been held at refrigeration temperatures and then eaten without further cooking, e.g. ready-to-eat deli meats and cole slaw. MENINGITIS - SPAIN: (MADRID) FOODBORNE, RAW CHEESE, RECALL, ALERT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n Invasive listeriosis is rare (about 2500 cases occur annually in the US), but the disease has an overall case fatality rate of 20 to 30 percent. [Byline: Karl Smallman]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2018-02-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Girona", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Cataluna", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Lleida", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Gutizia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Txuria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Sebasti\u00e1n", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Barcelona", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "San Sebastian", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5497099", "headline": "PRO/EDR>  Meningitis - Ghana (07): (AH) fatal, students, NOT, influenza H1N1, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5497099", "date": "2017-12-12 11:31:21", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - GHANA (07): (ASHANTI) FATAL, STUDENTS, NOT INFLUENZA H1N1, WHO\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] WHO\nDate: Sat 9 Dec 2017\nSource: WHO, Weekly Bulletin on Outbreaks and Other Emergencies. Week 49: 2-9 Dec 2017 [edited]\nhttp://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/259635/1/OEW49-29122017.pdf\n\n\nNew events: Influenza A H1N1 - Ghana\n\nEvent description: Ghana: 77 cases, 4 deaths. 5.2 percent case fatality rate\n\nOn 6 Dec 2017, the Ghana Ministry of Health notified WHO of a focal outbreak of influenza A H1N1 in a school in Kumasi city, Ashanti region. The event was detected on 30 Nov 2017 when a cluster of 13 cases of severe acute respiratory illness was reported from Kumasi Academy Senior High School. The initial cases developed illness on 29 Nov 2017 and 3 deaths were reported by 1 Dec 2017.\n\nThe case-patients presented with fever, cough, headache, joint and body pains, and abnormal chest auscultation. As of 9 Dec 2017, 77 cases with 4 deaths (case fatality rate 5.2 percent) have been the reported. The majority of the cases, 66 percent, were males and over 95 percent of the cases are teenagers. Thus far, the disease is still localized in the school as no cases have been reported among community members.\n\nLaboratory specimens, including blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and throat swabs were collected from the case-patients and sent to Noguchi Memorial Institute for Medical Research (NMIMR), Kumasi Centre for Collaborative Research (KCCR), and other public health laboratories. Test results from NMIMR (a national influenza centre) released on 6 Dec 2017 indicated that 12 out of 19 throat swabs were positive for influenza A H1N1 2009 pandemic strain using polymerase chain reaction.\n\nCorroborative test results from KCCR released on 7 Dec 2017 showed that seven out of 25 nasal and throat swabs were positive for influenza type A using quantitative real time polymerase chain reaction (rt-PCR).\n\n2 blood specimens tested negative for Ebola and Marburg virus diseases, Lassa fever, yellow fever, dengue, chikungunya, and Zika virus. Specimens analyzed in other public health and research laboratories were negative for meningitis and encephalitis. Accordingly, the Ministry of Health has declared an outbreak of influenza A H1N1 pandemic strain as further epidemiological investigations are ongoing.\n\nKumasi Academy High School is a mixed sex school with total population of 3010 (2814 students including 541 day students, 127 teaching staff, and 73 non-teaching staff).\n\nPublic health actions\n---------------------\nThe Minister of Health and the WHO Representative held a press briefing to inform the public and provide updates on the outbreak.\n\nThe Ministry of Health deployed a multi-disciplinary rapid response team to Kumasi to conduct the outbreak investigation and support response actions. WHO provided technical and logistical support to the investigation mission.\n\nActive surveillance has been enhanced: a case definition was developed and active case search is being done among students and staff at the school and four healthcare facilities that treated the ill students. Suspected cases are being line listed.\n\nFour hospitals in Kumasi have been designated as isolation and treatment centres. Doctors have been assigned to the school Sick Bay to provide high-level pre-referral care to students.\n\nPublic health education and community sensitization are ongoing. The Public Health Directorate has granted media interviews to provide updates on the outbreak and actions being taken. Simple messages on infection prevention and control have been developed for education at the school.\n\nSituation interpretation\n------------------------\nThe influenza A H1N1 virus that caused the 2009 pandemic is now a regular human influenza virus circulating seasonally worldwide. However, seasonal influenza spreads easily, with rapid transmission in crowded areas including schools. This is the case for the event in Kumasi, Ghana. When an infected person coughs or sneezes, droplets containing viruses (infectious droplets) are dispersed into the air and are spread to persons in close proximity who breathe these droplets in. The virus can also be spread by contamination of hands with influenza viruses, which are then deposited on fomites.\n\nGhana has a good influenza preparedness system. The National Influenza Centre at NMIMR is part of the Global Influenza Surveillance Network (GISN), coordinated by WHO since 1996. Furthermore, the country is benefiting from the Pandemic Influenza Preparedness (PIP) Framework for determination of influenza burden of disease. The PIP Framework facilitates sharing of influenza viruses and access to vaccines and other benefits to improve global pandemic influenza preparedness and response. These capabilities enhanced the ability to detect the current outbreak in real time and initiate containment measures. Going forward, it is necessary to remain vigilant and continue active epidemiologic and laboratory surveillance for early detection of further transmission of the virus in the community.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 11 Dec 2017\nFrom: Kwadwo Ansah Koram <KKoram@noguchi.ug.edu.gh> [edited]\n\n\nTo provide some information on the H1N1 outbreak in Kumasi Academy, the 19 samples received for testing at Noguchi Memorial Institute were nasopharyngeal swabs from some of the sick individuals on admission at the time.\n\n--\nDr Kwadwo Ansah Koram\nProfessor\nNMIMR [Noguchi Memorial Institute for Medical Research]\nUniversity of Ghana\nLegon, Ghana\n<KKoram@noguchi.ug.edu.gh>\n\n[The diagnosis for the illness that affected a total of 77 Kumasi Academy students since the end of November 2017 has now been apparently confirmed to be influenza due to A/(H1N1)pdm09. We are told that over 95 percent of the cases are teenagers. However, we still have not been informed if A/(H1N1)pdm09 was detected in the 4 Kumasi Academy students who died, or about the results of the post-mortem exams on the fatal cases.\n\nKumasi Academy is a public secondary boarding school located in Asokore-Mampong, a suburb of the city of Kumasi (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumasi_Academy). Kumasi, with an estimated population in 2013 of over 2 million residents, is the capital of the Ashanti region of Ghana (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumasi).\n\nMaps of Ghana can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Ghana.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2900. The Ashanti region is located in south-central Ghana and is the 3rd largest of 10 administrative regions, with a population of about 3.6 million residents in 2000, accounting for 19.1 percent of Ghana's total population (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashanti_Region). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] WHO\n University of Ghana\nLegon, Ghana\n<KKoram@noguchi.ug.edu.gh>\n\n[The diagnosis for the illness that affected a total of 77 Kumasi Academy students since the end of November 2017 has now been apparently confirmed to be influenza due to A/(H1N1)pdm09. 5.2 percent case fatality rate\n\nOn 6 Dec 2017, the Ghana Ministry of Health notified WHO of a focal outbreak of influenza A H1N1 in a school in Kumasi city, Ashanti region. \n\nKumasi Academy High School is a mixed sex school with total population of 3010 (2814 students including 541 day students, 127 teaching staff, and 73 non-teaching staff). \n\nActive surveillance has been enhanced: a case definition was developed and active case search is being done among students and staff at the school and four healthcare facilities that treated the ill students. Dr Kwadwo Ansah Koram\nProfessor\nNMIMR Week 49: 2-9 Dec 2017 [edited]\nhttp://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/259635/1/OEW49-29122017.pdf\n\n\nNew events: \n\n--\n \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "lassa fever", "marburg virus disease", "yellow fever", "zika"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2017-12-26 00:00:00", "1996-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "H1N1", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kumasi Academy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Legon", "country": "Cuba"}, {"location": "Asokore - Mampong", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Kumasi", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "Kumasi city", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "NMIMR", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5494656", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Ghana (06): (AH) fatal, H.S. students, influenza, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5494656", "date": "2017-12-10 23:35:03", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - GHANA (06): (ASHANTI) FATAL, HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, INFLUENZA, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 8 Dec 2017\nSource: YEN [edited]\nhttps://yen.com.gh/102560-mysterious-kumaca-deaths-caused-by-influenza-health-minister.html#102560\n\n\nDeaths at Kumasi Academy have been linked to spread of influenza. The health minister is calling for students to still stay on campus. It has emerged that the cause of mysterious deaths at the Kumasi Academy is due to type A influenza, the strain [that] causes the deadly swine flu.\n\nAddressing the press in an emergency briefing, the health minister, Kwaku Agyeman-Manu, revealed that out of 44 cases reported, only 4 have died, bringing a total of 11 deaths in the year alone.\n\nSamples of students taken for intense investigation at Nuguchi [Noguchi Memorial Institute for Medical Research, Accra] revealed that out of the 19 samples collected, 12 tested positive for influenza type A.\n\nMeanwhile, the health minister is calling for all students to be kept on campus to provide that vaccinations to control the outbreak are ensured.\n\nA senior pathologist at KATH, Dr Osei Sampene, revealed on Nyira FM that 'all bodies of students from Kumasi Academy showed signs of a strange disease, which could also be one of its kind in Ghana.' Meanwhile, vaccines are currently being administered to all students to protect them against possible viral or bacterial infections.\n\nParliament has summoned the minister for health, Kwaku Agyemang-Manu on updates related to the deaths of persons. According to him, any attempt by parents to send their wards home poses a serious national security threat since the cause of their deaths is strangely unknown.\n\nThe current atmosphere at Kumasi Academy is that of fear and uncertainty as parents run to the school to see if their wards are doing well, as others demand to take their wards home with them. The death toll continues to rise, as the total number of persons losing [their] lives in a week alone has reached 6.\n\n[Byline: Charles Ayitey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 8 Dec 2017\nSource: citifmonline.com [edited]\nhttps://citifmonline.com/2017/12/08/kumaca-students-to-stay-in-school-over-swine-flu-fears/\n\n\nIndications from the government are that the students and staff of Kumasi Academy will remain in the school till response efforts to the detected influenza virus are completed. Addressing Parliament on Friday [8 Dec 2017], the Health Minister, Kwaku Agyeman-Manu, said efforts are already underway in this regard while disease surveillance measures are being strengthened.\n\nParents want public health prioritized. 'Mr. Speaker, going forward, the ministries of Health and Education, the Ghana Health Service, and the Ghana Education Service have recommended, and we are embarking upon that, that students should continue to remain [on the school's premises] to enable final conclusion and response actions,' the Minister said.\n\nInitially, the Kumasi Academy was set to close down today [Fri 8 Dec 2017] until it became clearer that the health crisis in the school was brought by the pandemic strain of influenza type A, H1N1 2009, also known as swine flu.\n\nThe government is thus looking for support from the World Health Organization (WHO) to provide influenza vaccines for the students and staff.\n\nThe health crisis at the school has claimed 4 lives and hospitalized at least 32. However, the outright cause of death of the 4 students of the school and the hospitalization of 32 has yet to be fully confirmed.\n\nMinister of Health, Kwaku Agyemang-Manu added on the floor of Parliament that the government was going to rely on antiviral agents. 'We have procured already, and we are in the process of procuring, antiviral agents for case management. So far, that is what has been used, and it looks like it has succeeded in containing and treating the disease. Aside from these, steps are also being taken to enhance school health at Kumasi Academy, and there will be strict adherence to infection prevention and control measures along with intensified sensitisation and public education,' Mr. Agyemang-Manu added.\n\n[Byline: Delali Adogla-Bessa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Sun 10 Dec 2017\nSource: Ghana Web [edited]\nhttps://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/features/Kumasi-Academy-deaths-608240\n\n\nFinally, the health authorities have confirmed that there is an influenza outbreak at Kumasi Academy School. The health Minister assured parliament that his ministry was in discussions with the WHO to obtain vaccines for the students and staff of the school.\n\nIt appears obvious that there was no plan in place to tackle the outbreak, which killed 4 students and has left another 18 students on admission.\n\nWhile the plans to vaccinate the student body [are] appropriate, have close contacts of the dead and the sick been identified? How and where have these been monitored? Are there plans to provide them with chemoprophylaxis?\n\nIn March of this year [2017], 4 students of the same school were reported to have died of meningitis. If this report is accurate, what measures were taken before the students returned to school?\n\nIn an interaction with the press, the Minister of Health indicated that the president had been exposed. Who determined the exposure? If indeed the president was exposed, what steps have been taken to safeguard his health? Why was he permitted to go to the campus when there was an outbreak whose source had not been determined? Why was it deemed safe to have the school's anniversary celebration during the outbreak?\n\nFinally, too often, we do not learn the right lessons from such events. Hopefully, our authorities will develop a policy to handle such occurrences in the future.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 1st news report above says that there have been 44 cases reported, with 4 deaths in the current outbreak among students at Kumasi Academy; however, later in this news report the number of deaths in the current outbreak is stated to be 6; also 12 of 19 samples, the exact source of the samples not being specified, tested positive for influenza virus type A. Were the 'samples' respiratory secretions? Were the people sampled the dead students, the surviving hospitalized students, or non-hospitalized students with mild illness? The 2nd news report above says that this influenza A virus identified was 'the pandemic strain, H1N1 2009 also known as swine flu,' but questions whether influenza was 'the outright cause of death of the 4 students at the school and the hospitalization of 32 has yet to be fully confirmed.'\n\nThe H1N1 virus that caused the pandemic in 2009-2010 is now a regular human flu virus that continues to circulate seasonally worldwide and is now called A(H1N1)pdm09. A remarkable feature of A/(H1N1)pdm09 in the 2009 pandemic, compared with other seasonal strains, was noted to be its high fatality rate, admissions to ICUs for acute respiratory distress, and its higher incidence among younger people (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27941959, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5632968/, http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa0904252#t=abstract, and https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4910438/).\n\nThe current influenza vaccines protect against an influenza A (H1N1) virus, an influenza A (H3N2) virus, and one or 2 influenza B viruses (depending on the vaccine). Currently circulating influenza viruses are reported to be susceptible to the neuraminidase inhibitor antiviral medications, oseltamivir, zanamivir, and peramivir; however, rare sporadic instances of oseltamivir-resistant and peramivir-resistant influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 viruses have been detected worldwide (https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/index.htm). Antiviral treatment as early as possible is recommended for patients with confirmed or suspected influenza who have severe, complicated, or progressive illness; who require hospitalization; or who are at high risk for serious influenza-related complications (http://www.cdc.gov/flu/antivirals/index.htm).\n\nMore information on this outbreak at Kumasi Academy would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources, especially the findings of post-mortem exams on the 4 or 6 students who died recently.\n\nKumasi Academy is a public secondary boarding school located in Asokore-Mampong, a suburb of the city of Kumasi (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumasi_Academy). Kumasi, with an estimated population in 2013 of over 2 million residents, is the capital of the Ashanti region of Ghana (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumasi). Maps of Ghana can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Ghana.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50377. The Ashanti region is located in south-central Ghana and is the 3rd largest of 10 administrative regions, with a population of about 3.6 million residents in 2000, accounting for 19.1 percent of Ghana's total population (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashanti_Region). - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nAshanti Region, Ghana: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2900\n\nIt is very pertinent to know whether the samples that tested positive for influenza came from the fatal or hospitalized cases as referred to by ML, influenza associated morbidity and mortality rates are generally high in very young or the very old, the age group of these students is also not specified. Ghana is in West Africa and lies in Northern Hemisphere where the seasonal influenza activity is just picking up..Also the presentation of many viral infections is with 'flu' like symptoms, therefore the possibility of another viral pathogen cannot be ruled out unless results from other lab tests or autopsy findings are available-Mod.UBA]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 1st news report above says that there have been 44 cases reported, with 4 deaths in the current outbreak among students at Kumasi Academy; however, later in this news report the number of deaths in the current outbreak is stated to be 6; also 12 of 19 samples, the exact source of the samples not being specified, tested positive for influenza virus type A. Were the 'samples' respiratory secretions? A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n [Byline: Delali Adogla-Bessa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n***** \n\nThe current influenza vaccines protect against an influenza A (H1N1) virus, an influenza A (H3N2) virus, and one or 2 influenza B viruses (depending on the vaccine). The 2nd news report above says that this influenza A virus identified was 'the pandemic strain, H1N1 2009 also known as swine flu,' but questions whether influenza was 'the outright cause of death of the 4 students at the school and the hospitalization of 32 has yet to be fully confirmed.' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n MENINGITIS - GHANA (06): (ASHANTI) FATAL, HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, INFLUENZA, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************************\n Samples of students taken for intense investigation at Nuguchi [Noguchi Memorial Institute for Medical Research, Accra] revealed that out of the 19 samples collected, 12 tested positive for influenza type A.\n\n It is very pertinent to know whether the samples that tested positive for influenza came from the fatal or hospitalized cases as referred to by ML, influenza associated morbidity and mortality rates are generally high in very young or the very old, the age group of these students is also not specified. \n\nAddressing the press in an emergency briefing, the health minister, Kwaku Agyeman-Manu, revealed that out of 44 cases reported, only 4 have died, bringing a total of 11 deaths in the year alone. \n\nMore information on this outbreak at Kumasi Academy would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources, especially the findings of post-mortem exams on the 4 or 6 students who died recently. [Fri 8 Dec 2017] until it became clearer that the health crisis in the school was brought by the pandemic strain of influenza type A, H1N1 2009, also known as swine flu. https://citifmonline.com/2017/12/08/kumaca-students-to-stay-in-school-over-swine-flu-fears/\n\n\nIndications from the government are that the students and staff of Kumasi Academy will remain in the school till response efforts to the detected influenza virus are completed. Currently circulating influenza viruses are reported to be susceptible to the neuraminidase inhibitor antiviral medications, oseltamivir, zanamivir, and peramivir; however, rare sporadic instances of oseltamivir-resistant and peramivir-resistant influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 viruses have been detected worldwide (https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/index.htm). Mr. Speaker, going forward, the ministries of Health and Education, the Ghana Health Service, and the Ghana Education Service have recommended, and we are embarking upon that, that students should continue to remain [on the school's premises] to enable final conclusion and response actions,' the Minister said. Were the people sampled the dead students, the surviving hospitalized students, or non-hospitalized students with mild illness? \n\nThe health crisis at the school has claimed 4 lives and hospitalized at least 32. Antiviral treatment as early as possible is recommended for patients with confirmed or suspected influenza who have severe, complicated, or progressive illness; who require hospitalization; or who are at high risk for serious influenza-related complications (http://www.cdc.gov/flu/antivirals/index.htm). \n\nThe H1N1 virus that caused the pandemic in 2009-2010 is now a regular human flu virus that continues to circulate seasonally worldwide and is now called A(H1N1)pdm09. The government is thus looking for support from the World Health Organization (WHO) to provide influenza vaccines for the students and staff. It appears obvious that there was no plan in place to tackle the outbreak, which killed 4 students and has left another 18 students on admission. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nAshanti Region, Ghana: \n\nA senior pathologist at KATH, Dr Osei Sampene, revealed on Nyira FM that 'all bodies of students from Kumasi Academy showed signs of a strange disease, which could also be one of its kind in Ghana.' \n\nThe current atmosphere at Kumasi Academy is that of fear and uncertainty as parents run to the school to see if their wards are doing well, as others demand to take their wards home with them. However, the outright cause of death of the 4 students of the school and the hospitalization of 32 has yet to be fully confirmed.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2032-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Asokore - Mampong", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Kumasi", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "Chile"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5491799", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Ghana (05): (AH) fatal, H.S. students, azithromycin, NOT, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5491799", "date": "2017-12-08 15:30:13", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - GHANA (05): (ASHANTI) FATAL, HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, AZITHROMYCIN, NOT, COMMENT\n******************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Dec 2017\nSource: Source: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\nSuspected case definition for Asokore Mampong outbreak [outbreak in students at the Kumasi Academy, which is located in Asokore Mampong, a suburb of the city of Kumasi] and other matters\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------\nI write to update you on what is happening and the working suspected case definition we should be using to find more cases.\nBased on the symptoms reported and signs elicited so far, we can deduce that:\n1. The disease has a short incubation period of about 0-2 days\n2. The disease has a high fatality\n3. The disease is transmitted from person to person\nA suspected case therefore has been defined as anyone presenting with fever (greater than or equal to 38 degrees C [100.4 F]) headache, muscle pain, with or without any of the following:\n- Cough\n- Bleeding\n- Diarrhoea\n- Vomiting\n- Stiff neck\n\nPlease use this case definition to find more cases and do well to separate them from other cases for infection control. Taking detailed history (which should include details of recent travel outside school, visitors received, contacts with other cases, etc) and doing full physical examination is still imperative. Take appropriate laboratory samples, which may include:\n- Malaria RDT [Rapid Diagnostic Test]\n- CSF [cerebrospinal fluid] Microscopy for Meningitis\n- CSF Culture for meningitis\n- PCR for meningitis\n- Throat swab for Influenza\n- Blood for VHF [viral hemorrhagic fever]\n- Full blood count\n\nUpdate on Kamaka [Kamasi Academy] outbreak\n------------------------------------------\n1. A total of 46 students so far have been admitted in health facilities in the metropolis with KNUST hospital admitting the majority. KATH [Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital] has so far admitted 6 cases.\n\n2. In all there have been 4 mortalities.\n\n3. The major symptoms have been fever, headache and cough followed by vomiting, diarrhoea and neck pain.\n\n4. CSF latex agglutination tests, culture and PCR have not identified any organism yet. Tests were done in KATH, KCCR [Kumasi Center for Collaborative Research in Tropical Medicine] and Reference Lab in Tamale [Tamale is the capital city of the Northern Region].\n\n5. Tests done at Noguchi [a medical research institute at the University of Ghana in Accra] so [far] for Ebola, Marburg, Lassa, Dengue have [been] negative. KCCR has also done some viral screens, none of which has been positive. I don't have details on all tests done at KCCR but will ask the details from the Regional health directorate. We are awaiting results from about 19 throat swabs sent to KCCR for PCR.\n\n6. Regarding the antibiotic prophylaxis [azithromycin], the decision was made because the cases respond quite rapidly to antibiotics and so the thinking is that it could be bacterial.\n\n7. The decision was held off for a while with the hope that all the numerous tests being done would yield some results but so far everything has been negative.\n\n8. This is an emergency for all and multidisciplinary collaboration is what is needed. We are trying to get the clinical details of all the cases for a meeting being convened tomorrow [Sat 9 Dec 2017] for some clinicians, Microbiology, Pathology, public health and other disciplines to deliberate on what the picture points to and what else can be done in terms of investigations, clinical management, etc.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks the EpiCore Global Surveillance Project member for this update on the outbreak of a so far undiagnosed febrile illness among students at the Kumasi Academy.\n\nKumasi Academy is a public secondary boarding school located in Asokore-Mampong, a suburb of the city of Kumasi (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumasi_Academy). Kumasi, with an estimated population in 2013 of over 2 million residents, is the capital of the Ashanti Region of Ghana (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumasi). Maps of Ghana can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Ghana.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50377. The Ashanti Region is located in south-central Ghana and is 3rd largest of 10 administrative regions, with a population of about 3.6 million residents in 2000, accounting for 19.1 percent of Ghana's total population (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashanti_Region). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "[Rapid Diagnostic Test]\n- CSF [cerebrospinal fluid] Microscopy for Meningitis\n- CSF Culture for meningitis\n- PCR for meningitis\n- Throat swab for Influenza\n- Blood for VHF [viral hemorrhagic fever]\n- Full blood count\n\nUpdate on Kamaka [Kamasi Academy] outbreak\n------------------------------------------\n1. [100.4 F]) headache, muscle pain, with or without any of the following:\n- Cough\n- Bleeding\n- Diarrhoea\n- Vomiting\n- Stiff neck\n\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n We are trying to get the clinical details of all the cases for a meeting being convened tomorrow [Sat 9 Dec 2017] for some clinicians, Microbiology, Pathology, public health and other disciplines to deliberate on what the picture points to and what else can be done in terms of investigations, clinical management, etc.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n< MENINGITIS - GHANA (05): (ASHANTI) FATAL, HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, AZITHROMYCIN, NOT, COMMENT\n******************************************************************************************\n Source: Source: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\nSuspected case definition for Asokore Mampong outbreak [outbreak in students at the Kumasi Academy, which is located in Asokore Mampong, a suburb of the city of Kumasi] and other matters\n The disease has a short incubation period of about 0-2 days\n2.
