Date: Fri 8 Dec 2017\n \n \n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "malaria"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lassa", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Asokore - Mampong", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Marburg", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Kumasi", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "Asokore Mampong", "country": "Ghana"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5475220", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (MA) college, sg.B, mass sg.B vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5475220", "date": "2017-11-30 21:40:24", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (06): (MASSACHUSETTS) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B, MASS SEROGROUP B VACCINATION\n********************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 28 Nov 2017 6:13 pm\nSource: WWLP [edited]\nhttp://wwlp.com/2017/11/28/umass-amherst-preparing-to-vaccinate-students-after-meningitis-outbreak-declared/\n\n\nUMass Amherst [University of Massachusetts at Amherst] is preparing to vaccinate all 20 000 undergraduate students following an outbreak of meningitis. This is something that UMass trains for each year, but hasn't had to do in a real-world situation since the 2009 outbreak of Swine Flu.\n\nMeningitis is a potentially deadly bacterial infection. There are 2 confirmed cases at UMass and more may be carrying the bacteria. 'This bacteria exists as a carrier state mostly and it occasionally causes disease,' explained Dr. George Corey, the Executive Director of UMass University Health Services. 'So for every case there could be many carriers who will never become ill.'\n\nCDC testing shows the 2 sick students, who did not know each other, had the same genetic virus, which suggests that others who don't show symptoms may have the bacteria dormant in their body. That's why UMass is holding their 1st of 4 mass vaccination clinics [Thu 30 Nov 2017] inside the Student Union.\n\n'There's a good chance or a worrisome chance that someone else could get ill,' said UMass Public Health Nurse Ann Becker. 'The illness is severe enough that we really don't see any of our students get this, not one, one more is too many.' Becker recommends students avoid sharing food, drinks, and close contact, and to wash your hands. 'I am certainly worried. I've been paying attention to e-mails,' said UMass undergraduate student [MW]. 'I personally have not gotten the shot but a lot of my friends have so I think it's in everyone's minds across campus.'\n\nUMass wants you to know this vaccine is different than the meningitis vaccine you were required to get before you enrolled. UMass will bill your insurance, so there should be no out of pocket cost. So far, UMass has vaccinated 1500 students. Faculty and staff are not considered at risk.\n\nAs for the 2 students who already have meningitis, UMass health officials would only say they are getting positive updates.\n\n[Byline: Matt Caron]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A primary case is one that occurs in the absence of previous known close contact with another case-patient.\n\nAn outbreak is defined by the occurrence of at least 3 confirmed or probable primary cases of the same serogroup meningococcal disease during a period of 3 months or less, with a resulting primary attack rate of 10 or more cases per 100 000 population. Two primary cases caused by serogroup B in 21 000 UMass Amherst undergraduates gives a primary attack rate of 9.5 / 100 000.\n\nIn some instances the attack rate will be greater than 10 cases per 100 000 population with only 2 cases. In these situations, vaccination may be considered after only 2 primary cases are identified (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6202a3.htm). For outbreaks caused by serogroup B, the CDC recommends vaccination with a serogroup B meningococcal vaccine for anyone 10 years or older identified as being at increased risk.\n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal disease are usually caused by the same or closely related strains. Molecular genotyping will help characterize an outbreak clone. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/224.\n\n]", "summary": "\n\nAn outbreak is defined by the occurrence of at least 3 confirmed or probable primary cases of the same serogroup meningococcal disease during a period of 3 months or less, with a resulting primary attack rate of 10 or more cases per 100 000 population. For outbreaks caused by serogroup B, the CDC recommends vaccination with a serogroup B meningococcal vaccine for anyone 10 years or older identified as being at increased risk. \n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal disease are usually caused by the same or closely related strains. In these situations, vaccination may be considered after only 2 primary cases are identified (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6202a3.htm). [Byline: Matt Caron]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Amherst", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5489284", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Ghana (04): (AH) fatal, high school students, azithromycin, NOT, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5489284", "date": "2017-12-07 17:12:21", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - GHANA (04): (ASHANTI) FATAL, HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, AZITHROMYCIN, NOT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 7 Dec 2017 11:12:36 AM GMT\nSource: Myjoyonline, Nhyira FM report [edited]\nhttps://www.myjoyonline.com/lifestyle/2017/December-7th/no-more-deaths-at-kumaca-health-director-assures.php\n\n\nThe Ghana Health Service has assured no further deaths at Kumasi Academy as students undergo [treatment with] azithromycin, a broad-spectrum antibiotics medication.\n\n[Ashanti] Regional Health Director, Dr Emmanuel Tinkorang, says every student at Kumasi Academy [KUMACA] will survive the attack of a suspected bacterial infection, which has claimed lives of at least 11 students. Over 40 students have been affected, with 19 currently on admission at Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST) Hospital and Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital.\n\nThe assurance comes as students and teachers undergo antibiotics medication supplied by the World Health Organization. They are expected to complete the 3-dose medication they started on [Tue 5 Dec 2017].\n\nNineteen students, 16 on admission at Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology Hospital and 3 at Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital are said to be responding to treatment. Their high body temperatures are said to have normalised after taking azithromycin, a broad-spectrum antibiotic. With these actions taken, Dr Tinkorang is full of hope that no student will die again at Kumasi Academy. 'Every child will survive in this school. No child will die. I must assure you. Once you take the treatment, there would be no problem. Everybody will survive,' he assured.\n\nDr Tinkorang was speaking on [Tue 5 Dec 2017] during a meeting with parents, students, and teachers of KUMACA to begin the antibiotic medication. The Ministry of Education announced the school would be closed down to enable health officials to carry thorough investigations and surveillance in the school.\n\n[Byline: Ohemeng Tawiah]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 6 Dec 2017 11:12:16 AM GMT\nSource: Myjoyonline [edited]\nhttps://www.myjoyonline.com/news/2017/December-6th/strange-deaths-kumasi-academy-may-be-closed-down-thursday.php\n\n\nThe Health Minister, Kwaku Agyemang-Manu, has said the Kumasi Academy will not be closed down as stated earlier. The Ashanti Regional Minister, Simon Osei Mensah had told Luv News' Ohemeng Tawiah earlier that authorities were considering closing down the school on [Thu 30 Nov 2017].\n\nJoy News' Parliamentary Correspondent, Joseph Opoku Gapko, however, reports the Health Minister as saying adequate measures are being put in place to contain the situation, which has so far cost government GHS 100 000 [about USD 22 000]. Frantic efforts are being made to ascertain the cause of deaths at the school following the outbreak of an 'unknown' illness.\n\nSo far, 4 students -- 3 boys and a girl -- have lost their lives to the illness doctors at the Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital have described as the 1st of its kind in Ghana. Some 18 other students are on admission, while 6 have been treated and discharged.\n\nThe female student who died yesterday [5 Dec 2017] is reported to have had a high body temperature and died after she was rushed to the hospital.\n\nSchool and health authorities are undertaking a screening and treatment exercise for students. A number of students who left the school returned this morning [6 Dec 2017] to take part in the screening and treatment. They will, however, return to their various homes after school closes today and return tomorrow for teaching and learning to continue.\n\nAlready, most of the students have taken a broad-spectrum antibiotics being administered by health authorities. They suspect the cause of the deaths is a bacterial infection and they believe the antibiotics being administered will weaken it. Although the specific illness is still not known, health authorities expect each student to take the antibiotic before they go home to prevent the spread of the disease in case it is contagious. Tests are still being run and health authorities are hopeful that they will soon arrive at the real cause of the situation.\n\nOhemeng said the panic-stricken parents are cooperating with school and health authorities although they say there has been a lack of transparency on the issue. The recent deaths bring the total number of deaths in the school since March this year [2017] when the 'mysterious' illness broke to 11.\n\n[Byline: Naa Sakwaba Akwa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue 5 Dec 2017 01:12:44 PM GMT\nSource: Myjoyonline [edited]\nhttps://www.myjoyonline.com/lifestyle/2017/December-5th/fear-panic-in-kumasi-as-another-kumaca-student-dies.php\n\n\nAshanti Regional Minister, Simon Osei Mensah, has summoned a crisis meeting on the health situation in Kumasi Academy (KUMACA) after another student died this morning [5 Dec 2017]. The Minister is expected to meet with health officials and education authorities to explore ways to prevent more deaths in the school.\n\nThe death of a female student [Tue 5 Dec 2017] brings to 11 the total number of deaths recorded in KUMACA since March [2017]. She reportedly had increased body temperature but she died after she was rushed to a hospital.\n\nThere were reports meningitis was the cause of the deaths, but autopsy reports released on two of the bodies did not support that claim. Nhyira FM's Ohemeng Tawiah reported the examination conducted by a senior pathologist in Kumasi was not able to establish the cause of death, which further heightened the concerns of school authorities.\n\nAlready, parents and guardians have thronged the school to withdraw their wards.\n\nBut Asokore Mampong Municipal Chief Executive, Alidu Seidu, has said any parent who would want to take the ward will be required to sign a form to that effect. The situation has triggered concerns in Parliament, with lawmakers asking for Health Minister, Kwaku Agyeman Manu, to be summoned over the matter.\n\nAsawase Member of Parliament, Muntaka Mubarak Mohammed, said he has been inundated with calls over the health situation in the school. 'Fear and panic by students, by parents, and school authorities,' he told his colleagues in parliament, expressing worry that the release of students to their parents will jeopardize public safety. But the Health Minister who appeared before Parliament, later [Tue 5 Dec 2017] has pleaded for more time to ascertain the cause of deaths in the school.\n\n'As I speak the heads of public health are all in Kumasi... I will need a little bit of time to get the report,' he said, adding samples taken after the postmortem have been sent to the Noguchi Memorial Institute in Accra for further examination. He said because of the delicate nature of the situation, it would be a 'bit na\u00efve' on his part to give timelines.\n\n[Byline: Austin Brakopowers]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that the outbreak at the Kumasi Academy in Kumasi, Ghana has resulted in 4 dead students -- 3 boys and a girl; 19 other students still hospitalized; and 6 students treated and discharged. The hospitalized students are said to have had high-grade fever on admission, but we are not otherwise told the clinical manifestations of this illness, which is nevertheless thought to be bacterial infection that is now being treated with a 3-day course of azithromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, to which the hospitalized students are said to have responded.\n\nAutopsies on 2 of the 4 Kumasi students who died recently are said to have ruled out meningitis, but failed to yield a cause of death. Azithromycin is now apparently being given to all students and teachers at the school, although we are not told specifically the indication for this drug.\n\nThe outbreak is said to have started in March 2017 when there were 7 deaths among students at Kumasi Academy to bring the current total to 11 fatalities (please see ProMED-mail post Meningitis - Ghana: (AH) fatal, high school students, RFI 20170407.4953952)\n\nKumasi Academy is a public secondary boarding school located in Asokore-Mampong, a suburb of the city of Kumasi, the capital of the Ashanti Region of Ghana (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumasi_Academy). Maps of Ghana can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Ghana.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2900. The Ashanti region is located in south-central Ghana and is 3rd largest of 10 administrative regions, with a population of about 3.6 million residents in 2000, accounting for 19.1 percent of Ghana's total population (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashanti_Region).\n\nMore information on this outbreak would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nThe outbreak is said to have started in March 2017 when there were 7 deaths among students at Kumasi Academy to bring the current total to 11 fatalities (please see ProMED-mail post Meningitis - Ghana: (AH) fatal, high school students, RFI 20170407.4953952) promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that the outbreak at the Kumasi Academy in Kumasi, Ghana has resulted in 4 dead students -- 3 boys and a girl; 19 other students still hospitalized; and 6 students treated and discharged. Date: Tue 5 Dec 2017 01:12:44 PM GMT\nSource: Myjoyonline [edited]\n Date: Wed 6 Dec 2017 11:12:16 AM GMT\nSource: Myjoyonline [edited]\nhttps://www.myjoyonline.com/news/2017/December-6th/strange-deaths-kumasi-academy-may-be-closed-down-thursday.php But the Health Minister who appeared before Parliament, later [Tue 5 Dec 2017] has pleaded for more time to ascertain the cause of deaths in the school. The recent deaths bring the total number of deaths in the school since March this year [2017] when the 'mysterious' illness broke to 11. A number of students who left the school returned this morning [6 Dec 2017] to take part in the screening and treatment. \n\n\nThe Ghana Health Service has assured no further deaths at Kumasi Academy as students undergo [treatment with] azithromycin, a broad-spectrum antibiotics medication. \n\nJoy News' Parliamentary Correspondent, Joseph Opoku Gapko, however, reports the Health Minister as saying adequate measures are being put in place to contain the situation, which has so far cost government GHS 100 000 [Byline: Ohemeng Tawiah]\n\n--\n [Byline: Naa Sakwaba Akwa]\n\n--\n [Byline: Austin Brakopowers]\n\n--\n \n\nThere were reports meningitis was the cause of the deaths, but autopsy reports released on two of the bodies did not support that claim.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-12-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Asokore - Ghana (03): (AH) fatal, susp, high school students, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5483340", "date": "2017-12-05 10:50:07", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - GHANA (03): (ASHANTI) FATAL, SUSPECTED, HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 3 Dec 2017\nSource: Modern Ghana [edited]\nhttps://www.modernghana.com/news/820355/meningitis-kills-another-student-at-kumasi-academythe-3rd.html\n\n\nA 1st-year-student of Kumasi Academy Senior High School (KUMACA) has died from meningitis bringing the death toll recorded under similar circumstances in the school to 3 in the last week [week of Sun 26 Nov 2017[. The death of [the student], a General Arts student who died at the Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital (KATH) brings to 6 such occurrences this year [2017]. Luv News sources say several other students are on admission at the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST) Hospital and KATH.\n\nOhemeng Tawiah reported the death of 2 students on [Fri 1 Dec 2017] who were rushed to the hospital after they complained of 'fever-like conditions' at the school's clinic.\n\nUp to 3 students of the school died under similar circumstances in April [2017] this year, sparking off chaotic uproar as parents besieged the school in a desperate move to take their wards home. [Please see prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis - Ghana: (AH) fatal, high school students, RFI 20170407.4953952.]\n\nMeanwhile, results of a postmortem conducted on the deceased did not reveal meningitis as had been widely claimed by some students, the reporter added. Ohemeng Tawiah said blood samples of the affected students have been sent to the Noguchi Memorial Institute in Accra for examination.\n\nThe incident had come at a time the school is preparing to round up activities to climax the 60th-anniversary celebrations. As a result school authorities have remained tight-lipped over the incident, the reporter said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above news report says that 3 students at the Kumasi Academy in Kumasi, Ghana died of meningitis in the past several days, although post-mortem exam 'did not reveal meningitis'. The above news report also says that 3 additional students had died in April 2017 'under similar circumstances at the [Kumasi] school,' although a prior ProMED-mail post last April 2017 reported that 4 students had died out of 30 'confirmed cases' of pneumococcal meningitis at the Kumasi Academy school in Kumasi, Ghana. (Please see prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis - Ghana: (AH) fatal, high school students, RFI 20170407.4953952) and subsequent ProMED-mail post in Nov 2017 said, 'a thorough autopsy revealed that 4 students of Kumasi Academy Senior High in the Ashanti region died this year [2017] of the disease [pneumococcal meningitis].' This November 2017 report said that a total of 93 people had died of pneumococcal meningitis in Ghana 'since last year [2016]' (Meningitis, pneumococcal - Ghana: fatal, RFI 20171112.5439630.)\n\nKumasi Academy is a public secondary boarding school located in Asokore-Mampong, a suburb of the city of Kumasi, the capital of the Ashanti Region of Ghana (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumasi_Academy). Maps of Ghana can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Ghana.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50377. The Ashanti Region is located in south-central Ghana and is 3rd largest of 10 administrative regions, with a population of about 3.6 million residents in 2000, accounting for 19.1 percent of Ghana's total population (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashanti_Region).\n\nThe northern region of Ghana lies within the African meningitis belt where outbreaks of meningitis, usually due to _Neisseria meningitidis_, occur during the dry season, between November and May. The African meningitis belt is sub-Saharan and extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia in the east. A map can be seen at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/pdf/yellowbook-2012-map3-13-frequent-epidemics-meningococcal-meningitis.pdf.\n\nHowever, several studies have emphasized that _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ may also cause outbreaks of bacterial meningitis in an epidemic pattern in the African meningitis belt during the dry season (http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/192/2/192.abstract?ijkey=9d47813b96aa1d50880f62e9e7efbc4d32bfea9a&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha and http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.abstract?ijkey=7d2ca30004fffc8d1410102f6ec758a72efc1f82&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha).\n\nSome clarification would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources on the numbers of the affected Kumasi students and their exact diagnoses.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAshanti Region, Ghana: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2774. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "(Please see prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis - Ghana: (AH) fatal, high school students, RFI 20170407.4953952) and subsequent ProMED-mail post in Nov 2017 said, 'a thorough autopsy revealed that 4 students of Kumasi Academy Senior High in the Ashanti region died this year [2017] of the disease [pneumococcal meningitis].' MENINGITIS - GHANA (03): (ASHANTI) FATAL, SUSPECTED, HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************************\n \n\nOhemeng Tawiah reported the death of 2 students on [Fri 1 Dec 2017] who were rushed to the hospital after they complained of 'fever-like conditions' at the school's clinic.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-04-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-04-26 00:00:00", "2017-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kumasi", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Asokore - Mampong", "country": "Ghana"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5473532", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5473532", "date": "2017-11-30 12:02:08", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (06): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 29 Nov 2017\nFrom: Hannah Carey <hcarey@bu.edu> [edited]\n\n\nAn additional student at Oregon State University [OSU] was recently diagnosed with meningococcal [serogroup] B disease, for a total of 5 cases associated with the current outbreak. I have forwarded an e-mail sent out to the student body regarding the infection for your records [appended below].\n\n'Date: Sat, Nov 25, 2017 at 4:12 PM\n'Subject: [OSU-students-Corvallis] Urgent vaccinations urged; 5th meningococcal B case reported.\n\n'OSU Corvallis students,\n\n'We are urgently writing to inform you that yet another undergraduate student attending Oregon State University in Corvallis is being treated for meningococcal disease. This is the 5th OSU student to be treated for meningococcal disease in the past year [since November 2016].\n\n'It is important that you are aware of this latest case.\n\n'If you have not done so, we urge you immediately to be vaccinated for meningococcal B disease, which requires at least 2 doses to be effective. If you have started a vaccine series it is important that you compete the series in the requisite timeframe.\n\n'Please be aware that while meningococcal disease is uncommon, it is a serious disease. In 10 to 15 percent of all cases, death may result, as was the case with a University of Oregon student in February 2015. In 20 percent of cases, hearing loss, mental impairment, and limb loss can result. Those at highest risk include students aged 25 and younger who live in residence halls and in private cooperative group living units, or are members of -- or visit -- fraternal living groups associated with the university.\n\n'While extremely serious, meningococcal disease is not highly contagious and is transmitted through direct contact with droplets from an ill person coughing or sneezing; other discharges from the nose or throat; or by sharing of eating and drinking utensils, smoking devices; or intimate contact.\n\n'Health officials encourage everyone to monitor their own health and note the following symptoms specific to this disease: high fever, a rash, headache, stiff neck, exhaustion, nausea or vomiting. If these symptoms develop, seek prompt medical evaluation.\n\n'The best way to prevent meningococcal disease is by vaccination.\n\n'OSU Student Health Services (SHS) and the Student Health Pharmacy continue to provide students meningococcal B vaccines in Plageman Hall, 108 SW Memorial Place. Many other health care providers in the community have the meningococcal B vaccine available on request.\n\n'Before seeking to be vaccinated, students (or their family members) are encouraged to contact their private insurance provider to verify insurance coverage for the vaccine. When speaking with an insurance representative, it is important to mention that OSU Corvallis campus has been designated an 'outbreak' status by federal, state, and county public health officials.\n\n'For those receiving vaccines, SHS will bill students' insurance plans, including the Oregon Health Plan. Vaccines for domestic and international students on OSU's 2 sponsored plans (Aetna Student Health or Pacific Source) will be fully covered.\n\n'Many private insurance plans cover the cost of the meningococcal B vaccine, and SHS is working to ensure as many insurance plans as possible cover the vaccine when given at OSU. SHS will assist international students and others who have plans that do not cover the vaccine if provided at OSU to receive a vaccine at an alternate location. Students 18 or younger without insurance can receive the vaccination through benefits provided by the Oregon Health Plan.\n\n'Regardless of your insurance status, it is essential that students immediately take the time to be vaccinated.\n\n'Oregon State requires incoming students under the age of 22 to have the quadrivalent meningococcal vaccine (MCV4), which covers multiple strains of the disease but not the B strain. Starting this fall [2017], the university also began requiring incoming students aged 25 and under to receive the meningococcal B vaccine series due to 3 confirmed cases on campus during the last academic year.\n\n'For questions about insurance coverage, please contact the SHS Billing Office at 541-737-8370. Please be sure to bring insurance information to SHS or the OSU pharmacy.\n\n'More information on meningococcal disease is available by calling the OSU Student Health Services Nurse Advice line at 541-737-2724 or Benton County Health Department communicable disease nurses at 541-766-6835 or by visiting these websites:\nhttp://studenthealth.oregonstate.edu/infectious-diseases/meningococcal-disease and http://healthoregon.org/mening.\n\n'Sincerely,\nDan Larson. Interim Vice Provost, Student Affairs'\n\n--\nHannah Carey, MPH\n<hcarey@bu.edu>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Hannah Carey for submitting the information above regarding meningococcus group B disease on the Oregon State University (OSU) in Corvallis, Oregon.\n\nIn November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319) and in March 2017, meningococcal serogroup B meningitis was reported in a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298).\n\nIn October 2017, we posted a report of a 4th OSU student on the Corvallis campus with IMD; although we were not told at that time what the serogroup of the pathogen was, it apparently was also serogroup B (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497). We are now told in the report above that a 5th OSU student has developed IMD due to serogroup B.\n\nThese cases occurred despite a campus-wide vaccination program with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y. The news report above does not give the vaccination status of the latest OSU student with IMD.\n\nOSU is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). OSU has a total student enrollment of 30 354. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nOregon State University, Oregon, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733]", "summary": "In November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319) and in March 2017, meningococcal serogroup B meningitis was reported in a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298). We are now told in the report above that a 5th OSU student has developed IMD due to serogroup B.\n\nThese cases occurred despite a campus-wide vaccination program with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y. The news report above does not give the vaccination status of the latest OSU student with IMD. \n\n'More information on meningococcal disease is available by calling the OSU Student Health Services Nurse Advice line at 541-737-2724 or Benton County Health Department communicable disease nurses at 541-766-6835 or by visiting these websites:\nhttp://studenthealth.oregonstate.edu/infectious-diseases/meningococcal-disease and http://healthoregon.org/mening. other discharges from the nose or throat; or by sharing of eating and drinking utensils, smoking devices; or intimate contact.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2017-10-26 00:00:00", "2015-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oregon", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5479621", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - USA (03): (NV)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5479621", "date": "2017-12-03 13:44:06", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA (03): (NEVADA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 29 Nov 2017\nSource: My News 4 [edited]\nhttp://mynews4.com/news/local/54-cases-now-tied-to-washoe-county-viral-meningitis-outbreak\n\n\nThe number of cases tied to Washoe County's viral meningitis outbreak rose to 54 as of last week, according to health officials.\n\nThe county's Health District announced via Facebook the new figure, saying 72 percent of the cases, or about 39, are children age 17 and under. The news brings the number of cases up from the previous report of 46 cases from earlier in November 2017.\n\nHealth officials say parents should go over prevention efforts with their kids, including encouraging washing hands, covering coughs and sneezes and disinfecting surfaces like doorknobs, handrails and desks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Meningitis refers to the inflammation of the meninges, the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord, and implies lack of specific brain and spinal cord involvement (called encephalitis and myelitis, respectively, although some involvement may be present). In viral meningitis, the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is usually visibly clear, but on laboratory examination, the CSF white cell count is 6 to 500 cells per cmm, usually with lymphocytes predominating. Usually, the CSF glucose level is normal (as compared to bacterial meningitis, where it is low), and the CSF protein level is mildly elevated (where in bacterial meningitis it is significantly elevated). As noted, the symptoms of viral meningitis usually last from 7 to 10 days, and the patient recovers completely.\n\nThe non-polio enteroviruses are the most common causes of viral meningitis, especially during the summer and fall months. Most people who get infected with enteroviruses are asymptomatic or have only a non-specific febrile illness. Enteroviruses are most often spread via the fecal-oral route from person to person, through fecal contamination of water or food, or contact with contaminated inanimate objects.\n\nThe ECHO viruses (enteric cytopathic human orphan) viruses are part of the enterovirus species in the picornavirus family. Type 30 has certainly been reported to cause outbreaks of viral meningitis. An example is Faustino A, Fano V, Muscillo M, et al: An outbreak of aseptic meningitis due to echovirus 30 associated with attending school and swimming in pools. Int J Infect Dis. 2006;10: 291-7; available at:\nhttp://www.ijidonline.com/article/S1201-9712(05)00203-1/pdf.\n\nNo available specific therapy for ECHO viruses has existed; however, pleconaril, a 1st-of-its-kind viral capsid-inhibitor compound -- an experimental agent with in vitro activity against most enteroviruses -- appears to have efficacy with a good safety profile. It does not appear that it has received FDA approval in the USA. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNevada, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/230]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Meningitis refers to the inflammation of the meninges, the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord, and implies lack of specific brain and spinal cord involvement (called encephalitis and myelitis, respectively, although some involvement may be present). VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA (03): (NEVADA)\n*************************************\n No available specific therapy for ECHO viruses has existed; however, pleconaril, a 1st-of-its-kind viral capsid-inhibitor compound -- an experimental agent with in vitro activity against most enteroviruses -- appears to have efficacy with a good safety profile. Usually, the CSF glucose level is normal (as compared to bacterial meningitis, where it is low), and the CSF protein level is mildly elevated (where in bacterial meningitis it is significantly elevated). In viral meningitis, the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is usually visibly clear, but on laboratory examination, the CSF white cell count is 6 to 500 cells per cmm, usually with lymphocytes predominating. \n\nThe non-polio enteroviruses are the most common causes of viral meningitis, especially during the summer and fall months. The number of cases tied to Washoe County's viral meningitis outbreak rose to 54 as of last week, according to health officials.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2017-11-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washoe County 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5456199", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (05): (WA) sg W, sg Y", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5456199", "date": "2017-11-21 05:17:07", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (05): (WESTERN AUSTRALIA) SEROGROUPS W AND Y\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Nov 2017\nSource: AAP-SBS Wires [edited]\nhttp://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/11/20/child-dies-after-contracting-meningococcal-wa\n\n\nA young child in Western Australia [WA] is dead after contracting a virulent strain of meningococcal disease and another is also infected. The 2 children, both aged under 3, had contracted the serogroup W infection and one had since died, the state's health department said on [Mon 20 Nov 2017]. An adult from interstate [the same state? - Mod.SH] was also infected with another strain of the bacteria.\n\n'There have now been 4 deaths from meningococcal disease in WA in 2017, all infected with the serogroup W type of the organism,' a health department statement said. So far this year there have been 38 cases of the potentially deadly disease, up from 23 in 2016. 'The numbers of serogroup W and Y cases are well above the long term average of less than one case per year of each of these types,' the department said.\n\nThe children and adult are the latest cases of the disease in WA but none of the individuals are linked.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Immunity following use of a meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide that the vaccine contains, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups.\n\nVaccines exist that contain capsular polysaccharide (A, C, Y, and W), either alone or conjugated to protein. Serogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen.\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population of a vaccine specific for one particular serogroup, the incidence of disease due to that serogroup has been found to fall dramatically. In Australia, following the introduction of the conjugate meningococcal C vaccine in 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 per cent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 per cent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 per cent in 2003 to 83 per cent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). See ProMED-mail posts Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568 and Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI 20160513.4220868.\n\nProMED-mail reported in 2016 that serogroup W, rather than B, has become predominant in Western Australia (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. W 20160925.4513543).\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroups W and B, meningococcal serogroup B and quadrivalent conjugate (ACWY) vaccines are now funded for certain age groups in some Australian states 'in response to locally predominant meningococcal B or W disease' (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf).\n\nThe quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The B vaccine is available through private prescription and in South Australia from April 2017, in a statewide 2-year clinical study for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf).\n\nWestern Australia, covering the entire western third of Australia, is mostly arid, its population being concentrated in the fertile south west corner and its capital, Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Australia). A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/289. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "In Australia, following the introduction of the conjugate meningococcal C vaccine in 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 per cent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 per cent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 per cent in 2003 to 83 per cent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). \n\n[Immunity following use of a meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide that the vaccine contains, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups. Because of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroups W and B, meningococcal serogroup B and quadrivalent conjugate (ACWY) vaccines are now funded for certain age groups in some Australian states 'in response to locally predominant meningococcal B or W disease' (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). \n\n'There have now been 4 deaths from meningococcal disease in WA in 2017, all infected with the serogroup W type of the organism,' a health department statement said. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org> The B vaccine is available through private prescription and in South Australia from April 2017, in a statewide 2-year clinical study for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). Following the mass introduction into the population of a vaccine specific for one particular serogroup, the incidence of disease due to that serogroup has been found to fall dramatically. \n\nProMED-mail reported in 2016 that serogroup W, rather than B, has become predominant in Western Australia (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, Serogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-04-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "South Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/289", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perth", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5491258", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (06): (VI) MSM, sg C, vaccine, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5491258", "date": "2017-12-08 11:04:46", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (06): (VICTORIA) MEN WHO HAVE SEX WITH MEN, SEROGROUP C, VACCINE, ALERT\n*************************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Dec 2017\nFrom: Finn Romanes <finn.romanes@dhhs.vic.gov.au> [edited]\n\n\nAn outbreak of invasive meningococcal disease (serogroup c) amongst men who have sex with men in Victoria, Australia\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------\nIntroduction\n------------\nThe Victoria Department of Health and Human Services is responding to an outbreak of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to a closely related strain of serogroup C affecting men who have sex with men (MSM) across Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. All gay and bisexual men and men who have sex with men in the state are being offered free quadrivalent ACWY vaccine against invasive meningococcal disease in order to respond to this outbreak.\n\nRisk assessment and descriptive epidemiology\n--------------------------------------------\nA confirmed outbreak case was defined as:\n- a confirmed case of IMD according to the national surveillance case definition (http://www.health.gov.au/casedefinitions); AND\n- where the isolate was typed by the Microbiological Diagnostic Unit Public Health Laboratory in Victoria as _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C; AND\n- who was notified in Victoria during 2017 or was notified in another jurisdiction but is normally resident in Victoria.\n\nA total of 8 confirmed serogroup C cases were identified, with 2 cases becoming ill in May 2017, and 1 each in July, August, September, and October. Onset in the most recent 2 cases occurred in the last week of November. Whole genome sequencing on isolates has demonstrated marked relatedness in all confirmed outbreak cases.\n\nAll cases were hospitalised, and presentations ranged from meningitis (2 cases), sepsis (2 cases), meningitis and sepsis (3 cases), and pneumonia (1 case). The age range of cases was 28 to 43 years, and all cases were male, with almost all reporting MSM sexual activity. Local transmission appears likely with no identified links between cases and only 1 case reported overseas travel in the ten days preceding illness onset. None of the cases are known to be HIV positive.\n\nThe Department has estimated that the attack rate in MSM is high in this outbreak at around 9.8 to 13.3 per 100 000 MSM population, compared to a baseline annual notification rate of IMD in the Victorian population of 1.4 per 100 000.\n\nIn Victoria between 2012-2016 inclusive there were 3 confirmed cases of IMD caused by serogroup C. In 2016 there were a total of 3 serogroup C cases notified across Australia.\n\nPublic health response including control measures\n-------------------------------------------------\nA Chief Health Officer Alert was issued on 7 Dec 2017 (https://www2.health.vic.gov.au/about/key-staff/chief-health-officer). This alert advised that gay and bisexual men and MSM who have not received a vaccine against meningococcal serogroup C in the previous 5 years are at increased risk in this outbreak. The Department is providing free 4vMenCV (Menactra) for all gay and bisexual men and MSM, from [Mon 11 Dec 2017 until 30 Jun 2018]. Health professionals were also reminded about other groups who are recommended for meningococcal vaccination under national guidelines (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home), which includes all children aged 12 months, travellers to sites of current overseas epidemics, and people with selected other specific medical conditions listed in that guidance.\n\nThe Department has also called on clinics to bulk-bill consultations when providing this vaccine, which means patients are not charged a consultation fee, as this may make the public health initiative more accessible for some patients recommended for vaccination.\n\nOn [30 Sep 2016] the Australian Government expanded an existing national immunisation register to become a whole of life immunisation register for all Australians, intending to capture all vaccines received across the life course. In the management of this outbreak, the Department is requesting all ACWY vaccinations provided to gay and bisexual men and other MSM to be recorded on this expanded Australian Immunisation Register (AIR), so that uptake can be estimated and the AIR can be as complete as possible.\n\nCommunication with health professionals and the public about the outbreak\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------\nHealth professionals and health services in Victoria receive urgent public health advice through subscribing by email to Chief Health Officer Alerts and Advisories on the Department's website (https://www2.health.vic.gov.au/about/key-staff/chief-health-officer).\n\nIn addition to recommending vaccination, the alert issued on [7 Dec 2017] advises health professionals to consider IMD in MSM who present with symptoms consistent with meningitis or septicaemia, and to notify the Department under the Public Health and Wellbeing Regulations 2009 without delay, and to provide immediate antibiotic treatment. Under those Regulations, suspected invasive meningococcal disease is a group A notifiable condition, meaning it must be called through immediately to the Department as the public health authority in the state of Victoria.\n\nFurther information has been made available, including frequently asked questions for MSM (https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/health/healthyliving/meningococcal-vaccine-for-men-who-have-sex-with-men) and for health professionals (https://www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/immunisation/adults/meningococcal-acwy-vaccine-gbm-msm). The Department's online resource library known as the Better Health Channel (https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/) also contains other information on meningitis and meningococcal disease, as well as accessible health information across a range of other topics.\n\nFurther background on invasive meningococcal disease\n----------------------------------------------------\nFrom 2002 to 2015 the predominant invasive meningococcal disease serogroup in Australia was serogroup B. However, in 2016, serogroup W became the predominant meningococcal serogroup in Australia with a total of 109 cases reported to the National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System (NNDSS).\n\nInfection with the causative bacteria _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C can cause syndromes including meningitis and sepsis that progress rapidly and can cause death in up to 10 per cent of cases, and permanent sequelae in up to 20 per cent of survivors. Quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccine (4vMenCV) provides effective prevention for up to five years. Meningococcal bacteria are difficult to spread and are probably only passed from person to person by close, prolonged contact.\n\n--\nDr Finn Romanes, MBBS, MPHTM, FFPH, FAFPHM\nPublic Health Physician\nDepartment of Health and Human Services,\nVictoria State Government\nAustralia\n<finn.romanes@dhhs.vic.gov.au>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Finn Romanes for submitting the alert above.\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of invasive meningococcal disease (meningitis and sepsis), is usually transmitted from person to person via droplets of respiratory secretions, mostly from asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers of the microorganism. However, recent data suggest that meningococci can adapt to a urethral location (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28373547) and can be transmitted by sexual activity.\n\nUrogenital infections due to _N. meningitidis_ have been reported sporadically in the past, but in 2015, a marked increase in the incidence of meningococcal urethritis was noted in heterosexual men at 2 US sexual health clinics, one in Columbus, Ohio, and another in Oakland County, Michigan, as well as in clinics in Atlanta and Indianapolis. Oral sex was reported by almost all patients (see ProMED-mail post Urethritis, meningococcal - USA: (OH,MI) heterosex. men, oral sex trans, non-gr. 20160604.4265651.) The urethral isolates were nongroupable (nonencapsulated), ST-11 clonal complex 11 (cc11), ET-15, and clustered together phylogenetically. Urethral Nm isolates were similar by fine typing (PorA P1.5-1,10-8, PorB 2-2, FetA F3-6) and the strains grow well anaerobically (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28373547, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28481980, and https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28098538).\n\nOutbreaks of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) have occurred in the past several years among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Germany, Belgium, and France caused by a hypervirulent _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C strain (http://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/rapid-risk-assessment-invasive-meningococcal-disease-among-MSM.pdf). Similar outbreaks among MSM caused by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C have also occurred in Canada and the US (see ProMED-mail posts listed below).\n\nMeningococci isolated in Germany and France from these MSM with IMD and from MSM with urethritis/proctitis were found to have the same genotype, (serogroup C, PorA type P1.5-1,10-8, FetA type F3-6, and cc11) (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20523 and http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21016). Genome sequencing analysis showed that isolates from MSM with IMD clustered with urethritis and proctitis isolates collected in the 2 countries, distinct from other cc11/ET-15 isolates.\n\nThe meningococcal isolates from both MSM with IMD and urethritis were able to grow anaerobically in the presence of nitrite, as do gonococci, unlike non-MSM/urethritis meningococcal isolates. Anaerobic growth was thought to allow meningococci to survive under anaerobic and acidic pH in the urethra or rectum, leading to the clinical manifestation of urethritis/proctitis as well as the capacity for direct sexual transmission.\n\nHowever, invasive isolates from MSM, but not urethritis isolates, expressed a protein that binds human factor H, a complement regulatory protein, which favors survival in the bloodstream.\n\nThese studies suggested that in the outbreak of IMD in MSM, meningococci were transmitted sexually and that reverted to a phenotype with enhanced bacterial survival in the blood, which facilitated meningococcemia and systemic dissemination.\n\nSimilar to the meningococcal vaccine program in Victoria. Australia, vaccination campaigns with a meningococcal conjugate vaccine directed against serogroup C that target MSM have been carried out in Europe and the US to control outbreaks of IMD in MSM (CDC. Control and prevention of serogroup C meningococcal disease: evaluation and management of suspected outbreaks: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). MMWR Recomm Rep. 1997; 46(RR-5): 13-21; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm).\n\nMaps of Australia: http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288. Victoria, in southeastern Australia, is the country's 2nd-most populous state. Most of its population of over 5.7 million is concentrated in the area surrounding Port Phillip Bay, which includes the metropolitan area of its capital and largest city, Melbourne, Australia's 2nd-largest city http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_(Australia). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A confirmed outbreak case was defined as:\n- a confirmed case of IMD according to the national surveillance case definition (http://www.health.gov.au/casedefinitions); AND\n- where the isolate was typed by the Microbiological Diagnostic Unit Public Health Laboratory in Victoria as _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C; AND\n- who was notified in Victoria during 2017 or was notified in another jurisdiction but is normally resident in Victoria. From 2002 to 2015 the predominant invasive meningococcal disease serogroup in Australia was serogroup B. However, in 2016, serogroup W became the predominant meningococcal serogroup in Australia with a total of 109 cases reported to the National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System (NNDSS). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \nThe Victoria Department of Health and Human Services is responding to an outbreak of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to a closely related strain of serogroup C affecting men who have sex with men (MSM) across Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. In addition to recommending vaccination, the alert issued on [7 Dec 2017] advises health professionals to consider IMD in MSM who present with symptoms consistent with meningitis or septicaemia, and to notify the Department under the Public Health and Wellbeing Regulations 2009 without delay, and to provide immediate antibiotic treatment.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-12-26 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-10-26 00:00:00", "2017-12-07 00:00:00", "2017-05-26 00:00:00", "2021-09-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-07-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-02-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-06-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-08-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indianapolis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "st-11", "country": "Jamaica"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Melbourne", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Oakland County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Columbus", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5450880", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (05): (MA) college, sg. B", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5450880", "date": "2017-11-17 18:33:53", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (05): (MASSACHUSETTS) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Nov 2017\nSource: New England Public Radio [edited]\nhttp://nepr.net/post/100-students-get-meningococcal-vaccine-umass-amherst#stream/0\n\n\nA total of 2 University of Massachusetts Amherst students hospitalized to treat a potentially deadly meningococcal disease have a strain of the illness for which students are generally not vaccinated.\n\n'We have received confirmation that the diagnosis for the 2nd student is serogroup B. This is a confirmation that UHS [University Health Service] had anticipated,' University Health Services Executive Director George Corey said in an email to campus on [Wed 15 Nov 2017]. 'UHS continues to work in consultation with federal and state public health officials.'\n\nThe 1st UMass student to become ill with the disease was diagnosed [Tue Oct 24 2017] and was initially in critical condition. That student was diagnosed with the serogroup B strain. Three weeks later, the university announced on [Tue 14 Nov 2017] a 2nd person was ill, though it was unclear if student was also suffering from the serogroup B strain.\n\n'As a precaution, students may want to receive the serogroup B vaccine. The vaccine is available at UHS by appointment,' Corey wrote in his email. 'Please call 413-577-5101 between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. to schedule an appointment. Costs for vaccination are billed to your insurance company. Please bring your insurance card to your appointment.'\n\nBy [Wed 15 Nov 2017] afternoon, some 100 students had visited University Health Services to receive the 1st dose of a vaccine to protect against serogroup B. The meningitis vaccine required to attend the university only covers strains A, C, Y and W.\n\nThe university raised its level of concern because the infected students were not in close contact. Both are hospitalized in stable condition.\n\n'UHS continues to encourage students to consider making an appointment with their family health care provider if they are going home for Thanksgiving break to receive the [serogroup B] vaccine [serogroup B],' UMass spokesperson Mary Dettloff said in an email [Tue 14 Nov 2017]. 'The [serogroup B] vaccine is a 2-shot vaccination and requires that students return for the 2nd vaccine in 30 days.'\n\nMore than 21 000 undergraduates attend UMass Amherst and 77 percent of them live in the state, according to the university's website. Many students will head home over the weekend as residence halls close for a week-long Thanksgiving break.\n\nUMass officials did not say [Tue 14 Nov 2017] night whether they consider the situation an outbreak or anticipate additional cases. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says an outbreak occurs when multiple cases of the same strain happen in a short time period.\n\n'Depending on the population size and specific circumstances, health officials may declare an outbreak after just 2 cases,' the centers say. Outbreak control measures include vaccinating people at increased risk of contracting the disease and giving preventative antibiotics to those who were in close quarters with an infected person. The university has taken both precautions. Dettloff said the university has enough vaccines available to meet 'ongoing demand.' The serogroup B vaccine is relatively new. It was licensed by the Food and Drug Administration in late 2014. The vaccine does not take effect immediately.\n\nThe university told students to avoid coming into contact with saliva -- which is how the bacteria spread -- by not sharing food or drinks and washing hands frequently.\n\n[Byline: Stephanie Murray]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Please see my moderator comments in the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (04): (MA) college, sg. B 20171116.5448419 for a discussion of this outbreak of meningococcal meningitis serogroup B at the University of Massachusetts Amherst campus. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21151.]", "summary": "By [Wed 15 Nov 2017] afternoon, some 100 students had visited University Health Services to receive the 1st dose of a vaccine to protect against serogroup B. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (05): (MASSACHUSETTS) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n**************************************************************************\n \n\nThe 1st UMass student to become ill with the disease was diagnosed [Tue Oct 24 2017] and was initially in critical condition. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Please see my moderator comments in the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (04): (MA) college, sg. \n\nMore than 21 000 undergraduates attend UMass Amherst and 77 percent of them live in the state, according to the university's website.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "5439630", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Ghana (02): fatal, susp pneumococcal, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5439630", "date": "2017-11-12 17:56:12", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - GHANA (02): FATAL, SUSPECTED PNEUMOCOCCAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Nov 2017\nSource: Ghana Web [edited]\nhttps://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/health/Pneumococcal-Meningitis-killing-humans-Ghana-599363\n\n\nDreadful, life-threatening, and infectious pneumococcal meningitis has hit Ghana, taking 93 lives so far since last year [2016].\n\nPneumococcal meningitis is caused by _Streptococcus pneumoniae_, a bacterium that affects the lungs and is easily spread through coughing, sneezing, and prolonged body contact with an infected person. Living in a crowded setting, intimate kissing, and eating from the same bowl or drinking from the same cup as an infected person can equally help spread the disease-causing bacteria.\n\nBabies and children, mostly under 18 months of age, in most cases stand a higher risk of acquiring the disease in the early stages of their lives.\n\nThe disease has an incubation period of about 2-10 days before producing symptoms, which include neck pain, neck stiffness, convulsion, and vomiting.\n\nSeasonal reports on pneumococcal meningitis in Ghana usually come during the dry season from October to March, with the worst affected regions being the Ashanti, Central, Brong Ahafo and Northern region due to relatively low humidity and abundance of dust.\n\nA thorough autopsy revealed that 4 students of Kumasi Academy Senior High in the Ashanti region died this year [2017] of the disease.\n\nMarylin Amediwa, a nursing student at Pentecost University, when interviewed about the worrying disease, said that pneumococcal meningitis causes the same symptoms as malaria and fever, sounding a word of caution to Ghanaians to refrain from self-medication. [Although both meningitis and malaria present with malaise, shaking chills, and fever, meningitis, unlike malaria, presents additionally with neck stiffness and pain].\n\nAn infected person stands a chance of receiving early treatment with prescribed antibiotics should the victim consult the hospital on time when symptom show themselves.\n\n[Byline: Esther Agyei Ayimwa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Ghana can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Ghana.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50377.\n\nProMED-mail last posted on a pneumococcal meningitis outbreak in Ghana in January 2016, when the number of cases had risen to 55 and the number of deaths to 'slightly over 19.'\n\nUse of a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine would be beneficial. Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines reduce nasopharyngeal carriage of serotypes of _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ contained in the vaccine and thus person-to-person transmission of these pathogens, which occurs by close contact with respiratory secretions or saliva.\n\nIn neighboring Burkina Faso, a study found that the 7-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, which includes serotypes 4, 6B, 9V, 14, 18C, 19F, and 23F, was protective against only 8 per cent of the local isolates (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.full). The 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, Prevnar 13, which covers serotypes 1, 3, 4, 5, 6A, 6B, 7F, 9V, 14, 18C, 19A, 19F, and 23F, may be more effective, but we are not told the serotypes of pneumococci causing this outbreak in Ghana.\n\nThe 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine is included in the recommended routine infant immunization schedule in the U.S. (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/hcp/imz/child-adolescent.html), but not in Ghana (http://collections.infocollections.org/whocountry/en/d/Js6861e/6.1.html#Js6861e.6.1).\n\nInformation from knowledgeable sources regarding the serotypes of _S. pneumoniae_ involved in this outbreak in Ghana would be welcomed. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMarylin Amediwa, a nursing student at Pentecost University, when interviewed about the worrying disease, said that pneumococcal meningitis causes the same symptoms as malaria and fever, sounding a word of caution to Ghanaians to refrain from self-medication. \n\nPneumococcal meningitis is caused by _Streptococcus pneumoniae_, a bacterium that affects the lungs and is easily spread through coughing, sneezing, and prolonged body contact with an infected person. \n\nProMED-mail last posted on a pneumococcal meningitis outbreak in Ghana in January 2016, when the number of cases had risen to 55 and the number of deaths to 'slightly over 19.' The 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, Prevnar 13, which covers serotypes 1, 3, 4, 5, 6A, 6B, 7F, 9V, 14, 18C, 19A, 19F, and 23F, may be more effective, but we are not told the serotypes of pneumococci causing this outbreak in Ghana. Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines reduce nasopharyngeal carriage of serotypes of _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ contained in the vaccine and thus person-to-person transmission of these pathogens, which occurs by close contact with respiratory secretions or saliva. \n\nThe 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine is included in the recommended routine infant immunization schedule in the U.S. (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/hcp/imz/child-adolescent.html), but not in Ghana (http://collections.infocollections.org/whocountry/en/d/Js6861e/6.1.html#Js6861e.6.1). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Ghana can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Ghana.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50377.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["malaria"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 19:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2016-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "7f", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5425383", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (03): (OR) college, sg. B", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5425383", "date": "2017-11-05 11:21:35", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (03): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 4 Nov 2017\nFrom: Hannah Carey <hannah.carey@valleyaidsinfo.org> [edited]\n\n\nA student at Oregon State University [OSU] was recently diagnosed with meningococcal B [disease]. I have forwarded an e-mail sent out to the student body regarding the infection for your records [appended below]:\n\n'From: All Corvallis Student List <osu-students-corvallis@lists.oregonstate.edu>\nDate: Thu, Nov 2, 2017 at 2:30 PM\nSubject: [Osu-students-corvallis] Meningococcal disease results confirmed; vaccines clinics in November\nTo: 'osu-students-corvallis@lists.oregonstate.edu' <osu-students-corvallis@lists.oregonstate.edu>\n\nOSU Corvallis students,\n\nYou may be aware that an undergraduate student attending Oregon State University in Corvallis is being treated for meningococcal disease. We are writing to inform you that lab testing indicates that this infection is the B strain of meningococcal disease - the same type that infected three students on the Corvallis campus during the last academic year. At present, there is only one reported case this academic year.\n\nPlease be aware that meningococcal disease is uncommon, but it is a serious disease. Those at highest risk include students age 25 and younger who live in residence halls and in private cooperative group living units, or are members of - or visit - fraternal living groups associated with the university.\n\nMeningococcal disease is not highly contagious and is transmitted through direct contact with droplets from an ill person coughing or sneezing; other discharges from the nose or throat; or by sharing of eating and drinking utensils, smoking devices; or intimate contact.\n\nHealth officials encourage everyone to monitor their own health and note the following symptoms specific to this disease: high fever, a rash, headache, stiff neck, exhaustion, nausea or vomiting. If these symptoms develop, seek prompt medical evaluation.\n\nThe best way to prevent meningococcal disease is by vaccination. To promote good public health, the university will have two immunization clinics for students this month for meningitis as well as other vaccines:\n\nMeningococcal B Immunization Clinic\n\nWednesday, Nov. 8\n\nMU Multi-Purpose Room 13\n\n9 a.m. to 3 p.m.\n\nImmunizations Offered: Meningococcal (MCV4) and Meningococcal B\n\nImmunization Clinic\n\nTuesday, Nov. 21\n\nMU Journey Room 104\n\n9 a.m. to 3 p.m.\n\nImmunizations Offered: Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR), Varicella (Chickenpox), Hepatitis, Tetanus Diphtheria Pertussis (Tdap), Meningococcal (MCV4) and Meningococcal B.\n\nAdditionally, OSU Student Health Services (SHS) and the Student Health Pharmacy continue to provide students meningococcal B vaccines in Plageman Hall, 108 S.W. Memorial Place. Many other health care providers in the community have the meningococcal B vaccine available on request.\n\nSHS staff will be available to at the clinics to answer questions about individual vaccine needs as well as insurance coverage.\n\nImportant Insurance Information\n\nBefore attending the vaccination clinics, students (or their family members) are encouraged to contact their private insurance provider to verify insurance coverage for the vaccine. When speaking with an insurance representative, it is important to mention that OSU Corvallis campus has been designated an 'outbreak' status by federal, state and county public health officials.\n\nFor those receiving vaccines, SHS will bill students' insurance plans, including the Oregon Health Plan. Vaccines for domestic and international students on OSU's two sponsored plans (Aetna Student Health or Pacific Source) will be fully covered.\n\nMany private insurance plans cover the cost of the Meningococcal B vaccine, and SHS is working to ensure as many insurance plans as possible cover the vaccine when given at OSU. SHS will assist international students and others who have plans that do not cover the vaccine if provided at OSU to receive a vaccine at an alternate location. Students 18 or younger without insurance can receive the vaccination through benefits provided by the Oregon Health Plan.\n\nRegardless of your insurance status, it is important that students take the time to be vaccinated.\n\nOregon State requires incoming students under the age of 22 to have the quadrivalent meningococcal vaccine (MCV4), which covers multiple strains of the disease but not the B strain. Starting this fall, the university also began requiring incoming students age 25 and under to receive the meningococcal B vaccine series due to 3 confirmed cases on campus during the last academic year.\n\nFor questions about insurance coverage, please contact the SHS Billing Office at 541-737-8370. SHS staff will be at the vaccine clinics to assist with insurance questions as well. Please be sure to bring insurance information to the clinic.\n\nMore information on meningococcal disease is available by calling the OSU Student Health Services Nurse Advice line at 541-737-2724 or Benton County Health Department communicable disease nurses at 541-766-6835 or by visiting these websites:\nhttp://studenthealth.oregonstate.edu/infectious-diseases/meningococcal-disease\nhttp://healthoregon.org/mening.\n\nSincerely,\nDan Larson\nInterim Vice Provost\nStudent Affairs'\n\n--\nHannah Carey, MPH\n<hannah.carey@valleyaidsinfo.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Hannah Carey for submitting the above information regarding meningococcus group B disease on the Oregon State University Corvallis campus. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/239.]", "summary": "To promote good public health, the university will have two immunization clinics for students this month for meningitis as well as other vaccines:\n\nMeningococcal B Immunization Clinic\n\nWednesday, Nov. 8\n\nMU Multi-Purpose Room 13\n\n9 a.m. to 3 p.m.\n\nImmunizations Offered: Meningococcal (MCV4) and Meningococcal B\n\nImmunization Clinic\n\nTuesday, Nov. 21\n\nMU Journey Room 104\n\n9 a.m. to 3 p.m.\n\nImmunizations Offered: Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR), Varicella (Chickenpox), Hepatitis, Tetanus Diphtheria Pertussis (Tdap), Meningococcal (MCV4) and Meningococcal B.\n\n Sincerely,\nDan Larson\nInterim Vice Provost\nStudent Affairs'\n\n--\nHannah Carey, MPH\n<hannah.carey@valleyaidsinfo.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Hannah Carey for submitting the above information regarding meningococcus group B disease on the Oregon State University Corvallis campus. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMany private insurance plans cover the cost of the Meningococcal B vaccine, and SHS is working to ensure as many insurance plans as possible cover the vaccine when given at OSU. \n\nOregon State requires incoming students under the age of 22 to have the quadrivalent meningococcal vaccine (MCV4), which covers multiple strains of the disease but not the B strain.
