I have forwarded an e-mail sent out to the student body regarding the infection for your records [appended below]:\n\n'From: All Corvallis Student List <osu-students-corvallis@lists.oregonstate.edu>\n \n\nPlease be aware that meningococcal disease is uncommon, but it is a serious disease.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-11-21 00:00:00", "2017-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-11-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "OREGON", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5448419", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (04): (MA) college, sg. B", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5448419", "date": "2017-11-16 17:23:19", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (04): (MASSACHUSETTS) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 15 Nov 2017\nSource: Boston Globe [edited]\nhttps://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/11/14/umass-amherst-student-diagnosed-with-meningitis/OaJh05XsPlK3OqyVyCNPML/story.html\n\n\nUniversity of Massachusetts Amherst officials say a student on campus has been diagnosed with meningitis weeks after another student fell ill with a related illness and are suggesting students consider an additional vaccination as a precaution.\n\nA student was diagnosed with a meningococcal illness last month [October 2017] that was later determined to be a strain of the disease not covered by the vaccine students must have to attend the school. The 2nd student, who lives in a residence hall, was diagnosed on [Sun 12 Nov 2017] with bacterial meningitis.\n\n'It is not known yet whether the 1st case led to the 2nd case,' University Health Services [UHS] Executive Director George Corey said at a press conference [Tue 14 Nov 2017] afternoon. UMass Amherst is the state's largest public university and more than 3-quarters of its 21 000 undergraduate students are from the state.\n\nMeningococcal disease can lead to meningitis -- a potentially deadly infection of the lining of the brain and spinal cord -- and infections of the blood, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Even when treated, meningococcal disease kills 10 to 15 percent of infected people, the center says. As many as 10 to 20 percent of survivors suffer disabilities like hearing loss, brain damage, kidney failure and amputations. 'Meningococcal disease often occurs without warning - even among people who are otherwise healthy,' the center says.\n\nThe university said it is reaching out to those close to the student diagnosed this weekend, who is in stable condition at an area hospital. The student diagnosed [24 Oct 2017] is also in stable condition, the university said.\n\n'Because these 2 students were not in close contact with each other, these 2 cases raise our level of concern,' Corey said in a statement. 'UHS is working in consultation with federal and state public health officials, and will be updating advice as more information becomes available.'\n\nThe student diagnosed [24 Oct 2017] has a serogroup B infection, a strain not covered by the meningitis vaccine required for college attendance. That vaccine covers strains A, C, Y and W, the university said. The serogroup B vaccine is available on campus.\n\nMeningococcal disease spreads via close contact like coughing or kissing or lengthy contact among people living in the same household. The university advised students not to 'swap saliva' and to avoid sharing food and drinks, cover their mouths when coughing or sneezing and wash hands regularly.\n\n'As with all vaccines, protection is not immediate and should be thought of as a wise precaution for this winter and for several years to come,' Corey said in a statement.\n\n[Byline: Stephanie Murray]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAnn Yao Zhang\nUniversity of Rochester\nRochester, New York, USA\n<azhang27@u.rochester.edu>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Ann Yao Zhang for submitting the above information regarding meningococcus group B disease on the University of Massachusetts Amherst with 2 primary cases of meningococcus disease within 1 month. The 1st case was caused by serogroup B; the 2nd case's serogroup is still pending.\n\nA primary case is a case that occurs in the absence of previous known close contact with another case-patient.\n\nAn outbreak is defined by the occurrence of at least 3 confirmed or probable primary cases of the same serogroup meningococcal disease during a period of 3 months or less, with a resulting primary attack rate of 10 or more cases per 100 000 population. If both cases are caused by serogroup B, 2 primary cases in 21 000 UMass Amherst undergraduates gives a primary attack rate of 9.5 / 100 000.\n\nIn some instances the attack rate will be greater than 10 cases per 100 000 population with only 2 or 3 cases. According to the CDC, 'in these situations, vaccination may be considered after only 2 primary cases are identified. Examples of an organization-based outbreak include cases in schools, churches, and universities' (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/surv-manual/chpt08-mening.html).\n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal disease are usually caused by the same or closely related strains. Molecular genotyping will help characterize an outbreak clone. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/224.]", "summary": "\n\nAn outbreak is defined by the occurrence of at least 3 confirmed or probable primary cases of the same serogroup meningococcal disease during a period of 3 months or less, with a resulting primary attack rate of 10 or more cases per 100 000 population. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n If both cases are caused by serogroup B, 2 primary cases in 21 000 UMass Amherst undergraduates gives a primary attack rate of 9.5 / 100 000. \n\n'Because these 2 students were not in close contact with each other, these 2 cases raise our level of concern,' Corey said in a statement. ' \n\nMeningococcal disease can lead to meningitis -- a potentially deadly infection of the lining of the brain and spinal cord -- and infections of the blood, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. \n\nThe student diagnosed [24 Oct 2017] has a serogroup B infection, a strain not covered by the meningitis vaccine required for college attendance. \n\n'It is not known yet whether the 1st case led to the 2nd case,' University Health Services [UHS] Executive Director George Corey said at a press conference [Tue 14 Nov 2017] afternoon. \n\nA primary case is a case that occurs in the absence of previous known close contact with another case-patient. Ann Yao Zhang for submitting the above information regarding meningococcus group B disease on the University of Massachusetts Amherst with 2 primary cases of meningococcus disease within 1 month. \n\nMeningococcal disease spreads via close contact like coughing or kissing or lengthy contact among people living in the same household. A student was diagnosed with a meningococcal illness last month [October 2017] that was later determined to be a strain of the disease not covered by the vaccine students must have to attend the school. \n\nThe university said it is reaching out to those close to the student diagnosed this weekend, who is in stable condition at an area hospital.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-10-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5421941", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (04): (VI) vaccine, adolescents", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5421941", "date": "2017-11-03 12:01:43", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (04): (VICTORIA) VACCINE, ADOLESCENTS\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 1 Nov 2017 8:00 pm AEDT\nSource: Sunraysia Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.sunraysiadaily.com.au/story/5028793/vaccine-warning/\nVaccine warning\n\n\nFigures from the Department of Health and Human Services reveal that of the 24 cases of meningococcal disease diagnosed so far this year [2017] in regional Victoria, 2 were diagnosed in Greater Bendigo and one in the Swan Hill council area.\n\nThe Victorian Government is urging teenagers 15 to 19 to get the free meningococcal vaccine, available until [31 Dec 2017].\n\nOne in 5 people in this age bracket carry the bacteria, which can be passed on by close contact such as kissing, coughing or sneezing. In 10 percent of cases meningococcal disease proves to be fatal.\n\n[Byline: Ashlee Falvo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Sunraysia is an ill-defined district, located in northwestern Victoria and southwestern New South Wales in Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia). It can be can be found on the map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia#/media/File:Outline_map_of_the_Mallee_and_Sunraysia_regions.png. Greater Bendigo and Swan Hill are cities within the Loddon Mallee region that occupies more than a quarter of Victoria, known for its restaurants and wineries (http://www.rdv.vic.gov.au/victorian-regions/loddon-mallee).\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population in 2003 of serogroup C conjugated meningococcal vaccine, the incidence of disease due to serogroup C fell dramatically. Since 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 percent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 percent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 percent in 2003 to 83 percent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). Also see ProMED-mail posts: Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568 and Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI 20160513.4220868. ProMED-mail reported in 2016 that serogroup W, rather than B has become predominant in Western Australia (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. W 20160925.4513543).\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroups W and B, meningococcal serogroup B and quadrivalent conjugate (ACWY) vaccines are now funded for certain age groups in some Australian states 'in response to locally predominant meningococcal B or W disease' (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf).\n\nThe quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The B vaccine is available through private prescription and in South Australia from April 2017, in a statewide 2-year clinical study for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288.]", "summary": "Since 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 percent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 percent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 percent in 2003 to 83 percent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Because of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroups W and B, meningococcal serogroup B and quadrivalent conjugate (ACWY) vaccines are now funded for certain age groups in some Australian states 'in response to locally predominant meningococcal B or W disease' (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). \nVaccine warning\n\n\nFigures from the Department of Health and Human Services reveal that of the 24 cases of meningococcal disease diagnosed so far this year [2017] in regional Victoria, 2 were diagnosed in Greater Bendigo and one in the Swan Hill council area. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Sunraysia is an ill-defined district, located in northwestern Victoria and southwestern New South Wales in Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia). The B vaccine is available through private prescription and in South Australia from April 2017, in a statewide 2-year clinical study for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). Test results showing which strain of the disease is involved are expected to be available next week.\n\nBill Emminger, director of the county's Environmental Health Division, said in a news release that it seems likely that all close contacts of the unidentified student have been identified and given preventive antibiotics, but anyone experiencing high fever, headache, stiff neck, or other symptoms of meningitis should seek medical attention.\n\n3 OSU students were infected with strain [serogroup] B of the meningococcal virus last winter [2016-17], prompting health officials to declare an outbreak. All of the infected students were hospitalized for treatment and recovered from the disease, and dozens of people who were in close contact with them received antibiotics.\n\nThe university also scheduled large-scale vaccination clinics in an effort to ensure that potentially susceptible populations were immunized against strain B.\n\nA 2015 outbreak at the University of Oregon sickened 7 people and left 1 student dead.\n\n[Byline: Bennett Hall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Between 13 Jan 2015 and 19 Mar 2015, the University of Oregon campus in Eugene, Oregon had 6 cases of serogroup B invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) in students; a 7th case occurred in a student's father who visited the campus between 2 and 3 May 2015 (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946).\n\nIn November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University [OSU] students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with IMD due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319) and in Mar 2017, meningococcal serogroup B meningitis was reported in a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298).\n\nThe news report above tells of another OSU student on the Corvallis campus with IMD; we are not told in the report if the IMD is meningococcal meningitis or meningococcemia, or what the serogroup of the pathogen is. This case has occurred despite a campus-wide vaccination program with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A,C,W and Y. The news report above does not give the vaccination status of the latest OSU student with IMD.\n\nOSU is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). OSU has a total student enrollment of 30 354, the largest among all Oregon universities. The death occurred at the Pope John XXIII hospital in Bergamo, the province where the child was on vacation with grandparents for the Ognissanti Bridge. The parents who were accompanying children to school learned the dramatic news [Fri 3 Nov 2017] morning thanks to WhatsApp messages and chats. Panic was triggered: many moms brought the children home immediately. Other parents have stopped teachers and the headmaster to try to figure out how to behave.\n\nAfter a meeting with Mayor Barbara Agogliati and the school leader Danilo Guido, the leaders of the Health Protection Agency (ATS) decided to immediately start antibiotic prophylaxis for 75 people. First of all family members, including 10-year-old sister, classmates and street cartoon teachers who had direct contact with the girl in the 10 days prior to her death. Then the girls and instructors of the art gymnasium frequented by the little one in Rozzano, in addition to doctors of the nosocomio bergamasco and the staff of Areu who intervened on [Thu 2 Nov 2017] night.\n\nProtect yourself from meningitis with the vaccine: the guidance of the Higher Health Institute\n\nIn order to understand which strain of meningitis, however, it is necessary to wait for the results of the bacteriological examinations on samples that have been sent to the Policlinico di Milano. 'We have warned those who may have been in direct contact with the child in the past 10 days compared to today. The ATS physician met the parents of the school pupils, providing all the details of the case and explaining that prophylaxis is only for those who have come into contact with the child. 'I want to reassure parents that the school is open and there is no risk to children's health,' explained Mayor Agogliati.\n\n[Byline: Olivia Manola]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRemigio Russo\n<remigiorusso@tin.it>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Remigio Russo for submitting the news report above.\n\nRozzano is a town in the Metropolitan City of Milan in the Italian region of Lombardy; Rozzano is located about 9 km (6 mi) south of Milan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rozzano). A map showing the location of the school the 6-year-old attended on Via Garofani in Rozzano can be found at https://www.google.co.uk/maps/place/Via+Garofani,+20089+Rozzano+MI,+Italy. Bergamo, where the child died, is a city in Lombardy, northern Italy, about 40 km (25 mi) northeast of Milan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bergamo).\n\nAlthough the news report does not mention the microbial etiology of the meningitis that killed the 6-year-old, it was likely _Neisseria meningitidis_, for which antibiotic chemoprophylaxis is given to close contacts.\n\nIn Italy, as of January 2017, meningococcus serogroup B vaccine is to be given to children under one year of age and meningococcal serogroup C conjugate vaccine is to be given to children between 13-15 months of age; quadrivalent meningococcus serogroups ACWY conjugate vaccine is to be given to adolescents, age 12-14 (http://vaccine-schedule.ecdc.europa.eu/Pages/Scheduler.aspx). The meningococcus vaccine status of the 6-year-old who died is not mentioned in the news report above. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "In Italy, as of January 2017, meningococcus serogroup B vaccine is to be given to children under one year of age and meningococcal serogroup C conjugate vaccine is to be given to children between 13-15 months of age; quadrivalent meningococcus serogroups ACWY conjugate vaccine is to be given to adolescents, age 12-14 (http://vaccine-schedule.ecdc.europa.eu/Pages/Scheduler.aspx). In Susanville where the outbreak was initially traced to the high school football team and forced the temporary closure of the school as well as the Community College, public health officials say they've had 50 possible cases reported. Of those 22 are suspected and 18 are clinically diagnosed; 16 of which are lab confirmed. Another 10 have been ruled out. Here in Washoe County the count is now 36 cases.\n\nViral meningitis can be caused by a number of different viruses. In this case, there's initial evidence the outbreak is being caused by one particular enterovirus known as ECHO virus 30. 'We've got some evidence suggesting eco30 here,' says Washoe County Epidemiologist Dr. Randall Todd. 'They've got lab evidence suggesting ECHO 30 there. What we want to know is at the molecular level is this the same virus.' That would be a first step toward finding a common source for the outbreaks. 'It's more likely if they are the same molecularly there is a common source.'\n\nUnlike the Lassen County outbreak there appears to be no geographic hot spot here. No school, for instance, with a number of cases.\n\nLarge percentages however, are children. 'As many as 72 percent of the cases were in children,' says Dr. Todd. 'With 53 percent being children that are considered school age, between the ages of 5 and 17; and 67 percent of our cases were male.'\n\nThose numbers are fairly typical of an outbreak of viral meningitis, an inflammation of the tissues surrounding the brain and the spinal cord. Viral meningitis is less serious than bacterial meningitis. There's no treatment other than for symptoms which include a fever and headaches.\n\nThe advice for avoiding it remains the same. Don't share anything you're going to put in your mouth--a particular note of caution with Halloween and the other holidays coming up. Wash your hands often; keep common surfaces clean and; if you don't feel right see a doctor; don't spread it.\n\n[Byline: Ed Pearce]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would not be surprising if the agent or agents causing these clusters are the same. The areas are only about 100 miles [approx. 161 km] away as the crow flies.\n\nThe non-polio enteroviruses are the most common causes of viral meningitis, especially during the summer and fall months. Most people who get infected with enteroviruses are asymptomatic or have only a non-specific febrile illness. Enteroviruses are most often spread via the fecal-oral route from person to person, through fecal contamination of water or food, or contact with contaminated inanimate objects.\n\nThe ECHO viruses (enteric cytopathic human orphan) viruses are part of the enterovirus species in the picornavirus family. Type 30 has certainly been reported to cause outbreaks of viral meningitis. An example is Faustino A, Fano V, Muscillo M, et al: An outbreak of aseptic meningitis due to echovirus 30 associated with attending school and swimming in pools. Int J Infect Dis. 2006;10: 291-7; available at:\nhttp://www.ijidonline.com/article/S1201-9712(05)00203-1/pdf.\n\nNo available specific therapy for ECHO viruses has existed, however, pleconaril, a first-of-its-kind viral capsid-inhibitor compound -- an experimental agent with in vitro activity against most enteroviruses --, appears to have efficacy with a good safety profile. It does not appear that it has received FDA approval in the USA. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would not be surprising if the agent or agents causing these clusters are the same. No available specific therapy for ECHO viruses has existed, however, pleconaril, a first-of-its-kind viral capsid-inhibitor compound -- an experimental agent with in vitro activity against most enteroviruses --, appears to have efficacy with a good safety profile. \n\nThe non-polio enteroviruses are the most common causes of viral meningitis, especially during the summer and fall months. \n\nThose numbers are fairly typical of an outbreak of viral meningitis, an inflammation of the tissues surrounding the brain and the spinal cord. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nevada", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Washoe County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Lassen County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Susanville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NEVADA", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5376391", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5376391", "date": "2017-10-14 13:11:02", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (03): (NORTHERN TERRITORY) SEROGROUP W, ABORIGINAL CHILDREN\n*************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 10 Oct 2017\nSource: News.com.au [edited]\nhttp://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/nt-meningococcal-outbreak-worsens/news-story/64682d6f9c259f0fe5338d697663473d\n\n\nMore meningococcal diagnoses have been recorded amid an unprecedented outbreak in Central Australia that has so far affected mainly indigenous children.\n\nThere have been 25 confirmed cases of the W strain of the deadly disease so far this year [2017], with one awaiting final laboratory testing. There were only 3 cases last year, according to the NT [Northern Territory] Centre for Disease Control.\n\nAll of those affected are indigenous people from the Central Australian, Barkly and Katherine communities, while 19 cases are kids younger than 10 [years of age].\n\nNorthern Territory health authorities have mounted a large-scale immunisation campaign in the affected regions in an attempt to prevent it from spreading to the Top End. From this week, a free vaccine will be offered to all people aged between 12 months and 19 years living in remote communities, and all Aboriginal people aged between 12 months and 19 years living in Alice Springs, Tennant Creek and Katherine.\n\nThe NT government is also coordinating with other jurisdictions after a spate of cases was reported on South Australia's traditional APY lands. [Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara (APY) is a large Aboriginal local government area located in South Australia. It consists of the Pitjantjatjara, Yankunytjatjara and Ngaanyatjarra anangu (i.e. people), and has a population of around 2500 people (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anangu_Pitjantjatjara_Yankunytjatjara). A map of the Australian state of South Australia showing the location of the APY Local Government Area is available at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anangu_Pitjantjatjara_Yankunytjatjara#/media/File:APY_LGA.png. - Mod.ML]\n\n'This is a massive effort on the part of all the health services in the region and is focusing on those most at risk and those who are most likely to be carrying the germ in their nose or throat,' CDC acting director Charles Douglas said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Katherine, with an urban population of 6094 in 2011, is a town in the Northern Territory (NT), Australia, 320 km (200 miles) southeast of Darwin, the capital and largest city in the NT (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katherine,_Northern_Territory). The NT consists of 5 regions: Darwin, East Arnhem Land-Nhulunbuy, Katherine, Barkly, Central-Alice Springs (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_the_Northern_Territory). The Barkly region, with an estimated population of 8168 people, is located south of Katherine, and its main town is Tennant Creek, with a population of 3062 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennant_Creek). The city of Alice Springs, with a population of 27 972, located in the Central Australia-Alice Springs region, is nearly equidistant from the cities of Adelaide and Darwin. A map of the NT regions can be found at https://www.researchgate.net/figure/50251830_fig1_Figure-1-The-five-regions-of-the-Northern-Territory-highlighting-the-Alice-Springs.\n\nThe outbreak of meningococcal meningitis occurring in the NT is caused by serogroup W and is occurring mainly in Aboriginal children.\n\nProMED-mail previously reported in May 2016 (Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568) that an outbreak of meningococcal meningitis in the state of South Australia was due to serogroup B in 10 of the 11 cases. This previous news report did not say where in South Australia the cases occurred or whether the cases were mainly Aboriginal children. However, the news report above says that the current outbreak in South Australia is localized to the APY Local Government Area, a region where Aboriginals reside. So the current infected individuals in South Australia presumably are Aboriginals, but we are not told what serogroup is now causing their infections. Is it serogroup B, like the outbreak that occurred in South Australia in 2016, or serogroup W, like the current outbreak in the NT?\n\nA quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccine is available through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 Australian states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017 for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12; however, in the NT and South Australia, a quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccine can only be obtained through private prescription (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). Presumably because of the outbreak due to meningococcal serogroup W in the NT, the vaccine now being offered in the NT without private prescription is a quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccine that will protect against the current outbreak serogroup W strain. The B vaccine has been made available through a statewide 2-year clinical study in South Australia since April 2017 for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf).\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/292. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccine is available through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 Australian states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017 for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12; however, in the NT and South Australia, a quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccine can only be obtained through private prescription (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). Presumably because of the outbreak due to meningococcal serogroup W in the NT, the vaccine now being offered in the NT without private prescription is a quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccine that will protect against the current outbreak serogroup W strain. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n From this week, a free vaccine will be offered to all people aged between 12 months and 19 years living in remote communities, and all Aboriginal people aged between 12 months and 19 years living in Alice Springs, Tennant Creek and Katherine. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Katherine, with an urban population of 6094 in 2011, is a town in the Northern Territory (NT), Australia, 320 km (200 miles) southeast of Darwin, the capital and largest city in the NT (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katherine,_Northern_Territory). The B vaccine has been made available through a statewide 2-year clinical study in South Australia since April 2017 for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). \n\nThe outbreak of meningococcal meningitis occurring in the NT is caused by serogroup W and is occurring mainly in Aboriginal children. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (03): (NORTHERN TERRITORY) SEROGROUP W, ABORIGINAL CHILDREN\n*************************************************************************************************\n B 20160515.4222568) that an outbreak of meningococcal meningitis in the state of South Australia was due to serogroup B in 10 of the 11 cases. Is it serogroup B, like the outbreak that occurred in South Australia in 2016, or serogroup W, like the current outbreak in the NT? \n\nThere have been 25 confirmed cases of the W strain of the deadly disease so far this year [2017], with one awaiting final laboratory testing.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-04-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-05-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "8168-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Pitjantjatjara", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Tennant Creek", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Northern Territory", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "Alice Springs", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5345825", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5345825", "date": "2017-09-28 11:51:29", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (02): (NORTHERN TERRITORY) SEROGROUP W, ABORIGINAL CHILDREN\n*************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 26 Sep 2017 2:43 PM ACST\nSource: Katherine Times [edited]\nhttp://www.katherinetimes.com.au/story/4950048/outbreak-of-deadly-disease/\n\n\nThe Northern Territory [NT] has seen a rise in meningococcal infection with 17 cases so far this year [2017].\n\nMeningococcal disease is an uncommon, life-threatening illness due to a bacterial infection of the blood and/or the membranes that line the spinal cord and brain and occasionally infect other sites, such as large joints.\n\nMost of the meningococcal [serogroup] W infections in the NT have occurred in Aboriginal children living in Katherine, central Australia, and Barkly regions. Most of these cases are serogroup W, which has recently risen across Australia. 10 are definite serogroup W with 5 awaiting final laboratory testing but likely to be serogroup W.\n\nThere has been a rapid increase in meningococcal W disease in the month of September [2017] with 10 cases of confirmed or probable serogroup W reported.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Katherine, with an urban population of 6094 in 2011, is a town in Northern Territory, Australia, 320 km (200 mi) southeast of Darwin and 17 km (10.6 mi) northwest of Royal Australian Air Force Base (RAAF) Tindal, which has a residential population of 742. Katherine provides education, health, local government services and employment opportunities for the families of personnel stationed at RAAF Tindal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katherine,_Northern_Territory).\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population of a vaccine specific for one particular meningococcal serogroup, the incidence of disease due to that serogroup has been found to fall dramatically, such as, serogroup C disease in the UK following the introduction of C vaccine and serogroup A in the African meningitis belt following the introduction of A vaccine, only to be replaced by emergence of disease due to other meningococcal serogroups, such as serogroups B and W. A similar situation is apparently occurring in Australia; there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases after the introduction of conjugate meningococcal C vaccine to the National Immunisation Program (NIP) in 2003. Serogroup C disease has become very rare (1.2 percent of cases with identified serogroup in 2016) (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). See ProMED-mail posts Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568 and Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI 20160513.4220868.\n\nHowever, serogroup W disease has increased since 2013; this is now the main serogroup causing meningococcal disease (44.7 percent of cases with identified serogroup) in Australia in 2016 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The news report above says that most of the serogroup W infections in the NT have occurred in Aboriginal children living in Katherine.\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroup W in the UK, the UK is now offering an expanded conjugated serogroup vaccine, the quadrivalent Men ACWY, for adolescents, who are more likely to carry meningococcal bacteria than any other age group, to stop the spread of serogroup W. This is being done by replacing the routine teenage Men C booster with the Men ACWY vaccine (http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/vaccinations/Pages/men-acwy-vaccine.aspx).\n\n3 types of meningococcal vaccines are now available in Australia:\n- monovalent meningococcal C conjugate vaccine or meningococcal C conjugate combined with the _Haemophilus influenzae_ type b (Hib) vaccine;\n- meningococcal B vaccine;\n- quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines.\n\nRoutine meningococcal C conjugate vaccine at 12 months of age is recommended and funded under the NIP (National Immunisation Program). The meningococcal B vaccine and the quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription for this age group, but are not funded under the NIP.\n\nThe quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The B vaccine is available through private prescription and in South Australia from April 2017 in a statewide 2-year clinical study for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/292.]", "summary": "Following the mass introduction into the population of a vaccine specific for one particular meningococcal serogroup, the incidence of disease due to that serogroup has been found to fall dramatically, such as, serogroup C disease in the UK following the introduction of C vaccine and serogroup A in the African meningitis belt following the introduction of A vaccine, only to be replaced by emergence of disease due to other meningococcal serogroups, such as serogroups B and W. A similar situation is apparently occurring in Australia; there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases after the introduction of conjugate meningococcal C vaccine to the National Immunisation Program (NIP) in 2003. \n\n3 types of meningococcal vaccines are now available in Australia:\n- monovalent meningococcal C conjugate vaccine or meningococcal C conjugate combined with the _Haemophilus influenzae_ type b (Hib) vaccine;\n- meningococcal B vaccine;\n- quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines. Because of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroup W in the UK, the UK is now offering an expanded conjugated serogroup vaccine, the quadrivalent Men ACWY, for adolescents, who are more likely to carry meningococcal bacteria than any other age group, to stop the spread of serogroup However, serogroup W disease has increased since 2013; this is now the main serogroup causing meningococcal disease (44.7 percent of cases with identified serogroup) in Australia in 2016 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The meningococcal B vaccine and the quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription for this age group, but are not funded under the NIP. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (02): (NORTHERN TERRITORY) SEROGROUP W, ABORIGINAL CHILDREN\n*************************************************************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Katherine, with an urban population of 6094 in 2011, is a town in Northern Territory, Australia, 320 km (200 mi) southeast of Darwin and 17 km (10.6 mi) northwest of Royal Australian Air Force Base (RAAF) Tindal, which has a residential population of 742.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-04-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Katherine", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "South Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "Northern Territory", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5391253", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Japan: airplane exposure, boy scouts, 2015", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5391253", "date": "2017-10-19 18:03:13", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - JAPAN: AIRPLANE EXPOSURE, BOY SCOUTS, 2015\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Oct 2017, 6:33 AM ET\nSource: Live Science [edited]\nhttps://www.livescience.com/60685-woman-contracts-meningococcal-disease-on-flight.html\n\n\nIn a rare case, a woman contracted a potentially deadly bacterial infection while on a 12-hour flight from Japan to Germany, according to a new report.\n\nCalled meningococcal disease, this bacterial infection is generally transmitted only through close contact, for example, by kissing or living in close quarters with someone who is sick, according to the World Health Organization. The new report is only the 3rd case ever reported of this disease being transmitted on an airplane, said Yushi Hachisu, of the Chiba Prefectural Institute of Public Health in Chiba, Japan, who helped investigate the case. Hachisu presented the case on [5 Oct 2017] at IDWeek, an infectious disease conference in San Diego.\n\nMeningococcal disease is caused by the bacteria _Neisseria meningitidis_. About 10 percent of the population carries this bacterium in their nose and throat without showing any symptoms of disease. But the bacteria can cause serious illness if it gets into the blood or the brain. In the brain, the bacteria can cause meningitis -- a swelling of the membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord; in the blood, it can cause and infection called septicemia.\n\nThe woman and her husband, both in their 50s, were traveling from Japan to Germany on [8 Aug 2015], according to the report. They happened to be on the same flight as a team of Scottish and Swedish scouts who were returning from the World Scout Jamboree, an international gathering of scouts ages 14 to 17. A total of 6 of the scouts later developed meningococcal disease in an outbreak that was linked to attendance at the jamboree. [See ProMED-mail posts in the See Alsos. - Mod.ML]\n\nThe married couple did not sit directly next to the scouts, but sat in a row behind and across the aisle from the Scottish scouts. They noticed that one of the scouts seated in front of them was coughing throughout the flight, the report said. Once they arrived in Germany, the couple hopped on another flight to Spain, where they went sightseeing. But a few days later, on [11 Aug 2017], the woman felt tired and developed pain in her throat and a cough. Her husband also developed pain in his throat and a mild fever.\n\nThey felt sick for the rest of their trip, but felt somewhat better upon their return to Japan on [16 Aug 2015], the report said. However, on [19 Sept 2015], the woman developed a sudden high fever and chills, as well as pain in her joints. She visited four health care facilities and underwent tests before she was finally hospitalized on [25 Sept 2015]. The fluid in her joints tested positive for _N. meningitidis_ bacteria, which means she had a blood infection with _N. meningitidis_ that spread to her joints. Samples taken from the husband's nose and throat also tested positive for _N. meningitidis_, although he did not develop further symptoms. Both the woman and her husband were infected with the same strain of _N. meningitidis_ that caused the outbreak in the scouts, the report said. The woman was treated with antibiotics and recovered.\n\nMeningococcal disease is rare in Japan, with only about 3 cases per 10 million people, the researchers said.\n\nThe new report 'strongly suggests that _N. meningitidis_ was transmitted from the Scottish scouts to the Japanese couple during their international flight,' the researchers wrote in their report.\n\nStill, the overall risk of transmitting meningococcal disease on an airplane is low, Hachisu said. But it can happen -- in 2005, officials in Australia reported cases of 2 people who got sick with _N. meningitidis_ after traveling on a flight from Los Angeles to Sydney. Officials determined it was likely that one of the infected passengers spread the bacteria to the other passenger, or both of the infected individuals got the bacteria from another person on the flight that wasn't showing symptoms.\n\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that passengers who sit next to someone with _N. meningitidis_ on a flight that is more than 8 hours long receive preventive antibiotics. A longer flight increases the chance of transmission, Hachisu said.\n\n[Byline: Rachael Rettner]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 29 Jul 2015 through 8 Aug 2015, about 34 000 boy scouts and their leaders from 150 countries attended an international Jamboree in Yamaguchi, Japan. Invasive meningococcal disease subsequently developed in 3 scouts and one parent from Scotland and 2 scouts from Sweden after Jamboree ended. The index case was reported to have developed symptoms while returning to Scotland. The strains from all 6 cases were identical and belonged to serogroup W (Kanai M, Kamiya H, Smith-Palmer A, et al. Meningococcal disease outbreak related to the World Scout Jamboree in Japan, 2015. Western Pac Surveill Response J. 2017; 8(2): 25-30. Published online 2017 May 8. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28729922).\n\nThe Japanese woman and her husband, described in the news report above, were traveling by plane from Japan to Germany on 8 Aug 2015, and sat in a row behind and across the aisle from the Scottish scouts, one of whom, presumably the index case, was coughing throughout the flight. Three days later, they both began to feel ill with pain in the throat. About 6 weeks later, the woman developed a sudden high fever and chills, and was subsequently diagnosed with meningococcal septic arthritis. The incubation period for invasive meningococcal disease is 3 to 4 days, with a range of 2 to 10 days; however, this incubation period commonly pertains to meningitis or meningococcemia (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/mening.html).\n\nThe Japanese woman had primary meningococcal arthritis (i.e., arthritis without signs or symptoms suggestive of meningitis or meningococcaemia), which is rare occurring in as little as 1 percent of meningococcal infections (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3628474/). It is usually preceded by an upper respiratory infection in 50-55 percent of presentations, and patients may appear nontoxic, afebrile, and polyarthralgic. Her husband had pharyngitis from which meningococci were isolated.\n\nBoth the woman and her husband were said in the news report above to be infected with the same strain of _Neisseria meningitidis_ that caused the outbreak in the scouts. Presumably both wife and husband became infected with the outbreak strain by exposure to the index case on the 8 Aug 2015 airplane flight. However, we are not told if matching isolates was based on genotyping or just that all the isolates were serogroup W. Most likely genotyping was done.\n\nMeningococci are thought to spread from person to person by exposure to nasopharyngeal secretions, which can happen during close contact (coughing or kissing, living in the same household). Dispersion of large droplets of nasopharyngeal secretions occurs within 3 feet of a coughing patient, such as the few rows directly in front of or behind an ill airplane passenger.\n\nOther respiratory illnesses that have spread onboard air flights include influenza, tuberculosis and SARS (1-5). For active tuberculosis in a passenger, all passengers seated on an airplane in the same row and in the 2 rows in front of and behind the index case are considered contacts (http://www.who.int/tb/publications/2006/who_htm_tb_2006_363.pdf).\n\nIn addition to the proximity of passengers to the index case, risk to passengers and flight crew members also depends on the flight duration, the ability of a patient to generate an infectious spray of nasopharyngeal secretions, and the number of organisms per ml of respiratory excretion. However, aircraft ventilation systems are believed to be highly efficient at keeping the air free of pathogens, which it does by exchanging the air frequently in passenger cabins and passing the circulated air through high-efficiency particulate-arresting (HEPA) filters (http://www.who.int/tb/publications/2006/who_htm_tb_2006_363.pdf).\n\nThe U.S. CDC employs a passive surveillance system by which local health departments report suspected cases of air-travel-associated meningococcal disease. In 2001, the CDC reported that from February 1999 through May 2001, it received 21 reports of cases of air-travel-associated invasive meningococcal disease, an average of one report every 6 weeks (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm). Approximately half of these cases were reported to a CDC airport quarantine station, and the rest were reported to CDC headquarters. The mean time between the completion of the flight and the onset of illness was 1.9 days (range: 0--10 days). As many as 5 case-patients had onset of illness before arrival, but the others had onset of illness after the flight had landed and the exposed passengers had dispersed. The CDC noted at the time that no secondary cases among air travel contacts of persons with meningococcal disease had been reported to the CDC, perhaps because of difficulties in subsequently tracing exposed passengers.\n\nBecause the attack rate among close contacts of patients with meningococcal disease is an estimated 500--800 times greater than the general population, antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis is recommended for contacts that are exposed to the respiratory secretions of the index patient to prevent secondary cases of meningococcal disease. The assessment of risk to passengers and flight crew members should be based on the flight duration and seating proximity to the index case-patient. The CDC recommends that household members traveling with an index case-patient, persons traveling with an index case-patient who have had prolonged close contact (e.g., roommates), and, for flights more than 8 hours, including ground time, anyone having direct contact with a patient's oral secretions should also be identified and the need for antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis evaluated (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm).\n\nIn the CDC communication (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm), because of the absence of data at the time about increased risk to other passengers, the CDC limited their recommendations for chemoprophylaxis to those passengers seated in either seat next to an index case-patient. However, we now have data that risk extends to passengers in adjacent rows. Because the risk for illness in the close contacts is highest during the 1st few days after infection, chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible (ideally within 24 hours) after exposure to an index case-patient (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm). Chemoprophylaxis administered later than 14 days is probably of limited or no value.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Moser MR, Bender TR, Margolis HS, Noble GR, Kendal AP and Ritter DG. An outbreak of influenza aboard a commercial airliner. Am J Epidemiol 1979;110:1-6.\n\n2. Kenyon TA, Valway SE, Ihle WW, Onorato IM and Castro KG. Transmission of multidrug-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis during a long airplane flight. N Engl J Med 1996;334 (15):933-8, available at:\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199604113341501#t=articleTop\n\n3. Exposure of passengers and flight crew to Mycobacterium tuberculosis on commercial aircraft, 1992-1995. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 1995;44:137-140 [erratum, MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 1995;44:175.], available at:\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00036502.htm\n\n4. Olsen SJ, Chang H-L, Cheung TY-Y, et al. Transmission of the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome on Aircraft. N Engl J Med 2003; 349 (25):2416-22, available at:\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa031349#t=articleTop\n\n5. Wenzel RP. Airline travel and infection. N Engl J Med 1996;334:981-982, abstract available at:\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199604113341509\n- Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156.]", "summary": "\n\nBecause the attack rate among close contacts of patients with meningococcal disease is an estimated 500--800 times greater than the general population, antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis is recommended for contacts that are exposed to the respiratory secretions of the index patient to prevent secondary cases of meningococcal disease. The CDC recommends that household members traveling with an index case-patient, persons traveling with an index case-patient who have had prolonged close contact (e.g., roommates), and, for flights more than 8 hours, including ground time, anyone having direct contact with a patient's oral secretions should also be identified and the need for antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis evaluated (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm). In addition to the proximity of passengers to the index case, risk to passengers and flight crew members also depends on the flight duration, the ability of a patient to generate an infectious spray of nasopharyngeal secretions, and the number of organisms per ml of respiratory excretion. The Japanese woman and her husband, described in the news report above, were traveling by plane from Japan to Germany on 8 Aug 2015, and sat in a row behind and across the aisle from the Scottish scouts, one of whom, presumably the index case, was coughing throughout the flight. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 29 Jul 2015 through 8 Aug 2015, about 34 000 boy scouts and their leaders from 150 countries attended an international Jamboree in Yamaguchi, Japan. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe new report 'strongly suggests that _N. meningitidis_ was transmitted from the Scottish scouts to the Japanese couple during their international flight,' the researchers wrote in their report. \n\nBoth the woman and her husband were said in the news report above to be infected with the same strain of _Neisseria meningitidis_ that caused the outbreak in the scouts. The assessment of risk to passengers and flight crew members should be based on the flight duration and seating proximity to the index case-patient. \n\nCalled meningococcal disease, this bacterial infection is generally transmitted only through close contact, for example, by kissing or living in close quarters with someone who is sick, according to the World Health Organization. \n\nThe U.S. CDC employs a passive surveillance system by which local health departments report suspected cases of air-travel-associated meningococcal disease. Presumably both wife and husband became infected with the outbreak strain by exposure to the index case on the 8 Aug 2015 airplane flight. \n\nThe Japanese woman had primary meningococcal arthritis (i.e., arthritis without signs or symptoms suggestive of meningitis or meningococcaemia), which is rare occurring in as little as 1 percent of meningococcal infections (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3628474/). Because the risk for illness in the close contacts is highest during the 1st few days after infection, chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible (ideally within 24 hours) after exposure to an index case-patient (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm). The new report is only the 3rd case ever reported of this disease being transmitted on an airplane, said Yushi Hachisu, of the Chiba Prefectural Institute of Public Health in Chiba, Japan, who helped investigate the case. In 2001, the CDC reported that from February 1999 through May 2001, it received 21 reports of cases of air-travel-associated invasive meningococcal disease, an average of one report every 6 weeks (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm). \n\nMeningococcal disease is rare in Japan, with only about 3 cases per 10 million people, the researchers said. The CDC noted at the time that no secondary cases among air travel contacts of persons with meningococcal disease had been reported to the CDC, perhaps because of difficulties in subsequently tracing exposed passengers. In the CDC communication (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm), because of the absence of data at the time about increased risk to other passengers, the CDC limited their recommendations for chemoprophylaxis to those passengers seated in either seat next to an index case-patient. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - JAPAN: AIRPLANE EXPOSURE, BOY SCOUTS, 2015\n**********************************************************************\n \n\nStill, the overall risk of transmitting meningococcal disease on an airplane is low, Hachisu said. Invasive meningococcal disease subsequently developed in 3 scouts and one parent from Scotland and 2 scouts from Sweden after Jamboree ended. In a rare case, a woman contracted a potentially deadly bacterial infection while on a 12-hour flight from Japan to Germany, according to a new report. The incubation period for invasive meningococcal disease is 3 to 4 days, with a range of 2 to 10 days; however, this incubation period commonly pertains to meningitis or meningococcemia (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/mening.html). Officials determined it was likely that one of the infected passengers spread the bacteria to the other passenger, or both of the infected individuals got the bacteria from another person on the flight that wasn't showing symptoms. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that passengers who sit next to someone with _N. meningitidis_ on a flight that is more than 8 hours long receive preventive antibiotics. Both the woman and her husband were infected with the same strain of _N. meningitidis_ that caused the outbreak in the scouts, the report said. \n\nMeningococcal disease is caused by the bacteria _Neisseria meningitidis_. \n\nThey felt sick for the rest of their trip, but felt somewhat better upon their return to Japan on [16 Aug 2015], the report said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-08-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "1999-02-26 00:00:00", "2001-05-26 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:50", "2021-01-05 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-08-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Castro KG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Sydney", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Valway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "San Diego", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yamaguchi", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Chiba", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5363409", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - USA: (NV, CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5363409", "date": "2017-10-05 22:06:24", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA: (NEVADA, CALIFORNIA)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Nevada (Washoe County)\n[2] California (Lassen County)\n\n******\n[1] Nevada (Washoe County)\nDate: Tue 3 Oct 2017\nSource: KRNV [edited]\nhttp://mynews4.com/news/local/unusually-high-number-of-viral-meningitis-cases-reported-in-washoe-county\n\n\nWashoe County Health officials report they are concerned about a higher than usual number of viral meningitis cases in 2017. Officials say over 30 cases have been reported in Washoe County so far in 2017, with 27 reported since 15 Jul 2017. Patients have ranged in age from one to 81-years-old, and the median average is 13-years-old.\n\nMeningitis is a rare disease that causes inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord usually due to a bacterial or viral infection. While some types of meningitis can be fatal, viral meningitis is [so at least generally is - Mod.LL] the least dangerous type of meningitis. It is also the most common. There are no vaccines and those who get the disease often recover on their own within 7-10 days, but officials say they are continuing to monitor the patients\u0384 progress, and it is still important for anyone experiencing symptoms to see a healthcare provider right away. Babies younger than one-month-old and those with weakened immune systems are more likely to experience serious symptoms from the disease.\n\nDr. Randall Todd, the Director of Washoe County Health District's Epidemiology Division, says that most of the cases reported were hospitalized for about 2 days and have since recovered.\n\nThe Health District and the CDC are working to learn if the outbreak is associated with an outbreak in Susanville, California that prompted the closure of Lassen High School and Lassen Community College. Laboratory tests are underway to determine if there is a link between the 2 outbreaks.\n\nThe disease can be contracted by close contact, such as touching or shaking hands with an infected person; touching objects, surfaces, or dirty diapers that have the virus on them and then touching your eyes, nose, or mouth; or drinking water with the virus in it. You can prevent the disease by washing your hands often especially after changing diapers, using the toilet, coughing, or blowing your nose. Avoid touching your face with unwashed hands and avoid close contact such as kissing, touching, or sharing cups with people who are ill. The health district also recommends simply staying home when you are ill.\n\nSurfaces that may be contaminated can be disinfected using a bleach solution (1/2 cup [120 mL] of bleach to one gallon [3.785 L] of water.) Areas that should consider deep cleaning include households with anyone recently diagnosed with viral meningitis, community sports clubs, daycare facilities, group home daycare, public museums, playgrounds, or any other facilities that host activities for children, such as churches.\n\nDespite most of the cases being reported in students, Washoe County Schools say at this point they are not planning on closing schools because no single school has more than 2 cases.\n\n[Byline: Jaclyn Shearer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] California (Lassen County)\nDate: Tue 3 Oct 2017\nSource: KOLO [edited\nhttp://www.kolotv.com/content/news/Susanville-schools-closed-because-of-meningitis-cases-448516563.html\n\n\nLassen High School and Lassen Community College in Susanville, CA, are back open after being closed through 29 Sep 2017 after Lassen County's Public Health Department confirmed viral meningitis in Lassen County. A total of 14 cases have been clinically diagnosed, 9 of them lab-confirmed, of 43 total possible cases in Lassen County.\n\nAccording to a Public Health release, the department is working with medical providers to ensure prompt identification and reporting of patients with signs and symptoms of viral meningitis. Lassen Health says the investigation began with the high school football team, but is not further identifying anyone whose symptoms are being tested.\n\nAccording to the release, viral meningitis is an inflammation of the tissue that covers the brain and spinal cord that is caused by a virus. It is typically less severe than bacterial meningitis, and most people recover on their own within 7 to 10 days. Viral meningitis cannot be treated with antimicrobials, and there is no need for contacts of cases to receive preventive antimicrobials. Although clusters of cases of viral meningitis are not common, they do occur.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would not be surprising if the agent or agents causing these clusters are the same. The areas are only about 100 miles [161 km] away as the crow flies.\n\nMeningitis refers to the inflammation of the meninges, the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord, and implies lack of specific brain and spinal cord involvement (called encephalitis and myelitis, respectively, although some involvement may be present). In viral meningitis, the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is usually visibly clear, but on laboratory examination the CSF white cell count is 6 to 500 cells per cmm, usually with lymphocytes predominating. Usually the CSF glucose level is normal (as compared to bacterial meningitis where it is low) and the CSF protein level is mildly elevated (where in bacterial meningitis it is significantly elevated). As noted, the symptoms of viral meningitis usually last from 7 to 10 days, and the patient recovers completely.\n\nThe non-polio enteroviruses are the most common causes of viral meningitis, especially during the summer and fall months. However, other causes of viral meningitis include mumps, lymphocytic choriomeningitis viruses, arboviruses, HIV, herpes simplex virus (HSV) types 1 and 2. Non-infectious causes include certain drugs, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and systemic diseases, such as lupus, sarcoidosis, and metastatic cancer.\n\nMost people who get infected with enteroviruses are asymptomatic or have only a non-specific febrile illness. Enteroviruses are most often spread via the fecal-oral route from person to person, through fecal contamination of water or food, or contact with contaminated inanimate objects. Enteroviruses can also be spread through the respiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus) of an infected person.\n\nRecently introduced CSF gene screens for viral meningitis/encephalitis can be quite useful in making a specific diagnosis. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3549, http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14040.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nMeningitis is a rare disease that causes inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord usually due to a bacterial or viral infection. \n\nMeningitis refers to the inflammation of the meninges, the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord, and implies lack of specific brain and spinal cord involvement (called encephalitis and myelitis, respectively, although some involvement may be present). Source: KRNV [edited]\nhttp://mynews4.com/news/local/unusually-high-number-of-viral-meningitis-cases-reported-in-washoe-county\n\n\nWashoe County Health officials report they are concerned about a higher than usual number of viral meningitis cases in 2017. \n\nThe disease can be contracted by close contact, such as touching or shaking hands with an infected person; touching objects, surfaces, or dirty diapers that have the virus on them and then touching your eyes, nose, or mouth; or drinking water with the virus in it. VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA: (NEVADA, CALIFORNIA)\n********************************************\n Source: KOLO [edited\nhttp://www.kolotv.com/content/news/Susanville-schools-closed-because-of-meningitis-cases-448516563.html\n\n\nLassen High School and Lassen Community College in Susanville, CA, are back open after being closed through 29 Sep 2017 after Lassen County's Public Health Department confirmed viral meningitis in Lassen County. \n\nThe non-polio enteroviruses are the most common causes of viral meningitis, especially during the summer and fall months. Usually the CSF glucose level is normal (as compared to bacterial meningitis where it is low) and the CSF protein level is mildly elevated (where in bacterial meningitis it is significantly elevated). \n\nRecently introduced CSF gene screens for viral meningitis/encephalitis can be quite useful in making a specific diagnosis. Areas that should consider deep cleaning include households with anyone recently diagnosed with viral meningitis, community sports clubs, daycare facilities, group home daycare, public museums, playgrounds, or any other facilities that host activities for children, such as churches. However, other causes of viral meningitis include mumps, lymphocytic choriomeningitis viruses, arboviruses, HIV, herpes simplex virus (HSV) types 1 and 2.
