A statement by Nigeria Centre for Disease Control stated that the outbreak, which has been ravaging the country for 22 weeks, has affected 4 additional local government areas bringing the total affected local governments to 226 compared to what was obtainable last month [April 2017].\n\nZamfara State recorded the 1st case of the latest meningitis outbreak and has recorded the highest casualty; followed by Sokoto, Kano, Katsina, Kebbi and Yobe, which have reached the alert/epidemic threshold. So far, a total of 14 005 suspected cases have been identified from 23 states and the Federal Capital Territory. Out of 901 samples sent for laboratory testing, 423 were confirmed positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_ while 309 tested samples showed the causative organism to be _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C, with 8 per cent fatality rate from the disease. The health agency attributed the increase in the number of suspected cases to an increased knowledge of the case definition for the disease.\n\nMany health professionals at inception of the outbreak had missed the epidemiology of the disease when it 1st presented itself thereby making government intervention in providing vaccines to combat the spread of the disease late. According to the NCDC, the knowledge of the disease, however, does not translate to better outcome for the cases, as seen with the number of deaths recorded so far. The health agency said the case management, like other disease conditions, follows a sequence of case detection, laboratory confirmation, treatment using the preferred drug of choice and supportive care.\n\n'At the onset of the outbreak, a large number of identified cases did not have samples taken for laboratory testing and were managed empirically. This may have been a contributory factor to the high number of deaths recorded. However, the Rapid Response Teams deployed to the most affected states supported sample collection and therefore an increase in laboratory confirmed cases,' it said.\n\nThe agency said in order to prevent future outbreak of the disease since meningococcal meningitis is a seasonal event of public health concern, there is a need for intensive and periodical community sensitisation on the disease and the need for early presentation and use of the public health facilities for immediate and Control (NCDC) alongside the National Primary Health Care Development Agency (NPHCDA) and other partner agencies have provided on-site support for case management in the worst affected states.\n\n[byline: Ayodamola Owoseye]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak of subtype C meningococcal meningitis is continuing in Nigeria and surrounding countries.\n\nMeningococcal meningitis is a bacterial disease caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_. Of the 13 subtypes or serogroups of the organism identified, 4 (A, B, C and W) are recognized to be the main causes of epidemics, while occasional outbreaks are also caused by X and Y. Meningococcal meningitis cases occur throughout the world. However, large, recurring epidemics affect an extensive region of sub-Saharan Africa known as the 'meningitis belt' which comprises 26 countries from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia in the east. In this area, outbreaks occur during the dry 'epidemic' season, usually covering the 1st half of the year. Before 2010, serogroup A was responsible for the large majority of epidemics in this area but serogroup C is now prominent, probably related to the use of the serogroup A vaccine.\n\nA map showing the belt can be seen at: https://www.washingtontravelclinic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/meningitis-belt.png. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62.]", "summary": "\n\nThe agency said in order to prevent future outbreak of the disease since meningococcal meningitis is a seasonal event of public health concern, there is a need for intensive and periodical community sensitisation on the disease and the need for early presentation and use of the public health facilities for immediate and Control (NCDC) alongside the National Primary Health Care Development Agency (NPHCDA) and other partner agencies have provided on-site support for case management in the worst affected states. \n\n[byline: Ayodamola Owoseye]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak of subtype C meningococcal meningitis is continuing in Nigeria and surrounding countries. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMany health professionals at inception of the outbreak had missed the epidemiology of the disease when it 1st presented itself thereby making government intervention in providing vaccines to combat the spread of the disease late. A statement by Nigeria Centre for Disease Control stated that the outbreak, which has been ravaging the country for 22 weeks, has affected 4 additional local government areas bringing the total affected local governments to 226 compared to what was obtainable last month [April 2017]. \n\nZamfara State recorded the 1st case of the latest meningitis outbreak and has recorded the highest casualty; followed by Sokoto, Kano, Katsina, Kebbi and Yobe, which have reached the alert/epidemic threshold. The health agency said the case management, like other disease conditions, follows a sequence of case detection, laboratory confirmation, treatment using the preferred drug of choice and supportive care. \n\n'At the onset of the outbreak, a large number of identified cases did not have samples taken for laboratory testing and were managed empirically.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-26 00:00:00", "1114-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-05-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2016-11-26 00:00:00", "2017-04-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Katsina", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5032015", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (08): fatal, sg C", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5032015", "date": "2017-05-12 20:06:23", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (08): FATAL, SEROGROUP C\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 11 May 2017\nSource: Le Figaro [in French, trans. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttp://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2017/05/11/97001-20170511FILWWW00216-meningite-au-nigeria-plus-de-1000-morts.php\n\n\nMore than 1000 people have died, since November [2016], of the meningitis virus that has spread to northern Nigeria; but the epidemic is now under control, the National Center for Disease Surveillance (NCDC) said today [Thu 11 may 2017].\n\n'As of [Tue 9 May 2017], 13 420 suspected cases of meningitis were registered in 23 states of the country, causing 1069 deaths, or an 8 percent of infected people,' the NCDC said in a statement. The epidemic is thus present in half of the 36 states of Nigeria.\n\nThe 1st cases of infection with C-strain meningitis (reported for the 1st time in an epidemic in Nigeria) were reported in Zamfara State in November 2016. Then the disease spread to 22 other states before the authorities launched a mass vaccination campaign in this country of 190 million inhabitants, the most populous of Africa.\n\nMeningitis epidemics are not uncommon in Nigeria, which is located on the 'meningitis belt' running from Senegal to Ethiopia. By 2015, more than 13 700 people had been infected and more than 1100 had died in an outbreak in Nigeria and neighboring Niger.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria has been experiencing an outbreak of meningococcal meningitis serogroup C that has spread across the country but is mostly concentrated in states in the upper northwest that fall within the African meningitis belt. This epidemic is different from past ones in that _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A, the previous predominant pathogen, has been replaced by meningococcus serogroup C, likely as a consequence of mass vaccination campaigns using a conjugate meningococcal serogroup A vaccine, the MenAfriVac-A. This vaccine reduced by over 90 percent the incidence of meningococcal meningitis due to serogroup A.\n\nThe last update posted by ProMED-mail on the Nigerian meningococcal meningitis outbreak (Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (07): fatal, sg. C 20170510.5027149) reported that as of the end of April 2017, there were 9646 suspected cases of meningitis serogroup C, with a total of 839 deaths since late 2016. The news report above now reports that as of [Tue 9 May 2017], there are 13 420 suspected cases of meningitis in 23 states of the country, with 1069 deaths.\n\nA map of Nigerian states can be found at: http://dailymail.com.ng/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10360606_10203337420937904_71905998820449261_n.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria has been experiencing an outbreak of meningococcal meningitis serogroup C that has spread across the country but is mostly concentrated in states in the upper northwest that fall within the African meningitis belt. the MenAfriVac-A. This vaccine reduced by over 90 percent the incidence of meningococcal meningitis due to serogroup A.\n\nThe last update posted by ProMED-mail on the Nigerian meningococcal meningitis outbreak (Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (07): fatal, sg. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'As of [Tue 9 May 2017], 13 420 suspected cases of meningitis were registered in 23 states of the country, causing 1069 deaths, or an 8 percent of infected people,' the NCDC said in a statement. The news report above now reports that as of [Tue 9 May 2017], there are 13 420 suspected cases of meningitis in 23 states of the country, with 1069 deaths. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (08): FATAL, SEROGROUP C\n************************************************************\n This epidemic is different from past ones in that _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A, the previous predominant pathogen, has been replaced by meningococcus serogroup C, likely as a consequence of mass vaccination campaigns using a conjugate meningococcal serogroup A vaccine,", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-05-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "1069-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Zamfara State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5048548", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Niger: fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5048548", "date": "2017-05-19 21:12:27", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGER: FATAL\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 18 May 2017\nSource: Pulse News Agency International [edited]\nhttp://pulse.com.gh/health/meningitis-outbreak-caused-almost-180-deaths-in-niger-since-january-id6694385.html\n\n\nAt least 179 people, almost half of them children, have died of meningitis since January [2017] in Niger, where some 3000 suspected cases have been reported, the United Nations said [Wed 17 May 2017]. 'From [2 Jan to 7 May 2017], a total of 3037 suspected cases of meningitis, including 179 deaths, was reported in the country,' said the UN's humanitarian agency, OCHA. 'The fatality rate is 5.9 percent.'\n\nMeningitis is caused by different types of bacteria, 6 of which can cause epidemics. It is transmitted between people by coughing and sneezing, close contact and cramped living conditions. The illness causes acute inflammation of the outer layers of the brain and spinal cord, with the most common symptoms being fever, headache, and neck stiffness.\n\nThe UN agency had previously reported 120 deaths out of 2102 suspected meningitis cases at the end of April [2017]. 45 percent of the total cases were of children between 5 and 14.\n\nNiger however has not been the worst affected African country this year [2017]. Last week [week of 8 May 2017], the Centre for Disease Control announced that Nigeria -- Niger's neighbour to the south -- had recorded a total of 13 420 suspected cases in 23 states, with 1069 deaths.\n\nBoth countries lie in the so-called 'meningitis belt' of sub-Saharan Africa which stretches from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia in the east, where outbreaks of the disease are a regular occurrence.\n\nNiger's outbreak has been concentrated in the south and western parts of the country, but OCHA saw a drop in the number of cases beginning in April [2017]. The town of Madarounfa, south of Maradi, is still experiencing an outbreak and Niamey remains on alert.\n\nThe UN, along with medical charity Doctors Without Borders (MSF) and other organisations, launched mass vaccination programmes in the affected areas, including Niamey. Nigerian health minister Idi Illiassou Mainassara had said in April [2017] that Niger has enough medicine to treat up to 25 000 people. The country went through a similar outbreak between January and June last year [2016], when health authorities recorded 573 deaths and more than 8500 cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur George A Robertson\n\n[Maps of Niger can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Niger.gif and < http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58 >. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 18 May 2017\nSource: Sahel-Intelligence [in French, trans. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttp://sahel-intelligence.com/10054-niger-lepidemie-de-meningite-fait-plusieurs-dizaines-de-morts.html\n\n\nNiger is facing a severe epidemic of meningitis, which has raged since last January [2017] and killed nearly 180 people, according to the UN Office of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in Niamey.\n\nChildren aged 5 to 14 constitute 45 percent of the total number of deaths. The epidemic killed '179 people, from [2 Jan to 7 May 2017], from a total of 3037 suspected cases of meningitis, a case fatality rate of 5.9 percent,' said OCHA Niamey.\n\nLast April [2017], the Ministry of Health launched a major vaccination campaign to try to contain the epidemic. Nearly 100 000 people, [aged from] from 0 to 20, are concerned.\n\nThe health authorities of the country also have medicines to treat about 25 000 patients, said the Minister of Health, Idi Illiassou.\n\nThe capital Niamey is among the most affected. Between the beginning of January and the end of March [2017], 90 cases of meningitis, including 4 deaths were recorded in certain districts of the main city of the country.\n\nAt the end of last April [2017], the UN had reported 120 deaths out of the 2102 meningitis sufferers registered across the country.\n\nThis is not the 1st time that Niger has faced a meningitis epidemic of this magnitude. In 2015, a similar epidemic had spread to countries, leaving 577 deaths in more than 8589 cases between January and June.\n\n[Byline: Fr\u00e9d\u00e9ric Powelton]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Historically, the usual pathogen causing most bacterial meningitis in the African meningitis belt, which includes Niger, has been _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf). However, the epidemiology of meningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt changed after preventive vaccination of the population with conjugate meningitis A vaccine -- MenAfrivac (R) -- was introduced in 2010. Serogroup A meningococcus has been replaced by other meningococcal serogroups and other bacterial species, including _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ and _Haemophilus pneumoniae_ (http://bit.ly/2rAxx5Y and http://bit.ly/2r0UOlp).\n\n_S. pneumoniae_ serotype 1 from a single clonal complex (ST 217) has predominated in several outbreaks, but other pneumococcal serotypes are also isolated. The case-fatality rate for pneumococcal meningitis has been high; over 40 percent of cases are fatal, regardless of age group.\n\nThe news report above does not say which organism is causing the current outbreak. However a news report from 21 Apr 2017 said that this Niger outbreak was due to meningococcus serogroup C (http://reliefweb.int/report/niger/niger-meningitis-epidemic-outbreak-mdrne017-emergency-plan-action-epoa) and ProMED-mail reported in August 2015 that serogroup C caused an outbreak in Niger in 2015 (see archive no. 20150802.3552463). Identifying the specific microbial causes of a bacterial meningitis outbreak is critically important, because vaccines used to control an outbreak must cover the organism causing the outbreak. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Historically, the usual pathogen causing most bacterial meningitis in the African meningitis belt, which includes Niger, has been _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf). From [2 Jan to 7 May 2017], a total of 3037 suspected cases of meningitis, including 179 deaths, was reported in the country,' said the UN's humanitarian agency, OCHA. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGER: FATAL\n****************************************\n Niger's outbreak has been concentrated in the south and western parts of the country, but OCHA saw a drop in the number of cases beginning in April [2017]. \n\n\nNiger is facing a severe epidemic of meningitis, which has raged since last January [2017] and killed nearly 180 people, according to the UN Office of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in Niamey. \n\nLast April [2017], the Ministry of Health launched a major vaccination campaign to try to contain the epidemic.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-04-26 00:00:00", "2017-05-18 00:00:00", "1069-03-26 00:00:00", "2102-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-05-08 00:00:00", "2017-05-17 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-05-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-26 00:00:00", "2015-08-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Niger", "country": "Niger"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Maradi", "country": "Niger"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Niamey", "country": "Niger"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5023267", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Undiagnosed illness - Liberia (07): fatal, meningitis", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5023267", "date": "2017-05-09 13:08:08", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - LIBERIA (07): FATAL, MENINGITIS\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 May 2017\nSource: Global News Network [edited]\nhttp://gnnliberia.com/2017/05/08/liberian-health-authorities-say-recent-deaths-sinoe-caused-meningitis/\n\n\nAddressing a news conference in Monrovia [Mon 8 May 2017], Health Minister Bernice Dahn said based on the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) initial report on the cluster of deaths in Sinoe, which later spread to Montserrado and Grand Bassa counties, the Ministry believes that it is dealing with a probable outbreak of meningitis.\n\nAccording to Minister Dahn, the CDC tested specimens from 4 patients for 29 different diseases, noting that the tests for 28 of the diseases proved negative, while the meningitis test proved positive.\n\n'As a public health measure, we are taking it as that and we are working on it so that we do not have further spread.' Minister Dahn said.\n\nShe noted that the MOH will continue to conduct the previous investigation that is currently on the table so that it can clear all doubts, adding, 'Today [8 May 2017] the MSF was instructed to do a meningitis test on the specimens that we have.'\n\nMeningitis is an acute inflammation of the protective membrane covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges. The most common symptoms are fever, headache, and neck stiffness. Other symptoms include confusion or altered consciousness, vomiting, and inability to tolerate light or loud noise.\n\nMeanwhile, Minister Dahn has said as of 7 May [2017], a total of 31 cases, including 13 deaths have been reported from 3 counties.\n\nShe said a total of 27 cases and 10 deaths have been reported from Sinoe County, while Montserrado County recorded 2 cases and 2 deaths, and Grand Bassa County 2 cases and one death.\n\n'Liberia has never experienced meningitis before,' Dahn said, noting that meningitis normally affects countries that are hot and have long dry season; such as Mauritania, Burkina Faso, Sudan, Ethiopia and other sub-Sahara countries which usually experience meningitis every 2 years or sometimes annually.\n\n'Meningitis can be transmitted through saliva and close body contacts,' Dahn said, and urged the public not to panic because meningitis can be treated and prevented.\n\nShe is urging the public to report to health authorities anyone showing signs and symptoms of meningitis so that the person can be treated immediately.\n\n[Byline: Cholo Brooks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[There seems to be a definitive diagnosis at last. The increased surveillance and timely treatment that the Minister of Health has implemented will help to end the outbreak. An 8 May 2017 report in the Huffington Post indicated that the USA CDC is sending 2 meningitis laboratory scientists and one meningitis senior epidemiologist to Liberia this week to join the staff from the CDC Country Office in Liberia in the investigation (http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/meningitis-suspected-in-unexplained-cluster-of-deaths-in-liberia_us_59109a8ee4b0e7021e99b055).\n\nMaps of Liberia can be accessed at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/liberia/li2r765a/liberia_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/54. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "\n\n'Liberia has never experienced meningitis before,' Dahn said, noting that meningitis normally affects countries that are hot and have long dry season; such as Mauritania, Burkina Faso, Sudan, Ethiopia and other sub-Sahara countries which usually experience meningitis every 2 years or sometimes annually. A, B and C", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4976236", "date": "2017-04-17 22:14:37", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (06): (NIGER) FATAL, SEROGROUPS A, B, AND C\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Apr 2017\nSource: Nigeria Today, a Leadership New report [edited]\nhttp://www.nigeriatoday.ng/2017/04/meningitis-kills-33-in-niger/\n\n\nA total of 33 people have died from the cerebrospinal meningitis (CSM) in Niger state out of 116 suspected cases recorded, an official disclosed to the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) on Fri [14 Apr 2017].\n\nThe Executive Director of the state Primary Health Care Development Agency (SPCDA), Dr Yahaya Na'uzo, said that 9 persons died from the type [meningococcal serogroup] C meningitis while the remaining 24 died of the type [meningococcal serogroups] A and B since the outbreak of the disease.\n\nHe said that the disease is being contained in Magama, Agwara, Rijau, Kontagora local government areas. According to him, the suspected cases in Suleja and Paiko were persons on transit from Sokoto.\n\nHe explained that after the 1st fatality, the state embarked on sensitisation and awareness campaign to educate the people on preventive measures. 'We now have fewer cases reported per day because communities have been sensitised to report to the nearest hospital as soon as they suspect any case of meningitis. People have been educated to quickly report to the nearest hospital once they experience symptoms such as fever, vomiting and stiffness of the neck. With this, more people have been coming and the situation has stabilised as no more high report of confirmed cases,' he said.\n\nHe said that vaccination would commence immediately [after] the state receives the type [serogroup] C meningitis vaccines from international communities. He advised people to desist from self-medication and report to hospital when they notice any sign of CSM.\n\nNau'zo also advised people to always leave windows and doors open to ensure ventilation in their homes. To avoid the spread of the disease, he urged people to wash their hands always. He said that health personnel have been deployed to rural areas to help contain the spread.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Niger State is located in West-Central Nigeria and the largest state in the country (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niger_State). A map of Nigerian states can be found at: http://dailymail.com.ng/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10360606_10203337420937904_71905998820449261_n.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Niger State is located in West-Central Nigeria and the largest state in the country (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niger_State). The Executive Director of the state Primary Health Care Development Agency (SPCDA), Dr Yahaya Na'uzo, said that 9 persons died from the type [meningococcal serogroup] C meningitis while the remaining 24 died of the type [meningococcal serogroups] A total of 33 people have died from the cerebrospinal meningitis (CSM) in Niger state out of 116 suspected cases recorded, an official disclosed to the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) on Fri [14 Apr 2017]. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (06): (NIGER) FATAL, SEROGROUPS A, B, AND C\n*******************************************************************************\n We now have fewer cases reported per day because communities have been sensitised to report to the nearest hospital as soon as they suspect any case of meningitis. He said that vaccination would commence immediately [after] the state receives the type [serogroup] C meningitis vaccines from international communities. With this, more people have been coming and the situation has stabilised as no more high report of confirmed cases,' he said.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rijau", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Agwara", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Nau'zo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Magama", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4961260", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Nigeria: (LA) not meningococcal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4961260", "date": "2017-04-10 12:52:24", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - NIGERIA: (LAGOS) NOT MENINGOCOCCAL\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 9 Apr 2017 8:39 AM WAT\nSource: Vanguard Nigeria [edited]\nhttp://www.vanguardngr.com/2017/04/meningitis-lagos-state-refutes-allege-report-deaths/\n\n\nThe Lagos State Ministry of Health yesterday [8 Apr 2017] refuted media reports alleging that 2 deaths attributed to meningitis have been recorded in the state. The commissioner for health, Dr Jide Idris, while reviewing the activities of the state government with regards to curtailing and controlling the spread of the meningitis epidemic in press statement dismissed the report as false, capable of causing undue panic among the citizenry. 'The report carried by some newspapers and online platforms is untrue and does not represent the reality of the situation in Lagos State as at today', he said.\n\nFor the avoidance of doubt, there are 2 main types of meningitis. The epidemic-prone meningitis, which is referred to as cerebrospinal meningitis (CSM) is caused by a bacterium called _Neisseria meningitidis_ and its occurrence is seasonal or cyclical depending on the level of herd immunity and climatic conditions. The 2nd type of meningitis is non-epidemic meningitis. This type of meningitis is usually caused by a virus or other bacteria, but not by _N. meningitidis_. The non-epidemic meningitis occurs without any seasonal pattern or periodicity.\n\nIdris also disclosed that though the disease surveillance notification officer [for] Lagos Island Local Government reported 9 suspected cases of meningitis from Massey Street Children Hospital in week 13 of this year [week ending 31 Mar 2017] with 2 deaths, none of these was confirmed as due to the causative agent of CSM. He further revealed that though all the 9 cases presented with clinical features of meningitis at the said hospital but laboratory tests proved that they were either due to _Haemophilus influenzae_ or _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ and not _N. meningitidis_.\n\nIdris, in addition, said that the Ministry of Health was also notified last week of a 3 year old boy presenting clinically as meningitis at a registered private facility in Lagos but the laboratory investigations did not confirm CSM. According to him, 'the blood culture yielded no growth but the urine culture yielded klebsiella and not meningococcus. The patient is already responding to treatment.' Idris affirmed that 'none of these cases presented with a history of recent travel to any area with an outbreak of meningitis and neither were visits from such areas recorded with the aforementioned cases.'\n\nIdris seized the opportunity to reiterate the Lagos State government's firm resolve to prevent and control the spread of the epidemic to the state. He then urged the people of the state to support governmental effort by reporting suspected cases to the nearest public health facility or call the following lines 08037170614, 08023169485. The commissioner stressed the need for the observance of a high standard of personal and environmental hygiene as a preventive measure against the outbreak of the disease noting that such hygiene measures should include washing of hands with soap and water frequently and thoroughly, avoiding direct contact with the discharges from an infected person and covering of mouth and nose when coughing and sneezing.\n\n'It is strongly advised for people to avoid overcrowding in living quarters, provide cross ventilation in sleeping and work-rooms and other places where many people come together and get vaccinated with CSM vaccine when you are travelling to areas where meningitis outbreaks have been reported,' he added. Idris noted that health workers in the state have already been placed on red alert on the disease and surveillance teams consisting of epidemiologists are also intensifying their surveillance and monitoring activities.\n\n'Health workers are also advised to avoid close and prolonged contacts with suspected and probable cases of CSM, ensure proper disposal of respiratory and throat secretions of cases, report suspected or probable cases and observe universal precaution and make use of personal protective equipment when in contact with such cases. There is no need to panic. We will continue with our surveillance activities, constantly review our records and brief the public from time to time,' he added.\n\n[byline: Chioma Obinna]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The usual pathogen in the African meningitis belt during the dry season has been _Neisseria meningitidis_. However, some studies have emphasized that _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ may cause outbreaks of bacterial meningitis in an epidemic pattern in the African meningitis belt during the dry season (https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/43/6/701/326807/Pneumococcal-Meningitis-Epidemics-in-Africa, http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/192/2/192.abstract, and http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.abstract). _S. pneumoniae_ serotype 1 from a single clonal complex (ST 217) has predominated in several outbreaks, but other pneumococcal serotypes are also isolated. The case fatality rate for pneumococcal meningitis has been high; over 40 per cent of cases are fatal, regardless of age group.\n\nMaps of Nigeria can be seen at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/617. Lagos, a western coastal city in the Nigerian state of Lagos, with an estimated population in the city and adjoining areas of 16 million residents, is the largest in Nigeria, as well as on the African continent (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagos). Western coastal Nigeria lies within the African meningitis belt (http://img.static.reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/A592137EAFA85677C1256F2D0047FD68-af_menen.jpg). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Chioma Obinna]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The usual pathogen in the African meningitis belt during the dry season has been _Neisseria meningitidis_. \n\n'Health workers are also advised to avoid close and prolonged contacts with suspected and probable cases of CSM, ensure proper disposal of respiratory and throat secretions of cases, report suspected or probable cases and observe universal precaution and make use of personal protective equipment when in contact with such cases. \n\nIdris also disclosed that though the disease surveillance notification officer [for] Lagos Island Local Government reported 9 suspected cases of meningitis from Massey Street Children Hospital in week 13 of this year [week ending 31 Mar 2017] with 2 deaths, none of these was confirmed as due to the causative agent of CSM. The epidemic-prone meningitis, which is referred to as cerebrospinal meningitis (CSM) is caused by a bacterium called _Neisseria meningitidis_ and its occurrence is seasonal or cyclical depending on the level of herd immunity and climatic conditions. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n However, some studies have emphasized that _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ may cause outbreaks of bacterial meningitis in an epidemic pattern in the African meningitis belt during the dry season (https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/43/6/701/326807/Pneumococcal-Meningitis-Epidemics-in-Africa, http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/192/2/192.abstract, and http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.abstract). \n\n'It is strongly advised for people to avoid overcrowding in living quarters, provide cross ventilation in sleeping and work-rooms and other places where many people come together and get vaccinated with CSM vaccine when you are travelling to areas where meningitis outbreaks have been reported,' he added. The commissioner for health, Dr Jide Idris, while reviewing the activities of the state government with regards to curtailing and controlling the spread of the meningitis epidemic in press statement dismissed the report as false, capable of causing undue panic among the citizenry. ' Idris affirmed that 'none of these cases presented with a history of recent travel to any area with an outbreak of meningitis and neither were visits from such areas recorded with the aforementioned cases.' He further revealed that though all the 9 cases presented with clinical features of meningitis at the said hospital but laboratory tests proved that they were either due to _Haemophilus influenzae_ or _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ and not _N. meningitidis_. http://www.vanguardngr.com/2017/04/meningitis-lagos-state-refutes-allege-report-deaths/\n\n\nThe Lagos State Ministry of Health yesterday [8 Apr 2017] refuted media reports alleging that 2 deaths attributed to meningitis have been recorded in the state.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lagos", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Lagos State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4953954", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (05): (CR) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4953954", "date": "2017-04-07 11:01:09", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (05): (CROSS RIVER) FATAL\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Apr 2017\nSource: Daily Post [edited]\nhttp://dailypost.ng/2017/04/05/meningitis-outbreak-hits-cross-river-one-person-confirmed-dead/\n\n\nCerebral meningitis outbreak has reportedly hit Cross River State with one person confirmed dead.\n\nCommissioner of Health in the state, Dr Inyang Asibong, addressing newsmen in Calabar (Capital of Cross River state), on [Wed 5 Apr 2017], shortly after visiting some victims at University of Calabar Teaching Hospital, said about 24 cases have been reported with one confirmed dead.\n\nThe Commissioner said the ministry has put facilities and personnel in place to reduce the impact of the disease, adding that most of the victims have been treated and discharged from the hospital. She added that the death toll would have been heavier if not for the prompt action of her ministry to contain its outbreak.\n\nAsibong said only about 3 people were currently undergoing treatment at the University of Calabar Teaching Hospital (UCTH) just as the situation in the state is calm.\n\nShe said, 'We have recorded one death but we have tried to ensure that the situation is contained, that is why we have put in place facilities and personnel to ensure that as much as possible, we do not record more cases of death.\n\n'The ministry has started sensitizing the public on the dangers of meningitis in particular and other communicable diseases in general. Besides, the state government has given the ministry the needed support to contain the situation.\n\n'We are fighting the outbreak of the disease with everything within our power to ensure that the disease is contained as soon as possible. We in the ministry are mobilizing to drastically reduce the Impact of the disease, so we are doing something about the situation.'\n\n[Byline: John Owen Nwachukwu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A summary of the ongoing meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in Nigeria can be found in item 6 of the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments 20170403.4944602.\n\nCross River is a coastal state in southeastern Nigeria, bordering Cameroon to the east; its capital is Calabar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_River_State). A map of Nigerian states can be found at: http://dailymail.com.ng/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10360606_10203337420937904_71905998820449261_n.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/41305.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A summary of the ongoing meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in Nigeria can be found in item 6 of the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments 20170403.4944602. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nCommissioner of Health in the state, Dr Inyang Asibong, addressing newsmen in Calabar (Capital of Cross River state), on [Wed 5 Apr 2017], shortly after visiting some victims at University of Calabar Teaching Hospital, said about 24 cases have been reported with one confirmed dead. \n\nThe Commissioner said the ministry has put facilities and personnel in place to reduce the impact of the disease, adding that most of the victims have been treated and discharged from the hospital. \n\n[Byline: John Owen Nwachukwu]\n\n--\n She said, 'We have recorded one death but we have tried to ensure that the situation is contained, that is why we have put in place facilities and personnel to ensure that as much as possible, we do not record more cases of death. \n\n'We are fighting the outbreak of the disease with everything within our power to ensure that the disease is contained as soon as possible.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Calabar", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Asibong", "country": "Cameroon"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4953952", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Ghana: (AH) fatal, high school students, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4953952", "date": "2017-04-07 09:36:49", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - GHANA: (ASHANTI) FATAL, HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n*****\n[1]\nDate: Wed 5 Apr 2017\nSource: StarrFM Online [edited]\nhttp://starrfmonline.com/2017/04/05/meningitis-cause-of-kumaca-deaths-not-food-poisoning-reg-minister/\n\n\nThe Ashanti regional Minister, Simon Osei Mensah has revealed that the 4 students who died at the Kumasi Academy in the Ashanti region died from meningitis and not food poisoning. The 4 students died over a 10-day period with colleague students and parents of the deceased suspecting the cause of death to be food poisoning.\n\nTerrified students abandoned academic work and fled the campus for fear of suffering a similar fate. But after an autopsy conducted on the bodies of the students, it has been revealed that they did not die from food poisoning.\n\nAddressing a press conference [Wed 5 Apr 2017], Mr. Osei stated that through collaboration between the Ghana Health Service (GHS) and doctors from the Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital, 'the cause of the deaths has been identified as meningitis'. He added that 26 more cases have been identified and health officials have intensified surveillance to contain the disease and prevent further outbreak.\n\nAuthorities of the school are currently putting in place measures to decongest some of the dormitories in order to contain the spread of the disease.\n\nMeningitis is usually caused by bacteria or viruses, but can be a result of injury, cancer, or certain drugs. The type of meningitis is, however, yet to be identified as the doctors conduct further tests.\n\n[Byline: Kobina Welsing]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n[2]\nDate: 7 Apr 2017\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [Edited]\n\nMeningitis outbreak in Ghana is not only in the Ashanti region, rather also in Upper East region of Ghana that 58 people\nhave dies within 13 weeks. From the Ghanaian Times - Thursday April, 6th 2017 Edition\n\n--\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project Member\nErasmus Gidimadjor\nGhana Health Service\n\n*****\n[3]\nDate: 7 Apr 2017\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [Edited]\n\n4 students of the Kumasi academy school died and was later confirmed to have died from pneumococcus meningitis and 26 others cases confirmed. The school which is largely a boarding secondary school with ... parents withdrawing their wards from school. 300 other cases has been recorded in the Upper East region which lie within the meningitis belt.\n--\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n****\n[4]\nDate: 7 Apr 2017\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [Edited]\n\nAuthorities have indicated that 26 suspected cases and 4 deaths have been recorded so far. No case has been detected after the 31 March 2017. The Ashanti Region, where the outbreak has occurred, is outside the Africa meningitis belt and thus there is low index of suspicion among attending clinicians. The last two outbreaks in this region occurred in 2008 and 2011. Authorities believe there could be more undetected cases and thus surveillance activities have been intensified. Authorities have warned of possible misdiagnosis of meningitis cases as upper respiratory tract infection or malaria. The immediate setting of the outbreak (boarding high school) presents many surveillance challenges: High School sick bays do not usually have the capacity to handle such cases and therefore refer them. However, referrals are to parents/guardians and not health facilities. Information on the causative pathogen will be available in 2 - 3 days time. The Ghana EPI routinely vaccinates against _Haemophilus influenzae_ type b (Hib). Routine vaccination with _Neisseria meningitidis_ (MenAfriVac) was scheduled to start in November, 2016. The EPI has vaccinated high risk population with MenAfriVac in the past.\n\n--\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Member\nDaniel Amoako-Sakyi\nSenior Lecturer\nSchool of Medical Sciences\nUniversity Cape Coast, Ghana\n\n\n[Maps of Ghana can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Ghana.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50377. The Ashanti Region is located in south Ghana and is 3rd largest of 10 administrative regions, with a population of about 3.6 million residents in 2000, accounting for 19.1 percent of Ghana's total population (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashanti_Region). The capital city is Kumasi, where Kumasi Academy, a high school and site of the meningitis outbreak, is located (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashanti_Region).\n\nThe northern region of Ghana lies within the African meningitis belt where outbreaks of meningitis, usually due to _Neisseria meningitidis_, occur during the dry season, between December and May. The African meningitis belt is sub-Saharan and extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia in the east. A map can be seen at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/pdf/yellowbook-2012-map3-13-frequent-epidemics-meningococcal-meningitis.pdf.\n\nHowever, several studies have emphasized that _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ may also cause outbreaks of bacterial meningitis in an epidemic pattern in the African meningitis belt during the dry season (http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/192/2/192.abstract?ijkey=9d47813b96aa1d50880f62e9e7efbc4d32bfea9a&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha and http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.abstract?ijkey=7d2ca30004fffc8d1410102f6ec758a72efc1f82&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha). In fact, ProMED-mail posted on an outbreak of pneumococcal meningitis in Ghana in 2016 (see also's below).\n\nInformation from knowledgeable sources on this outbreak in Ghana would be welcomed. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2900.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n*****\n From the Ghanaian Times - Thursday April, 6th 2017 Edition\n\n--\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project Member\nErasmus Gidimadjor\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n \nEpiCore Global Surveillance Member\nDaniel Amoako-Sakyi\n Source: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [Edited]\n\nMeningitis outbreak in Ghana is not only in the Ashanti region, rather also in Upper East region of Ghana that 58 people\nhave dies within 13 weeks. Source: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [Edited]\n\n4 students of the Kumasi academy school died and was later confirmed to have died from pneumococcus meningitis and 26 others cases confirmed. Senior Lecturer\nSchool of Medical Sciences\nUniversity Cape Coast, Ghana\n\n\n --\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n< 300 other cases has been recorded in the Upper East region which lie within the meningitis belt.\n MENINGITIS - GHANA: (ASHANTI) FATAL, HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n [Byline: Kobina Welsing]\n\n--\n Ghana Health Service\n\n*****\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n****\n The northern region of Ghana lies within the African meningitis belt where outbreaks of meningitis, usually due to _Neisseria meningitidis_, occur during the dry season, between December and May. \n\n\nThe Ashanti regional Minister, Simon Osei Mensah has revealed that the 4 students who died at the Kumasi Academy in the Ashanti region died from meningitis and not food poisoning. However, several studies have emphasized that _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ may also cause outbreaks of bacterial meningitis in an epidemic pattern in the African meningitis belt during the dry season (http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/192/2/192.abstract?ijkey=9d47813b96aa1d50880f62e9e7efbc4d32bfea9a&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha and http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.abstract?ijkey=7d2ca30004fffc8d1410102f6ec758a72efc1f82&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha). The immediate setting of the outbreak (boarding high school) presents many surveillance challenges: High School sick bays do not usually have the capacity to handle such cases and therefore refer them. Date: Wed 5 Apr 2017\n Source: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [Edited]\n\nAuthorities have indicated that 26 suspected cases and 4 deaths have been recorded so far.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-11-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Kumasi", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "Chile"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5027149", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (07): fatal, sg. C", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5027149", "date": "2017-05-10 21:10:12", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (07): FATAL, SEROGROUP C\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 9 May 2017\nSource: Medecins Sans Frontieres [edited]\nhttp://www.msf.org/en/article/nigeria-fighting-worst-meningitis-c-outbreak-2008\n\n\nThousands of men, women, and children in northern Nigeria have been affected by a meningitis C outbreak, reportedly the largest to hit the country in the past 9 years.\n\nAlmost 6 months after the 1st cases were recorded in Zamfara State, Nigeria's Ministry of Health (MoH) is still struggling to fight this epidemic in 7 states of the country. M\u00e9decins Sans Fronti\u00e8res has supported the health authorities with surveillance and case management in the most-affected areas since February [2017], when the outbreak was officially declared. However, the slow reaction of the country and a global shortage of vaccines have hampered the response.\n\nOn 15 Apr [2017], MSF set up a 200-bed treatment centre in Sokoto Town, followed by a 20-bed facility in Anka, Zamfara. In these locations, MSF's Nigeria Emergency Response Unit (NERU) works intensively to provide free, high-quality medical care and reduce mortality rates as much as possible.\n\nThese teams treat challenging cases in a difficult environment. 'A few days ago, a 9-year-old boy was brought in unconsciousness and with severe meningitis,' recalls Caroline Riefthuis, an MSF nurse in Sokoto. 'He received treatment for 5 days and recovered, but unfortunately we found out that he had become deaf and blind, some of the side-effects of severe meningitis.'\n\nThis little boy is one of 614 patients treated in Sokoto Mutalah Mohamad Hospital since April 2017, when MSF took over the management of the centre from the MoH due to a lack of supplies and qualified staff to run it. In Anka General Hospital, 137 patients were admitted since the beginning of the outbreak. Most are between 5-20 years old.\n\nIn addition to the staff working in the treatment centres, 11 MSF surveillance teams visited health facilities to determine the origins of new cases in Sokoto, Zamfara, Yobe, Niger and Kebbi. These visits also allowed MSF to implement additional activities, such as health promotion, to increase community awareness of the signs and symptoms of meningitis and active case finding.\n\nAt the end of April [2017], the Nigerian MoH reported 9646 suspected cases of meningitis C, with a total of 839 deaths since late 2016. And on 1 May [2017], MSF was finally able to join a vaccination campaign launched by the health authorities in Sokoto. In the 3 most-affected Local Government Areas (LGAs), 25 MSF teams vaccinated approximately 850 people per day for 7 days to reach a target population of 148 000 people -- of a total target of 800 000 -- between the ages of 1-20. An additional campaign with a target population of nearly 130 000 people will start later this month [May 2017] in the 4 most-affected LGAs of Yobe State.\n\nAlthough these vaccination campaigns are a crucial step to stop the spread of the disease, MSF has concerns regarding the late response to the crisis in a country where meningitis epidemics are not rare. 'The national early warning system and timely response needs to be strengthened, and the implementation strategy better-defined, to reduce the impact of the outbreak as much as possible,' explains Philip Aruna, MSF Head of Mission in Nigeria.\n\nEven more worrisome is the global shortage of meningitis C vaccine, which contributed to the delayed response and increased mortality rates in Nigeria. 'The outbreak is spreading fast, and we are concerned because there are not enough vaccines to cover the affected population,' says Aruna. In Sokoto, for example, 3 million vaccines are required to launch a mass campaign, but only 800 000 were available. This insufficient quantity only allows for a reactive campaign, which requires teams to act fast to prevent the disease from spreading further.\n\nTo address these logistical challenges and reduce the mortality rates, MSF insists that treatment centres be decentralised so that all people affected by the disease, even those in remote areas, can access free, quality health care and the right tests to quickly confirm cases and prevent misdiagnosis. It is crucial that adequate prevention measures be put in place to avoid another delayed response when the next meningitis outbreak inevitably occurs.\n\nMSF has worked in Nigeria since 1996, running extensive projects on child health, sexual and reproductive health, lead poisoning, and reconstructive surgery in places like Sokoto, Zamfara, Niger, Port Harcourt, and Jahun. The MSF Emergency Response Unit (NERU) also responds to medical emergencies such as meningitis and measles outbreaks. NERU has been active in the country since 2006.\n\nMSF has provided health care to people displaced by violence as well as host communities in northeastern Nigeria's Borno State since mid-2014. MSF currently manages 11 medical facilities in 7 towns in Borno (Maiduguri, Dikwa, Monguno, Gwoza, Pulka, Ngala, and Benisheikh) and regularly provides care in 4 other locations.\n\n[Byline: Fabrice Caterini]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Nigeria has been experiencing an outbreak of meningococcal meningitis serogroup C that has spread across the country but is mostly concentrated in states in the upper northwest that fall within the African meningitis belt. This epidemic is different from past ones in that _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A, the previous predominant pathogen, has been replaced by meningococcus serogroup C, likely as a consequence of mass vaccination campaigns using a conjugate meningococcal serogroup A vaccine, the MenAfriVac-A. This vaccine reduced by over 90 per cent the incidence of meningococcal meningitis due to serogroup A.\n\nTo prevent replacement by other pathogenic serogroups, a quadrivalent conjugate meningococcal vaccine, such the ACYW vaccine, would be ideal. Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines. Serogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen.\n\nA map of Nigerian states can be found at: http://dailymail.com.ng/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10360606_10203337420937904_71905998820449261_n.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "This epidemic is different from past ones in that _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A, the previous predominant pathogen, has been replaced by meningococcus serogroup C, likely as a consequence of mass vaccination campaigns using a conjugate meningococcal serogroup A vaccine, the MenAfriVac-A. This vaccine reduced by over 90 per cent the incidence of meningococcal meningitis due to serogroup A.\n\nTo prevent replacement by other pathogenic serogroups, a quadrivalent conjugate meningococcal vaccine, such the ACYW vaccine, would be ideal. \n\nTo address these logistical challenges and reduce the mortality rates, MSF insists that treatment centres be decentralised so that all people affected by the disease, even those in remote areas, can access free, quality health care and the right tests to quickly confirm cases and prevent misdiagnosis. In the 3 most-affected Local Government Areas (LGAs), 25 MSF teams vaccinated approximately 850 people per day for 7 days to reach a target population of 148 000 people -- of a total target of 800 000 -- between the ages of 1-20. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines. [Nigeria has been experiencing an outbreak of meningococcal meningitis serogroup C that has spread across the country but is mostly concentrated in states in the upper northwest that fall within the African meningitis belt. \n\nEven more worrisome is the global shortage of meningitis C vaccine, which contributed to the delayed response and increased mortality rates in Nigeria. ' \n\nAlmost 6 months after the 1st cases were recorded in Zamfara State, Nigeria's Ministry of Health (MoH) is still struggling to fight this epidemic in 7 states of the country. \n\nMSF has worked in Nigeria since 1996, running extensive projects on child health, sexual and reproductive health, lead poisoning, and reconstructive surgery in places like Sokoto, Zamfara, Niger, Port Harcourt, and Jahun. Thousands of men, women, and children in northern Nigeria have been affected by a meningitis C outbreak, reportedly the largest to hit the country in the past 9 years. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (07): FATAL, SEROGROUP C\n************************************************************\n Although these vaccination campaigns are a crucial step to stop the spread of the disease, MSF has concerns regarding the late response to the crisis in a country where meningitis epidemics are not rare. An additional campaign with a target population of nearly 130 000 people will start later this month [May 2017] in the 4 most-affected LGAs of Yobe State. M\u00e9decins Sans Fronti\u00e8res has supported the health authorities with surveillance and case management in the most-affected areas since February [2017], when the outbreak was officially declared.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-03-26 00:00:00", "9646-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-04-26 00:00:00", "2021-05-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-02-26 00:00:00", "1996-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-05-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Zamfara State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Pulka", "country": "North Macedonia"}, {"location": "Dikwa", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Gwoza", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Ngala", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Sokoto Town", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Borno State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Maiduguri", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Monguno", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Borno", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "MoH", "country": "Singapore"}, {"location": "Sokoto", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4942532", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03): fatal, more states, vaccine short, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4942532", "date": "2017-04-02 16:54:11", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (03): FATAL, SEROGROUP C, MORE STATES, VACCINE SHORTAGE, RFI\n************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Plateau State\n[2] More states, Vaccine Shortage\n\n******\n[1] Plateau State\nDate: Fri 31 Mar 2017\nSource: The Nation Online [edited]\nhttp://thenationonlineng.net/plateau-has-suspected-cases-of-cerebra-spinal-meningitis-commissioner/\n\n\nPlateau [state] has recorded some suspected cases of cerebro-spinal meningitis in Langtang South and Mikang Local Government Areas, Dr. Kunden Deyin, the state Commissioner for Health, disclosed to the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) on Friday [31 Mar 2017] in Jos.\n\nDeyin said that findings from the suspected cases were consistent with cerebra-spinal meningitis, clinically. He said that the national policy on meningitis now stipulates that before any case is confirmed as being that of meningitis, a blood sample or cerebra-spinal fluid must have been diagnosed at a government approved medical laboratory. It is the results from such a laboratory that will confirm the case as being that of cerebra-spinal meningitis, he said.\n\nThe commissioner said that those persons suspected to be suffering from the disease had commenced treatment with antibiotics.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] More states, Vaccine Shortage\nDate: Fri 31 Mar 2017\nSource: Click on Detroit [edited]\nhttp://www.clickondetroit.com/health/meningitis-outbreak-in-nigeria-kills-nearly-300\n\n\nThe Center for Disease Control and Prevention said 282 people have died since Nigeria was struck with a meningitis outbreak. The agency reported a wide outbreak of cerebrospinal meningitis across 15 states.\n\nA new strain of the disease called 'stereotype C' has emerged, and there are not enough vaccines against it, the Center for Disease Control warned.\n\n'There is a vaccine available,' Chief Executive Chikwe Ihekweazu said, 'but it is not commercially available for the stereotype involved in this specific outbreak, and we have to make application to the World Health Organization for the vaccines.'\n\nNearly 2000 suspected cases have been recorded, and 109 have been treated since the outbreak began in February 2017.\n\nAn emergency response team has been sent to the 5 states in the northwest of the country.\n\nAs one of the 26 countries in the African 'meningitis belt,' Nigeria records some of the highest incidences of the disease on the continent. The outbreaks peak in the dry season in certain states due to the low humidity and dusty conditions and usually end as the rainy season approaches, Ihekweazu added.\n\n'Meningitis is a tough disease, especially during this period, and it is associated with overcrowding; understanding the living conditions in the country, people must keep their building ventilated,' he said. According to the WHO, even when the disease is diagnosed early, and adequate treatment begins, 5 percent to 10 percent of patients die, typically within 24 to 48 hours of the onset of symptoms.\n\nSome common symptoms are stiff neck, high fever, sensitivity to light, confusion, headaches and vomiting.\n\nLocal and international organizations are working together to manage the epidemic. 'We believe that our concerted efforts will bring this outbreak under control, as we also work towards preventing outbreaks of this scale in the future,' the Center for Disease Control stated.\n\n[Byline: Stephanie Busari]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Prior ProMED-mail posts reported that a _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C outbreak is occurring in the northwestern states of Nigeria, with Katsina, Sokoto and Zamfara accounting for almost 90 percent of cases (see 'see also' section below). According to the 2nd news report above, the outbreak may be spreading, with 10 more Nigerian states involved than initially reported.\n\nThe 1st news report above says that cases of suspected meningitis are also occurring in Plateau state, which is located in approximately the center of the country; its capital is Jos (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plateau_State). However, we are not told the number of cases in Plateau state, if any have been confirmed to be meningococcal meningitis, and, if so, what the serogroups are. More information in this regard would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nA map of Nigerian states can be found at: http://dailymail.com.ng/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10360606_10203337420937904_71905998820449261_n.jpg. Cameroon: (Yaounde) fatal, sg W", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4933744", "date": "2017-03-29 12:30:08", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CAMEROON: (YAOUNDE) FATAL, SEROGROUP W\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 27 Mar 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/cameroon-meningitis-outbreak-reported-yaounde-central-prison-64353/\n\n\nA meningitis outbreak that began earlier this month [March 2017] at the Yaounde Central Prison in Kondengui has grown to about [24] cases in a matter of about 4 weeks.\n\nAs of 24 Mar 2017, a total of 23 suspected/confirmed cases including 9 deaths (case fatality rate of 39 percent) have been reported. While majority of the affected people were prisoners, 5 suspected cases came from the surrounding community in the affected district.\n\nOutbreak investigation conducted by the Ministry of Health obtained 11 cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples, 5 of which tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_ (Nm) serogroup Y/W135 by rapid diagnostic test. Subsequent bacteriological culture isolated Nm W135 from 2 samples, thus confirming the outbreak.\n\nWHO supported the Ministry of Health to secure 7079 doses of ACYW tetravalent meningitis vaccine from the International Coordinating Group (ICG), targeting 6436 persons. Preparation for reactive meningitis vaccination campaign is being finalized.\n\nSince the outbreak occurred in a closed setting, chemoprophylaxis was administered to 4007 close contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The northern portion of Cameroon is part of the African meningitis belt, a region in the semi-arid area of sub-Saharan Africa that extends from the Atlantic Ocean to the Red Sea, where the rate of incidence of meningitis is very high. The northern provinces of Cameroon are periodically affected by meningococcal meningitis (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3310568/). A map of the African meningitis belt can be found at http://www.meningvax.org/epidemics-africa.php. The attack rate of meningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt ranges from 100 to 800 per 100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates as high as 1/100.\n\nIn the early 1990s, meningococcus serogroup A was the most frequently identified serogroup in Cameroon; during the 2007 and 2008 meningitis seasons, an outbreak of meningococcus serogroup W135 was reported in northern Cameroon (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2662656/). In 2010, an outbreak (70 cases/100 000 inhabitants) of meningococcal meningitis due to serogroup A was reported in the northern region, a serogroup that had not been identified in north Cameroon since 2006 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3310568/).\n\nYaounde, the capital of Cameroon, with a population of approximately 2.5 million, is in the Central Region of the nation, outside of the usual African meningitis belt. From 1999 through 2001, a few cases of meningitis were attributed to serogroup W135 in Yaounde (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2732466/). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34100.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The northern portion of Cameroon is part of the African meningitis belt, a region in the semi-arid area of sub-Saharan Africa that extends from the Atlantic Ocean to the Red Sea, where the rate of incidence of meningitis is very high. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In the early 1990s, meningococcus serogroup A was the most frequently identified serogroup in Cameroon; during the 2007 and 2008 meningitis seasons, an outbreak of meningococcus serogroup W135 was reported in northern Cameroon (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2662656/). The attack rate of meningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt ranges from 100 to 800 per 100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates as high as 1/100. In 2010, an outbreak (70 cases/100 000 inhabitants) of meningococcal meningitis due to serogroup A was reported in the northern region, a serogroup that had not been identified in north Cameroon since 2006 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3310568/). MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CAMEROON: (YAOUNDE) FATAL, SEROGROUP W\n******************************************************************\n \n\nOutbreak investigation conducted by the Ministry of Health obtained 11 cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples, 5 of which tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_ (Nm) serogroup Y/W135 by rapid diagnostic test. A meningitis outbreak that began earlier this month [March 2017] at the Yaounde Central Prison in Kondengui has grown to about [24] cases in a matter of about 4 weeks.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "6436-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kondengui", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4925882", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): fatal, emergence sg C, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4925882", "date": "2017-03-25 19:27:22", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (02): FATAL, EMERGENCE OF SEROGROUP C, WHO\n******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Mar 2017\nSource: WHO Disease Outbreak News [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/24-march-2017-meningococcal-disease-nigeria/en/\n\n\nAs of [Sun 19 Mar 2017] (epidemiological week 11), a total of 1407 suspected cases of meningitis and 211 deaths (case fatality rate: 15 percent) have been reported from 40 local government areas (LGAs) in 5 states of Nigeria since December 2016. Zamfara, Katsina and Sokoto account for 89 percent of these cases.\n\nA total of 26 LGAs from all 5 states reported 361 cases in epidemiological week 11 alone. Up to 22 wards in 15 LGAs have crossed the epidemic threshold. Only 3 of these LGAs share borders with Niger. NmC [_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C] is the predominant serotype in this outbreak.\n\nThe most affected age group is 5 to 14 year olds and they are responsible for about half of reported cases. Both sexes are almost equally affected.\n\nWHO and partners including National Primary health Care Development Authority, UNICEF, Nigeria Field Epidemiology and Laboratory training Program, eHealth Africa, M\u00e9decins Sans Fronti\u00e8res, Rotary International, and Nigeria Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are providing support to this outbreak.\n\nThe following measures are being implemented:\n- Nigeria Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, with support from the WHO, is taking the overall lead in coordinating the response at the national level.\n- Daily coordination meetings are being held at the state and LGA levels.\n- The rapid response teams are conducting active case finding, performing lumbar puncture of suspect cases and training local staff on case management.\n- Case management is being carried out at the public health centers at the LGA level.\n- 19 600 persons were vaccinated with the meningococcal ACWY vaccine in Gora ward in Zamfara state.\n- 500 000 doses of meningococcal AC PS vaccines and injection supplies was approved by the International Coordination Group (ICG) for utilization in Zamfara State which are planned to arrive on [Mon 27 Mar 2017].\n- Katsina state is preparing an ICG request for submission.\n\nThe successful roll-out of MenA conjugate vaccine has resulted to the decreasing trend of meningitis A, however, other meningococcal serogroups are still causing epidemics. The most recent outbreak that has been reported was in Togo due to Neisseria meningitidis serogroup W (see Disease Outbreak News as published by WHO on 23 February 2017). [Also see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Togo: fatal, emergence of serogroup W 20170225.4863648.]\n\nThe outbreak response consists of appropriate case management with reactive mass vaccination of populations. Promptness of the reactive campaign is essential, ideally within 4 weeks of crossing the epidemic threshold.\n\nWHO does not recommend any travel or trade restriction to Nigeria based on the current information available on this outbreak.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The above report confirms the suspicion of the emergence of Neiseria meningitidis_ serogroup C after successful reduction of serogroup A following mass immunization program with meningococcal conjugate serogroup A vaccine.\n\nKatsina, Sokoto and Zamfara States are located in the extreme northwest of Nigeria; a map of Nigerian states can be found at: http://dailymail.com.ng/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10360606_10203337420937904_71905998820449261_n.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1780. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: WHO Disease Outbreak News [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/24-march-2017-meningococcal-disease-nigeria/en/\n\n\nAs of [Sun 19 Mar 2017] (epidemiological week 11), a total of 1407 suspected cases of meningitis and 211 deaths (case fatality rate: 15 percent) have been reported from 40 local government areas (LGAs) in 5 states of Nigeria since December 2016. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (02): FATAL, EMERGENCE OF SEROGROUP C, WHO\n******************************************************************************\n [The above report confirms the suspicion of the emergence of Neiseria meningitidis_ serogroup C after successful reduction of serogroup A following mass immunization program with meningococcal conjugate serogroup A vaccine. \n\nThe following measures are being implemented:\n- Nigeria Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, with support from the WHO, is taking the overall lead in coordinating the response at the national level. \n- 500 000 doses of meningococcal AC PS vaccines and injection supplies was approved by the International Coordination Group (ICG) for utilization in Zamfara State which are planned to arrive on [Mon 27 Mar 2017]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n \n\nThe outbreak response consists of appropriate case management with reactive mass vaccination of populations. \n- 19 600 persons were vaccinated with the meningococcal ACWY vaccine in Gora ward in Zamfara state.
