The rapid response teams are conducting active case finding, performing lumbar puncture of suspect cases and training local staff on case management. \n- Case management is being carried out at the public health centers at the LGA level.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-02-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-12-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Katsina", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "eHealth Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zamfara State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Zamfara", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Neiseria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4944602", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4944602", "date": "2017-04-03 15:57:06", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (04): MASS VACCINATION, COMMENTS\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sun 2 Apr 2017\nSource: Nigeria Today [edited]\nhttp://www.nigeriatoday.ng/2017/04/new-strain-of-meningitis-fg-secures-500000-vaccines-from-w-h-o/\n\n\nIn a bid to tackle the menace and spread of the cerebrospinal meningitis (CSM), the Federal government said it has secured not less than 500 000 meningococcal vaccines which will be used in Zamfara and Katsina States, respectively.\n\nSince the outbreak of the disease, in late 2016, Zamfara has experienced the highest number of deaths, losing 44 persons, while Katsina has lost 32.\n\nA press release made available to journalists by the Federal Ministry of Health further revealed that additional 800 000 units are expected from the British government on [Tue 4 Apr 2017]. 'By Tuesday [4 Apr 2017], there will be a meeting with the International Review Group of The World Health Organization (WHO) where request for additional vaccines shall be approved, as part of practical and medically certified efforts to stem this ugly incidence,' the statement reads.\n\nThe Minister of Health, Prof Isaac Adewole also assured Nigerians of the federal government's quick response in tackling the disease. 'We have started working with all the affected states in specific areas of collaboration on massive awareness and sensitization, laboratory investigation and analysis, proper documentation and disease surveillance techniques through the National Centre for Disease Control and National Primary Health Care Development Authority (NPHCDA) who have been of tremendous support since the outbreak. We are in constant discussion with World Health Organization (WHO), UNICEF, E-health Africa and other international health agencies for supplies of vaccines and injections,' he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 2 Apr 2017\nSource: The Nation Online [edited]\nhttp://thenationonlineng.net/41-die-of-meningitis-in-sokoto-state-commissioner/\n\n\nThe death toll as a result of the meningitis epidemic in Sokoto State [Nigeria] has now risen to 41, Health Commissioner Dr Balarabe Kakale has said. Kakale disclosed this to newsmen in Sokoto on Sunday [2 Mar 2017] when he gave an update on the state of high alert declared by the state government since [Mon 20 Mar 2017]. He said that the deaths were mostly recorded out of the nearly 600 clinically confirmed cases of meningitis in the 8 worst-hit local governments; Rabah, Kebbe, Tureta, Gada, Dange/Shuni, Wamakko, Kware and Bodinga.\n\nKakale said, 'The epidemic was caused by the serogroup 'C'' strains of meningitis and not the serogroup 'A'' strains, which the people of the state had hitherto developed immunity for. This new strain of meningitis is deadlier than the dreaded Ebola disease as it kills within 4 to 6 hours of afflicting a patient. More than 80 per cent of the victims also had not been immunised, hence, the aggravation of the epidemic.'\n\nThe commissioner further stated that the state government has embarked on a statewide, mass vaccination for the people of the state, against meningitis. He explained that over 700 000 persons, aged 1 to 30 years were being targeted across the 23 local governments of the state. Kakale further stressed the need for the people of the state to ensure that their children were fully immunised against the child killer diseases like measles, whooping cough, yellow fever and diphtheria, among others. 'They should also desist from self medication as adequate drugs and medications are provided by the state government for the free treatment of the patients.'\n\n'No fewer than 100 medical personnel comprising medical doctors, nurses, ambulances and other logistics are still operating across the state. The people should also desist attaching traditional beliefs like witchcraft and report all suspected cases of meningitis, measles and other diseases to the nearest health facility. We will not rest on our oars until the epidemic is fully mitigated, although the cases have drastically reduced. Some of the isolation camps hitherto set had since been closed in most of the local governments,'' Kakale said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Sun 2 Apr 2017\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\nThis information has not yet been verified. Though follow up has begun by the team of experts in Plateau to investigate through series of laboratory tests. The results/information on the suspected outbreak will be shared with members here as soon as possible.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Surveillance Project member\nHogan Usoro\nUCTH (University of Calabar Teaching Hospital)\nCalabar, Nigeria\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: Sun 2 Apr 2017\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\nThe total number of cases is 4 in 1 local government [area] [Plateau State?]. This is according to the CSM [cerebrospinal meningitis] situation report by Nigeria Centre for Disease Control on [28 Mar 2017]. I cannot ascertain the serogroup but the most common is NmC [_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Surveillance Project member\nJelili Mustapha\nBiomedical Scientist\nUniversity of Salford, UK\n\n******\n[5]\nDate: Sun 2 Apr 2017\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\nThere are 4 cases, no deaths, and no lab confirmation as samples were not collected [Plateau State?]. However drugs have been commenced. The circulating strain in other affected states is NmC [_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C].\n\nPlateau State is 1 of the states affected by the current outbreak of cerebrospinal meningitis in Nigeria. _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C is said to be responsible for the current outbreak. According to an official release, so far some 2500 cases have been reported in all the affected States, out of which 328 have been fatal.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[6]\nDate: Mon 3 Apr 2017\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\nA total of 5 cases have been reported in Plateau state and none is yet confirmed by blood culture.\n\nThe outbreak of cerebrospinal meningitis started on the [Tue 28 Mar 2017] in some states in Northern Nigeria. Already 90 Local Government Areas in 16 states have been affected. The death toll recorded so far is 328. The states affected include: Zamfara, Kano, Katsina, Sokoto, Kebbe, Niger, Nassarawa, Jigawa, Abuja, Gombe, Tarawa, Yobe, Osun, Cross River, Lagos and Plateau. The Minister of Health said that neighbouring West African Countries are also facing similar health threats from _Neisseria meningitidis_.\n\nAccording to the Minister [of Health], the country is currently experiencing an outbreak of cerebrospinal meningitis (CSM) that has spread across the country and mostly affecting states in the upper parts of the country that fall within the African Meningitis Belt. Other countries that are facing similar outbreaks at the moment include our West-African neighbours like Niger, Chad, Cameroun, Togo, and Burkina Faso. This epidemic has come with a difference, as all previous epidemics were caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup 'A' but this year [2017] we are recording serogroup C in epidemic proportion for the 1st time. The worst CSM epidemics experienced in Nigeria occurred in 1996 (109 580 cases and 11 717 deaths), 2003 (4130 cases and 401 deaths), 2008 (9086 cases and 562 deaths), and 2009 (9086 cases and 562 deaths). Following these successive outbreaks, the World Health Organisation (WHO) instituted a mass vaccination campaign using a new conjugate vaccine the MenAfriVac-A in about 16 out of the 26 vulnerable countries (including Nigeria). It resulted in a reduction of over 94 per cent incidence of the disease in most countries, thus significantly reducing the risk of serogroup A.\n\nSome key lessons learnt from the MenAfriVac-A mass vaccination campaign and the recent happenings across the sub-region, are that although serogroup A was successfully displaced, other strains which were hitherto less significant can actually assume epidemic proportions. Thus efforts must continue towards preventing a rebound of the serogroup A and also preventing a potential replacement by all other strains, said the Minister.\n\nAs at [Fri 31 March 31], 90 Local Government Areas (LGAs) in 16 states of the Federation are so far affected by the new strain of CSM including Zamfara, Katsina, Sokoto, Kebbe, Niger, Nassarawa, Jigawa, FCT, Gombe, Tarawa, Yobe, Kano, Osun, Cross Rivers, Lagos and Plateau.\n\nA total number of 2524 people have been reportedly affected while the death toll has risen to 328. So far, a total 131 samples have been confirmed in the laboratory, out of which a majority is _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C. This current outbreak started in Zamfara State in the 50th week of 2016 (i.e. November 2016).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks EpiCore Global Surveillance Project members for their prompt responses.\n\nA map of Nigerian states can be found at: http://dailymail.com.ng/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10360606_10203337420937904_71905998820449261_n.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nEpiCore Surveillance Project member\nJelili Mustapha\nBiomedical Scientist\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nEpiCore Surveillance Project member\nHogan Usoro\n MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (04): MASS VACCINATION, COMMENTS\n********************************************************************\n \n\nKakale said, 'The epidemic was caused by the serogroup 'C'' strains of meningitis and not the serogroup 'A'' strains, which the people of the state had hitherto developed immunity for. It resulted in a reduction of over 94 per cent incidence of the disease in most countries, thus significantly reducing the risk of serogroup A.\n\nSome key lessons learnt from the MenAfriVac-A mass vaccination campaign and the recent happenings across the sub-region, are that although serogroup A was successfully displaced, other strains which were hitherto less significant can actually assume epidemic proportions. The worst CSM epidemics experienced in Nigeria occurred in 1996 (109 580 cases and 11 717 deaths), 2003 (4130 cases and 401 deaths), 2008 (9086 cases and 562 deaths), and 2009 (9086 cases and 562 deaths). Communicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n< Communicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n< \n\nPlateau State is 1 of the states affected by the current outbreak of cerebrospinal meningitis in Nigeria. \n\n--\n \n\nThe commissioner further stated that the state government has embarked on a statewide, mass vaccination for the people of the state, against meningitis. \n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\n--\n \n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nThe outbreak of cerebrospinal meningitis started on the [Tue 28 Mar 2017] in some states in Northern Nigeria. Calabar, Nigeria\n\n******\n University of Salford, UK\n\n******\n \n\nA press release made available to journalists by the Federal Ministry of Health further revealed that additional 800 000 units are expected from the British government on [Tue 4 Apr 2017]. ' Kakale disclosed this to newsmen in Sokoto on Sunday [2 Mar 2017] when he gave an update on the state of high alert declared by the state government since [Mon 20 Mar 2017]. Date: Sun 2 Apr 2017\n Date: Sun 2 Apr 2017\n According to the Minister [of Health], the country is currently experiencing an outbreak of cerebrospinal meningitis (CSM) that has spread across the country and mostly affecting states in the upper parts of the country that fall within the African Meningitis Belt. Date: Mon 3 Apr 2017\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "yellow fever"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "1996-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Katsina States", "country": "Estonia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rabah", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "States", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lagos", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Plateau State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Bodinga", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Calabar", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Cross Rivers", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Zamfara", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Zamfara State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Sokoto State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Katsina", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Jigawa", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Kano", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4909903", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: (SO, ZA) fatal, new sg.susp., RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4909903", "date": "2017-03-18 11:18:32", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA: (SOKOTO, ZAMFARA) FATAL, NEW SEROGROUP SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 17 Mar 2017\nSource: NAIJ [edited]\nhttps://www.naij.com/1094177-fg-announces-outbreak-a-disease-nigeria.html\n\n\nThe Federal Government says it has deployed epidemiologists and vaccines to arrest the outbreak of a new a strain of cerebrospinal meningitis (CSM) in parts of the country.\n\nThe Minister of Health, Prof. Isaac Adewole said this on [Thu 16 Mar 2017] in Abuja that the new strain, which is not common in Nigeria, was imported from Niger Republic. Adewole said that the new strain requires a different type of vaccine and a team of epidemiologists has been deployed to address the challenge.\n\nHe described the outbreak of meningitis in Sokoto and Zamfara States as an unfortunate incidence, stressing that the ministry is working hard to contain the situation. 'It has become an annual ritual under this administration; we would want to put an end to annual outbreak of meningitis in some of the northern states. I have just spoken with the commissioner for health in Zamfara who is appreciative of what the Federal Ministry of Health has been doing through the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control. We have sent field epidemiologists; they are actually called disease detectives, to support them at the state level,' Adewole said.\n\nThe minister said that government has provided vaccines and would continue to do more in terms of whatever was needed with respect to material and technical support to overcome the outbreak. 'What we know in public health is that there is always an outbreak, but what is uncertain is where and the type. We want to be ready at any time,' he said.\n\nAdewole said he has scheduled a meeting with the commissioners of health from the Northern states to plan a resilient and strong strategy to put an end to meningitis outbreak in the country. He said all the states in northwest region are prone to the disease and the states would be treated equally when confronted by outbreaks such as this.\n\nAn outbreak of CSM has claimed 5 lives in Gada and Wauru towns of Gada Local Government Area of Sokoto State. The state Commissioner for Health, Dr Balarabe Kakale, said that the victims died at the Gada General Hospital and Wauru Primary Health Centre. He said: '3 of the deaths were recorded at the Gada General hospital, while 2 were recorded at the Wauru PHC.' A similar report outbreak was also reported from Zamfara on [Tue 14 Mar 2017].\n\n[Byline: Aanu Adegun]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that a 'new strain, which is not common in Nigeria,' 'imported from Niger' is responsible for a recurrence of meningitis during the current dry season. Although the organism is not stated, it is likely to be _Neisseria meningitidis_, which causes annual outbreaks of meningitis in the African meningitis belt during the hot, dry season, between December and June. Both Nigeria and Niger fall within the African Meningitis Belt.\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A has been the main cause of epidemic meningococcal disease in this region (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf). However, since the introduction of the meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt in 2010, WHO has noted a decrease in the number of cases of meningitis; in fact, the number of cases in 2013 was the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years (http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/), and _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was noted to be no longer the predominant pathogen, having been replaced by other meningococcal serogroups and other bacterial species.\n\nProMED-mail previously reported in 2015 on the emergence of outbreaks of meningitis due to _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C in Kebbi State (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kebbi) in northwest Nigeria and Niger (see alsos below). The emergence of serogroup C outbreaks in the African Meningitis Belt has been thought to be evidence of serogroup replacement in the meningitis belt following mass vaccination with serogroup A conjugate vaccine. However, the current outbreak may be due to serogroup C or some other serogroup such as W. which had been reported in Niger in 2015 (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Niger: fatal, serogroups C, W 20150430.3332448). More information from knowledgeable sources in this regard would be appreciated.\n\nSokoto and Zamfara States are located in the extreme northwest of Nigeria; a map of Nigerian states can be found at: http://dailymail.com.ng/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10360606_10203337420937904_71905998820449261_n.jpg. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1780.]", "summary": "However, since the introduction of the meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt in 2010, WHO has noted a decrease in the number of cases of meningitis; in fact, the number of cases in 2013 was the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years (http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/), and _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was noted to be no longer the predominant pathogen, having been replaced by other meningococcal serogroups and other bacterial species. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that a 'new strain, which is not common in Nigeria,' 'imported from Niger' is responsible for a recurrence of meningitis during the current dry season. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The emergence of serogroup C outbreaks in the African Meningitis Belt has been thought to be evidence of serogroup replacement in the meningitis belt following mass vaccination with serogroup A conjugate vaccine. \n\nAdewole said he has scheduled a meeting with the commissioners of health from the Northern states to plan a resilient and strong strategy to put an end to meningitis outbreak in the country. \n\nProMED-mail previously reported in 2015 on the emergence of outbreaks of meningitis due to _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C in Kebbi State (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kebbi) in northwest Nigeria and Niger (see alsos below). However, the current outbreak may be due to serogroup C or some other serogroup such as W. which had been reported in Niger in 2015 (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Niger: fatal, serogroups C, W 20150430.3332448). MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA: (SOKOTO, ZAMFARA) FATAL, NEW SEROGROUP SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************************************\n Although the organism is not stated, it is likely to be _Neisseria meningitidis_, which causes annual outbreaks of meningitis in the African meningitis belt during the hot, dry season, between December and June. \n\nThe minister said that government has provided vaccines and would continue to do more in terms of whatever was needed with respect to material and technical support to overcome the outbreak. ' Adewole said that the new strain requires a different type of vaccine and a team of epidemiologists has been deployed to address the challenge.\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Gada", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "Zamfara", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Wauru", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Sokoto", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Abuja", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "the African Meningitis Belt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Niger Republic", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Niger", "country": "Niger"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4863648", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Togo: fatal, emergence of serogroup W", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4863648", "date": "2017-02-25 11:27:42", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - TOGO: FATAL, EMERGENCE OF SEROGROUP W\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 23 Feb 2017\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/23-february-2017-meningococcal-disease-togo/en/\n\n\nMeningococcal Disease - Togo:\n-----------------------------\nSince [Sun 1 Jan 2017], 201 suspected cases of meningitis with 17 deaths were reported by 19 health districts. In week 2, the district of Akebou, which is part of the Plateau Region, issued an alert after 4 cases of meningitis were reported. In week 4, the epidemic threshold was reached with 9 cases and an attack rate of 12.4 per 100 000 inhabitants. From 2 January to 12 February 2017, 48 suspected meningitis cases with 3 deaths were reported (case fatality rate of 6.3 percent). Of these, 14 specimens were confirmed as _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup W by PCR.\n\nThe Plateau Region, together with the other 3 regions in the country benefited from the mass vaccination campaign with MenAfriVac in December 2014. [MenAfriVac is a protein conjugate vaccine developed for use in sub-Saharan Africa for children and adults between 9 months and 29 years of age against _Neisseria meningitidis_ group A (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MenAfriVac).]\n\nTogo is part of the African meningitis belt and documents cases and deaths due to meningitis every year. In 2016, the country recorded an epidemic in the northern part caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup W. A total of 1975 cases and 127 deaths were reported in 2016.\n\nIn response to the outbreak, the following measures are being implemented:\n- 56 000 doses of meningitis vaccines have been requested from the International Coordinating Group (ICG) for the planned vaccination campaign.\n- WHO Field Mission was deployed in the field to strengthen outbreak management.\n- Strengthening of meningitis surveillance at the district level.\n- Training of clinicians at the district level on case management.\n- Conducting cross-border meetings with Ghana and Benin.\n\nWHO risk assessment\n------------------\nThe largest burden of meningococcal disease occurs in the African meningitis belt. Although the successful roll-out of MenA conjugate vaccine has resulted in the decreasing trend of meningitis A, other meningococcal serogroups are shown to have caused epidemics. This report of the _Neisseria meningitidis_ W outbreak in Togo calls for a close monitoring of the changing epidemiology of meningococcal disease. There is a need to ensure that global stocks of vaccines are available, laboratory and epidemiologic surveillance systems are strengthened and outbreak response strategies in the countries are on hand.\n\nThe epidemic response consists of prompt, appropriate case management involving reactive mass vaccination of populations, and strengthening of meningitis surveillance.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Although there are at least 13 _ Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W are most common. There are vaccines that contain capsular polysaccharide (A, C, Y, W), either alone or conjugated to protein. Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines. Serogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen.\n\nImmunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide the vaccine contains in regard to the A, C, Y, and W polysaccharide vaccines or the surface proteins in regard to serogroup B vaccine, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal groups.\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population of a vaccine specific for one particular meningococcal serogroup, the incidence of disease due to that serogroup has been found to fall dramatically, e.g., serogroup C disease in the UK following the introduction of C vaccine and serogroup A in the African Meningitis Belt following A vaccine, only to be replaced by emergence of disease due to other meningococcal serogroups.\n\nIn view of replacement of meningococcal serogroup A with other serogroups, in the current case serogroup W, following mass vaccination of the population with serogroup A conjugate vaccine in Togo, reactive mass vaccination to control this outbreak would require use of a meningococcal vaccine containing serogroup W, e.g., the conjugate ACWY vaccine. However, the news article above fails to say what vaccine is being used.\n\nProMED-mail would appreciate more information in this regard from knowledgeable sources.\n\nTogo is a country in West Africa on the Gulf of Guinea, between Ghana to the west, Benin to the east. The country is divided into 5 regions; from north to south, the regions are Savanes, Kara, Centrale, Plateaux and Maritime (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Togo). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64.]", "summary": "Following the mass introduction into the population of a vaccine specific for one particular meningococcal serogroup, the incidence of disease due to that serogroup has been found to fall dramatically, e.g., serogroup C disease in the UK following the introduction of C vaccine and serogroup A in the African Meningitis Belt following A vaccine, only to be replaced by emergence of disease due to other meningococcal serogroups. In view of replacement of meningococcal serogroup A with other serogroups, in the current case serogroup W, following mass vaccination of the population with serogroup A conjugate vaccine in Togo, reactive mass vaccination to control this outbreak would require use of a meningococcal vaccine containing serogroup W, e.g., the conjugate ACWY vaccine. Immunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide the vaccine contains in regard to the A, C, Y, and W polysaccharide vaccines or the surface proteins in regard to serogroup B vaccine, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal groups. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - TOGO: FATAL, EMERGENCE OF SEROGROUP W\n*****************************************************************\n In response to the outbreak, the following measures are being implemented:\n- 56 000 doses of meningitis vaccines have been requested from the International Coordinating Group (ICG) for the planned vaccination campaign. Source: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/23-february-2017-meningococcal-disease-togo/en/\n\n\nMeningococcal Disease - Togo:\n----------------------------- Serogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. Although the successful roll-out of MenA conjugate vaccine has resulted in the decreasing trend of meningitis A, other meningococcal serogroups are shown to have caused epidemics. \n\nTogo is part of the African meningitis belt and documents cases and deaths due to meningitis every year. In 2016, the country recorded an epidemic in the northern part caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup W. A total of 1975 cases and 127 deaths were reported in 2016. The epidemic response consists of prompt, appropriate case management involving reactive mass vaccination of populations, and strengthening of meningitis surveillance. From 2 January to 12 February 2017, 48 suspected meningitis cases with 3 deaths were reported (case fatality rate of 6.3 percent).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1975-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-01-01 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-02-23 00:00:00", "2014-12-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Akebou", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4881298", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4881298", "date": "2017-03-05 21:31:13", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA: (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B, SEROGROUP B VACCINE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Oregonlive [edited]\nhttp://www.oregonlive.com/health/index.ssf/2017/03/osu_student_receiving_treatmen.html\n\n\nAn Oregon State University student being treated for meningitis is the 3rd to come down with the disease in the past 4 months.\n\nThe university and Benton County announced Thursday [2 Mar 2017] that an undergraduate student is being treated for the B strain of meningococcal disease at Good Samaritan Regional Medical Center in Corvallis. The student is in good condition, officials said.\n\nUniversity spokesman Steve Clark said school officials think the case is unrelated to the November 2016 cases, which weren't related to one another.\n\nCounty officials have identified people who had close personal contact with the student before he or she was taken to the hospital, Clark said. They were treated with a preventative medicine and didn't exhibit any signs of meningitis, as far as officials know.\n\nOfficials recommend all undergraduate students under 25 years old get vaccinated, per Centers for Control and Prevention advice. Clark especially urged students 25 and younger who live in congregate housing -- such as residence halls, Greek houses and private co-ops -- to get vaccinated.\n\nOfficials also urge people under 25 who visit such housing to get vaccinated.\n\nClark said about 5000 students live in student housing. As many as 2000 more students 25 and younger live in off-campus congregate housing, he said.\n\nThe university will host vaccination clinics at its McAlexander Fieldhouse next Wednesday and Thursday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. The clinics target students who are 25 and younger and live in congregate housing, Clark said, but the university won't turn anyone away.\n\n'We understand that news of this matter is concerning for our students and their families,' he said in a statement. 'While this is a serious matter, it is not emergency.'\n\nOregon children have not been routinely vaccinated against type B, the most common form of the disease in the state, causing an outbreak at the University of Oregon in 2015 and infecting the 2 students at OSU this past November [2016].\n\nSymptoms include fever, headache, weakness and rash. The bacteria can spread, inflaming tissue in the brain and around the spine. It's imperative to get quick treatment with antibiotics. The disease can be deadly. Between 2003 and 2007 in the United States, 500 people among 4100 died from meningitis, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nThe infection is spread by coughing and sneezing, sharing drinking, eating and smoking utensils, and intimate activity, officials said.\n\nOregon Senate Bill 274, which would require colleges and universities that provide student housing to give enrolling students information about vaccine-preventable diseases known to affect people between 16 and 21 years old, was introduced in January [2017]. It was referred to the Senate Committee on Education later that month.\n\n[Byline: Jim Ryan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 3 Mar 2017\nSource: KATU News [edited]\nhttp://katu.com/news/local/3rd-osu-student-hit-with-meningococcal-disease\n\n\nThe same strain of [_Neisseria meningitidis_, the bacterium that causes] meningococcal disease that infected 2 Oregon State University students last fall has sickened another student.\n\nThe Gazette-Times reports the student has been hospitalized in Corvallis since 23 Feb [2017] and is in good condition. The [2] students admitted to hospital for the same disease in November [2016] were later released.\n\nCharlie Fautin is the deputy director of the Benton County Health Department. He says health workers have identified 43 people who may have been exposed to the infected student and have treated them with antibiotics.\n\nThe Benton County Health Department also tells KATU News that they are now considering this an outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Joe Douglass]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Serogroups B, C, and Y are the major causes of meningococcal disease in the United States, each being responsible for about 1/3rd of cases (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm). In infants aged under one year, over 50 per cent of cases are caused by serogroup B, and in people over 11 years of age, 75 per cent are caused by serogroups (C, Y, or W). Serogroup B meningococci have also been responsible for several outbreaks and isolated cases on US college campuses in the last 5 years (http://www.nfid.org/idinfo/meningococcal/meningococcal-b-college-outbreaks.html).\n\nIn November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 OSU [Oregon State University] students in Corvallis were diagnosed with meningococcal disease due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B. According to the 1st news report above, meningococcus serogroup B was also isolated from a 3rd case of meningococcal meningitis on the Corvallis campus of OSU. The 'same strain' mentioned in the 2nd news report could mean that perhaps genotyping had been done that would indicate all 3 isolates are closely related genetically. More information in this regard would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nThe CDC defines an outbreak of meningococcal disease as the occurrence of 3 or more confirmed or probable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3 months, resulting in a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per 100 000 persons, which is approximately 10-fold greater than the normal occurrence http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm.\n\nOregon State University (OSU) is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). The university has a total student enrollment of 30 354, the largest among all Oregon universities.\n\nIn 2015, ProMED-mail reported that 6 cases of invasive serogroup B meningococcal disease occurred in students at the University of Oregon campus in Eugene, Oregon between 13 Jan 2015 and 19 Mar 2015 (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946). Eugene is 47 miles (75.6 km) south of Corvallis.\n\nA 7th case associated with the University of Oregon occurred in a father of a student who visited the campus in May 2015. Presumably, if he was infected with the outbreak strain, he must have had contact with someone on campus who was a persistent asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carrier over a month after the last student case. Five of the 6 student cases, including a case who died, had bloodstream meningococcal infections. At the time, the University of Oregon offered meningococcal serogroup B vaccination to the students.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n In 2015, ProMED-mail reported that 6 cases of invasive serogroup B meningococcal disease occurred in students at the University of Oregon campus in Eugene, Oregon between 13 Jan 2015 and 19 Mar 2015 (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. \n\nIn November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 OSU [Oregon State University] students in Corvallis were diagnosed with meningococcal disease due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B. \n\nOregon Senate Bill 274, which would require colleges and universities that provide student housing to give enrolling students information about vaccine-preventable diseases known to affect people between 16 and 21 years old, was introduced in January [2017]. \n\nOregon children have not been routinely vaccinated against type B, the most common form of the disease in the state, causing an outbreak at the University of Oregon in 2015 and infecting the 2 students at OSU this past November [2016]. The CDC defines an outbreak of meningococcal disease as the occurrence of 3 or more confirmed or probable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3 months, resulting in a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per 100 000 persons, which is approximately 10-fold greater than the normal occurrence http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm. The same strain of [_Neisseria meningitidis_, the bacterium that causes] meningococcal disease that infected 2 Oregon State University students last fall has sickened another student. \n\nClark said about 5000 students live in student housing. Source: Oregonlive [edited]\nhttp://www.oregonlive.com/health/index.ssf/2017/03/osu_student_receiving_treatmen.html\n\n\nAn Oregon State University student being treated for meningitis is the 3rd to come down with the disease in the past 4 months. \n\nUniversity spokesman Steve Clark said school officials think the case is unrelated to the November 2016 cases, which weren't related to one another. \n\nCounty officials have identified people who had close personal contact with the student before he or she was taken to the hospital, Clark said. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA: (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B, SEROGROUP B VACCINE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************************************************************************\n \n\nA 7th case associated with the University of Oregon occurred in a father of a student who visited the campus in May 2015. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Serogroups B, C, and Y are the major causes of meningococcal disease in the United States, each being responsible for about 1/3rd of cases (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm). \n\nOfficials recommend all undergraduate students under 25 years old get vaccinated, per Centers for Control and Prevention advice. The university and Benton County announced Thursday [2 Mar 2017] that an undergraduate student is being treated for the B strain of meningococcal disease at Good Samaritan Regional Medical Center in Corvallis. \n\nOfficials also urge people under 25 who visit such housing to get vaccinated. Clark especially urged students 25 and younger who live in congregate housing -- such as residence halls, Greek houses and private co-ops -- to get vaccinated. The clinics target students who are 25 and younger and live in congregate housing, Clark said, but the university won't turn anyone away. \n\nOregon State University (OSU) is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). \n\nThe Gazette-Times reports the student has been hospitalized in Corvallis since 23 Feb [2017] and is in good condition.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2021-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-02-23 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-11-26 00:00:00", "2015-05-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Eugene", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Benton County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4865078", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Malta: fatal, serogroup B, vaccine shortage", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4865078", "date": "2017-02-26 11:25:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - MALTA: FATAL, SEROGROUP B, VACCINE SHORTAGE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Feb 2017\nSource: Times of Malta [edited]\nhttp://www.com/articles/view/20170224/local/meningitis-b-vaccine-shortage-likely-to-persist.640542\n\n\nThe meningitis B vaccine shortage [is] likely to persist. Malta will have to wait its turn, manufacturers say. Global demand for the vaccine outstrips supply, manufacturers say.\n\nA one-year-old baby died of [meningococcal] meningitis [serogroup] B, a disease against which vaccines are currently unavailable, this newspaper is informed. Sources said the baby died last month [January 2017] after contracting the disease that affects the lining around the brain and spinal cord. The Central Procurement and Supplies Unit (CPSU) was informed that the local agent for the meningitis B vaccine had a stock of vaccines available in a number of local pharmacies, a Health Ministry spokeswoman said.\n\nThe representatives of international pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Malta were in liaison with their suppliers to hasten further delivery, and the CPSU was in liaison with both companies to monitor the situation, the spokeswoman added.\n\nThe ministry was also asked about the baby's death, but no reference was made to it in its reply late yesterday [23 Feb 2017] evening.\n\nThe government does not supply the vaccine against the specific strain that affected the infant, which can, however, be purchased from private hospitals and pharmacies. Paediatricians said private hospitals had purchased the vaccine from pharmacies abroad, but these too had since run out.\n\nAccording to one paediatrician, the unavailability of such a vaccine in light of the baby's death was very worrying, particularly to parents. Another paediatrician, however, warned against the matter getting out of hand, saying the issue was not as worrying as parents were making it out to be. Babies who were not vaccinated were not in any immediate danger, he said.\n\nA spokeswoman for the local representative of GSK confirmed that the vaccine was not available and it would not be for some time. She said no fixed date had yet been given as to when a supply would be made available to the local market. According to the spokeswoman, the vaccine was in high demand all over the world, and as GSK [GlaxoSmithKline] had agreements with a number of governments abroad, supplies would be shipped to these countries 1st. At present, demand exceeded the quantity manufactured.\n\n'It's important to understand that, in these cases, we need to stock enough for boosters, so before sufficient doses are available, this will not be made available,' the GSK spokeswoman said.\n\nAccording to the Maltese Paediatric Association, about 10 cases of meningitis have been reported among children. The signs of meningitis are fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, vomiting, dislike of bright light and drowsiness. Infants and younger children may not always show such symptoms but, instead, feed poorly or become very lethargic.\n\n[Byline: Claire Caruana]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although there are at least 13 _ Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W is most common. Meningococcal vaccines contain capsular polysaccharide for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A, C, Y, and W, either alone or conjugated to protein. The conjugate capsular polysaccharide vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines.\n\nSerogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. At least 2 serogroup B meningococcal vaccines -- Bexsero (GlaxoSmithKline, GSK) and Trumenba (Pfizer) -- are available.\n\nMeningococcal disease often occurs without warning and frequently progresses rapidly to death, even when it is treated appropriately. In addition, about 10-20 percent of survivors of meningococcal disease will suffer disabilities such as hearing loss, brain damage, and amputations. Vaccines are used to prevent meningococcal disease, not treat someone already ill from the disease. Immunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide the vaccine contains regarding the A, C, Y, and W polysaccharide or conjugate vaccines or the surface proteins regarding serogroup B vaccines, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal groups.\n\nVaccines are frequently used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in the face of an institutional or community outbreak (https://www.cdc.gov/meningococcal/downloads/interim-guidance.pdf). Antibiotics are also used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in persons who are at high risk because they have been in close contact (coughing or kissing) or lengthy contact, especially among people living in the same household.\n\nAccording to the 2017 Malta National Immunization Schedule, meningococcal vaccines are not included in the series of vaccines for infants and children (https://health.gov.mt/en/phc/pchyhi/Pages/National-Immunisation-Schedule.aspx). In the U.S., vaccination against meningococcal disease due to serogroups A, C, Y, and W is only recommended for children aged 2 months through 10 years who are at increased risk for meningococcal disease, i.e., have complement component deficiencies, have functional or anatomic asplenia (including sickle cell disease), are in the risk group for an outbreak for which vaccination is recommended, or are traveling to or residing in regions where meningitis is epidemic or hyper-endemic (for specifics, see Table at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6324a2.htm#Tab). The serogroup B vaccines Bexsero and Trumenba have been licensed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) only for individuals aged 10 through 25 years. However, the European Medicines Agency has approved Bexsero for use in individuals of 2 months of age and older, and Bexsero has been added to the routine childhood immunization schedule in the UK and Ireland (http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine).\n\nMalta, a member of the EU, is a southern European island country consisting of an archipelago in the Mediterranean Sea, 80 km (50 miles) south of Italy, with a population of just under 450 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malta). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/77.]", "summary": "In the U.S., vaccination against meningococcal disease due to serogroups A, C, Y, and W is only recommended for children aged 2 months through 10 years who are at increased risk for meningococcal disease, i.e., have complement component deficiencies, have functional or anatomic asplenia (including sickle cell disease), are in the risk group for an outbreak for which vaccination is recommended, or are traveling to or residing in regions where meningitis is epidemic or hyper-endemic (for specifics, see Table at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6324a2.htm#Tab). Immunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide the vaccine contains regarding the A, C, Y, and W polysaccharide or conjugate vaccines or the surface proteins regarding serogroup B vaccines, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal groups. The conjugate capsular polysaccharide vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines. \n\nA one-year-old baby died of [meningococcal] meningitis [serogroup] B, a disease against which vaccines are currently unavailable, this newspaper is informed. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although there are at least 13 _ Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W is most common. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nSerogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. \n\nVaccines are frequently used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in the face of an institutional or community outbreak (https://www.cdc.gov/meningococcal/downloads/interim-guidance.pdf). The Central Procurement and Supplies Unit (CPSU) was informed that the local agent for the meningitis B vaccine had a stock of vaccines available in a number of local pharmacies, a Health Ministry spokeswoman said. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - MALTA: FATAL, SEROGROUP B, VACCINE SHORTAGE\n************************************************************************\n Vaccines are used to prevent meningococcal disease, not treat someone already ill from the disease. According to the 2017 Malta National Immunization Schedule, meningococcal vaccines are not included in the series of vaccines for infants and children (https://health.gov.mt/en/phc/pchyhi/Pages/National-Immunisation-Schedule.aspx). \n\nMeningococcal disease often occurs without warning and frequently progresses rapidly to death, even when it is treated appropriately. Meningococcal vaccines contain capsular polysaccharide for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A, C, Y, and W, either alone or conjugated to protein. Antibiotics are also used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in persons who are at high risk because they have been in close contact (coughing or kissing) or lengthy contact, especially among people living in the same household.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-02-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2017-01-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4706311", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (09): (TC) fatal, sg. C, another case", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4706311", "date": "2016-12-18 12:51:49", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (09): (TUSCANY) FATAL, SEROGROUP C, ANOTHER CASE\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 17 Dec 2016\nFrom: Pasquale Urbano <pasquale.urbano@unifi.it> [edited]\n\n\nThe local press reports that a 4-year-old child from Pisa has been transferred to the Meyer Children's Hospital in Florence. The child is affected by _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C, the same that has been circulating in Tuscany since 2015, when it caused 31 cases of meningitis or sepsis; the present case is the 29th case in 2016.\n\nThe child is in critical condition. This case is particularly worrying because the child had been vaccinated, as were 12 others of the 60 in the current outbreak, which is occurring in a limited part of Tuscany, where a massive vaccination campaign has been launched.\n\nContacts of the case are being traced and treated according to protocols. So far, there has been no secondary case, and the organism seems to be circulating among healthy carriers.\n\n--\nPasquale Urbano\nFormerly: Dept. of Public Health\nUniversity of Florence\nFlorence, Italy\n<pasquale.urbano@unifi.it>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Prof. Urbano for his contributions on this persistent outbreak of meningococcal serogroup C in Tuscany, Italy.\n\nThe following is extracted from my comments in a prior ProMED-mail post, Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (05): (TC) fatal, sg C, more cases 20161024.4582016:\n\nMeningococcal conjugate vaccines (in which bacterial polysaccharide is conjugated to a protein carrier) have several advantages over polysaccharide vaccines, including the ability to induce greater antibody persistence, avidity, immunologic memory, reduced nasopharyngeal carriage of meningococci, and herd immunity, but protection induced by meningococcal vaccines is strictly serotype-specific. Meningococcal serogroup C conjugate (MCC) vaccine was introduced in the Tuscany regional immunization schedule in 2005, with 3 doses to all children at 3, 5, and 13 months of age, and at the national level, MCC was introduced in 2012.\n\nThe effectiveness of MCC vaccination given in infancy has been found to wane in UK studies after one year, but the numbers of cases of serogroup C disease in the population remained low (2,3) as a consequence of a reduction in the prevalence of serogroup C nasopharyngeal carriage after vaccination leading to high levels of herd protection (4). If herd protection wanes, many children may become vulnerable to infection (5).\n\nHowever, cohorts vaccinated at older ages seem to have greater and longer-lasting protection than those routinely vaccinated in infancy in the UK study. Prompted by the serogroup C outbreak, health officials promoted an MCC vaccination campaign in 2015 in adolescents and adults in the area where serogroup C _N. meningitidis_ disease was reported 2015, which was extended to the whole Tuscany Region and to the elderly in 2016.\n\n1. ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (04): (TC) fatal, sg C, genotype, epidemiology 20160325.4118731 (http://www.promedmail.org/post/4118731.\n2. http://www.sciencedirect.com.ezproxy2.library.drexel.edu/science/article/pii/S0140673604167251.\n3. https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Caroline_Trotter/publication/41894604_Updated_postlicensure_surveillance_of_the_meningococcal_C_conjugate_vaccine_in_England_and_Wales_effectiveness_validation_of_serological_correlates_of_protection_and_modeling_predictions_of_the_duration_of_herd_immunity/links/0c9605239774712235000000.pdf.\n4. http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(02)08679-8/abstract, http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/197/5/737.abstract.\n5. http://vaccinesafetyresource.elsevier.com/sites/default/files/Men-Borrow-Effectiveness.pdf.\n\nAlthough we are not told how long ago this 4-year-old child with invasive meningococcal serogroup C disease last received MCC vaccine, it was probably more than 3 years ago, when she received the series of 3 doses at 3, 5, and 13 months of age.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Italy can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/15523. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nThe following is extracted from my comments in a prior ProMED-mail post, Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (05): (TC) fatal, sg C, more cases 20161024.4582016:\n\nMeningococcal conjugate vaccines (in which bacterial polysaccharide is conjugated to a protein carrier) have several advantages over polysaccharide vaccines, including the ability to induce greater antibody persistence, avidity, immunologic memory, reduced nasopharyngeal carriage of meningococci, and herd immunity, but protection induced by meningococcal vaccines is strictly serotype-specific. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Formerly: Dept. of Public Health\nUniversity of Florence\nFlorence, Italy\n<pasquale.urbano@unifi.it>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Prof. Urbano for his contributions on this persistent outbreak of meningococcal serogroup C in Tuscany, Italy. \n\nAlthough we are not told how long ago this 4-year-old child with invasive meningococcal serogroup C disease last received MCC vaccine, it was probably more than 3 years ago, when she received the series of 3 doses at 3, 5, and 13 months of age. The effectiveness of MCC vaccination given in infancy has been found to wane in UK studies after one year, but the numbers of cases of serogroup C disease in the population remained low (2,3) as a consequence of a reduction in the prevalence of serogroup C nasopharyngeal carriage after vaccination leading to high levels of herd protection (4). MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (09): (TUSCANY) FATAL, SEROGROUP C, ANOTHER CASE\n**********************************************************************************\n Meningococcal serogroup C conjugate (MCC) vaccine was introduced in the Tuscany regional immunization schedule in 2005, with 3 doses to all children at 3, 5, and 13 months of age, and at the national level, MCC was introduced in 2012. Prompted by the serogroup C outbreak, health officials promoted an MCC vaccination campaign in 2015 in adolescents and adults in the area where serogroup C _N. meningitidis_ disease was reported 2015, which was extended to the whole Tuscany Region and to the elderly in 2016. \n\n--\nPasquale Urbano\n The child is affected by _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C, the same that has been circulating in Tuscany since 2015, when it caused 31 cases of meningitis or sepsis; the present case is the 29th case in 2016. This case is particularly worrying because the child had been vaccinated, as were 12 others of the 60 in the current outbreak, which is occurring in a limited part of Tuscany, where a massive vaccination campaign has been launched.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florence", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4808261", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Undiagnosed illness - Benin: (AL) fatal, children, meningitis excl, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4808261", "date": "2017-02-01 18:21:49", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - BENIN: (ALIBORI) FATAL, CHILDREN, MENINGITIS EXCLUDED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n****************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 14 Jan 2017\nSource: Benin WEB TV [in French, machine trans, edited]\nhttps://beninwebtv.com/2017/01/panique-a-malanville-alassane-seibou-rassure-depidemie-de-meningite/\n\n\nThe deaths of 4 schoolchildren from Madecali Center in the commune of Malanville [Alibori department] in December [2016] and beginning of the current year [2017] as a result of brutal headache without fever and followed by a brutal death the same day has been the subject of various interpretations. For many people, these deaths were due to a meningitis epidemic. Assertion [was] fed [by] social networks throughout the week.\n\nBut through a press statement made in his office on [Thu 12 Jan 2017], the Minister of Health, Alassane S\u00e9ibou, wanted to reassure the population. 'We are not in a situation of meningococcal meningitis epidemic ... Benin is not in an epidemic situation' said the minister to say that there was more fear than evil.\n\nAccording to Minister Alassane S\u00e9ibou, the teams in the health zone 'undertook systematic examinations of children and to date 22 children with similar signs of headache, fever have been identified and put [under] observation at the Malanville area hospital for care and follow-up.' At the end of the analyses according to the explanations provided by the Minister of Health, 'On the samples taken, the presence of Gram-positive diplococcus was obtained in a single child. The other samples are negative,' said the minister before concluding that the results obtained so far exclude the hypothesis of 'an epidemic of meningococcal meningitis.'\n\nHowever, the joint teams of the Ministry of Health of the departments of Borgou, Alibori, and the health zone of Malanville are working on the ground for further investigations.\n\n[Byline: Edouard Djogbenou]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland H\u00fcbner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Roland H\u00fcbner for the submission above that concerns an outbreak in Malanville, a city, arrondissement, and commune, with a population of 168 006 residents, in the Alibori Department of northeastern Benin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malanville). The illness was fatal in 4 children and was initially suspected to be bacterial meningitis, but a 'systematic investigation' that may have included examination of cerebrospinal fluid in 22 children was 'negative' in all but one patient, in whom the 'sample' revealed 'Gram-positive diplococci', which presumably is _Streptococcus pneumoniae_.\n\nThere is some confusion in the discription of the children's illness in the news report above; the 4 children who died had 'headache, without fever', but the other 22 ill children were said to have 'similar signs of headache, fever'. More information in this regard would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nDiagnoses in the other patients are not stated in the news report above, but Roland H\u00fcbner also submitted an article that was recently (in February 2017) published in the Lancet (http://www.thelancet.com/pdfs/journals/langlo/PIIS2214-109X(16)30287-X.pdf), which concerned an outbreak of suspected meningitis in the Democratic Republic of Congo in December 2014. Meningitis was initially suspected by health workers because of neck muscle spasm, but only 4 of 83 patients who underwent lumbar puncture had cerebrospinal fluid evidence of meningococcal meningitis. The outbreak was attributed to a dystonic reaction secondary to haloperidol, which patients had mistakenly taken when consuming tablets labeled fraudulently as diazepam, but which in fact contained undeclared haloperidol.\n\nDystonic reactions are characterized by intermittent spasmodic or sustained involuntary contractions of muscles in the face, neck, trunk, pelvis, or extremities that can result in stiff neck, tongue protrusion, lockjaw, facial grimacing, or eye deviation, most often associated with use of antiemetics, antidepressants, and antipsychotics, such as haloperidol (http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/814632-clinical). These reactions are more common in children and young adults. Dystonic reactions are treated with benztropine (Cogentin) or diphenhydramine (Benadryl). Diazepam may also be useful, but diazepam has been found rarely to cause an acute dystonic reaction (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3065401).\n\nA drug-related dystonic reaction maybe the cause of the outbreak in Benin; its diagnosis will require a thorough history of drug use. Substandard and falsified medicines pose a serious threat to public health worldwide, but are especially a problem in developing countries (http://cmr.asm.org/content/28/2/443.full, http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4137817/, and http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK202527/). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/41803.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThere is some confusion in the discription of the children's illness in the news report above; the 4 children who died had 'headache, without fever', but the other 22 ill children were said to have 'similar signs of headache, fever'. Brussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Roland H\u00fcbner for the submission above that concerns an outbreak in Malanville, a city, arrondissement, and commune, with a population of 168 006 residents, in the Alibori Department of northeastern Benin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malanville). The illness was fatal in 4 children and was initially suspected to be bacterial meningitis, but a 'systematic investigation' that may have included examination of cerebrospinal fluid in 22 children was 'negative' in all but one patient, in whom the 'sample' revealed 'Gram-positive diplococci', which presumably is _Streptococcus pneumoniae_. \n\nDystonic reactions are characterized by intermittent spasmodic or sustained involuntary contractions of muscles in the face, neck, trunk, pelvis, or extremities that can result in stiff neck, tongue protrusion, lockjaw, facial grimacing, or eye deviation, most often associated with use of antiemetics, antidepressants, and antipsychotics, such as haloperidol (http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/814632-clinical). According to Minister Alassane S\u00e9ibou, the teams in the health zone 'undertook systematic examinations of children and to date 22 children with similar signs of headache, fever have been identified and put [under] observation at the Malanville area hospital for care and follow-up.' Meningitis was initially suspected by health workers because of neck muscle spasm, but only 4 of 83 patients who underwent lumbar puncture had cerebrospinal fluid evidence of meningococcal meningitis. \n\nDiagnoses in the other patients are not stated in the news report above, but Roland H\u00fcbner also submitted an article that was recently (in February 2017) published in the Lancet (http://www.thelancet.com/pdfs/journals/langlo/PIIS2214-109X(16)30287-X.pdf), which concerned an outbreak of suspected meningitis in the Democratic Republic of Congo in December 2014. The deaths of 4 schoolchildren from Madecali Center in the commune of Malanville [Alibori department] in December [2016] and beginning of the current year [2017] as a result of brutal headache without fever and followed by a brutal death the same day has been the subject of various interpretations. \n\nA drug-related dystonic reaction maybe the cause of the outbreak in Benin; its diagnosis will require a thorough history of drug use. The outbreak was attributed to a dystonic reaction secondary to haloperidol, which patients had mistakenly taken when consuming tablets labeled fraudulently as diazepam, but which in fact contained undeclared haloperidol.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-01-12 00:00:00", "2021-12-26 00:00:00", "2017-02-26 00:00:00", "2014-12-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Borgou", "country": "Benin"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malanville", "country": "Benin"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "CHILDREN", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Malanville", "country": "Benin"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4756272", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - UK: emergence of serogroup W, changed vaccine policy", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4756272", "date": "2017-01-11 10:46:49", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - UK: EMERGENCE OF SEROGROUP W, CHANGED VACCINE POLICY\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 10 Jan 2017\nSource: Eagle Radio [edited]\nhttp://www.964eagle.co.uk/news/local-news/2194701/deadly-meningitis-strain-is-on-the-rise/\n\n\nThere is a warning about a strain of meningitis hitting students returning to university in Surrey and Hampshire [UK]. There is growing concern about Men-W, which is increasingly affecting young adults. Meningitis has serious consequences and can prove fatal. Charity Meningitis Now is urging all students returning to university after the Christmas and New Year break to make themselves aware of the signs and symptoms of meningitis and to take up a free vaccine. Cases of the killer disease peak during the winter months, and students are a high-risk group.\n\nThe charity's acting chief executive Rachel Robinson said: 'The ability to recognise meningitis and septicaemia quickly can save lives. 'The sooner you can get medical help, the less likely it is to become life-threatening. That's why learning the signs and symptoms is so important.' Early symptoms such as fever, headache, nausea, vomiting and muscle pain are very similar to flu or even a hangover, but someone with meningitis or septicaemia can get a lot worse very quickly. More specific signs and symptoms to look out for include fever with cold hands and feet, drowsiness, confusion, pale blotchy skin, stiff neck, dislike of bright lights, and a rash which doesn't fade under pressure.\n\nRachel added: 'Prevention is also vital, which is why we're also encouraging all eligible young people to take up the free vaccine for Men ACWY. 'Hopefully our ongoing campaign will encourage more of them to take this simple and potentially lifesaving step.' Men ACWY immunisation was added to the national programme in August 2015 following advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation (JCVI) in response to the rising number of meningococcal W (Men-W) cases. But figures from Public Health England show that just 11.1 percent of 18-year-olds eligible to get the Men ACWY vaccine between April and July last year [2016] had taken up the offer, leaving about half a million young people in England in this age group still at risk from the disease.\n\nFor more information, visit the Meningitis Now website. Freephone helpline: 0808 80 10 388.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The incidence of invasive disease due to meningococcal serogroup W (Men W) has been found to have increased 88% between 2014 and 2015 in the UK (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - UK: emergence of serogroup W, changed vaccine policy 20150926.3673122). Between July 2013 and June 2014, just 98 cases were reported in England and Wales, but 184 cases were reported between July 2014-June 2015, at which time, Men W accounted for 15 per cent of all meningococcal disease. In 2009, Men W accounted for only 1-2 percent of all meningococcal cases in the UK. The strain of Men W (ST-11) is particularly virulent, causing more severe illness and a higher case fatality rate.\n\nThe vaccination schedule in the UK had been as follows: At 2 months of age, babies were given meningococcal serogroup B (Men B) vaccine; at 3 months of age, Men C vaccine; at 4 months, a 2nd dose of Men B; at 12-13 months, a 3rd dose of Men B and a 2nd dose of Men C in a combined vaccine with _Haemophilus influenzae_ type b (Hib); and at 13-18 years of age and 1st-time university students, meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y (Men ACWY) vaccine (http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/vaccinations/Pages/men-c-vaccine.aspx).\n\nSince the Men C vaccine was introduced in 1999, the Men C disease has been virtually eliminated in the UK. Nowadays, there are just a handful of Men C cases each year, mainly in older, unvaccinated adults (http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/vaccinations/Pages/men-c-vaccine.aspx). However, the near elimination of Men C as a consequence of the Men C conjugate vaccine program in the UK has been followed by the emergence of a 'replacement' pathogen, Men W. Consequently, starting on 1 Jul 2016, the dose of Men C vaccine that had been offered to babies at 3 months of age has been removed from the vaccination schedule (http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/vaccinations/Pages/men-c-vaccine.aspx). All children will continue to be offered the Hib/Men C vaccine at one year of age, and the tetravalent Men ACWY vaccine at 14 years of age, and students up to the age of 25 1st going to university, to prevent Men W disease (http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/vaccinations/Pages/men-acwy-vaccine.aspx).\n\nSouth East England is the most populous of the 9 official regions of England and includes the counties of Hampshire, Surrey, Berkshire, Buckinghamshire, East Sussex, the Isle of Wight, Kent, Oxfordshire, and West Sussex. A map of the counties of England can be found at http://www.picturesofengland.com/mapofengland/counties-map.html. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40.]", "summary": "At 2 months of age, babies were given meningococcal serogroup B (Men B) vaccine; at 3 months of age, Men C vaccine; at 4 months, a 2nd dose of Men B; at 12-13 months, a 3rd dose of Men B and a 2nd dose of Men C in a combined vaccine with _Haemophilus influenzae_ type b (Hib); and at 13-18 years of age and 1st-time university students, meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y (Men ACWY) vaccine (http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/vaccinations/Pages/men-c-vaccine.aspx). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n But figures from Public Health England show that just 11.1 percent of 18-year-olds eligible to get the Men ACWY vaccine between April and July last year [2016] had taken up the offer, leaving about half a million young people in England in this age group still at risk from the disease.
