'", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-01-10 00:00:00", "2014-06-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-08-26 00:00:00", "1999-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Berkshire", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Sussex", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hampshire", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Surrey", "country": "Jamaica"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Buckinghamshire", "country": "United Kingdom"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4733476", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (10): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4733476", "date": "2016-12-30 17:03:19", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (10): FATAL\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 28 Dec 2016\nSource: ANSA [edited]\nhttp://www.ansa.it/english/news/general_news/2016/12/28/28-tuscany-meningitis-cases-in-2016_97b796bb-0870-4b02-9884-555f563376df.html\n\n\nAs many as 59 cases of meningitis C have been registered in Tuscany from 2015 to today, authorities said Wednesday [28 Dec 2016] after a Rome elementary-school teacher became the latest victim of the virus [_Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of meningococcal meningitis is a bacterium, not a virus]: 31 last year [2015] and 28 this year [2016].\n\n12 people have died of meningitis, 6 this year and 6 last, they said. To these must be added a death from meningitis B and the death of a patient affected by another strain, pneumococcal meningitis. The greatest incidence of the virus [sic] was in the 20-29-year-old age bracket, followed by the 0-19-year-old [age] bracket. Only in 19 cases the persons affected were more than 40 years of age. But the average age of those who died was 52 [years].\n\nTuscany has seen more meningitis deaths than any other Italian region.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 30 Dec 2016\nFrom: Pasquale Urbano <rbnpql@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\nThe most alarming case is that of a 22-month-old child from Porcari, province of Lucca, Tuscany, who died while being transferred to the Meyer Children's Hospital of Florence where the causal agent was identified as _Neisseria meningitidis_, type C, strain st11. The child had not been vaccinated against meningococcus, notwithstanding the reiterated offers to do so, in the course of the campaign launched by the Tuscan health service in an effort to curb the morbidity by the hypervirulent strain which, since 2015, has already caused 60 cases in a limited part of the region, with 7 deaths.\n\nTwo other fatal cases occurred in the province of Naples, Campania: an 18-year-old in Agerola and a 46-year-old in Naples. The news reported that _N. meningitidis_ was involved in the youngster.\n\nA further, unrelated case of meningitis has been reported in a 34-year-old Peruvian woman residing in Chiavari, province of Genova, Liguria, presently in critical condition at the San Martino hospital of Genoa.\n\nIn the past week, the death from meningitis at the Gemelli hospital of Rome, of a primary school teacher, had activated the protocol for the tracing and prophylaxis of the contacts, which was stopped after the agent involved was identified as _Escherichia coli_.\n\nReferences [in Italian]:\n\nhttp://www.lastampa.it/2016/12/29/italia/cronache/altri-due-casi-di-meningite-dopo-quello-di-roma-muore-un-enne-nel-napoletano-rmq9xbs7hQqqQPz7H1TFcP/pagina.html\n\nhttp://firenze.repubblica.it/cronaca/2016/12/29/news/firenze_bambino_muore_di_meningite_c_non_era_vaccinato-155044879/?ref=HREC1-5\n\nhttp://corrierefiorentino.corriere.it/firenze/notizie/cronaca/16_dicembre_30/muore-meningite-fulminante-d6818b66-ce6d-11e6-b534-47d649da6f06.shtml\n\nhttp://corrieredelmezzogiorno.corriere.it/napoli/cronaca/16_dicembre_30/napoli-ha-febbre-alta-muore-caso-sospetta-meningite-39a4b794-ce74-11e6-b534-47d649da6f06.shtml\n\n--\nPasquale Urbano\nFormerly: Dept. of Public Health, University of Florence\nFlorence, Italy\n<rbnpql@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Prof. Urbano for his updates on meningococcal meningitis in Italy. - The greatest incidence of the virus [sic] was in the 20-29-year-old age bracket, followed by the 0-19-year-old [age] bracket.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-12-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "st11", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chiavari", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Campania", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Agerola", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Porcari", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Naples", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Genoa", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Lucca", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Rome", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Genova", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Liguria", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4649319", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4649319", "date": "2016-11-23 12:58:23", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (02): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B, SEROGROUP B VACCINE\n****************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 21 Nov 2016\nSource: Corvallis Gazette-Times [edited]\nhttp://www.gazettetimes.com/news/local/second-case-of-strain-b-confirmed/article_110ea1b1-53dd-5865-9a06-565ee27312d8.html\n\n\nTwo OSU [Oregon State University] students have been diagnosed with meningococcal disease strain [serogroup] B. Both cases involve Oregon State University students who are being treated for the disease at Good Samaritan Regional Medical Center in Corvallis, and both were reportedly in good condition on [Mon 21 Nov 2016].\n\nTest results established the 1st case was strain [serogroup] B, but testing of the 2nd patient late last week [week of 14 Nov 2016] was inconclusive. Over the weekend [19-20 Nov 2016], a 2nd test performed by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta determined that patient was infected with the same strain [serogroup] of the disease, according to Lili'a Neville, public information officer for Benton County. No additional cases have been diagnosed, Neville said.\n\nOn [Fri 18 Nov 2016], OSU Student Health Services began offering vaccinations against the B strain [serogroup] of the disease to students under 25 [years of age] and is continuing to do so. 'We'll be communicating to students as they leave (campus) for the Thanksgiving [24 Nov 2016] holiday to continue to watch for symptoms,' said Steve Clark, OSU's vice president for marketing and university relations.\n\nMeningococcal disease primarily afflicts young people. Most incoming students at OSU are required to be inoculated against 4 of the most common variants of the disease, but that vaccine does not protect against the B strain [serogroup].\n\nWhile the disease is not highly contagious, it is dangerous and can be fatal. To spread, it generally requires close contact with an infected person for a cumulative total of at least 4 hours. OSU and county health officials have been working to identify people who may have been exposed to the infected students and treat them with antibiotics as a preventative measure. 'We have about 230 on our list,' said Charlie Fautin, deputy administrator of the Benton County Health Department. He said most of those people had been contacted and given antibiotics, but others have not yet been located.\n\nSymptoms of meningococcal disease include high fever, headache, stiff neck, exhaustion, nausea, rash, vomiting, and diarrhea. Anyone experiencing these symptoms is advised to seek medical attention right away.\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease at the University of Oregon early last year [2015] made 7 people sick and killed one student.\n\nVaccinations against meningococcal disease-B are available locally beyond the OSU campus, Neville said, but they require a doctor's prescription.\n\n[byline: Bennett Hall]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Serogroups B, C, and Y are the major causes of meningococcal disease in the United States, each being responsible for about a third of cases (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm). In infants aged under 1 year, over 50 per cent of cases are caused by serogroup B and in people over 11 years of age, 75 per cent are caused by serogroups (C, Y, or W-135). Serogroup B meningococci have also been responsible for several outbreaks and isolated cases on US college campuses in the last 5 years (http://www.nfid.org/idinfo/meningococcal/meningococcal-b-college-outbreaks.html).\n\nIn the current outbreak on the Corvallis campus of Oregon State University, genotyping will need to be done to establish if the strains of serogroup B meningococci isolated from the 2 student cases are closely related, which would establish an outbreak strain.\n\nOregon State University (OSU) is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). The university has a total student enrollment of 30 354, the largest among all Oregon universities.\n\nLast year (2015) ProMED-mail reported that 6 cases of invasive serogroup B meningococcal disease occurred in students at the University of Oregon campus in Eugene, Oregon, between 13 Jan 2015 and 19 Mar 2015 (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946). Eugene is 47 miles (75.6 km) south of Corvallis. A 7th case associated with the University of Oregon occurred in a father of a student who visited the campus in May 2015. Presumably, if he was infected with the outbreak strain, he must have had contact with someone on campus who was a persistent asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carrier over a month after the last student case. 5 of the 6 student cases, including a case who died, had bloodstream meningococcal infections. At the time, the University of Oregon offered meningococcal serogroup B vaccination to the students. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Bennett Hall]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Serogroups B, C, and Y are the major causes of meningococcal disease in the United States, each being responsible for about a third of cases (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm). \n\nLast year (2015) ProMED-mail reported that 6 cases of invasive serogroup B meningococcal disease occurred in students at the University of Oregon campus in Eugene, Oregon, between 13 Jan 2015 and 19 Mar 2015 (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. \n\n\nTwo OSU [Oregon State University] students have been diagnosed with meningococcal disease strain [serogroup] B. Both cases involve Oregon State University students who are being treated for the disease at Good Samaritan Regional Medical Center in Corvallis, and both were reportedly in good condition on [Mon 21 Nov 2016]. \n\nIn the current outbreak on the Corvallis campus of Oregon State University, genotyping will need to be done to establish if the strains of serogroup B meningococci isolated from the 2 student cases are closely related, which would establish an outbreak strain. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Over the weekend [19-20 Nov 2016], a 2nd test performed by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta determined that patient was infected with the same strain [serogroup] of the disease, according to Lili'a Neville, public information officer for Benton County. \n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease at the University of Oregon early last year [2015] made 7 people sick and killed one student. On [Fri 18 Nov 2016], OSU Student Health Services began offering vaccinations against the B strain [serogroup] of the disease to students under 25 [years of age] and is continuing to do so. ' MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (02): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B, SEROGROUP B VACCINE\n****************************************************************************************\n \n\nVaccinations against meningococcal disease-B are available locally beyond the OSU campus, Neville said, but they require a doctor's prescription. \n\nSymptoms of meningococcal disease include high fever, headache, stiff neck, exhaustion, nausea, rash, vomiting, and diarrhea. Most incoming students at OSU are required to be inoculated against 4 of the most common variants of the disease, but that vaccine does not protect against the B strain [serogroup].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-05-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-11-24 00:00:00", "2016-11-14 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Benton County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Eugene", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4582016", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (05): (TC) fatal, sg C, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4582016", "date": "2016-10-24 20:25:48", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (05): (TUSCANY) FATAL, SEROGROUP C, MORE CASES\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 23 Oct 2016\nFrom: Pasquale Urbano <micro@unifi.it> [edited]\n\n\n[La Repubblica] reports that a new case of type C meningococcal meningitis is now in the intensive care unit of the Prato hospital [1]. The local health unit has offered antibiotic prophylaxis to all possible contacts.\n\nThe case is particularly worrying because the young man had been recently vaccinated against _N. meningitis_ type C in the campaign set up by the Tuscany Region in an effort to curb the meningitis morbidity peak, which reached 31 cases in 2015 and 23 so far in 2016. The present case is the 10th that has occurred in vaccinated people, which raises doubts on the protective efficacy of the vaccine.\n\n[La Repubblica also reported that] Rino Rappuoli, credited as the developer of the conjugated vaccine, pointed out in an interview with the newspaper that 7 of the 10 cases had been vaccinated more than 5 years earlier and suggested that a recall could be advisable every 5 years [2].\n\n[1. La Repubblica, 21 Oct 2016 (in Italian, translated by Pasquale Urbano, edited):\nhttp://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2016/10/21/contagiato-a-20-anni-era-vaccinatoFirenze01.html?ref=search.\n\n2. La Repubblica, 22 Oct 2016 (in Italian, translated by Pasquale Urbano, edited):\nhttp://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2016/10/22/vaccino-meningite-il-richiamo-va-fatto-ogni-cinque-anniFirenze01.html?ref=search.]\n\n--\nProf. Pasquale Urbano\nUniversity of Florence (retired)\nFlorence, Italy\n<micro@unifi.it>\n\n[The total number of cases of invasive meningococcal disease caused by serogroup C in Tuscany, Italy since January 2015 is now 54, with 31 cases in 2015, and 23 so far in 2016, compared to 2 cases in 2014 and 3 in 2013. When last reported by ProMED-mail in March 2016, there were a total of 43 cases; 18 of the 43 patients had sepsis only; 14 had sepsis and meningitis; 11 had meningitis only; 10 patients died; there were no secondary cases; and 35 of the 43 strains belonged to C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:ST-11(cc11) (1). (Meningococcal serogroup C cc11 strains are known to cause invasive disease burden worldwide and are responsible for high mortality rates among cases.) The median age of the 43 cases in the Tuscany outbreak was 28 years (range: 9-82); 18 of the 43 cases were over 30 years old, and 11 were over 55 years old.\n\nMeningococcal conjugate vaccines (in which bacterial polysaccharide is conjugated to a protein carrier) have several advantages over polysaccharide vaccines, including the ability to induce greater antibody persistence, avidity, immunologic memory, reduced nasopharyngeal carriage of meningococci, and herd immunity, but protection induced by meningococcal vaccines is strictly serotype-specific. Meningococcal serogroup C conjugate (MCC) vaccine was introduced in the Tuscany regional immunization schedule in 2005, with 3 doses to all children at 3, 5, and 13 months of age, and at the national level, MCC was introduced in 2012.\n\nThe effectiveness of MCC vaccination given in infancy has been found to wane in UK studies after one year, but the numbers of cases of serogroup C disease in the population remained low (2,3) as a consequence of a reduction in the prevalence of serogroup C nasopharyngeal carriage after vaccination leading to high levels of herd protection (4). If herd protection wanes, many children may become vulnerable to infection (5). However, cohorts vaccinated at older ages seem to have greater and longer-lasting protection than those routinely vaccinated in infancy in the UK study. Prompted by the serogroup C outbreak, health officials promoted an MCC vaccination campaign in 2015 in adolescents and adults in the area where serogroup C _N. meningitidis_ disease was reported 2015, which was extended to the whole Tuscany Region and to the elderly in 2016.\n\n1. ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (04): (TC) fatal, sg C, genotype, epidemiology 20160325.4118731 (http://www.promedmail.org/post/4118731.\n2. http://www.sciencedirect.com.ezproxy2.library.drexel.edu/science/article/pii/S0140673604167251.\n3. https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Caroline_Trotter/publication/41894604_Updated_postlicensure_surveillance_of_the_meningococcal_C_conjugate_vaccine_in_England_and_Wales_effectiveness_validation_of_serological_correlates_of_protection_and_modeling_predictions_of_the_duration_of_herd_immunity/links/0c9605239774712235000000.pdf.\n4. http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(02)08679-8/abstract, http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/197/5/737.abstract.\n5. http://vaccinesafetyresource.elsevier.com/sites/default/files/Men-Borrow-Effectiveness.pdf. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/75.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n When last reported by ProMED-mail in March 2016, there were a total of 43 cases; 18 of the 43 patients had sepsis only; 14 had sepsis and meningitis; 11 had meningitis only; 10 patients died; there were no secondary cases; and 35 of the 43 strains belonged to C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:ST-11(cc11) (1). [The total number of cases of invasive meningococcal disease caused by serogroup C in Tuscany, Italy since January 2015 is now 54, with 31 cases in 2015, and 23 so far in 2016, compared to 2 cases in 2014 and 3 in 2013. La Repubblica, 22 Oct 2016 (in Italian, translated by Pasquale Urbano, edited):\nhttp://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2016/10/22/vaccino-meningite-il-richiamo-va-fatto-ogni-cinque-anniFirenze01.html?ref=search.]\n\n--\nProf. Pasquale Urbano\n \n\nThe case is particularly worrying because the young man had been recently vaccinated against _N. meningitis_ type C in the campaign set up by the Tuscany Region in an effort to curb the meningitis morbidity peak, which reached 31 cases in 2015 and 23 so far in 2016. The effectiveness of MCC vaccination given in infancy has been found to wane in UK studies after one year, but the numbers of cases of serogroup C disease in the population remained low (2,3) as a consequence of a reduction in the prevalence of serogroup C nasopharyngeal carriage after vaccination leading to high levels of herd protection (4). \n\nMeningococcal conjugate vaccines (in which bacterial polysaccharide is conjugated to a protein carrier) have several advantages over polysaccharide vaccines, including the ability to induce greater antibody persistence, avidity, immunologic memory, reduced nasopharyngeal carriage of meningococci, and herd immunity, but protection induced by meningococcal vaccines is strictly serotype-specific. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (05): (TUSCANY) FATAL, SEROGROUP C, MORE CASES\n********************************************************************************\n The median age of the 43 cases in the Tuscany outbreak was 28 years (range: 9-82); 18 of the 43 cases were over 30 years old, and 11 were over 55 years old. [La Repubblica also reported that] Rino Rappuoli, credited as the developer of the conjugated vaccine, pointed out in an interview with the newspaper that 7 of the 10 cases had been vaccinated more than 5 years earlier and suggested that a recall could be advisable every 5 years [2]. Prompted by the serogroup C outbreak, health officials promoted an MCC vaccination campaign in 2015 in adolescents and adults in the area where serogroup C _N. meningitidis_ disease was reported 2015, which was extended to the whole Tuscany Region and to the elderly in 2016. Meningococcal serogroup C conjugate (MCC) vaccine was introduced in the Tuscany regional immunization schedule in 2005, with 3 doses to all children at 3, 5, and 13 months of age, and at the national level, MCC was introduced in 2012.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2054-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-01-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "1982-09-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Tuscany", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4513543", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. W", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4513543", "date": "2016-09-25 12:56:52", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (03): (WESTERN AUSTRALIA) SEROGROUP W\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 24 Sep 2016\nSource: The West Australian [edited]\nhttps://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/wa/a/32713148/rare-strain-of-bacteria-on-the-rise/#page1\n\n\n3/4ths of the cases of meningococcal disease in WA [Western Australia] so far this year [2016] have been caused by rare W strains [_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup W] that very few people are vaccinated against. Figures obtained by The Weekend West show 9 of the 12 cases of the disease this year have been linked to strains from the bacteria group W. Type B [_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B] caused the other 3.\n\nMeningococcal disease is a rare, life-threatening illness caused by a bacterial infection of the blood or the membranes that line the spinal cord and brain.\n\nA young WA child -- the 12th case this year [2016] -- died from the disease last week. In the past, there have been virtually no local cases caused by W strains, but there were 2 in 2014, 4 cases last year [2015] and 9 this year. The WA Health Department said this week it was monitoring the trend, which was also being seen in states including Victoria and could have implications for vaccination recommendations.\n\nVictorian authorities have seen a sharp rise in a group W strain known as ST11, which was responsible for 4 per cent of meningococcal cases in 2013 but 30 percent of cases last year [2015].\n\nAt present, a vaccine to protect against type C meningococcal disease, historically the most common in Australia, is free for children and given at 12 months [of age]. A vaccine against meningococcal B, the most common type in WA [the 1st paragraph above says that this year [2016] serogroup W, not serogroup B, is the most common serogroup], is available but not government-funded. There is a privately funded vaccine against W strains, but it is usually only advised for overseas travellers.\n\nThe Health Department spokesman said that while the overall number of invasive meningococcal disease cases in WA had been falling since 2000, there had been a recent increase in cases linked to W strains.\n\nThe Telethon Kids Institute is doing a trial of a vaccine against the A, C, W and Y strains in young children.\n\n[Byline: Cathy O'Leary]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Neisseria meningitidis_ only infects humans; there is no animal reservoir, and the organism dies quickly outside the human host. _N. meningitidis_ colonizes the mucosal membranes of the nose and throat; up to 5-10 percent of a population may be asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers, but the carrier rate may be higher in epidemic situations. Droplets of nasopharyngeal secretions from these carriers are responsible for the spread of the disease. Close and prolonged contact with an infected person or a carrier facilitates the spread of the disease. The average incubation period is 4 days but can range between 2 and 10 days.\n\nImmunity following use of a meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide that the vaccine contains, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups. Although there are at least 13 _N. meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135 are most common.\n\nThere are vaccines that contain capsular polysaccharide (A, C, Y, W135), either alone or conjugated to protein. Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines. Serogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen.\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population of a vaccine specific for one particular serogroup, the incidence of disease due to that serogroup has been found to fall dramatically, e.g., serogroup C disease in the UK following the introduction of C vaccine and serogroup A in the African Meningitis Belt following A vaccine, only to be replaced by emergence of disease due to other meningococcal serogroups.\n\nSimilarly, serotype replacement has been observed following pneumococcal vaccination programs, which necessitated expansion of serotypes covered by the vaccine (see ProMED-mail post Streptococcus pneumoniae, non-vaccine strain emergence - USA (AK) 20070425.1348).\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroup W ST-11 as a cause of invasive meningococcal disease in the UK, the UK is now offering an expanded conjugated serogroup vaccine, Men ACWY, for adolescents, who are more likely to carry meningococcal bacteria than any other age group, to stop the spread of serogroup W. This is being done by replacing the routine teenage Men C booster with the Men ACWY vaccine (http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/vaccinations/Pages/men-acwy-vaccine.aspx).\n\nWestern Australia, covering the entire western 1/3rd of Australia, is mostly arid, its population being concentrated in the fertile southwest corner and its capital, Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Australia). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/289.]", "summary": "Following the mass introduction into the population of a vaccine specific for one particular serogroup, the incidence of disease due to that serogroup has been found to fall dramatically, e.g., serogroup C disease in the UK following the introduction of C vaccine and serogroup A in the African Meningitis Belt following A vaccine, only to be replaced by emergence of disease due to other meningococcal serogroups. Because of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroup W ST-11 as a cause of invasive meningococcal disease in the UK, the UK is now offering an expanded conjugated serogroup vaccine, Men ACWY, for adolescents, who are more likely to carry meningococcal bacteria than any other age group, to stop the spread of serogroup A vaccine against meningococcal B, the most common type in WA [the 1st paragraph above says that this year [2016] serogroup W, not serogroup B, is the most common serogroup], is available but not government-funded. Immunity following use of a meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide that the vaccine contains, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups. https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/wa/a/32713148/rare-strain-of-bacteria-on-the-rise/#page1\n\n\n3/4ths of the cases of meningococcal disease in WA [Western Australia] so far this year [2016] have been caused by rare W strains [_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup W] that very few people are vaccinated against. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe Health Department spokesman said that while the overall number of invasive meningococcal disease cases in WA had been falling since 2000, there had been a recent increase in cases linked to W strains. \n\nVictorian authorities have seen a sharp rise in a group W strain known as ST11, which was responsible for 4 per cent of meningococcal cases in 2013 but 30 percent of cases last year [2015]. Figures obtained by The Weekend West show 9 of the 12 cases of the disease this year have been linked to strains from the bacteria group W. Type B [_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B] caused the other 3. \n\nAt present, a vaccine to protect against type C meningococcal disease, historically the most common in Australia, is free for children and given at 12 months [of age]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Neisseria meningitidis_ only infects humans; there is no animal reservoir, and the organism dies quickly outside the human host. \n\nMeningococcal disease is a rare, life-threatening illness caused by a bacterial infection of the blood or the membranes that line the spinal cord and brain.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Perth", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4464322", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Syria: refugee, susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4464322", "date": "2016-09-04 13:07:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - SYRIA: REFUGEE, SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 2 Sep 2016\nSource: Daily Mail Online [edited]\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-3771229/Six-suspected-meningitis-cases-near-Damascus.html\n\n\nSix suspected cases of meningitis have been identified in a Syrian town near Damascus that is under siege by government forces, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Friday [2 Sep 2016]. The suspected cases were diagnosed in the town of Madaya between 3-30 Aug 2016. WHO has already evacuated 2 of those infected, a child and an adolescent. The UN agency said it was in contact with health officials about sending medicines and organising the evacuation of the other 4 suspected cases.\n\nAn activist in Madaya, Abdel Wahab Ahmed, who works at a health facility in the town, told AFP that the mother and 2 sisters of the evacuated child had also become infected. 'The family has been placed in medical isolation in their home after 2 weeks of treatment with the only medicines available failed,' he said.\n\nSeveral cases of meningitis are reported every week, according to WHO. Most of them are viral forms of the disease, which tend to be less severe than the bacterial form. WHO was not in a position to say on Friday [2 Sep 2016] which type of meningitis was suspected in Madaya.\n\nOn 19 Aug 2016, the Red Crescent evacuated 18 people, including 13 sick children from Madaya, according to a doctor who treated the children. Among the children was a 10 year old boy who had been suffering from meningitis for a month. Under a September 2015 accord, all evacuations from the government-besieged towns of Madaya and Zabadani have to be done in parallel with similar evacuations from Fuaa and Kafraya.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 3 Sep 2016\nSource: en.zamanalwsl.net [edited]\nhttps://en.zamanalwsl.net/news/17807.html\n\n\nDoctor Mohamed al-Yousef, director of the medical body in Madaya and Biqin, announced via a recording sent to Zaman al-Wasl that 'Madaya was plagued with meningitis due to [a patient's] whole family getting infected by it as well as the infection of medical staff in contact with the patients. Also, there are new cases on a daily basis.'\n\nMeanwhile, a private source told Zaman al-Wasl that there are 18 infected cases with meningitis in Madaya, mostly women and children, clarifying that the medical office in the town decided to put them in quarantine fearing more spread of the disease.\n\nMadaya suffers a suffocating blockade imposed mainly by Hezbollah mercenaries who surrounded the town with checkpoints and mines to prevent leaks of any medical supplies or food aid to thousands of besieged people. This has resulted in great deterioration in the humanitarian situation in the town and spreading death and disease due to malnutrition and lack of medical services there.\n\nThe Madaya blockade has entered the 14th month, while 40 000 residents await international aid, which is insufficient to stop the suffering of the hungry and injured, according to a local source.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri 19 Aug 2016\nSource: Huffington Post [edited]\nhttp://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/syrian-boy-with-meningitis-evacuated-from-besieged-town_us_57b73aabe4b0b51733a329db\n\n\nFor nearly a month, [an] 11 year old [boy] has been suffering from horrible pain caused by meningitis that his doctors in Madaya, Syria, lack the equipment and medicine to treat.\n\nMadaya is under siege by the Syrian government, so [the boy's] family in Syria and the United States have pleaded for help from aid organizations and lawmakers so he could leave the town to get treatment elsewhere.\n\nOn Friday [19 Aug 2016?], their prayers were finally answered as the Syrian Arab Red Crescent evacuated [the boy] and 12 other children out of the besieged town and took them to Damascus for needed medical attention, [the boy's] doctor said.\n\nThe news came less than 24 hours after The WorldPost 1st reported on [the boy's] condition. [The 11 year old boy] was suffering from severe meningitis in the weeks prior his evacuation. The Syrian Arab Red Crescent said in a tweet that it was evacuating a total of '36 humanitarian cases' from Madaya and 2 government-held towns, Kafraya and Fuaa, in the north western province of Idlib.\n\nA local Syrian doctor, Mohamed Darwich, who had diagnosed [the 11 year old boy], told The WorldPost that [the boy] was among those evacuated to Damascus to receive treatment, along with children suffering from malnutrition and 2 babies with blood poisoning, according to AFP.\n\nFor [the 11 year old boy's mother] and others in Madaya, a rural town on the outskirts of Damascus, starvation and a severe lack of medical and humanitarian aid are a part of daily life. An estimated 40 000 residents have been affected by food and medicine shortages in the town. The starvation and blockades persist despite multiple U.N. Security Council resolutions aimed at ensuring the delivery of aid to those in need, regardless of who controls the territory. There are 4.5 million people who live in regions of Syria that are hard to reach for aid groups, 400 000 of whom live in besieged areas, according to the United Nations.\n\n[byline: Rowaida Abdelaziz]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news reports above say that several people have been diagnosed as having suspected meningitis in a small town near Damascus in the past month, most of whom were thought to have viral rather than bacterial meningitis. One child in the 2nd and 3rd news report, who is likely the same as the 10 year old mentioned in the 1st news report, was said to have 'severe meningitis' causing headache for one month. This boy is said to have transmitted the illness to his 'whole family' as well as medical staff in contact with the patients. However, the absence of clear clinical descriptions of the illnesses in these news reports makes a differential diagnosis difficult.\n\nA report, which appeared in 2014 (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25424959), said that an 11 year old Syrian refugee girl living in Turkey for 3 months was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis type B, but other reports of meningitis in Syrian refugees could not be found in a brief scan of the internet. More clinical and epidemiologic information on the illness in these Syrian refugees in Madaya would be greatly appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nMadaya is a small mountainous town with a population of 9371 in the 2004 census located in southwestern Syria about 40 km (25 miles) north west of Damascus in the Rif Dimashq Governorate (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madaya,_Syria).\n\nMaps of Syria can be seen at http://www.freeworldmaps.net/asia/syria/syria-political-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/86. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n[byline: Rowaida Abdelaziz]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nOn Friday [19 Aug 2016?], their prayers were finally answered as the Syrian Arab Red Crescent evacuated [the boy] and 12 other children out of the besieged town and took them to Damascus for needed medical attention, [the boy's] doctor said. \n\nA report, which appeared in 2014 (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25424959), said that an 11 year old Syrian refugee girl living in Turkey for 3 months was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis type B, but other reports of meningitis in Syrian refugees could not be found in a brief scan of the internet. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news reports above say that several people have been diagnosed as having suspected meningitis in a small town near Damascus in the past month, most of whom were thought to have viral rather than bacterial meningitis. \n\nMeanwhile, a private source told Zaman al-Wasl that there are 18 infected cases with meningitis in Madaya, mostly women and children, clarifying that the medical office in the town decided to put them in quarantine fearing more spread of the disease. For [the 11 year old boy's mother] and others in Madaya, a rural town on the outskirts of Damascus, starvation and a severe lack of medical and humanitarian aid are a part of daily life. One child in the 2nd and 3rd news report, who is likely the same as the 10 year old mentioned in the 1st news report, was said to have 'severe meningitis' causing headache for one month. \n\nMadaya is under siege by the Syrian government, so [the boy's] family in Syria and the United States have pleaded for help from aid organizations and lawmakers so he could leave the town to get treatment elsewhere. https://en.zamanalwsl.net/news/17807.html\n\n\nDoctor Mohamed al-Yousef, director of the medical body in Madaya and Biqin, announced via a recording sent to Zaman al-Wasl that 'Madaya was plagued with meningitis due to [a patient's] whole family getting infected by it as well as the infection of medical staff in contact with the patients. \n\nAn activist in Madaya, Abdel Wahab Ahmed, who works at a health facility in the town, told AFP that the mother and 2 sisters of the evacuated child had also become infected. [The 11 year old boy] was suffering from severe meningitis in the weeks prior his evacuation. Among the children was a 10 year old boy who had been suffering from meningitis for a month. \n\nMadaya is a small mountainous town with a population of 9371 in the 2004 census located in southwestern Syria about 40 km (25 miles) north west of Damascus in the Rif Dimashq Governorate (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madaya,_Syria). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2004-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-09-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-08-19 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-09-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madaya", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Damascus", "country": "Syria"}, {"location": "Syria", "country": "Syria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4513490", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Solomon Islands: (ML) susp. bacterial, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4513490", "date": "2016-09-25 12:51:39", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - SOLOMON ISLANDS: (MALAITA) SUSPECTED, BACTERIAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 23 Sep 2016\nSource: Radionz.co.nz [edited]\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/314048/reports-of-meningitis-outbreak-in-solomon-islands\n\n\nThere have been unconfirmed reports of an outbreak of meningitis in the Malaita Province of Solomon Islands. A doctor working in the Atoifi Hospital told the Solomon Star on Monday [19 Sep 2016] that 5 people had been diagnosed with the disease. [Dr] Chellion Evan said the patients who arrived at the hospital were in a serious condition but could not be immediately treated. However, they were being closely monitored in isolation.\n\nDr Evan said he believed these were cases of bacterial meningitis, which can be fatal if left untreated.\n\nHe said villagers in the area had been warned to look out for early symptoms of meningitis; these include fever, vomiting, headaches and nausea, as well as joint pain, pale skin, and cold hands and feet. Dr Evan said this could be followed by a rash, neck stiffness, disorientation, and a dislike of bright lights.\n\nThe last suspected outbreak of meningitis in the Solomon Islands was in July 2014 when 4 children were reported to have died in Makira Province.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that 5 people have been diagnosed as having suspected bacterial meningitis but are not being immediately treated, although the news article goes on to say without further explanation that the disease is fatal if left untreated.\n\nAcute bacterial meningitis is a rapidly progressive disease. In a patient with suspected acute bacterial meningitis, blood cultures and a lumbar puncture (LP) and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination and culture are indicated to determine the causative organism and its antibiotic susceptibilities. An empiric intravenous antibiotic regimen is started as quickly as possible that has a spectrum broad enough to cover the most likely bacterial pathogens until the specific bacterial etiology is known. It is vital to begin treatment as early as possible in the course of the disease, as delay may contribute significantly to morbidity and mortality. Adjunctive dexamethasone is also given before or with the 1st antibiotic dose. Once a pathogen is known, the antibiotic regimen can be tailored to the antibiotic susceptibilities of the pathogen.\n\nCommon causes of bacterial meningitis vary by age group: in newborns - Group B _Streptococcus_, _Streptococcus pneumoniae_, _Escherichia coli_, _Listeria monocytogenes_; in infants and children - _S. pneumoniae_, _Neisseria meningitidis_, _Haemophilus influenzae_ type b, Group B _Streptococcus_; in adolescents and young adults - _N. meningitidis_, _S. pneumoniae_; and in older adults - _S. pneumoniae_, _N. meningitidis_, _H. influenzae_ type b, Group B _Streptococcus_, _L. monocytogenes_. Outbreaks of meningitis in the community are often due to _N. meningitidis_.\n\nMore information on this outbreak would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nSolomon Islands is a sovereign country consisting of 6 major islands and over 900 smaller islands, lying to the east of Papua New Guinea (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solomon_Islands). Malaita Province, with a population of 122 620 residents, is named after its largest island, Malaita (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaita_Province). The island of Malaita is the most populous island of the Solomon Islands, with 140 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaita).\n\nThe patients were admitted to Atoifi Hospital, which is located on Malaita Island (https://www.google.com/maps/place/Atoifi+Hospital/@-8.6322791,160.9558439,10z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0x4da3895b3191bd81!8m2!3d-8.8698072!4d161.0039091). In 1965, the 7th day Adventist Church established the 80-bed Atoifi Hospital, which serves a population of 80 000 people in the eastern half of Malaita (https://news.adventist.org/en/all-news/news/go/2004-04-19/solomon-islands-atoifi-hospital-continues-operations-despite-acquittals/). The hospital has an operating theatre that performs around 600 surgical operations per year, a laboratory for simple medical tests, and an x-ray unit (http://www.electives.net/hospital/3613/preview). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/189.]\n\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/mpp", "summary": "\n\nCommon causes of bacterial meningitis vary by age group: in newborns - Group B _Streptococcus_, _Streptococcus pneumoniae_, _Escherichia coli_, _Listeria monocytogenes_; in infants and children - _S. pneumoniae_, _Neisseria meningitidis_, _Haemophilus influenzae_ type b, Group B _Streptococcus_; in adolescents and young adults - _N. meningitidis_, _S. pneumoniae_; and in older adults - _S. pneumoniae_, _N. meningitidis_, _H. influenzae_ type b, Group B _Streptococcus_, _L. monocytogenes_. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that 5 people have been diagnosed as having suspected bacterial meningitis but are not being immediately treated, although the news article goes on to say without further explanation that the disease is fatal if left untreated. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nDr Evan said he believed these were cases of bacterial meningitis, which can be fatal if left untreated. In a patient with suspected acute bacterial meningitis, blood cultures and a lumbar puncture (LP) and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination and culture are indicated to determine the causative organism and its antibiotic susceptibilities. \n\nAcute bacterial meningitis is a rapidly progressive disease. An empiric intravenous antibiotic regimen is started as quickly as possible that has a spectrum broad enough to cover the most likely bacterial pathogens until the specific bacterial etiology is known. MENINGITIS - SOLOMON ISLANDS: (MALAITA) SUSPECTED, BACTERIAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n He said villagers in the area had been warned to look out for early symptoms of meningitis; these include fever, vomiting, headaches and nausea, as well as joint pain, pale skin, and cold hands and feet. \n\nSolomon Islands is a sovereign country consisting of 6 major islands and over 900 smaller islands, lying to the east of Papua New Guinea (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solomon_Islands). \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2014-07-26 00:00:00", "1965-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-09-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}, {"location": "the Malaita Province of Solomon Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Makira Province", "country": "Solomon Islands"}, {"location": "acute", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Malaita Province", "country": "Solomon Islands"}, {"location": "Malaita", "country": "Solomon Islands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4390751", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Austria: ex Poland, fatal, pilgrim, WYD, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4390751", "date": "2016-08-03 13:24:04", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRIA: ex POLAND, FATAL, PILGRIM, WORLD YOUTH DAY, ALERT\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 2 Aug 2016\nSource: Catholic News Agency (CNA/EWTN News) [edited]\nhttp://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/meningitis-death-of-world-youth-day-pilgrim-prompts-health-alert-52288/\n\n\nThe Italian bishops' conference has issued an advisory to pilgrims, after a young [19-year-old] Italian girl died of meningitis [on Mon 1 Aug 2016 in Vienna, Austria, while] returning home from World Youth Day [WYD] in Poland [Krakow, 26-31 Jul 2016].\n\n'She had been preparing for WYD for a year,' recounted Fr. Alessandro, the parish priest of her local Saint Polycarp parish in Rome, according to Corriere della Sera. 'She was a wonderful girl, very active in the parish,' he said, adding that she got good grades, and was active in the choir.\n\n[She] had reported feeling ill on Sunday evening [31 Jul 2016], after arriving in Vienna with some 50 young people from the parishes of Saint Polycarp and Our Lady of Good Counsel, reports the Italian agency.\n\nMeningitis is an infection-based inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms include a headache, fever, and stiff neck. Meningitis, which can be fatal, is spread through respiratory droplets, for example through coughing or sneezing.\n\nAccording to a [1 Aug 2016] statement issued by the Italian bishops' conference, the members of the girl's pilgrimage group have taken prophylaxis as a precaution.\n\nThe conference advised all World Youth Day pilgrims who passed through the Italian House -- the center in Krakow, which served Italian pilgrims -- to undergo the same prophylaxis, per the advice of the Vienna hospital.\n\nThose at risk of exposure who experience a high fever, headache, sore throat, vision problems, or loss of consciousness should go immediately to the hospital, as these symptoms could indicate an infection, the statement advised.\n\nThe bishops' conference offered its condolences to the girl's family, 'at the conclusion of an experience which was a lesson in fraternity and sharing.'\n\nTens of thousands of Italians were among the many pilgrims to attend World Youth Day in Krakow, which at its peak was attended by as many as 2 million people during its final days.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nZbigniew Halat, MD,\nMedical Epidemiology Consultant\nHealth Risk Management & Communication\nPoland\n<drhalat@halat.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 2 Aug 2016\nSource: Catholic Herald, Catholic News Service report [edited]\nhttp://www.catholicherald.co.uk/news/2016/08/02/health-alert-for-italian-wyd-pilgrims-after-young-woman-dies-of-meningitis/\n\n\nAfter an Italian pilgrim to World Youth Day in Krakow, Poland, died of meningitis, the Italian bishops' conference advised all pilgrims who visited or attended events at its Casa Italia centre in Krakow to see a doctor, especially if they have a high fever, severe headache, and rash.\n\nThe young female pilgrim from Rome died on [1 Aug 2016] in Vienna, where her group stopped on the way back from Italy, according to a note from the Italian bishops' conference, which did not release the young woman's name.\n\nAs a precaution, the bishops' statement said, doctors in Vienna administered the antibiotic ciprofloxacin to all the members of the young woman's group and recommended the same for other pilgrims who stayed at Casa Italia or spent a significant amount of time there.\n\nThe Casa Italia centre was set up at Krakow's Church of St Bernard of Siena and the adjoining convent. Some Italian pilgrims stayed there during World Youth Day and hundreds more joined them each day for catechesis and Mass in Italian.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nZbigniew Halat, MD,\nMedical Epidemiology Consultant\nHealth Risk Management & Communication\nPoland\n<drhalat@halat.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Zbigniew Halat for this information. Although the news reports above do not specify the microorganism causing this woman's meningitis, presumably it is _Neisseria meningitidis_. Los Angeles County Epidemiology Report [edited]\nhttp://publichealth.lacounty.gov/acd/docs/IMD2016.pdf\n\n\nSince May 2016, 9 confirmed cases of meningococcal disease among adult men have been reported in Southern California, including 1 death. This represents an increase above the typical number of reported cases. 6 of the cases are known to be caused by serogroup C, and an additional case is awaiting serogroup identification. 4 cases occurred among residents of LAC [Los Angeles County] (excluding Long Beach and Pasadena, which have their own health departments) with no associated deaths. The other 5 cases occurred in neighboring health jurisdictions. Most cases have occurred in the past 4 weeks. To date, public health investigation has not determined any common social linkages among LAC gay/MSM [men who have sex with men] cases with the other cases in the region. Based on these recent cases, LAC DPH [Department of Health] is reiterating its 2014 recommendation that gay/MSM who are HIV-positive or are at increased risk of IMD [invasive meningococcal disease] receive meningococcal vaccination (shown below). Additionally, on [22 Jun 2016], the US Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices voted to recommend that all persons with HIV infection who are 2 months of age and older be routinely vaccinated with quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate (MCV4) vaccine, which protects against serogroup C, as well as serogroups A, W, and Y.\n\nTable 1. B", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4222568", "date": "2016-05-15 11:17:10", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (02): (SOUTH AUSTRALIA) SEROGROUP B\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 May 2016\nSource: The Advertiser [edited]\nhttp://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/three-meningococcal-cases-in-the-past-week-prompts-health-alert/news-story/681c132691978c1a7ad4bac74872bf18\n\n\nThree South Australians have been diagnosed with meningococcal infection in the past week, prompting a public health warning. So far this year [2016], there has been a total of 11 cases of the potentially deadly infection -- ranging from a one-year-old to a 94-year-old -- up from 7 cases at the same time last year and 30 for all of 2015.\n\nOf the 11 cases this year [2016], 10 have been the meningococcal [serogroup] B strain, which is not covered on the national vaccine register, prompting calls for it to be added to the list. Health Minister Jack Snelling said the federal government should give 'careful consideration' to adding the [serogroup] B strain vaccine. 'In the meantime, probably the most important thing is for parents to speak to their local GP about whether it is advised to have that particular vaccination for meningococcal B,' he said.\n\nAt present, the meningococcal C vaccine is available through the National Immunisation Program, but the meningococcal B vaccine is only available from GPs at a cost of USD 125 per vaccine. Four shots are needed in total. SA [South Australia] Health chief medical officer Professor Paddy Phillips said it was an individual decision between parents and GPs about whether to vaccinate children against the B strain. 'It's a safe vaccine, and it's an effective vaccine, but is not on the free list at the moment,' he said.\n\nA federal government spokesman said the government could not include a new vaccine on the register unless it was recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. 'On each occasion, the application was rejected on the basis of clinical uncertainty; that is, where the clinical evidence for its effectiveness has not been demonstrated in the applicant's submission,' the spokesman said.\n\nSA Health would not disclose the ages or suburbs of the latest 3 people diagnosed with the infection. 'Some are doing very well. Some were in hospital ... Thank heavens none have died,' Prof Phillips said.\n\nWhile the infection is most common among children under 2 and people aged between 16 and 25, it can affect anyone at any age, especially during the cooler months when there are more respiratory infections around. Symptoms include fever, headache, vomiting, a stiff neck, sore muscles and, in some cases, a rash of red and purple spots.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nKathleen Harriman, PhD, MPH, RN\nChief, Vaccine Preventable Diseases Epidemiology Section\nImmunization Branch\nCalifornia Department of Public Health\n<kathleen.harriman@cdph.ca.gov>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Kathleen Harriman for providing the news report that says that 10 of the 11 cases of meningococcal meningitis in the state of South Australia have been due to serogroup B.\n\nSouth Australia (SA) is a state in the southern central part of Australia. Its population of 1.7 million people is the most highly concentrated, with more than 75 percent of South Australians living in the capital, Adelaide, or its environs; other population centers in the state are relatively small (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Australia). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186.]", "summary": "Chief, Vaccine Preventable Diseases Epidemiology Section\nImmunization Branch\nCalifornia Department of Public Health\n<kathleen.harriman@cdph.ca.gov>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Kathleen Harriman for providing the news report that says that 10 of the 11 cases of meningococcal meningitis in the state of South Australia have been due to serogroup B.\n\nSouth Australia (SA) is a state in the southern central part of Australia. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n So far this year [2016], there has been a total of 11 cases of the potentially deadly infection -- ranging from a one-year-old to a 94-year-old -- up from 7 cases at the same time last year and 30 for all of 2015. \n\nOf the 11 cases this year [2016], 10 have been the meningococcal [serogroup] B strain, which is not covered on the national vaccine register, prompting calls for it to be added to the list. \n\nAt present, the meningococcal C vaccine is available through the National Immunisation Program, but the meningococcal B vaccine is only available from GPs at a cost of USD 125 per vaccine. Symptoms include fever, headache, vomiting, a stiff neck, sore muscles and, in some cases, a rash of red and purple spots.\n\n--\n \n\nA federal government spokesman said the government could not include a new vaccine on the register unless it was recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-05-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4371802", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (04): (CA) fatal, MSM, sg C, vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4371802", "date": "2016-07-27 12:05:01", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (04): (CALIFORNIA) FATAL, MEN WHO HAVE SEX WITH MEN, SEROGROUP C, VACCINATION\n*************************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 25 Jul 2016\nSource: Orange County Breeze [edited]\nhttp://www.oc-breeze.com/2016/07/25/88715_dept-public-health-reports-increase-meningococcal-disease-men-sex-men/\n\n\nThe California Department of Public Health is reporting an increase of meningococcal disease in Southern California, particularly in Orange and Los Angeles Counties. A cluster of cases in the last several months has disproportionately affected men who have sex with men (MSM).\n\nMeningococcal disease is caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ bacteria, which are transmitted from person-to-person through respiratory droplets, during face-to-face or prolonged contact, or by sharing utensils, drinks, or cigarettes. It is a serious infection that can cause meningitis (brain infection) and/or bacteremia (blood infection), and can lead to death.\n\nTo date, Orange County has had 4 cases that are part of the cluster in Southern California; 3 of these cases have occurred since 1 Jun 2016, including 1 death. On average, Orange County has only 5 meningococcal cases each year.\n\nBecause of this local increase in risk, the County of Orange Health Care Agency, in conjunction with the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health and City of Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services, is expanding vaccination recommendations for meningococcal disease to include all gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men, in addition to all persons with HIV infection.\n\nHigher risk for meningococcal disease in MSM has been associated with: regularly visiting crowded venues such as bars, parties, etc.; regularly having close or intimate contact with multiple partners; smoking or illicit drug use; and/or HIV positive status.\n\nMSM who are unaware of their current HIV status and who have not been tested in the past year should seek HIV testing.\n\nIndividuals covered under this new recommendation are encouraged to speak to their medical providers about getting the vaccine. For those who are uninsured or whose insurance does not cover the vaccine, the OC Health Care Agency can provide vaccinations at low or no cost. There are 2 clinics located at 1725 W 17th Street in Santa Ana that will offer vaccine to qualified individuals:\n\nImmunization Clinic: 7:30 am - 4:30 pm, Mon-Fri, closed for lunch 11:45 am - 12:45 pm\nTesting, Treatment and Care Clinic: 8 am - 4 pm, Mon, Wed, Thu, and Fri; 10 am - 4 pm Tue.\n\nBoth are walk-in clinics, so wait times can be expected. Those needing just vaccination should go to the Immunization Clinic, but if testing for sexually transmitted disease and/or HIV is desired, please go to the Testing, Treatment and Care Clinic. For more information, please call the Health Referral Line at 800-564-8448.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) includes meningitis, bacteremia and sepsis and is caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ bacteria, which are transmitted from person-to-person through respiratory droplets usually during close contact. Persons who are HIV-infected are at increased risk of meningococcal disease.\n\nOutbreaks of IMD have recently occurred among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Germany, Belgium, and France caused by a _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C strain with the same multilocus sequence type (http://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/rapid-risk-assessment-invasive-meningococcal-disease-among-MSM.pdf). This genotype has also caused IMD in individuals (women, as well as those men who do not identify as MSM) who attended social venues associated with the gay community in France (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V20N03/art21016.pdf).\n\nSimilar outbreaks among MSM occurred in Canada and the US caused by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C (see prior ProMED-mail posts listed below).\n\nThe California Department of Public Health reported in mid July 2016 an increase of IMD among men living in Southern California, most of whom were MSM (http://ochealthinfo.com/civicax/filebank/blobdload.aspx?BlobID=56087). The current status (as of 14 Jul 2016):\n- 22 cases of IMD have been identified in Los Angeles County (LAC), including the city of Long Beach, and Orange County since 1 Jan 2016.\n- 15 of these cases have occurred since 1 May 2016.\n- 10 cases were in men who have sex with men (MSM), though no direct social connection between cases has been found.\n- 8 of the cases in MSM have been confirmed infected with _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C (NmC); 4 of these cases have an indistinguishable strain.\n- 3 serogroup C cases have occurred in Orange County residents, with one resulting in death.\n\nAccording to the Los Angeles County Epidemiology Report - Invasive Meningococcal Disease: 2016. 25 Jul 2016 (http://publichealth.lacounty.gov/acd/docs/IMD2016.pdf):\n- 13 cases of IMD have occurred in LAC, excluding Long Beach, since the beginning of 2016.\n- 9 of these cases have occurred since 1 May 2016.\n- 9 of the 13 cases were males; 8 of whom are serogroup C-positive.\n- 7 of the cases were MSM and all were serogroup C-positive.\n- No common social linkages among cases in the region.\n\nSubtracting the LAC cases from the totals in Southern California, this leaves\n- 9 cases of IMD in Orange County since the beginning of 2016.\n- 6 of these cases have occurred since May 1 2016.\n- 3 of the cases were MSM; all were serogroup C.\n\nThe state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/california-county-map.gif. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) includes meningitis, bacteremia and sepsis and is caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ bacteria, which are transmitted from person-to-person through respiratory droplets usually during close contact. \n\nSubtracting the LAC cases from the totals in Southern California, this leaves\n- 9 cases of IMD in Orange County since the beginning of 2016. \n- 10 cases were in men who have sex with men (MSM), though no direct social connection between cases has been found. (SOUTH AUSTRALIA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 May 2016\nSource: SBS News, AAP (Australian Associated Press) report [edited]\nhttp://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2016/05/13/sa-confirms-11-cases-meningococcal\n\n\nSouth Australia [SA] Health says 11 meningococcal cases have been confirmed so far this year [2016], an officer Paddy Phillips says it compares with 7 meningococcal cases this time last year [2015] and a total of 30 throughout 2015.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[South Australia (SA) is a state in the southern central part of Australia. Its population of 1.7 million people is the most highly concentrated, with more than 75 percent of South Australians living in the capital, Adelaide, or its environs; other population centers in the state are relatively small (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Australia).\n\nWe are not told in the news report above any of the characteristics of the 11 cases. For example, are the cases sporadic or part of an outbreak? If it is an outbreak, is it community- or organization-based? What are the ages of the cases, ethnic group, or sexual orientation? How many of the cases are primary (i.e., no known close contact with another patient with meningococcal disease) and how many are secondary (i.e., close contacts of another patient with meningococcal disease)? What are the serogroups of the meningococcal isolates? If they are the same serogroup, have the isolates been genotyped? ProMED-mail would appreciate more information in this regard from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/286.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[South Australia (SA) is a state in the southern central part of Australia.
