Myanmar: (ML) fatal, sg B, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4115532", "date": "2016-03-24 05:38:44", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - MYANMAR: (MANDALAY) FATAL, SEROGROUP B, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 15 Mar 2016\nSource: Myanmar Times [edited]\nhttp://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/national-news/mandalay-upper-myanmar/19460-meningococcal-outbreak-claims-four-lives.html\n\n\nHealth authorities are on high alert following a recent meningococcal meningitis outbreak that has claimed the lives of 4 children in Mandalay Region. 2 children in a serious condition are being treated for the bacterial infection at Mandalay General Hospital, while 5 more children are receiving treatment at Meiktila General Hospital. All are from villages in Tharsi Township.\n\nDr Win Naing, head of the Department of Public Health in Mandalay Region, said health officials were taking preventative measures to control the outbreak. They have started a vaccination campaign and advised people in the affected area to avoid large crowds. 'We are doing fieldwork in the area where the patients live and other locations nearby,' he said. 'We are monitoring around the clock for any further outbreaks in the area.'\n\nThe cases were reported from [5 Mar 2016], when the 1st death was reported. Another child died on [7 Mar 2016], while 2 more passed away on [9 Mar 2016]. The most recent cases were detected in Aung Myin Thar village on [12 Mar 2016], with 2 suspected patients immediately taken for medical treatment, according to the Department of Public Health.\n\nU Myint Thein, a senior National League for Democracy official in Tharsi Township, said 2 patients had been transferred to Mandalay due to the severity of their illness. 'Today we went to see the patients at Meiktila Hospital. The 5 children ... are in a stable condition,' he said.\n\nTests of the blood samples taken from infected children confirmed that the meningitis had been caused by the _Neisseria meningitidis_ group B bacteria, one of 6 serotypes that can cause an outbreak.\n\nThe deaths have been attributed to delays in seeking treatment. Dr Win Naing said it was essential that anyone suspected of having the highly fatal disease present for treatment as soon as possible. 'Meningitis tends to happen in the early summer season because ... the disease can be transmitted in dusty places,' Dr Win Naing said. 'It is most commonly found in dry zone areas, such as Mandalay and Magwe.' He added that outbreaks of the vaccine-preventable disease have occurred seasonally since 1992. 'People need to look out for the symptoms and if they notice any people with them then they should be reported to the health department,' he said. 'They should also avoid areas with large numbers of people and use a face mask when in a dusty place.'\n\nMeningococcal meningitis is transmitted person-to-person via mucus, particularly through coughing and sneezing, or sharing eating or drinking utensils. The infection affects the lining around the brain and spinal cord. According to the World Health Organization, the commonest symptoms are a stiff neck, high fever, sensitivity to light, confusion, headaches, and vomiting.\n\nAbout 20 per cent of infected people do not show symptoms, but can act as carriers within the community, according to Dr Win Naing. Even with early treatment, 5 to 10 per cent of cases are fatal, typically within 24 to 48 hours after symptoms appear. Between 10 and 20 per cent of survivors suffer from brain damage, hearing loss or a learning disability. Without immediate antibiotic treatment, the disease is fatal in closer to 50 per cent of cases.\n\nIn order to control the spread of the outbreak, Dr Win Naing said the region health department has been vaccinating family members of affected children, and anyone else who may have been in close contact with the patients. Adjacent villages have been warned to be on the lookout for the disease and to avoid festivals, donation ceremonies or other events where crowds may congregate. The health officials also recommended sprinkling water over dirt roads to limit dust.\n\n'Any age can suffer from the disease, but children whose resistance is weak are at highest risk to be infected,' Dr Win Naing said. Meningitis is considered a leading cause of death of children under five in Myanmar.\n\n[byline: Myint Kay Thi, Kyaw Ko Ko]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-MBDS from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that 11 children, 4 of whom have died, developed bacterial meningitis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B in the first 2 weeks of March 2016. All are from Tharsi Township in the Mandalay Region of central Myanmar. The news report says that family members and other close contacts of affected children are being vaccinated in order to control the spread of the outbreak. However, we are not told which meningococcal vaccine is being used.\n\nSeveral meningococcal vaccines are available. Immunity following use of a meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide that the vaccine contains, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups. Although there are at least 13 _N. meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135 are the commonest.\n\nThere are vaccines that contain capsular polysaccharide (A, C, Y, W135), either alone or conjugated to protein. Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines.\n\nSerogroup B vaccines have been developed based upon meningococcal B protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. Bexsero and Trumenba are 2 new serogroup B vaccines approved for use in the US. ProMED-mail would appreciate knowing the vaccine being used to control the outbreak in Mandalay from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML\n\nMaps of Myanmar can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/myanmar_map2.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16960. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Myint Kay Thi, Kyaw Ko Ko]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-MBDS from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines. Immunity following use of a meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide that the vaccine contains, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups. In order to control the spread of the outbreak, Dr Win Naing said the region health department has been vaccinating family members of affected children, and anyone else who may have been in close contact with the patients. \n\nTests of the blood samples taken from infected children confirmed that the meningitis had been caused by the _Neisseria meningitidis_ group B bacteria, one of 6 serotypes that can cause an outbreak. \n\nSerogroup B vaccines have been developed based upon meningococcal B protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. \n\n'Any age can suffer from the disease, but children whose resistance is weak are at highest risk to be infected,' Dr Win Naing said. The news report above says that 11 children, 4 of whom have died, developed bacterial meningitis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B in the first 2 weeks of March 2016. The most recent cases were detected in Aung Myin Thar village on [12 Mar 2016], with 2 suspected patients immediately taken for medical treatment, according to the Department of Public Health. 2 children in a serious condition are being treated for the bacterial infection at Mandalay General Hospital, while 5 more children are receiving treatment at Meiktila General Hospital. \n\n\nHealth authorities are on high alert following a recent meningococcal meningitis outbreak that has claimed the lives of 4 children in Mandalay Region. The news report says that family members and other close contacts of affected children are being vaccinated in order to control the spread of the outbreak. \n\nMeningococcal meningitis is transmitted person-to-person via mucus, particularly through coughing and sneezing, or sharing eating or drinking utensils. \n\nThe cases were reported from [5 Mar 2016], when the 1st death was reported. \n\nThere are vaccines that contain capsular polysaccharide (A, C, Y, W135), either alone or conjugated to protein. \n\nAbout 20 per cent of infected people do not show symptoms, but can act as carriers within the community, according to Dr Win Naing. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - MYANMAR: (MANDALAY) FATAL, SEROGROUP B, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1992-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Tharsi Township", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4118731", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (04): (TC) fatal, sg C, genotype, epidemiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4118731", "date": "2016-03-25 13:42:20", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (04): (TUSCANY) FATAL, SEROGROUP C, GENOTYPE, EPIDEMIOLOGY\n********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 24 March 2016\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2016; 21(12) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21423#aff2\n\n\nIncreased incidence of invasive meningococcal disease of serogroup C / clonal complex 11, Tuscany, Italy, 2015 to 2016\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[authors: Stefanelli P, Miglietta A, Pezzotti P, Fazio C, Neri A, Vacca P, et al.]\n\nSummary\n-------\nWe report an increase of serogroup C _Neisseria meningitidis_ invasive meningococcal disease in Tuscany. From January 2015 to end February 2016, 43 cases were reported, among which 10 were fatal, compared to two cases caused by serogroup C recorded in 2014 and three in 2013. No secondary cases occurred. 35 strains belonged to C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:ST-11(cc11). Control measures have been adopted and immunisation campaigns implemented. Studies on risk factors and carriage are ongoing.\n\nIn this report we present an unexpected increase of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) in Tuscany, Italy, since January 2015, leading to a total of 43 cases, of whom 10 were fatal, due to infection with serogroup C _N. meningitidis_. In Italy, serogroup C is the second commonest serogroup (31 per cent of the 115 cases with a known serogroup in 2014), after serogroup B (48 per cent of the 115 cases in 2014) [1]. In Tuscany, the total number of IMD cases was 16 in 2014 and 12 in 2013, with 2 and 3 cases caused by serogroup C, respectively [1].\n\nEpidemiological features\n------------------------\nFrom January 2015 to February 2016, 43 laboratory-confirmed cases of IMD due to serogroup C _N. meningitidis_ (31 in 2015, 12 in 2016) were reported from the Regional Health Authority of Tuscany (RHAT) to the Italian National Surveillance System for Invasive Bacterial Disease (IBD). No secondary cases were detected. The incidence of serogroup C cases was higher than in previous years: 0.83 per 100 000 inhabitants in 2015 and 1.98 in the 1st 2 months of 2016, whereas the average incidence for 2012-2014 was 0.08 per 100 000 inhabitants ranging from 0.05 in 2014 to 0.11 in 2012.\n\nThe National Reference Laboratory at the National Institute of Health (Istituto Superiore di Sanit\u00e0, ISS) received 22 bacterial isolates and 18 clinical samples (10 from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and 8 from blood) from 40 patients; for 3 cases material was not available. 35 out of the 40 samples analysed were confirmed as C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:ST-11 (cc11).\n\nThe median age of the 43 cases reported in the period was 28 years (range: 9-82), with the age group 20-29 years being the most affected (n\u2009=\u200915; incidence: 3.9/100 000), followed by the age group 9-19 years (n\u2009=\u200910; incidence: 2.6/100 000). Interestingly, 18 cases were reported among people over 30 years old (incidence: 0.5/100 000), and 11 among people over 55 years old (incidence: 0.6/100 000). There was no notable difference between males and females, with 21 cases registered among women and 22 among men.\n\nThe main clinical manifestations were: sepsis only (n=18), sepsis and meningitis (n=14), followed by meningitis only (n=11). 10 patients aged between 12 and 82 years died.\n\nInformation on vaccination status was available for 42 of the 43 cases detected between January 2015 and February 2016. 5 patients had been vaccinated with meningococcal C conjugate (MCC) vaccine. Apart from one case in an individual aged 62 years, vaccinated on the day of the symptom onset, in the remaining 4 cases aged 9, 12, 17, 22 years, the vaccine was administered in 2006, 2007, 2013, and 2008, respectively. In the latter cases, the apparent vaccine failure was likely to be due to the relatively short duration of the protection induced by one vaccine dose [2]. 2 of the vaccinated cases developed meningitis and 2 sepsis (one of them died).\n\nFigure 1 [see source URL] shows the case distribution by year from January 2000 to February 2016 and by month for January 2015 to February 2016, and Figure 2 [see source URL] presents the geographical distribution of the cases. An increase in the number of cases was observed since January 2015 in a densely populated area in the north of Tuscany, between the cities of Florence, Prato, and Empoli. Between January and April 2015, the cases were confined in this area. At the end of the spring, some cases occurred in the coastal area of Tuscany, between Pisa and Viareggio, an area frequented by young people during the summer. From the end of September 2015, the cases reappeared in the original area, where 12 cases with four deaths occurred in the 1st 2 months of 2016.\n\nThe incidence was calculated as the ratio between the number of cases in the study period (14 months) divided by the person-years of exposure (calculated as the people living in each municipality of Tuscany in 2015 (http://www.demo.istat.it in Italian), multiplied by the exposure time in years (that is, 14 months/12=1.17 years)).\n\nBackground\n----------\nMeningococcal serogroup C strains cc11, are known to cause invasive disease burden worldwide [3] and are responsible for high mortality rates among cases [4]. Outbreaks due to C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:ST-11(cc11) of IMD were reported in Germany in 2013 [5], in France in 2014 [6], in Italy among staff members of a cruise ship at the port of Livorno, Tuscany, in 2012 [7], and in 2 clusters in northern Italy, in December 2007 and July 2008, respectively, showing a high rate of septicaemia and fatal outcome [8].\n\nThe RHAT introduced the MCC vaccine in the regional immunisation schedule in 2005, with 3 doses to all children at 3, 5, and 13 months of age (subsequently turning to a single dose at 13 months, in 2008), and a catch-up immunisation until 6 years of age with a single dose. In 2007, the RHAT also implemented a catch-up vaccination programme with a single dose of MCC targeting the age group 11 to 14 year-olds. At national level, MCC was introduced in the Italian National Immunisation Plan in 2012 [9].\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\nSince March 2015, the RHAT involved ISS in the microbiological characterisation (including genomic analysis) and public health response. The factors contributing to an excess of IMD cases due to such hyper-virulent meningococcal C strain remain currently unknown but investigations are ongoing. An immunisation campaign has been implemented and continuously adapted to the evolution of the epidemiological situation. Starting with 30 March 2015, a single dose of meningococcal (ACYW) polysaccharide\u2010protein conjugate vaccine has been actively offered free-of-charge to the age group 11-19 years, even if already vaccinated with MCC in childhood (letters with invitations have been sent to individuals within this age group); the vaccine has been offered to individuals aged 20-44 years residing in the area of the local health units that reported at least one case of serogroup C _N. meningitidis_ since 2015 (Arezzo, Empoli, Florence, Lucca, Massa, Pistoia, Pisa, Prato, and Versilia). Up to 31 Dec 2015, 120 272 children and teenagers aged between 11 and 19 years were vaccinated, leading to a coverage of 42.5 per cent in this age group; 109 101 individuals aged between 20 and 44 years were vaccinated (vaccine coverage 14 per cent). On 16 Feb 2016, due to the increasing number of cases in age groups not previously included in the vaccination target groups, the immunisation campaign was extended to the whole Tuscany Region and to older people, using the monovalent vaccine as an alternative option to the tetravalent vaccine, maintaining the active offer only to 11-20 years age group.\n\nFollowing the advice of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), standard operating procedures for public health management of IMD, including contact tracing and administration of chemoprophylaxis to close contacts, already established before 2015, were extended and included the recommendation to offer vaccination to unimmunised people [10].\n\nConclusion\n----------\nIn order to investigate the reasons of this unusual increase in the number of cases, to assess possible epidemiological links between cases, and to identify specific groups of population at risk for both meningococcal serogroup C disease and carriage status, research protocols consisting in detailed investigation of the cases and _N. meningitidis_ cross sectional carriage surveys are going to be implemented in Tuscany, shortly. Molecular characterisation of meningococcal of serogroup C isolates, in particular those belonging to the finetype C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:ST-11(cc11), is in progress, to define the correlation with isolates reported in other countries [5,6]. The same analysis is now performed also in IMD cases occurring in other Italian Regions, in order to verify the spread of the strain involved in the outbreak in Tuscany to other Italian areas.\n\nThese investigations will help to better understand the dynamic of the ongoing circulation of this hyper-virulent meningococcal serogroup C strain and to identify groups of population at higher risk, in order to address specific prevention strategies, develop preparedness plans for an effective response to future IMD threats, and to address the ongoing public health concern.\n\nAt present, the Italian Health Authorities have enhanced IMD surveillance activities but did not consider necessary to provide special recommendations for people travelling to Tuscany.\n\n[Figures and references are available at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report above gives a fuller picture of the meningococcal C outbreak in Tuscany, Italy, than ProMED-mail has so far reported. The total number of cases has increased from 31 to 43, with deaths increasing from 6 to 10. For discussion of this outbreak, see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/15523.]", "summary": "\n\nThe median age of the 43 cases reported in the period was 28 years (range: 9-82), with the age group 20-29 years being the most affected (n\u2009=\u200915; incidence: 3.9/100 000), followed by the age group 9-19 years (n\u2009=\u200910; incidence: 2.6/100 000). Starting with 30 March 2015, a single dose of meningococcal (ACYW) polysaccharide\u2010protein conjugate vaccine has been actively offered free-of-charge to the age group 11-19 years, even if already vaccinated with MCC in childhood (letters with invitations have been sent to individuals within this age group); the vaccine has been offered to individuals aged 20-44 years residing in the area of the local health units that reported at least one case of serogroup C _N. meningitidis_ since 2015 (Arezzo, Empoli, Florence, Lucca, Massa, Pistoia, Pisa, Prato, and Versilia). In order to investigate the reasons of this unusual increase in the number of cases, to assess possible epidemiological links between cases, and to identify specific groups of population at risk for both meningococcal serogroup C disease and carriage status, research protocols consisting in detailed investigation of the cases and _N. meningitidis_ cross sectional carriage surveys are going to be implemented in Tuscany, shortly. The incidence of serogroup C cases was higher than in previous years: 0.83 per 100 000 inhabitants in 2015 and 1.98 in the 1st 2 months of 2016, whereas the average incidence for 2012-2014 was 0.08 per 100 000 inhabitants ranging from 0.05 in 2014 to 0.11 in 2012. On 16 Feb 2016, due to the increasing number of cases in age groups not previously included in the vaccination target groups, the immunisation campaign was extended to the whole Tuscany Region and to older people, using the monovalent vaccine as an alternative option to the tetravalent vaccine, maintaining the active offer only to 11-20 years age group. In Italy, serogroup C is the second commonest serogroup (31 per cent of the 115 cases with a known serogroup in 2014), after serogroup B (48 per cent of the 115 cases in 2014) The incidence was calculated as the ratio between the number of cases in the study period (14 months) divided by the person-years of exposure (calculated as the people living in each municipality of Tuscany in 2015 (http://www.demo.istat.it in Italian), multiplied by the exposure time in years (that is, 14 months/12=1.17 years)). From January 2015 to February 2016, 43 laboratory-confirmed cases of IMD due to serogroup C _N. meningitidis_ (31 in 2015, 12 in 2016) were reported from the Regional Health Authority of Tuscany (RHAT) to the Italian National Surveillance System for Invasive Bacterial Disease (IBD). From January 2015 to end February 2016, 43 cases were reported, among which 10 were fatal, compared to two cases caused by serogroup C recorded in 2014 and three in 2013. Up to 31 Dec 2015, 120 272 children and teenagers aged between 11 and 19 years were vaccinated, leading to a coverage of 42.5 per cent in this age group; 109 101 individuals aged between 20 and 44 years were vaccinated (vaccine coverage 14 per cent). \n\nThe RHAT introduced the MCC vaccine in the regional immunisation schedule in 2005, with 3 doses to all children at 3, 5, and 13 months of age (subsequently turning to a single dose at 13 months, in 2008), and a catch-up immunisation until 6 years of age with a single dose. Source: Eurosurveillance edition 2016; 21(12) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21423#aff2\n\n\nIncreased incidence of invasive meningococcal disease of serogroup C / clonal complex 11, Tuscany, Italy, 2015 to 2016\n Interestingly, 18 cases were reported among people over 30 years old (incidence: 0.5/100 000), and 11 among people over 55 years old (incidence: 0.6/100 000). Apart from one case in an individual aged 62 years, vaccinated on the day of the symptom onset, in the remaining 4 cases aged 9, 12, 17, 22 years, the vaccine was administered in 2006, 2007, 2013, and 2008, respectively. From the end of September 2015, the cases reappeared in the original area, where 12 cases with four deaths occurred in the 1st 2 months of 2016. In Tuscany, the total number of IMD cases was 16 in 2014 and 12 in 2013, with 2 and 3 cases caused by serogroup C, respectively [1]. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In this report we present an unexpected increase of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) in Tuscany, Italy, since January 2015, leading to a total of 43 cases, of whom 10 were fatal, due to infection with serogroup C _N. meningitidis_. \n\nThese investigations will help to better understand the dynamic of the ongoing circulation of this hyper-virulent meningococcal serogroup C strain and to identify groups of population at higher risk, in order to address specific prevention strategies, develop preparedness plans for an effective response to future IMD threats, and to address the ongoing public health concern. \n\nThe National Reference Laboratory at the National Institute of Health (Istituto Superiore di Sanit\u00e0, ISS) received 22 bacterial isolates and 18 clinical samples (10 from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and 8 from blood) from 40 patients; for 3 cases material was not available. [Figures and references are available at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< [see source URL] shows the case distribution by year from January 2000 to February 2016 and by month for January 2015 to February 2016, and Figure 2 [see source URL] presents the geographical distribution of the cases. \n\nInformation on vaccination status was available for 42 of the 43 cases detected between January 2015 and February 2016.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2015-12-31 00:00:00", "2015-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1982-09-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-24 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-12-26 00:00:00", "2008-07-26 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-02-16 00:00:00", "2015-01-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Background", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Tuscany", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Versilia", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Tuscany , Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4095606", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, bacterial - Cote d'Ivoire: S. pneumoniae st.1 predominates", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4095606", "date": "2016-03-15 19:17:59", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, BACTERIAL - COTE D'IVOIRE: STREPTOCOCCUS PNEUMONIAE ST.1 PREDOMINATES\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 14 Mar 2016\nFrom: Clarisse Kouame Elogne <nzolecla@yahoo.fr> [edited]\n\n\nPneumococcal infection in the Meningitis Outbreak of 2016 in West Africa: Cote d'Ivoire\n-------------------\nBacterial meningitis is an infection caused by 3 main germs named _Neisseria meningitidis_, _Haemophilus influenzae_ and _Streptococcus pneumoniae_. In Africa, meningitis causes each year sporadic cases in many countries and outbreaks in countries along the meningitis belt in West and Central Africa. In 2012, _Neisseria meningitidis_ was the cause of the epidemic with a predominant serogroup NmW135 in Cote d'Ivoire. In 2016 _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ was confirmed to be the main agent of the meningitis epidemic in Ghana. This article aims to bring forward the features of the circulating serotypes of this epidemic that caused 50% mortality in order to contribute to the therapeutic and immunization response to the serotypes components of vaccines.\n\nA total of 66 cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) were collected from the National Reference Center of Meningitis in Pasteur Institute of Cote d'Ivoire, which were coming from areas affected by the epidemic germs. The identification of the germs was made through conventional bacteriology and by the PCR method. The MIC (minimum inhibitory concentration) [was determined for] penicillin G and ceftriaxone. The _S. pneumoniae_ serotypes [were determined] by region based on differences in the [capsular] polyssacharides. The molecular serotyping of pneumococci was done according to the Rekha et al, 2006 Protocol.\n\nOut of the 66 CSF collected from the patients suspected to have meningitis, 28 were positive with a rate of 42.4%: 71.4% (20/28) [were positive for] _S. pneumoniae_, 17.8% (5/28) [for] _N. meningitidis_ and 7.1% (2/28) _H. influenzae_ b.\n\nThe MIC [for an isolate of _S. pneumoniae_] was 0.015 to penicillin G and 0.06 mg/L for the ceftriaxone. The strains were very sensitive, allowing treatment according to the national protocol.\n\nSerotyping (PCR) of _S. pneumoniae_ shows a distribution of 50% (10/20) for serotype 1, 5% (1/20) for serotype 12 and 5% (1/20) for the serotype 5.\n\nThese results confirm the predominance of serotype 1 _S. pneumoniae_ in Cote d'Ivoire. This is a polyclonal epidemic. The [molecular?] sequencing will clarify the characteristics of the serotype 1 strains.\n\n--\nDr. Clarisse Kouame Elogne\nAttach\u00e9 de recherche\nUnite de Bacteriologie Clinique\nResponsable qualit\u00e9 et bios\u00e9curit\u00e9\nInstitut Pasteur de CI\nCote d'Ivoire\n<nzolecla@yahoo.fr>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Clarisse Kouame Elogne for submission of data on the etiology of bacterial meningitis in Cote d'Ivoire, a country in the African meningitis belt.\n\nThe usual pathogen in this region has been _Neisseria meningitidis_. However, several other bacterial species, including _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ and _Hemophilus pneumoniae_, have noted to be involved in bacterial meningitis outbreaks in the African meningitis belt before (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1699486).\n\nSome studies have emphasized that _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ may cause outbreaks of bacterial meningitis in an epidemic pattern in the African meningitis belt during the dry season, especially in older children and young adults (http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/192/2/192.abstract?ijkey=9d47813b96aa1d50880f62e9e7efbc4d32bfea9a&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha and http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.abstract?ijkey=7d2ca30004fffc8d1410102f6ec758a72efc1f82&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha). _S. pneumoniae_ serotype 1 from a single clonal complex (ST 217) has predominated in several outbreaks, but other pneumococcal serotypes are also isolated. The case-fatality rate for pneumococcal meningitis has been high; over 40 percent of cases are fatal, regardless of age group.\n\nIdentifying the specific microbial causes of a bacterial meningitis outbreak is critically important, because prior meningococcal immunization programs with a particular serogroup vaccine in the region may have resulted in replacement of a previous serogroup with other meningococcal serogroups or the outbreak may actually be due to non-meningococcal bacterial species.\n\nUse of a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine could be beneficial in an outbreak where pneumococcal etiology predominates. Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines reduce carriage of serotypes of _S. pneumoniae_ contained in the vaccine and thus person-to-person transmission of these pathogens, which occurs by close contact with respiratory secretions or saliva. However, the 7-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine was found to include serotypes (4, 6B, 9V, 14, 18C, 19F, and 23F) protective against only 8 percent of the isolates in one study in Burkina Faso (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.full). The 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, Prevnar 13, which covers serotypes 1, 3, 4, 5, 6A, 6B, 7F, 9V, 14, 18C, 19A, 19F, and 23F, may be more effective, especially when serotype 1 predominates. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52.]", "summary": "\n\n--\nDr. Clarisse Kouame Elogne\nAttach\u00e9 de recherche\nUnite de Bacteriologie Clinique\nResponsable qualit\u00e9 et bios\u00e9curit\u00e9\n Institut Pasteur de CI\nCote d'Ivoire\n<nzolecla@yahoo.fr>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Clarisse Kouame Elogne for submission of data on the etiology of bacterial meningitis in Cote d'Ivoire, a country in the African meningitis belt. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIdentifying the specific microbial causes of a bacterial meningitis outbreak is critically important, because prior meningococcal immunization programs with a particular serogroup vaccine in the region may have resulted in replacement of a previous serogroup with other meningococcal serogroups or the outbreak may actually be due to non-meningococcal bacterial species. However, several other bacterial species, including _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ and _Hemophilus pneumoniae_, have noted to be involved in bacterial meningitis outbreaks in the African meningitis belt before (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1699486). Some studies have emphasized that _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ may cause outbreaks of bacterial meningitis in an epidemic pattern in the African meningitis belt during the dry season, especially in older children and young adults (http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/192/2/192.abstract?ijkey=9d47813b96aa1d50880f62e9e7efbc4d32bfea9a&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha and http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.abstract?ijkey=7d2ca30004fffc8d1410102f6ec758a72efc1f82&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha). \nBacterial meningitis is an infection caused by 3 main germs named _Neisseria meningitidis_, _Haemophilus influenzae_ and _Streptococcus pneumoniae_. The 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, Prevnar 13, which covers serotypes 1, 3, 4, 5, 6A, 6B, 7F, 9V, 14, 18C, 19A, 19F, and 23F, may be more effective, especially when serotype 1 predominates. Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines reduce carriage of serotypes of _S. pneumoniae_ contained in the vaccine and thus person-to-person transmission of these pathogens, which occurs by close contact with respiratory secretions or saliva. MENINGITIS, BACTERIAL - COTE D'IVOIRE: STREPTOCOCCUS PNEUMONIAE ST.1 PREDOMINATES\n shows a distribution of 50% (10/20) for serotype 1, 5% (1/20) for serotype 12 and 5% (1/20) for the serotype 5. From: Clarisse Kouame Elogne <nzolecla@yahoo.fr> [edited]\n\n\nPneumococcal infection in the Meningitis Outbreak of 2016 in West Africa: Cote d'Ivoire\n------------------- _S. pneumoniae_ serotype 1 from a single clonal complex (ST 217) has predominated in several outbreaks, but other pneumococcal serotypes are also isolated. In Africa, meningitis causes each year sporadic cases in many countries and outbreaks in countries along the meningitis belt in West and Central Africa. Out of the 66 CSF collected from the patients suspected to have meningitis, 28 were positive with a rate of 42.4%: 71.4% (20/28) [were positive for] _S. pneumoniae_, 17.8% (5/28) [for] _N. meningitidis_ and 7.1% (2/28) _H. influenzae_ b.\n\nThe MIC [for an isolate of _S. pneumoniae_] was 0.015 to penicillin G and 0.06 mg/L for the ceftriaxone. \n\nUse of a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine could be beneficial in an outbreak where pneumococcal etiology predominates. This article aims to bring forward the features of the circulating serotypes of this epidemic that caused 50% mortality in order to contribute to the therapeutic and immunization response to the serotypes components of vaccines. However, the 7-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine was found to include serotypes (4, 6B, 9V, 14, 18C, 19F, and 23F) protective against only 8 percent of the isolates in one study in Burkina Faso (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.full). In 2016 _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ was confirmed to be the main agent of the meningitis epidemic in Ghana. A total of 66 cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) were collected from the National Reference Center of Meningitis in Pasteur Institute of Cote d'Ivoire, which were coming from areas affected by the epidemic germs. The case-fatality rate for pneumococcal meningitis has been high; over 40 percent of cases are fatal, regardless of age group. The _S. pneumoniae_ serotypes [were determined] by region based on differences in the [capsular] polyssacharides. These results confirm the predominance of serotype 1 _S. pneumoniae_ in Cote d'Ivoire. \n\nSerotyping (PCR) of _S. pneumoniae_ Date: Mon 14 Mar 2016\n \n\nThe usual pathogen in this region has been _Neisseria meningitidis_. ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52.] sequencing will clarify the characteristics of the serotype 1 strains. In 2012, _Neisseria meningitidis_ was the cause of the epidemic with a predominant serogroup NmW135 in Cote d'Ivoire. **\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n The molecular serotyping of pneumococci was done according to the Rekha et al, 2006 Protocol.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 19:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "7f", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4071047", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (02): (TC) fatal, sg C, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4071047", "date": "2016-03-05 11:02:35", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (02): (TUSCANY) FATAL, SEROGROUP C, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/italy-four-meningitis-c-deaths-recorded-in-tuscany-year-to-date-66459/\n\n\nIn a continuation of the 2015 meningococcal meningitis C outbreak in Tuscany, health officials have reported a dozen cases and 4 deaths through [26 Feb 2016], according to an Italian media account (computer translated).\n\nIn 2015, 31 cases, including 6 deaths, attributable to serogroup C were reported. This compares to the 2 and 3 cases reported in 2014 and 2013, respectively.\n\nThe increase in cases has prompted health officials to extend the vaccination campaign to adolescents, adults and the elderly. In addition, they reiterated that [being in] crowded rooms, alcohol use and smoking habits [sharing cigarettes?] [during an outbreak] of invasive meningococcal disease may increase the risk of infection through close contact with potential carriers.\n\nThey did not, however, suggest recommendations against travel to the Tuscany region.\n\nThe national system of surveillance of invasive bacterial diseases has not revealed an increase in cases in other Italian regions, neither in 2015 nor in the early months of 2016. However, it could not rule out the spread in other regions.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report posted by ProMED-mail previously on this outbreak in Tuscany (Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (TC): increased incidence, sg. C 20160210.4009797) noted no deaths in either the past year (2015) or this year (2016). The above news report now says that there were 6 deaths attributable to meningococcal meningitis serogroup C in 2015 and 4 deaths so far this year.\n\nWe are not told whether the strains of _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C that are causing the current outbreak in Tuscany have been genotyped. It would be interesting to know whether any of the strains causing the Tuscany outbreak have a matching genotype and whether the genotype matches that causing the international meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in men who have sex with men. ProMED-mail would appreciate information in this regard from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/15523.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report posted by ProMED-mail previously on this outbreak in Tuscany (Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (TC): increased incidence, sg. In a continuation of the 2015 meningococcal meningitis C outbreak in Tuscany, health officials have reported a dozen cases and 4 deaths through [26 Feb 2016], according to an Italian media account (computer translated). The above news report now says that there were 6 deaths attributable to meningococcal meningitis serogroup C in 2015 and 4 deaths so far this year. \n\nThe national system of surveillance of invasive bacterial diseases has not revealed an increase in cases in other Italian regions, neither in 2015 nor in the early months of 2016. \n\nThe increase in cases has prompted health officials to extend the vaccination campaign to adolescents, adults and the elderly.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-02-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SEROGROUP c", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4073441", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (03): (TC) fatal, sg C, genotype, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4073441", "date": "2016-03-06 22:03:12", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (03): (TUSCANY) FATAL, SEROGROUP C, GENOTYPE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 6 Mar 2016\nFrom: Franco Giovanetti <fgiovanetti@aslcn2.it> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (02): (TC) fatal, sg C, RFI 20160305.4071047\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAccording to a note of the Italian Ministry of Health, isolates from cases that occurred in a relatively limited area of the Tuscany Region belong to the ST-11 clonal complex (fine typing C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:ST11). Surveillance has been strengthened at a national level in order to promptly detect the possible (although unlikely) spread of the same clone in other areas of the country. (Source http://goo.gl/6tl61E)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nFranco Giovanetti\nASL CN2 Alba Bra - Department of Prevention\nAlba, Piedmont Region\nItaly\n<fgiovanetti@aslcn2.it>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Franco Giovanetti for responding to the query concerning the genotype of the strain of _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C that is causing the outbreak of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) in Tuscany.\n\nApparently the genotype of the outbreak strain of _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C is multilocus sequence typing (MLST) sequence type 11 (ST-11) (C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:ST11). This genotype is the same as that of the strain causing IMD among men who have sex with men (MSM) in France and Germany. IMD cases in MSM living in the Paris region was linked to the circulation since mid-2013 of C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:cc11 isolates, and this strain is also reported to be the same as that causing the outbreak of IMD in MSM in Germany (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V20N03/art21016.pdf).\n\nThis genotype caused IMD not only in MSM, but also in individuals (women, as well as those men who do not identify as MSM) who attended social venues associated with the gay community in France (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V20N03/art21016.pdf). ProMED-mail would appreciate any information on contacts of cases of IMD in Tuscany with MSM or social venues associated with the gay community, if available, from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/75.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Alba, Piedmont Region\nItaly\n<fgiovanetti@aslcn2.it>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Franco Giovanetti for responding to the query concerning the genotype of the strain of _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C that is causing the outbreak of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) in Tuscany. (Source http://goo.gl/6tl61E)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nFranco Giovanetti\nASL CN2 Alba Bra - Department of Prevention\n MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (03): (TUSCANY) FATAL, SEROGROUP C, GENOTYPE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Paris", "country": "France"}, {"location": "st-11", "country": "Jamaica"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4009797", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (TC): increased incidence, sg. C", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4009797", "date": "2016-02-10 15:18:49", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (TUSCANY): INCREASED INCIDENCE, SEROGROUP C\n*****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Feb 2016\nSource: ANSA.it [edited]\nhttp://www.ansa.it/english/news/2016/02/08/tuscan-woman-infected-with-meningitis-c_c8e19209-7cae-4018-b5aa-9d7f6d5fb735.html\n\n\nA 50-year-old woman from Campi Bisenzio, near Florence, has been confirmed as having contracted [meningococcal?] meningitis [serogroup] C, bringing the total cases of [meningococcal?] meningitis in the region to 12 thus far this year [2016], the local health authority said on Monday [8 Feb 2016].\n\nThe woman is being treated in the infectious diseases unit of Florence's Careggi Hospital and didn't have direct contact with the public in her administrative job.\n\nItalian Health Minister Beatrice Lorenzin will discuss the situation on Tuesday [9 Feb 2016] in a previously scheduled meeting with Tuscan regional councilor Stefania Saccardi and representatives from the Italian medicines agency (AIFA) and the Higher Health Institute (ISS). Saccardi in recent days said the number of meningitis vaccinations has increased in the region, and the vaccination is free to all through age 45.\n\nIn 2015, there were 38 cases of [meningococcal?] meningitis in the region.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Prior news reports indicate that the above news report is referring to meningococcal meningitis (http://www.thelocal.it/20151006/meningitis-outbreak-spurs-vaccinations-in-tuscany).\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of invasive meningococcal disease [IMD] (meningitis and sepsis), is transmitted from person to person via droplets of respiratory secretions, mostly from asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers of the microorganism. It is estimated that between 10 to 25 percent of the population carry _N. meningitidis_ at any given time, and the carriage rate may be much higher in epidemic situations. Close and prolonged contact (such as kissing, sneezing, and coughing on someone), living in close quarters or dormitories (military recruits, students), sharing eating or drinking utensils, etc. facilitates the spread of the disease. The average incubation period for meningococcal meningitis is 4 days, ranging between 2 and 10 days (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). Invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) carries a high mortality rate if untreated. Even with early and appropriate treatment, patients can die within 24-48 hours.\n\nIMD is reportedly rare in Italy, where 0.25 confirmed cases per 100 000 population were observed in 2011, whereas the rate for Europe as a whole was 0.77 (http://www.hindawi.com/journals/jir/2015/710656/#B2).\n\nThere are 12 serogroups, but the majority of invasive meningococcal infections are caused by organisms from the A, B, C, X, Y, or W-135 serogroups. Serogroup B and C have been responsible for the majority of IMD in Europe, but since implementation of conjugated meningococcal serogroup C vaccine immunization programs, the frequency of IMD due to serogroup C has dropped; 73.6 percent of IMD was caused by serogroup B in Europe in 2011, while serogroup C accounted for only 14.4 percent of cases in 2011 (http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/invasive-bacterial-diseases-surveillance-2011.pdf).\n\nIn Italy, since 2009-2010, most regions have established a universal infant free-of-charge meningococcal C conjugate vaccine program, reaching an average vaccination coverage of 68 percent in the 2008 birth cohort (http://www.hindawi.com/journals/jir/2015/710656/#B2), and in the same period, 12 regions recommended the immunization of adolescents aged between 11 and 16 years, with one dose. The National Vaccination Plan 2012-2014 included meningococcal serogroup C conjugate universal routine vaccination for toddlers between 13 and 15 months of age and 11-18-year-old adolescents (http://www.hindawi.com/journals/jir/2015/710656/#B2).\n\nMolecular epidemiology has revealed that most cases of IMD are caused by only a few hypervirulent clonal lineages, whereas the genetic diversity is higher in meningococci recovered from healthy carriers (Claus H, Weinand H, Frosch M, Vogel U. Identification of the hypervirulent lineages of _Neisseria meningitidis_, the ST-8 and ST-11 complexes, by using monoclonal antibodies specific to NmeDI. J Clin Microbiol. 2003; 41(8): 3873-6; available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC179822/). We are not told whether the strains of _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C that are causing the current outbreak in Tuscany have been genotyped.\n\nOutbreaks of IMD caused by a strain _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C with a distinct genotype have recently occurred among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Germany, Belgium and France (http://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/rapid-risk-assessment-invasive-meningococcal-disease-among-MSM.pdf). Similar outbreaks among MSM caused by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C have occurred in Canada and the US (see prior ProMED-mail posts). It would be interesting to know whether any of the strains causing the Tuscany outbreak have a matching genotype and whether the genotype matches that causing the outbreak in MSM. ProMED-mail would appreciate information in this regard from knowledgeable sources.\n\nTuscany is a region in central Italy with a population of about 3.8 million inhabitants (2013); the regional capital is Florence (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuscany). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/75.]", "summary": "Serogroup B and C have been responsible for the majority of IMD in Europe, but since implementation of conjugated meningococcal serogroup C vaccine immunization programs, the frequency of IMD due to serogroup C has dropped; 73.6 percent of IMD was caused by serogroup B in Europe in 2011, while serogroup C accounted for only 14.4 percent of cases in 2011 (http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/invasive-bacterial-diseases-surveillance-2011.pdf). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Prior news reports indicate that the above news report is referring to meningococcal meningitis (http://www.thelocal.it/20151006/meningitis-outbreak-spurs-vaccinations-in-tuscany). meningitis [serogroup] C, bringing the total cases of [meningococcal?] meningitis in the region to 12 thus far this year [2016], the local health authority said on Monday [8 Feb 2016]. In Italy, since 2009-2010, most regions have established a universal infant free-of-charge meningococcal C conjugate vaccine program, reaching an average vaccination coverage of 68 percent in the 2008 birth cohort (http://www.hindawi.com/journals/jir/2015/710656/#B2), and in the same period, 12 regions recommended the immunization of adolescents aged between 11 and 16 years, with one dose. \n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of invasive meningococcal disease [IMD] (meningitis and sepsis), is transmitted from person to person via droplets of respiratory secretions, mostly from asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers of the microorganism. \n\nMolecular epidemiology has revealed that most cases of IMD are caused by only a few hypervirulent clonal lineages, whereas the genetic diversity is higher in meningococci recovered from healthy carriers (Claus H, Weinand H, Frosch M, Vogel U. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (TUSCANY): INCREASED INCIDENCE, SEROGROUP C\n*****************************************************************************\n The National Vaccination Plan 2012-2014 included meningococcal serogroup C conjugate universal routine vaccination for toddlers between 13 and 15 months of age and 11-18-year-old adolescents (http://www.hindawi.com/journals/jir/2015/710656/#B2). \n\nOutbreaks of IMD caused by a strain _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C with a distinct genotype have recently occurred among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Germany, Belgium and France (http://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/rapid-risk-assessment-invasive-meningococcal-disease-among-MSM.pdf).", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-02-08 00:00:00", "2016-02-09 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florence", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3916285", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, pneumococcal - Ghana: (BA) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3916285", "date": "2016-01-07 12:09:12", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, PNEUMOCOCCAL - GHANA: (BRONG-AHAFO) FATAL\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 5 Jan 2016\nSource: Pulse.com.gh [edited]\n<pulse.com.gh/health/epidemic-eight-die-over-outbreak-of-pneumococcal-meningitis-id4522944.html>\n\n\nDistrict health director for Tain, Dr Michael Rockson Adjei said 30 people have so far been hospitalized after being infected with the deadly pneumococcal meningitis. 8 people have died in the Brong Ahafo region following an outbreak of pneumococcal meningitis in the area.\n\nConfirming the news to Accra-based Starr FM, District health director for Tain, Dr Michael Rockson Adjei, said 30 people have so far been hospitalized after being infected with the deadly pneumococcal meningitis. He added that the affected are responding to treatment.\n\n'The symptoms are just like CSM [cerebral spinal meningitis], but let me put on record it is not CSM. [The writer is likely referring to CSM due to meningococcus.] There are certain factors that may give rise for the bacteria to spread from a fellow to another. Usually causes ear infection, throat infection, and pneumonia,' he added.\n\nDr Michael Rockson added that the outbreak started around [24 Dec 2015] and called on infected persons to report quickly for treatment.\n\n'All things being equal, by close of 2 weeks, we should be able to overcome the epidemic,' he said.\n\n[Byline: Mildred Europa Taylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Ghana can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Ghana.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50377. Tain District, where the pneumococcal meningitis outbreak is occurring, is one of the 22 districts of the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tain_District). The northern region of Ghana lies within the African meningitis belt where outbreaks of meningitis, usually due to _Neisseria meningitidis_, occur during the dry season, between December and May. The African meningitis belt is sub-Saharan and extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia in the east. A map can be seen at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/pdf/yellowbook-2012-map3-13-frequent-epidemics-meningococcal-meningitis.pdf.\n\nHowever, several studies have emphasized that _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ may also cause outbreaks of bacterial meningitis in an epidemic pattern in the African meningitis belt during the dry season, especially in older children and young adults (http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/192/2/192.abstract?ijkey=9d47813b96aa1d50880f62e9e7efbc4d32bfea9a&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha and http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.abstract?ijkey=7d2ca30004fffc8d1410102f6ec758a72efc1f82&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha). _S. pneumoniae_ serotype 1 from a single clonal complex (ST 217) has predominated in several outbreaks, but other pneumococcal serotypes are also isolated. The case-fatality rate for pneumococcal meningitis has been high; over 40 percent of cases are fatal, regardless of age group.\n\nA pneumococcal conjugate vaccine could beneficial. Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines reduce carriage of serotypes of _S. pneumoniae_ contained in the vaccine and thus person-to-person transmission of these pathogens, which occurs by close contact with respiratory secretions or saliva. However, the 7-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine was found to include serotypes (4, 6B, 9V, 14, 18C, 19F, and 23F) protective against only 8 percent of the isolates in one study in Burkina Faso (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.full). The 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, Prevnar 13, which covers serotypes 1, 3, 4, 5, 6A, 6B, 7F, 9V, 14, 18C, 19A, 19F, and 23F, may be more effective, but we are not told the serotypes of pneumococci causing this outbreak in Ghana. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, Prevnar 13, which covers serotypes 1, 3, 4, 5, 6A, 6B, 7F, 9V, 14, 18C, 19A, 19F, and 23F, may be more effective, but we are not told the serotypes of pneumococci causing this outbreak in Ghana. However, several studies have emphasized that _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ may also cause outbreaks of bacterial meningitis in an epidemic pattern in the African meningitis belt during the dry season, especially in older children and young adults (http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/192/2/192.abstract?ijkey=9d47813b96aa1d50880f62e9e7efbc4d32bfea9a&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha and http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/6/693.abstract?ijkey=7d2ca30004fffc8d1410102f6ec758a72efc1f82&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha). Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines reduce carriage of serotypes of _S. pneumoniae_ contained in the vaccine and thus person-to-person transmission of these pathogens, which occurs by close contact with respiratory secretions or saliva. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Ghana can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Ghana.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50377. The northern region of Ghana lies within the African meningitis belt where outbreaks of meningitis, usually due to _Neisseria meningitidis_, occur during the dry season, between December and May.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2016-01-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 19:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "7f", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4040007", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Russia: (VO) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4040007", "date": "2016-02-22 09:49:14", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - RUSSIA: (VOLOGDA) FATAL\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Feb 2016\nSource: Newsvo [in Russian, trans. Mod.NP, edited]\nhttp://newsvo.ru/news/97976\n\n\nIn January 2016, 3 children in the Vologda region (in Veliky Ustyug and Sheksninsky districts and in Vologda city) fell ill with meningococcal infection; 2 of them died, said the regional Ministry of Health.\n\nIn 2015, 7 cases of meningococcal disease were recorded in the Vologda region (1 case each in Babaev, Verhovazhsky, Vologda, and Veliky districts, and 3 cases in Vologda city); 5 of them were children; 1 of the 7 died, so mortality from meningococcal disease was 14 percent in 2015.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed-rus@promedmail.org>\n\n[The morbidity with generalized forms of meningococcal infection during the last 20 years varied within wide limits: from 0.2 to 5.0 per 100 thousand population in the different regions. Epidemics occur in cycles with peaks in incidence every 10-12 to 30 years. Currently in Russia, several polysaccharide vaccines against meningococcus A and C and meningococcal conjugate vaccine (serogroups A, C, Y and W-135) are registered. Vaccines against the meningococcus serogroup B are not available in Russia. Meningococcal vaccine coverage in Russia is, on average, 30-40 percent. - Mod.NP\n\nMaps of Russia can be seen at http://www.mapsofworld.com/images/russia-political-enlarged-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/483.\nVologda Oblast, situated in Northwestern Russia on the Eastern European plain, with a population of 1.2 million people, is a federal subject of Russia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vologda_Oblast#Geography); it is divided into 4 cities and towns under the oblast's jurisdiction (Vologda, Cherepovets, Sokol, and Veliky Ustyug) and 26 districts. Its administrative center is the city of Vologda, with a population of 301 755 inhabitants in 2010 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vologda). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed-rus@promedmail.org>\n\n[The morbidity with generalized forms of meningococcal infection during the last 20 years varied within wide limits: from 0.2 to 5.0 per 100 thousand population in the different regions. In 2015, 7 cases of meningococcal disease were recorded in the Vologda region (1 case each in Babaev, Verhovazhsky, Vologda, and Veliky districts, and 3 cases in Vologda city); 5 of them were children; 1 of the 7 died, so mortality from meningococcal disease was 14 percent in 2015. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - RUSSIA: (VOLOGDA) FATAL\n***************************************************\n In January 2016, 3 children in the Vologda region (in Veliky Ustyug and Sheksninsky districts and in Vologda city) fell ill with meningococcal infection; 2 of them died, said the regional Ministry of Health. Vologda Oblast, situated in Northwestern Russia on the Eastern European plain, with a population of 1.2 million people, is a federal subject of Russia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vologda_Oblast#Geography); it is divided into 4 cities and towns under the oblast's jurisdiction (Vologda, Cherepovets, Sokol, and Veliky Ustyug) and 26 districts.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-01-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-02-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Veliky Ustyug", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Northwestern", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Vologda", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Verhovazhsky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Babaev", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4037676", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: (Kebbi) fatal, sg C", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4037676", "date": "2016-02-21 05:31:23", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA: (KEBBI) FATAL, SEROGROUP C\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 20 Feb 2016\nSource: Daily Trust [edited]\nhttp://www.dailytrust.com.ng/news/general/how-mysterious-disease-killed-many-in-kebbi/134492.html\n\n\nThe cause of the death of several people in Yauri Local Government Area [LGA] of Kebbi State has remained a mystery. While the state authorities attribute it to the outbreak of cerebrospinal meningitis, the locals believe it is simply witchcraft or a Jin spirit that struck.\n\nThe victims were initially said to have complained of severe headache, stomach pain and high body temperature. They all died within 24 hours after contracting the disease. There are divergent views about the number of deaths so far recorded, with some putting it at 10; others claiming they are higher since the disease manifested. Thus, it remains a source of controversy even when state officials maintain there was no death recorded because those that were brought to Yauri General Hospital had been treated and discharged.\n\nCommunity leaders contacted refused to talk because they were asked not to by the Emir of Yauri, Dr Zayyanu Abdullahi. However, some locals who spoke to Daily Trust confirmed that many deaths were recorded as a result of the disease, which emanated from Kasuwan Albasa (Onion market) very close to Yauri River, a tributary of the Niger.\n\nThe market is patronized by farmers from different states, particularly the neighbouring Niger State, whose locals transport their farm produce to the market by canoe. A resident of Yauri, Alhaji Shehu Wakala, said the death toll has as of Thursday 18 [Feb 2016] reached 17, saying it was a mysterious disease because it strikes only those with links to the market.\n\nA trader at the market said the disease started manifesting in the market on Mon 8 Feb [2016], when the market was filled to capacity. 'I was in the shop when I was told of the disease. And few minutes later the market became deserted by traders for fear of contacting it,' he recounted, adding that it was after 2 days that people started returning and opened their shops for business, and there had been no report of such disease since then.\n\nAn onion dealer who spoke on condition of anonymity confirmed that 4 deaths had been recorded in the market on that fateful Monday. 2 of the people that died were female and two male, including a purified-water hawker and a sugar-cane trader. He could not tell the actual cause of the deaths, but revealed there were conflicting reports about it, with some saying it was a spirit that struck, while others attributed it to witchcraft, and some health workers from Birnin Kebbi who visited the market said their investigation showed it was cerebrospinal meningitis.\n\nHe however believed that the disease was caused by contaminated water from the river, which he said was used by virtually all the traders for drinking and performing ablution, as it remains the only source of water in the area and environs. 'We had made several complaints to the local authorities that we need a clean source of water in the area, but nothing has been done about it. The last time our chairman complained they said they were looking for private individuals who would provide such amenities and manage them, but that was not forthcoming,' he said.\n\nWhen contacted, chairman of the traders association declined to speak until there was written permission from the Emirate Council. He intimated that they were summoned and warned by the council not to grant any interview to the media unless there was a written permission duly signed by the secretary of the palace. The secretary on the other hand said it was the principal medical officer of the Yauri General Hospital who has been authorised to speak on the matter by the ministry. But the principal officer declined to comment on the matter, saying nobody authorised him to entertain any questions from the press.\n\nHowever, a [member of] senior medical personnel in the hospital confirmed that based on the outcome of their investigation, the disease was the result of the outbreak of cerebrospinal meningitis. He denied that it was witchcraft or a spirit and revealed they were on top of the situation. 'I don't practice witchcraft. I don't believe in it. This is what the people out there have been saying. As a result of the disease, an isolation centre was opened at Rukuballo which is a few kilometers from the city,' he said, adding that 9 people who suffered the attack were treated and discharged at the centre and 7 were presently on admission and responding to treatment. He said that no deaths had been recorded in the centre and if there [had been], [they must have been] outside the facility.\n\nIn addition, patients were provided with enough drugs and there was an Abuja-based organization which visited the facility and promised to support them. It was observed at the isolation centre that few people were on admission and they were managed with only 2 nurses, who kept sealed lips on the matter.\n\nSadly, [a] 14 year old was not fortunate to be among the survivors. Her father said his daughter was among the vendors at the onion market, selling pure water. He recalled her breaking the news of the outbreak of the disease to her grandmother, who in turn asked her not to go there again but she was adamant. She later complained of headache, stomach pain, and fever after returning from the market on Monday [15 Feb 2016] and she was taken to a herbalist who said she was suffering from spiritual attack and gave them some herbs. After taking it she was relieved that night. But her condition worsened the following day and her uncle was called after which he decided to take her to the hospital but she died on the way.\n\nThe Kebbi State government, in a statement signed by special adviser to Governor Atiku Bagudu on health, Dr Fatima Mustapha Bunza, said the recent 'strange' killer disease in Yauri, Yauri LGA has not put the state at epidemic threshold. It said it was caused by cerebrospinal meningitis, adding that the outbreak was reported from Yauri town in Yauri LGA on 8 Feb 2016 with additional cases on 13 Fri Feb 2016, making a total of 9 cases. [The statement] read: 'An isolation camp was immediately established in Yauri and samples for laboratory investigations dispatched to the laboratory in Sokoto.'\n\nThe statement continued: '2 out of 9 samples tested were confirmed positive for [_Neisseria meningitidis_ ] serotype C. A single case from Andarai in Maiyama LGA was earlier confirmed in January [2016]. The 1st confirmed case was treated and discharged in January [2016] and currently the 2 confirmed cases are responding to treatment at the isolation camp in Yauri. With these numbers alone, we are not yet at the epidemic threshold, but we should all be on the alert and intensify surveillance in all our communities as the government of Kebbi State deploys proactive measures to forestall escalation of the situation.'\n\nThe statement also revealed that the state government has already instituted some measures, which included the state's rapid-response team and the Yauri LGA teams which were activated from the 1st day of the report. In addition, CSM [cerebrospinal meningitis] Treatment protocol has been shared to all the disease surveillance and notification officers (DSNOs) and some test lumbar puncture kits were also shared. More kits are being expected from World Health Organization (WHO) country office.\n\nIt further intimated that an active case search supported by DSNOs, as well as WHO, is on-going, including community mobilisation, advocacy and sensitisation of traditional leaders in the LGA. In this regard, Kebbi State government is working with the Federal Ministry of Health, National Primary Health Care Development Agency (NPHCDA) and Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (CDC) to mobilise support to contain further spread as well as secure vaccines for dual purposes of prevention and [creating] immunity within the population, based on available results and epidemiological history.\n\n[byline: Anyichie Tochukwu]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria falls within the African Meningitis Belt, the semi-arid areas of sub-Saharan Africa where epidemics of meningococcal meningitis recur each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June. _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A has been the main cause of epidemic meningococcal disease in this region (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf). However, since the introduction of the meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt in 2010, WHO has noted a decrease in the number of cases of meningitis; in fact, the number of cases in 2013 was the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years (http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/), and _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was noted to be no longer the predominant pathogen, having been replaced by other serogroups.\n\nProMED-mail previously reported in 2015 on the emergence of outbreaks of meningitis due to _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C in Kebbi State (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kebbi) in north west Nigeria (see alsos below). The emergence of serogroup C outbreaks in the African Meningitis Belt has been thought to be evidence of serogroup replacement in the meningitis belt following mass vaccination with serogroup A conjugate vaccine.\n\nThe above news release reports the recurrence of the serogroup C meningitis outbreak in Kebbi State in north west Nigeria since January 2016. Several vaccines are available to control the disease during an outbreak: a meningococcal A conjugate vaccine, C conjugate vaccines, tetravalent A, C, Y, and W conjugate vaccines and meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines. Unlike polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and therefore longer-term protection, than the polysaccharide vaccines. Consideration should be given to vaccination with of tetravalent conjugate vaccine to control this outbreak. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1279.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Anyichie Tochukwu]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nigeria falls within the African Meningitis Belt, the semi-arid areas of sub-Saharan Africa where epidemics of meningococcal meningitis recur each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June.
