ASEPTIC MENINGITIS - RUSSIA: (TOMSK) ENTEROVIRUS SUSPECTED\n**********************************************************", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-08-26 00:00:00", "2070-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Simbirtseva", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3776965", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - USA: (CA) college students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3776965", "date": "2015-11-09 09:38:43", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA: (CALIFORNIA) COLLEGE STUDENTS\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 6 Nov 2015\nSource: KEYT.com [edited]\nhttp://www.keyt.com/news/meningitis-cases-discovered-at-cal-poly/36305972\n\n\nPublic Health officials in San Luis Obispo County [California] are warning about cases of viral meningitis discovered at Cal Poly.\n\nSo far 5 students [in the past month] have been diagnosed with the infection. County Public Health officials stress these are cases of viral meningitis and not the more dangerous bacterial meningitis.\n\n'People with viral meningitis usually complain they've got the worst headache of their life', says Ann McDowell, epidemiologist with the San Luis Obispo County Public Health Department, 'they're feeling nauseous, they might throw up, a stiff neck, they are sensitive to light, those are the most common symptoms that you see.' Meningitis, be it viral or bacterial, must be reported to the local county public health department wherever it is detected. So far no bacterial meningitis has been detected on or off the Cal Poly campus.\n\n'Viral meningitis is contagious person to person only if you are in close proximity and sharing personal fluids', McDowell says, 'so if you are sharing cups or eating utensils, or personal hygiene, or if you are hugging or kissing or in close contact with somebody you can you can spread it but it's very rare to spread viral meningitis.'\n\nCal Poly students we spoke with say they were alerted about the viral meningitis cases on campus by the University via email. 'I'm glad that I'm aware of it', says Cal Poly student Erin Clark, 'but I feel like that's a pretty low percentage of people affected.' 'Wash your hands more, don't go to class if you're feeling real bad, professors are really understanding', adds Cal Poly student Martha Limon, 'go to the health center, even if its just a cough, just go to the health center.'\n\nThere's no vaccine or antibiotic for viral meningitis, treatment includes plenty of rest and fluids, full recovery can take up to 10 days.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term 'meningitis' means an inflammation of the meninges, which are the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord, and implies lack of brain and spinal cord involvement (otherwise called encephalitis and myelitis, respectively). In viral meningitis, the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is usually visibly clear, but on laboratory examination the CSF white cell count is 6 to 500 cells per cmm, usually with lymphocytes predominating. The symptoms of viral meningitis usually last from 7 to 10 days, and the patient recovers completely.\n\nThe non-polio enteroviruses are the most common causes of viral meningitis, especially during the summer and fall months. However, other causes of viral meningitis include mumps, lymphocytic choriomeningitis viruses, arboviruses, HIV, herpes simplex virus (HSV) types 1 and 2. Some bacteria and non-infectious causes of meningitis can produce a CSF picture simulating viral meningitis. Non-infectious causes include certain drugs, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and systemic diseases, such as lupus, sarcoidosis, and metastatic cancer.\n\nMost people who get infected with enteroviruses are asymptomatic or have only a non-specific febrile illness. Enteroviruses are most often spread via the fecal-oral route from person to person, through fecal contamination of water or food, or contact with contaminated inanimate objects. Enteroviruses can also be spread through the respiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus) of an infected person.\n\nCalifornia Polytechnic State University, also known as Cal Poly, is a public university located in San Luis Obispo, California, United States, with almost 20 000 undergraduate and 1000 postgraduate students (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Polytechnic_State_University). San Luis Obispo, with a population of over 45 000, is a coastal city located about midway between the California cities of Los Angeles and San Francisco (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Luis_Obispo,_California). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1036.]", "summary": "\n\n'Viral meningitis is contagious person to person only if you are in close proximity and sharing personal fluids', McDowell says, 'so if you are sharing cups or eating utensils, or personal hygiene, or if you are hugging or kissing or in close contact with somebody you can you can spread it Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term 'meningitis' means an inflammation of the meninges, which are the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord, and implies lack of brain and spinal cord involvement (otherwise called encephalitis and myelitis, respectively). \n\n'People with viral meningitis usually complain they've got the worst headache of their life', says Ann McDowell, epidemiologist with the San Luis Obispo County Public Health Department, 'they're feeling nauseous, they might throw up, a stiff neck, they are sensitive to light, those are the most common symptoms that you see.' A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n County Public Health officials stress these are cases of viral meningitis and not the more dangerous bacterial meningitis. Some bacteria and non-infectious causes of meningitis can produce a CSF picture simulating viral meningitis. \n\nThe non-polio enteroviruses are the most common causes of viral meningitis, especially during the summer and fall months. \n\nThere's no vaccine or antibiotic for viral meningitis, treatment includes plenty of rest and fluids, full recovery can take up to 10 days. \n\nCal Poly students we spoke with say they were alerted about the viral meningitis cases on campus by the University via email. In viral meningitis, the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is usually visibly clear, but on laboratory examination the CSF white cell count is 6 to 500 cells per cmm, usually with lymphocytes predominating.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Luis Obispo County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Luis Obispo", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Francisco", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3533998", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Niger (04): serogroup C, fatal, WHO, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3533998", "date": "2015-07-24 17:40:30", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGER (04): SEROGROUP C, FATAL, WHO, UPDATE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 23 Jul 2015\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/23-july-2015-niger/en/\n\n\nDisease outbreak news - Meningococcal disease - Niger (update)\n-----------------\nBetween 1 Jan and 28 Jun 2015, the Ministry of Public Health of Niger notified WHO of 8500 suspected cases of meningococcal meningitis, including 573 deaths. This was the largest meningitis outbreak caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C in the African meningitis belt.\n\nThe number of suspected cases increased very rapidly, tripling weekly between 1 and 15 May 2015. 13 districts in Niger crossed the epidemic threshold. The 5 districts of Niamey, Niger's capital and largest city, reported 5267 suspected cases and 260 deaths.\n\nThe outbreak peaked between 4 and 10 May 2015 when 2182 cases, including 132 deaths, were reported. Since then, the outbreak declined substantially -- from 22 to 28 Jun, a total of 11 cases, including 2 deaths, were reported.\n\nLaboratory tests confirmed the predominance of _Neisseria meningitidis_ (Nm) serogroup C in the affected areas, with Nm serogroup W also being identified in 12 percent of positive samples. Although serogroup C has been the predominant cause of meningitis in wealthy countries, it has never been of high concern in Africa.\n\nAn epidemic committee was activated to manage the outbreak at all levels of the country. An international team comprising experts from WHO and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) was deployed to support the Ministry of Public Health in carrying out epidemiological investigations and strengthening the national surveillance capacity.\n\nTogether with its partners, WHO assisted the government of Niger in the implementation of mass vaccination campaigns and other emergency control measures. The International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control approved 4 vaccination requests and released 965 000 doses of multivalent C and W containing polysaccharide vaccine and 200 000 doses of ACYW conjugate vaccine. Furthermore, the government of Niger obtained 200 000 doses of polysaccharide ACWY vaccine from the government of Mali.\n\nIn addition to mass immunization campaigns and enhanced surveillance, social mobilization and case management activities were performed in all affected areas. These measures led to the control of the outbreak. Currently, all districts are below the epidemic threshold.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Serogroup A meningococcus had been the main cause of epidemic meningococcal disease in the African meningitis belt, which includes Niger (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf; see map at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/travel-static/yellowbook/2014/map_3-11.pdf).\nHowever, the epidemiology of meningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt has changed after preventive vaccination with conjugate meningitis A vaccine -- MenAfrivac (R) -- was introduced in 2010.\n\nImmunity following use of a meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is serogroup-specific with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups. Consequently, serogroup A meningococcal meningitis outbreaks have not been reported in countries like Niger where preventive vaccination with the conjugate meningitis A vaccine has been undertaken. Serogroups like C and W have now emerged as the common causes of outbreaks in the belt as seen in the current outbreak in Niger.\n\nThe current outbreak highlights the need for enhanced surveillance of meningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt and linking the findings to better preparedness and response to prevent large-scale outbreaks like the current one.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe current outbreak highlights the need for enhanced surveillance of meningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt and linking the findings to better preparedness and response to prevent large-scale outbreaks like the current one. However, the epidemiology of meningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt has changed after preventive vaccination with conjugate meningitis A vaccine -- MenAfrivac (R) -- was introduced in 2010. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Serogroup A meningococcus had been the main cause of epidemic meningococcal disease in the African meningitis belt, which includes Niger (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf; see map at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/travel-static/yellowbook/2014/map_3-11.pdf). The International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control approved 4 vaccination requests and released 965 000 doses of multivalent C and W containing polysaccharide vaccine and 200 000 doses of ACYW conjugate vaccine. Consequently, serogroup A meningococcal meningitis outbreaks have not been reported in countries like Niger where preventive vaccination with the conjugate meningitis A vaccine has been undertaken. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGER (04): SEROGROUP C, FATAL, WHO, UPDATE\n***********************************************************************\n This was the largest meningitis outbreak caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C in the African meningitis belt. \n\nThe outbreak peaked between 4 and 10 May 2015 when 2182 cases, including 132 deaths, were reported. Between 1 Jan and 28 Jun 2015, the Ministry of Public Health of Niger notified WHO of 8500 suspected cases of meningococcal meningitis, including 573 deaths. Immunity following use of a meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is serogroup-specific with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-05-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "Chile"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3604861", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Europe (02): (Sweden, UK) ex Japan, Boy Scouts alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3604861", "date": "2015-08-26 21:15:10", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - UNITED KINGDOM, EUROPE (02): (SWEDEN, UK) ex JAPAN, BOY SCOUTS ALERT\n************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 26 Aug 2015\nFrom: Hajime Kamiya <hakamiya@niid.go.jp> [edited]\n\n\nBetween 8-19 Aug 2015, 8 cases (5 confirmed and 3 suspected) of meningococcal disease were reported from the UK (Scotland) and Sweden following attendance at the World Scout Jamboree (WSJ), Yamaguchi, Japan from 28 Jul-8 Aug 2015. _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup W was isolated from blood samples of 2 of the cases. ECDC reported the rapid risk assessment of this event on 21 Aug 2015 http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/Meningococcal-disease-scouts-EU-August-2015.pdf.\n\nIn Japan, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) requested the Scout Association of Japan on 14 Aug 2015 to alert the WSJ participants to visit a hospital as soon as possible if they develop any signs or symptoms of meningococcal disease. At this moment, no cases linked with WSJ have been reported in Japan. For further information on this event, please see http://www.nih.go.jp/niid/en/id/997-disease-based/sa/bac-megingitis/idsc/ias.\n\nIn Japan, 7-21 cases of meningococcal meningitis have been annually notified since 1999 to March 2013. In April 2013, meningococcal meningitis and meningococcal sepsis together were newly classified as 'invasive meningococcal infection.' Since then, a total of 60 cases have been reported to the national surveillance system up to December 2014. While not included as a routine vaccination, meningococcal conjugate vaccine (MCV4) was approved for licensure in July 2014 in Japan.\n\nPlease refer to http://www.nih.go.jp/niid/en/iasr-vol34-e/865-iasr/4202-tpc406.html and\nhttp://www.nih.go.jp/niid/en/2013-03-15-04-55-59/997-disease-based/sa/bac-megingitis/idsc/iasr-in/5879-pr4272e.html\nfor the recent epidemiology of invasive meningococcal disease cases and serogroup in Japan.\n\n--\nHajime Kamiya\nInfectious Disease Surveillance Center\nNational Institute of Infectious Diseases\nJapan\n<hakamiya@niid.go.jp>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Hajime Kamiya for this information.\n\nA total of about 34 000 [mostly young] people [Boy Scouts and their leaders] from some 150 countries and territories converged on the Kirara-hama beach in Yamaguchi, Japan for this event from 29 Jul through 8 Aug 2015. While no cases have been reported from countries other than Sweden and Scotland in relation to this event thus far, it is likely that we will be hearing reports from other countries (perhaps including Japan). However, we are getting late in the game for disease related to contact at the WSJ. Serogroup W, the putative infecting agent, is included in the standard meningococcal vaccines, and prior immunization will provide protection to those who were immunized. Immunization should be considered for the unimmunized Scouts.\n\nAntimicrobial prophylaxis would be important for close contacts of the cases (e.g. roommates), but this information may not be available for the great majority of the Scouts. The Swedish health agency urged all returning participants to seek preventive treatment as a precaution.\n\nSee ProMED-mail archived post 20150820.3591304: 'Meningitis, meningococcal - Europe: (Sweden, Scotland), Japan, Boy Scouts, RFI' for Mod.ML's review of meningococcal meningitis. - Mod.DK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nPlease refer to http://www.nih.go.jp/niid/en/iasr-vol34-e/865-iasr/4202-tpc406.html and\nhttp://www.nih.go.jp/niid/en/2013-03-15-04-55-59/997-disease-based/sa/bac-megingitis/idsc/iasr-in/5879-pr4272e.html\nfor the recent epidemiology of invasive meningococcal disease cases and serogroup in Japan. Infectious Disease Surveillance Center\nNational Institute of Infectious Diseases\nJapan\n<hakamiya@niid.go.jp>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Hajime Kamiya for this information. From: Hajime Kamiya <hakamiya@niid.go.jp> [edited]\n\n\nBetween 8-19 Aug 2015, 8 cases (5 confirmed and 3 suspected) of meningococcal disease were reported from the UK (Scotland) and Sweden following attendance at the World Scout Jamboree (WSJ), Yamaguchi, Japan from 28 Jul-8 Aug 2015. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - UNITED KINGDOM, EUROPE (02): (SWEDEN, UK) ex JAPAN, BOY SCOUTS ALERT\n************************************************************************************************\n In April 2013, meningococcal meningitis and meningococcal sepsis together were newly classified as 'invasive meningococcal infection.' In Japan, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) requested the Scout Association of Japan on 14 Aug 2015 to alert the WSJ participants to visit a hospital as soon as possible if they develop any signs or symptoms of meningococcal disease. \n\nSee ProMED-mail archived post 20150820.3591304: 'Meningitis, meningococcal - Europe: (Sweden, Scotland), Japan, Boy Scouts, RFI' for Mod. In Japan, 7-21 cases of meningococcal meningitis have been annually notified since 1999 to March 2013.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-08-21 00:00:00", "2014-12-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-07-21 00:00:00", "2015-08-14 00:00:00", "2015-08-08 00:00:00", "2014-07-26 00:00:00", "2013-04-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Boy Scouts", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "JAPAN", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Yamaguchi", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Kirara", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3552463", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Niger (05): serogroup C, fatal, vaccine shortage", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3552463", "date": "2015-08-02 09:43:12", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGER (05): SEROGROUP C, FATAL, VACCINE SHORTAGE\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 1 Aug 2015\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/01/health/new-meningitis-strain-in-africa-brings-call-for-more-vaccines.html?_r=1\n\n\nMeningitis may be poised for a ferocious comeback in Africa, international aid organizations are warning, and vaccine manufacturers must step up production if the outbreak is to be averted.\n\nMeningitis is caused by one of several strains of the bacteria _Neisseria meningitidis_. A vaccine introduced 5 years ago has all but defeated meningitis A infections in Africa. But infections with another strain, Type C, are on the rise.\n\nSome experts fear the new strain will explode next year [2016], while others say too little is known to predict its course reliably.\n\nMeningitis C vaccines exist but are expensive: USD 20 per shot is the lowest price offered thus far to an international public health consortium, led by the World Health Organization, that stockpiles vaccines for emergencies. The consortium, the International Coordinating Group for Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control, is seeking 5 million doses. To be effective, they must be shipped and injected before January [2016], when meningitis normally returns to Africa with the dry harmattan winds. Unless something drastic happens -- a surge of donor money, or huge price cuts -- the consortium's experts do not hold out much hope. 'If we don't get the doses, we'll be having a really hard time,' said Dr. William A. Perea, coordinator of the WHO's epidemic diseases control unit. 'So we are making a little noise.'\n\nThe global vaccine industry is fragile. Because of mergers and acquisitions, only 4 major pharmaceutical companies -- GlaxoSmithKline, Sanofi-Pasteur, Merck and Pfizer -- still make vaccines for diseases other than flu. They are primarily interested in serving wealthy countries, where they can charge USD 100 or more per dose. As a result, there are too few factories to supply the vaccines poor countries need and, also, little competition to drive down prices.\n\n'Vaccine pricing has traditionally been much more secretive than drug pricing,' said Kate Elder, vaccines policy adviser at Doctors Without Borders. 'When we survey companies, they never tell us how they arrive at prices.' State-owned factories in India, Brazil, Cuba and elsewhere also manufacture meningitis vaccines. While they can sometimes be paid to make more than their own countries need, many are reliant on old technology and hampered by government bureaucracies. A low-priced vaccine against meningitis C and 4 other strains of the infection is being developed in India but will need at least another 5 years of testing.\n\nMeningitis used to strike thousands of Africans every year. In 1997, meningitis sickened 250 000 people and killed 25 000. Survivors also suffer. 1/4th are left brain-damaged, paralyzed, prone to seizures, or without limbs that had to be amputated. In African schools for the deaf, most students are meningitis victims. Desperate families often sell everything to pay for care: chickens, cows, even front doors, which in West Africa can be elaborately carved heirlooms.\n\nType A bacteria were once responsible for more than 80 percent of Africa's meningitis cases, but that infection is being vanquished by a new vaccine, MenAfriVac, which was introduced in 2010 by the WHO, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, and PATH, a Seattle health technology group. Over 220 million doses against Type A, made by the Serum Institute of India for 50 cents each, have been injected. But that success has had an alarming coda. Two years ago, a new Type C strain appeared, a genetic variant from the previous Type C.\n\nIn April [2015], a serious outbreak in Niger sickened nearly 6000 people and caused nearly 500 deaths. 'There was a lot of anxiety, because very few people in Niger didn't know somebody who'd gotten ill or died in the past,' said Dr. Sarah A. Meyer, an epidemiologist for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention who helped fight the outbreak. 'People prayed for the rains to start. And they started rushing to the pharmacy for vaccines.' Experts are now fiercely debating what will happen when the harmattan winds return to Africa's so-called meningitis belt, which stretches from the Atlantic Coast to Ethiopia.\n\nExperts at the WHO and Doctors Without Borders fear that the new strain will spread. But others, including Dr. Meyer and colleagues at the CDC, say there is no way to predict that with confidence. Previous outbreaks of meningitis C -- in Europe, for example -- have not followed the pattern typical of Type A in Africa: a few low-level years, then an explosive epidemic. 'The idea that there is a death knell sounding for these countries is exaggerated,' said Dr. Marc LaForce, a meningitis expert who led the development of MenAfriVac. But the new Type C strain is not identical to its European ancestor, 'so one has to prepare,' said Dr. Olivier Ronveaux, an epidemiologist at the WHO. Over the next few weeks, his agency hopes to swab the throats of Africans across the belt to see how many carry the new Type C strain without symptoms. That may help predict what will happen in January [2016].\n\nOn a much smaller scale, a similar strain substitution took place on American college campuses in the last decade. Expensive new quadrivalent vaccines, effective against multiple strains of meningitis, were introduced in 2005 and reduced infections with Types A, C, W and Y by more than 90 percent. Then, in 2013, the B strain surged, causing outbreaks at Princeton and the University of California, Santa Barbara. One student died. The Obama administration responded by importing a meningitis B vaccine that had been approved in Europe but not in the United States.\n\nMeningitis often strikes young people and can progress from a bad headache to death so quickly that hospital care comes too late, even in the United States. Mysteriously, _Neisseria_ bacteria spread easily in saliva and harmlessly colonize the throats of about a 1/5th of the world's population. The bacteria kill only if they reach the bloodstream or the meninges, membranes protecting the brain and spine. In the West, 'freshman meningitis' or 'boot camp meningitis' affects people gathered in dorms or barracks who adopt new habits like sharing beer bottles, toothbrushes, cigarettes or joints, or kissing.\n\nIn Africa, meningitis surges when cold winds force families indoors and dry out throats, opening tiny cracks through which bacteria enter the blood.\n\nThe world used to rely on polysaccharide vaccines, which are cheap, but their protection does not last long, and they do not kill silent throat infections. About 20 years ago, conjugate vaccines were introduced. By coupling the polysaccharides -- sugarlike molecules from the bacterial membranes -- to proteins, they provoke long-lasting immune responses and can also clear silent infections.\n\nSix strains of the meningitis bacteria cause disease: A, B, C, W, X and Y. GlaxoSmithKline and Sanofi make conjugate vaccines against A, C, W and Y and have made some of them available to the WHO at lower prices. But the manufacturers cannot produce enough for a major outbreak. The Serum Institute of India is working on a vaccine against 5 strains -- all but B -- but it will not be finished until about 2020, Dr. LaForce said, assuming it passes all clinical trials.\n\nVaccines against Type B bacteria must be made differently because the polysaccharides on the membrane of that strain resemble some on the surface of human nerve cells, so there is a risk that making antibodies to them could cause a dangerous autoimmune reaction.\n\n[Byline: Donald G. McNeil Jr.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are at least 13 _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides; disease due serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135 are most common. Serogroup A meningococcus had been the main cause of epidemic meningococcal disease in the African meningitis belt, which includes Niger (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf; see map of the African meningitis belt at http://www.cdc.gov/travel-static/yellowbook/2014/map_3-11.pdf). However, the epidemiology of meningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt has changed after preventive vaccination with conjugate meningitis A vaccine -- MenAfrivac (R) -- was introduced in 2010.\n\nSeveral vaccines are available to control the disease during an outbreak: a meningococcal A conjugate vaccine, C conjugate vaccine, tetravalent A, C, Y, and W conjugate vaccines, and meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines. Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines.\n\nThe presence of circulating bactericidal antibody at the time of exposure appears to be critical for protection against meningococcal disease. Immunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is serogroup-specific with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups. Consequently, serogroup A meningococcal meningitis outbreaks have not been reported in countries like Niger where preventive vaccination with the conjugate meningitis A vaccine has been undertaken. Serogroups like C and W have now emerged as the common causes of outbreaks in the African meningitis belt as seen in the current outbreak in Niger.\n\nIn view of replacement of meningococcal serogroup A with other serogroups following mass vaccination of the population with serogroup A conjugate vaccine, reactive mass vaccination to control an outbreak would require use of a meningococcal vaccine containing the serogroup causing the particular outbreak.\n\nThe current outbreak highlights the need for enhanced surveillance of meningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt and linking the findings to better preparedness and response to prevent large-scale outbreaks like the current one. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58.]", "summary": "\n\nSeveral vaccines are available to control the disease during an outbreak: a meningococcal A conjugate vaccine, C conjugate vaccine, tetravalent A, C, Y, and W conjugate vaccines, and meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines. However, the epidemiology of meningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt has changed after preventive vaccination with conjugate meningitis A vaccine -- MenAfrivac (R) -- was introduced in 2010. In view of replacement of meningococcal serogroup A with other serogroups following mass vaccination of the population with serogroup A conjugate vaccine, reactive mass vaccination to control an outbreak would require use of a meningococcal vaccine containing the serogroup causing the particular outbreak. Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines. Consequently, serogroup A meningococcal meningitis outbreaks have not been reported in countries like Niger where preventive vaccination with the conjugate meningitis A vaccine has been undertaken. \n\nMeningitis C vaccines exist but are expensive: USD 20 per shot is the lowest price offered thus far to an international public health consortium, led by the World Health Organization, that stockpiles vaccines for emergencies. The current outbreak highlights the need for enhanced surveillance of meningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt and linking the findings to better preparedness and response to prevent large-scale outbreaks like the current one. \n\nSix strains of the meningitis bacteria cause disease: A, B, C, W, X and Y. GlaxoSmithKline and Sanofi make conjugate vaccines against A, C, W and Y and have made some of them available to the WHO at lower prices. Serogroup A meningococcus had been the main cause of epidemic meningococcal disease in the African meningitis belt, which includes Niger (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf; see map of the African meningitis belt at http://www.cdc.gov/travel-static/yellowbook/2014/map_3-11.pdf). In the West, 'freshman meningitis' or 'boot camp meningitis' affects people gathered in dorms or barracks who adopt new habits like sharing beer bottles, toothbrushes, cigarettes or joints, or kissing. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Two years ago, a new Type C strain appeared, a genetic variant from the previous Type C.\n\nIn April [2015], a serious outbreak in Niger sickened nearly 6000 people and caused nearly 500 deaths. ' MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGER (05): SEROGROUP C, FATAL, VACCINE SHORTAGE\n****************************************************************************\n \n\nVaccines against Type B bacteria must be made differently because the polysaccharides on the membrane of that strain resemble some on the surface of human nerve cells, so there is a risk that making antibodies to them could cause a dangerous autoimmune reaction. Expensive new quadrivalent vaccines, effective against multiple strains of meningitis, were introduced in 2005 and reduced infections with Types A, C, W and Y by more than 90 percent. Type A bacteria were once responsible for more than 80 percent of Africa's meningitis cases, but that infection is being vanquished by a new vaccine, MenAfriVac, which was introduced in 2010 by the WHO, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, and PATH, a Seattle health technology group. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are at least 13 _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides; disease due serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135 are most common. Previous outbreaks of meningitis C -- in Europe, for example -- have not followed the pattern typical of Type A in Africa: a few low-level years, then an explosive epidemic. ' \n\n'Vaccine pricing has traditionally been much more secretive than drug pricing,' said Kate Elder, vaccines policy adviser at Doctors Without Borders. ' A low-priced vaccine against meningitis C and 4 other strains of the infection is being developed in India but will need at least another 5 years of testing. \n\nMeningitis often strikes young people and can progress from a bad headache to death so quickly that hospital care comes too late, even in the United States. \n\nMeningitis is caused by one of several strains of the bacteria _Neisseria meningitidis_. \n\n\nMeningitis may be poised for a ferocious comeback in Africa, international aid organizations are warning, and vaccine manufacturers must step up production if the outbreak is to be averted. A vaccine introduced 5 years ago has all but defeated meningitis A infections in Africa. The consortium, the International Coordinating Group for Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control, is seeking 5 million doses.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-26 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cuba", "country": "Cuba"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Santa Barbara", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3591304", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Europe: (Sweden, UK) ex Japan, Boy Scouts, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3591304", "date": "2015-08-20 15:39:33", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - EUROPE: (SWEDEN, UK) ex JAPAN, BOY SCOUTS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 18 Aug 2015\nSource: ABC News [edited]\nhttp://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/sweden-suspects-meningitis-outbreak-scout-camp-japan-33132190\n\n\nA total of about 34 000 people from some 150 countries and territories converge on the Kirara-hama beach in Yamaguchi, Japan, 29 Jul 2015, to kick off the 23rd World Scout Jamboree.\n\nSweden's health authority is urging nearly 2000 scouts returning from a gathering in Japan to get medical treatment after a suspected outbreak of meningitis. The Swedish Public Health Agency on Monday said 1 Swedish participant was likely to have contracted the disease at the World Scout Jamboree. 2 other cases were under investigation.\n\nThe agency also said 3 cases have been reported in Scotland.\n\nThe Scout Association of Japan said it was aware of the cases in Scotland, and that it had warned others who had camped near the Scottish scouts, including groups from Sweden, Switzerland, France, Finland, the United States and Japan.\n\nAn estimated 30 000 scouts from around the world attended the 28 Jul - 8 Aug 2015 event in Kirara-hama in western Japan, including 1900 from Sweden.\n\nThe Swedish health agency urged returning participants to seek preventive treatment as a precaution, even if they're not feeling sick.\n\nMeningitis is a bacterial infection of the lining surrounding the brain and spinal cord that most commonly affects children and teenagers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nCamden Choo\n<camden.choo@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 18 Aug 2015\nSource: Daily Record [edited]\nhttp://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/scottish-teenage-scouts-recovering-well-6273145\n\n\n3 Scots scouts are suffering from meningitis, which they contracted during a jamboree in Japan. 2 cases of meningococcal disease -- the most common cause of bacterial meningitis -- were confirmed last week, but a further teenager was found to be suffering from the condition in the last few days. All 3 are aged between 14 and 18 and are from the Highlands.\n\nThe 3 were in a group of around 30 from the north of Scotland who were in Kirara-hama, Japan, along with another 150 Scots, to attend an international Scout jamboree which was attended by 33 000 teenagers from around the globe.\n\nThey returned on 8 Aug [2015] and it was only after arrival home they began to exhibit signs of the illness.\n\nAll 3 Scouts were treated in hospital and are 'recovering well'. An Incident Management Team led by Health Protection Scotland and NHS boards identified all close contacts and gave them antibiotics and immunisation as a precautionary measure. HPS also sent an 'advise and inform' letter to the participants from other units in Scotland who attended the Jamboree, and approximately 4000 letters were also issued to other participants in the rest of UK alerting them to the signs and symptoms of disease.\n\nThere have been no other reported British cases but on Monday [17 Aug 2015] the Public Health Agency of Sweden reported 3 suspected cases of meningococcal infection in Swedish participants who attended the same jamboree.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nCamden Choo\n<camden.choo@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Camden Choo for the submission.\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ only infects humans; there is no animal reservoir and the organism dies quickly outside the human host. _N. meningitidis_ colonizes the mucosal membranes of the nose and throat; up to 5-10 percent of a population may be asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers, but the carrier rate may be higher in epidemic situations. Droplets of nasopharyngeal secretions from these carriers are responsible for the spread of the disease. Close and prolonged contact with an infected person or a carrier facilitates the spread of the disease. The average incubation period is 4 days, but can range between 2 and 10 days.\n\nThe news reports say that antibiotics and immunization are being given to close contacts as precautionary measures. The risk for acquiring meningococcal disease in close contacts is 500-800 times greater than among the general population (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm). Effective prophylactic antibiotic regimens for adults include: rifampin 600 mg orally twice daily for 2 days; ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally as a single dose; and ceftriaxone 250 mg as a single intramuscular injection.\n\nSeveral meningococcal vaccines are available to control the disease during an outbreak. Immunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is specific for the capsular polysaccharide that the vaccine contains, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups. Although there are at least 13 _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135 are most common.\n\nThere are vaccines that contain capsular polysaccharide A, C, Y, or W135, either alone or conjugated to protein. Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines. Serogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. However, we are not told in the news reports above which serogroup or serogroups are involved in the Boy Scout Jamboree outbreak and what vaccines are being offered. More information in this regard would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nFor further discussion of invasive meningococcal disease, see moderator comments in prior ProMED-mail posts. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nThere have been no other reported British cases but on Monday [17 Aug 2015] the Public Health Agency of Sweden reported 3 suspected cases of meningococcal infection in Swedish participants who attended the same jamboree. Communicated by:\nCamden Choo\n<camden.choo@gmail.com>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nCamden Choo\n<camden.choo@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Camden Choo for the submission. Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - EUROPE: (SWEDEN, UK) ex JAPAN, BOY SCOUTS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************************\n 2 cases of meningococcal disease -- the most common cause of bacterial meningitis -- were confirmed last week, but a further teenager was found to be suffering from the condition in the last few days. \n\nAn estimated 30 000 scouts from around the world attended the 28 Jul - 8 Aug 2015 event in Kirara-hama in western Japan, including 1900 from Sweden. \n\nSeveral meningococcal vaccines are available to control the disease during an outbreak. Immunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is specific for the capsular polysaccharide that the vaccine contains, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups. \n\nSweden's health authority is urging nearly 2000 scouts returning from a gathering in Japan to get medical treatment after a suspected outbreak of meningitis. \n\n--\n \n\n--\n Effective prophylactic antibiotic regimens for adults include: rifampin 600 mg orally twice daily for 2 days; ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally as a single dose; and ceftriaxone 250 mg as a single intramuscular injection. \n\nThere are vaccines that contain capsular polysaccharide A, C, Y, or W135, either alone or conjugated to protein. \n\nMeningitis is a bacterial infection of the lining surrounding the brain and spinal cord that most commonly affects children and teenagers.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1900-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-08-18 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "Finland"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "JAPAN", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Kirara", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Yamaguchi", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3502722", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (IL) fatal, MSM, vaccine, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3502722", "date": "2015-07-11 10:11:19", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (02): (ILLINOIS) FATAL, MEN WHO HAVE SEX WITH MEN, VACCINE, INFORMATION REQUEST\n***************************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 9 Jul 2015\nSource: TribTown, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.tribtown.com/view/story/1dc2a639e3ee431eb05d7356002a5244/IL--Chicago-Meningitis-Outbreak\n\n\nHealth officials have identified another case in a serious outbreak of meningitis affecting gay and bisexual men in the Chicago [Illinois] area. Chicago Department of Public Health commissioner Julie Morita says a 7th case was identified over the weekend [4-5 Jul 2015]. It is the 6th case in Chicago and the 7th in Illinois. One person has died. Another person remains hospitalized and 2 are confined to rehabilitation facilities. Morita says that shows how serious the infection can be.\n\nMorita held a meeting on Thursday morning [9 Jul 2015] with Chicago aldermen to enlist their support.\n\nThe majority of individuals who have been identified as having meningitis have been African-American men.\n\nThe city's health department has distributed 11 000 vaccines to pharmacies and other providers. The department has given more than 5100 vaccines to residents directly.\n\n--\n\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 24 Jun 2015\nSource: Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) [edited]\nhttp://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/cdph/supp_info/infectious/get-the-facts--invasive-meningococcal-disease.html\n\n\nIn early June 2015, an outbreak of invasive meningococcal disease (also referred to as 'meningitis') was identified among men who have sex with men (MSM). Invasive meningococcal disease [IMD] can refer to any illness caused by the bacteria, _Neisseria meningitidis_. This includes bloodstream infections and meningitis, when the bacteria enter the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord.\n\nInitially, the Chicago Department of Public Health [CDPH] made vaccine recommendations for a subgroup of MSM to prevent IMD. However, cases continue to occur. As of 18 Jun 2015, CDPH is broadening our vaccination recommendation to include all MSM.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although we are not told the microbial etiology of meningitis in men who have sex with men (MSM) in the Chicago, Illinois, area in the 1st news report above, I assume this meningitis outbreak is due to _Neisseria meningitidis_, as mentioned in the 2nd news report above.\n\nThe following was extracted from my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - France: (Paris) serogroup C, MSM, vaccination 20150124.3116307:\n\nOutbreaks of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) have occurred among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Germany, Belgium and France caused by a _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C strain with a certain genotype (http://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/rapid-risk-assessment-invasive-meningococcal-disease-among-MSM.pdf). Similar outbreaks among MSM caused by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C have occurred in Canada and the US (see prior ProMED-mail posts).\n\nMolecular epidemiology has revealed that most cases of IMD are caused by only a few hypervirulent clonal lineages, whereas the genetic diversity is higher in meningococci recovered from healthy carriers (Claus H, Weinand H, Frosch M, Vogel U. Identification of the hypervirulent lineages of _Neisseria meningitidis_, the ST-8 and ST-11 complexes, by using monoclonal antibodies specific to NmeDI. J Clin Microbiol. 2003; 41(8): 3873-6; available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC179822/).\n\nHowever, less virulent strains have been reported to cause IMD in immunocompromised HIV-infected patients (Ferreira de Andrade C, Cotrim da Cunha D, Cavalcanti V, de Filippis I. Fatal meningococcal meningitis in a HIV-infected patient caused by serogroup C _Neisseria meningitidis_ belonging to the non-hypervirulent clonal complex ST-60 (cc60). Braz J Infect Dis. 2011; 15(2): 178-80; available at http://dx.doi.org/10.1590/S1413-86702011000200017).\n\nSeverely immunosuppressed patients with HIV infection and a low CD4 cell count of less than or equal to 200/mm3 are likely to be at greater risk of developing bacterial meningitis (Domingo P, Suarez-Lozano I, Torres F, et al. Bacterial meningitis in HIV-1-infected patients in the era of highly active antiretroviral therapy. J Acquir Immune Defic Syndr. 2009; 51(5): 582-7; available at http://www.researchgate.net/publication/26279285).\n\nMass vaccination campaigns have been used to control outbreaks of IMD in MSM ('See Also' below). The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) has released recommendations for the use of meningococcal vaccines to control outbreaks of serogroup C meningococcal disease (CDC. Control and prevention of serogroup C meningococcal disease: evaluation and management of suspected outbreaks: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). MMWR Recomm Rep. 1997; 46(RR-5): 13-21; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm).\n\nMore information on the HIV status of the cases of IMD, and the serogroup and genotype of the meningococcal isolates in the Chicago outbreak would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/216.]", "summary": "\n\nThe following was extracted from my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - France: (Paris) serogroup C, MSM, vaccination 20150124.3116307:\n\nOutbreaks of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) have occurred among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Germany, Belgium and France caused by a _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C strain with a certain genotype (http://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/rapid-risk-assessment-invasive-meningococcal-disease-among-MSM.pdf). Similar outbreaks among MSM caused by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C have occurred in Canada and the US (see prior ProMED-mail posts).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-06-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "France"}, {"location": "http://www.researchgate.net/publication/26279285", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Chicago", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3520169", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (03): (MN,IL) fatal, MSM, vaccine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3520169", "date": "2015-07-18 22:35:10", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (03): (MINNESOTA, ILLINOIS) FATAL, MEN WHO HAVE SEX WITH MEN, VACCINE\n*****************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 17 Jul 2015\nSource: BringMeTheNews.com [edited]\nhttp://bringmethenews.com/2015/07/17/meningitis-death-prompts-vaccination-warning-for-men-who-have-sex-with-men/\n\n\nThe death of a Ramsey County man prompted a public health warning in Minnesota aimed at men who have sex with men. State health officials are urging men who have sex with men (often shortened to MSM) to be vaccinated as soon as possible for meningococcal meningitis, after the Ramsey County resident became infected with and died from the disease.\n\nIn a news release, Minnesota Department of Health [MDH] officials say they are concerned about possible connections between the victim and an ongoing outbreak of disease, though no direct connection has yet been found.\n\nThe release says the man in his 40s, who is known to have had sex with men, died in the past week from the disease, which [is] caused by bacteria [_Neisseria meningitidis_] that progresses rapidly and can be fatal in about 10-15 percent of cases.\n\nHis condition was exacerbated by the fact that he was also HIV-positive, which placed him at greater risk of developing serious illness from meningococcal meningitis, according to the department.\n\n'We believe that the MSM community in Minnesota may be at increased risk for meningococcal disease,' Kristen Ehresmann, director of the infectious disease division at the MDH, said. 'We want to try to head off the possibility of an outbreak occurring here, so we strongly encourage all MSM, especially those who are HIV-positive, to go get vaccinated.'\n\nBecause the outbreak in Chicago [Illinois] has seen 7 people infected in the MSM community, of whom 1 has died, the MDH says those who are most at risk of infection are HIV-infected men who have sex with men. Also at high risk are men who regularly have close or intimate sexual contact with men met through websites, apps, or at bars or parties.\n\nThey are being advised to see their doctor or go to a vaccination clinic to get a quadrivalent meningococcal vaccination, which covers the bacteria (serogroup C _Neisseria meningitidis_) currently causing the outbreak.\n\nThe disease is transmitted through close personal contact in small droplets of saliva or nasal secretions, with those who have it contracting it through kissing, drinking directly from the same container, sharing smoking materials or through other contact with nose or throat secretions.\n\nAccording to WebMD, it is a 'rare but serious infection' that causes the membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord to become inflamed. It affects around 1000 people in the US every year and can be fatal or cause serious complications without quick treatment, with the Centers for Disease Control [CDC] saying around 15 percent of those who survive can be left with disabilities including deafness or brain damage.\n\nThe most common symptoms of the disease are sudden high fever, a severe and persistent headache, neck stiffness, nausea and vomiting, a discomfort with bright light, drowsiness, joint pain, and confusion. WebMD said that a 'reddish or purple' skin rash that doesn't turn white when a glass is pressed against it is another important sign to watch for, as the disease can cause blood poisoning.\n\n[Byline: Adam Uren]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Minnesota, with a population of almost 5.5 million people, is a state in the Midwestern United States. Ramsey County, where the man who died of meningococcal meningitis resided, is located directly to the east of the city of Minneapolis. The seat of Ramsey County is the city of St. Paul, which is also Minnesota's state capital. Nearly 60 percent of state's residents live in the Minneapolis-Saint Paul metropolitan area (known as the 'Twin Cities'); the rest of the state consists of farming country and the less populated North Woods, used for mining, forestry, and recreation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minnesota). Minneapolis-Saint Paul is about 400 miles (650 km) to the northwest of Chicago by interstate highways.\n\nThe news report refers to an outbreak of meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in men who have sex with men (MSM) in the Chicago, Illinois, area, which ProMED-mail reported last week (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (IL) fatal, MSM, vaccine, RFI 20150711.3502722) and which has now apparently extended to the nearby US state of Minnesota, although we are not told directly if serogroup C was responsible for the Ramsey County resident's death.\n\nThe following was extracted from my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - France: (Paris) serogroup C, MSM, vaccination 20150124.3116307:\n\nOutbreaks of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) have occurred among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Germany, Belgium and France caused by a _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C strain with a certain genotype (http://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/rapid-risk-assessment-invasive-meningococcal-disease-among-MSM.pdf). Similar outbreaks among MSM caused by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C have occurred in Canada and the US (see prior ProMED-mail posts).\n\nMolecular epidemiology has revealed that most cases of IMD are caused by only a few hypervirulent clonal lineages, whereas the genetic diversity is higher in meningococci recovered from healthy carriers (Claus H, Weinand H, Frosch M, Vogel U. Identification of the hypervirulent lineages of _Neisseria meningitidis_, the ST-8 and ST-11 complexes, by using monoclonal antibodies specific to NmeDI. J Clin Microbiol. 2003; 41(8): 3873-6; available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC179822/).\n\nHowever, less virulent strains have been reported to cause IMD in immunocompromised HIV-infected patients (Ferreira de Andrade C, Cotrim da Cunha D, Cavalcanti V, de Filippis I. Fatal meningococcal meningitis in a HIV-infected patient caused by serogroup C _Neisseria meningitidis_ belonging to the non-hypervirulent clonal complex ST-60 (cc60). Braz J Infect Dis. 2011; 15(2): 178-80; available at http://dx.doi.org/10.1590/S1413-86702011000200017).\n\nSeverely immunosuppressed patients with HIV infection and a low CD4 cell count of less than or equal to 200/mm3 are likely to be at greater risk of developing bacterial meningitis (Domingo P, Suarez-Lozano I, Torres F, et al. Bacterial meningitis in HIV-1-infected patients in the era of highly active antiretroviral therapy. J Acquir Immune Defic Syndr. 2009; 51(5): 582-7; available at http://www.researchgate.net/publication/26279285).\n\nMass vaccination campaigns have been used to control outbreaks of IMD in MSM ('See Also' below). The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) has released recommendations for the use of meningococcal vaccines to control outbreaks of serogroup C meningococcal disease (CDC. Control and prevention of serogroup C meningococcal disease: evaluation and management of suspected outbreaks: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). MMWR Recomm Rep. 1997; 46(RR-5): 13-21; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/354.]", "summary": "\n\nThe news report refers to an outbreak of meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in men who have sex with men (MSM) in the Chicago, Illinois, area, which ProMED-mail reported last week (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (IL) fatal, MSM, vaccine, RFI 20150711.3502722) and which has now apparently extended to the nearby US state of Minnesota, although we are not told directly if serogroup C was responsible for the Ramsey County resident's death. The following was extracted from my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - France: (Paris) serogroup C, MSM, vaccination 20150124.3116307:\n\nOutbreaks of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) have occurred among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Germany, Belgium and France caused by a _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C strain with a certain genotype (http://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/rapid-risk-assessment-invasive-meningococcal-disease-among-MSM.pdf). \n\nBecause the outbreak in Chicago [Illinois] has seen 7 people infected in the MSM community, of whom 1 has died, the MDH says those who are most at risk of infection are HIV-infected men who have sex with men. \n\nThe release says the man in his 40s, who is known to have had sex with men, died in the past week from the disease, which [is] caused by bacteria [_Neisseria meningitidis_] that progresses rapidly and can be fatal in about 10-15 percent of cases. State health officials are urging men who have sex with men (often shortened to MSM) to be vaccinated as soon as possible for meningococcal meningitis, after the Ramsey County resident became infected with and died from the disease. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (03): (MINNESOTA, ILLINOIS) FATAL, MEN WHO HAVE SEX WITH MEN, VACCINE\n*****************************************************************************************************\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n However, less virulent strains have been reported to cause IMD in immunocompromised HIV-infected patients (Ferreira de Andrade C, Cotrim da Cunha D, Cavalcanti V, de Filippis I. Fatal meningococcal meningitis in a HIV-infected patient caused by serogroup C _Neisseria meningitidis_ belonging to the non-hypervirulent clonal complex ST-60 (cc60). \n\nThey are being advised to see their doctor or go to a vaccination clinic to get a quadrivalent meningococcal vaccination, which covers the bacteria (serogroup C _Neisseria meningitidis_) currently causing the outbreak. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Minnesota, with a population of almost 5.5 million people, is a state in the Midwestern United States. \n\nMolecular epidemiology has revealed that most cases of IMD are caused by only a few hypervirulent clonal lineages, whereas the genetic diversity is higher in meningococci recovered from healthy carriers (Claus H, Weinand H, Frosch M, Vogel U. Identification of the hypervirulent lineages of _Neisseria meningitidis_, the ST-8 and ST-11 complexes, by using monoclonal antibodies specific to NmeDI. Saudi Arabia: prevention, Hajj travel advice", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3500894", "date": "2015-07-10 12:23:52", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - SAUDI ARABIA: PREVENTION, HAJJ TRAVEL ADVICE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Jul 2015\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2015/07/09/foreign/meningitis-vaccination-now-mandatory-for-hajj-visa/\n\n\nDate: Thu 9 Jul 2015\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2015/07/09/foreign/meningitis-vaccination-now-mandatory-for-hajj-visa/\n\n\nSaudi authorities have made a meningitis vaccination compulsory for all people planning to come for Hajj [annual Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca] this year [2015], according to sources. The Saudi foreign ministry has sent a circular abroad asking people to follow quarantine regulations while issuing visas to intending pilgrims, according to health ministry spokesman Khalid Al Mirghalani.\n\nThe pilgrims must be vaccinated against the disease at least 10 days before arriving in the Kingdom, he stated. Mirghalani further added that vaccinations against the disease are valid for up to 3 years, however, it is not administered to pregnant women.\n\nHe added that his ministry's national scientific committee would be monitoring all the pilgrims arriving from various countries. Teams of officials would be deployed at 14 ports of entry in the western province to look for infection cases among pilgrims.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More than 2 million Muslims from over 183 countries make the Hajj pilgrimage each year. Because of intense crowding and high carrier rates of _Neisseria meningitidis_ among pilgrims, large epidemics of meningococcal disease have been linked to the Hajj pilgrimage, at first due to meningococcal serogroup A in 1987. After requiring vaccination with the bivalent A and C meningococcal vaccine for attending the Hajj, no further outbreaks due to serogroup A occurred, but then in 2000 and again in 2001, large epidemics due to meningococcal serogroup W135 occurred among pilgrims and their families.\n\nA change in the Hajj pilgrimage requirements from bivalent to quadrivalent (serogroups A, C, Y, and W135) meningococcal vaccine ended further meningococcal outbreaks. Pilgrims on Hajj or Umrah are required to present a certificate of vaccination with ACYW135, issued at least 10 days, but not more than 3 years before arrival. Hajj visas cannot be issued without proof of vaccination. Conjugated meningococcal vaccines are preferred over polysaccharide meningococcal vaccines because of lack of herd immunity and persistence of meningococcal carriage among vaccinated pilgrims with the polysaccharide vaccine. Menveo and Nimenrix are 2 conjugated quadrivalent (serogroups A, C, W135 and Y); Nimenrix is conjugated to tetanus toxoid.\n\nFor the official documentation of full requirements for entry into Saudi Arabia for the Hajj, see the following websites:\n- Saudi Ministry of Health Regulations:\nhttp://www.saudiembassy.net/services/hajj_requirements.aspx;\n- Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia requirements to apply for a Hajj visa:\nhttp://www.saudiembassy.net/services/Visa_Application_Forms.aspx.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has also outlined its recommendations for pilgrims during the Hajj (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/yellowbook/2014/chapter-4-select-destinations/saudi-arabia-hajj-pilgrimage). These recommendations include restricting travel to only those in good health and being up to date on all routine vaccinations, which include vaccines for polio, influenza, measles/mumps/rubella (MMR), tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis. CDC also recommends vaccinations for meningococcal disease, hepatitis A and B, and typhoid. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/131.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n For the official documentation of full requirements for entry into Saudi Arabia for the Hajj, see the following websites:\n- Saudi Ministry of Health Regulations:\nhttp://www.saudiembassy.net/services/hajj_requirements.aspx;\n- Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia requirements to apply for a Hajj visa:\nhttp://www.saudiembassy.net/services/Visa_Application_Forms.aspx. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More than 2 million Muslims from over 183 countries make the Hajj pilgrimage each year.
