MenAfrivac (R), a serogroup A conjugate vaccine, was first used for mass vaccination in northwest Nigeria in late 2012.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "1979-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-01-26 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-12-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sokoto State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Oslo", "country": "Norway"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2963933", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Enteroviral meningitis - USA: (MD) university students, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2963933", "date": "2014-11-18 10:43:16", "main_text": "ENTEROVIRAL MENINGITIS - USA: (MARYLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, UPDATE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Nov 2014\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/maryland-meningitis-outbreak-now-at-31-79865/\n\n\nThe number of confirmed and suspected viral meningitis cases [that has] affected University of Maryland students has grown to 31, with 19 requiring hospitalization for their illness. This is up from 19 cases about 2 weeks ago.\n\nTwo School of Public Health professors offered some advice concerning prevention and symptoms to look for: '[M]y emphasis would be to be alert about the symptoms, and to not hesitate to go to your primary care physician immediately with concerns,' said Dr Muhiuddin Haider, a research associate professor in the Maryland Institute of Applied Environmental Health. He also noted that the meningitis vaccine is only available for bacterial meningitis, not the viral kind that is affecting the campus. [There are vaccines available to prevent some types of viral meningitis, such as mumps. - Mod.ML]\n\nWhile symptoms of viral meningitis often mimic the flu, Dr Gretchen De Silva, lecturer in the Public Health Science program at College Park, said that more severe cases may [have] sensitivity to light, stiffness of neck, and nausea. She said that washing hands, not sharing items, and boosting one's immune through sufficient sleep helps prevent catching meningitis.\n\nThe debilitating, but rarely fatal viral meningitis (also known as aseptic meningitis) is a very common type of meningitis affecting newborns, children, and adults alike. The symptoms of viral meningitis typically last a week or so; however, in some patients they can last for months. Symptoms include headache, fever, irritability, stiff neck, nausea, and sensitivity to light.\n\nThe Meningitis Foundation of America says viral meningitis is spread through the exchange of respiratory and throat secretions (kissing, coughing, sneezing, and sharing a cup, utensil, lip gloss, or cigarette). [Some of the organisms that cause] viral meningitis are also found in one's stool, which is how infants and neonates who aren't toilet trained and adults changing diapers develop it.\n\nThere is no specific treatment for viral meningitis at this time. Treating the symptoms of viral meningitis include getting plenty of rest, relaxation, fluids, and medicine to relieve a fever or headache.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term 'meningitis' means an inflammation of the meninges, which are the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord. The term implies lack of parenchymal brain and spinal cord involvement (otherwise called encephalitis and myelitis, respectively). Normally, there are 0 to 5 white cells (all mononuclear cells) per cmm [per cubic millimeter] in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). CSF becomes cloudy when there are more than 500 white cells per cmm. When the CSF is visibly clear, but on laboratory examination the CSF white cell count is 6 to 500 cells per cmm, usually with lymphocytes predominating, the term aseptic meningitis is used.\n\nThe most common cause of aseptic meningitis is a viral infection and enteroviruses are the most common causes of viral meningitis, especially in children during the summer and early fall months. A prior ProMED-mail post (Human enterovirus D68 - North America (16): meningitis-associated? 20141031.2919892) reported that viral meningitis in 5 of the more than 20 cases at that time in University of Maryland students was confirmed as having been caused by an enterovirus, although the specific type was not specified.\n\nEnteroviruses are most often spread via the fecal-oral route from person to person through fecal contamination of water or food or contact with contaminated inanimate objects. Enteroviruses can also be spread through respiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus) of an infected person. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7110.]", "summary": "The debilitating, but rarely fatal viral meningitis (also known as aseptic meningitis) is a very common type of meningitis affecting newborns, children, and adults alike. A prior ProMED-mail post (Human enterovirus D68 - North America (16): meningitis-associated? 20141031.2919892) reported that viral meningitis in 5 of the more than 20 cases at that time in University of Maryland students was confirmed as having been caused by an enterovirus, although the specific type was not specified. The most common cause of aseptic meningitis is a viral infection and enteroviruses are the most common causes of viral meningitis, especially in children during the summer and early fall months. \n\nThe Meningitis Foundation of America says viral meningitis is spread through the exchange of respiratory and throat secretions (kissing, coughing, sneezing, and sharing a cup, utensil, lip gloss, or cigarette). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term 'meningitis' means an inflammation of the meninges, which are the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n ML]\n\nWhile symptoms of viral meningitis often mimic the flu, Dr Gretchen De Silva, lecturer in the Public Health Science program at College Park, said that more severe cases may [have] sensitivity to light, stiffness of neck, and nausea. He also noted that the meningitis vaccine is only available for bacterial meningitis, not the viral kind that is affecting the campus. The number of confirmed and suspected viral meningitis cases [that has] affected University of Maryland students has grown to 31, with 19 requiring hospitalization for their illness. Treating the symptoms of viral meningitis include getting plenty of rest, relaxation, fluids, and medicine to relieve a fever or headache.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "3332448", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Niger: fatal, serogroups C, W", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3332448", "date": "2015-04-30 08:22:46", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGER: FATAL, SEROGROUPS C, W\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 29 Apr 2015\nSource: WHO Global Alert and Response (GAR), Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/29-april-2015-niger/en/\n\n\nBetween 1 Jan and 25 Apr 2015, the Ministry of Public Health of Niger notified WHO of 1543 suspected cases of meningococcal disease, including 147 deaths. Suspected cases have been reported in 7 of Niger's 8 regions. Meningococcal meningitis outbreaks have been confirmed in several areas of Dosso and Niamey regions.\n\nIn Dosso region, 282 cases, including 27 deaths have been reported, primarily from Dogon-Doutchi and Gaya districts where several areas have exceeded the epidemic threshold. In Niamey, 944 suspected cases, including 88 deaths, have so far been reported. 3 of Niamey's 5 districts (Niamey I, II, and III, with a total population of over 660 000) have exceeded the epidemic threshold.\n\nLaboratory tests have confirmed the predominance of _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C in the affected areas, with _N. meningitidis_ serogroup W also being identified in several samples.\n\nA national epidemic committee has been activated to manage the outbreak. An international investigation team composed of WHO and CDC has been deployed to support the Ministry of Public Health's (MoH) investigation of the outbreak and reinforce the surveillance capacity in the country.\n\nWHO and partners are providing support to the government of Niger for the implementation of mass vaccination campaigns and other emergency control measures. The International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control has approved three vaccination requests, one from MSF and 2 from the MoH with support from WHO and UNICEF, releasing in total 460 000 doses of [meningitis] ACW vaccine, as well as 18 500 antibiotic vials to respond to the outbreak. Case management and social mobilisation activities are also ongoing.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Tony Ellam\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control (ret)\n<tonypj@meadlane.freeserve.co.uk>\nand\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Maps of Niger can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Niger.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58.\n\nMeningococcal disease is most commonly due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, W135, and sometimes X. In the semi-arid areas of sub-Saharan Africa, designated the WHO African meningitis belt, large epidemics of meningococcal meningitis recur each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June. The African meningitis belt extends from Ethiopia in the East, to Senegal in the West and includes Senegal, Gambia, Guinea-Bissau, Guinea, Mali, Cote d'Ivoire, Burkina Faso, Ghana, Togo, Benin, Niger, Nigeria, Cameroon, Chad, Central African Republic, Sudan, South Sudan, Uganda, Kenya, Ethiopia, and Eritrea (see map at http://www.cdc.gov/travel-static/yellowbook/2014/map_3-11.pdf).\n\nSerogroup A meningococcus had been the main cause of epidemic meningococcal disease in this region (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf). WHO has promoted vaccinating all 1-29 year-olds in the African meningitis belt with the MenA conjugate vaccine. As of January 2015, over 217 million persons in 15 of the 26 countries of the meningitis belt of sub-Saharan Africa have received meningococcal A conjugate vaccine (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). Recent outbreaks of other meningococcal serogroups following recent mass vaccination with serogroup A conjugate vaccine likely represent serogroup replacement in the meningitis belt. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nDr Tony Ellam\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control (ret)\n<tonypj@meadlane.freeserve.co.uk>\nand\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Maps of Niger can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Niger.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control has approved three vaccination requests, one from MSF and 2 from the MoH with support from WHO and UNICEF, releasing in total 460 000 doses of [meningitis] ACW vaccine, as well as 18 500 antibiotic vials to respond to the outbreak. Recent outbreaks of other meningococcal serogroups following recent mass vaccination with serogroup A conjugate vaccine likely represent serogroup replacement in the meningitis belt. In the semi-arid areas of sub-Saharan Africa, designated the WHO African meningitis belt, large epidemics of meningococcal meningitis recur each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGER: FATAL, SEROGROUPS C, W\n*********************************************************\n As of January 2015, over 217 million persons in 15 of the 26 countries of the meningitis belt of sub-Saharan Africa have received meningococcal A conjugate vaccine (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). \n\nLaboratory tests have confirmed the predominance of _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C in the affected areas, with _N. meningitidis_ serogroup W also being identified in several samples. In Dosso region, 282 cases, including 27 deaths have been reported, primarily from Dogon-Doutchi and Gaya districts where several areas have exceeded the epidemic threshold.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1543-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-01-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Guinea", "country": "Guinea"}, {"location": "Eritrea", "country": "Eritrea"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "Mali"}, {"location": "Senegal ,", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Cameroon", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Gambia", "country": "Gambia"}, {"location": "Niamey", "country": "Niger"}, {"location": "MoH", "country": "Singapore"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3116307", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - France: (Paris) serogroup C, MSM, vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3116307", "date": "2015-01-24 11:35:32", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - FRANCE: (PARIS) SEROGROUP C, MEN WHO HAVE SEX WITH MEN, VACCINATION\n***********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 22 Jan 2015\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 20, Issue 3 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21016\n\n\nSerogroup C invasive meningococcal disease among men who have sex with men and in gay-oriented social venues in the Paris region: July 2013 to December 2014\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAubert L, Taha MK, Boo N, Le Strat Y, Deghmane AE, Sanna A, Barret AS, Levy-Bruhl D, Vandentorren S, Parent du Chatelet I.\n\nAbstract\n--------\nIn November 2014, French public health authorities renewed the recommendation to target for vaccination against invasive meningococcal disease men who have sex with men (MSM) and all individuals 25 years or older attending social venues associated with the gay community. This policy was extended beyond the Paris region as a reaction to the continuing spread of serogroup C isolates belonging to a new lineage within clonal complex cc11 since the recommendation was 1st issued in July 2013.\n\nIntroduction\n------------\nIn this report, we describe, based on combined epidemiological surveillance data and genetic typing of serogroup C meningococcal isolates, the spread of a specific invasive strain of meningococcus C (MenC) in the Paris region that had started as an outbreak among men who have sex with men (MSM) in June 2013.\n\nThe alert in June 2013\n----------------------\nIn the 1st half of 2013, 14 serogroup C IMD [invasive meningococcal disease] cases were reported in France in 25 to 59 year-old men, while 6 cases were reported in women. Of the adult male cases, 6 affected residents of the Paris region and 3 occurred within one week in early June in MSM. The variable regions 1 and 2 of PorA, the variable region of FetA and the clonal complex (cc) of the 3 isolates were characterised. These isolates showed the genotype C:P1.5-1,10-8:F:3-6:cc11 and belonged to the electrophoretic type (ET) 15 of the cc11 (cc11 harbours several lineages). Between October 2012 and May 2013, 5 serogroup C IMD cases in MSM were also reported in Germany [1], caused by isolates sharing the same characteristics as the ones in France. Further genetic analysis showed that the German and the French isolates shared additional markers that also differed from other lineages of the cc11 isolates (data not shown). These findings raised the question of the emergence of a new clone of serogroup C _Neisseria meningitidis_ in the European MSM community [2]. Considering that serogroup C outbreaks occurred also among MSM in Canada in 2001 and in the United States in 2003 (Chicago [Illinois]) and in 2011-13 (New York City), a rapid risk assessment was prepared by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) in July 2013 [3,4].\n\nWe established a national enhanced surveillance and prompted the regional public health officers to assess a possible link to the MSM community for all cases infected by C:P1.5-1,10-8:F:3-6:cc11 isolates.\n\nSerogroup C invasive meningococcal disease cases in the Paris region from July 2013 to December 2014\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nSince July 2013, 34 cases of serogroup C IMD have been notified in the Paris region and 2 other cases have been diagnosed in other countries but were very likely to be linked to a source of exposure in the Paris region. Among these 36 cases, 17 were 25 to 59 years old and 5 were aged 60 years and older. The case fatality rate was 17 percent (6/36). The male/female ratio was 1.6 (22/14) (Table 1). None of the cases had been vaccinated against MenC disease.\n\nTABLE 1. Incidence and case fatality rates of serogroup C invasive meningococcal disease cases by age and sex, 1 Jul 2013 to 31 Dec 2014, Paris region, France (n=36)\n\nIsolates from 29 of the 36 cases were subjected to a complete molecular analysis and 14 were related to the genotype C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:cc11. Among those 14, 9 isolates showed the above-mentioned additional specific markers (Figure 1). They corresponded to 7 men (1 aged 15-24 years and 6 aged 25-59 years) and 2 women (one aged 25-59 years and 1 in the age group 60 years and older). 1 additional male case (15-24 years old) was epidemiologically linked to one of them (family cluster). These 10 cases were directly or indirectly linked to the MSM community (4 cases aged 25-59 years who self-identified as MSM and 6 who did not identify as MSM but attended social venues associated with the gay community in the Paris region).\n\nFIGURE 1. Cases of serogroup C invasive meningococcal disease by month of hospitalisation and genotypic combination, Paris region, France, 1 Jul 2013 to 31 Dec 2014 (n\u2009=\u200936)\n\nIncidence rates and risk evaluation\n-----------------------------------\nWhen considering all reported serogroup C IMD cases for all age groups and both women and men, no excess of cases was observed in the Paris region compared with the general population of France since July 2013. In contrast, we observed a gradual increase in the incidence of serogroup C IMD in the Paris region since 2013, a trend that was less marked elsewhere in France (Figure 2).\n\nFIGURE 2. Incidence rates of serogroup C invasive meningococcal disease cases France, 2010-14 (n=409)\n\nMoreover, IMD caused by C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:cc11 isolates have increased since 2011 particularly in the Paris region where it represented about half (11/22) of the notified meningococcus C IMD cases in 2014 (vs 12 percent elsewhere in France, p less than 10-3). During the period from 2011 to 2014, the mean annual reporting rate for these isolates was estimated at 0.05 cases per 100 000 inhabitants in the Paris region (vs 0.02 elsewhere in France, p less than 10-3).\n\nIn order to estimate the incidence among MSM in the Paris region, we used as the denominator the estimated figures from the 2006 national survey on sexual behaviour [5]. About 175 000 men living in the Paris region and aged 25 to 59 years reported sexual encounters with men at least once during their life.\n\nTaking into account the 4 cases notified in MSM since July 2013, the incidence of serogroup C IMD among 25 to 59 year-old MSM (individuals older than 25 years are not targeted by the national vaccination programme) in the Paris region was 2.28 per 100 000 person-years. The observed number of cases was 10 times greater than the expected number among men in this age group, if the incidence rate of C IMD cases was the same in Paris region than in all regions in France. No excess risk was demonstrated among men living in the Paris region who did not identify as MSM (Table 2).\n\nTABLE 2. Risk analysis of excess cases of serogroup C invasive meningococcal disease in 25-59 year-old MSM and men not identifying as MSM, Paris region, 1 Jul 2013 to 31 Dec 2014 (n=11)\n\nPublic health response and discussion\n-------------------------------------\nSurveillance of invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) in France relies on the mandatory reporting of cases to the French Institute for Public Health Surveillance (InVS) and the characterisation of invasive strains at the National Reference Centre (NRC) for Meningococci. Combined epidemiological surveillance and genetic typing of meningococcal isolates highlighted an increase of invasive meningococcal disease among MSM. These data suggested that the excess of serogroup C IMD cases among MSM living in the Paris region was linked to the circulation since mid-2013 of C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:cc11 isolates with additional specific markers, not only in MSM but also among individuals (women, as well as those men who do not identify as MSM) who attend social venues associated with the gay community. Following the 1st outbreak reported in June 2013, the French Council of Public Health (HCSP) issued a recommendation for a 3-month period of vaccination, with a meningococcal conjugate C vaccine offered to all MSM aged 25 years and older, living in the Paris region and attending social venues associated with the gay community. This recommendation also included all individuals attending gay festivals during summer 2013 in France [6]. Several health promotion activities were carried out during that summer by associations well-known in the gay community in France, but no vaccination campaign was officially performed. No data are available on the vaccine coverage reached in the targeted population.\n\nMoreover, data from national surveillance highlighted that 2 family clusters of 2 cases each were also reported outside the Paris region in 2014, indicating that such isolates may spread all over the country and not only in the Paris region. Because of the high serogroup C IMD incidence due to the C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:cc11 isolates and the persistence of cases linked to the MSM community, the recommendation was renewed in November 2014 for one year and extended beyond the Paris region to the whole country, targeting MSM and all individuals aged 25 years and older attending social venues associated with the gay community [7]. Vaccination against serogroup C meningococci had been recommended in France since 2010 at the age of 12 months, with a catch-up in children and young adults (13 months to 24 years old). However, the incidence of serogroup C IMD gradually increased between 2010 and 2013, mostly in infants younger than one year and in adults [8]. This increase suggested a lack of vaccine-induced herd immunity to reduce circulation of serogroup C meningococci, caused by low vaccine uptake (56 percent at the age of 2 years and 17 percent among the 15 to 19 year-olds in 2013).\n\nVaccine policy for targeting 1 to 24 year-olds should be strengthened more efficiently in France. In addition, enhanced microbiological and epidemiological surveillance should be currently maintained for the isolates responsible of continuous spread of invasive MenC among MSM and adults older than 25 years attending social venues associated with the gay community.\n\n[Tables, figures and references are available at the source URL.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of invasive meningococcal disease (meningitis and sepsis), is transmitted from person to person via droplets of respiratory secretions, mostly from asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers of the microorganism. It is estimated that between 10 to 25 percent of the population carry _N. meningitidis_ at any given time, and the carriage rate may be much higher in epidemic situations. Close and prolonged contact (such as kissing, sneezing, and coughing on someone), living in close quarters or dormitories (military recruits, students), sharing eating or drinking utensils, etc., facilitates the spread of the disease. The average incubation period for meningococcal meningitis is 4 days, ranging between 2 and 10 days (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). Invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) carries a high mortality rate if untreated. Even with early and appropriate treatment, patients can die within 24-48 hours.\n\nOutbreaks of IMD have recently occurred among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Germany, Belgium and France caused by a _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C strain with a certain genotype (http://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/rapid-risk-assessment-invasive-meningococcal-disease-among-MSM.pdf). Similar outbreaks among MSM caused by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup C have occurred in Canada and the US (see prior ProMED-mail posts).\n\nMolecular epidemiology has revealed that most cases of IMD are caused by only a few hypervirulent clonal lineages, whereas the genetic diversity is higher in meningococci recovered from healthy carriers (Claus H, Weinand H, Frosch M, Vogel U. Identification of the hypervirulent lineages of _Neisseria meningitidis_, the ST-8 and ST-11 complexes, by using monoclonal antibodies specific to NmeDI. J Clin Microbiol. 2003; 41(8): 3873-6; available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC179822/). We are not told of the HIV status of the cases of IMD among MSM in France.\n\nHowever, less virulent strains have been reported to cause IMD in immunocompromised HIV-infected patients (Ferreira de Andrade C, Cotrim da Cunha D, Cavalcanti V, de Filippis I. Fatal meningococcal meningitis in a HIV-infected patient caused by serogroup C _Neisseria meningitidis_ belonging to the non-hypervirulent clonal complex ST-60 (cc60). Braz J Infect Dis. 2011; 15(2): 178-80, available at http://dx.doi.org/10.1590/S1413-86702011000200017).\n\nSeverely immunosuppressed patients with HIV infection and a low CD4 cell count of less than or equal to 200/mm3 are likely to be at greater risk of developing bacterial meningitis (Domingo P, Suarez-Lozano I, Torres F, et al. Bacterial meningitis in HIV-1-infected patients in the era of highly active antiretroviral therapy. J Acquir Immune Defic Syndr. 2009; 51(5): 582-7; available at http://www.researchgate.net/publication/26279285).\n\nMass vaccination campaigns have been used to control outbreaks of IMD in MSM ('See Also' below). The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) has released recommendations for the use of meningococcal vaccines to control outbreaks of serogroup C meningococcal disease (CDC. Control and prevention of serogroup C meningococcal disease: evaluation and management of suspected outbreaks: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). MMWR Recomm Rep. 1997; 46(RR-5): 13-21; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1871.]", "summary": "Incidence and case fatality rates of serogroup C invasive meningococcal disease cases by age and sex, 1 Jul 2013 to 31 Dec 2014, Paris region, France (n=36)\n\nIsolates from 29 of the 36 cases were subjected to a complete molecular analysis and 14 were related to the genotype C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:cc11. Incidence rates of serogroup C invasive meningococcal disease cases France, 2010-14 (n=409)\n\nMoreover, IMD caused by C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:cc11 isolates have increased since 2011 particularly in the Paris region where it represented about half (11/22) of the notified meningococcus C IMD cases in 2014 (vs 12 percent elsewhere in France, p less than 10-3). Risk analysis of excess cases of serogroup C invasive meningococcal disease in 25-59 year-old MSM and men not identifying as MSM, Paris region, 1 Jul 2013 to 31 Dec 2014 (n=11)\n\nPublic health response and discussion\n Because of the high serogroup C IMD incidence due to the C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:cc11 isolates and the persistence of cases linked to the MSM community, the recommendation was renewed in November 2014 for one year and extended beyond the Paris region to the whole country, targeting MSM and all individuals aged 25 years and older attending social venues associated with the gay community [7]. They corresponded to 7 men (1 aged 15-24 years and 6 aged 25-59 years) and 2 women (one aged 25-59 years and 1 in the age group 60 years and older). These data suggested that the excess of serogroup C IMD cases among MSM living in the Paris region was linked to the circulation since mid-2013 of C:P1.5-1,10-8:F3-6:cc11 isolates with additional specific markers, not only in MSM but also among individuals (women, as well as those men who do not identify as MSM) who attend social venues associated with the gay community. In November 2014, French public health authorities renewed the recommendation to target for vaccination against invasive meningococcal disease men who have sex with men (MSM) and all individuals 25 years or older attending social venues associated with the gay community. In this report, we describe, based on combined epidemiological surveillance data and genetic typing of serogroup C meningococcal isolates, the spread of a specific invasive strain of meningococcus C (MenC) in the Paris region that had started as an outbreak among men who have sex with men (MSM) in June 2013. \n\nMoreover, data from national surveillance highlighted that 2 family clusters of 2 cases each were also reported outside the Paris region in 2014, indicating that such isolates may spread all over the country and not only in the Paris region. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - FRANCE: (PARIS) SEROGROUP C, MEN WHO HAVE SEX WITH MEN, VACCINATION\n***********************************************************************************************\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The observed number of cases was 10 times greater than the expected number among men in this age group, if the incidence rate of C IMD cases was the same in Paris region than in all regions in France. This increase suggested a lack of vaccine-induced herd immunity to reduce circulation of serogroup C meningococci, caused by low vaccine uptake (56 percent at the age of 2 years and 17 percent among the 15 to 19 year-olds in 2013). In addition, enhanced microbiological and epidemiological surveillance should be currently maintained for the isolates responsible of continuous spread of invasive MenC among MSM and adults older than 25 years attending social venues associated with the gay community. This policy was extended beyond the Paris region as a reaction to the continuing spread of serogroup C isolates belonging to a new lineage within clonal complex cc11 since the recommendation was 1st issued in July 2013. About 175 000 men living in the Paris region and aged 25 to 59 years reported sexual encounters with men at least once during their life. During the period from 2011 to 2014, the mean annual reporting rate for these isolates was estimated at 0.05 cases per 100 000 inhabitants in the Paris region (vs 0.02 elsewhere in France, p less than 10-3).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-01-22 00:00:00", "2014-11-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-06-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-07-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2013-05-26 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-12-26 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chicago", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "isolate", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.researchgate.net/publication/26279285", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "HCSP", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "France"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Parent", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3236196", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: serogroup C, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3236196", "date": "2015-03-17 23:30:29", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA: SEROGROUP C, WHO\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Mar 2015\nSource: WHO Global Alert and Response (GAR), Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/13-march-2015-nigeria/en/\n\n\nBetween 26 Jan and 5 Mar 2015, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) of the Federal Ministry of Health of Nigeria notified WHO of 652 suspected cases of meningococcal disease, including 50 deaths. Cases have been reported in 10 local government areas of 2 states, Kebbi and Sokoto. Laboratory tests have confirmed the predominance of _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup C in the affected areas, with no other serogroups being identified. In Zamfara state, there has been a recent emergence of suspected cases of meningococcal disease; however, an outbreak has not yet been confirmed.\n\nA national task force was activated to manage the outbreak. WHO and partners, including Medecins Sans Frontieres and UNICEF, are closely monitoring the situation, and providing support to the government of Nigeria for the implementation of a mass vaccination campaign and other emergency control measures. The International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control has released 204 850 doses of vaccine, with the support of the GAVI Alliance, as well as 5000 antibiotic vials to respond to the outbreak. Case management and social mobilisation activities are also ongoing.\n\nCerebrospinal [bacterial] meningitis is caused by several microorganisms; among these, _N. meningitidis_ (Nm) is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis. The disease is highly contagious with seasonal epidemics in many African countries. Since the introduction of the Men A conjugate vaccine (MenAfrivac), which protects against the most prevalent type of Nm (serogroup A) the occurrence of the disease has declined significantly. From 2011 to 2014, the government of Nigeria conducted mass campaigns with the type A vaccine in all states at risk, including Kebbi state. Still, the risk of other types of _N. meningitidis_ persists, as evidenced by the current Nm C outbreak. The disease can be cured with antibiotics and prevented with vaccines.\n\nWHO does not recommend any travel or trade restriction to Nigeria based on the current information available on this outbreak.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[At least 13 serogroups of _Neisseria meningitidis_, based on polysaccharide capsular antigens, have been described. Meningococcal disease is most commonly due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, W135, and sometimes X. In the semi-arid areas of sub-Saharan Africa, designated the WHO African meningitis belt, large epidemics of meningococcal meningitis recur each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June. The African meningitis belt extends from Ethiopia in the East, to Senegal in the West and includes Senegal, Gambia, Guinea-Bissau, Guinea, Mali, Cote d'Ivoire, Burkina Faso, Ghana, Togo, Benin, Niger, Nigeria, Cameroon, Chad, Central African Republic, Sudan, South Sudan, Uganda, Kenya, Ethiopia, and Eritrea (see map at http://www.cdc.gov/travel-static/yellowbook/2014/map_3-11.pdf).\n\nSerogroup A meningococcus has been the main cause of epidemic meningococcal disease in this region (http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/meningitis/whoemcbac983.pdf). However, outbreaks have also been caused by other _N. meningitidis_ serogroups, such as serogroup C (http://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/lab-manual/chpt02-epi.html), W135 (http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=17334579), X (http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264410X13004751), and in March 2012, a serogroup B outbreak occurred in Ethiopia (http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news/3581-ethiopia-suspected-meningitis-outbreak-situation-as-of-08-march-2012-.html).\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an attempt to induce herd immunity, whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the population has been vaccinated (see http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). Meningococcal vaccines will only protect against meningitis due to the meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups that the vaccine contains. Since the introduction of the meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt in 2010, the WHO noted a decrease in the number of cases of meningitis; in fact, the number of cases in 2013 was the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years (http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/), and _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was noted to be no longer the predominant pathogen, to be replaced by other serogroups.\n\nA map of Nigeria that shows the location of the northwestern states of Kebbi, Sokoto, and Zamfara can be found at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62.]", "summary": "Since the introduction of the meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt in 2010, the WHO noted a decrease in the number of cases of meningitis; in fact, the number of cases in 2013 was the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years (http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/), and _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was noted to be no longer the predominant pathogen, to be replaced by other serogroups. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an attempt to induce herd immunity, whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the population has been vaccinated (see http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). In the semi-arid areas of sub-Saharan Africa, designated the WHO African meningitis belt, large epidemics of meningococcal meningitis recur each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June. The International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control has released 204 850 doses of vaccine, with the support of the GAVI Alliance, as well as 5000 antibiotic vials to respond to the outbreak. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA: SEROGROUP C, WHO\n*****************************************************\n Between 26 Jan and 5 Mar 2015, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) of the Federal Ministry of Health of Nigeria notified WHO of 652 suspected cases of meningococcal disease, including 50 deaths. Meningococcal vaccines will only protect against meningitis due to the meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups that the vaccine contains. However, outbreaks have also been caused by other _N. meningitidis_ serogroups, such as serogroup C (http://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/lab-manual/chpt02-epi.html), W135 (http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=17334579), X (http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264410X13004751), and in March 2012, a serogroup B outbreak occurred in Ethiopia (http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news/3581-ethiopia-suspected-meningitis-outbreak-situation-as-of-08-march-2012-.html). In Zamfara state, there has been a recent emergence of suspected cases of meningococcal disease; however, an outbreak has not yet been confirmed.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Senegal ,", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "Guinea"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "Mali"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Eritrea", "country": "Eritrea"}, {"location": "Zamfara", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Cameroon", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Gambia", "country": "Gambia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2919892", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Human enterovirus D68 - North America (16): meningitis-associated?", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2919892", "date": "2014-10-31 18:15:33", "main_text": "HUMAN ENTEROVIRUS D68 - NORTH AMERICA (16): MENINGITIS-ASSOCIATED?\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Genome function analysis\n[2] Susceptibility analysis\n\n******\n[1] Genome function analysis\nDate: Thu 30 Oct 2014\nSource: US News & World Report [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/10/30/enterovirus-may-have-caused-maryland-meningitis-outbreak\n\n\nA meningitis outbreak at the University of Maryland may be related to another virus that has swept across the country [USA] during recent months, though further testing is being conducted to determine the possibility. If the tests are positive, it would mean that yet another manifestation of enterovirus-68 has occurred. In Maryland, the state public health lab is conducting a broad range of testing on specimens submitted to the agency, state epidemiologist Dr. David Blythe says. Agency officials would not specify whether testing for EV-68 was occurring and did not confirm whether samples had been sent to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC]. County health officials say that testing will occur at either the state level or be performed by the CDC.\n\nFive viral meningitis cases at the University of Maryland were confirmed as having been caused by an enterovirus, according to the University Health Center, and it's possible the EV-68 strain is causing the outbreak at the school, where more than 20 students have been infected. So far, only one instance of the specific meningitis-enterovirus-68 match has been confirmed recently in the U.S. In Connecticut, an elementary school student tested positive Thursday [30 Oct 2014] for both viral meningitis and EV-68. EV-68 symptoms have varied widely during the recent outbreak, from severe respiratory illness to paralysis and muscle weakness -- even resulting in one death. Latest figures from the CDC show that 1101 cases have been diagnosed in 47 states and the District of Columbia. Almost all cases have been among children, and the virus strain seems to particularly affect those with asthma or a history of wheezing.\n\nThe University of Maryland's health center had issued a statement about the viral meningitis cases, not wanting to cause alarm and hoping to avoid public confusion about bacterial meningitis, a much more serious condition that can result in hearing loss, seizures, brain damage and death. Bacterial meningitis is treated with antibiotics, and most colleges require students to be vaccinated against it before they are allowed to attend. Viral meningitis, on the other hand, can be treated with bed rest and water, along with medication to relieve fever and headache.\n\nThough a range of viruses can cause viral meningitis, it is possible that EV-68 is one of them, says Dr. Robert Wergin, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians and a practicing physician in Nebraska.\n\nFor reasons that remain unclear, University of Maryland officials say they will not know the particular strain of enterovirus behind the meningitis cases for weeks, according to an email from the University Health Center. Viral meningitis can come from a range of infections, including the mumps, herpes, measles, influenza, or even West Nile virus, though most cases are caused by an enterovirus -- cases of which are typically seen throughout the fall and spring. A teacher and a student also were infected with viral meningitis at a public school in the District of Columbia, only 10 miles away from the University of Maryland campus in College Park, Maryland. It is unclear whether a transmission occurred between the 2 or whether an enterovirus was the cause of the cases in the district. Other individual cases of viral meningitis have been confirmed across the country. Last week, an elementary school student was diagnosed with the virus [a virus?] in Stillwater, Oklahoma. Another case was diagnosed in a student at Sam Houston State University in Texas. Public information about what virus caused the meningitis or whether additional tests had been conducted was not released in either case.\n\nSymptoms of viral meningitis can last up to 10 days and include fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and a lack of appetite. People generally recover spontaneously with supportive care, Wergin says. But as an enterovirus spreads, it can [may?] get into the tissues of the brain and spinal cord, causing inflammation. In rare, more severe cases, patients might require hospitalisation. It's unusual for an otherwise healthy person who is college-age to get viral meningitis, Wergin says; typically, it occurs among children younger than 5. It makes sense, however, that people could be more at risk in an enclosed environment like a classroom or dorm, he says.\n\n[Byline: Kimberly Leonard]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Susceptibility analysis\nDate: Thu 30 Oct 2014\nFrom: Stephen J. Seligman <stephen_seligman@nymc.edu> [edited]\n\n\nComment on: Human enterovirus D68 - North America (14): genome sequence 20141029.2912217. Request for collaborators\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThis ProMED-mail post reports on an investigation into sequence variation in the virus in an attempt to understand the epidemic potential and virulence of strains in the current outbreak. However, in addition to changes in the virus, rare human mutations affecting immunity to infection may be responsible for increased susceptibility to infections.\n\nThe laboratory of Dr. Jean-Laurent Casanova at Rockefeller University is devoted to the analysis of these kinds of mutations and has discovered numerous instances with increased susceptibility to a variety of organisms. They study cases and families in which unusual or unusually severe infections have occurred. Information thus far available (almost entirely from the news media) is limited. If confirmed by more complete investigation, the 3 fatal cases associated with enterovirus D68 in which the age and gender have been mentioned, fall into the category of unusually severe reactions to infection. One of these cases had concomitant _Staphylococcus aureus_ septicemia, a finding consistent with an immune defect that increased susceptibility both to the virus and to the bacterium. Dr. Casanova's laboratory would like to collaborate with groups that have access to specimens and families of patients who have died, with evidence of enterovirus D68 infection. CDC is aware of our efforts. Anyone with such access should contact me. All of the experimental work will be done in Casanova's laboratory.\n\nAn abstract outlining the general principles of the work follows. 'Guidelines for genetic studies in single patients: lessons from primary immunodeficiencies' authored by Jean-Laurent Casanova, Mary Ellen Conley, Stephen J. Seligman, Laurent Abel, and Luigi D. Notarangelo, published in J Exp Med 2014 211:2137-2149. The Abstract states: 'Can genetic and clinical findings made in a single patient be considered sufficient to establish a causal relationship between genotype and phenotype? We report that up to 49 of the 232 monogenic etiologies (21 percent) of human primary immunodeficiencies (PIDs) were initially reported in single patients. The ability to incriminate single-gene inborn errors in immunodeficient patients results from the relative ease in validating the disease-causing role of the genotype by in-depth mechanistic studies demonstrating the structural and functional consequences of the mutations using blood samples. The candidate genotype can be causally connected to a clinical phenotype using cellular (leukocytes) or molecular (plasma) substrates. The recent advent of next generation sequencing (NGS), with whole exome and whole genome sequencing, induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) technology, and gene editing technologies-including in particular the clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)/Cas9 technology-offer new and exciting possibilities for the genetic exploration of single patients not only in hematology and immunology but also in other fields. We propose 3 criteria for deciding if the clinical and experimental data suffice to establish a causal relationship based on only one case. The patient's candidate genotype must not occur in individuals without the clinical phenotype. Experimental studies must indicate that the genetic variant impairs, destroys, or alters the expression or function of the gene product (or 2 genetic variants for compound heterozygosity). The causal relationship between the candidate genotype and the clinical phenotype must be confirmed via a relevant cellular phenotype, or by default via a relevant animal phenotype. When supported by satisfaction of rigorous criteria, the report of single patient-based discovery of Mendelian disorders should be encouraged, as it can provide the 1st step in the understanding of a group of human diseases, thereby revealing crucial pathways underlying physiological and pathological processes.'\n\n--\nStephen J. Seligman, MD\nResearch Professor\nDepartment of Microbiology and Immunology\nNew York Medical College\n<stephen_seligman@nymc.edu>\n\n[The 1st report advances the proposition that human enterovirus D68 virus infection may be the principal determinant of (non-bacterial) meningitis. While this is an interesting proposition, no conclusive evidence is presented to support this contention. The commentary from Stephen J. Seligman seeks collaborators in a different molecular approach to analysis of enterovirus D68 genome function. This methodology has not so far been employed in the analysis of human enterovirus D68 genome function. Thus at present there is no definitive evidence that enterovirus D68 infection plays a major role in viral meningitis. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "When supported by satisfaction of rigorous criteria, the report of single patient-based discovery of Mendelian disorders should be encouraged, as it can provide the 1st step in the understanding of a group of human diseases, thereby revealing crucial pathways underlying physiological and pathological processes.'\n\n--\nStephen J. Seligman, MD\nResearch Professor\nDepartment of Microbiology and Immunology\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Viral meningitis can come from a range of infections, including the mumps, herpes, measles, influenza, or even West Nile virus, though most cases are caused by an enterovirus -- cases of which are typically seen throughout the fall and spring. HUMAN ENTEROVIRUS D68 - NORTH AMERICA (16): MENINGITIS-ASSOCIATED?\n [The 1st report advances the proposition that human enterovirus D68 virus infection may be the principal determinant of (non-bacterial) meningitis. The recent advent of next generation sequencing (NGS), with whole exome and whole genome sequencing, induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) technology, and gene editing technologies-including in particular the clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)/Cas9 technology-offer new and exciting possibilities for the genetic exploration of single patients not only in hematology and immunology but also in other fields. \n\nSymptoms of viral meningitis can last up to 10 days and include fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and a lack of appetite. If confirmed by more complete investigation, the 3 fatal cases associated with enterovirus D68 in which the age and gender have been mentioned, fall into the category of unusually severe reactions to infection. [2] Susceptibility analysis\n\n******\n Thus at present there is no definitive evidence that enterovirus D68 infection plays a major role in viral meningitis. The ability to incriminate single-gene inborn errors in immunodeficient patients results from the relative ease in validating the disease-causing role of the genotype by in-depth mechanistic studies demonstrating the structural and functional consequences of the mutations using blood samples. \n\n\nA meningitis outbreak at the University of Maryland may be related to another virus that has swept across the country [USA] during recent months, though further testing is being conducted to determine the possibility. The causal relationship between the candidate genotype and the clinical phenotype must be confirmed via a relevant cellular phenotype, or by default via a relevant animal phenotype. A teacher and a student also were infected with viral meningitis at a public school in the District of Columbia, only 10 miles away from the University of Maryland campus in College Park, Maryland. Public information about what virus caused the meningitis or whether additional tests had been conducted was not released in either case. The Abstract states: 'Can genetic and clinical findings made in a single patient be considered sufficient to establish a causal relationship between genotype and phenotype? Though a range of viruses can cause viral meningitis, it is possible that EV-68 is one of them, says Dr. Robert Wergin, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians and a practicing physician in Nebraska.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "west nile virus"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "1101-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "College Park", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Stillwater", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "Colombia"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2673398", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Enteroviral meningitis - Armenia (02): susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2673398", "date": "2014-08-09 09:15:51", "main_text": "ENTEROVIRAL MENINGITIS - ARMENIA (02): SUSPECTED\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Aug 2014\nSource: ARKA News Agency [edited]\nhttp://arka.am/en/news/society/nearly_450_people_hospitalized_in_june_august_with_suspected_acute_meningitis_/\n\n\nNearly 450 people were hospitalized in Armenia in June, July, and the 1st week of August [2014] with suspected acute meningitis, a disease caused by enterovirus infections, Gayane Sahakyan, the head of the National Immunization Program of the Health Ministry, told a news conference today [7 Aug 2014]. 'Fortunately, the diagnosis of acute meningitis was confirmed only in less than 1/3 of cases. The number of people seeking [the] assistance of hospitals is gradually decreasing. There is no epidemic,' she said.\n\nSahakyan noted that diseases caused by enteroviruses are dangerous and have a variety of symptoms. They are transmitted through air and tactile contacts with sick people or contaminated objects. The point is that a healthy person could be a carrier of the disease for 5-6 months, and thus become a source of infection to others.\n\n'The danger is that the symptoms of enteroviral diseases can manifest themselves in many different ways, such as acute respiratory infections and diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. For an accurate diagnosis a special laboratory study is required,' Sahakyan said.\n\n'To protect against enterovirus diseases people must comply with the most basic rules of personal hygiene, wash hands, fruits, and vegetables thoroughly, disinfect homes and premises, not to swim in open water reservoirs not intended for swimming,' she said.\n\nShe said preventive measures are being implemented in kindergartens and children's summer camps at the order of the health minister in order to prevent outbreaks of enterovirus infections.\n\nEnterovirus infection is a group of acute infectious diseases caused by enteric viruses (enteroviruses), characterized by fever and [a variety] of clinical symptoms involving people's central nervous system, cardiovascular system, gastrointestinal tract, muscle, lung, liver, kidney, and other body organs.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail posted a report of an outbreak of serous acute meningitis presumed to be due to enteroviruses in Armenia in May-June 2014, with a total of 38 cases recorded, mainly in the 3- to 8-year-old age group (Enteroviral meningitis - Armenia 20140628.2572211). The news report above says the diagnosis of viral meningitis has now been confirmed in 'less than 1/3' of the total of 450 cases hospitalized with suspected acute viral meningitis and the number of hospitalized cases has been decreasing. The news report does not say if the enteroviral etiology has been confirmed in any of these cases.\n\nThe term 'meningitis' means an inflammation of the meninges, which are the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord. 'Serous' meningitis is a term used when clinical findings (such as a stiff neck) suggest meningitis, but the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), although under increased pressure, is clear to the naked eye (http://www.bmj.com/content/2/3691/627.3).\n\nNormally, there are 0 to 5 white cells (all mononuclear cells) per cmm [per cubic millimeter] in the CSF. CSF becomes cloudy when there are more than 500 white cells per cmm. When the CSF is visibly clear, but on laboratory examination the CSF white cell count is 6 to 500 cells per cmm, usually with lymphocytes predominating, the term aseptic meningitis is used.\n\nThe most common cause of aseptic meningitis is a viral infection and enteroviruses are common causes of viral meningitis, especially in children during the summer months. However, aseptic meningitis may be caused by other viruses, such as arboviruses, HIV, herpes simplex virus (HSV) types 1 and 2, some bacteria, fungi, and parasites. Non-infectious causes include certain drugs, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and systemic diseases, such as lupus, sarcoidosis, and metastatic cancer.\n\nMost people who get infected with enteroviruses are asymptomatic or have only a non-specific febrile illness. Enteroviruses are most often spread via the fecal-oral route from person to person through fecal contamination of water or food or contact with contaminated inanimate objects. Enteroviruses can also be spread through respiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus) of an infected person. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/133.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail posted a report of an outbreak of serous acute meningitis presumed to be due to enteroviruses in Armenia in May-June 2014, with a total of 38 cases recorded, mainly in the 3- to 8-year-old age group (Enteroviral meningitis - Armenia 20140628.2572211). The news report above says the diagnosis of viral meningitis has now been confirmed in 'less than 1/3' of the total of 450 cases hospitalized with suspected acute viral meningitis and the number of hospitalized cases has been decreasing. \n\nEnterovirus infection is a group of acute infectious diseases caused by enteric viruses (enteroviruses), characterized by fever and [a variety] of clinical symptoms involving people's central nervous system, cardiovascular system, gastrointestinal tract, muscle, lung, liver, kidney, and other body organs. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n\nNearly 450 people were hospitalized in Armenia in June, July, and the 1st week of August [2014] with suspected acute meningitis, a disease caused by enterovirus infections, Gayane Sahakyan, the head of the National Immunization Program of the Health Ministry, told a news conference today [7 Aug 2014]. ' The most common cause of aseptic meningitis is a viral infection and enteroviruses are common causes of viral meningitis, especially in children during the summer months. \n\n'To protect against enterovirus diseases people must comply with the most basic rules of personal hygiene, wash hands, fruits, and vegetables thoroughly, disinfect homes and premises, not to swim in open water reservoirs not intended for swimming,' she said. \n\n'The danger is that the symptoms of enteroviral diseases can manifest themselves in many different ways, such as acute respiratory infections and diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. Serous' meningitis is a term used when clinical findings (such as a stiff neck) suggest meningitis, but the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), although under increased pressure, is clear to the naked eye (http://www.bmj.com/content/2/3691/627.3). When the CSF is visibly clear, but on laboratory examination the CSF white cell count is 6 to 500 cells per cmm, usually with lymphocytes predominating, the term aseptic meningitis is used. ENTEROVIRAL MENINGITIS - ARMENIA (02): SUSPECTED\n************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Armenia", "country": "Armenia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2799732", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2799732", "date": "2014-09-24 10:25:18", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA: (SOUTH AUSTRALIA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 23 Sep 2014\nSource: The Murray Valley Standard [edited]\nhttp://www.murrayvalleystandard.com.au/story/2575955/meningococcal-rates-rise-in-sa/?cs=12\n\n\nSouth Australians (SA) are being reminded to be aware of symptoms of meningococcal disease after an influx of cases were reported to SA Health in recent weeks. So far this year [2014], 20 cases of meningococcal infections have been reported with 8 of those occurring since September.\n\nChief Public Health Officer Dr Stephen Christley said while the disease was usually rare, numbers increased when more respiratory infections were around. 'As we have experienced increased numbers of cases in the past few weeks we're asking the general public to be aware of the symptoms of meningococcal disease and seek medical advice is necessary,' he said. 'Symptoms of meningococcal infection may include fever, headache, vomiting, stiff neck and sore muscles, followed in some cases by a rash of red and purple spots. Babies or young children with meningococcal infection may also be fretful, refuse feeds or be difficult to wake.'\n\nDr Christley said meningococcal bacteria were carried in the nose and throat of about 10 per cent of the population, but the bacteria were usually harmless. 'The bacteria are spread from person to person through close contact, but only a very small number of people develop meningococcal disease,' he said. 'With all cases of meningococcal infection, SA Health will identify people who may have been in contact with the patient to provide them with information.' A Meningococcal Australia spokesperson recommended people keep vaccinations up-to-date and act quickly if they suspected someone had contracted the disease.\n\n'Meningococcal disease, while rare, is a disease that can lead to death in less than 24 hours,' the spokesperson said.\n\n'Around 5 to 10 percent of those who contract meningococcal disease will not survive and 20 percent of survivors are left with permanent disabilities that range from learning difficulties, sight or hearing problems, loss of fingers, toes and limbs, and scarring from skin grafts.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ga.gov.au/image_cache/GA4073.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/286. South Australia is a state in the southern central part of Australia, with a population of 1 650 600 in 2012. A majority of the state's population (77.1 percent) resides within Greater Adelaide's metropolitan area (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Australia).\n\nWith 20 cases of meningococcal disease so far this year (2014) in South Australia, the incidence rate is 1.21 per 100 000. However, the news report above fails to tell us the incidence rates in prior years for comparison and we are not told the serogroups involved. We are also not told if any outbreaks of meningococcal disease contributed to the total number of cases in South Australia. (In the US, only about 2 percent of cases of meningococcal disease occurs as part of an outbreak.) Outbreaks can occur in communities, schools, colleges, prisons, and other populations and are usually caused by the same or closely related strains. More information concerning the epidemiological findings concerning the cases of meningococcal disease in South Australia would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nFor Australia as a whole, the incidence of meningococcal disease declined from about 700 cases in 2001 to 208 laboratory-confirmed cases in 2012 (incidence rate 0.88 per 100 000), the lowest annual total incidence since surveillance data was collated (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). The conjugate meningococcal C vaccine was introduced into the National Immunisation Program in 2003. Since 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 percent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 percent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 percent in 2003 to 83 percent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf).\n\nAccording to the annual reports of the Australian Meningococcal Surveillance Programme, the number of cases of meningococcal disease in South Australia fluctuated each year, from 13 to 24, of which the percent due to serogroup B ranged from 64 in 2001 to 96 in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-pubs-annlrpt-menganrep.htm).\n\nFor comparison, in the US, prior to 2000, an estimated 1400 to 2800 cases of meningococcal disease occurred each year, with an incidence rate of 0.5 to 1.1 per 100 000 population. Since 2000, the incidence of meningococcal disease has decreased (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/downloads/mening.pdf). There are now fewer than 1000 cases reported each year (http://www.cdc.gov/meningococcal/surveillance/index.html). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Since 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 percent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 percent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 percent in 2003 to 83 percent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). For Australia as a whole, the incidence of meningococcal disease declined from about 700 cases in 2001 to 208 laboratory-confirmed cases in 2012 (incidence rate 0.88 per 100 000), the lowest annual total incidence since surveillance data was collated (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). According to the annual reports of the Australian Meningococcal Surveillance Programme, the number of cases of meningococcal disease in South Australia fluctuated each year, from 13 to 24, of which the percent due to serogroup B ranged from 64 in 2001 to 96 in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-pubs-annlrpt-menganrep.htm). \n\n'Around 5 to 10 percent of those who contract meningococcal disease will not survive and 20 percent of survivors are left with permanent disabilities that range from learning difficulties, sight or hearing problems, loss of fingers, toes and limbs, and scarring from skin grafts.' For comparison, in the US, prior to 2000, an estimated 1400 to 2800 cases of meningococcal disease occurred each year, with an incidence rate of 0.5 to 1.1 per 100 000 population. With 20 cases of meningococcal disease so far this year (2014) in South Australia, the incidence rate is 1.21 per 100 000. \n\n'Meningococcal disease, while rare, is a disease that can lead to death in less than 24 hours,' the spokesperson said. As we have experienced increased numbers of cases in the past few weeks we're asking the general public to be aware of the symptoms of meningococcal disease and seek medical advice is necessary,' he said. ' A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n\nSouth Australians (SA) are being reminded to be aware of symptoms of meningococcal disease after an influx of cases were reported to SA Health in recent weeks. (In the US, only about 2 percent of cases of meningococcal disease occurs as part of an outbreak.)", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2064-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-09-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-09-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2620445", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - Viet Nam: (Ho Chi Minh City)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2620445", "date": "2014-07-18 20:43:07", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - VIET NAM: (HO CHI MINH CITY)\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 15 Jul 2014\nSource: The Global Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/vietnamese-doctor-says-dozens-of-children-are-admitted-for-meningitis-linked-to-a-parasite-in-snails-22586/\n\n\nDozens of children with meningitis linked to _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nOne physician from a Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC), Vietnam hospital says his hospital admits dozens of children with meningitis caused by eating land snails, according to a Thanh Nien News report Tuesday [15 Jul 2014].\n\nThe story begins with a 9-year-old boy who was recently hospitalized for meningitis after eating snails contaminated with the dangerous roundworm, _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_.\n\nDr Truong Huu Khanh of the HCMC Children's Hospital No. 1 notes that some of his patients reported only playing with the snails without eating them. Another doctor, Dr Nguyen Hoang Phu of the Hospital for Tropical Diseases, [said] most patients hospitalized after eating land snails ate them for medicinal purposes or as a drinking snack. 'No scientific studies have ascribed land snails with any medicinal properties,' he said.\n\nThis story comes at the same time federal authorities at Los Angeles International Airport seized 67 live giant African snails from Lagos, Nigeria meant for human consumption.\n\nWhat is angiostrongyliasis?\nIt is an infection caused by the rat lungworm, _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_. This is a parasitic infection in rats, where it matures. Mollusks like snails and slugs pick up _Angiostrongylus_ larvae by ingesting them in rat feces.\n\nHow do people get this parasite?\nInfection is [caused] by accidentally or intentionally ingesting raw snails and slugs. Lettuce and other leafy vegetables may also be a source if contaminated by small mollusks. Eating raw or undercooked prawns and crabs that have ingested mollusks may also be a source of infection.\n\nWhat are the symptoms and disease?\n_A. cantonensis_ infection is usually asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic. Symptoms usually appear in 1-3 weeks. The most serious disease is eosinophilic meningitis. The symptoms can include headache, stiff neck, tingling or painful feelings in the skin, low-grade fever, nausea, and vomiting. The spinal fluid exhibits eosinophilia of over 20 percent. Deaths are sometimes reported.\n\nSymptoms may last for weeks to months.\n\nHow is this infection diagnosed?\nThe presence of eosinophils in the spinal fluid and a history of eating raw snails suggest angiostrongyliasis. Finding the worms in spinal fluid or at autopsy is confirmation.\n\nWhat about treatment?\nTreatment is usually not necessary. The parasite dies over time since it can't mature and complete its life cycle. Usually treatment of symptoms -- headache medicine, steroids -- are all that is needed. Treatment with anti-parasitic drugs is generally ineffective against angiostrongyliasis.\n\nHow do you prevent getting angiostrongyliasis?\nDo not eat raw or undercooked snails or slugs; cook crabs and prawns to kill the larvae; and thoroughly clean lettuce and other produce.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Occasional cases of _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ meningitis are common in societies where raw snails are regarded as a delicacy. Outbreaks like the one described here are rare and could indicate a batch of heavily infected snails sold to the consumers within a short time. A detailed risk factor analysis should be performed to identify the supplier and source of the snails. - Mod.EP\n\nLife cycle diagram of A. cantonensis:\nhttp://www.phsource.us/PH/PARA/Chapter_7_files/image002.jpg - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Occasional cases of _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ meningitis are common in societies where raw snails are regarded as a delicacy. \n\nThe story begins with a 9-year-old boy who was recently hospitalized for meningitis after eating snails contaminated with the dangerous roundworm, _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_. \n\nWhat are the symptoms and disease?\n_A. cantonensis_ infection is usually asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic.
