WHO procured 200 000 doses of meningitis vaccines in response to the increasing meningitis caseload and ahead of the meningitis epidemic season starting in October 2014.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nOta Masaki, MD, PhD\n<masaki.ota@mb6.seikyou.ne.jp>\n<otam@jata.or.jp>\n\n[Maps of Ethiopia can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/95 and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethiopia#mediaviewer/File:Ethiopia_zone_region.jpg.\n\nEthiopia is one of the countries in the WHO African meningitis belt, a region in sub-Saharan Africa stretching from Senegal in West Africa to the Horn of Africa where the incidence rate of meningitis is very high (see map at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/map3-13-frequent-epidemics-meningococcal-meningitis-large.png). Outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the African meningitis belt each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June (http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx).\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A is said to be the most commonly isolated pathogen in the African meningitis belt. However, outbreaks have also been caused by other _N. meningitidis_ serogroups, such as serogroup C (http://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/lab-manual/chpt02-epi.html), W135 (http://cel.webofknowledge.com/InboundService.do?product=CEL&SID=4BczB7VSGYERs55e6vX&UT=000076093900009&SrcApp=Highwire&action=retrieve&Init=Yes&Func=Frame&SrcAuth=Highwire&customersID=Highwire&IsProductCode=Yes&mode=FullRecord), and X (http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264410X13004751), and in March 2012, a serogroup B outbreak occurred in Ethiopia (http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news/3581-ethiopia-suspected-meningitis-outbreak-situation-as-of-08-march-2012-.html). No reports on meningitis were available for Ethiopia for 2013 (http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/) and we are not told the microbial etiology of the meningitis outbreak in the various regions of Ethiopia, nor the types of meningococcal vaccine being used, in the report above. ProMED-mail would appreciate information on the microbial causes of the meningitis outbreaks in Ethiopia and the meningococcal vaccines being used from knowledgeable sources.\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an attempt to induce herd immunity, whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the population has been vaccinated (see http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). Meningococcal vaccines will only protect against meningitis due to the meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups that the vaccine contains. Meningococcal disease is most commonly due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135. Rarely, outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis have been related to other serogroups, such as type X, which has occurred in Niger in 2006 and Burkina Faso in 2010.\n\nSerogroup A, B, C, Y, and W135 polysaccharides are immunogenic in humans; serogroup B is poorly immunogenic, presumably because serogroup B polysaccharide resembles the human neural cell adhesion molecule. While effective capsular polysaccharides-based vaccines exist against serogroups A, C, W135, and Y, no similar vaccine is available against disease caused by serogroup B strains. However, a new protein-based, broad-spectrum meningococcal serogroup B vaccine has been developed. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n WHO procured 200 000 doses of meningitis vaccines in response to the increasing meningitis caseload and ahead of the meningitis epidemic season starting in October 2014. No reports on meningitis were available for Ethiopia for 2013 (http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/) and we are not told the microbial etiology of the meningitis outbreak in the various regions of Ethiopia, nor the types of meningococcal vaccine being used, in the report above. Outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the African meningitis belt each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June (http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx). MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ETHIOPIA (02): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************************\n \n\nEthiopia is one of the countries in the WHO African meningitis belt, a region in sub-Saharan Africa stretching from Senegal in West Africa to the Horn of Africa where the incidence rate of meningitis is very high (see map at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/map3-13-frequent-epidemics-meningococcal-meningitis-large.png). Meningococcal vaccines will only protect against meningitis due to the meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups that the vaccine contains.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-10-26 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oromia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amhara", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2692227", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Saudi Arabia: prevention, Hajj travel advice", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2692227", "date": "2014-08-15 11:45:29", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - SAUDI ARABIA: PREVENTION, HAJJ PILGRIM TRAVEL ADVICE\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Aug 2014\nSource: Vaccine News Daily [edited]\nhttp://vaccinenewsdaily.com/medical_countermeasures/331397-hajj-pilgrims-leaving-from-u-k-required-to-vaccinate-against-meningitis/\n\n\nThe Meningitis Research Foundation recently urged Hajj pilgrims embarking on a trip to Mecca from the UK to ensure their vaccinations are up-to-date to meet visa requirements.\n\nVaccination against meningitis is required for all travelers, who must carry a certificate showing they were vaccinated at least 10 days before leaving for Saudi Arabia, but no more than 3 years before arrival. Seasonal workers in Hajj areas are also required to be vaccinated.\n\nThe visa requirement was added more than 10 years ago after a number of large meningitis epidemics occurred when travelers visiting Mecca -- widely regarded as the holiest city in Islam -- returned to their home countries.\n\nNewer vaccines like Menveo and Nimenrix, according to the foundation, are preferred. The Muslim Council of Britain (MCB) has established a national network of vaccination clinics in England, Wales, or Scotland, though the network does not extend to Northern Ireland.\n\nMeningitis is inflammation of the delicate protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. The condition, which may be life-threatening, is caused primarily by viral or bacterial infection. Symptoms include headache, stiff neck, fever and confusion or altered consciousness.\n\n[Byline: Alexandra Villareal]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More than 2 million Muslims from over 183 countries make the Hajj pilgrimage each year. Because of intense crowding and high carrier rates of _Neisseria meningitidis_ among pilgrims, large epidemics of meningococcal disease have been linked to the Hajj pilgrimage, at first due to meningococcal serogroup A in 1987. After requiring vaccination with the bivalent A and C meningococcal vaccine for attending the Hajj, no further outbreaks due to serogroup A occurred, but then in 2000 and again in 2001, large epidemics due to meningococcal serogroup W135 occurred among pilgrims and their families.\n\nA change in the Hajj pilgrimage requirements from bivalent to quadrivalent (serogroups A, C, Y, and W135) meningococcal vaccine ended further meningococcal outbreaks. Pilgrims on Hajj or Umrah are required to present a certificate of vaccination with ACYW135, issued at least 10 days, but not more than 3 years before arrival. Hajj visas cannot be issued without proof of vaccination. Conjugated meningococcal vaccines are preferred over polysaccharide meningococcal vaccines because of lack of herd immunity and persistence of meningococcal carriage among vaccinated pilgrims with the polysaccharide vaccine. Menveo and Nimenrix are 2 conjugated quadrivalent (serogroups A, C, W135 and Y); Nimenrix is conjugated to tetanus toxoid.\n\nFor the official documentation of full requirements for entry into Saudi Arabia for the Hajj, see the following websites:\n- Saudi Ministry of Health Regulations:\nhttp://www.saudiembassy.net/services/hajj_requirements.aspx\n- Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia requirements to apply for a Hajj visa\nhttp://www.saudiembassy.net/services/Visa_Application_Forms.aspx\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has also outlined its recommendations for pilgrims during the Hajj (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/yellowbook/2014/chapter-4-select-destinations/saudi-arabia-hajj-pilgrimage). These recommendations include restricting travel to only those in good health and being up to date on all routine vaccinations, which include vaccines for polio, influenza, measles/mumps/rubella (MMR), tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis. The CDC also recommends vaccinations for meningococcal disease, hepatitis A and B, and typhoid. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/131.]", "summary": "For the official documentation of full requirements for entry into Saudi Arabia for the Hajj, see the following websites:\n- Saudi Ministry of Health Regulations:\nhttp://www.saudiembassy.net/services/hajj_requirements.aspx\n- Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia requirements to apply for a Hajj visa\nhttp://www.saudiembassy.net/services/Visa_Application_Forms.aspx\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has also outlined its recommendations for pilgrims during the Hajj (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/yellowbook/2014/chapter-4-select-destinations/saudi-arabia-hajj-pilgrimage). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Conjugated meningococcal vaccines are preferred over polysaccharide meningococcal vaccines because of lack of herd immunity and persistence of meningococcal carriage among vaccinated pilgrims with the polysaccharide vaccine. After requiring vaccination with the bivalent A and C meningococcal vaccine for attending the Hajj, no further outbreaks due to serogroup A occurred, but then in 2000 and again in 2001, large epidemics due to meningococcal serogroup W135 occurred among pilgrims and their families. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More than 2 million Muslims from over 183 countries make the Hajj pilgrimage each year. \n\nThe visa requirement was added more than 10 years ago after a number of large meningitis epidemics occurred when travelers visiting Mecca -- widely regarded as the holiest city in Islam -- returned to their home countries. Because of intense crowding and high carrier rates of _Neisseria meningitidis_ among pilgrims, large epidemics of meningococcal disease have been linked to the Hajj pilgrimage, at first due to meningococcal serogroup A in 1987. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - SAUDI ARABIA: PREVENTION, HAJJ PILGRIM TRAVEL ADVICE\n********************************************************************************\n \n\nVaccination against meningitis is required for all travelers, who must carry a certificate showing they were vaccinated at least 10 days before leaving for Saudi Arabia, but no more than 3 years before arrival.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hepatitis a", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "1987-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nimenrix", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Mecca", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Islam", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/131", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2648233", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aseptic meningitis - Kazakhstan: (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2648233", "date": "2014-07-31 15:56:36", "main_text": "ASEPTIC MENINGITIS - KAZAKHSTAN: (ASTANA)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 30 Jul 2014\nSource: Tengri News [edited]\nhttp://en.tengrinews.kz/health/Suspected-meningitis-knocks-down-160-in-Astana-255094/\n\n\nSuspected meningitis has forced more than a 100 people into hospital beds in Astana, Tengrinews reports. According to the Department of Consumer Protection of the capital of Kazakhstan, 160 people have been hospitalized in 1 month.\n\n'As of 25 Jul 2014, there were 160 patients in hospitals' in-patient wards with symptoms that do not exclude meningitis. Since 1 Jul 2014, after clinical examination 139 patients have been diagnosed with serous meningitis. Of them, 50 cases are laboratory-confirmed,' the Department said in a response to a formal inquiry from Tengrinews.\n\nThe Department assured that it was not an outbreak but a seasonal rise, since there was a similar number of cases during the same period of last year [2013]. The number of cases peaked in July. The majority -- 95 percent -- of those diagnosed with meningitis were children under the age of 14.\n\n'No instances of group contagion have been registered; therefore, restrictive measures are not necessary,' the Department said in response to a question on whether educational institutions and kindergartens had to be quarantined.\n\n'The Health Department ensured timely hospitalization of the patients with serous meningitis. In cases of serous meningitis caused by enterovirus, disinfection measures in crowded places are not required as personal hygiene is enough to eliminate the non-percutaneous channel of the infection,' the agency said.\n\nVirological investigators tested 11 samples from fountains, 16 samples from surface water reservoirs, and 10 samples of sewage water. Only one sewage water sample showed enterovirus, indicating circulation of the virus in the external environment.\n\nThe Department called the citizens to carefully [follow] the general preventive measures to reduce the risk of catching the enterovirus infection.\n\nThese are: drink only bottled water or boiled tap water; wash hands with soap before each meal and after each visit to the toilet; strictly observe the rules of personal and public hygiene; wash fruit and vegetables with a brush before eating them, swim only in officially designated places; abstain from purchasing food products of unclear origin or away from officially designated trading areas.\n\n[Bacterial] meningitis is an infection of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. Viral meningitis occurs more often than bacterial meningitis, and is milder. It usually occurs in the late summer and early fall. It most often affects children and adults under age 30. Symptoms usually come on quickly, and may include: fever and chills, mental status changes, nausea and vomiting, sensitivity to light (photophobia), severe headache, stiff neck, agitation, bulging fontanelles in babies, decreased alertness, poor feeding or irritability in children, rapid breathing, unusual posture, with the head and neck arched backwards.\n\nThe heath department specifically urged people not to reserve to self-treatment but to immediately see a doctor in case of noticing the symptoms.\n\n[Byline: Altynai Zhumzhumina, Dinara Urazova, Tatyana Kuzmina]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term 'meningitis' means an inflammation of the meninges, which are the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord. 'Serous' meningitis is a term used when clinical findings (such as a stiff neck) suggest meningitis, but the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), although under increased pressure, is clear to the naked eye (http://www.bmj.com/content/2/3691/627.3).\n\nNormally, there are 0 to 5 white cells (all mononuclear cells) per cmm [per cubic millimeter] in the CSF. CSF becomes cloudy when there are more than 500 white cells per cmm. When the CSF is visibly clear, but on laboratory examination the CSF white cell count is 6 to 500 cells per cmm, usually with lymphocytes predominating, the term aseptic meningitis is used.\n\nAs stated in the news report above, the most common cause of aseptic meningitis is a viral infection and enteroviruses are usually the cause of viral meningitis, especially in children during the summer months. However, aseptic meningitis may be caused by other viruses, such as arboviruses, HIV, herpes simplex virus (HSV) types 1 and 2, some bacteria, fungi, and parasites. Non-infectious causes include certain drugs, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and systemic diseases, such as lupus, sarcoidosis, and metastatic cancer.\n\nMost people who get infected with enteroviruses are asymptomatic or have only a non-specific febrile illness. Enteroviruses are most often spread via the fecal-oral route from person to person through fecal contamination of water or food or contact with contaminated inanimate objects. Enteroviruses can also be spread through respiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus) of an infected person.\n\nMaps of Kazakhstan can be seen at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/kazakhst.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6183. Astana is the capital of Kazakhstan since 1997, and is the country's 2nd largest city (after Almaty, the former capital) with an estimated population of 814 401 in 2014; it is located in the north portion of Kazakhstan, within Akmola Province (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astana). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nThese are: drink only bottled water or boiled tap water; wash hands with soap before each meal and after each visit to the toilet; strictly observe the rules of personal and public hygiene; wash fruit and vegetables with a brush before eating them, swim only in officially designated places; abstain from purchasing food products of unclear origin or away from officially designated trading areas. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term 'meningitis' means an inflammation of the meninges, which are the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord. ' As stated in the news report above, the most common cause of aseptic meningitis is a viral infection and enteroviruses are usually the cause of viral meningitis, especially in children during the summer months. Serous' meningitis is a term used when clinical findings (such as a stiff neck) suggest meningitis, but the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), although under increased pressure, is clear to the naked eye (http://www.bmj.com/content/2/3691/627.3). In cases of serous meningitis caused by enterovirus, disinfection measures in crowded places are not required as personal hygiene is enough to eliminate the non-percutaneous channel of the infection,' the agency said. When the CSF is visibly clear, but on laboratory examination the CSF white cell count is 6 to 500 cells per cmm, usually with lymphocytes predominating, the term aseptic meningitis is used. Symptoms usually come on quickly, and may include: fever and chills, mental status changes, nausea and vomiting, sensitivity to light (photophobia), severe headache, stiff neck, agitation, bulging fontanelles in babies, decreased alertness, poor feeding or irritability in children, rapid breathing, unusual posture, with the head and neck arched backwards. \n\n'As of 25 Jul 2014, there were 160 patients in hospitals' in-patient wards with symptoms that do not exclude meningitis. \n\nVirological investigators tested 11 samples from fountains, 16 samples from surface water reservoirs, and 10 samples of sewage water. Viral meningitis occurs more often than bacterial meningitis, and is milder. \n\n'No instances of group contagion have been registered; therefore, restrictive measures are not necessary,' the Department said in response to a question on whether educational institutions and kindergartens had to be quarantined. Since 1 Jul 2014, after clinical examination 139 patients have been diagnosed with serous meningitis. \n\nNormally, there are 0 to 5 white cells (all mononuclear cells) per cmm [per cubic millimeter] in the CSF.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2014-03-26 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-07-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Akmola Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tatyana", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Astana", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2572211", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Enteroviral meningitis - Armenia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2572211", "date": "2014-06-28 16:39:41", "main_text": "ENTEROVIRAL MENINGITIS - ARMENIA\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 26 Jun 2014\nSource: ARKA [edited]\nhttp://arka.am/en/news/society/serous_meningitis_incidence_rate_increased_in_armenia_/\n\n\nSerous [more formally called aseptic or viral - Mod.LL] meningitis rates have increased in Armenia, the press office of Armenia's ministry of health reported. In May-June 2014, a total of 38 cases of acute meningitis were recorded, mainly in the 3-8-years-old age group. No group cases were recorded, according to the report.\n\nThe report says enteroviral infections have become more common in a number of countries in May-June 2014, in Georgia, Moldova and Kyrgyzstan in particular.\n\nInstructed by the minister of health, the respective bodies are taking preventive and anti-epidemic measures.\n\nEnteroviral infections cover a wide range of illnesses that are caused by a group of viruses called enteroviruses (EVs). They are members of the Picornaviridae family and are small, icosahedral, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although in spring and summer, enteroviruses such as Coxsackie and ECHO are common causes of viral meningitis worldwide, they were not the 1st viruses to be associated with a non-purulent (serous) and generally less pathogenic form of meningitis. It was lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus that was the 1st, and prototypic, agent to cause viral meningitis. Previously, however, a variety of viruses were known to cause an encephalitis type of illness. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/133.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although in spring and summer, enteroviruses such as Coxsackie and ECHO are common causes of viral meningitis worldwide, they were not the 1st viruses to be associated with a non-purulent (serous) and generally less pathogenic form of meningitis. Source: ARKA [edited]\nhttp://arka.am/en/news/society/serous_meningitis_incidence_rate_increased_in_armenia_/ They are members of the Picornaviridae family and are small, icosahedral, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses. **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Armenia", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Moldova", "country": "Moldova"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2515425", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - Georgia (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2515425", "date": "2014-06-03 10:37:31", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - GEORGIA (02)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 26 May 2014\nSource: Democracy & Freedom Watch [edited]\nhttp://dfwatch.net/meningitis-cases-rise-to-306-in-georgia-outbreak-98989\n\n\nThe number of confirmed cases of viral meningitis in the last 2 months in Georgia has jumped to 306. According to Georgia's National Center for Disease Control and Public Health (NCDC), 169 of the cases were in Tbilisi, 51 in Kutaisi, 18 in Adjara, 11 in Rustavi, and one isolated case in each of a number of cities and towns all over Georgia.\n\n[Over the weekend (24-25 May 2014)], 7 new cases were registered in Kutaisi. 38 patients are receiving medical treatment at the hospital in that 2nd largest Georgian city.\n\nThe minister of health has repeatedly said that there is no cause for alarm about the viral meningitis outbreak. Also NCDC representatives have said that this kind of thing happens every four years. The last two times viral meningitis peaked was in 2010 and 2006.\n\nNonetheless, authorities view the situation serious enough that kindergartens and schools up to 6th grade were closed until [27 May 2014] to, as they say, implement additional sanitary measures. TV news showed schools buildings being decontaminated.\n\nThe ministry also called on the parents themselves and schools staff to take additional hygiene measures to protect children, most importantly, by providing for a strict personal hygiene, and washing hands frequently. Dining areas should be thoroughly cleaned with disinfectants.\n\nIt further said that in schools, pupils should not share utensils like plates and forks. If the 1st symptoms of meningitis are noted, immediately see the doctor. Parents should monitor that their children are following all the hygiene rules.\n\nSchools that have had cases of meningitis must be [?de]contaminated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases of viral meningitis in Georgia has more than doubled -- from 142 cases when last reported on 21 May (ProMED-mail post Viral meningitis - Georgia 20140524.2496603) to now 306 cases on 26 May. The age range of cases is 2 to 34 years and none were said to be severely ill in the prior ProMED-mail post. The cases seem to be occurring throughout Georgia. Apparently the specific virus causing this outbreak has not been identified as yet, even though there were said to be similar outbreaks of viral meningitis in Georgia in 2006 and 2010 (ProMED-mail post Viral meningitis - Georgia 20140524.2496603). However, there were no ProMED-mail posts of viral meningitis outbreaks in Georgia in prior years.\n\nMaps of Georgia can be seen at http://www.mapsofworld.com/georgia/maps/georgia-political-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/84. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases of viral meningitis in Georgia has more than doubled -- from 142 cases when last reported on 21 May (ProMED-mail post Viral meningitis - Georgia 20140524.2496603) to now 306 cases on 26 May. Date: Mon 26 May 2014\n If the 1st symptoms of meningitis are noted, immediately see the doctor.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2014-05-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-05-27 00:00:00", "2021-05-21 00:00:00", "2051-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Rustavi", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Adjara", "country": "Benin"}, {"location": "Kutaisi", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Tbilisi", "country": "Georgia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2496603", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - Georgia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2496603", "date": "2014-05-24 19:28:07", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - GEORGIA\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 21 May 2014\nSource: Democracy and Freedom Watch [edited]\nhttp://dfwatch.net/schools-closed-in-georgia-due-to-outbreak-of-viral-meningitis-49006\n\n\nAn outbreak of viral meningitis has spread in schools and kindergartens in Georgia the last few weeks, with 142 confirmed cases so far. Kindergartens and schools up to 6th grade will be closed until 27 May [2014], while sanitary measures are being implemented. This was decided Wednesday [21 May 2014] at a session between staff of the education and health ministries.\n\nBut health minister Davit Sergeenko says there is no reason for panic. 'Viral meningitis may peak within a 4 year time frame, but it doesn't get severe,' Sergeenko said at a press conference on Wednesday [21 May 2014]. He said all the cases are only of medium or light severity. Of the patients, 87 are receiving medical treatment at Iashvili hospital in Tbilisi, he said.\n\nAbout 15 of the cases are in Kutaisi, Georgia's 2nd largest city, and 4 in Batumi on the Black Sea coast. The youngest patient is 2 years old and the oldest 34.\n\nThe health minister says there is no vaccine for the virus causing this outbreak. One of the most effective ways to avoid infection is through good personal hygiene. At the press conference, Sergeenko underlined that there have been no severe cases among all the patients, but added that he has a plan prepared in case the outbreak gets worse. Later, it was announced that the Health Ministry and Education Ministry had decided at a session to close all kindergartens and schools up to 6th grade until 27 May [2014] to tackle the outbreak by beefing up sanitary measures.\n\nGeorgia usually has about 150 cases of meningitis in a year, but once every 4 years the number of cases peaks, as it did in 2006 and 2010.\n\nParents should be on guard and if they see that a child is irritated, lacks appetite or has fever, headache or other symptoms, they must immediately take them to a doctor.\n\nViral meningitis may be caused by a variety of viruses. Meningitis may also be caused by a certain type of bacteria, and this type of the disease is fatal in about 10 per cent of cases.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viral meningitis can be caused by a variety of viruses. Enteroviruses such as Coxsackie and echoviruses are the commonest, although mumps, herpes simplex and polio can be the cause in some instances. The viruses involved in the outbreak above are not specified. Closure of schools and emphasis on personal hygiene are prudent measures under the circumstances. This is the 1st ProMED-mail post of viral meningitis in Georgia, although the above report indicates that outbreaks have occurred there in recent years.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Georgia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/84. - Mod.TY]\n\n.................................................sh/ty/je/sh", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nGeorgia usually has about 150 cases of meningitis in a year, but once every 4 years the number of cases peaks, as it did in 2006 and 2010. Later, it was announced that the Health Ministry and Education Ministry had decided at a session to close all kindergartens and schools up to 6th grade until 27 May [2014] to tackle the outbreak by beefing up sanitary measures. Viral meningitis may peak within a 4 year time frame, but it doesn't get severe,' Sergeenko said at a press conference on Wednesday [21 May 2014]. An outbreak of viral meningitis has spread in schools and kindergartens in Georgia the last few weeks, with 142 confirmed cases so far. VIRAL MENINGITIS - GEORGIA\n**************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viral meningitis can be caused by a variety of viruses. At the press conference, Sergeenko underlined that there have been no severe cases among all the patients, but added that he has a plan prepared in case the outbreak gets worse. \n\nAbout 15 of the cases are in Kutaisi, Georgia's 2nd largest city, and 4 in Batumi on the Black Sea coast.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-05-21 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-05-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kutaisi", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Batumi", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Tbilisi", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2420130", "headline": "PRO/AH> Meningitis, bacterial - UK (02): Pasteurella multocida, background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2420130", "date": "2014-04-22 13:36:52", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, BACTERIAL - UK (02): PASTEURELLA MULTOCIDA, BACKGROUND\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 21 Apr 2014\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network) [edited]\nhttp://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Pmultocida-UK.bmp\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Meningitis, bacterial - UK: (England) domestic cat-to-human infant transm 20140420.2417385\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nFew countries publish reports of _Pasteurella multocida_ infection on a national level. The incidence of human pasteurellosis in the United Kingdom increased from 172 cases in 1972, to 426 in 2006 and 466 in 2007. 5 fatal cases were reported during 1993 to 2006. Reporting trends for _P. multicida_ infection in England and Wales are depicted in the graph at http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Pmultocida-UK.bmp.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Berger SA: Infectious Diseases of the United Kingdom, 2014. 1154 pages, 959 graphs, 4208 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-the-united-kingdom/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<steve@gideononline.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Berger for his continuing contributions. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/279.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n MENINGITIS, BACTERIAL - UK (02): PASTEURELLA MULTOCIDA, BACKGROUND\n******************************************************************\n Reference\n---------\n1. Communicated by:\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine \n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Meningitis, bacterial - UK: (England) domestic cat-to-human infant transm 20140420.2417385\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "1972-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2417385", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Meningitis, bacterial - UK: (England) domestic cat-to-human infant transm.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2417385", "date": "2014-04-20 15:52:18", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, BACTERIAL - UK: (ENGLAND) DOMESTIC CAT-TO-HUMAN INFANT TRANSMISSION\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nSource: Mirror [edited]\nhttp://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/baby-given-meningitis-cat-sparkle-3424700\n\n\n[A baby] almost died after contracting an infection passed to her in the saliva of the family's ginger tomcat, Chesney.\n\nA mum told today [17 Apr 2014] how her baby daughter nearly died from meningitis after being infected by the family's pet cat. The girl was just 3 weeks old when she was rushed to hospital with a high temperature and sickness. She was left fighting for life in an isolation unit after it was confirmed she was suffering from meningitis.\n\nDoctors later told her frantic mum that tests showed the infection had been passed to her daughter in the saliva of their ginger tomcat Chesney. Mum-of-one, aged 21, said: 'I was just really, really surprised when the doctors said she caught it from the cat; I didn't have a clue it was possible.\n\n'For the 1st couple of days we feared the worst because [she] was so unwell. About 5 days later, the doctors asked if we had any pets. I said we had a cat. They explained to us that [her] illness had been caused by a bug carried by bacteria in the cat's saliva. It took them a while to find out what it was, because they had never seen it before. The doctor said that from the swab they had, there was a bug that grew, and they didn't know what it was. It turned out it was in cats, dogs, rabbits, and pigs; it was in their saliva and really rare. The doctors said there were only 39 recorded cases in the world, and most involved newborn babies because they didn't have an immune system. I was told that she could have died within hours if I hadn't brought her in. They thought the bug was transferred through Chesney's saliva. I'd been careful not to leave them alone together, but Chesney must have licked [her] milk bottle while my back was turned.'\n\n'When Sparkle began to improve she had to go and have her bones checked because the doctors said in half the cases, people later suffered a bone disease. I didn't really let Chesney near her when she was tiny. But I was breast-feeding and bottle feeding, and he must have licked her milk bottle or my hand. The cat did have a thing about going for her bottle to get at the milk; it's just a cat thing isn't it.'\n\n'[She] spent about 3 weeks in hospital, and then we had to take her back every day for a week to take antibiotics. Fortunately, she made a full recovery. The cat was never unwell; it was just a natural bacteria in his saliva.'\n\n[The girl] is now aged 3 and learning to ride a pony.\n\nThe terrifying episode unfolded shortly after [the mother] gave birth to her only child at the age of 18. She and [the baby]'s dad were at home at 7 pm one evening when their baby suddenly became very unwell. [The mother], from Winsham, Somerset, said: 'She was restless and had a very high temperature and wouldn't stop crying. It was a very piercing cry, and she then started being sick. I thought she had colic and sent [my husband] down to Tesco to get some colic drops. She didn't have a rash but was really, really hot and we gave her a bath to cool her down because she loved a bath.' But [the baby] became more unwell, and the couple wrapped her in a blanket and went to Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton after phoning NHS Direct.\n\nHer mother decided not to have 2-year-old Chesney put down after [her baby] recovered from the life-threatening illness. Instead, she gave the cat to her mum who lives 4 miles away. [Her mother] said: 'I used to worry about Sparkle at 1st and didn't let her near any animals for more than a year. But it was not Chesney's fault; he didn't mean to do it. I'd had him since he was a kitten; he was like my 1st baby, and I couldn't have put him down. We asked the doctors if we should get rid of the cat, and they said it wasn't really necessary. Now the baby is more immune to it than us because she has all the antibodies.' Sparkle now plays with Chesney every time she visits her grandmother's home in Chard.\n\nA spokeswoman for Musgrove Park Hospital today [17 Apr 2014] confirmed Sparkle was treated at the facility 3 years ago.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Gregory, Richard Smith]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above news report describes acute meningitis in a 3-week-old baby that was attributed to a pathogen found normally in cat saliva. The news report, unfortunately, fails to mention what that pathogen was, except to say that it was a rare cause of meningitis: '...only 39 recorded cases in the world and most involved newborn babies because they didn't have an immune system.'\n\nPossible pathogens in cat's saliva can be inferred from those isolated in cat bite infections. Anywhere from 20-80 percent of cat bites may become infected. _Pasteurella_, a Gram-negative coccobacillus that resembles _Hemophilus influenzae_, is the organism most commonly found in cat bite wound infections, with _Pasteurella multocida_ being the predominant _Pasteurella_ species; various viridans _Streptococci_ and _Streptococcus agalactiae_ (also known as Group B beta-hemolytic streptococci or GBS) are the 2nd most common type of organisms isolated (http://cmr.asm.org/content/24/2/231.full). (_Streptococcus pyogenes_, also known as Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus, has not been isolated in cat bite wound infections.) Less frequently encountered aerobic organisms in cat bite infections include _Capnocytophaga_ species. Cats are also the main reservoir of _Bartonella henselae_, the causative agent of cat scratch disease, which is found in cat saliva.\n\n_Pasteurella multocida_ has been implicated as a rare cause of bacterial meningitis. Most of these meningitis patients had an animal contact, and many were newborns (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2425895/, http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19730153, http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17055368, http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17206557 and http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8666850). Meningitis in these patients can be complicated by osteomyelitis (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12878338).\n\n_S. agalactiae_ (GBS) is a major cause infection of the newborn; early-onset disease occurring in the 1st week of life is septicemia accompanied by pneumonia, while late-onset disease is septicemia more often accompanied by meningitis (http://www.cdc.gov/groupbstrep/about/newborns-pregnant.html). GBS thus cannot be considered a rare cause of meningitis.\n\n_Capnocytophaga_ cause overwhelming sepsis in asplenic patients, the elderly, and the immunocompromised. About 20 patients with _Capnoytophaga_ meningitis have been described in the medical literature, but the age range has been 17-83 years (mean, 50.6 years) (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/36/3/e42.full.pdf).\n\n_Bartonella henselae_ has not been shown to cause bacterial meningitis (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12051353, http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8562744). Anaerobic bacteria, although common in cat saliva and cat bite wound infections, are very rarely the cause of acute bacterial meningitis without identifiable risk factors (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC268396/?page=1, http://anaerobicinfections.blogspot.com/p/central-nervous-system-infections.html).\n\nCat and other feline bites and exposures can also transmit to humans _Francisella tularensis_, the cause of tularemia, _Yersinia pestis_, the cause of plague, and _Mycobacterium bovis_, which can cause human tuberculosis (ProMED-mail post Bovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 2013, domestic cat-to-human transm. 20140327.2361967). Although these organisms can cause meningitis, they would not be described as normal flora in cats' saliva.\n\nSo my vote is for _Pasteurella multocida_ as the etiologic agent in this child's meningitis. More specific information about the etiology of meningitis in this case would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/279.]", "summary": "The news report, unfortunately, fails to mention what that pathogen was, except to say that it was a rare cause of meningitis: '...only 39 recorded cases in the world and most involved newborn babies because they didn't have an immune system.'\n\nPossible pathogens in cat's saliva can be inferred from those isolated in cat bite infections. Anaerobic bacteria, although common in cat saliva and cat bite wound infections, are very rarely the cause of acute bacterial meningitis without identifiable risk factors (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC268396/?page=1, http://anaerobicinfections.blogspot.com/p/central-nervous-system-infections.html). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above news report describes acute meningitis in a 3-week-old baby that was attributed to a pathogen found normally in cat saliva. \n\n_S. agalactiae_ (GBS) is a major cause infection of the newborn; early-onset disease occurring in the 1st week of life is septicemia accompanied by pneumonia, while late-onset disease is septicemia more often accompanied by meningitis (http://www.cdc.gov/groupbstrep/about/newborns-pregnant.html). Cats are also the main reservoir of _Bartonella henselae_, the causative agent of cat scratch disease, which is found in cat saliva.
