' However, a 3rd-year resident assistant for Santa Catalina [UCSB's largest residence hall] said he does not think students living in residence halls are at increased risk for contracting the disease, because other students come in contact with each other just as much [as] freshmen in the dorms do. ' MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (04): (CALIFORNIA, NEW JERSEY) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B, VACCINE\n********************************************************************************************\n For further discussion of invasive meningococcal disease on a college campus, see moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail postings Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (PA) 20090218.0674 and Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (03): (NJ) college, sg. \n\n'All close contacts of the meningitis cases are being offered treatment, and Public Health has made no recommendation to cancel any activities or scheduled events on campus,' Ferris said. The US Centers for Disease Control (CDC) is preparing to recommend that all undergraduate students, as well as graduate students living in dormitories, get the vaccine, the Princeton, New Jersey-based college said yesterday [18 Nov 2913] in a statement. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 1st 3 news reports above describe another outbreak of meningococcal meningitis serogroup B that is occurring at the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB) campus. A quadrivalent serogroup A, C, Y, and W-135 conjugate meningococcal vaccine is not effective against _N. meningitidis_ serogroup B, only the Bexsero serogroup B meningococcal vaccine would be expected to be effective in the face of a serogroup B outbreak. \n\n\nA bacterial meningitis outbreak has sickened 3 students at the University of California, Santa Barbara, health officials said on Thursday [21 Nov 2013]. \n\n\nPrinceton University will offer students, pending federal approval, a meningitis vaccine not currently available in the US, after a 7th case was reported this year [2013] on the Ivy League campus. A 1st-year student, who was the first to contract meningococcal disease and meningitis, was taken to the hospital last Tuesday [12 Nov 2013], according to Student Health executive director Mary Ferris. \n\nChemoprophylaxis is given to close contacts whose risk for acquiring meningococcal disease is 500-800 times greater than among the total population (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm). \n\nMeningococcal disease is transmitted through contact with another individual's respiratory and throat secretions, such as through activities like kissing and even just living in close quarters. \n\nStudent Health will offer a meningitis vaccine on a walk-in basis on Tuesdays from 9 to 11 a.m. and Fridays from 1:30 to 3:30 p.m. Over 300 students who had close contact with the ill students were given antibiotics, said Charity Thoman, deputy health officer at the Santa Barbara County Public Health Department. \n\nThe latest case involved a female student who was diagnosed with meningococcal disease earlier this week. \n\nPublic health and school officials urged people on campus to watch out for signs of meningitis and to practice good hygiene such as covering their mouths when coughing. By early May [2013], 3 Princeton University students were diagnosed with meningitis, spread through kissing, sharing drinking glasses, and other forms of close contact. \n\nTo obtain the immunization for Princeton, CDC asked the FDA to grant the vaccine investigational new drug status, typically used to begin a clinical trial, Oswald said. \n\nWhile Student Health officials say the newest case has been identified, confirmation of meningitis in this 3rd case is still 'pending'. \n\n'I just want to express our extreme sympathy for the family and for students that... have this illness,' Ferris said. [week of 12 Nov 2013] from the Food and Drug Administration to bring in the vaccine, Barbara Reynolds, a CDC spokeswoman, said [16 Nov 2013] in a telephone interview. \n\nPrinceton earlier this week decided to make available a meningitis vaccine that hasn't been approved in the US. \n\n'[Princeton] University is prepared to accept these recommendations and make arrangements to provide access to this vaccine as soon as possible,' Princeton said. That's significantly higher than most other vaccine-preventable diseases, and 100 times the 1 to 2 in 100 000 seen with other forms of meningitis, he said. \n\n'We've been on high alert,' said Mary Ferris, executive director of student health services. \n\nFrequent handwashing and overall good hygiene can help to prevent the spread of the disease, as well as abstaining from sharing water bottles, drinking glasses, eating utensils, and cosmetics, according to Ferris. In addition, the new reports above say that University of California Santa Barbara students are being encouraged to be vaccinated against this disease, but does not say which type of meningococcal vaccine is being offered. She also said meningitis occurs most frequently amongst young freshmen or college students because the bacterium attacks young, healthy people. \n\nNovartis, Sanofi, and GlaxoSmithKline Plc all make shots available in Europe and the US that protect against 4 of the 5 major [serogroups] of the disease, not including the B [serogroup]. \n\nPublic Health and UCSB officials will host a press conference to discuss preventative measures being taken to halt spread of disease.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-08-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-02-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-12-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-26 00:00:00", "2013-11-17 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Basel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Santa Barbara", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Santa Catalina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "UCSB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Princeton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2024307", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa (02): WHO meningitis region", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2024307", "date": "2013-10-28 10:17:17", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA (02): WHO MENINGITIS REGION\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Oct 2013\nSource: The Global Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/africa-meningitis-deaths-near-1500-for-first-nine-months-of-2013-29020/\n\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) Regional Office for Africa recently released its updated Meningitis Weekly [2-29 Sep 2013] Bulletin [http://www.meningvax.org/files/BulletinMeningite2013_S36_39September.pdf], which shows the number of cases and fatalities from meningitis in 19 countries from the 'African Meningitis Belt' and it shows that for the 1st 39 weeks [as of 29 Sep 2013] there were 16 385 cases including 1460 deaths. [For a map of the African meningitis belt see the source URL above.]\n\nThe overall lethality rate for this time frame is 8.9 percent. Nearly half (48 percent) of the total cases were reported from the Democratic Republic of the Congo (7880), which resulted in 712 deaths [a case-fatality rate of 9 percent]. Burkina Faso reported 2409 cases, being the country with the second most cases.\n\nThe countries of the African meningitis belt face outbreaks of the deadly bacterial disease every year.\n\nAccording to the global health non-profit organization, PATH, about 450 million people are at risk of the deadly disease. Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger, Chad, Sudan, and Ethiopia are considered hyperendemic, meaning populations in these countries are at the highest risk of developing meningitis.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the sub-Saharan African region known as the 'African meningitis belt' each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June (http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx). _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A is said to be the most commonly isolated pathogen in the African meningitis belt. However, outbreaks have also been caused by other _N. meningitidis_ serogroups, such as serogroup C (http://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/lab-manual/chpt02-epi.html), W135 (14760584.5.3.319' target='_blank' rel='noopener noreferrer'>http://www.expert-reviews.com/doi/abs/10.1586/ 14760584.5.3.319), and X (http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264410X13004751), and in March 2012, a serogroup B outbreak occurred in Ethiopia (http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news/3581-ethiopia-suspected-meningitis-outbreak-situation-as-of-08-march-2012-.html).\n\nWHO recently reported (WHO Global Alert and Response, available at http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/index.html) that the number of cases reported from 1 Jan to 12 May 2013 (epidemiological week 19) is the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20130606.1759273). The decrease in number of cases of meningitis was thought to be due to the progressive introduction of the newly developed meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt since 2010. A preventive strategy based on conjugate vaccines could have a significantly larger and more enduring impact on attempts to control the yearly recurrences of this disease in Africa that causes considerable morbidity and mortality, especially among children (see http://www.jidc.org/index.php/journal/article/view/19745499/102). The meningococcal protein conjugate polysaccharide vaccines induce a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved immune response in infants, provide long-lasting immunity, and prevent nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_, thus reducing transmission of this microorganism from person to person (see http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf).\n\nAccording to the WHO Meningitis Weekly Bulletin referred to above (Table 3, http://www.meningvax.org/files/BulletinMeningite2013_S36_39September.pdf), a bacterial pathogen was identified (by PCR, latex agglutination, or culture) in 802 out of 4209 (19 percent) cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) specimens that were obtained in the 16 385 (25.7 percent) meningitis cases. Of the bacterial pathogens identified, _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ was the most frequent (404 cases), followed by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup W135 (229 cases). _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was identified in only 22 cases.\n\nNo bacterial pathogen was identified in almost 80 percent of the CSF specimens (3350 of the 4209). Presumably meningitis in these cases with CSF negative by PCR, latex agglutination, and culture was caused most commonly by viruses. In 57 CSF samples a contaminant was said to have been identified.\n\nIn Burkina Faso (BF), a CSF specimen was obtained in 1104 of 2409 cases (45.8 percent), but in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), in only 289 of 7880 (3.7 percent) cases. In Burkina Faso (BF), a bacterial pathogen was identified in 448 of the 1104 CSF specimens (40.6 percent) and in DRC in only 37 of the 289 CSF specimens (12.8 percent). In BF, _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ was the most frequent bacterial pathogen (244 cases), followed by _N. meningitidis_ W135 (165 cases). In DRC, 'other pathogens' were most common (22 cases), followed by _S. pneumoniae_ (9 cases). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1Ahy.]", "summary": "According to the WHO Meningitis Weekly Bulletin referred to above (Table 3, http://www.meningvax.org/files/BulletinMeningite2013_S36_39September.pdf), a bacterial pathogen was identified (by PCR, latex agglutination, or culture) in 802 out of 4209 (19 percent) cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) specimens that were obtained in the 16 385 (25.7 percent) meningitis cases. \n\nWHO recently reported (WHO Global Alert and Response, available at http://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/index.html) that the number of cases reported from 1 Jan to 12 May 2013 (epidemiological week 19) is the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20130606.1759273). Bulletin [http://www.meningvax.org/files/BulletinMeningite2013_S36_39September.pdf], which shows the number of cases and fatalities from meningitis in 19 countries from the 'African Meningitis Belt' and it shows that for the 1st 39 weeks [as of 29 Sep 2013] there were 16 385 cases including 1460 deaths. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the sub-Saharan African region known as the 'African meningitis belt' each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June (http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Of the bacterial pathogens identified, _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ was the most frequent (404 cases), followed by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup W135 (229 cases). In Burkina Faso (BF), a CSF specimen was obtained in 1104 of 2409 cases (45.8 percent), but in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), in only 289 of 7880 (3.7 percent) cases. The decrease in number of cases of meningitis was thought to be due to the progressive introduction of the newly developed meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt since 2010. In BF, _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ was the most frequent bacterial pathogen (244 cases), followed by _N. meningitidis_ W135 (165 cases). Nearly half (48 percent) of the total cases were reported from the Democratic Republic of the Congo (7880), which resulted in 712 deaths [a case-fatality rate of 9 percent]. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA (02): WHO MENINGITIS REGION\n**************************************************************\n In Burkina Faso (BF), a bacterial pathogen was identified in 448 of the 1104 CSF specimens (40.6 percent) and in DRC in only 37 of the 289 CSF specimens (12.8 percent).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1104-03-26 00:00:00", "2409-03-26 00:00:00", "1460-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2060293", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (03): (NJ) college, sg. B, new vaccine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2060293", "date": "2013-11-17 18:27:26", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (03): (NEW JERSEY), COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B, NEW VACCINE\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 16 Nov 2013\nSource: The Global Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/princeton-considers-the-use-of-bexsero-meningitis-vaccine-to-curb-spread-of-meningitis-b-60884/\n\n\nFollowing the 7th confirmed case of _Neisseria meningitidis_ [serogroup] B infection at Princeton University since March 2013, the school is considering the use of a European Union/Australia-approved vaccine that will protect against this strain of the potentially lethal infection.\n\nCBS New York reports that the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has offered the school to use the Novartis vaccine, Bexsero. The CDC has been working with the Food and Drug Administration about gaining access to this particular vaccine, CDC spokeswoman Barbara Reynolds told CNN. 'We just got the approval from FDA this week to import the vaccine under the Investigational New Drug Application program,' Reynolds said, 'Now we're consulting with the Princeton University officials and New Jersey Health Department officials about the next step.'\n\nMeningococcal meningitis is caused by a bacteria called _N. meningitidis_ that can infect the lining of the brain and spinal cord. There are a few different types or strains of _N. meningitidis_. In the US, types B, C and Y cause the majority of disease.\n\nCurrently, there are 2 vaccines in the United States, meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine (Menomune), and meningococcal conjugate vaccine (Menactra and Menveo), that protect against _N. meningitidis_. However, they only protect against _N. meningitidis_ serogroups A, C, Y and W-135. There is currently no licensed vaccine that protects against serogroup B in the U.S.\n\nAs Reynolds points out in the CNN interview, the Princeton situation is 'unique' as it's the 1st time there has been an outbreak in a population where we have an option to control the outbreak using the serogroup B vaccine.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 16 Nov 2013\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/16/us-usa-princeton-meningitis-idUSBRE9AF08H20131116\n\n\nA meningitis vaccine approved for use in Europe and Australia but not in the United States can be imported to try to stop an outbreak of the disease at Princeton University in New Jersey, federal health officials said.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration agreed this week to the importation of the vaccine, Bexsero, for potential use on the Ivy League campus, Barbara Reynolds, a spokeswoman for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said on Saturday [16 Nov 2013].\n\nThe school, which has about 7900 students, reported its 7th case of the year [2013] this week, said university spokesman Martin Mbugua.\n\nBexsero, a new vaccine made by Swiss drug maker Novartis, is designed to protect against a strain of the disease, serogroup B, that is not as common in the United States as it is in other parts of the world, Reynolds said.\n\nThe outbreak of serogroup B meningitis at Princeton is rare but not the 1st of its kind in the United States, Reynolds said. 'What's a little different now is this is the 1st time we've had an outbreak and also have had the possibility of using a vaccine that could protect against it,' she said.\n\nThe university's trustees are meeting this weekend to discuss the outbreak. Mbugua would not talk about the nature of those discussions or what day they would be held. 'I will not pre-empt the trustees' discussion by talking about it beforehand,' he said.\n\nReynolds said she did not have a timetable for how quickly the vaccine could be available. Its use would be optional for students at Princeton, she said. The most recent case at the school was diagnosed last Sunday, Mbugua said. Six of those affected are students, and one was a visitor, he said.\n\nThe student who most recently became ill remains hospitalized, according to the New Jersey Department of Health. Five other students have recovered, and the visitor's case is being followed by another state health department. The 1st case was reported in March 2013.\n\nMeningitis is a serious disease that is spread through coughing and exchanges of saliva, and people living in dormitories or other crowded living quarters are especially at risk. There is a vaccine available in the United States for other strains of the disease, Reynolds said. The CDC recommends the vaccine for children and students before they head off to college.\n\nBacterial meningitis can cause the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord to swell. The most severe cases can result in death, hearing loss, brain damage, kidney disease or require the amputation of limbs. Symptoms include fever, headaches and stiff neck.\n\n[Byline: Noreen O'Donnell, Colleen Jenkins, Eric Beech]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of invasive meningococcal disease on a college campus, see moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (PA) 20090218.0674.\n\nThe annual incidence has been 0.3-1.1 per 100 000 persons, or approximately 1400 to 2800 cases, which usually occur as either sporadic cases or at times as outbreaks, usually in closed communities (e.g., college students living in dormitories, particularly freshman, and new military recruits). The highest incidence of meningococcal disease occurs in infants, with a secondary peak in adolescents.\n\n13 serogroups of _Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of invasive meningococcal disease, have been identified based on the bacterial outer polysaccharide capsule, of which 5 serogroups, A, B, C, W-135, and Y, cause the majority of meningococcal disease globally. In the United States, the majority of invasive meningococcal disease is caused by serogroups B, C, W-135, and Y. However, serogroup B accounts for approximately 1/3rd of all invasive meningococcal infections and about half of invasive infections in infants.\n\nThe CDC recommends the meningococcal conjugate vaccination for college students and any persons aged 11 to 18 years, military recruits, microbiologists who are routinely exposed to isolates of _N. meningitidis_, persons who travel to Mecca during the annual Hajj or to countries in which _N. meningitidis_ is hyper-endemic or epidemic, particularly if contact with the local population will be prolonged, persons who have terminal complement component deficiencies, and persons who have anatomic or functional asplenia [without normal spleen function] (http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/559807 and http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm). Also, in an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the meningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the outbreak as soon as possible after an outbreak has been declared http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm.\n\nAlthough there are several vaccines based on the meningococcal capsular polysaccharide that cover serogroups A, C, W-135, and Y, there has been no licensed serogroup B vaccine in the U.S. Because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen, group B vaccines cannot be based on capsular polysaccharide. Vaccines that use outer membrane vesicle protein from an outbreak strain have been used successfully in New Zealand and Cuba to control epidemics in those countries caused by the targeted serogroup B strain, but these vaccines do not cover other strains of serogroup B organisms.\n\nThe Novartis Bexsero vaccine contains 4 antigenic components: Factor H Binding Protein (fHbp), Neisseria Heparin Binding Antigen (NHBA), Neisserial Adhesin A (NadA), and the outer membrane vesicle protein that is in the New Zealand MenB Vaccine (MenZB) derived from the New Zealand outbreak strain of MenB (strain NZ 98/254) (http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine). The NZ98/254 component, which contains PorA serosubtype 1.4, was effective in a strain-specific outbreak in New Zealand. The Bexsero vaccine contains surface proteins that occur across most serogroup B strains and elicits bactericidal antibodies that can confer protective immune responses (http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2010/10/19/1013758107.full.pdf). Bexsero is the 1st and only broad coverage vaccine to help protect all age groups against serogroup B disease, including infants who are at the greatest risk of infection (Cohn AC, Messonnier ME. Inching Toward a Serogroup B Meningococcal Vaccine for Infants. JAMA 2012;307(6):614-615.; and, Stephens DS. Comment. Prevention of serogroup B meningococcal disease. Lancet 2012;379(9816):592-594).\n\nThe Bexsero vaccine side effects may include soreness at the injection site, and sometimes fever, lack of appetite, muscle aches, irritability and rashes. Almost 8000 people, including more than 5000 infants and toddlers, have had the new vaccine during clinical trials, and the side effects are said to be the usual ones expected with any of the current childhood vaccines (http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine and http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine#sthash.GLMd4xiU.dpuf).\n\nPrinceton University is a private university ranked either 1st or 2nd among national universities by U.S. News & World Report from 2001 to 2013, with a highly selective undergraduate program, located in Princeton, New Jersey, United States. There are 5113 undergraduates and 2479 postgraduates (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princeton_University#Organization). More than 98 percent of students live on campus in dormitories. Freshmen and sophomores must live in one of 6 residential colleges, while juniors and seniors typically live in designated upperclassman dormitories with the option of living off-campus (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princeton_University#Organization). 11 eating clubs serve as dining halls and communal spaces for their members throughout the academic year (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eating_club_(Princeton_University)). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/35Bq.]", "summary": "There is currently no licensed vaccine that protects against serogroup B in the U.S.\n\nAs Reynolds points out in the CNN interview, the Princeton situation is 'unique' as it's the 1st time there has been an outbreak in a population where we have an option to control the outbreak using the serogroup B vaccine. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n13 serogroups of _Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of invasive meningococcal disease, have been identified based on the bacterial outer polysaccharide capsule, of which 5 serogroups, A, B, C, W-135, and Y, cause the majority of meningococcal disease globally. \n\nAlthough there are several vaccines based on the meningococcal capsular polysaccharide that cover serogroups A, C, W-135, and Y, there has been no licensed serogroup B vaccine in the U.S. Because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen, group B vaccines cannot be based on capsular polysaccharide. Vaccines that use outer membrane vesicle protein from an outbreak strain have been used successfully in New Zealand and Cuba to control epidemics in those countries caused by the targeted serogroup B strain, but these vaccines do not cover other strains of serogroup B organisms.\n\n \n\nBexsero, a new vaccine made by Swiss drug maker Novartis, is designed to protect against a strain of the disease, serogroup B, that is not as common in the United States as it is in other parts of the world, Reynolds said. Source: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/16/us-usa-princeton-meningitis-idUSBRE9AF08H20131116\n\n\nA meningitis vaccine approved for use in Europe and Australia but not in the United States can be imported to try to stop an outbreak of the disease at Princeton University in New Jersey, federal health officials said. \n\nThe Food and Drug Administration agreed this week to the importation of the vaccine, Bexsero, for potential use on the Ivy League campus, Barbara Reynolds, a spokeswoman for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said on Saturday [16 Nov 2013]. The CDC recommends the meningococcal conjugate vaccination for college students and any persons aged 11 to 18 years, military recruits, microbiologists who are routinely exposed to isolates of _N. meningitidis_, persons who travel to Mecca during the annual Hajj or to countries in which _N. meningitidis_ is hyper-endemic or epidemic, particularly if contact with the local population will be prolonged, persons who have terminal complement component deficiencies, and persons who have anatomic or functional asplenia [without normal spleen function] (http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/559807 and http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm). MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (03): (NEW JERSEY), COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B, NEW VACCINE\n*************************************************************************************\n Currently, there are 2 vaccines in the United States, meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine (Menomune), and meningococcal conjugate vaccine (Menactra and Menveo), that protect against _N. meningitidis_. The Novartis Bexsero vaccine contains 4 antigenic components: Factor H Binding Protein (fHbp), Neisseria Heparin Binding Antigen (NHBA), Neisserial Adhesin A (NadA), and the outer membrane vesicle protein that is in the New Zealand MenB Vaccine (MenZB) derived from the New Zealand outbreak strain of MenB (strain NZ 98/254) (http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of invasive meningococcal disease on a college campus, see moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (PA) 20090218.0674. Also, in an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the meningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the outbreak as soon as possible after an outbreak has been declared http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm. Following the 7th confirmed case of _Neisseria meningitidis_ [serogroup] B infection at Princeton University since March 2013, the school is considering the use of a European Union/Australia-approved vaccine that will protect against this strain of the potentially lethal infection. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nThe annual incidence has been 0.3-1.1 per 100 000 persons, or approximately 1400 to 2800 cases, which usually occur as either sporadic cases or at times as outbreaks, usually in closed communities (e.g., college students living in dormitories, particularly freshman, and new military recruits). In the United States, the majority of invasive meningococcal disease is caused by serogroups B, C, W-135, and Y. However, serogroup B accounts for approximately 1/3rd of all invasive meningococcal infections and about half of invasive infections in infants. \n\nThe school, which has about 7900 students, reported its 7th case of the year [2013] this week, said university spokesman Martin Mbugua. \n\nThe outbreak of serogroup B meningitis at Princeton is rare but not the 1st of its kind in the United States, Reynolds said. ' Bexsero is the 1st and only broad coverage vaccine to help protect all age groups against serogroup B disease, including infants who are at the greatest risk of infection (Cohn AC, Messonnier ME. \n\nMeningitis is a serious disease that is spread through coughing and exchanges of saliva, and people living in dormitories or other crowded living quarters are especially at risk. \n\nReynolds said she did not have a timetable for how quickly the vaccine could be available.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["5113-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2479-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Princeton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mecca", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1801989", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aseptic meningitis - Russia: epidemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1801989", "date": "2013-07-01 17:09:04", "main_text": "ASEPTIC MENINGITIS - RUSSIA: EPIDEMIC\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Jul2013\nSource: Vestnik Kavkaza [edited]\nhttp://vestnikkavkaza.net/articles/society/42063.html\n\n\nIn Moscow, 40 children have been hospitalized with various forms of meningitis, and for 7 of them, a diagnosis of 'serous meningitis' has been confirmed. In early June 2013, due to an outbreak of meningitis, more than 100 children in Rostov-on-Don were admitted to the hospital.\n\nDuring a press conference, Professor of the Department of Infectious Diseases and Epidemiology of MSMSU [Moscow State Medico-Stomatological University] Yuri Vengerov spoke about the disease, its symptoms and methods of treatment. He said that 'meningitis is an inflammation of the meninges, which is caused by many different organisms. And very much depends both on the pathogen and on the form of meningitis. In particular, enteroviral meningitis -- caused by an enterovirus or [other] intestinal viruses -- is included in the number of benign meningitis cases, which rarely provide any complications or adverse effects.\n\nThe name enterovirus, or intestinal virus, suggests that it is an intestinal infection, but the virus is capable of getting from the digestive tract through the bloodstream into the brain causing inflammation, i.e. meningitis. As with other intestinal infections, the spread of enteroviral meningitis occurs in the summer, and the incidence is related to the consumption of untreated water, not washing fruits, and bathing in polluted water. Meningitis may also be transmitted via droplets, i.e. close contact. Patients may be [infected] in this way and can infect each other.\n\nThe basis for the diagnosis of meningitis is fever followed by severe headache of unusual intensity. It is accompanied by nausea and vomiting. These symptoms, fever and headache with vomiting, are an indication for emergency hospitalization. Severe forms, which can be fatal, are very rare in the case of enteroviral meningitis.\n\nPanic associated with an outbreak in Rostov ensued following diagnosis of a single case of pneumococcal meningitis. This is a severe form of meningitis which often leads to death. This was not divulged [by authorities] and was perceived to be part of the same epidemic. In fact, these are completely different diseases.\n\nMost enteroviral meningitis cases used to be in the Far East. There, the Amur river [the longest river in the world] and its tributaries arising in China carry untreated waste water contaminated by enteroviruses downstream. Every summer, there are up to several hundred cases. Now, it has spread to the Ural Mountains and along the coast of the Black Sea.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In Russian language reports, the term meningitis usually implies aseptic (serous) meningitis. During the past few weeks, there have been numerous reports of outbreaks of meningitis throughout Russia reported in ProMED-RUS and elsewhere. These are almost invariably outbreaks of serous meningitis and not the more dangerous meningoencephalitis. Outbreaks of serous meningitis occur habitually in the summer months.\n\nThe word 'meningitis' means an inflammation of the meninges, which are the tissues that surround the brain and spinal cord. These tissues can be damaged by bacteria, viruses, fungi, cancers, and even some anti-inflammatory medications. Meningitis caused by bacteria is called septic meningitis. This is a medical emergency and calls for immediate treatment with intravenous antibiotics. Fortunately, this type of meningitis is less common than aseptic meningitis. Most of the time, aseptic meningitis is not life threatening. If the brain tissues also become inflamed (encephalitis), the situation is more serious. The classic findings of meningitis are fever, a stiff neck, and headache. Other signs include nausea, vomiting and worsening of headache and photophobia. Children who are old enough to talk may complain of headache or nausea.\n\nThe most common cause of aseptic meningitis is a viral infection. In fact, sometimes the terms aseptic meningitis and viral meningitis are used interchangeably, although in actuality, other things like an allergic reaction can also cause aseptic meningitis. The viruses that usually cause meningitis in children include the enteroviruses. Enteroviruses cause about 90 percent of all viral meningitis cases. This family of viruses usually causes a rash, nausea, vomiting, and some respiratory symptoms as well as muscle aches (myalgias). The most common symptoms, however, are just irritability, fever, and rash. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1MnT.]", "summary": "In fact, sometimes the terms aseptic meningitis and viral meningitis are used interchangeably, although in actuality, other things like an allergic reaction can also cause aseptic meningitis. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In Russian language reports, the term meningitis usually implies aseptic (serous) meningitis. In particular, enteroviral meningitis -- caused by an enterovirus or [other] intestinal viruses -- is included in the number of benign meningitis cases, which rarely provide any complications or adverse effects. http://vestnikkavkaza.net/articles/society/42063.html\n\n\nIn Moscow, 40 children have been hospitalized with various forms of meningitis, and for 7 of them, a diagnosis of 'serous meningitis' has been confirmed. Fortunately, this type of meningitis is less common than aseptic meningitis. Meningitis caused by bacteria is called septic meningitis. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The name enterovirus, or intestinal virus, suggests that it is an intestinal infection, but the virus is capable of getting from the digestive tract through the bloodstream into the brain causing inflammation, i.e. meningitis. As with other intestinal infections, the spread of enteroviral meningitis occurs in the summer, and the incidence is related to the consumption of untreated water, not washing fruits, and bathing in polluted water. \n\nThe basis for the diagnosis of meningitis is fever followed by severe headache of unusual intensity. \n\nMost enteroviral meningitis cases used to be in the Far East. The viruses that usually cause meningitis in children include the enteroviruses. According to a news report posted by ProMED-mail (Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (03): (VS, RM) update 20121110.1403844), there were 98 cases of meningococcal meningitis in 2012. The outbreak has centered mainly in 2 Chilean regions: the Metropolitan Region (RM), which includes Santiago, and the region of Valparaiso. _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B predominates in Valparaiso and serogroup W-135 predominates in the Metropolitan Region. On the last report in November 2012 (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (04): (RM) 20121118.1414639), there were 46 cases due to serogroup W-135 in the country, 37 of which occurred in the Metropolitan Region. The news report above says that so far this year (2013) there have been 18 additional cases due to W-135 in the country.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Chile can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/2E*Q. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail has been posting reports of an outbreak of meningococcal meningitis in Chile during the past year (2012) (see postings listed below). On the last report in November 2012 (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (04): (RM) 20121118.1414639), there were 46 cases due to serogroup W-135 in the country, 37 of which occurred in the Metropolitan Region.
