MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CHILE: (SANTIAGO METROPOLITAN REGION) FATAL, UPDATE\n*******************************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-11-26 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2013-05-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Valparaiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "RM", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1759273", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1759273", "date": "2013-06-06 20:31:02", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA: WHO MENINGITIS REGION\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 6 Jun 2013\nSource: WHO Global Alert and Response (GAR) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/2013_06_06_menin/en/index.html\n\n\nFrom 1 Jan to 12 May 2013 (epidemiologic week 19), 9249 suspected cases of meningitis, including 857 deaths, with a case fatality ratio of 9.3 percent, have been reported from 18 of the 19 African countries under enhanced surveillance [Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ethiopia, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, South Sudan, Sudan and Togo] for meningitis. The number of cases reported so far are the lowest recorded during the epidemic season in the last 10 years.\n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal disease have been confirmed in Guinea and South Sudan, where 404 suspected cases (38 deaths) and 196 suspected cases (13 deaths) have respectively been notified.\n\nIn Guinea, a small outbreak at the sub-district level was reported in Siguiri district, predominantly due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup W135 (Nm W135). Upon request from the Ministry of Health of Guinea, the International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control released 63 075 doses of ACW polysaccharide vaccines. A reactive vaccination campaign targeting the affected population was conducted by the Ministry of Health from 2-7 May 2013.\n\nIn South Sudan, an outbreak of _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A (Nm A) was confirmed in Malakal County in the Upper Nile state. The ICG released 198 770 doses of meningococcal A conjugate vaccine to implement a reactive vaccination campaign from 15-24 May 2013, which was led by the Ministry of Health of South Sudan with the support of WHO and partners.\n\nAdditionally, outbreaks of meningitis were reported in Benin (one district), Burkina Faso (one district), and Nigeria (3 districts). These outbreaks were of short duration, and the predominance of the Nm bacteria was not confirmed. The ministries of health of affected areas implemented a series of preventive and control measures, which include reinforcement of surveillance, case management, and sensitization of the population.\n\nThe decrease in the number of cases of meningitis reported during the period under review is thought to be due to the progressive introduction of the newly developed meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt since 2010. The introduction of this 1st meningococcal vaccine available for preventive purposes in Africa has enabled the immunization of over 100 million people from 10 countries [1] in the meningitis belt in the past 3 years (2010-2012). The reduced case load and epidemic activity observed this year [2013] adds to the evidence on the impact of the introduction of this vaccine, which is expected to eliminate epidemics of Nm A, which is the predominant cause of the disease in Africa. Given that large-scale epidemics in the African meningitis belt appear to occur in waves of 4 to 10 years, close surveillance for meningitis remains essential.\n\nMeningitis outbreaks are detected as part of the enhanced meningitis surveillance system introduced in 2002, whereby participating countries collect and send weekly, district level data to the WHO African Regional Office Inter-Country support team of Ouagadougou, which compiles and disseminates this data through a weekly regional bulletin. This allows for timely detection of outbreaks at the district level as well as monitoring of the situation at a regional level, enabling the identification of cross border, multi-country epidemics and a coordinated response.\n\nWHO continues to monitor the epidemiological situation closely, in collaboration with partners and ministries of health in the affected countries.\n\n[1.] Burkina Faso (2010), Mali (2010-2011), Niger (2010-2011), Cameroon (2011-2012), Chad (2011-2012), Nigeria (2011-), Ghana (2012), Benin (2012), Senegal (2012), Sudan (2012-). Campaigns' beginning and end years are indicated in parentheses; a single date indicates that the campaign was conducted during one year; an open date indicates the campaigns have not yet ended. Guinea and South Sudan preventive campaigns are planned for 2014.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Numerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the sub-Saharan African region known as the 'meningitis belt' each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June (http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx). A map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif.\n\nAt least 13 serogroups of _Neisseria meningitidis_, based on polysaccharide capsular antigens, have been described: 5 serogroups (A, B, C, Y, and W-135) most commonly cause human disease. Although serogroup C accounts for most US outbreaks (Woods CW, Rosenstein NE, Perkins BA: _Neisseria meningitidis_ outbreaks in the United States 1994-1997 (Abstract). In: Proceedings of Annual Meeting of IDSA. 12-15 Nov 1998. Denver, Colorado. Alexandria (VA): Infectious Disease Society of America; 1998), serogroup A is most commonly associated with meningitis in the African meningitis belt. However, outbreaks have also been caused by serogroups C (http://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/lab-manual/chpt02-epi.html), W135 (14760584.5.3.319' target='_blank' rel='noopener noreferrer'>http://www.expert-reviews.com/doi/abs/10.1586/ 14760584.5.3.319), and X (http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264410X13004751), and in March 2012, a serogroup B outbreak occurred in Ethiopia (http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news/3581-ethiopia-suspected-meningitis-outbreak-situation-as-of-08-march-2012-.html).\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an attempt to induce herd immunity, whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the population has been vaccinated (see http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/).\n\nCapsular polysaccharide or protein conjugate vaccines are available to immunize against disease caused by serogroups A, C, W-135, and Y. However, no similar vaccine is available against disease caused by serogroup B or X strains. A new protein-based, 4-component meningococcal serogroup B (4CMenB) vaccine has been developed that is hoped will be a broad-spectrum B vaccine (Cohn AC, Messonnier ME. Inching Toward a Serogroup B Meningococcal Vaccine for Infants. JAMA 2012;307(6):614-615.; and Stephens DS. Comment. Prevention of serogroup B meningococcal disease. Lancet 2012;379(9816):592-594).\n\nThe meningococcal protein conjugate polysaccharide vaccines induce a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved immune response in infants, provide long-lasting immunity, and prevent nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_, thus reducing transmission of this microorganism person-to-person (see http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf). A preventive strategy based on conjugate vaccines could have a significantly larger and more enduring impact on attempts to control the yearly recurrences of this disease in Africa that causes considerable morbidity and mortality, especially among children (see http://www.jidc.org/index.php/journal/article/view/19745499/102).\n\nBecause meningococcal vaccines will only protect against meningitis due to the meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups that the vaccine contains, laboratory confirmation of the serogroup causing an outbreak is important so that the appropriate vaccine is used. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1IeR.]", "summary": "\n\nBecause meningococcal vaccines will only protect against meningitis due to the meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups that the vaccine contains, laboratory confirmation of the serogroup causing an outbreak is important so that the appropriate vaccine is used. \n\nMeningitis outbreaks are detected as part of the enhanced meningitis surveillance system introduced in 2002, whereby participating countries collect and send weekly, district level data to the WHO African Regional Office Inter-Country support team of Ouagadougou, which compiles and disseminates this data through a weekly regional bulletin. The decrease in the number of cases of meningitis reported during the period under review is thought to be due to the progressive introduction of the newly developed meningococcal A conjugate vaccine in countries of the African meningitis belt since 2010. The introduction of this 1st meningococcal vaccine available for preventive purposes in Africa has enabled the immunization of over 100 million people from 10 countries [1] in the meningitis belt in the past 3 years (2010-2012). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Numerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the sub-Saharan African region known as the 'meningitis belt' each year during the hot, dry season, between December and June (http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx). From 1 Jan to 12 May 2013 (epidemiologic week 19), 9249 suspected cases of meningitis, including 857 deaths, with a case fatality ratio of 9.3 percent, have been reported from 18 of the 19 African countries under enhanced surveillance [Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ethiopia, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, South Sudan, Sudan and Togo] for meningitis. \n\nThe meningococcal protein conjugate polysaccharide vaccines induce a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved immune response in infants, provide long-lasting immunity, and prevent nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_, thus reducing transmission of this microorganism person-to-person (see http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf). \n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an attempt to induce herd immunity, whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the population has been vaccinated (see http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). \n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal disease have been confirmed in Guinea and South Sudan, where 404 suspected cases (38 deaths) and 196 suspected cases (13 deaths) have respectively been notified. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Burkina Faso (2010), Mali (2010-2011), Niger (2010-2011), Cameroon (2011-2012), Chad (2011-2012), Nigeria (2011-), Ghana (2012), Benin (2012), Senegal (2012), Sudan (2012-). MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA: WHO MENINGITIS REGION\n*********************************************************\n Given that large-scale epidemics in the African meningitis belt appear to occur in waves of 4 to 10 years, close surveillance for meningitis remains essential. Alexandria (VA): Infectious Disease Society of America; 1998), serogroup A is most commonly associated with meningitis in the African meningitis belt. \n\nAt least 13 serogroups of _Neisseria meningitidis_, based on polysaccharide capsular antigens, have been described: 5 serogroups (A, B, C, Y, and W-135) most commonly cause human disease. The ICG released 198 770 doses of meningococcal A conjugate vaccine to implement a reactive vaccination campaign from 15-24 May 2013, which was led by the Ministry of Health of South Sudan with the support of WHO and partners. A new protein-based, 4-component meningococcal serogroup B (4CMenB) vaccine has been developed that is hoped will be a broad-spectrum B vaccine (Cohn AC, Messonnier ME. \n\nCapsular polysaccharide or protein conjugate vaccines are available to immunize against disease caused by serogroups A, C, W-135, and", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-02-07 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-05-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "Guinea"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "VA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gambia", "country": "Gambia"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "Mali"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malakal County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1690719", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - South Sudan: (ML) fatal, sg A", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1690719", "date": "2013-05-04 10:02:40", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - SOUTH SUDAN: (MALAKAL) FATAL, SEROGROUP A\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 30 Apr 2013\nSource: All Africa [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201305010340.html\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health has declared an outbreak of meningitis in South Sudan's Upper Nile state, after the disease reportedly killed 2 people in its Malakal County.\n\nAt least 38 suspected cases, the ministry said in a release, have so far been recorded since the 1st patient was admitted in Malakal teaching hospital on 15 Apr 2013. The most affected patients, it added, are between the ages of 18 and 20 years.\n\n'The State Ministry of Health has so far collected 11 CSF [cerebrospinal fluid] samples; these were tested, and 8 of them tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A using latex agglutination testing (Pastorex rapid test),' says the release signed by Kariom Makur, the ministry's undersecretary.\n\nThe meningitis bacteria, according to the Health Ministry, are transmitted from one person to another through droplets of respiratory or throat secretions. The commonest symptoms of the disease are stiff neck, high fever, confusion, headaches, and vomiting, among others.\n\nThe ministry, in February last year [2012], declared the young nation, which lies in Africa's meningitis belt, free from the bacterial disease. Meanwhile, the health ministry said it had undertaken several activities to contain the disease outbreak. These included: reactivation of national and state epidemic task forces to coordinate the intervention response; heightening of surveillance at facility and community levels; enhancement of case management and laboratory capacity through training and deployment of technical officers from Juba [the capital of South Sudan]; the provision of drugs and laboratory supplies and their transport to Malakal; and planning with health partners to conduct a mass meningitis vaccination campaign targeting over 260 000 people living in Malakal county and surrounding payams [districts].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 2 May 2013\nSource: Voice of America News [edited]\nhttp://www.voanews.com/content/meningitis-kills-infects-dozens-south-sudan/1653653.html\n\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal meningitis has claimed 2 lives and infected dozens of people in Upper Nile State in South Sudan, health officials said on Thursday [2 May 2013], warning that the number of new cases was still rising.\n\n'In week 15, there were 3 cases; in week 16, there were 19, and this week there are already 16 cases,' Dr John Lagu, the director of emergency preparedness at the Ministry of Health, said, adding that 2 patients have died of the disease.\n\nMeningococcal meningitis is caused by bacteria that affect the brain and spinal cord. The infection causes high fever, confusion, headache, and vomiting. Untreated, the illness can kill in 24 to 48 hours. The disease is contagious and spreads particularly quickly among people in close contact. Avoiding contact with an infected person is not always easy because some people show no symptoms of the disease even when they are infected and also because of the difficulty of keeping people isolated, Lagu said.\n\n'Mass gatherings are discouraged but, of course, you cannot discourage them 100 per cent because people have to go on with their daily lives, to buy things,' he said. To try to prevent the disease spreading further, South Sudanese health authorities plan to conduct a vaccination campaign, focused on the area in and around Malakal.\n\nA meningitis vaccine that costs USD 0.50 cents a dose and can be transported and stored for as long as 4 days without refrigeration or an icepack is available in Africa and has already had a dramatic impact in fighting the disease in the parts of Burkina Faso and Chad where it has been administered.\n\nSouth Sudan lies in the meningitis belt of sub-Saharan Africa, which stretches from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia in the east, and has the highest rates of the disease in the world. In 2009, 14 African countries reported 5532 deaths from meningitis, the highest toll since an epidemic in 1996 claimed more than 10 000 lives.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[South Sudan is one of the countries in the African 'meningitis belt' that stretches from Senegal in West Africa to the Horn of Africa in the east. This region is plagued yearly by large epidemics of meningococcal meningitis (http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm). The meningitis outbreaks occur in the dry season (December to April) and end at the onset of the rainy season (from May to June). Larger outbreaks occur every 8-12 years (http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx). Attack rates during these cyclic epidemics of meningitis range from 100 to 800 per 100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates as high as 1000 per 100 000 (World Health Organization (WHO): Meningococcal meningitis fact sheet: http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/pdf/FactSheet-Meningitis.pdf).\n\nThere are at least 13 serogroups of _Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of meningococcal meningitis, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides; disease is most commonly due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135.\n\nThe serogroup most commonly associated with the African meningitis belt is A. However, outbreaks have also been caused by serogroups C (http://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/lab-manual/chpt02-epi.html), W135 (14760584.5.3.319' target='_blank' rel='noopener noreferrer'>http://www.expert-reviews.com/doi/abs/10.1586/ 14760584.5.3.319), and X (http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264410X13004751 ). In March 2012, a serogroup B outbreak occurred in Ethiopia (http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news/3581-ethiopia-suspected-meningitis-outbreak-situation-as-of-08-march-2012-.html). The 1st news report above says that the current outbreak in South Sudan is due to serogroup A.\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an attempt to induce herd immunity, whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the population has been vaccinated (see http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). While effective capsular polysaccharides-based vaccines exist against serogroups A, C, W135, and Y, no similar vaccine is available against disease caused by serogroup B or X strains. A new protein-based, 4-component meningococcal serogroup B (4CMenB) vaccine has been developed that is hoped will be a broad-spectrum B vaccine (Cohn AC, Messonnier ME. Inching Toward a Serogroup B Meningococcal Vaccine for Infants. JAMA 2012;307(6):614-615.; and Stephens DS. Comment. Prevention of serogroup B meningococcal disease. Lancet 2012;379(9816):592-594).\n\nBecause meningococcal vaccines will only protect against meningitis due to the meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups that the vaccine contains, laboratory confirmation of the serogroup causing an outbreak is important so that the appropriate vaccine is used.\n\nSouth Sudan became an independent country on 9 Jul 2011. Upper Nile is one of the 10 states of South Sudan and is located in the South Sudan's northeast corner. Malakal is the capital of Upper Nile. A map that shows the location of the Upper Nile State can be found at http://reliefinternational.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/ri-ss-upper-nile-program-locations1.jpg. A map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of this region is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1Ahu. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "[the capital of South Sudan]; the provision of drugs and laboratory supplies and their transport to Malakal; and planning with health partners to conduct a mass meningitis vaccination campaign targeting over 260 000 people living in Malakal county and surrounding payams [districts].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nBecause meningococcal vaccines will only protect against meningitis due to the meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups that the vaccine contains, laboratory confirmation of the serogroup causing an outbreak is important so that the appropriate vaccine is used. Attack rates during these cyclic epidemics of meningitis range from 100 to 800 per 100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates as high as 1000 per 100 000 (World Health Organization (WHO): Meningococcal meningitis fact sheet: http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/pdf/FactSheet-Meningitis.pdf). \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org> An outbreak of meningococcal meningitis has claimed 2 lives and infected dozens of people in Upper Nile State in South Sudan, health officials said on Thursday [2 May 2013], warning that the number of new cases was still rising. The 1st news report above says that the current outbreak in South Sudan is due to serogroup A.\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an attempt to induce herd immunity, whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the population has been vaccinated (see http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). \n\n'In week 15, there were 3 cases; in week 16, there were 19, and this week there are already 16 cases,' Dr John Lagu, the director of emergency preparedness at the Ministry of Health, said, adding that 2 patients have died of the disease. \n\nThere are at least 13 serogroups of _Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of meningococcal meningitis, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides; disease is most commonly due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135. \n\nA meningitis vaccine that costs USD 0.50 cents a dose and can be transported and stored for as long as 4 days without refrigeration or an icepack is available in Africa and has already had a dramatic impact in fighting the disease in the parts of Burkina Faso and Chad where it has been administered. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - SOUTH SUDAN: (MALAKAL) FATAL, SEROGROUP A\n*********************************************************************\n \n\nSouth Sudan lies in the meningitis belt of sub-Saharan Africa, which stretches from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia in the east, and has the highest rates of the disease in the world. http://allafrica.com/stories/201305010340.html\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health has declared an outbreak of meningitis in South Sudan's Upper Nile state, after the disease reportedly killed 2 people in its Malakal County. \n\n'The State Ministry of Health has so far collected 11 CSF [cerebrospinal fluid] samples; these were tested, and 8 of them tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A using latex agglutination testing (Pastorex rapid test),' says the release signed by Kariom Makur, the ministry's undersecretary. \n\nThe meningitis bacteria, according to the Health Ministry, are transmitted from one person to another through droplets of respiratory or throat secretions. \n\nMeningococcal meningitis is caused by bacteria that affect the brain and spinal cord. \n\nThe serogroup most commonly associated with the African meningitis belt is A.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-03-26 00:00:00", "1996-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-05-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "5532-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malakal county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "South Sudan 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malakal County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1844122", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Germany: (BE) fatal, MSM, vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1844122", "date": "2013-07-25 02:44:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - GERMANY: (BERLIN) FATAL, MEN WHO HAVE SEX WITH MEN, VACCINATION\n*******************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSource: Zeit Online [in German, machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.zeit.de/wissen/gesundheit/2013-07/meningokokken-homosexualitaet-berlin/komplettansicht?print=true\n\n\nDeath came quickly, as is typical for this disease. A few weeks ago, on 8 May [2013] the 2 young men had been out with friends in Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg and visited a gay club. Two days later, both felt sick. One suffered from nausea, vomiting, and a stiff neck. A little later, he was admitted to the hospital and remains in a coma. The other went to work; in the evening, he met friends, but he felt worse. Two days later, he died in his apartment. A bacterium called _Neisseria meningitidis_ was isolated from both men.\n\nMany people may carry these bacteria on the mucous membranes of nose and throat for months without becoming ill; the organism may then disappear. '20-30 per cent of young people in Germany may carry the pathogen,' said Wiebke Hellenbrand, of the Robert Koch Institute (RKI). What distinguishes the healthy carrier from the sick, nobody knows.\n\nHow the 2 Berliners were infected is unclear. Meningococci are transmitted by droplet [aerosol or secretions from the nasopharynx of colonized persons]. Humans can be infected by kissing or coughing. 'Maybe the 2 infected each other. Or maybe they were both infected by a 3rd party,' said Ulrich Marcus of RKI. The exact route of the pathogen cannot be reconstructed but has led to investigations that have uncovered additional cases and a call to vaccinate some 80 000 men who have sex with men in Berlin.\n\nDeaths caused by _N. meningitidis_ are not unusual. In Europe, the subgroups B and C are particularly responsible for causing illness, mostly in children and teenagers. In 2012, the Robert Koch Institute (RKI: the German national disease surveillance insitute) reported 300 ill, 33 of whom died.\n\n'This case was really only noticed because these 2 men were diagnosed within 24 hours, and it was clear that they had spent the night together,' said Hellenbrand. That sounds like an outbreak. Meningococcal infections tend to break out in places where people come together in a confined space: guests on a cruise ship, fans at a rugby game, kids at a carnival party.\n\nAnd another thing made the RKI experts take notice: the 2 men were gay, or, as the RKI epidemiologists called them, MSM (men who have sex with men). Epidemiologists are concerned with behavior, not sexual orientation. MSM includes gays, as well as bisexuals and male prostitutes.\n\nActually, gays are not considered particularly vulnerable to meningococcal disease, which affects men and women, homo- and heterosexuals alike. But doctors in Toronto in 2001 described a small outbreak of meningococcal disease among MSM: six people developed the disease, and 2 of them died. This was followed by outbreaks in Chicago and Los Angeles. But doctors were really attentive only when an outbreak in New York City last year [2012] afflicted 22 gays, 7 of whom died.\n\nAnd now Berlin: investigation revealed that a young gay man had come to the hospital in February [which year?] with meningococcal disease. He died 10 hours later in the operating room. Later in Berlin, 2 cases were yet to be identified, one died in October 2012, the other fell ill in February 2013 and survived.\n\nConcerns have been expressed by the European Centre for Disease Control (ECDC). On 3 Jul 2013, ECDC experts published a brief risk assessment. They concluded that in big cities in Europe, there is an increased risk that gay men are infected with meningococcus and warned that huge gay festivals, such as the Christopher Street Day in Berlin, might contribute to the dissemination of the pathogen. Countries should, therefore, be particularly vigilant for meningococcal cases.\n\nWhy gays in particular? Don Weiss of the health department in New York, who experienced the outbreak in his own city, wonders whether the pathogen has changed and adapted to the group of MSM. Could meningococci be colonizing the urethra of gay men and be transmitted during oral sex? Or has the pathogen adapted to the anal mucosa? 'We know that smoking is a risk factor, because it damages the lining of the airways and makes it easier for bacteria to enter the body,' says White [Weiss?]. 'The same could happen if the anal mucosa is irritated.' Then, anal intercourse would be a risk factor.\n\nAmanda Cohn of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta believes there is a simpler explanation: gays are a social group with close contacts and could, therefore, be affected like a school class. Many gay men have multiple sexual partners quickly, kiss in greeting, and go to crowded parties, which could magnify the problem. In one study, 43 per cent of gays carried the pathogen.\n\nThe question of whether a special strain of bacteria is circulating in the gay community must be examined in each case, says Ulrich Vogel from the National Reference Center for Meningococcal Disease at the University of Wurzburg. It would be possible to examine whether bacteria isolated from the Berlin patients grew better in intestinal mucosal cells or urethral cells than bacteria from other patients. Genetic sequencing of the Berlin strains is planned, and American and French researchers also want to sequence their samples. Perhaps a tiny change in the genetic material appears only in cases in MSM.\n\nMarlen Suckau of the Berlin Impfbeirat [vaccination advisory board] had wide ranging discussions to decide whether the situation was disturbing enough for them to issue a recommendation for vaccination. In essence, vaccination would be recommended if a regional cluster were identified. For meningococcal disease, that means 10 cases per 100 000 people in one year. The group of MSM in Berlin is estimated at 80 000, and 5 cases in 10 months is significantly below the threshold. On the other hand, France had already issued a recommendation for vaccination and gays were vaccinated in New York and Chicago.\n\nIn the end, the Impfbeirat noted that the cases were all aged 20 to 29 years, says Suckau. In this age group, there are an estimated 18 000 MSM in Berlin. Thus, the threshold was exceeded in this group.\n\nThe recommendation is still valid for all MSM. 'It's easier to communicate, and you cannot send away a 19 year old from a doctor's office,' says Suckau. The recommendation was published in the Official Journal. On Sat 27 Jul 2013, it will come into force. For 6 months, gays will be eligible for vaccination in Berlin.\n\n'This is a unique vaccine that is well tolerated,' says Suckau, who wonders how high uptake will be. Germans have a hard time with vaccination -- for example, debating measles vaccination. Against the swine flu virus H1N1, only 5 per cent in Berlin were vaccinated, says Suckau. 'So 20 per cent uptake for meningococcal vaccine would be a great success.'\n\n[byline: Kai Kupferschmidt]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 18 Jul 2013\nSource: Berlin.de/The Official Capital City Portal [in German, machine trans. edited]\n20130718.1630.387129.html' target='_blank' rel='noopener noreferrer'>http://www.berlin.de/sen/gessoz/presse/archiv/ 20130718.1630.387129.html\n\n\nThe Berlin Impfbeirat on 17 Jul 2013 has recommended an extension of public vaccination in Berlin, according to which men who have sex with men (MSM) should be vaccinated against meningococcal disease. The scheme is expected to start on 27 Jul 2013. The reason for the extended vaccination recommendation is an increased incidence of meningococcal disease among MSM in Berlin.\n\nOf the total of 18 [cases of] meningococcal disease in Berlin in 2013, 7 were caused by group C _Neisseria meningitidis_. Of the latter, 3 patients died, and a 4th remains ill. These 4 patients are MSM and recent disease outbreaks among MSM have occurred in New York and Paris.\n\nMeningococcal bacteria are found in the nasopharyngeal cavity in humans and can be transmitted by kissing, for example, or coughing. About 10 per cent of the population carry the bacteria without necessarily being ill. It is assumed that about 40 per cent of MSM are carriers of the bacteria and thus may be at higher risk of disease. The disease is taken very seriously, as it may be associated with serious complications and permanent damage. 2/3rds of affected patients suffer meningitis, and 1/3rd a life-threatening bloodstream infection (sepsis). In 10-20 per cent of cases, there are permanent sequelae. The mortality rate of group C meningococcal disease is as high as 10 per cent.\n\nThe only effective way to prevent meningococcal disease is vaccination. According to the recommendation of the Standing Committee on Vaccination at the Robert Koch Institute (STIKO), all children up to the age of 18 years should receive a single dose of vaccine against group C meningococcal infection. In adults, the STIKO recommends vaccination for certain people with immune deficiencies, such as those who are HIV positive, or for travelers to certain countries. The STIKO has not issued any recommendation for vaccination for MSM, but this gap is now closed due to the current events. The vaccine used for the current outbreak in MSM must contain a meningococcal group C component and be approved for adults. The vaccine is very well tolerated in general.\n\nThe recommendation for vaccination is planned to expire on 31 Jan 2014, and its effectiveness will be reviewed after this period. At the same time, the state of Berlin is committed to ensuring that the issues of vaccination for MSM by STIKO be uniform and thus cleared for other states.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is extracted in part from moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (New York City) fatal, MSM, alert 20130308.1576590:\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of invasive meningococcal disease (meningitis and sepsis), is transmitted from person to person via droplets of respiratory secretions, mostly from asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers of the microorganism. It is estimated that between 10 to 25 per cent of the population carry _N. meningitidis_ at any given time, and the carriage rate may be much higher in epidemic situations. Close and prolonged contact (such as kissing, sneezing, and coughing on someone), living in close quarters or dormitories (military recruits, students), sharing eating or drinking utensils, etc. facilitates the spread of the disease. The average incubation period for meningococcal meningitis is 4 days, ranging between 2 and 10 days (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). Invasive meningococcal disease carries a high mortality rate if untreated. Even with early and appropriate treatment, patients can die within 24-48 hours.\n\nAt least 13 serogroups, based on polysaccharide capsular antigens, have been described: 5 serogroups (A, B, C, Y, and W-135) most commonly cause human disease. Molecular epidemiology has revealed that most cases of invasive meningococcal disease are caused by only a few hypervirulent clonal lineages, whereas the genetic diversity is higher in meningococci recovered from healthy carriers (Claus H, Weinand H, Frosch M, Vogel U. Identification of the hypervirulent lineages of _Neisseria meningitidis_, the ST-8 and ST-11 complexes, by using monoclonal antibodies specific to NmeDI. J Clin Microbiol. 2003; 41(8): 3873-6; available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC179822/).\n\nHowever, less virulent strains have been reported to cause invasive meningococcal disease in immunocompromised HIV infected patients (Ferreira de Andrade C, Cotrim da Cunha D, Cavalcanti V, de Filippis I. Fatal meningococcal meningitis in a HIV-infected patient caused by serogroup C _Neisseria meningitidis_ belonging to the non-hypervirulent clonal complex ST-60 (cc60). Braz J Infect Dis. 2011; 15(2): 178-80, available at http://dx.doi.org/10.1590/S1413-86702011000200017).\n\nSince 2010, there have been 22 cases due to serogroup C in New York City among MSM (http://eziz.org/assets/docs/cdphmemo_2012_12_MeningitisAdvisoryMSM.pdf); this serogroup accounts for most US outbreaks (Woods CW, Rosenstein NE, Perkins BA. _Neisseria meningitidis_ outbreaks in the United States 1994-1997 (abstract). In: Proceedings of Annual Meeting of IDSA. 12-15 Nov 1998. Denver, Colorado. Alexandria (VA): Infectious Disease Society of America; 1998).\n\nAccording to the 2nd news report above, there have been 18 cases in Berlin in 2013, 7 of which were due to serogroup C, but only 4 of the 18 cases were MSM, all of whom were infected with serogroup C organisms. The 3 deaths in Berlin were among MSM. Genotyping the Berlin and New York City serogroup C isolates would enable us to see if the same strain has spread to Europe.\n\nWe are not told whether any of the 4 infected MSM were co-infected with HIV and whether their CD4 counts were low. Severely immunosuppressed patients with HIV infection and a low CD4 cell count of less than or equal to 200/mm3 are likely to be at greater risk of developing invasive meningococcal disease (Domingo P, Suarez-Lozano I, Torres F, et al. Bacterial meningitis in HIV-1-infected patients in the era of highly active antiretroviral therapy. J Acquir Immune Defic Syndr. 2009; 51(5): 582-7; available at http://www.researchgate.net/publication/26279285_Bacterial_meningitis_in_HIV-1-infected_patients_in_the_era_of_highly_active_antiretroviral_therapy).\n\nThe primary method for preventing sporadic meningococcal disease is chemoprophylaxis with antibiotics, such as rifampin, ciprofloxacin, or ceftriaxone for persons who are known to be close contacts after a case is identified. Close contacts of patients are considered to be household members, day-care center contacts, and other persons directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions. Administering chemoprophylaxis to persons who are not close contacts of patients usually is not recommended. Neither oropharyngeal nor nasopharyngeal cultures for _N. meningitidis_ are useful for deciding who should receive chemoprophylaxis.\n\nHowever, in the face of multiple anonymous sexual encounters among some MSM, a mass vaccination campaign is being used to control this outbreak as detailed in the news releases above. The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) has released recommendations for the use of meningococcal vaccine to control outbreaks of serogroup C meningococcal disease (CDC. Control and prevention of serogroup C meningococcal disease: evaluation and management of suspected outbreaks: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). MMWR Recomm Rep. 1997; 46(RR-5): 13-21; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm).\n\nBerlin, located in north eastern Germany, with a population of 3.3 million people, is the capital of Germany and one of its 16 states; it is Germany's largest city and the 2nd most populous city in the European Union (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin). The city has a long history of gay culture and a large number of gay clubs and festivals (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#Gay_life). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJl.]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is extracted in part from moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (New York City) fatal, MSM, alert 20130308.1576590:\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of invasive meningococcal disease (meningitis and sepsis), is transmitted from person to person via droplets of respiratory secretions, mostly from asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers of the microorganism. However, less virulent strains have been reported to cause invasive meningococcal disease in immunocompromised HIV infected patients (Ferreira de Andrade C, Cotrim da Cunha D, Cavalcanti V, de Filippis I. Fatal meningococcal meningitis in a HIV-infected patient caused by serogroup C _Neisseria meningitidis_ belonging to the non-hypervirulent clonal complex ST-60 (cc60). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n[byline: Kai Kupferschmidt]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe question of whether a special strain of bacteria is circulating in the gay community must be examined in each case, says Ulrich Vogel from the National Reference Center for Meningococcal Disease at the University of Wurzburg. \n\nActually, gays are not considered particularly vulnerable to meningococcal disease, which affects men and women, homo- and heterosexuals alike. The Berlin Impfbeirat on 17 Jul 2013 has recommended an extension of public vaccination in Berlin, according to which men who have sex with men (MSM) should be vaccinated against meningococcal disease. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - GERMANY: (BERLIN) FATAL, MEN WHO HAVE SEX WITH MEN, VACCINATION\n*******************************************************************************************\n \n\nThe primary method for preventing sporadic meningococcal disease is chemoprophylaxis with antibiotics, such as rifampin, ciprofloxacin, or ceftriaxone for persons who are known to be close contacts after a case is identified. Molecular epidemiology has revealed that most cases of invasive meningococcal disease are caused by only a few hypervirulent clonal lineages, whereas the genetic diversity is higher in meningococci recovered from healthy carriers (Claus H, Weinand H, Frosch M, Vogel U. Identification of the hypervirulent lineages of _Neisseria meningitidis_, the ST-8 and ST-11 complexes, by using monoclonal antibodies specific to NmeDI. But doctors in Toronto in 2001 described a small outbreak of meningococcal disease among MSM: six people developed the disease, and 2 of them died. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) has released recommendations for the use of meningococcal vaccine to control outbreaks of serogroup C meningococcal disease (CDC. [cases of] meningococcal disease in Berlin in 2013, 7 were caused by group C _Neisseria meningitidis_. According to the 2nd news report above, there have been 18 cases in Berlin in 2013, 7 of which were due to serogroup C, but only 4 of the 18 cases were MSM, all of whom were infected with serogroup C organisms. For meningococcal disease, that means 10 cases per 100 000 people in one year. Severely immunosuppressed patients with HIV infection and a low CD4 cell count of less than or equal to 200/mm3 are likely to be at greater risk of developing invasive meningococcal disease (Domingo P, Suarez-Lozano I, Torres F, et al. \n\nMeningococcal bacteria are found in the nasopharyngeal cavity in humans and can be transmitted by kissing, for example, or coughing. The mortality rate of group C meningococcal disease is as high as 10 per cent. According to the recommendation of the Standing Committee on Vaccination at the Robert Koch Institute (STIKO), all children up to the age of 18 years should receive a single dose of vaccine against group C meningococcal infection. \n\nAt least 13 serogroups, based on polysaccharide capsular antigens, have been described: 5 serogroups (A, B, C, Y, and W-135) most commonly cause human disease. The reason for the extended vaccination recommendation is an increased incidence of meningococcal disease among MSM in Berlin. And now Berlin: investigation revealed that a young gay man had come to the hospital in February [which year?] with meningococcal disease. \n\n'This case was really only noticed because these 2 men were diagnosed within 24 hours, and it was clear that they had spent the night together,' said Hellenbrand. Control and prevention of serogroup C meningococcal disease: evaluation and management of suspected outbreaks: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). And another thing made the RKI experts take notice: the 2 men were gay, or, as the RKI epidemiologists called them, MSM (men who have sex with men). They concluded that in big cities in Europe, there is an increased risk that gay men are infected with meningococcus and warned that huge gay festivals, such as the Christopher Street Day in Berlin, might contribute to the dissemination of the pathogen. The only effective way to prevent meningococcal disease is vaccination. \n\nMany people may carry these bacteria on the mucous membranes of nose and throat for months without becoming ill; the organism may then disappear. The average incubation period for meningococcal meningitis is 4 days, ranging between 2 and 10 days (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). The exact route of the pathogen cannot be reconstructed but has led to investigations that have uncovered additional cases and a call to vaccinate some 80 000 men who have sex with men in Berlin. \n\nWe are not told whether any of the 4 infected MSM were co-infected with HIV and whether their CD4 counts were low. \n\nBerlin, located in north eastern Germany, with a population of 3.3 million people, is the capital of Germany and one of its 16 states; it is Germany's largest city and the 2nd most populous city in the European Union (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin). \n\nIn the end, the Impfbeirat noted that the cases were all aged 20 to 29 years, says Suckau. Since 2010, there have been 22 cases due to serogroup C in New York City among MSM (http://eziz.org/assets/docs/cdphmemo_2012_12_MeningitisAdvisoryMSM.pdf); this serogroup accounts for most US outbreaks (Woods CW, Rosenstein NE, Perkins BA. _Neisseria meningitidis_ outbreaks in the United States 1994-1997 (abstract). Amanda Cohn of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta believes there is a simpler explanation: gays are a social group with close contacts and could, therefore, be affected like a school class. Invasive meningococcal disease carries a high mortality rate if untreated. \n\nConcerns have been expressed by the European Centre for Disease Control (ECDC). \n\n'This is a unique vaccine that is well tolerated,' says Suckau, who wonders how high uptake will be. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n It is assumed that about 40 per cent of MSM are carriers of the bacteria and thus may be at higher risk of disease. Close and prolonged contact (such as kissing, sneezing, and coughing on someone), living in close quarters or dormitories (military recruits, students), sharing eating or drinking utensils, etc. facilitates the spread of the disease. Neither oropharyngeal nor nasopharyngeal cultures for _N. meningitidis_ are useful for deciding who should receive chemoprophylaxis.\n\n \n\nHow the 2 Berliners were infected is unclear. Later in Berlin, 2 cases were yet to be identified, one died in October 2012, the other fell ill in February 2013 and survived.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-02-26 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-07-27 00:00:00", "2012-10-26 00:00:00", "2013-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-05-08 00:00:00", "2014-01-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chicago", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Berlin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hellenbrand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Friedrichshain - Kreuzberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1687659", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Russia: (SV,IK) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1687659", "date": "2013-05-02 17:02:49", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - RUSSIA: (SVERDLOVSK, IRKUTSK), FATAL\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n\n[1] Sverdlovsk\n[2] Irkutsk\n\n******\n[1] Sverdlovsk\nDate: Tue 23 Apr 2013\nSource: Rossiyskaya Gazeta [in Russian, trans. Mod.NP, edited]\nhttp://www.rg.ru/2013/04/23/reg-urfo/meningit-anons.html\n\n\nThe investigative department of the Russian Federation in Sverdlovsk region initiated an investigation in connection with the death of a 7 year old boy from meningococcal infection. In the early morning of 17 Apr 2013, a child with a high temperature was admitted to the hospital in Pervouralsk; however, the attempts to save him failed.\n\nThe investigation determined that on 16 Apr 2013, the boy as usual came back from the kindergarten home at 1700, but in the morning of 17 Apr 2013, his temperature was very high. His mother called an ambulance, which rapidly brought the child to the infectious diseases unit of the city hospital for emergency medical assistance, but the child died. The medical examiner determined that the cause of death of the preschooler was meningococcal infection.\n\nAt present, an investigation has been initiated to establish all the circumstances of the accident. Medical workers of the hospital and ambulance staff, as well as relatives of the dead boy, were interviewed.\n\nAlexander Shulga, the official representative of emergency situations of The Russian Federation for Sverdlovsk Region said that a court of inquiry is scheduled to establish the exact cause of death. After the results of the autopsy, the investigation will be finished, and a decision will be made.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pervouralsk, with a population of 124 528 (2010 census), is a city in the Sverdlovsk Oblast located 24 miles (39 km) west of Yekaterinburg, the administrative center of Sverlovsk Oblast (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pervouralsk). Sverdlovsk Oblast is located mostly on the eastern slopes of the Middle and North Urals and the Western Siberian Plain, in the Urals Federal District. - Mod.ML\n\nThis is the 5th ProMED-RUS posting of meningococcal disease in less than 4 months in Russia. A rise in the incidence of this disease has been noted in several regions: in the Penza region, 11 cases were diagnosed in 2 months (an increase of 56 per cent compared with the previous year); in the Nizhny Novgorod region, 5 cases were diagnosed in 3 months; an increase in numbers of cases has also been observed in the Yaroslavl region and in the Perm region - Mod.NP]\n\n******\n[2] Irkutsk\nDate: Wed 24 Apr 2013\nSource: Interfax [in Russian, trans. Mod.NP, edited]\nhttp://www.interfax-russia.ru/Siberia/news.asp?id=397398 &sec=1672\n\n\nA fatal case of meningococcal infection in a 15 year old schoolgirl was reported in Angarsk in the Irkutsk region on Wednesday [24 Apr 2013] by the press service of the city administration.\n\n'The girl fell ill on 18 Apr 2013. Her symptoms were consistent with acute respiratory infection: she had a temperature of 37 C [98.6 F] and a headache. The parents of the girl sought medical assistance on Sun 21 Apr 2013 when she developed a rash and her temperature had risen to 39 C [102.2],' according to the press service. The girl was placed in the intensive care unit, but attempts to save her failed. The press service said: 'The disease developed fast and led to death.'\n\nAt the present time, countermeasures have been taken in the girl's home and at her school. In her classroom, a quarantine was introduced. Tests were done on her contacts among classmates, teachers, and relatives. The test results will be known at the beginning of next week.\n\n'Symptoms of the disease in her close contacts have not been observed,' says the press-service. In 2012, one lethal case [of meningococcal disease] was reported.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Angarsk, with a population of 233 567 (2010 census), is a city in Irkutsk Oblast, Russia located 3200 miles (5150 km) east of Moscow (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angarsk). Irkutsk Oblast is located in southeastern Siberia. - Mod.ML\n\nCases of meningococcal infection are registered annually in the Irkutsk region. In 2012, 20 cases of this disease were registered in the region. - Corr.BA\n\nAlthough not mentioned in the above news report, antibiotics are recommended to prevent secondary infection in close contacts of patients with invasive meningococcal disease. These at-risk contacts include household members, roommates, attendees at the same child care center, or anyone directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions through close social contact during the 7 days before onset of disease in the index case, such as through kissing, mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, or endotracheal intubation.\n\nBecause the risk for illness in contacts is highest during the 1st few days after infection, chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible (ideally within 24 hours) after contact with an index case-patient. Chemoprophylaxis administered after 14 days is probably of limited or no value (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/rr/rr4605.pdf). Antibiotics that effectively eliminate nasopharyngeal carriage of _Neisseria meningitidis_ include rifampin, ciprofloxacin, ceftriaxone, and azithromycin, and these drugs are appropriate for chemoprophylaxis. In areas of the United States where ciprofloxacin-resistant strains of _N. meningitidis_ have been detected, ciprofloxacin should not be used for chemoprophylaxis (http://www.cdc.gov/MMWR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm and http://www.unboundmedicine.com/redbook/ub/view/RedBook/187078/7/meningococcal_vaccine_for).\n\nWe are not told in the 2nd news report above what tests are being done on the index patient's close contacts. However, close contacts of patients with invasive meningococcal disease are at high risk and should receive chemoprophylaxis. For example, the attack rate for household contacts is 500 to 800 times the rate for the general population. The decision to give chemoprophylaxis to contacts of people with meningococcal disease is based on risk of contracting invasive disease. Neither oropharyngeal nor nasopharyngeal cultures for _N. meningitidis_ are useful in deciding who should receive chemoprophylaxis (http://www.unboundmedicine.com/redbook/ub/view/RedBook/187078/7/meningococcal_vaccine_for and CDC. Control and prevention of meningococcal disease and Control and prevention of serogroup C meningococcal disease: evaluation and management of suspected outbreaks: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). MMWR 1997;46(No. RR-5. Available at: http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm).\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Russia is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=499068&v=57,50,4. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Angarsk, with a population of 233 567 (2010 census), is a city in Irkutsk Oblast, Russia located 3200 miles (5150 km) east of Moscow (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angarsk). A fatal case of meningococcal infection in a 15 year old schoolgirl was reported in Angarsk in the Irkutsk region on Wednesday [24 Apr 2013] by the press service of the city administration. The decision to give chemoprophylaxis to contacts of people with meningococcal disease is based on risk of contracting invasive disease. \n\nThe investigation determined that on 16 Apr 2013, the boy as usual came back from the kindergarten home at 1700, but in the morning of 17 Apr 2013, his temperature was very high. \n\n'Symptoms of the disease in her close contacts have not been observed,' says the press-service.
