According to Dr. Zenati Ahmed, the director of health in the city of Blida, the cases of meningitis have been reported in patients who sought treatment at the clinic.\n\nBased on health records, the 1st patient came in on 6 Dec 2012, although the alert was issued on 24 Dec 2012 following the diagnosis of additional cases. The patients were then transferred to a hospital in the town of Boufarik. Since then, 2 patients died including a 57-year-old woman and a 27-year-old man. Ahmed said that an investigation is ongoing to determine the cause of the outbreak or potential contamination in the clinic. He added that the investigation was initiated by the specialized services of the Ministry of Health, Population and Hospital Reform, aside from investigations by other relevant authorities.\n\nIt is worth mentioning that this is not the 1st time that health authorities are shutting down a private clinic due to a possible disease outbreak. In 2008, the clinic Rosiers Blida was also closed down.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above does not indicate the microbial etiology in the 13 meningitis cases in the Algerian town of Chiffa. Algeria is not one of the countries in the African meningitis belt. The African meningitis belt, which is plagued yearly by large epidemics of meningococcal meningitis, lies in the sub-Saharan region of Africa (http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm).\n\nThe news report above also does not clearly state if the 13 cases were admitted with meningitis that was acquired in the community or were admitted to the hospital for some other diagnosis and acquired meningitis only after admission to the hospital. From the news article, there seems to be some implication of 'potential contamination in the clinic' that prompted closure of the clinic as a 'preventive' measure. (See ProMed-mail posts of the nosocomial fungal meningitis outbreak in the United States this past year.) The institute has asked that all labs deliver samples of the outbreak to them as quickly as possible in order to protect biosafety.\n\n'Nowadays, we are not in an epidemic,' assured Velenzuela. She explained that the cases have been appearing sporadically, and that there is only a danger of an epidemic when, 'there are 3 cases of the same strain in a similar area within 3 months.'\n\nBoth private and public laboratories have been notified of the importance of delivering samples of the meningitis strains as quickly as possible.\n\nTo date, 75 percent of the meningitis cases in Valparaiso are [due to _Neisseria meningitidis_serogroup B]. [Whereas,] in the Region Metropolitana area, 80 percent of meningitis cases are [due to _N. meningitidis_serogroup] W135. Many of these cases have, for the most part, been in children between the ages of 9 months and 4 years.\n\nCurrently there is no up-to-date vaccination for meningitis [due to _N. meningitidis_ serogroup B]. However, meningitis [due to _N. meningitidis_ serogroup B] only has a 10 percent mortality rate, while [that due to] W135 has a 20 percent mortality rate. Symptoms for both strains include high fever, headaches, vomiting, light-headedness, and severe confusion.\n\nFor more information on where to get vaccinated for meningococcal meningitis W135 visit the Institute of Public Health website for Chile.\n\n[Byline: Casey Pechan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the news report above, there has been an increase of 15 cases of meningococcal meningitis (83 to now 98 cases) compared to data in the last report posted by ProMED-mail on 17 Oct 2012 (Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (02): (VS, RM) update 20121017.1348918). The outbreak is centered mainly in 2 Chilean regions: the Metropolitan Region (RM), which includes Santiago, and the region of Valparaiso. Serogroup W135 predominates in the Metropolitan Region and serogroup B predominates in Valparaiso.\n\nA map of Chile's regions can be seen at http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/chilfung/chile_regions.gif. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1Aht.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the news report above, there has been an increase of 15 cases of meningococcal meningitis (83 to now 98 cases) compared to data in the last report posted by ProMED-mail on 17 Oct 2012 (Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (02): (VS, RM) update 20121017.1348918). Despite the discovery of 98 new cases of meningitis in Chile, the Institute of Public Health assures citizens that the infection has not reached epidemic levels.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Valparaiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "RM", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1467561", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Russia: (PR) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1467561", "date": "2012-12-24 13:30:15", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - RUSSIA: (PRIMORSKY), FATAL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Dec 2012\nSource: AIF Argumenty i Fakty [in Russian, trans. Corr.BA, edited]\nhttp://www.vl.aif.ru/health/news/51673\n\n\nA 2-year-old girl has died of meningococcal disease in Arsenyev. The kindergarten that the child was attending has been temporarily closed for quarantine.\n\nThe diagnosis of meningitis was confirmed on 10 Dec 2012. The child was admitted to a children's hospital, but the infection developed rapidly, and the girl could not be saved, said the press service of the city hall. All children and adults who have been in contact with the child have been vaccinated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As reported by Arsenyev City Hospital, cases of meningitis are recorded each year. In 2000, a one-year-old child died after severe meningococcal disease. With regards to the current case, a nursery in the kindergarten has been temporarily closed. Medical observation has been organized for children of the nursery group. - Corr.BA]\n\n[Although not mentioned in the above news report, antibiotics are recommended to prevent secondary infection in close contacts of patients with invasive meningococcal disease. These at-risk contacts include household members, roommates, attendees at the same child-care center, or anyone directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions through close social contact during the 7 days before onset of disease in the index case, such as through kissing, mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, or endotracheal intubation. Risk is also high in travelers who have prolonged contact with local populations in the Africa meningitis belt during an epidemic. The Hajj pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia has also been associated with outbreaks of meningococcal disease in returning pilgrims and their contacts.\n\nBecause the risk for illness in contacts is highest during the 1st few days after infection, chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible (ideally within 24 hours) after contact with an index case-patient. Chemoprophylaxis administered after 14 days is probably of limited or no value. Antibiotics that effectively eliminate nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ include rifampin, ciprofloxacin, ceftriaxone, and azithromycin, and these drugs are appropriate for chemoprophylaxis. In areas of the United States where ciprofloxacin-resistant strains of _N. meningitidis_ have been detected, ciprofloxacin should not be used for chemoprophylaxis (http://www.cdc.gov/MMWR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm and http://www.unboundmedicine.com/redbook/ub/view/RedBook/187078/7/meningococcal_vaccine_for).\n\nPrimorsky, also known as Primorye, is a federal subject of Russia (a krai) with a population of 1 956 497 (2010 census) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primorsky_Krai). Primorsky means 'maritime' in Russian, hence the region is sometimes referred to as Maritime Province or Maritime Territory. Its administrative center is in the city of Vladivostok. Arsenyev is a town with a population of 56 742 (2010 census) in Primorsky Krai, located about 250 km (160 miles) northeast of Vladivostok. A map of Russia showing the location of Primorsky is available at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Primorsky_in_Russia.svg.\n\nA HealthMap/ ProMED-mail interactive map of Russia is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=499068&v=57,50,4. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n These at-risk contacts include household members, roommates, attendees at the same child-care center, or anyone directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions through close social contact during the 7 days before onset of disease in the index case, such as through kissing, mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, or endotracheal intubation. Because the risk for illness in contacts is highest during the 1st few days after infection, chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible (ideally within 24 hours) after contact with an index case-patient. BA]\n\n[Although not mentioned in the above news report, antibiotics are recommended to prevent secondary infection in close contacts of patients with invasive meningococcal disease. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://noticias.terra.cl/gobierno-decreta-alerta-sanitaria-por-meningitis,e9077a526d90b310VgnVCM3000009acceb0aRCRD.html\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health has issued a 'health alert' to address the cases of meningitis, which this year [2012] have exceeded estimates by experts and authorities.\n\nIn his daily report on the situation of meningitis in the country, the undersecretary of public health indicated that the health alert was published today [16 Nov 2012] in the Official Journal, facilitating the necessary actions for vaccination, such as obtaining financial resources and streamlining procurement processes, among others.\n\nRegarding the surveillance of cases, Diaz said that no new cases of infection with [_Neisseria meningitidis_] serogroup W135 had been reported. The cumulative number of people afflicted with this variant of the disease is 46, 37 of which are in the [Santiago] Metropolitan Region.\n\nAs for the prevention plan in the Metropolitan Region, the [health] authority said they have vaccinated 68 027 minors, corresponding to 17 per cent of the target population to be immunized in the 8 districts in which the campaign is being implemented to date.\n\nRegarding the lack of vaccines in some clinics and preschool education centers in the Metropolitan Region, the health authority said that the doses needed are available and that it has instructed municipalities to redistribute the vaccines from the overstocked centers to those that are understocked.\n\nJorge Diaz said they are investigating a possible case of adverse reaction to the vaccine yesterday in a girl who today shows no complications. He also reported that more than 200 000 doses of vaccine will arrive Saturday morning [17 Nov 2012] via the Santiago international airport, which will allow for vaccination in all communes of the Metropolitan Region.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the most recent news report posted by ProMED-mail (Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (03): (VS, RM) update 20121110.1403844), there were a total of 98 cases of meningococcal meningitis. The outbreak is centered mainly in 2 Chilean regions: the Metropolitan Region (RM), which includes Santiago, and the region of Valparaiso. _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup W135 predominates in the Metropolitan Region, where the vaccination program is ongoing; and serogroup B predominates in Valparaiso.\n\nWhile effective capsular polysaccharides-based vaccines exist against serogroups A, C, W135, and Y, no similar vaccine is available against disease caused by serogroup B strains. The serogroup B capsular polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic presumably because serogroup B polysaccharide resembles the human neural cell adhesion molecule. A new protein-based, 4-component meningococcal serogroup B (4CMenB) vaccine has been developed that is hoped will be a broad-spectrum B vaccine (Cohn AC, Messonnier ME. Inching Toward a Serogroup B Meningococcal Vaccine for Infants. JAMA 2012;307(6):614-615.; and Stephens DS. Comment. Prevention of serogroup B meningococcal disease. Lancet 2012;379(9816):592-594).\n\nA map of Chile's regions can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/chile-administrative-map.jpg. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1Aht.]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the most recent news report posted by ProMED-mail (Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (03): (VS, RM) update 20121110.1403844), there were a total of 98 cases of meningococcal meningitis. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nWhile effective capsular polysaccharides-based vaccines exist against serogroups A, C, W135, and Y, no similar vaccine is available against disease caused by serogroup B strains. \n\nIn his daily report on the situation of meningitis in the country, the undersecretary of public health indicated that the health alert was published today Regarding the lack of vaccines in some clinics and preschool education centers in the Metropolitan Region, the health authority said that the doses needed are available and that it has instructed municipalities to redistribute the vaccines from the overstocked centers to those that are understocked. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CHILE (04): (SANTIAGO METROPOLITAN REGION)\n**********************************************************************\n A new protein-based, 4-component meningococcal serogroup B (4CMenB) vaccine has been developed that is hoped will be a broad-spectrum B vaccine (Cohn AC, Messonnier ME. \n\n\nThe Ministry of Health has issued a 'health alert' to address the cases of meningitis, which this year [2012] have exceeded estimates by experts and authorities. The serogroup B capsular polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic presumably because serogroup B polysaccharide resembles the human neural cell adhesion molecule. As for the prevention plan in the Metropolitan Region, the [health] authority said they have vaccinated 68 027 minors, corresponding to 17 per cent of the target population to be immunized in the 8 districts in which the campaign is being implemented to date.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2046-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Valparaiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "RM", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1346329", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile: (VS, RM) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1346329", "date": "2012-10-16 13:44:12", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CHILE: (VALPARAISO, SANTIAGO METROPOLITAN REGION) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sun 14 Oct 2012\nSource: Cooperativa.cl [in Spanish, trans. Mod.MPP, edited]\nhttp://www.cooperativa.cl/noticias/pais/salud/vacunacion/confusam-gobierno-reacciono-tarde-por-meningitis/2012-10-14/141843.html\n\n\nThe National Confederation of Municipal Health Officials (CONFUSAM) accused the Government of a delayed response and negligence when facing the recent increase in cases of meningitis in Chile.\n\nBetween January and October 2012, 87 cases of [meningococcal] meningitis type W135 have already been confirmed, while in all of 2011 there were only 73 cases reported.\n\nFor Esteban Maturana, leader of the organization [CONFUSAM], the negligence lies in 'the existing controls of the Ministry of Health,' specifically the 'surveillance system which verifies the number of cases, and this system has alerts which signal when there is a health problem.'\n\nThe Government recently announced a round of vaccines that will arrive in the country on Monday morning [15 Oct 2012], and [vaccination] will be focused on children less than 4 years of age, the population most vulnerable for this disease.\n\nFor the senator of the PPD [Partido por la Democracia/Party for Democracy], Guido Girardi, the announcement by the government is important, even if it was late, and he urged authorities to also include an educational campaign. 'Better late than never, always. I think the important thing is to begin with a public health action, as has already been announced, [the need for vaccination], but I hope that vaccination [activities] are accompanied by an educational campaign, which I think is as important as the vaccine,' he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Guido Girardi Lavin is a Chilean physician and politician. He is currently serving the period between 2006 and 2014 as senator for district No. 7 for Santiago Poniente (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guido_Girardi). He is also serving as the current president of that chamber. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 25 Sep 2012\nSource: Nacion.cl [in Spanish, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://www.lanacion.cl/minsal-alerta-a-red-hospitalaria-por-agresiva-cepa-que-produce-meningitis/noticias/2012-09-25/140206.html\n\n\nA total of 73 cases of meningitis have been recorded so far this year [2012] in Chile, a figure that exceeds the notifications for the same period of 2011 (46 cases). The health authority is keeping under surveillance serogroup W135, which has been detected in 42 percent of cases from January [2012] to date. Children under 4 years of age are the most affected group and accounted for 45 percent of all reported cases; children between 5 and 9 years of age accounted for 7 percent; and 45 percent of the cases occurred in people over 20 years of age. 17 cases occurred in children under one year (23 percent), who had the highest incidence rate of 6.7 cases per 100 000 children.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological report of the Ministry of Health (Minsal), the Region of Valparaiso has the highest incidence rate (0.9 per 100 000 population), followed by the [Santiago] Metropolitan Region. No epidemiological link between the most affected areas has been identified.\n\nThere have been 14 deaths (CFR 19 percent) reported this year [2012], higher than expected; 5 of the deaths were due to W135; 1 due to B; 1 due to C, and 3 unidentified.\n\nBy this time of year, there are usually between 56 and 60 cases. The Health Secretary, Jorge Diaz, said that the increase in reported cases this year 'is small and does not constitute an outbreak.'\n\n[Byline: Patricia Schuller G]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the news reports above, there are discrepancies in the number of cases and the meningococcal serogroups that are causing meningococcal meningitis in Chile. A clarification would be appreciated.\n\nThere are 5 common meningococcal serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides: A, B, C, W135, and Y, and a 6th type (X) has recently emerged in Africa. Capsular polysaccharide or protein conjugate vaccines can immunize against disease caused by serogroups A, C, W135, and Y. Serogroup B remains a major cause of severe invasive disease in infants and adolescents worldwide; but, because the serogroup B polysaccharide resembles the human neural cell adhesion molecule, the serogroup B capsular polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic. To control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an attempt to induce herd immunity, whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the population has been vaccinated (see http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). Meningococcal vaccines will only protect against meningitis due to the meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups that the vaccine contains. The components and the type of the vaccine being used in Chile are not stated in the news reports above.\n\nThe Valparaiso Region and Santiago Metropolitan Region (or simply Metropolitan Region), 2 of Chile's 15 administrative divisions, are adjacent to each other in the center of Chile. A map of Chile's regions can be seen at http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/chilfung/chile_regions.gif.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Chile can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aht. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Children under 4 years of age are the most affected group and accounted for 45 percent of all reported cases; children between 5 and 9 years of age accounted for 7 percent; and 45 percent of the cases occurred in people over 20 years of age. \n\nBetween January and October 2012, 87 cases of [meningococcal] meningitis type W135 have already been confirmed, while in all of 2011 there were only 73 cases reported. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the news reports above, there are discrepancies in the number of cases and the meningococcal serogroups that are causing meningococcal meningitis in Chile. 17 cases occurred in children under one year (23 percent), who had the highest incidence rate of 6.7 cases per 100 000 children. \n\n\nA total of 73 cases of meningitis have been recorded so far this year [2012] in Chile, a figure that exceeds the notifications for the same period of 2011 (46 cases). \n\nThere have been 14 deaths (CFR 19 percent) reported this year [2012], higher than expected; 5 of the deaths were due to W135; 1 due to B; 1 due to C, and 3 unidentified. The health authority is keeping under surveillance serogroup W135, which has been detected in 42 percent of cases from January [2012] to date.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valparaiso", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1348918", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (02): (VS, RM) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1348918", "date": "2012-10-17 14:54:29", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CHILE (02): (VALPARAISO, SANTIAGO METROPOLITAN REGION) UPDATE\n*****************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 17 Oct 2012\nFrom: Thomas Weitzel <thomas.weitzel@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile: (VS, RM) RFI 20121016.1346329\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nChile is currently facing an increase of meningococcal disease and also a shift of serotypes compared to the year 2011.\n\nThe surveillance system of the Chilean Ministry of Health has reported the following numbers, which reflect the epidemiological situation of meningococcal disease for 2012 from week 1 to 40 [1 Jan-6 Oct 2012]:\n\nThere are a total of 83 accumulated cases compared with 52 for the total of 2011 (median number of cases 2007-2011: 76). The increase is mainly observed in 2 Chilean regions: the Metropolitan Region (RM), which includes Santiago, with 58 percent of cases and the region of Valparaiso with 21 percent of cases. The RM is divided into several health administrative regions; of those, 3 were mostly affected.\n\nInterestingly, in the RM 76 percent of cases were caused by serogroup W135, compared with 14 percent and 48 percent in the years 2010 and 2011, respectively. This epidemiological change is not observed in the other regions, where serogroup B is predominant.\n\nThe most affected age groups are children under the age of 5 (48 percent of cases); almost half of those are 9 months or younger. In the age group under 5 years, 55 percent of the cases are caused by serogroup W135.\n\nThe reported case fatality rate reached 20 percent (17/83) and seems to be higher than in previous years (2011: 15 percent). This increase might be related to serogroup W135, since, of 9 fatal cases with available serogroup, 6 belonged to this group. According to our information, the Chilean Ministry of Health is planning to start a targeted vaccination campaign (with quadrivalent conjugate vaccine) focusing on the areas and age groups mostly affected by serotype W135 by the end of October 2012.\n\n--\nJeannette Dabanch, Alberto Fica, and Thomas Weitzel\nComite de Infecciones Emergentes\nSociedad Chilena de Infectologia, Santiago, Chile\nAv Bernarda Morin 488\nSantiago\nChile\n<thomas.weitzel@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks the authors for a more detailed, authoritative description of the outbreak of meningococcal meningitis in Chile.\n\nA map of Chile's regions can be seen at http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/chilfung/chile_regions.gif. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Chile can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aht. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nThe surveillance system of the Chilean Ministry of Health has reported the following numbers, which reflect the epidemiological situation of meningococcal disease for 2012 from week 1 to 40 [1 Jan-6 Oct 2012]:\n\nThere are a total of 83 accumulated cases compared with 52 for the total of 2011 (median number of cases 2007-2011: 76). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nInterestingly, in the RM 76 percent of cases were caused by serogroup W135, compared with 14 percent and 48 percent in the years 2010 and 2011, respectively. \n\n--\nJeannette Dabanch, Alberto Fica, and Thomas Weitzel\nComite de Infecciones Emergentes\n The increase is mainly observed in 2 Chilean regions: the Metropolitan Region (RM), which includes Santiago, with 58 percent of cases and the region of Valparaiso with 21 percent of cases. \n\nThe most affected age groups are children under the age of 5 (48 percent of cases); almost half of those are 9 months or younger. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CHILE (02): (VALPARAISO, SANTIAGO METROPOLITAN REGION) UPDATE\n*****************************************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valparaiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santiago", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "RM", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1464977", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (05): (RM) airplane exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1464977", "date": "2012-12-22 19:57:13", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CHILE (05): (SANTIAGO METROPOLITAN REGION) AIRPLANE EXPOSURE\n****************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 20 Dec 2012\nSource: Terra [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://noticias.terra.cl/nacional/buscan-pasajeros-que-volaron-con-victima-fatal-de-meningitis,9fdc03264dabb310VgnVCM4000009bcceb0aRCRD.html\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health has implemented an action plan to locate passengers who shared a flight to Punta Cana [Dominican Republic] with a woman who died of meningitis.\n\nPassengers shared LAN flight no 592, which departed from Santiago [Chile] at 9:55 pm last Sunday [16 Dec 2012], bound for the Dominican Republic.\n\nThe health authority began by giving preventive treatment to direct contacts of the passenger who died, while travel agencies are trying to locate the rest of the passengers.\n\nAn estimated 200 passengers were exposed to infection during the 7 hour long trip.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[LAN is the flag carrier of Chile and it is based in Santiago, Chile, serving Latin America, the United States, the Caribbean, Oceania, and Europe (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LAN_Airlines).\n\nProMED-mail has been posting reports of an outbreak of meningococcal meningitis in Chile this year (2012) (see postings listed below). According to a recent news report posted by ProMED-mail (Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (03): (VS, RM) update 20121110.1403844), there have been a total of 98 cases of meningococcal meningitis. The outbreak is centered mainly in 2 Chilean regions: the Metropolitan Region (RM), which includes Santiago, and the region of Valparaiso. _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup W135 predominates in the Metropolitan Region and serogroup B predominates in Valparaiso.\n\nAlthough the microbe that caused meningitis in the passenger on LAN flight 592 was not stated in the news report above, presumably it was the meningococcus, _N. meningitidis_. Meningococcal infection is spread primarily through direct contact with respiratory droplets from a nasopharyngeal carrier or an infected person. The incubation period between infection and appearance of symptoms is generally 3 to 4 days, but may range from 2 to 10 days.\n\nWhile this risk of secondary transmission among household members is estimated to be low (4 cases per 1000 household members at risk), it is 500 to 800 times higher than in the general population. Other at-risk contacts include attendees at the same child-care center, or anyone directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions (such as, through kissing, mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, or endotracheal intubation). Risk is also high in travelers who have prolonged contact with local populations in the Africa meningitis belt during an epidemic. The Hajj pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia has been associated with outbreaks of meningococcal disease in returning pilgrims and their contacts.\n\nAntibiotics are recommended to prevent secondary infection in close contacts of patients with invasive meningococcal disease. Because the risk for illness is highest during the 1st few days after infection, chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible (ideally within 24 hours) after contact with an index case-patient. Chemoprophylaxis administered after 14 days is probably of limited or no value. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended for people in the same household, roommates, child-care/preschool contacts, and people who have been exposed directly to a patient's oral secretions through close social contact (such as kissing or sharing of eating utensils) during the 7 days before onset of disease in the index case. Antibiotics that effectively eliminate nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ include rifampin, ciprofloxacin, ceftriaxone, and azithromycin and these drugs are appropriate for chemoprophylaxis. In areas of the United States where ciprofloxacin-resistant strains of _N. meningitidis_ have been detected, ciprofloxacin should not be used for chemoprophylaxis (http://www.cdc.gov/MMWR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm and http://www.unboundmedicine.com/redbook/ub/view/RedBook/187078/7/meningococcal_vaccine_for).\n\nFrom February 1999 through May 2001, the US CDC reported it received 21 reports from local health departments of suspected cases of air travel associated meningococcal disease, on average 1.9 days (range: 0--10 days) between the completion of the flight and the onset of illness; CDC reported that 5 of these passengers had symptomatic meningococcal disease before their arrival (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm). No cases of secondary disease occurred among air travel contacts of persons with meningococcal disease; nevertheless, CDC noted that passengers who are seated next to a person with meningococcal disease for a prolonged flight are more likely to be exposed directly to the patient's oral secretions and are probably at higher risk for developing meningococcal disease than those seated farther from the index case-patient (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm).\n\nCDC, in collaboration with the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists, developed procedures for the management of air travel associated exposure to the meningococcus. The assessment of risk to passengers and flight crew members is based on the flight duration and seating proximity to the index case-patient. In the absence of data about increased risk to other passengers, they recommend antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should be considered for passengers who are seated immediately next to an index case-patient for flights of more than 8 hours, including ground time (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm).\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Chile can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/2E*Q. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "No cases of secondary disease occurred among air travel contacts of persons with meningococcal disease; nevertheless, CDC noted that passengers who are seated next to a person with meningococcal disease for a prolonged flight are more likely to be exposed directly to the patient's oral secretions and are probably at higher risk for developing meningococcal disease than those seated farther from the index case-patient (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm). \n\nFrom February 1999 through May 2001, the US CDC reported it received 21 reports from local health departments of suspected cases of air travel associated meningococcal disease, on average 1.9 days (range: 0--10 days) between the completion of the flight and the onset of illness; CDC reported that 5 of these passengers had symptomatic meningococcal disease before their arrival (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm). Chemoprophylaxis is recommended for people in the same household, roommates, child-care/preschool contacts, and people who have been exposed directly to a patient's oral secretions through close social contact (such as kissing or sharing of eating utensils) during the 7 days before onset of disease in the index case. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n In the absence of data about increased risk to other passengers, they recommend antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should be considered for passengers who are seated immediately next to an index case-patient for flights of more than 8 hours, including ground time (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm). \n\nWhile this risk of secondary transmission among household members is estimated to be low (4 cases per 1000 household members at risk), it is 500 to 800 times higher than in the general population. Because the risk for illness is highest during the 1st few days after infection, chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible (ideally within 24 hours) after contact with an index case-patient. The assessment of risk to passengers and flight crew members is based on the flight duration and seating proximity to the index case-patient. According to a recent news report posted by ProMED-mail (Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (03): (VS, RM) update 20121110.1403844), there have been a total of 98 cases of meningococcal meningitis. \n\nAntibiotics are recommended to prevent secondary infection in close contacts of patients with invasive meningococcal disease. Other at-risk contacts include attendees at the same child-care center, or anyone directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions (such as, through kissing, mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, or endotracheal intubation).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2001-05-26 00:00:00", "1999-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Dominican Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santiago", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oceania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valparaiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "RM", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1337615", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aspergillus meningitis - USA (09): Exserohilum", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1337615", "date": "2012-10-11 15:45:54", "main_text": "ASPERGILLUS MENINGITIS - USA (09): EXSEROHILUM\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] CDC: _Exserohilum_ predominant mold\nDate: Thu 11 Oct 2012\nSource: CDC [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/hai/outbreaks/meningitis.html\n\n\nAs of 10 Oct 2012, CDC's fungal disease laboratory has confirmed the presence of the fungus exserohilum in 10 people with meningitis and the fungus aspergillus in one person with meningitis.\n\nClinicians should continue to contact patients who have received medicines associated with 3 lots of preservative-free methylprednisolone acetate (80mg/mL) from the New England Compounding Center (NECC) that were recalled on 26 Sep 2012, 2012. The potentially contaminated injections were given starting 21 May 2012.\n\nCDC's guidance to patients has not changed as a result of the expanded voluntary recall of all NECC products, announced 6 Oct 2012. Patients who feel ill and are concerned about whether they received a medication from one of the NECC products recalled on 26 Sep 2012 should contact their physician.\n\nOnset of symptoms is typically 1 to 4 weeks following injection, but there are also reports of shorter and longer periods of time between injection and onset of symptoms.\n\nAt-a-glance\n-----------\nStatus: ongoing investigation\nInfection: fungal meningitis\nFacility type: outpatient setting\nCase count: 170\nStates: 11\nDeaths: 14\n\nA map of the states affected can be found at:\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/hai/outbreaks/meningitis-map.html.\n\nState / Case Count / Deaths\nFlorida / 7 / 2\nIdaho / 1 / 0\nIndiana / 21 / 1\nMaryland / 13 / 1\nMichigan / 39 / 3\nMinnesota / 3 / 0\nNew Jersey / 2 / 0\nNorth Carolina / 2 / 0\nOhio / 3 / 0\nTennessee / 49 / 6\nVirginia / 30 / 1\nTOTALS = 170 cases with 14 deaths\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Tennessee health commissioner: Exserohilum predominant mold\nDate: Tue 9 Oct 2012\nSource: Examiner.com [edited]\nhttp://www.examiner.com/article/tennessee-reports-two-more-deaths-exserohilum-is-the-primary-fungus-implicated\n\nDuring his daily statement, Tennessee Health Commissioner John Dreyzehner, MD, MPH, made several key points concerning the outbreak in Tennessee and in general.\n\nHe noted that the primary fungus infecting patients in Tennessee is exserohilum, a mold rarely seen in human infections. It is a cosmopolitan fungus inhabiting plant material, particularly grasses and soil. Dr Dreyzehner points out that currently used antifungal treatments are effective against this fungus.\n\nIn addition, he says that the incubation time for the infection may be significantly longer than originally suspected. What was initially reported to be an incubation time of up to a month is now believed it may possibly be up to 3 months.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] CDC: Septic arthritis and suspect case definitions added\nDate: Wed 10 Oct 2012\nSource: CDC [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/HAI/outbreaks/clinicians/casedef_multistate_outbreak.html\n\n\nCase definitions for meningitis and septic arthritis\n----------------------------------------------------\nA person who received an injection with methylprednisolone acetate produced by the New England Compounding Center (NECC) who has developed any of the following:\n\n- fungal meningitis or non-bacterial and non-viral meningitis (1) of subacute onset, following epidural injection on and after 21 May 2012;\n- basilar stroke following epidural injection after 21 May 2012, who has not received a diagnostic lumbar puncture (2);\n- evidence of spinal osteomyelitis or epidural abscess at the site of injection following epidural or sacroiliac injection after 21 May 2012;\n- septic arthritis or osteomyelitis of a peripheral joint (for example, knee) diagnosed following joint injection after 21 May 2012.\n\n1. Clinically diagnosed meningitis meaning one or more of the following symptoms: headache, fever, stiff neck, or photophobia and a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) profile showing pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells, adjusting for presence of red blood cells) regardless of glucose or protein levels.\n2. These people, if possible, should have a lumbar puncture.\n3. Clinically diagnosed septic arthritis meaning new or worsening pain with presence of effusion or new or worsening effusion.\n\nSuspect case:\n-------------\nA person who has developed an infection of a normally sterile site (for example, blood, CSF, pleural fluid, peritoneal fluid, pericardial fluid, surgical aspirate, bone, joint fluid, or internal body site [for example, lymph node, brain]) following use of a product labeled as sterile prepared by the New England Compounding Center (NECC).\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Role of antifungal prophylaxis in asymptomatic patients\nDate: Wed 10 Oct 2012\nSource: CDC [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/HAI/outbreaks/clinicians/gudance_antifungal_prophylaxis.html\n\n\nAt this time, CDC does not recommend initiation of antifungal prophylaxis in exposed patients who are asymptomatic. These patients should be closely monitored for development of symptoms, with a low threshold for performing lumbar puncture should the patient become symptomatic.\n\nIn addition, CDC does not recommend empiric antifungal therapy for symptomatic patients who have normal cerebrospinal fluid laboratory examination. These patients should be closely monitored and re-evaluated should their symptoms worsen. Should the patient have progression of symptoms, a lumbar puncture should be repeated immediately.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would be useful to know the date of administration of the contaminated corticosteroid and the date of initial onset of symptoms as well as the cell count, chemistries, and time to positive culture in documented cases. As well, the species of _Aspergillus_ mold has not been reported but cases with _Exserohilum_ species seem to be commoner than those with aspergillus.\n\nAs the number of cases continues to rise, a 2nd mold, exserohilum, has been reported to be the dominant organism. This environmental organism is much less common as a human pathogen than aspergillus. This agent is one of the molds associated with phaeohyphomycosis (McGinnis MR, Rinaldi MG, Winn RE. Emerging agents of phaeohyphomycosis: pathogenic species of Bipolaris and Exserohilum. J Clin Microbiol. 1986;24:250-259). A more definitive discussion on exserohilum will occur in the next posting on this expanding outbreak.\n\nThis is the 1st time CDC has added a case definition for septic arthritis although no cases related to joint injection of the contaminated corticosteroid have yet occurred. The numbers of joint injections compared with the numbers of injections into the lumbar spinal canal have not been reported.\n\nRelated to the date of reporting (not date of onset), the number of cases, number of states involved and deaths is:\n\nDate of report / Cases / States / Deaths\n----------------------------------------\n02 Oct 2012 / 12 / 2 / 2\n04 Oct 2012 / 26 / 5 / 4\n05 Oct 2012 / 35 / 5 / 5 (9 more cases, 1 more death)\n06 Oct 2012 / 64 / 9 / 7 (29 more cases, 2 more deaths)\n07 Oct 2012 / 91 / 9 / 7 (27 more cases, 0 more deaths)\n08 Oct 2012 / 101 / 9 / 8 (10 more cases, 1 more death)\n09 Oct 2012 / 119 / 10 / 11 (18 more cases, 3 more deaths)\n10 Oct 2012 / 137 / 10 / 12 (28 more cases, 1 more death)\n11 Oct 2012 / 170 / 11 / 14 (33 more cases, 2 more deaths)\n\nCase fatality rate = 8.2 per cent - Mod. LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]", "summary": "A person who received an injection with methylprednisolone acetate produced by the New England Compounding Center (NECC) who has developed any of the following:\n\n- fungal meningitis or non-bacterial and non-viral meningitis (1) of subacute onset, following epidural injection on and after 21 May 2012;\n- basilar stroke following epidural injection after 21 May 2012, who has not received a diagnostic lumbar puncture (2);\n- evidence of spinal osteomyelitis or epidural abscess at the site of injection following epidural or sacroiliac injection after 21 May 2012;\n- septic arthritis or osteomyelitis of a peripheral joint (for example, knee) diagnosed following joint injection after 21 May 2012. USA (09): EXSEROHILUM\n**********************************************\n Status: ongoing investigation\nInfection: fungal meningitis\n Source: Examiner.com [edited]\nhttp://www.examiner.com/article/tennessee-reports-two-more-deaths-exserohilum-is-the-primary-fungus-implicated\n\nDuring his daily statement, Tennessee Health Commissioner John Dreyzehner, MD, MPH, made several key points concerning the outbreak in Tennessee and in general.\n\n 10 Oct 2012 / 137 / 10 / 12 (28 more cases, 1 more death)\n 09 Oct 2012 / 119 / 10 / 11 (18 more cases, 3 more deaths)\n 08 Oct 2012 / 101 / 9 / 8 (10 more cases, 1 more death)\n 06 Oct 2012 / 64 / 9 / 7 (29 more cases, 2 more deaths)\n 07 Oct 2012 / 91 / 9 / 7 (27 more cases, 0 more deaths)\n Deaths: 14\n\nA map of the states affected can be found at:\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/hai/outbreaks/meningitis-map.html. \n\nClinicians should continue to contact patients who have received medicines associated with 3 lots of preservative-free methylprednisolone acetate (80mg/mL) from the New England Compounding Center (NECC) that were recalled on 26 Sep 2012, 2012. Date: Wed 10 Oct 2012\n Date: Wed 10 Oct 2012\n Date: Thu 11 Oct 2012\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Date: Tue 9 Oct 2012\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-09-26 20:12:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2012-09-26 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2012-05-21 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey / 2", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1335715", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aspergillus meningitis - USA (08)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1335715", "date": "2012-10-11 02:36:50", "main_text": "ASPERGILLUS MENINGITIS - USA (08)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 10 Oct 2012\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/HAI/outbreaks/meningitis.html\n\n\nAt-a-glance\n-----------\nStatus: ongoing Investigation\nInfection: fungal meningitis\nFacility type: outpatient setting\nCase Count: 137\nStates: 10\nDeaths: 12\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\n10 Oct 2012\nSource: CDC [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/HAI/outbreaks/clinicians/guidance_cns.html\n\n\nInterim guidance for CNS and/or parameningeal infections associated with injection of potentially contaminated products\n--------------------------------------------------------\nThe pathogens involved in this cluster of infections are still under investigation. At present, there is culture, PCR, and/or histopathologic evidence of fungal central nervous system (CNS) infection in at least 25 patients. The commonest pathogen identified in these patients to date is _Exserohilum_ spp.\n\nOne patient has documented evidence of _Aspergillus_ spp. infection. When initiating treatment for patients with meningitis (that is, CSF [cerebrospinal fluid] pleocytosis* regardless of glucose and protein levels), epidural abscess, and/or vertebral osteomyelitis of unknown etiology who received an epidural injection with a New England Compounding Center product, clinicians should continue to follow routine empiric treatment protocols to cover for potential bacterial pathogens and add empiric broad spectrum antifungal therapy to the treatment regimen because of the severe adverse outcomes of untreated invasive fungal infection.\n\nThese recommendations are based upon current evidence that at least 2 fungal pathogens are involved, and the possibility that additional pathogens may be identified as the investigation continues. CDC has consulted with national experts on treatment options for fungal CNS and/or parameningeal infections in patients associated with this cluster. The following represents interim guidance and may change as new information becomes available.\n\nConsult an infectious disease physician to assist with diagnosis, management, and follow-up, which may be complex and prolonged.\n\nAfter collecting cerebrospinal fluid for culture, initiate empiric combination antifungal therapy using the following regimen in addition to routine empiric treatment protocols to cover for potential bacterial pathogens until the etiology of the patient's CNS and/or parameningeal infection has been identified:\n\nVoriconazole, preferably at a dose of 6mg/kg every 12 hours (IV initially) and to continue on this high dose for the duration of treatment, if possible. Regular monitoring of serum concentration (for example, weekly interval) is advisable.\n\nAND\n\nLiposomal amphotericin B, preferably at a dose of 7.5 mg/kg IV daily (higher than standard dose). The liposomal preparation of amphotericin B [AmBisome] is preferred over other lipid formulations. If nephrotoxicity is a potential concern, particularly in older patients, the dose may be decreased to 5mg/kg IV daily. Administration of 1L normal saline prior to infusion may be considered to minimize risk of nephrotoxicity.\n\nAvoid routine use of intrathecal amphotericin B, either the deoxycholate or the lipid formulations, due to limited data on its use and associated toxicities.\n\nThere is currently no clear evidence for the use of adjuvant steroid therapy. If used, careful monitoring of clinical status is warranted.\n\nAdequate duration of antifungal treatment is unknown but likely will require prolonged therapy (for example, months) tailored by the clinical response to treatment. Individual management decisions, including choice of long-term antifungal regimen, should be made in consultation with infectious disease physicians experienced in the treatment of fungal infections. Clinicians should be vigilant for potential relapse of infection after completion of therapy.\n\nAt this time, CDC does not recommend initiation of antifungal prophylaxis in exposed patients who are asymptomatic. These patients should be closely monitored for development of symptoms, with a low threshold for performing lumbar puncture should the patient become symptomatic.\n\nAt this time, CDC does not recommend empiric antifungal therapy for symptomatic patients who have normal cerebrospinal fluid laboratory examination. These patients should be closely monitored and re-evaluated for progression of symptoms. Should the patient have progression of symptoms, a lumbar puncture should be repeated immediately.\n\n*CSF WBC greater than 5 in a non-traumatic lumbar puncture. If a traumatic lumbar puncture is suspected, a corrected CSF WBC count can be calculated by subtracting one WBC for every 500 RBCs present in the CSF.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would be useful to know the date of administration of the contaminated corticosteroid and the date of initial onset of symptoms as well as the cell count, chemistries, and time to positive culture in documented cases. As well, the species of _Aspergillus_ mold and the number of cases with _Exserohilum_ species has not been reported. This is the 1st time that it has been reported that exserohilum may be commoner than aspergillus in this outbreak.\n\nRelated to the date of reporting (not date of onset), the number of cases, number of states involved and deaths is:\n\nDate of report / Cases / States / Deaths\n----------------------------------------\n02 Oct 2012 / 12 / 2 / 2\n04 Oct 2012 / 26 / 5 / 4\n05 Oct 2012 / 35 / 5 / 5\n06 Oct 2012 / 64 / 9 / 7\n07 Oct 2012 / 91 / 9 / 7\n08 Oct 2012 / 101 / 9 / 8\n09 Oct 2012 / 119 / 10 / 11\n10 Oct 2012 / 137 / 10 / 12\n--------------------------\nTotal case fatality rate: 8.7 per cent - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]", "summary": "Oct 2012 / 64 / 9 / 7\n07 Oct 2012 / 91 / 9 / 7\n08 Oct 2012 / 101 / 9 / 8\n09 Oct 2012 / 119 / 10 / 11\n10 Oct 2012 / 137 / 10 / 12\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Deaths: 12\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< After collecting cerebrospinal fluid for culture, initiate empiric combination antifungal therapy using the following regimen in addition to routine empiric treatment protocols to cover for potential bacterial pathogens until the etiology of the patient's CNS and/or parameningeal infection has been identified:\n\nVoriconazole, preferably at a dose of 6mg/kg every 12 hours (IV initially) and to continue on this high dose for the duration of treatment, if possible. When initiating treatment for patients with meningitis (that is, CSF [cerebrospinal fluid] pleocytosis* regardless of glucose and protein levels), epidural abscess, and/or vertebral osteomyelitis of unknown etiology who received an epidural injection with a New England Compounding Center product, clinicians should continue to follow routine empiric treatment protocols to cover for potential bacterial pathogens and add empiric broad spectrum antifungal therapy to the treatment regimen because of the severe adverse outcomes of untreated invasive fungal infection. USA (07)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1333926", "date": "2012-10-10 14:16:01", "main_text": "ASPERGILLUS MENINGITIS - USA (07)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 9 Oct 2012\nSource: CDC [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/HAI/outbreaks/meningitis.html\n\n\nCurrent situation\n-----------------\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is aware that New England Compounding Center (NECC) has voluntarily expanded its recall to include all products currently in circulation that were compounded at and distributed from its facility in Framingham, Massachusetts.\n\nCDC's guidance to patients has not changed as a result of this voluntary recall. Patients who feel ill and are concerned about whether they received a medication from NECC at one of the affected facilities should contact their physicians.\n\nClinicians should actively contact patients who have received medicines associated with 3 lots of preservative-free methylprednisolone acetate (80mg/ml) recalled on 26 Sep 2012. The potentially contaminated injections were given starting 21 May 2012.\n\nPatients have had symptoms generally starting from 1 to 4 weeks after their injection. Not all patients who received the medicine will become sick. Symptoms that should prompt patients to seek medical care include: fever, new or worsening headache, neck stiffness, sensitivity to light, new weakness or numbness, increasing pain, redness or swelling of the injection site.\n\nAt-a-glance\n-----------\nStatus: ongoing investigation\nInfection: fungal meningitis\nFacility type: outpatient setting\nCase count: 119\nStates: 10\nDeaths: 11\n\nA map of the outbreak by state can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/hai/outbreaks/meningitis-map.html:\nState / Case count / Deaths\nFlorida / 4 / 0\nIndiana / 12 / 0\nMaryland / 8 / 1\nMichigan / 25 / 3\nMinnesota / 3 / 0\nNew Jersey / 1 / 0\nNorth Carolina / 2 / 0\nOhio / 1 / 0\nTennessee / 39 / 6\nVirginia / 24 /1\n----------------\nTOTALS: 119 cases with 11 deaths. Case fatality rate: 9.2 per cent\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would be useful to know the date of administration of the contaminated corticosteroid and the date of initial onset of symptoms as well as the cell count, chemistries and time to positive culture in documented cases. As well, the species of _Aspergillus_ mold and the number of cases with _Exserohilum_ species has not been reported.\n\nRelated to the date of reporting (not date of onset), the number of cases, number of states involved and deaths is:\n\nDate of report / Cases / States / Deaths\n------------------------------\n2 Oct 2012 / 12 / 2 / 2\n4 Oct 2012 / 26 / 5 / 4\n5 Oct 2012 / 35 / 5 / 5\n6 Oct 2012 / 64 / 9 / 7\n7 Oct 2012 / 91 / 9 / 7\n8 Oct 2012 / 101 / 9 / 8\n9 Oct 2012 / 119 / 10 / 11\n\nThe scope of this outbreak is yet to be determined. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]", "summary": "\n2 Oct 2012 / 12 / 2 / 2\n4 Oct 2012 / 26 / 5 / 4\n5 Oct 2012 / 35 / 5 / 5\n6 Oct 2012 / 64 / 9 / 7\n7 Oct 2012 / 91 / 9 / 7\n8 Oct 2012 / 101 / 9 / 8\n9 Oct 2012 / 119 / 10 / 11\n\nThe scope of this outbreak is yet to be determined. Indiana / 12 / 0\nMaryland / 8 / 1\nMichigan / 25 / 3\nMinnesota / 3 / 0\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Case fatality rate: 9.2 per cent\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Case count: 119\nStates: 10\n Related to the date of reporting (not date of onset), the number of cases, number of states involved and deaths is:\n\nDate of report / Cases / States / Deaths\n------------------------------ Tennessee / 39 / 6\nVirginia / 24 /1\n Status: ongoing investigation\nInfection: fungal meningitis\n ASPERGILLUS MENINGITIS - USA (07)\n*********************************\n Deaths: 11\n\nA map of the outbreak by state can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/hai/outbreaks/meningitis-map.html:\n Date: Tue 9 Oct 2012\n ----------------\nTOTALS: 119 cases with 11 deaths.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2012-09-26 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2012-05-21 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey /", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Framingham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1333637", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy: cruise ship, exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1333637", "date": "2012-10-09 16:40:45", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY: CRUISE SHIP, EXPOSURE\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Mon 8 Oct 2012\nSource: prensa-latina.cu [in Italian, machine transl., edited]\nhttp://www.prensa-latina.cu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=594231&Itemid=5\n\n\nA meningitis outbreak spread to 4 of the nearly 3000 people aboard the MSC Orchestra cruise [ship], which docked yesterday [7 Oct 2012] in an Italian port, said local authorities. According to the source, the 2800 passengers on the boat had to be treated [urgently] against disease, after 4 crew members were hospitalized in serious condition.\n\nOne of the patients, a 32 year old Indonesian citizen, was reported to be very seriously ill by the head of emergency medicine at the hospital in Livorno, Francesco Genovesi, where a 47 year old Italian who worked in the ship's galley was also transferred. The other 2 infected people, a Brazilian and a Filipino, were admitted to the infectious diseases section of the hospital.\n\nIn a statement issued on Monday [8 Oct 2012] by MSC Cruises reported that 'as a precaution and according to maritime authorities, all passengers received antibiotic prophylaxis. No other member of the crew or passengers showed symptoms of meningitis.' The alarm about the spread had been given on Sunday [7 Oct 2012], when the MSC Orchestra arrived in Livorno (west of Italy), and since continued its journey to the French town of Villefranche, where another tour will to begin. The shipping company said that health authorities provided maritime antibiotic prophylaxis 'just a precaution' and that the ship sailed after receiving clearance from doctors.\n\nAccording to several media outlets say, the incident is another blow to the cruise industry, after 32 people died last January during the sinking of the Costa Crociere along the Tuscan coast.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 8 Oct 2012\nSource: cruiselawnews.com [edited]\nhttp://www.cruiselawnews.com/2012/10/articles/crew-member-rights-1/crew-members-aboard-msc-orchestra-stricken-with-meningitis/\n\n\nA newspaper in Italy [http://www.ansa.it/web/notizie/rubriche/cronaca/2012/10/07/Meningite-nave-quattro-casi-sospetti-_7592928.html] is reporting that 4 crew members of the cruise ship MSC Orchestra have contracted bacterial meningitis. 2 of the 4 crew members are considered to be in serious condition. They were all hospitalized once the cruise ship reached port yesterday [7 Oct 2012].\n\nAccording to this newspaper, one crew member is a 32 year old Indonesian who is currently in septic shock in the intensive care unit of a hospital in Livorno, Italy. He apparently worked in the engine room. A 2nd crew member is a 47 year old Italian who works in the cruise ship's galley, who also is in the intensive care unit. 2 other crew members include a Brazilian and a Filipino, whose conditions are described as less serious. They are hospitalized in the hospital's infectious disease department.\n\nOther newspapers [http://www.abc.es/20121008/local-comunidad-valenciana/abci-cuatro-miembros-tripulacion-crucero-201210081422.html] state that the serious cases involve an Indonesian, age 32, and a Filipino, age 30, both of whom worked in the engine room.\n\nMeningitis is an infection of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. Bacterial meningitis is very serious and can be fatal. It is not common on cruise ships, although it has occurred on other cruise ships [http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10670158] as this case illustrates.\n\nAll of the crew members were given prophylactic antibiotics, which were also offered to the passengers. The 2800 dosages were described as an 'unprecedented quantity over a period of time so limited.' The medicine consisted of an antibiotic tablet of 500 milligrams for adults and syrup for about 400 children who were on board. An epidemiological survey was also conducted among the crew members who in recent days have been most in contact with the hospitalized crew.\n\nThe Orchestra is continuing its cruise as planned and has meanwhile docked in France's Villafranche, with next stops including Valencia, Ibiza, Tunis, Catania and Naples.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue 9 Oct 2012\nSource: ubalert.com [edited]\nhttp://www.ubalert.com/0o2?open_ctab=1\n\n\nThe Italian Health Ministry reported on Monday [8 Oct 2012] that passengers on board an Italian cruise ship were given antibiotics after 4 of the ship's crew members were found to have bacterial meningitis. The ministry said that all 4 had been transported to hospitals in the port of Livorno. Doctors have distributed more than 2800 doses of rifampicin and ciprofloxacin to passengers of the MSC Orchestra. Those who had already disembarked over the past week are advised to take similar precautionary measures. The 2500 passenger cruise ship is now anchored in the port of Villefranche sur Mer in France.\n\nItalian officials have already contacted their French counterparts. The cruise company stated that it was doing all that is necessary to ensure the health and well-being of its crew members and guests. The 4 crew members were found to have contracted meningococcal meningitis. The illness is transmitted through close contact with saliva or respiratory secretions. The Health Ministry also noted that the strain was detected in crew members working in the ship's kitchen; hence, it is not likely that they had close contact with guests. 2 out of the 4 cases were diagnosed as [meningitis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup] C.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the United States and most industrialized countries, antibiotic chemoprophylaxis among close contacts of a patient with invasive meningococcal disease is recommended to prevent secondary cases.\n\nThe following is extracted from moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Meningitis, bacterial, airplane exposure - USA (KS ex FL): alert 20070724.2378:\n\nMeningococcal meningitis occurs sporadically or as epidemics. Certain types of close contact of a case of meningococcal meningitis place a person at increased risk of developing meningitis for which antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis is recommended. These contacts include household members, daycare center members, and anyone directly exposed to the patient's respiratory secretions (for example, by kissing, mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, or intubation of the patient) [see:\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046263.htm].\n\nAntibiotics recommended for chemoprophylaxis are rifampin (an oral dose administered twice daily for 2 days), ciprofloxacin (single oral dose), and ceftriaxone (a single intramuscular dose). Chemoprophylaxis is not recommended for school or work contacts not directly exposed to directly exposed to a patient's respiratory secretions (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5945a2.htm).\n\nAccording to CDC, for management of passengers aboard an airplane exposed to meningococcal disease, household members traveling with the index patient as well as persons traveling with the index patient who have prolonged close contact (for example, roommates, members of the same sports team) should be identified and the need for antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis evaluated. Antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should also be considered for airline passengers who have had direct contact with respiratory secretions from the index patient, and for passengers seated directly next to the index patient on prolonged flights (>8 hours)\n(http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/yellowbook/2012/chapter-6-conveyance-and-transportation-issues/air-travel.htm).\n\nBecause the risk for illness is highest during the first few days after infection, chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible (ideally within 24 hours) after contact with an index case-patient\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm).\n\nChemoprophylaxis administered >14 days is probably of limited or no value. For both the meningococcal conjugate and the polysaccharide vaccines, at least 7-10 days are required following vaccination for development of immunity. Meningococcal vaccination, however, is used to control spread of meningitis in outbreak situations.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be found at http://healthmap.org/r/1BIF. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n******\n 2 out of the 4 cases were diagnosed as [meningitis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup] C.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< According to CDC, for management of passengers aboard an airplane exposed to meningococcal disease, household members traveling with the index patient as well as persons traveling with the index patient who have prolonged close contact (for example, roommates, members of the same sports team) should be identified and the need for antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis evaluated. The Italian Health Ministry reported on Monday [8 Oct 2012] that passengers on board an Italian cruise ship were given antibiotics after 4 of the ship's crew members were found to have bacterial meningitis. Antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should also be considered for airline passengers who have had direct contact with respiratory secretions from the index patient, and for passengers seated directly next to the index patient on prolonged flights (>8 hours)\n \n\nBecause the risk for illness is highest during the first few days after infection, chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible (ideally within 24 hours) after contact with an index case-patient\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm). \n\nThe following is extracted from moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Meningitis, bacterial, airplane exposure - USA (KS ex FL): alert 20070724.2378:\n\nMeningococcal meningitis occurs sporadically or as epidemics. CRUISE SHIP, EXPOSURE\n********************************************************\n These contacts include household members, daycare center members, and anyone directly exposed to the patient's respiratory secretions (for example, by kissing, mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, or intubation of the patient) A meningitis outbreak spread to 4 of the nearly 3000 people aboard the MSC Orchestra cruise [ship], which docked yesterday [7 Oct 2012] in an Italian port, said local authorities. \n\nOne of the patients, a 32 year old Indonesian citizen, was reported to be very seriously ill by the head of emergency medicine at the hospital in Livorno, Francesco Genovesi, where a 47 year old Italian who worked in the ship's galley was also transferred. A newspaper in Italy [http://www.ansa.it/web/notizie/rubriche/cronaca/2012/10/07/Meningite-nave-quattro-casi-sospetti-_7592928.html] is reporting that 4 crew members of the cruise ship MSC Orchestra have contracted bacterial meningitis. \n\nAntibiotics recommended for chemoprophylaxis are rifampin (an oral dose administered twice daily for 2 days), ciprofloxacin (single oral dose), and ceftriaxone (a single intramuscular dose). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the United States and most industrialized countries, antibiotic chemoprophylaxis among close contacts of a patient with invasive meningococcal disease is recommended to prevent secondary cases. An epidemiological survey was also conducted among the crew members who in recent days have been most in contact with the hospitalized crew. The Health Ministry also noted that the strain was detected in crew members working in the ship's kitchen; hence, it is not likely that they had close contact with guests. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) posted updated figures to its website on Sun 7 Oct 2012. The death toll stood at 7, the same number as a day earlier.\n\nThe steroid linked to the outbreak has been recalled, and health officials have been scrambling to notify anyone who may have received an injection of it. On Sat 6 Oct 2012, the pharmacy that distributed the steroid, meant for back pain, has issued a voluntary recall of all of its products. The New England Compounding Center in Framingham, Massachusetts, announced in a news release that the move was taken out of an abundance of caution because of the risk of contamination. It says there is no indication that any other products have been contaminated. The Food and Drug Administration had previously told health professionals not to use any products distributed by the center.\n\nThe outbreak is spread across 9 states, the same states previously reported.\n\nMeanwhile, Senator Richard Blumenthal, from Connecticut, is calling for stronger government oversight of so-called 'compounding pharmacies'. Blumenthal said on Sun 7 Oct 2012, that he will be writing to FDA commissioner Margaret Hamburg to ask for stricter scrutiny of such pharmacies. He said the facilities appear to operate in a 'regulatory black hole' and are only marginally overseen by the FDA. Blumenthal says he will be proposing more authority for the FDA in such cases, if needed.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As the number of cases reported continues to grow, it has not been stated if one or more species of _Aspergillus_ is involved and how many cases involved the 2nd fungus, _Exserohilum_. The increase in cases occurring so rapidly is in part due to 'look back' programs to follow up on patients who were treated with the contaminated medication.\n\nThe health care facilities to which the product had been distributed can be found on a list at http://www.cdc.gov/hai/outbreaks/meningitis-facilities-map.html.\n\nAn excellent, long overview, including a discussion on the role of compounding pharmacies, can be found at http://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/07/us/scant-drug-maker-oversight-in-meningitis-outbreak.html?pagewanted=all. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As the number of cases reported continues to grow, it has not been stated if one or more species of _Aspergillus_ is involved and how many cases involved the 2nd fungus, _Exserohilum_. \n\nThe steroid linked to the outbreak has been recalled, and health officials have been scrambling to notify anyone who may have received an injection of it. A patient who received the same type of treatment in North Carolina is sick, and health officials say patients in other states may be affected.\n\nMeningitis is an infection involving the lining of the brain and central nervous system. The outbreak is an unusual type caused by a fungus and is not spread from person to person. Doctors think the infections were caused by contamination of the steroid with the fungus, known as _Aspergillus_. One lot of the medication has been recalled, and more than 700 patients who received the shots at the Nashville clinic, which has closed, have been notified.\n\n[Byline: Denise Grady]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail awaits further information about and the scope of this outbreak, which is presumably related to contamination of the injectable steroid. The local injection of the steroid may well have a promoting effect on growth of the mold.\n\nA previous outbreak due to _Exophiala (Wangiella) dermatitidis_ was reported in MMWR 13 Dec 2002; 51(49): 1109-12 (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5149a1.htm) and on ProMED-mail [see below]. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3BOA.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail awaits further information about and the scope of this outbreak, which is presumably related to contamination of the injectable steroid.
