MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - VIET NAM: (HO CHI MINH CITY)\n********************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-01-09 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Saigon", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "District 7", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1044117", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - USA: (HI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1044117", "date": "2012-02-16 16:29:35", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - USA: (HAWAII)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 Feb 2012\nSource: The Republic [edited]\nhttp://www.therepublic.com/view/story/5c3a3956b9074e2084218608e3cf1cce/HI--Rat-Lungworm-Disease/\n\n\nA 22 year old Minnesota man is recovering from a rare form of meningitis he believes he contracted by eating unwashed fruit in Hawaii. In October [2011], he was working on an organic farm on the Big Island when he ate fruit growing wild. He was hospitalized on 10 Nov 2011 for 7 weeks in Hilo.\n\nThe Honolulu Star-Advertiser (http://bit.ly/znWVbc) reported Mon 13 Feb 2012 that the patient said from his Watertown, Minnesota home that he wants to urge people in Hawaii to carefully wash produce to avoid ingesting slugs or snails that can spread rat lungworm disease.\n\nThe present patient is one of 37 cases confirmed or tested probable for the disease in Hawaii from 2005 to 2011. A Big Island baby is the only fatality since 2005, when the state Department of Health began collecting data.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail can only support the suggestion that fruits and vegetables be thoroughly cleaned before being consumed. - Mod.EP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1CMN.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org> \n\nThe Honolulu Star-Advertiser (http://bit.ly/znWVbc) reported Mon 13 Feb 2012 that the patient said from his Watertown, Minnesota home that he wants to urge people in Hawaii to carefully wash produce to avoid ingesting slugs or snails that can spread rat lungworm disease. \n\nThe present patient is one of 37 cases confirmed or tested probable for the disease in Hawaii from 2005 to 2011.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-02-13 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-10-26 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-11-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "hilo", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Watertown", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1124002", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (CA) lab-acquired, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1124002", "date": "2012-05-05 17:01:47", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA: (CALIFORNIA) LABORATORY-ACQUIRED, FATAL\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 May 2012\nSource: guardian.co.uk [edited]\nhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/may/04/lab-worker-killed-bacteria-vaccine\n\n\nA young research associate killed by a highly virulent strain of meningococcal disease is believed to have contracted the bacteria from the San Francisco lab where he was working on a vaccine against it, public health officials said on Thursday.\n\nUS Centers for Disease Control and Prevention experts are seeking to confirm what they already suspect: that the researcher, 25, died Saturday in an unusual case of a scientist being fatally infected with an agent from his own laboratory. Tom Skinner, a CDC spokesman in Atlanta, said it would test a biopsy sample from the researcher and a sample of the laboratory pathogen he was working with to create fingerprints for each. 'If the fingerprints match, you know it's highly likely he acquired the infection from working in the lab,' he said. 'Someone getting sick and dying from the organism they're working with in the lab is exceedingly rare,' he added.\n\nMeanwhile, dozens of people, including relatives, close friends, medical personnel who treated the researcher and some of his co-workers at the research department of the San Francisco Veterans Affairs Medical Center were being given antibiotics as a precaution.\n\nHarry Lampiris, chief of infectious disease at the San Francisco VA, said it is likely the researcher died as a result of his work with _Neisseria meningitidis_, a strain of bacteria that causes meningococcal disease, which leads to meningitis and bloodstream infections. 'It's our responsibility to assume it's laboratory-associated until proven otherwise,' he said.\n\nSince the 1960s, vaccines have been available for some strains of meningococcal disease. But scientists in the San Francisco lab have spent more than 20 years trying unsuccessfully to develop a vaccine against serogroup B, the strain that killed the researcher. 'It's been like the Holy Grail to develop the vaccine against [serogroup] B,' Lampiris said.\n\nThe researcher died of multiple organ failure caused by meningococcal infection and septic shock, said Eileen Shields, a spokeswoman for the San Francisco Department of Public Health. He died less than a day after becoming ill. The disease can come on quickly with symptoms including high fever, headache, stiff neck, vomiting, rash, confusion and fatigue.\n\nLampiris said coworkers described the researcher, who began work at the lab in October, as 'a very talented, hard-working and fastidious individual. He was a very bright person who was probably at the beginning of a long research career,' he said.\n\nMeningitis, an inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, commonly strikes infants and college students living in dormitories, Lampiris said. He said the researcher had not had contact with either group.\n\nAbout 1000 Americans each year suffer from meningococcal disease, and an estimated 10 to 15% die from it, Skinner said. He could not say how many of the cases resulted from serogroup B.\n\nThe California Division of Occupational Safety and Health is investigating the circumstances of the researcher's death, along with its federal counterpart and the CDC, the city Public Health Department and the San Francisco VA.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRobert Spencer\n<Robert.Spencer@UHBristol.nhs.uk>\n\n\n[The following was extracted from a Journal Watch report on laboratory-acquired meningococcal disease\n(http://infectious-diseases.jwatch.org/cgi/content/full/2002/322/1):\n\n'_Neisseria meningitides_ causes bacterial meningitis and sepsis. Diagnosis is usually made by culturing the organisms on standard microbiologic media. Disease is most often acquired by inhalation, and microbiology personnel may be exposed when processing lab isolates. Following the deaths of 2 microbiologists in 2000 from meningococcal disease after occupational exposure, the CDC posted an Internet request for reports of similar cases of occupationally acquired meningococcal disease [see Laboratory-acquired meningococcal disease - United States, 2000. CDC MMWR 2002 Feb 22; 51(7): 141-4; available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5107a1.htm &\nSejvar JJ, et al: Assessing the risk of laboratory-acquired meningococcal disease. J Clin Microbiol 2005; 43(9): 4811-4; available at http://jcm.asm.org/cgi/reprint/43/9/4811.pdf].\n\n'A total of 16 cases were reported; 8 were from the USA. 9 (56 percent) were caused by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup B and 7 (44 percent) by serogroup C. 8 patients (50 percent) died. Patients were exposed by reading plates (50 percent), making subcultures (50 percent), and performing serogroup identification (38 percent). All patients worked in microbiology labs. The risk for infection among microbiologists is estimated to be 7 times that among the general population (95 percent confidence interval, 1-19).\n\n'Comment: Although meningococcal disease is uncommon, microbiologists working with _N. meningitidis_ should take special care, because their infection risk is elevated, and the case-fatality rate is high. Most risk is likely associated with exposure to pure cultures rather than to patient samples. Precautions should include using a biosafety hood when manipulating isolates and wearing splash-guards and masks. When such protections are not available, isolates should be referred to other labs for serotyping. Vaccination of personnel may also be considered, but current meningococcal vaccines do not protect against disease from _N. meningitidis_ type B and thus will not eliminate risk for infection.\n- C Robert Horsburgh Jr, MD'\n\nThere are five common meningococcal serogroups: A, B, C, W135, and Y, and a sixth type (X) has recently emerged in Africa. Capsular polysaccharide or protein conjugate vaccines can immunize against disease caused by serogroups A, C, W-135, and Y. Serogroup B remains a major cause of severe invasive disease in infants and adolescents worldwide; but, because the serogroup B polysaccharide resembles the human neural cell adhesion molecule, the serogroup B capsular polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic. The MeNZB\u2122 vaccine previously used in New Zealand was developed to protect against a particular strain of meningococcal B disease in New Zealand. However, the MeNZB\u2122 vaccine only protected against this specific B strain, and did not protect against meningococcal A, C, Y or W135 or the many other strains of B.\n\nA new protein-based, 4 component meningococcal serogroup B (4CMenB) vaccine includes the New Zealand outbreak strain\u2019s outer membrane vesicle plus three semiconserved surface-protein antigens: factor-H binding protein variant 1(fHbp1), neisserial heparin binding antigen (NHBA), and neisserial adhesin A (NadA) is under study (Gossger N, Snape MD, Yu L-M, et al. Immunogenicity and tolerability of recombinant serogroup B meningococcal vaccine administered with or without routine infant vaccinations according to different immunization schedules: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA 2012;307(6):573\u2013582; and Santolaya ME, O'Ryan ML, Valenzuela MT, et al. Immunogenicity and tolerability of a multicomponent meningococcal serogroup B (4CMenB) vaccine in healthy adolescents in Chile: a phase 2b/3 randomised, observer-blind, placebo-controlled study. Lancet 2012;379(9816): 617\u2013624). It is hoped it will be a broad-spectrum B vaccine (Cohn AC, Messonnier ME. Inching Toward a Serogroup B Meningococcal Vaccine for Infants. JAMA 2012;307(6):614-615.; and, Stephens DS. Comment. Prevention of serogroup B meningococcal disease. Lancet 2012;379(9816):592\u2013594).\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hcv. - Mod.ML\n]", "summary": "However, the MeNZB\u2122 vaccine only protected against this specific B strain, and did not protect against meningococcal A, C, Y or W135 or the many other strains of B.\n\nA new protein-based, 4 component meningococcal serogroup B (4CMenB) vaccine includes the New Zealand outbreak strain\u2019s outer membrane vesicle plus three semiconserved surface-protein antigens: factor-H binding protein variant 1(fHbp1), neisserial heparin binding antigen (NHBA), and neisserial adhesin Following the deaths of 2 microbiologists in 2000 from meningococcal disease after occupational exposure, the CDC posted an Internet request for reports of similar cases of occupationally acquired meningococcal disease [see Laboratory-acquired meningococcal disease - United States, 2000. \n\nHarry Lampiris, chief of infectious disease at the San Francisco VA, said it is likely the researcher died as a result of his work with _Neisseria meningitidis_, a strain of bacteria that causes meningococcal disease, which leads to meningitis and bloodstream infections. ' Capsular polysaccharide or protein conjugate vaccines can immunize against disease caused by serogroups A, C, W-135, and Y. Serogroup B remains a major cause of severe invasive disease in infants and adolescents worldwide; but, because the serogroup B polysaccharide resembles the human neural cell adhesion molecule, the serogroup B capsular polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic. Feb 22; 51(7): 141-4; available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5107a1.htm &\nSejvar JJ, et al: Assessing the risk of laboratory-acquired meningococcal disease. [The following was extracted from a Journal Watch report on laboratory-acquired meningococcal disease\n(http://infectious-diseases.jwatch.org/cgi/content/full/2002/322/1):\n\n'_Neisseria meningitides_ causes bacterial meningitis and sepsis. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n A young research associate killed by a highly virulent strain of meningococcal disease is believed to have contracted the bacteria from the San Francisco lab where he was working on a vaccine against it, public health officials said on Thursday. \n\n'Comment: Although meningococcal disease is uncommon, microbiologists working with _N. meningitidis_ should take special care, because their infection risk is elevated, and the case-fatality rate is high. \n\nThe researcher died of multiple organ failure caused by meningococcal infection and septic shock, said Eileen Shields, a spokeswoman for the San Francisco Department of Public Health. \n\nAbout 1000 Americans each year suffer from meningococcal disease, and an estimated 10 to 15% die from it, Skinner said. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRobert Spencer\n<Robert.Spencer@UHBristol.nhs.uk>\n\n\n 9 (56 percent) were caused by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup B and 7 (44 percent) by serogroup C. 8 patients (50 percent) died. \n\nUS Centers for Disease Control and Prevention experts are seeking to confirm what they already suspect: that the researcher, 25, died Saturday in an unusual case of a scientist being fatally infected with an agent from his own laboratory. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA: (CALIFORNIA) LABORATORY-ACQUIRED, FATAL\n************************************************************************\n Vaccination of personnel may also be considered, but current meningococcal vaccines do not protect against disease from _N. meningitidis_ type B and thus will not eliminate risk for infection. \n\nSince the 1960s, vaccines have been available for some strains of meningococcal disease. The MeNZB\u2122 vaccine previously used in New Zealand was developed to protect against a particular strain of meningococcal B disease in New Zealand.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-10-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-02-22 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Francisco", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "975124", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Brazil: (BA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=975124", "date": "2011-12-11 05:31:53", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BRAZIL: (BAHIA)\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 9 Dec 2011\nSource: New Strait Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nst.com.my/latest/meningitis-epidemic-in-brazil-s-bahia-state-kills-109-1.17134?localLinksEnabled=false\n\n\nA meningitis epidemic has killed 109 people in the north eastern\nBrazilian state of Bahia since the start of the year, according to a\nreport released by local authorities on Friday [9 Dec 2011]. A total\nof 1670 people have been hit by bacterial meningitis, the most serious\nform of the disease, officials said.\n\nThe mortality rate for cerebrospinal meningitis, characterized by an\ninflammation of the membranes of the brain and spinal cord, is around\neight to 10 per cent of cases.\n\nIn the tourist resort of Costa do Sauipe, dozens of tourists have\ncanceled their bookings as a result of the epidemic, hotel staff told\nthe media.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n\n[The state of Bahia is one of 26 states of Brazil and is located in\nthe north eastern part of the country on the Atlantic coast. The\npopulation of Bahia in 2008 was 14 109 000; the capital is Salvador,\nwith a population of 2.8 million\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahia). The Costa do Sau\u00edpe contains\none of the largest resort hotel developments in Brazil and South\nAmerica (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahia).\n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal meningitis in Brazil in the past have been\ndue to both serogroups B and C (see ProMED-mail post: Meningitis,\nmeningococcal - Brazil 19960125.0182). There was an ongoing outbreak\nof meningococcal meningitis in Bahia in 2009 and 2010: In 2009, there\nwere a total of 2218 cases of meningococcal meningitis with 138\ndeaths; Of that total 178 cases were due to serogroup C with 48 deaths\n(27 per cent case fatality rate) (ProMED-mail post Meningitis,\nmeningococcal - Brazil (02): (BA) RFI 20091212.4229); In 2010, there\nwere 330 cases of meningitis confirmed in Bahia, as of 5 May of that\nyear, of which 39 of were fatal -- 27 of the deaths were caused by\nserogroup C (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Brazil: (BA)\nRFI 20100509.1510).\n\nThe state of Bahia and its capital Salvador can be seen on the map at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia and\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/00ZA. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BRAZIL: (BAHIA)\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In 2009, there\nwere a total of 2218 cases of meningococcal meningitis with 138\ndeaths; Of that total 178 cases were due to serogroup C with 48 deaths\n(27 per cent case fatality rate) (ProMED-mail post Meningitis,\nmeningococcal - Brazil (02): (BA) RFI 20091212.4229); In 2010, there\nwere 330 cases of meningitis confirmed in Bahia, as of 5 May of that\nyear, of which 39 of were fatal -- 27 of the deaths were caused by\nserogroup C (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Brazil: (BA)\nRFI 20100509.1510). \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n\n[The state of Bahia is one of 26 states of Brazil and is located in\nthe north eastern part of the country on the Atlantic coast. The\npopulation of Bahia in 2008 was 14 109 000; the capital is Salvador,\nwith a population of 2.8 million\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahia).", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bahia", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Costa", "country": "Ivory Coast"}, {"location": "Salvador", "country": "El Salvador"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1080222", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal -  Africa", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1080222", "date": "2012-03-25 13:51:23", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] African Meningitis Belt\nDate: Fri 23 Mar 2012\nSoure: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/2012_03_23/en/index.html\n\nFrom 1 Jan 2012 to 11 Mar 2012 (epidemiologic weeks 1-10), outbreaks of meningococcal disease has been reported in 15 districts in Benin, Burkina Faso, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire and Ghana. These outbreaks have been detected as part of the enhanced surveillance in the African Meningitis Belt conducted in 14 countries where a total of 6685 suspected meningitis cases including 639 deaths have been reported.\n\nThe outbreaks are mainly caused by the W135 serogroup of _Neisseria meningitidis_. In Chad, the predominant pathogen is serogroup A, although W135 contributed to an outbreak in 1 district. Type A has always been the leading cause of epidemics in sub-Saharan Africa, outbreaks of W135 have already occurred in the region, especially since 2002.\n\nThe countries are responding to these outbreaks by enhancing surveillance, reinforcing treatment of patients and implementing mass vaccination campaigns. The International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control has approved the release of 117 500 doses of trivalent polysaccharide ACW vaccine to Cote d'Ivoire, 195 540 doses of quadrivalent polysaccharide ACYW vaccine to Ghana and 359 000 doses of conjugate type A vaccine to Chad, along with injection materials and ceftriaxone (an antimicrobial agent) when necessary. The ICG constitutes of United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF), International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) and WHO.\n\nCountry/Cases/Deaths/CFR (percent)/Predominant type/Districts involved\nBenin 381 / 38 / 10 / W135 / 3\nBurkina Faso / 1966 / 212 / 10.8 / W135 / 2\nChad / 1043 / 67 / 6.4 / A / 6\nCote d'Ivoire / 281 / 39 / 13.9 / W135 / 1\nGhana / 369 / 37 / 10 / W135 / 3\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 14 countries in the African Meningitis Belt with enhanced surveillance for meningococcal disease include Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Sudan and Togo. - Mod. LL]\n*****\n[2] Cote d'Ivoire\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2012\nSource: AllAfrica.com [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201203230695.html\n\nAn outbreak of meningitis has claimed the lives of a dozen people in the western town of Toulepleu according to a report by Le Nouveau Reveil. The epidemic, the paper said, is spreading quickly throughout the war-torn city despite the timely reaction of the Ivorian government which has delivered drugs to the area and is undertaking measures to curb the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[3] Uganda\nDate: Fri 23 Mar 2012\nSource: IRIN News [edited]\nhttp://www.irinnews.org/Report/95139/UGANDA-Meningitis-outbreak-kills-16-in-north\n\nAt least 16 people have died in a meningitis epidemic in two districts in northern Uganda over the past 3 weeks, say health officials. Amuru District, where the epidemic is spreading fast, has recorded 33 cases with 14 deaths since 24 Feb 2012, while Oyam District has reported 25 cases with 2 deaths. The districts are just recovering from 2 decades of Lord's Resistance Army insurgency which displaced over 1.8 million people and left thousands dead.\n\n'The deadly disease is spreading. The number could be higher as not all come to health facilities,' Charles Okwera, deputy district health officer in Amuru, told IRIN.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nme\n\n[There are at least 13 serogroups of _Neisseria meningitidis_ based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides; disease is most commonly due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135. All these serogroup polysaccharides except B are immunogenic in humans. Rarely outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis have been related to other serogroups such as type X which has occurred in Niger in 2006 and Burkina Faso in 2010. - Mod. The rat lungworm parasite, also known as\n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_, is passed to slugs from rodent\ndroppings.\n\nDoctors believe that the 21-year-old, who has not been named,\ncontracted the rare rat lungworm parasite from the slugs.\n\nThe disease, which is a type of meningitis, can lead to swelling of\nthe brain and spinal cord and has been known to be fatal. The rat\nlungworm parasite, also known as _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_, is\npassed to slugs from rodent droppings. It can also be caught from raw\nvegetables or fruit which have not been washed properly.\n\nDoctors said the man told them he had swallowed 2 slugs from a Sydney\ngarden after a dare and had then fallen ill. He has spent the past\nmonth in hospital in Sydney but is expected to survive. One relative,\nwho asked not to be named, told the Sydney Morning Herald that the man\nhad spent some time in intensive care.\n\n'It's a real warning for people not to eat a slug.' The New South\nWales health department said that slugs such as the giant African\nsnail could infect humans with bacteria, viruses and parasites.\nSymptoms of the disease, which is not infectious, include headaches, a\nstiff neck, tingling or pain in the skin, fever, nausea, and\nvomiting.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is a well known nematode in Australia\n(Prociv P & Carlisle MS. The spread of _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_\nin Australia. SE Asian J Trop Med Publ Hlth. 2001;32(Suppl2):126-8).\nCiting from the paper: 'Almost 50 years ago, the life cycle was\nelucidated there, in the city of Brisbane, and the 1st human\ninfections probably occurred in 1959. From the 1970s, increasing\nnumbers of autochthonous infections have been reported along the\ncentral east coast of the continent (southeast Queensland and northern\nNew South Wales), involving humans, rats, dogs, horses, flying foxes\nand marsupials,' and 'it seems that virtually all species of native\nand exotic terrestrial molluscs can serve as intermediate hosts.'\n\nThus, it is no surprise that the unfortunate patient was infected, and\nwe hope it will help to remind others to avoid eating raw slugs and\nmolluscs. ProMED has not reported human infections with\n_Angiostrongylus_ from Australia before. To see the ProMED HealthMap\nfor the location of this outbreak, go to:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1kJ8. - Mod.EP]", "summary": "SYDNEY\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n From the 1970s, increasing\nnumbers of autochthonous infections have been reported along the\ncentral east coast of the continent (southeast Queensland and northern\n The rat\nlungworm parasite, also known as _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_, is\npassed to slugs from rodent droppings. The rat lungworm parasite, also known as\n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_, is passed to slugs from rodent\ndroppings. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is a well known nematode in Australia\n Thus, it is no surprise that the unfortunate patient was infected, and\nwe hope it will help to remind others to avoid eating raw slugs and\nmolluscs. The New South\nWales health department said that slugs such as the giant African\nsnail could infect humans with bacteria, viruses and parasites. New South Wales), involving humans, rats, dogs, horses, flying foxes\nand marsupials,' and 'it seems that virtually all species of native\nand exotic terrestrial molluscs can serve as intermediate hosts.' Citing from the paper: 'Almost 50 years ago, the life cycle was\nelucidated there, in the city of Brisbane, and the 1st human\ninfections probably occurred in 1959. One relative,\nwho asked not to be named, told the Sydney Morning Herald that the man\nhad spent some time in intensive care.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2011-03-26 00:00:00", "1959-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Brisbane", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "SYDNEY", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Sydney", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "945942", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, drug-induced - India: (Mumbai)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=945942", "date": "2011-11-12 19:53:35", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, DRUG-INDUCED - INDIA: (MUMBAI)\n******************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2011\nSource: MidDay [edited]\nhttp://www.mid-day.com/news/2011/nov/111111-Hospitals-can-give-you-meningitis.htm\n\n\nOver the past 5 months, 11 patients contracted a rare drug-induced\ntype of the disease at 3 BMC hospitals; doctors believe it could be\nstemming from contaminated samples of anaesthetic drug bupivacaine.\n\nIn a shocking reversal of the natural order of things, 11 patients,\nwho were admitted across 3 civic hospitals over the past 5 months,\nended up contracting a disease which was far more lethal than the ones\nthat they were seeking treatment for.\n\nWithin hours of undergoing their respective procedures, these patients\ndeveloped meningitis -- an acute inflammation of the brain.\nAnaesthesiologists in KEM, Sion and Bhabha hospital, where the\npatients were diagnosed with the infection, suspect that the\nadministration of an anaesthetic drug -- which is injected into the\nspinal cord prior to procedures -- may have been responsible for the\ndisease.\n\nThe suspected drug is bupivacaine, which is supplied to the BMC\nhospitals by Ciron, a Jogeshwari-based pharmaceutical company, as per\nthe civic body's rate contract.\n\nMeningitis is a potentially fatal inflammation of the protective\nmembranes covering the brain and spinal cord. In some rare cases, it\nis drug-induced, caused by the administration of contaminated drugs,\nsuch as anaesthesia.\n\nMid DAY met one of the unlucky 11 [patients], who recently underwent a\nprocedure for ligament reconstruction. Soon after the surgery at KEM\nhospital, however, [the patient] started showing symptoms of high\nfever with chills and a headache. 'He fell unconscious and started\nconvulsing, as a result of which we had to admit him to the ICU,' said\na doctor. 'Ligament reconstruction allows a patient to go home hours\nafter the surgery. But [the patient] ended up with meningitis. The\ndoctors have clearly diagnosed him with post spinal meningitis,' said\na doctor.\n\nPost spinal meningitis is a rare medical complication caused by the\nintroduction of anaesthesia through the spine. The disease may be\ncaused by the mechanism of administration, the contamination of\nequipment used, or the contamination of the drug itself.\n\n[The patient], who has been kept under observation is now undergoing\nrigorous antibiotic treatment to cure him. 'The doctor had told us\nthat I could go home on the very day of the surgery, so I was shocked\nwhen I ended up in the ICU,' said [the patient] who still suffers from\nheadaches.\n\nBesides [this patient], 10 other patients who were admitted to the\nhospitals to be cured of sundry ailments ended up contracting the\ndeadly disease. 3 of them were new mothers, who had undergone\nC-section deliveries. Out of the 11 patients, 4 cases each have been\nreported in Sion and Bhabha hospital, while the 3 others were admitted\nat KEM for treatment.\n\nOf the 4 cases reported at Sion hospital, 2 patients were critical,\nbut were pulled out of infection after rigorous antibiotic treatment.\nThe others are also stable after receiving treatment.\n\nCiron supplies approximately 2 lakh ampules of bupivacaine annually,\nto various civic hospitals. Dr Sanjay Oak, dean of KEM hospital and\ndirector of major civic hospitals, said, 'I have received the\ncomplaints. Anaesthesiologists suspect that an anaesthetic drug used\nduring procedures is causing the disease. We will refer this matter to\nthe FDA. To prevent other casualties, we have stopped using the drugs\nbeing delivered by the company to our hospitals.'\n\nDr Shashikant Wadekar, medical superintendent, Bhabha hospital, said,\n'After our anaesthesiologists brought this anomaly to my notice, we\nstopped using the drug. All the 4 patients had developed post spinal\nmeningitis, but we treated them here. They are now stable.'\n\nDr Sandhya Kamat, dean of Sion hospital, said, 'After doctors\ncontended that the anaesthesia could be responsible for the\nmeningitis, we had sent samples of it to FDA for examination. They\nhave [confirmed] that it is a standard sample of the drug. However, as\na precautionary measure, we have discarded the drug received from our\npharmaceutical company, and have got another sample from a different\ncompany.'\n\nDr Ami Merchant, consultant anaesthesiologist at Lilavati hospital\nsaid, 'Bupivacaine is a very common drug used as spinal anaesthesia.\nIt is very safe. Incidence of drug-induced meningitis is very rare.\nThere are several ways in which one can contract post-operative\nmeningitis. In some cases, doctors fail to follow strict aseptic\nprocedures and equipment, like using antiseptic masks and gear, or\nsterile gloves. In other cases, the contamination of a drug during\nmanufacture can ultimately be responsible for the disease. The\noccurrence of 11 cases over 5 months needs to be studied.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate Sat 12 Nov 2011\nSource: MidDay [edited]\nhttp://www.mid-day.com/news/2011/nov/121111-mumbai-After-meningitis-cases-FDA-inspects-pharma-plant.htm\n\n\nAfter Mid DAY's [report] on 11 patients who contracted meningitis\nafter being administered local anaesthetic drug bupivacaine at 3 civic\nhospitals, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has inspected the\nmanufacturing plant of Ciron Pharmaceuticals, which supplies the drug\nto the hospitals. It is also collecting bupivacaine samples from the\nfacilities for testing them.\n\nCivic doctors said they were shocked over the apathy of the\nadministration. 'Even if there was the slightest of doubt about the\nanaesthetic, the BMC hospitals should have stopped the drugs, instead\nof waiting for 11 patients to get meningitis,' said a senior doctor\nrequesting anonymity.\n\nThey also claimed they were compelled to use the drug despite having\ndoubts as a circular from the director's office prohibited them from\nprescribing it from pharmacies outside. After 2 cases of meningitis\nsurfaced from Sion hospital, the doctors suspected that the drugs had\na role to play in the infection and alerted the FDA, which checked the\ndrugs and gave it a clean chit.\n\nK B Shende, joint commissioner, FDA (drugs), said, 'Sion hospital had\ngiven us the drugs for examination earlier. After testing them, we\nfound them to be of standard quality. But now, we have started a fresh\ninvestigation and we are looking at all possible causes of infection\nas well as contamination.'\n\nHowever, when Sion, Bhabha and KEM hospitals reported cases of post\nspinal meningitis (contamination in the body while administration of\nthe anaesthetic) even after FDA's clean chit, they should have\nimmediately stopped using it, doctors opine.\n\nDr Sanjay Oak, dean of KEM hospital and director of major civic\nhospitals, was unreachable for comment. Rajul Patel, health committee\nchairman, BMC, said, 'We will initiate an inquiry. Doctors and the\ndrug's manufacturing company will have to answer.' Kirti Shah,\ndirector, Ciron pharmaceutical, said, 'We are cooperating with the FDA\nin their investigations.'\n\n--\nCommunicated:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bupivacaine is an anesthetic drug that can be administered by\nepidural or intrathecal injection via lumbar puncture. Intrathecal\ndrug administration means the introduction of a drug by injection into\nthe subarachnoid space around the spinal cord. Drug may also enter the\nsubarachnoid space inadvertently after injection into the epidural\nspace.\n\nMeningitis that follows drug administration by lumbar puncture can be\neither 'septic' or 'aseptic.' The term 'septic meningitis' is used to\nindicate that infectious agents such as bacteria were introduced\nintrathecally at the time of the lumbar puncture. The term 'aseptic\nmeningitis' following intrathecal drug administration usually refers\nto meningitis due to the drug itself or due to a chemical contaminant\nof the drug or the equipment used to administer the drug.\n\nThe clinical presentation of drug-induced aseptic meningitis is very\nsimilar to that of the septic variety, with fever, headache, stiff\nneck, and changes in mental status; the prognosis of drug-induced\naseptic meningitis is generally excellent with complete long-term\nrecovery. A hypersensitivity mechanism is invoked to explain\ndrug-induced aseptic meningitis.\n\nThere are several reports in the literature of drug-induced aseptic\nmeningitis associated with intrathecal administration of bupivacaine\n(http://www.hopkinsguides.com/hopkins/ub/citation/17641986/[Bupivacaine_induced_aseptic_meningitis]_,\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17641986,\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20306069, and\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19653822). It is unclear from the\nnews reports above if the 11 patients suffered from the septic or\naseptic variety. More information to clarify this issue would be\nappreciated.\n\nClusters of cases of septic meningitis have been reported as a rare\ncomplication of a lumbar puncture performed for various reasons.\nMicroorganisms that have caused meningitis following lumbar puncture\ninclude _Streptococcus salivarius_, _Pseudomonas aeruginosa_,\n_Staphylococcus aureus_, _Acinetobacter_ spp., and _Aspergillus_ spp.\n(http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15019223).\n\nThe following is extracted from the U.S. CDC Morbidity and Mortality\nWeekly Report (MMWR). Bacterial Meningitis After Intrapartum Spinal\nAnesthesia --- New York and Ohio, 2008-2009. January 29, 2010 /\n59(03);65-69. Available at:\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5903a1.htm\n\n'The intrathecal space is entered during several diagnostic and\ntherapeutic spinal procedures, including lumbar puncture, myelography,\nand spinal anesthesia, and can occur inadvertently during epidural\nanesthesia. Cases of meningitis have been reported after all of these\nprocedures, although most published cases have involved spinal\nanesthesia (2). A literature review identified only 179 cases of post\nspinal procedure meningitis reported worldwide during 1952--2005 (2);\nin contrast, approximately 300 000 diagnostic lumbar punctures were\nperformed on inpatients in the United States in 2007 alone (4). Post\nspinal procedure meningitis causes serious infections; in one case\nseries, one third of cases resulted in death (5).\n\nPotential sources of bacterial introduction into the intrathecal space\nduring spinal procedures include intrinsic or extrinsic contamination\nof needles, syringes, or injected medications; inadequately\ndecontaminated patient skin; inadequately cleaned health-care provider\nhands; a contaminated sterile field; and droplet transmission from the\nhealth-care provider's upper airway. _Streptococcus salivarius_ and\nother viridans group streptococci, which are normal mouth flora, are\nthe most commonly identified etiologies of meningitis after spinal\nprocedures, accounting for 49 percent and 60 percent of cases in\nliterature reviews (2,6). Droplet transmission of oral flora has been\nsuggested as the most likely route of transmission in reports of\nclusters associated with a single health-care provider (7,8).\n\nReferences:\n-----------\n2. Baer E. Post-dural puncture bacterial meningitis. Anesthesiology\n2006;105: 381--93.\n3. Moen V, Dahlgren N, Irestedt L. Severe neurological complications\nafter central neuraxial blockades in Sweden 1990--1999. Anesthesiology\n2004;101:950--9.\n4. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. Healthcare Cost and\nUtilization Project (HCUPnet). Available at\nhttp://hcupnet.ahrq.gov/hcupnet.jsp. Accessed January 22, 2010.\n5. Pandian JD, Sarada C, Radhakrishnan VV, Kishore A. Iatrogenic\nmeningitis after lumbar puncture-a preventable health hazard. J Hosp\nInfect 2004;56:119--24.\n6. Yaniv LG, Potasman I. Iatrogenic meningitis: an increasing role for\nresistant viridans streptococci? Case report and review of the last 20\nyears. Scand J Infect Dis 2000;32:693--6.\n7. Schneeberger P, Janssen M, Voss A. Alpha-hemolytic streptococci: a\nmajor pathogen of iatrogenic meningitis following lumbar puncture.\nCase reports and a review of the literature. Infection\n1996;24:29--33.\n8. Veringa E, Van Belkum A, Schellekens H. Iatrogenic meningitis by\nStreptococcus salivarius following lumbar puncture. J Hosp Infect\n1995;29:316--8.'\n\nAnother postulated mechanism for post-lumbar puncture meningitis is\nbacteremia at the time of the lumbar puncture; the bacteria in the\npatient's blood gain access to the intrathecal space because of\nmicroscopic bleeding caused by insertion of the needle\n(http://bja.oxfordjournals.org/content/78/6/635.full.pdf).\n\nBrihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) is the civic body that\ngoverns the city of Mumbai. KEM and Sion are teaching hospitals and\nBhabha is a municipal hospital in Mumbai. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of India, showing the location of Mumbai, can be\naccessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1iZ2. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "MENINGITIS, DRUG-INDUCED - INDIA: (MUMBAI)\n******************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n******\n \n\nPotential sources of bacterial introduction into the intrathecal space\nduring spinal procedures include intrinsic or extrinsic contamination\nof needles, syringes, or injected medications; inadequately\ndecontaminated patient skin; inadequately cleaned health-care provider\nhands; a contaminated sterile field; and droplet transmission from the\nhealth-care provider's upper airway. After Mid DAY's [report] on 11 patients who contracted meningitis\nafter being administered local anaesthetic drug bupivacaine at 3 civic\nhospitals, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has inspected the\nmanufacturing plant of Ciron Pharmaceuticals, which supplies the drug\nto the hospitals. \n\nThe clinical presentation of drug-induced aseptic meningitis is very\nsimilar to that of the septic variety, with fever, headache, stiff\nneck, and changes in mental status; the prognosis of drug-induced\naseptic meningitis is generally excellent with complete long-term\nrecovery. In a shocking reversal of the natural order of things, 11 patients,\nwho were admitted across 3 civic hospitals over the past 5 months,\nended up contracting a disease which was far more lethal than the ones\nthat they were seeking treatment for.\n\nWithin hours of undergoing their respective procedures, these patients\ndeveloped meningitis -- an acute inflammation of the brain. \n\nAnother postulated mechanism for post-lumbar puncture meningitis is\nbacteremia at the time of the lumbar puncture; the bacteria in the\npatient's blood gain access to the intrathecal space because of\nmicroscopic bleeding caused by insertion of the needle\n Anaesthesiologists in KEM, Sion and Bhabha hospital, where the\npatients were diagnosed with the infection, suspect that the\nadministration of an anaesthetic drug -- which is injected into the\nspinal cord prior to procedures -- may have been responsible for the\ndisease. _Streptococcus salivarius_ and\nother viridans group streptococci, which are normal mouth flora, are\nthe most commonly identified etiologies of meningitis after spinal\nprocedures, accounting for 49 percent and 60 percent of cases in\nliterature reviews (2,6). The term 'aseptic\nmeningitis' following intrathecal drug administration usually refers\nto meningitis due to the drug itself or due to a chemical contaminant\nof the drug or the equipment used to administer the drug. http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5903a1.htm\n\n'The intrathecal space is entered during several diagnostic and\ntherapeutic spinal procedures, including lumbar puncture, myelography,\nand spinal anesthesia, and can occur inadvertently during epidural\nanesthesia. However, when Sion, Bhabha and KEM hospitals reported cases of post\nspinal meningitis (contamination in the body while administration of\nthe anaesthetic) even after FDA's clean chit, they should have\nimmediately stopped using it, doctors opine. A literature review identified only 179 cases of post\nspinal procedure meningitis reported worldwide during 1952--2005 (2);\nin contrast, approximately 300 000 diagnostic lumbar punctures were\nperformed on inpatients in the United States in 2007 alone (4). Communicated:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bupivacaine is an anesthetic drug that can be administered by\nepidural or intrathecal injection via lumbar puncture. Even if there was the slightest of doubt about the\nanaesthetic, the BMC hospitals should have stopped the drugs, instead\nof waiting for 11 patients to get meningitis,' said a senior doctor\nrequesting anonymity. After 2 cases of meningitis\nsurfaced from Sion hospital, the doctors suspected that the drugs had\na role to play in the infection and alerted the FDA, which checked the\ndrugs and gave it a clean chit. Kirti Shah,\ndirector, Ciron pharmaceutical, said, 'We are cooperating with the FDA\nin their investigations.'\n\n--\n However, as\na precautionary measure, we have discarded the drug received from our\npharmaceutical company, and have got another sample from a different\ncompany.' Communicated by\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n The doctor had told us\nthat I could go home on the very day of the surgery, so I was shocked\nwhen I ended up in the ICU,' said [the patient] who still suffers from\nheadaches. (http://www.hopkinsguides.com/hopkins/ub/citation/17641986/[Bupivacaine_induced_aseptic_meningitis]_,\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17641986,\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20306069, and\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19653822). Over the past 5 months, 11 patients contracted a rare drug-induced\ntype of the disease at 3 BMC hospitals; doctors believe it could be\nstemming from contaminated samples of anaesthetic drug bupivacaine. \n\nThere are several reports in the literature of drug-induced aseptic\nmeningitis associated with intrathecal administration of bupivacaine\n \n\nDr Sandhya Kamat, dean of Sion hospital, said, 'After doctors\ncontended that the anaesthesia could be responsible for the\nmeningitis, we had sent samples of it to FDA for examination. Intrathecal\ndrug administration means the introduction of a drug by injection into\nthe subarachnoid space around the spinal cord. \n\nDr Shashikant Wadekar, medical superintendent, Bhabha hospital, said,\n'After our anaesthesiologists brought this anomaly to my notice, we\nstopped using the drug. Cases of meningitis have been reported after all of these\nprocedures, although most published cases have involved spinal\nanesthesia (2). In some rare cases, it\nis drug-induced, caused by the administration of contaminated drugs,\nsuch as anaesthesia. Post\nspinal procedure meningitis causes serious infections; in one case\nseries, one third of cases resulted in death (5). The\ndoctors have clearly diagnosed him with post spinal meningitis,' said\na doctor. \n\nThey also claimed they were compelled to use the drug despite having\ndoubts as a circular from the director's office prohibited them from\nprescribing it from pharmacies outside. The suspected drug is bupivacaine, which is supplied to the BMC\nhospitals by Ciron, a Jogeshwari-based pharmaceutical company, as per\nthe civic body's rate contract. The\noccurrence of 11 cases over 5 months needs to be studied.'\n\n--\n The term 'septic meningitis' is used to\nindicate that infectious agents such as bacteria were introduced\nintrathecally at the time of the lumbar puncture. Out of the 11 patients, 4 cases each have been\nreported in Sion and Bhabha hospital, while the 3 others were admitted\nat KEM for treatment. The disease may be\ncaused by the mechanism of administration, the contamination of\nequipment used, or the contamination of the drug itself. Dr Sanjay Oak, dean of KEM hospital and\ndirector of major civic hospitals, said, 'I have received the\ncomplaints. Besides [this patient], 10 other patients who were admitted to the\nhospitals to be cured of sundry ailments ended up contracting the\ndeadly disease. But now, we have started a fresh\ninvestigation and we are looking at all possible causes of infection\nas well as contamination.'\n\n Drug may also enter the\nsubarachnoid space inadvertently after injection into the epidural\nspace. In some cases, doctors fail to follow strict aseptic\nprocedures and equipment, like using antiseptic masks and gear, or\nsterile gloves. ' Droplet transmission of oral flora has been\nsuggested as the most likely route of transmission in reports of\nclusters associated with a single health-care provider (7,8).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1990-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-01-29 00:00:00", "1952-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-01-22 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumbai", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Jogeshwari", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Anesthesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Radhakrishnan VV", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "946642", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, drug-induced - India (02): Mumbai, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=946642", "date": "2011-11-13 21:11:19", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, DRUG-INDUCED - INDIA (02): MUMBAI, COMMENT\n******************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 13 Nov 2011\nFrom: Nick Beeching <nbeeching@blueyonder.co.uk> [edited]\n\n\nThe recent reports of possible drug-related meningitis in India\nhighlight the possibility of introduction of bacteria at various\nstages in drug manufacture, storage and administration, including a\nbrief mention of contamination of syringes and needles. A recent\nepisode in Sri Lanka demonstrated the risk of iatrogenic fungal\ninfection of the meninges and emphasised the importance of safe\nwarehousing of basic equipment.\n\nIn 2005, an outbreak of _Aspergillus fumigatus_ meningitis resulted in\nthe deaths of 3 of 6 obstetric patients following spinal anaesthesia\nat 2 hospitals in Colombo, Sri Lanka (1-4). _Aspergillus_ meningitis\nwas also implicated in 5/27 patients with sporadic iatrogenic\nmeningitis in 2 Indian referral hospitals over a prolonged period (5),\nand fungal contamination of drugs has previously been reported by\nProMED-mail [Fungal meningitis, contaminated drug - USA (03)\n20021212.6046; Fungal meningitis, contaminated drug - USA: alert (02)\n20021117.5831 Fungal meningitis, contaminated drug - USA: alert\n20021002.5444].\n\nThe Colombo outbreak was linked to contamination of poorly stored\nsyringes, needles and other equipment donated from many sources after\nthe tsunami. The precise point at which fungal contamination happened\nwas not identified, but the equipment had been distributed to both the\nhospitals involved. Once the source was identified and remaining\nstocks destroyed, there were no further cases.\n\nThe dangers of poor quality control of material donated from multiple\nsources in disaster settings and of incorrect storage should always be\nremembered.\n\nReferences:\n-------------\n1. Gunaratne PS, Wijeyaratne CN, Chandrasiri P, Sivakumaran S,\nSellahawa K, Perera P, et al. An outbreak of Aspergillus meningitis\nfollowing spinal anaesthesia for caesarean section in Sri Lanka: a\npost-tsunami effect? Ceylon Med J 2006 Dec;51(4):137-42.\n2. Gunaratne PS, Wijeyaratne CN, Seneviratne HR. Aspergillus\nmeningitis in Sri Lanka--a post-tsunami effect? N Engl J Med 2007 Feb\n15;356(7):754-6.\n3. Rodrigo N, Perera KN, Ranwala R, Jayasinghe S, Warnakulasuriya A,\nHapuarachchi S. Aspergillus meningitis following spinal anaesthesia\nfor caesarean section in Colombo, Sri Lanka. Int J Obstet Anesth 2007\nJul;16(3):256-60. Epub 2006 Sep 1.\n4. Lokuhetty MD, Wijesinghe HD, Weerasundra B, Dayapula A. Iatrogenic\nAspergillus infection of the central nervous system in a pregnant\nwoman. Indian J Pathol Microbiol 2009 Jul-Sep;52(3):427-9.\n5. Pandian JD, Sarada C, Radhakrishnan VV, Kishore A. Iatrogenic\nmeningitis after lumbar puncture-a preventable health hazard. J Hosp\nInfect 2004 Feb;56(2):119-24.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Nick Beeching\nSenior Lecturer, Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine\nLiverpool, UK\n<nbeeching@blueyonder.co.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Beeching for his references and commentary on\nfungal meningitis after lumbar puncture due to contaminated equipment.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "MENINGITIS, DRUG-INDUCED - INDIA (02): MUMBAI, COMMENT\n******************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n _Aspergillus_ meningitis\nwas also implicated in 5/27 patients with sporadic iatrogenic\nmeningitis in 2 Indian referral hospitals over a prolonged period (5),\nand fungal contamination of drugs has previously been reported by\nProMED-mail The recent reports of possible drug-related meningitis in India\nhighlight the possibility of introduction of bacteria at various\nstages in drug manufacture, storage and administration, including a\nbrief mention of contamination of syringes and needles. Senior Lecturer, Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine\nLiverpool, UK\n<nbeeching@blueyonder.co.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Beeching for his references and commentary on\nfungal meningitis after lumbar puncture due to contaminated equipment. A recent\nepisode in Sri Lanka demonstrated the risk of iatrogenic fungal\ninfection of the meninges and emphasised the importance of safe\nwarehousing of basic equipment. In 2005, an outbreak of _Aspergillus fumigatus_ meningitis resulted in\nthe deaths of 3 of 6 obstetric patients following spinal anaesthesia\nat 2 hospitals in Colombo, Sri Lanka (1-4). An outbreak of Aspergillus meningitis\nfollowing spinal anaesthesia for caesarean section in Sri Lanka: a\npost-tsunami effect? The Colombo outbreak was linked to contamination of poorly stored\nsyringes, needles and other equipment donated from many sources after\nthe tsunami. Rodrigo N, Perera KN, Ranwala R, Jayasinghe S, Warnakulasuriya A,\nHapuarachchi S. Aspergillus meningitis following spinal anaesthesia\nfor caesarean section in Colombo, Sri Lanka. The precise point at which fungal contamination happened\nwas not identified, but the equipment had been distributed to both the\nhospitals involved. N Engl J Med 2007 Feb\n15;356(7):754-6.\n 20021212.6046; Fungal meningitis, contaminated drug - USA: alert (02)\n20021117.5831 Fungal meningitis, contaminated drug - USA: alert\n20021002.5444].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pathol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fungal", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}, {"location": "Radhakrishnan VV", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Perera P", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MUMBAI", "country": "India"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colombo", "country": "Sri Lanka"}, {"location": "Sri Lanka", "country": "Sri Lanka"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "813259", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (QL) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=813259", "date": "2011-08-09 10:50:45", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (02): (QUEENSLAND) FATAL\n**************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 1 Aug 2011\nSource: News.com.au, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report\n[edited]\nhttp://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/queensland-meningococcal-student-to-recover/story-e6frfku0-1226105791520\n\n\nA North Queensland university student who contracted meningococcal\ndisease on campus is expected to recover. The assurance comes after an\n18 year old medical student was found dead in his room at the Catholic\nCollege at James Cook University in Townsville on Wednesday night [27\nJul 2011]. Then a friend who lived on the same floor at the college\nalso started showing symptoms of the disease and was admitted to\nTownsville Hospital on Friday [29 Jul 2011].\n\nQueensland Health's public health medical officer in Townsville, Dr\nSteven Donohue, said that he visited the student last night [31 Jul\n2011]. 'He's going to be fine,' Dr Donohue told the ABC. 'Fortunately\nhe presented very early.'\n\nQueensland Health has offered clearance antibiotics to those who had\nclose contact with the 2 students.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 8 Aug 2011\nSource: ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)/Australian\nAssociated Press (AAP) [edited]\nhttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-08-07/qld-toddler-hospitalised-meningococcal/2828324\n\n\nA 17 month old boy has become the latest person to fall ill with\nmeningococcal [disease] in Queensland's north following the death of a\nuniversity student last week [27 Jul 2011].\n\nQueensland Health confirmed the toddler had tested positive for the\nbacteria but said the child was in a stable condition and is\nrecovering in Cairns Base Hospital.\n\nA total of 6 cases of the disease have been confirmed in north and far\nnorth Queensland in recent weeks, including an 18 year old, who was\nfound dead in his bed at James Cook University's Townsville campus\nlast week.\n\nA 19 year old woman is also recovering in Cairns Base Hospital while\nan elderly woman who fell ill while holidaying on Magnetic Island\nremains in a critical but stable condition.\n\nThe other cases involved a 2nd JCU [James Cook University] student and\na young child in Townsville.\n\nAnother 2 people in Cairns are awaiting final test results for the\nbacteria after initial laboratory tests came back negative.\n\nTownsville Public Health Unit physician Dr Steven Donohue says there\nare no connections between the cases. He has moved to assure residents\nthe bacterium is not common. 'The risk to the general community is\nvery low as the disease is not highly infectious, and is generally\nonly spread in situations of close and prolonged contact, for example\nin household settings,' he said.\n\nMeningococci infect the area around the brainstem and spinal cord and\ncan cause blood poisoning. The disease is uncommon and has similar\nsymptoms to the flu.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDenis Green\n<legion@q-net.net.au>\n\n[For a discussion of meningococcal disease, see ProMED-mail post:\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (CO) fatal 20100625.2115.\n\nThe 1st news release above confirms that the 2 Townsville medical\nstudents likely had close contact, being friends and living on the\nsame college dormitory floor. However, the 2nd news release says there\nis a 3rd case in the city of Townsville in a 'young child'. A 4th case\nin an 'elderly woman' occurred on Magnetic Island, which is 5 miles (8\nkm) offshore from Townsville. The island is accessible from Townsville\nby ferry and is considered a suburb of Townsville\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_Island).\n\nWe are told in the 2nd news release that there are no connections\namong these cases, but that is obviously not true for the 2 medical\nstudents. Thus, there are 3 confirmed cases of meningococcal disease\nin Townsville (population of about 150 000) during a period of 3\nmonths or less in people who live in the same community, but have no\nclose contact with each other; however, the primary disease attack\nrate is less than 10 cases per 100 000 persons; a community-based\noutbreak of meningococcal disease is defined by a primary disease\nattack rate of 10 or more cases per 100 000 persons\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm).\n\nThere are at least 2 more cases of meningococcal disease in Cairns\n(population 150 000). Townsville and Cairns are cities about 175 miles\n(281 km) apart in the state of Queensland\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Townsville and\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cairns), on the northeastern coast of\nAustralia. The medical school of James Cook University is based in\nTownsville during the 1st 4 years; in the final 2 years, the majority\nof students relocate to other teaching sites such as Cairns, Mackay,\nand Darwin\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Cook_University_School_of_Medicine_and_Dentistry).\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Queensland that shows\nTownsville can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/15NZ. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Thus, there are 3 confirmed cases of meningococcal disease\nin Townsville (population of about 150 000) during a period of 3\nmonths or less in people who live in the same community, but have no\nclose contact with each other; however, the primary disease attack\nrate is less than 10 cases per 100 000 persons; a community-based\noutbreak of meningococcal disease is defined by a primary disease\nattack rate of 10 or more cases per 100 000 persons\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm). MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (02): (QUEENSLAND) FATAL\n**************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDenis Green\n<legion@q-net.net.au>\n\n[For a discussion of meningococcal disease, see ProMED-mail post:\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (CO) fatal 20100625.2115. The medical school of James Cook University is based in\nTownsville during the 1st 4 years; in the final 2 years, the majority\nof students relocate to other teaching sites such as Cairns, Mackay,\nand Darwin\n \n\nA total of 6 cases of the disease have been confirmed in north and far\nnorth Queensland in recent weeks, including an 18 year old, who was\nfound dead in his bed at James Cook University's Townsville campus\nlast week. The assurance comes after an\n18 year old medical student was found dead in his room at the Catholic\nCollege at James Cook University in Townsville on Wednesday night [27\nJul 2011]. The risk to the general community is\nvery low as the disease is not highly infectious, and is generally\nonly spread in situations of close and prolonged contact, for example\nin household settings,' he said. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nWe are told in the 2nd news release that there are no connections\namong these cases, but that is obviously not true for the 2 medical\nstudents. \n\nA 19 year old woman is also recovering in Cairns Base Hospital while\nan elderly woman who fell ill while holidaying on Magnetic Island\nremains in a critical but stable condition. \n\nQueensland Health's public health medical officer in Townsville, Dr\nSteven Donohue, said that he visited the student last night [31 Jul\n2011]. ' The 1st news release above confirms that the 2 Townsville medical\nstudents likely had close contact, being friends and living on the\nsame college dormitory floor. \n\nQueensland Health confirmed the toddler had tested positive for the\nbacteria but said the child was in a stable condition and is\nrecovering in Cairns Base Hospital. Then a friend who lived on the same floor at the college\nalso started showing symptoms of the disease and was admitted to\nTownsville Hospital on Friday [29 Jul 2011].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Townsville", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "875862", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - New Zealand: (NO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=875862", "date": "2011-09-18 11:18:35", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NEW ZEALAND: (NORTHLAND)\n****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 17 Sep 2011\nSource: The Northern Advocate [edited]\nhttp://www.northernadvocate.co.nz/news/38000-to-be-vaccinated-in-3-months/1107145/\n\n\nHealth officials hope a mass vaccination programme aimed at 44 000\npeople aged between 1-20 will prevent the spread of the deadly\nmeningococcal C disease in Northland after 2 deaths in the past\nmonth.\n\nTwo Northlanders have died from meningococcal C disease, a\none-year-old from Ruakaka and [another person] from Whangarei, and 4\nother people have been confirmed as having type C, while 2 others had\ntype B meningococcal [disease].\n\nNorthland medical officer of health Clair Mills said the situation was\nnow a community outbreak and that concern over the spread of the\ndisease and its random nature -- there are no known links between any\nof the cases -- had prompted the mass vaccination campaign.\n\nDr Mills said the programme would target the highest risk group of\nthose aged between 1-20, with the most at risk, high school children,\nto be the 1st to receive the free meningococcal C vaccination.\n\nThose out-of-school-aged under 20 will be able to get the vaccine from\ntheir GP, or attend special clinics in their area, as soon as vaccine\nbecomes available. The DHB [District Health Boards] will liaise with\ncommunity groups, employers and tertiary institutions to get to that\ngroup.\n\n'Initially, the programme will be offered to high school students in\nthe highest risk areas progressively over the 2 weeks from 26 Sep\n2011,' Dr Mills said. 'With exams coming up, it's important to get\nthat group vaccinated before the exam season starts.' The 1st schools\ninvolved are Kamo High, Bream Bay College, Whangarei Boys' and Girls'\nHigh, Whangaroa College, Kerikeri High, Springbank, Northland College,\nTe Kura Kaupapa O Kaikohe, Okaihau College, Bay of Islands College,\nTaipa Area School, and Kaikohe Christian School.\n\nDr Mills said there are usually between 0-2 cases of type C per year\nin Northland, while in previous years, meningococcal type B disease\nwas the most common type in the region. 'The current situation is,\ntherefore, consistent with a community outbreak. Following expert\nadvice and in consultation with the Ministry of Health, we have\ndecided to launch a vaccination campaign to help control this outbreak\nand prevent more cases of disease,' she said.\n\nThe DHB hoped to vaccinate about 35 000 of those in the 1-20 age group\nbefore 16 Dec 2011 and was optimistic it would reach this target. Dr\nMills said the disease was serious and had major health implications,\nand she did not think there would be widespread opposition to the\nvaccination campaign. The DHB would not say how much the vaccination\ncampaign would cost or who was paying for it -- the DHB or the\nMinistry of Health -- with discussions between the 2 organisations\nover that issue ongoing.\n\nThose outside the targeted age group could buy type C vaccinations\nfrom their doctor, but the immunisation campaign is likely to take up\nmost of the country's available stock. Once new stock arrives from 6\nOct 2011, the campaign is expected to be offered to primary schools\nfrom the beginning of November 2011.\n\n'Vaccination offered through a school-based programme is the most\neffective way of ensuring that as many students as possible are\nprotected against the disease,' Dr Mills said. The vaccination\ncampaign will be launched with extensive media advertising, public\nrelations, a poster campaign and widespread communication with\nschools, parents and caregivers, students, and health professionals in\nNorthland.\n\n[Byline: Mike Dinsdale]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Meningococcal disease is caused by the bacterium _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_. There are several different pathogenic serogroups of\nmeningococcal bacteria including groups A, B, C, Y and W135. These\ngroups of bacteria can be further divided into specific strains.\nBetween 1991 and 2004, New Zealand experienced epidemic levels of\nmeningococcal disease due to a particular strain of group B\nmeningococcus (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/).\nDuring the outbreak, the number of cases grew to about 400 cases each\nyear, with 80 of every 100 cases caused by the epidemic strain. There\nwere over 5300 cases of meningococcal disease reported, with 215\ndeaths\n(http://www.southerncross.co.nz/AboutTheGroup/HealthResources/MedicalLibrary/tabid/178/vw/1/ItemID/143/Meningococcal-Disease.aspx).\nThe epidemic disproportionately affected Maori and Pacific peoples,\nand the greatest number of cases consistently occurred in the upper\nNorth Island\n(http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/Files/immunise-handbook/$file/16MeningococcalInvDisease.pdf).\nThe MeNZB vaccine was developed to curb this epidemic due to the\nparticular group B strain. However, this vaccine only protected\nagainst the particular strain that was causing the epidemic, not any\nother group or strain of meningococcus.\n\nThe news release above states that the current outbreak in the\nNorthland region of New Zealand is caused by serogroup C _N.\nmeningitidis_. The Northland region, one of the 16 regions of New\nZealand, is the northernmost of New Zealand's administrative regions,\nwith an estimated population of 157 300 in 2010, approximately 1/3rd\nof which are Maori (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northland_Region).\n\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Zealand can be\naccessed at http://healthmap.org/promed?v=-42.4,172.7,5. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NEW ZEALAND: (NORTHLAND)\n****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The vaccination\ncampaign will be launched with extensive media advertising, public\nrelations, a poster campaign and widespread communication with\nschools, parents and caregivers, students, and health professionals in\nNorthland. \n\nNorthland medical officer of health Clair Mills said the situation was\nnow a community outbreak and that concern over the spread of the\ndisease and its random nature -- there are no known links between any\nof the cases -- had prompted the mass vaccination campaign. \n\nTwo Northlanders have died from meningococcal C disease, a\none-year-old from Ruakaka and [another person] from Whangarei, and 4\nother people have been confirmed as having type C, while 2 others had\ntype B meningococcal [disease]. \n\n\nHealth officials hope a mass vaccination programme aimed at 44 000\npeople aged between 1-20 will prevent the spread of the deadly\nmeningococcal C disease in Northland after 2 deaths in the past\nmonth. Following expert\nadvice and in consultation with the Ministry of Health, we have\ndecided to launch a vaccination campaign to help control this outbreak\nand prevent more cases of disease,' she said. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Meningococcal disease is caused by the bacterium _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_. Dr\nMills said the disease was serious and had major health implications,\nand she did not think there would be widespread opposition to the\nvaccination campaign. The DHB would not say how much the vaccination\ncampaign would cost or who was paying for it -- the DHB or the\nMinistry of Health -- with discussions between the 2 organisations\nover that issue ongoing. There\nwere over 5300 cases of meningococcal disease reported, with 215\ndeaths\n(http://www.southerncross.co.nz/AboutTheGroup/HealthResources/MedicalLibrary/tabid/178/vw/1/ItemID/143/Meningococcal-Disease.aspx). The epidemic disproportionately affected Maori and Pacific peoples,\nand the greatest number of cases consistently occurred in the upper\nNorth Island\n(http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/Files/immunise-handbook/$file/16MeningococcalInvDisease.pdf). The Northland region, one of the 16 regions of New\nZealand, is the northernmost of New Zealand's administrative regions,\nwith an estimated population of 157 300 in 2010, approximately 1/3rd\nof which are Maori (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northland_Region). \n\nDr Mills said the programme would target the highest risk group of\nthose aged between 1-20, with the most at risk, high school children,\nto be the 1st to receive the free meningococcal C vaccination.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2011-12-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand 's", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Northland", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Ruakaka", "country": "New Zealand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "804163", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (QL) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=804163", "date": "2011-08-01 10:31:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA: (QUEENSLAND) FATAL\n*********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 31 Jul 2011\nSource: ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) [edited]\nhttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-07-31/meningococcal-death-in-queensland/2817688\n\n\nOne university student is dead and a 2nd is in hospital after an\noutbreak of meningococcal disease in Townsville in north Queensland\n[Australia]. An 18-year-old medical student was found dead in his\nbedroom at James Cook University on Wednesday [27 Jul 2011].\n\nThe dean of medicine and dentistry, professor Richard Murray, says the\nstudent was from Western Australia and was planning a career in\nhumanitarian medicine. He says a memorial service was held on Saturday\n[30 Jul 2011]. 'This is a fine, very talented, and widely admired and\nliked young man,' he said. Another medical student from the college\nhas also tested positive for the infection. The university says he is\nresponding well to treatment.\n\nProfessor Murray says people who have been in close contact with the\nmen have been interviewed and given antibiotics. 'Certainly with the\nwidened antibiotic clearance we wouldn't be expecting to see any\nfurther cases; however, vigilance of anybody really is important,' he\nsaid. Students and staff have also been offered counselling.\n\nMeningococci invade the area around the brainstem and spinal cord and\ncan also cause blood poisoning. In the past 4 years there have been\nbetween 2 and 4 deaths in the state annually.\n\nMeningococcal [disease] is uncommon and has similar symptoms to the\nflu. So far this year [2011] there have been 38 cases in Queensland;\nbut it is believed this is the 1st death. The dead student's family\nhas taken their son's body home to Perth. Queensland premier Anna\nBligh says the cases are concerning. 'It is very worrying. It is\ntragic to see a young 18-year-old lose their [sic] life to this awful\ndisease,' she said. 'That's why Queensland Health is, as of right now,\nout tracing every contact that they can so that we can understand\nwhere this disease may be operating.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDenis Green\n<legion@q-net.net.au>\n\n[For a discussion of meningococcal disease, see ProMED-mail post\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (CO) fatal 20100625.2115.\n\nLiving in college dormitories has been associated with a higher risk\nfor meningococcal disease. However, the occurrence of 2 cases of\nmeningococcal disease in a short span of time at the medical school of\nJames Cook University in Townsville fails to meet the US CDC\ndefinition of an organization-based outbreak, which is the occurrence\nof 3 or more confirmed or probable cases of meningococcal disease\nduring a period of less than or equal to 3 months in persons who have\na common affiliation but no close contact with each other, resulting\nin a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per 100 000\npersons\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm).\nNevertheless, the attack rate of 2 cases among the 440 medical\nstudents located in Townsville\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Cook_University_School_of_Medicine_and_Dentistry)\nis about 50 times greater than a primary disease attack rate in an\noutbreak of at least 10 cases per 100 000 persons.\n\nNo information of the meningococcal vaccination status of the cases is\ngiven in the news release above. The CDC's Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices (ACIP) recommends routine vaccination with\nquadrivalent (serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135) meningococcal conjugate\nvaccines (Menveo, Novartis; and Menactra, Sanofi Pasteur) of\npreviously unvaccinated college freshmen, particularly those living in\ndormitories, for primary prophylaxis of meningococcal disease\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/rr/rr5407.pdf), and also recommends\nvaccination of all adolescents at age 11 or 12 years, or at ages 13\nthrough 18 years if not previously vaccinated.
