In addition, a booster\ndose of quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine is recommended at\nage 16 years to protect teenagers through the peak ages of 16 to 21\nyears, because additional data on bactericidal antibody persistence,\ntrends in meningococcal disease epidemiology in the United States, and\nvaccine effectiveness have indicated many adolescents might not be\nprotected for more than 5 years\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6003a3.htm).\n\nTownsville is a city on the northeastern coast of Australia, in the\nstate of Queensland, with a 2006 census population of 143 328\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Townsville). The medical school of\nJames Cook University is based in Townsville during the 1st 4 years;\nin the final 2 years, the majority of students relocate to other\nteaching sites such as Cairns, Mackay, and Darwin\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Cook_University_School_of_Medicine_and_Dentistry).\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Queensland that shows\nTownsville can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/15NZ. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "However, the occurrence of 2 cases of\nmeningococcal disease in a short span of time at the medical school of\nJames Cook University in Townsville fails to meet the US CDC\ndefinition of an organization-based outbreak, which is the occurrence\nof 3 or more confirmed or probable cases of meningococcal disease\nduring a period of less than or equal to 3 months in persons who have\na common affiliation but no close contact with each other, resulting\nin a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per 100 000\npersons\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm). The CDC's Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices (ACIP) recommends routine vaccination with\nquadrivalent (serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135) meningococcal conjugate\nvaccines (Menveo, Novartis; and Menactra, Sanofi Pasteur) of\npreviously unvaccinated college freshmen, particularly those living in\ndormitories, for primary prophylaxis of meningococcal disease\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/rr/rr5407.pdf), and also recommends\nvaccination of all adolescents at age 11 or 12 years, or at ages 13\nthrough 18 years if not previously vaccinated. In addition, a booster\ndose of quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine is recommended at\nage 16 years to protect teenagers through the peak ages of 16 to 21\nyears, because additional data on bactericidal antibody persistence,\ntrends in meningococcal disease epidemiology in the United States, and\nvaccine effectiveness have indicated many adolescents might not be\nprotected for more than 5 years\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6003a3.htm). That's why Queensland Health is, as of right now,\nout tracing every contact that they can so that we can understand\nwhere this disease may be operating.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDenis Green\n<legion@q-net.net.au>\n\n[For a discussion of meningococcal disease, see ProMED-mail post\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (CO) fatal 20100625.2115. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA: (QUEENSLAND) FATAL\n*********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Nevertheless, the attack rate of 2 cases among the 440 medical\nstudents located in Townsville\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Cook_University_School_of_Medicine_and_Dentistry)\nis about 50 times greater than a primary disease attack rate in an\noutbreak of at least 10 cases per 100 000 persons. The medical school of\nJames Cook University is based in Townsville during the 1st 4 years;\nin the final 2 years, the majority of students relocate to other\nteaching sites such as Cairns, Mackay, and Darwin\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Cook_University_School_of_Medicine_and_Dentistry). Certainly with the\nwidened antibiotic clearance we wouldn't be expecting to see any\nfurther cases; however, vigilance of anybody really is important,' he\nsaid. http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-07-31/meningococcal-death-in-queensland/2817688\n\n\nOne university student is dead and a 2nd is in hospital after an\noutbreak of meningococcal disease in Townsville in north Queensland\n It is\ntragic to see a young 18-year-old lose their [sic] life to this awful\ndisease,' she said. ' The dean of medicine and dentistry, professor Richard Murray, says the\nstudent was from Western Australia and was planning a career in\nhumanitarian medicine. Townsville is a city on the northeastern coast of Australia, in the\nstate of Queensland, with a 2006 census population of 143 328\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Townsville).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Townsville", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Perth", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "728785", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: (YO), susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=728785", "date": "2011-05-24 21:11:26", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA: (YOBE), SUSPECTED\n******************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 23 May 2011\nSource: allafrica.com [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201105230763.html\n\n\nAccording to a report by the state's Epidemiological Department in\nDamaturu yesterday, Yobe State recorded 322 cases of cerebrospinal\nmeningitis across the 17 local government areas of the state last\nyear, and 22 persons died from the disease. It added that 4 persons\ndied out of the 51 cases that were reported between January and May\nthis year [2011].\n\nReacting to the report, the Director General of the Yobe State Health\nCare Management Board, Alhaji Lawal Ibrahim said the board had\nprocured preposition drugs on measles, meningitis and other related\ndiseases and that they had already been distributed to the 6\nepidemiological zonal offices in the state.\n\nHe said that government has also embarked on a campaign against\novercrowding, personal and environmental hygiene, saying those were\npreventive measures against disease outbreak in the state.\n\n[Byline: Kabir Matazu]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the above news release does not specify the microbial cause\nof the meningitis outbreak in Nigeria, the sub-Saharan region of\nAfrica is plagued yearly by large epidemics of meningococcal\nmeningitis. This region, known as the 'Meningitis Belt,' stretches\nfrom the east to the west coast of Africa, and includes Nigeria, as\nwell as Burkina Faso, Benin, Chad, Democratic Republic of the Congo,\nEthiopia, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Kenya, Mali, Niger, Sudan, Togo, and\nUganda\n(http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm). The\nmeningitis outbreaks occur in the dry season (December to June), and\nevery 8-12 years large outbreaks occur\n(http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx). Attack rates\nduring these cyclic epidemics of meningitis range from 100 to 800 per\n100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates as\nhigh as 1000 per 100 000 (World Health Organization: Meningococcal\nmeningitis fact sheet:\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/sudan/pdf/FactSheet-Meningitis.pdf).\n\nEpidemic thresholds are used to confirm the emergence of an epidemic\nin order to step up control measures, that is, mass vaccination and\nappropriate case management. For definitions of epidemic thresholds,\nsee\nhttp://www.who.int/disasters/repo/6618.doc.\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an\nattempt to induce herd immunity, whereby transmission is blocked when\na critical percentage of the population has been vaccinated (see\nhttp://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). In 2009,\nmeningococcal serogroups A and W135 were involved in outbreaks in\nNigeria (see ProMED mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03)\n20090509.1731). These serogroups cause meningitis that is potentially\nvaccine-preventable. However, in 2010, a new strain (serogroup X) of\nmeningococcal meningitis emerged in Burkina Faso that led to huge\noutbreaks in that country, with 46 percent (6/13) of the regions in\nthe country being at epidemic level. Serogroup X is one of those for\nwhich no vaccine exists. Niger, which borders the Yobe State of\nNigeria, also experienced cases due to serogroup X in 2010 and\nexperienced an epidemic of meningitis due to this strain in 2006 (see\nProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa (02): WHO\nmeningitis region. 20100426.1343)\n\nIn addition, _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ is a pathogen also known to\ncause outbreaks of meningitis in the African 'meningitis' region (see\nProMED-mail post Meningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis\nregion 20100213.0507).\n\nYobe State is located in northeastern Nigeria that borders on Niger.\nDamaturu is the capital of Yobe State, which has a population of\n88,014 at the 2006 census (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damaturu).\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6. A map of the African\nbacterial meningitis belt can be found at\nhttp://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Attack rates\nduring these cyclic epidemics of meningitis range from 100 to 800 per\n100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates as\nhigh as 1000 per 100 000 (World Health Organization: Meningococcal\nmeningitis fact sheet:\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/sudan/pdf/FactSheet-Meningitis.pdf). MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA: (YOBE), SUSPECTED\n******************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n This region, known as the 'Meningitis Belt,' stretches\nfrom the east to the west coast of Africa, and includes Nigeria, as\nwell as Burkina Faso, Benin, Chad, Democratic Republic of the Congo,\nEthiopia, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Kenya, Mali, Niger, Sudan, Togo, and\nUganda\n(http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm). Niger, which borders the Yobe State of\nNigeria, also experienced cases due to serogroup X in 2010 and\nexperienced an epidemic of meningitis due to this strain in 2006 (see\nProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa (02): WHO\nmeningitis region. \n\nReacting to the report, the Director General of the Yobe State Health\nCare Management Board, Alhaji Lawal Ibrahim said the board had\nprocured preposition drugs on measles, meningitis and other related\ndiseases and that they had already been distributed to the 6\nepidemiological zonal offices in the state. \n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an\nattempt to induce herd immunity, whereby transmission is blocked when\na critical percentage of the population has been vaccinated (see\nhttp://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/). In addition, _Streptococcus pneumoniae_ is a pathogen also known to\ncause outbreaks of meningitis in the African 'meningitis' region (see\nProMED-mail post Meningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis\nregion 20100213.0507). Although the above news release does not specify the microbial cause\nof the meningitis outbreak in Nigeria, the sub-Saharan region of\nAfrica is plagued yearly by large epidemics of meningococcal\nmeningitis. According to a report by the state's Epidemiological Department in\nDamaturu yesterday, Yobe State recorded 322 cases of cerebrospinal\nmeningitis across the 17 local government areas of the state last\nyear, and 22 persons died from the disease. However, in 2010, a new strain (serogroup X) of\nmeningococcal meningitis emerged in Burkina Faso that led to huge\noutbreaks in that country, with 46 percent (6/13) of the regions in\nthe country being at epidemic level.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Yobe State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of the", "country": "Yemen"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "Mali"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Ivory Coast", "country": "Ivory Coast"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "615580", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (03): (CO) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=615580", "date": "2010-12-30 07:00:09", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (03): (COLORADO) FATAL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 29 Dec 2010\nFrom: Adrienne LeBailly <lebailae@co.larimer.co.us> [edited]\n\n\nRe: follow-up information on the northern Colorado meningococcal disease cases\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe bacteria involved in the Larimer County outbreak are _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_, serogroup C, in the ST-11/ET-37 complex. PFGE [pulsed\nfield gel electrophoresis] testing done by the Colorado Department of\nPublic Health and Environment demonstrated that the 8 linked cases\n(including the Denver Metro State student) were from the same clonal\ngroup, and MLST [multilocus sequence typing] testing by CDC identified\nthe matching sequence types.\n\nAn additional case of meningococcal meningitis that occurred at the\nsame time as the hockey league outbreak (June 2010) did not grow out\n_N. meningitidis_, but was identified by CDC (using PCR testing) as\nmeningococcal serogroup B. This case is believed to be unrelated to\nthe outbreak, although the possibility of capsule switching was\nconsidered. Only one housekeeping gene was able to be amplified by CDC\nin MLST testing, and this one gene sequence did not match the outbreak\nstrain.\n\nThere are epidemiologic links between the Metro State student and\nother (non-ill) Colorado State University (CSU) students. Numerous\n(non-ill) persons who play in the Fort Collins adult hockey league are\nstudents or staff at CSU, including 4 people who played in the 9 Jun\n2010 hockey game when 3 fatal cases appear to have become infected.\nOther possible connections have been suggested for the 2 most recent\nCSU student cases occurring in October and December 2010, but no\nsurveys of pharyngeal carriage of the outbreak strain have been done.\n\nAll hockey league players were offered antibiotic prophylaxis and free\nmeningococcal vaccine, as were all close contacts of the CSU student\ncases.\n\nAfter the fatal case in a CSU student in October 2010, a mass\nvaccination effort was implemented on the CSU campus for students,\nstaff, faculty, (including household members) ages 2-29 who had not\nreceived meningococcal vaccine in the past 3 years. Approximately 11\n000 persons received free vaccinations in November and December 2010\n\nConcerns about waning immunity occurring in persons vaccinated with\nmeningococcal conjugate vaccine have been discussed at recent meetings\nof CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). They\nhave also identified [the problem] that immune memory cells may not be\nable to mount a response as rapidly as meningococcal bacteria can\ncause severe or fatal illness.\n\nBased on information presented at the 27 Oct 2010 ACIP meeting\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/recs/acip/downloads/mtg-slides-oct10/02-5-mening-mcv4.pdf>), consultation with the state and CDC, and the high case-fatality observed in this outbreak (5 of 7 cases [71 percent] at the time; now 5 of 8 [62 percent]), the 'greater than 3-year period since immunization' was selected for this vaccination campaign -- an even shorter time frame than the 5-year booster recently recommended by ACIP in October\n2010.\n\nAlthough 6 of the northern Colorado outbreak cases had not been\nvaccinated for meningococcal disease, the 2 most recent cases in CSU\nstudents -- one of which was fatal -- had both received meningococcal\nconjugate vaccine in 2006.\n\n--\nAdrienne LeBailly, MD, MPH\nDirector, Larimer County Department of Health and Environment\nColorado, USA\n<lebailae@co.larimer.co.us>\n\n[As Dr LeBailly notes, it is concerning that the 2 most recent cases\nin CSU students, one of which was fatal, both received meningococcal\nconjugate vaccine in 2006. Data (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/recs/acip/downloads/mtg-slides-oct10/02-5-mening-mcv4.pdf>) indicate protection wanes within 5 years after vaccination. In addition, invasive disease develops so rapidly, immune memory cells may not be able to mount a response in sufficient time to control the\ninfection.\n\nFort Collins in northern Colorado can be seen on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the USA at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00-s>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "PFGE [pulsed\nfield gel electrophoresis] testing done by the Colorado Department of\nPublic Health and Environment demonstrated that the 8 linked cases\n(including the Denver Metro State student) were from the same clonal\ngroup, and MLST [multilocus sequence typing] testing by CDC identified\nthe matching sequence types. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 29 Dec 2010\n Director, Larimer County Department of Health and Environment\nColorado, USA\n<lebailae@co.larimer.co.us>\n\n[As Dr LeBailly notes, it is concerning that the 2 most recent cases\nin CSU students, one of which was fatal, both received meningococcal\nconjugate vaccine in 2006. Although 6 of the northern Colorado outbreak cases had not been\nvaccinated for meningococcal disease, the 2 most recent cases in CSU\nstudents -- one of which was fatal -- had both received meningococcal\nconjugate vaccine in 2006. \n\nAn additional case of meningococcal meningitis that occurred at the\nsame time as the hockey league outbreak (June 2010) did not grow out\n_N. meningitidis_, but was identified by CDC (using PCR testing) as\nmeningococcal serogroup After the fatal case in a CSU student in October 2010, a mass\nvaccination effort was implemented on the CSU campus for students,\nstaff, faculty, (including household members) ages 2-29 who had not\nreceived meningococcal vaccine in the past 3 years. Approximately 11\n000 persons received free vaccinations in November and December 2010\n\nConcerns about waning immunity occurring in persons vaccinated with\nmeningococcal conjugate vaccine have been discussed at recent meetings\nof CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). They\nhave also identified [the problem] that immune memory cells may not be\nable to mount a response as rapidly as meningococcal bacteria can\ncause severe or fatal illness. (non-ill) persons who play in the Fort Collins adult hockey league are\nstudents or staff at CSU, including 4 people who played in the 9 Jun\n2010 hockey game when 3 fatal cases appear to have become infected.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-10-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-10-26 00:00:00", "2010-12-26 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-06-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Fort Collins", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "671338", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Chad: WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=671338", "date": "2011-03-09 16:00:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CHAD: WHO\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 8 Mar 2011\nSource: WHO Global Alert and Response (GAR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2011_03_08/en/index.html>\n\n\nMeningococcal disease in Chad\n-----------------------------\nFrom 1 Jan to 6 Mar 2011, the Ministry of Health of Chad reported 923\nsuspected cases of meningococcal disease including 57 deaths (case\nfatality rate: 6.2 per cent). So far, 5 districts primarily in the\nregion of Logone Occidental are experiencing an epidemic (Benoye,\nKello, Laokassy, Melfi, and Moundou) while 2 others are on alert\n(Boussou and Sarh).\n\nThe predominance of _Neisseria meningitidis_ A in epidemic districts\nhas been laboratory-confirmed by latex agglutination test, with no\nother _N. meningitidis_ serogroup being identified in these areas.\n\nThe International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for\nEpidemic Meningitis Control has provided 752 000 doses of bivalent\npolysaccharide AC vaccine for a mass vaccination campaign in affected\nareas of Benoye, Kello, Laokassy, Melfi, and Moundou. Vaccines are\nbeing provided with the support of the Global Alliance for Vaccines\nand Immunization (GAVI) and Medecins sans Frontieres.\n\nWHO, UNICEF, Medecins sans Frontieres, and the International\nFederation of Red Cross (IFRC) are working with the Ministry of\nHealth, Chad, to implement the vaccination campaigns as well as other\nemergency control measures, including case management and enhanced\nsurveillance in neighbouring districts.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Chad is a poor, landlocked country in central Africa, which is\nbordered by Libya to the north, Sudan to the east, the Central African\nRepublic to the south, Cameroon and Nigeria to the south west, and\nNiger to the west. It is largely desert and as of 2008, Chad hosted\nover 280 000 refugees from the Sudan's Darfur region, over 55 000 from\nthe Central African Republic, as well as over 170 000 internally\ndisplaced people (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chad>). N'Djamena is\nthe national capital of Chad. The 22 regions of Chad are divided into\n53 departments, which in turn are subdivided into sub prefectures\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chad>).\n\nFor an administrative map of Chad, see\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/chad.pdf>. Logone\nOccidental, which is a region in southwestern Chad, includes the sub\nprefectures of Benoye, Laokassy, Moundou, and Sarh\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logone_Occidental_Region>). Melfi is a\ntown in the Guera Region of southern-central Chad\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guera_Region>), and Kelo is in the\nsouthwestern Tandjile Region\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tandjile_Region>).\n\nSub-Saharan Africa is been plagued yearly by large epidemics of\nmeningococcal meningitis that occur in the dry season (December to\nJune). Chad is in the middle of this 'meningitis belt', which\nstretches from the east to the west coast of Africa, taking in Burkina\nFaso, Benin, Chad, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ethiopia, Ghana,\nIvory Coast, Kenya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Sudan, Togo, and Uganda.\nAttack rates during these cyclic epidemics of meningitis range from\n100 to 800 per 100 000 population, but individual communities have\nreported rates as high as 1000 per 100 000 (World Health Organization:\nMeningococcal meningitis fact sheet;\n<http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/pdf/FactSheet-Meningitis.pdf>).\nEpidemic thresholds are used to confirm the emergence of an epidemic\nin order to step up control measures, that is, mass vaccination and\nappropriate case management. For definitions of epidemic thresholds,\nsee <http://www.who.int/disasters/repo/6618.doc>.\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an\nattempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is blocked when\na critical percentage of the population have been vaccinated (see\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>).\n\nIn 2010, ProMED-mail posted a report of an outbreak of meningitis of\nunspecified etiology in Chad in 2010 (Meningitis - Chad: (LR, MA) RFI\n20100223.0600) and in 2009 ProMED-mail posted a report of an outbreak\nof meningitis in Chad due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A and\nW135, with an 11.7-per cent mortality rate (Meningitis, meningococcal\n- Chad (02) 20090424.1544).\n\nThe current outbreak reported in the news release above is said to be\ndue to _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A, with mortality rate of 6.2 per\ncent. The WHO defines successful epidemic control as keeping the\nmortality rate below 10 per cent.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Chad is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/017X>. Maps of the African bacterial\nmeningitis belt can be found at\n<http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "In 2010, ProMED-mail posted a report of an outbreak of meningitis of\nunspecified etiology in Chad in 2010 (Meningitis - Chad: (LR, MA) RFI\n20100223.0600) and in 2009 ProMED-mail posted a report of an outbreak\nof meningitis in Chad due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A and\nW135, with an 11.7-per cent mortality rate (Meningitis, meningococcal\n- Chad (02) 20090424.1544). \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Chad is a poor, landlocked country in central Africa, which is\nbordered by Libya to the north, Sudan to the east, the Central African\nRepublic to the south, Cameroon and Nigeria to the south west, and\n Attack rates during these cyclic epidemics of meningitis range from\n100 to 800 per 100 000 population, but individual communities have\nreported rates as high as 1000 per 100 000 (World Health Organization:\nMeningococcal meningitis fact sheet;\n<http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/pdf/FactSheet-Meningitis.pdf>). \n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate meningococcal vaccine in every involved district in an\nattempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is blocked when\na critical percentage of the population have been vaccinated (see\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). \n\nWHO, UNICEF, Medecins sans Frontieres, and the International\nFederation of Red Cross (IFRC) are working with the Ministry of\nHealth, Chad, to implement the vaccination campaigns as well as other\nemergency control measures, including case management and enhanced\nsurveillance in neighbouring districts. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: \n\nThe International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for\nEpidemic Meningitis Control has provided 752 000 doses of bivalent\npolysaccharide AC vaccine for a mass vaccination campaign in affected\nareas of Benoye, Kello, Laokassy, Melfi, and Moundou. It is largely desert and as of 2008, Chad hosted\nover 280 000 refugees from the Sudan's Darfur region, over 55 000 from\nthe Central African Republic, as well as over 170 000 internally\ndisplaced people (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chad>). So far, 5 districts primarily in the\nregion of Logone Occidental are experiencing an epidemic (Benoye,\nKello, Laokassy, Melfi, and Moundou) while 2 others are on alert\n Maps of the African bacterial\nmeningitis belt can be found at\n<http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>. Logone\nOccidental, which is a region in southwestern Chad, includes the sub\nprefectures of Benoye, Laokassy, Moundou, and Sarh\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logone_Occidental_Region>). \n\nThe current outbreak reported in the news release above is said to be\ndue to _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A, with mortality rate of 6.2 per\ncent.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Darfur", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Benoye", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "Mali"}, {"location": "Libya", "country": "Libya"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of the", "country": "Yemen"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Ivory Coast", "country": "Ivory Coast"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "497210", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - Canada: (AB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=497210", "date": "2010-08-18 18:00:04", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - CANADA: (ALBERTA)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 17 Aug 2010\nSource: Edmonton Sun [edited]\n<http://www.edmontonsun.com/news/alberta/2010/08/17/15053831.html>\n\n\nAlberta Heath Services is reminding Albertans to keep clean, as an\noutbreak of viral meningitis has spread across the province. Symptoms\nstart out much like a summer cold with dry coughs or fevers, but\nsince April 2010, 90 of those colds turned into reported cases of\nviral meningitis in Alberta, with half of those cases originating in\nEdmonton, says Dr. Gerry Predy, senior medical officer with Alberta\nHealth Services. 'Over the past few months we've been seeing quite a\nbit of viral meningitis,' Predy told reporters on Tuesday [17 Aug\n2010]. 'It is more than what we usually see. With kids going back to\nschool, we thought we should issue this advisory.'\n\nThe cases reported concern people between the ages of 10 and 30, and\nfor people who do recreational activities in large groups. 'A lot of\nthe cases have been related to sports tournaments, recreational\nactivities,' he said. 'If you are sick or your children are sick,\ndon't send them to sports camp; don't send them to school; keep them\nat home until they are better.' Albertans are encouraged to avoid\nsharing water bottles or soft drinks, to wash hands thoroughly, and\nto clean surfaces of gym equipment and common household surfaces.\n\nThe majority of viral meningitis cases don't cause death. The cases\nhave been known to spring up in the region every couple of years\nduring the summer. Predy reminds Albertans this incident is not as\nserious as the string of bacterial meningitis cases in 2000, where\nsome cases led to death. Of the 90 recent viral meningitis cases in\nAlberta, no one has died from the disease. But those who do get\nmeningitis should get checked to 'rule out other, more serious forms\nof meningitis,' Predy said.\n\nViral meningitis can cause fever, dry cough, headaches, body aches,\nweakness, tiredness and rash and can usually last 7 to 10 days.\n\n[Byline: Linda Hoang]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes ('meninges') that\ncover the brain and spinal cord. Viral infections are the most common\ncause of meningitis. Viral ('aseptic') meningitis is serious but\nrarely fatal in people with normal immune systems. Usually, the\nsymptoms last from 7 to 10 days, and the patient recovers completely.\n\nDifferent viral infections can lead to viral meningitis. But most\ncases, particularly during the summer and autumn months, are caused\nby enteroviruses (which include enteroviruses, coxsackieviruses, and\nechoviruses). Most people who are infected with enteroviruses either\nhave no symptoms or only get a cold, rash, or mouth sores with\nlow-grade fever. And, only a small number of people with enterovirus\ninfections develop meningitis.\n\nEnteroviruses, the most common cause of viral meningitis, are most\noften spread through direct contact with an infected person's faeces.\nThe virus is spread through this route mainly among small children\nwho are not yet toilet trained. It can also be spread this way to\nadults changing the diapers of an infected infant.\n\nEnteroviruses and other viruses (such as mumps and varicella-zoster\nvirus) can also be spread through direct or indirect contact with\nrespiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus) of an\ninfected person. The viruses can also stay on surfaces for days and\ncan be transferred from objects. Viruses also can spread directly\nwhen infected people cough or sneeze and send droplets containing the\nvirus into the air we breathe. The time from when a person is\ninfected until they develop symptoms (incubation period) is usually\nbetween 3 and 7 days for enteroviruses. An infected person is usually\ncontagious from the time they develop symptoms until the symptoms go\naway. Young children and people with low immune systems may spread\nthe infection even after symptoms have resolved. Detailed information\non viral and bacterial meningitis can be obtained from the CDC\nweb-site at: <http://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/about/faq.html>.\n\nThe province of Alberta and the city of Edmonton can be located using\nthe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/007x>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Symptoms\nstart out much like a summer cold with dry coughs or fevers, but\nsince April 2010, 90 of those colds turned into reported cases of\nviral meningitis in Alberta, with half of those cases originating in\nEdmonton, says Dr. Gerry Predy, senior medical officer with Alberta\nHealth Services. ' A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 17 Aug 2010\n \n\nEnteroviruses and other viruses (such as mumps and varicella-zoster\nvirus) can also be spread through direct or indirect contact with\nrespiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus) of an\ninfected person. But most\ncases, particularly during the summer and autumn months, are caused\nby enteroviruses (which include enteroviruses, coxsackieviruses, and\nechoviruses). Predy reminds Albertans this incident is not as\nserious as the string of bacterial meningitis cases in 2000, where\nsome cases led to death. Source: Edmonton Sun [edited]\n<http://www.edmontonsun.com/news/alberta/2010/08/17/15053831.html>\n\n\nAlberta Heath Services is reminding Albertans to keep clean, as an\noutbreak of viral meningitis has spread across the province. The time from when a person is\ninfected until they develop symptoms (incubation period) is usually\nbetween 3 and 7 days for enteroviruses. Viruses also can spread directly\nwhen infected people cough or sneeze and send droplets containing the\nvirus into the air we breathe. Over the past few months we've been seeing quite a\nbit of viral meningitis,' Predy told reporters on Tuesday [17 Aug\n2010]. ' But those who do get\nmeningitis should get checked to 'rule out other, more serious forms\nof meningitis,' Predy said. Most people who are infected with enteroviruses either\nhave no symptoms or only get a cold, rash, or mouth sores with\nlow-grade fever. An infected person is usually\ncontagious from the time they develop symptoms until the symptoms go\naway. Detailed information\non viral and bacterial meningitis can be obtained from the CDC\nweb-site at: <http://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/about/faq.html>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "varicella"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2010-04-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Edmonton", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "612096", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (CO) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=612096", "date": "2010-12-24 18:00:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (02): (COLORADO), FATAL\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 23 Dec 2010\nSource: TheDenverChannel.com [edited]\n<http://www.thedenverchannel.com/health/26260041/detail.html>\n\n\nThe recent case [of meningococcal disease] involving a Colorado State\nUniversity student is connected to the other cases in Larimer County,\nas health department officials suspected.\n\n'The bacteria that caused invasive meningococcal disease in a CSU\nstudent in early December 2010 match the organisms that caused other\ncases in Northern Colorado over the last 8 months,' the health\ndepartment announced Thursday [23 Dec 2010]. 'The Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment's lab has confirmed that the\nbacteria that caused the recent infection were Group C meningococcal\nbacteria (also called _Neisseria meningitidis_, serogroup C). In\naddition, special molecular 'fingerprinting' tests (called PFGE\n[pulsed field gel electrophoresis] tests) allowed them to confirm 8\nof these cases were caused by identical strains.'\n\nFour of the 8 cases reported in Larimer County since May 2010 have been fatal.\n\nThe most recent case was a CSU student who was hospitalized in early\nDecember 2010 with a meningococcal disease. He was released from\nPoudre Valley Hospital about a week later and is believed to be doing\nwell at his parents' home out of state.\n\nThe linked cases include illnesses that killed a Metro State College\n[student] in April 2010; caused a disabling case of meningitis in a\nCSU student in May 2010; led to 3 fatal meningococcal cases among 3\nFort Collins hockey players in June 2010; caused a less severe case\nin a hockey player's child in August 2010; and killed a CSU student\nin October 2010.\n\n'We have looked at a number of connections between all the cases,'\nsaid Dr. Adrienne LeBailly, director of the Larimer County Health\nDepartment. 'We know that for each case of meningococcal infection,\nthere are likely numerous symptom-free carriers of the outbreak\nstrain who never become ill but who can transmit the bacteria to\nothers, most of whom will also never become ill. This makes it\nimpossible to confirm exactly how the bacteria were transmitted\nbetween individual cases.'\n\nMeningococcal vaccines provide protection against 4 meningococcal\ngroups (Serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135), health officials said.\n\nAlthough the effectiveness of the vaccine is high for the 1st couple\nof years, protection wanes quickly and is largely gone by 5 years\nafter vaccination. For this reason, CSU students were advised to be\nrevaccinated if it had been 3 or more years since they had received\nthe vaccine.\n\nThe signs and symptoms of meningococcal disease can include high\nfever, headache, severe body aches, vomiting, disorientation, and a\ncharacteristic skin rash, among others.\n\nMeningococcal bacteria commonly cause meningitis -- an inflammation\nof the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord -- and\nsepticemia, or sepsis, an infection in the bloodstream.\n\nSix of the 8 Larimer County meningococcal cases have been sepsis,\nwhich generally has a higher fatality rate. All the 4 fatal cases in\nLarimer County have been from meningococcal sepsis, rather than\nmeningococcal meningitis.\n\n[Byline: Kim Nguyen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nJoyce Knutsen\n<jknutsen@smtpgate.dphe.state.co.us>\n\n[The above news release adds 3 cases to the 5 previously reported in\na ProMED-mail post concerning a northern Colorado outbreak of\nmeningococcal disease due to a genetically identical strain of\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (CO) fatal\n20100625.2115). Three cases involved students at Colorado State\nUniversity (CSU), which is located in the city of Fort Collins (the\ncounty seat of Larimer County), and 4 cases were associated with a\nFort Collins hockey team. An 8th case apparently was a student at\nMetro State College, which is located in the city of Denver, about 60\nmiles south of Fort Collins\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Collins,_Colorado>).\n\n_N. meningitidis_ causes bacterial meningitis and sepsis and is\ntransmitted from person to person via droplets of respiratory\nsecretions, mostly from asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers of the\nmicroorganism. It is estimated that between 10 to 25 percent of the\npopulation carry _N. meningitidis_ at any given time, and the\ncarriage rate may be much higher in epidemic situations. Close and\nprolonged contact (such as kissing, sneezing and coughing on someone,\nliving in close quarters or dormitories (military recruits,\nstudents), sharing eating or drinking utensils, etc.) facilitates the\nspread of the microorganism. The average incubation period for\nmeningococcal meningitis is 4 days, ranging between 2 and 10 days\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>).\n\nEach year, up to 3000 people in the USA develop meningococcal\ndisease. The annual incidence generally ranges from 0.5 to 1.1 cases\nper 100 000. The incidence peaks in late winter and early spring.\nMost cases are sporadic; less than 2 percent occur in outbreaks\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm>; updated at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5631a3.htm>). Outbreaks\ntend to occur in semi-closed communities, such military recruit\ncamps, college dormitories, schools, and day-care centers.\nCommunity-based outbreaks in towns, cities, and counties may also\noccur among persons who are not close contacts of each other and who\ndo not share a common affiliation.\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease in either an organization or\ncommunity is defined as the occurrence of 3 or more confirmed or\nprobable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3 months,\nresulting in a primary disease attack rate in the population at risk\n(such as the hockey team in the outbreak in the news release above)\nof at least 10 cases per 100 000 persons, which is about 10 times\ngreater than the normal occurrence\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>).\n\nChemoprophylaxis is given to close contacts whose risk for acquiring\nmeningococcal disease is 500-800 times greater than the general\npopulation (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>).\nClose contacts of patients are household members, day-care center\ncontacts, and persons directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions.\n\nRoutine vaccination of college freshman, particularly those living in\ndormitories, has been recommended for primary prophylaxis of\nmeningococcal disease (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/rr/rr5407.pdf>).\nIn an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the\nmeningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the\noutbreak as soon as possible after an outbreak has been declared\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5407.pdf>). Because available\nvaccines are not effective against _N. meningitidis_ serogroup B,\nvaccination is not considered during serogroup B outbreaks.\n\nThe northern Colorado outbreak is reported to be due to serogroup C.\nA quadrivalent A, C, Y, and W135 meningococcal conjugate vaccine was\nlicensed in the United States in January 2005. The conjugate vaccine\ninduces a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved immune\nresponse, providing long-lasting immunity and preventing\nnasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ and thus reducing\nbacterial transmission of this microorganism\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>).\n\nFort Collins in northern Colorado can be seen on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00-s>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nJoyce Knutsen\n<jknutsen@smtpgate.dphe.state.co.us>\n\n[The above news release adds 3 cases to the 5 previously reported in\na ProMED-mail post concerning a northern Colorado outbreak of\nmeningococcal disease due to a genetically identical strain of\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (CO) fatal\n20100625.2115). [student] in April 2010; caused a disabling case of meningitis in a\nCSU student in May 2010; led to 3 fatal meningococcal cases among 3\nFort Collins hockey players in June 2010; caused a less severe case\nin a hockey player's child in August 2010; and killed a CSU student\nin October 2010. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 23 Dec 2010\n The conjugate vaccine\ninduces a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved immune\nresponse, providing long-lasting immunity and preventing\nnasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ and thus reducing\nbacterial transmission of this microorganism\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>). \n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease in either an organization or\ncommunity is defined as the occurrence of 3 or more confirmed or\nprobable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3 months,\nresulting in a primary disease attack rate in the population at risk\n(such as the hockey team in the outbreak in the news release above) Close and\nprolonged contact (such as kissing, sneezing and coughing on someone,\nliving in close quarters or dormitories (military recruits,\nstudents), sharing eating or drinking utensils, etc.) facilitates the\nspread of the microorganism. \n\n'The bacteria that caused invasive meningococcal disease in a CSU\nstudent in early December 2010 match the organisms that caused other\ncases in Northern Colorado over the last 8 months,' the health\ndepartment announced Thursday In an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the\nmeningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the\noutbreak as soon as possible after an outbreak has been declared\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5407.pdf>). The Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment's lab has confirmed that the\nbacteria that caused the recent infection were Group C meningococcal\nbacteria (also called _Neisseria meningitidis_, serogroup C). \n\n_N. meningitidis_ causes bacterial meningitis and sepsis and is\ntransmitted from person to person via droplets of respiratory\nsecretions, mostly from asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers of the\nmicroorganism. We know that for each case of meningococcal infection,\nthere are likely numerous symptom-free carriers of the outbreak\nstrain who never become ill but who can transmit the bacteria to\nothers, most of whom will also never become ill. Three cases involved students at Colorado State\nUniversity (CSU), which is located in the city of Fort Collins (the\ncounty seat of Larimer County), and 4 cases were associated with a\nFort Collins hockey team. \nof at least 10 cases per 100 000 persons, which is about 10 times\ngreater than the normal occurrence\n An 8th case apparently was a student at\nMetro State College, which is located in the city of Denver, about 60\nmiles south of Fort Collins\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Collins,_Colorado>). \n\nChemoprophylaxis is given to close contacts whose risk for acquiring\nmeningococcal disease is 500-800 times greater than the general\npopulation (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). \n\nMeningococcal bacteria commonly cause meningitis -- an inflammation\nof the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord -- and\nsepticemia, or sepsis, an infection in the bloodstream. The recent case [of meningococcal disease] involving a Colorado State\nUniversity student is connected to the other cases in Larimer County,\nas health department officials suspected. All the 4 fatal cases in\nLarimer County have been from meningococcal sepsis, rather than\nmeningococcal meningitis.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-08-26 00:00:00", "2010-06-26 00:00:00", "2005-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-04-26 00:00:00", "2010-10-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-05-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Fort Collins", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "621264", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, postinf. hydrocephalus, Acinetobacter - Uganda", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=621264", "date": "2011-01-06 17:00:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, POSTINFECTIOUS HYDROCEPHALUS, ACINETOBACTER - UGANDA: (MBALE)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 3 Jan 2011\nSource: Eurekalert.org [edited]\n<http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2011-01/ps-ihs122210.php>\n\n\nHydrocephalus in children [in Uganda] and other developing countries\nis seasonal, linked to farm animals and in part, caused by previous\nbacterial infection, according to an international team of\nresearchers from Uganda and the United States, who believe that the\nbest approach to this problem is prevention.\n\n'Hydrocephalus in infants in developing countries is a grand medical\nmystery,' said Steven Schiff, the Brush Chair professor of\nengineering and director, Penn State Center for Neural Engineering.\n\nHydrocephalus is a build up of the fluid that normally surrounds the\nbrain. The increased pressure causes the head to swell and damages\nbrain tissue. Treatment includes placing a shunt to drain the fluid,\nbut inevitably these shunts become plugged and require emergency\ncare, not always available in rural Africa and other resource-limited\nregions of the developing world. Surgeons vigorously explore the use\nof new brain endoscopes to divert fluid buildup internally in such\nchildren, but this approach addresses the fluid and does not fix\nprevious infection damage to the brain.\n\n'Brains of children with hydrocephalus can be completely or mostly\ndestroyed either by the scarring from the disease or by the pressure\nof the cerebrospinal fluid that cannot escape,' said Schiff. 'Many of\nthese children with the worst aftereffects of infection will be\nmentally deficient and survive only as long as their mothers can\nadequately care for them. Understanding the causes could eliminate or\nprevent the enormous costs to lives and families that hydrocephalus brings.'\n\nHydrocephalus in infants in sub-Saharan Africa is thought to be\ncaused most often by meningitis-type infections during the 1st month\nof life. The U.S. and Ugandan researchers looked at the fluid from\nthe brains of 3 sets of 25 consecutive infant hydrocephalus patients\nduring January, July and October [2010] to try to determine the cause\nof the disease. By the time parents bring infants with rapidly\ngrowing heads to the CURE Children's Hospital in Mbale, Uganda, the\nunderlying infection is gone. The researchers were unable to culture\nany bacteria from the samples.\n\nTo identify traces of previous bacterial infection, the researchers\nused DNA sequencing to look for 16S ribosomal DNA that exists in all\nbacteria. They reported their findings in the current issue of the\nJournal of Neurosurgery: Pediatrics [Lingling L, et al. Association\nof bacteria with hydrocephalus in Ugandan infants. J Neurosurg\nPediatrics 2011; 70:73-87. Available at:\n<http://www.esm.psu.edu/wiki/_media/research:sjs49:li_et_al_association_of_bacteria_with_hydrocephalus_in_ugandan_infants_j_neurosurg_peds_2011.pdf>],\nshowing that 94 percent of the samples contained bacterial remnants.\nThe researchers found a seasonal difference between samples\nrepresenting infection during the dry season that were predominantly\nBetaproteobacteria and [infection during the rainy season that were\npredominantly Gammaproteobacteria]. [Betaproteobacteria is a class of\nGram-negative bacteria in the phylum Proteobacteria, which includes\n_Burkholderia_ and _Neisseria meningitidis_, and Gammaproteobacteria\nis a class of Gram-negative bacteria in the phylum Proteobacteria,\nwhich includes _Pseudomonas_, _Escherichia_, and _Acinetobacter_.]\n_Acinetobacter_ appeared in the majority [95 percent according to the\nLingling et al J Neurosurg Pediatrics study] of patients following\nrainy season infection. Some sequences that appeared in the DNA\nanalysis were from unknown bacteria, and in many cases, the bacterial\nfragments were not identifiable as to the type of _Acinetobacter_\nthey represented.\n\nIn the United States and other industrialized countries, infant\nhydrocephalus is usually due to either a congenital anomaly or, in\nlow birth weight premature infants, due to brain hemorrhages from\nimmature blood vessels. At one time, Group B _Streptococcus_ was a\ncommon cause of postinfectious hydrocephalus in infants in\nindustrialized countries, but now physicians test mothers for the\ninfection and treat with antibiotics before they give birth, and the\ninfections are rare. Surprisingly, according to Schiff, in Uganda,\nnone of the remnant DNA in the infants was from Group B _Streptococcus_.\n\nLooking for the source of the neonatal infections, the researchers\ntargeted the living environment from infants with evidence of prior\n_Acinetobacter_ infection and located patients' homes. What they\nfound were villages of huts where cow dung was pounded into the hut\nfloors to keep water and ants out and used in patios around the huts\nwhere vegetation is cleared to protect against snakes. Newborns enter\nan environment where they not only live near animals but also are\nsurrounded by their material.\n\nThe researchers sampled both the cow dung floors and excrement from\ncattle, goats and chickens. They found similar genetic sequences from\nthe bacteria retrieved from the infants as in the hut floors and\nnearby dung. 'It is really hard to keep infants to an adequate\nstandard of cleanliness in this environment,' said Schiff. 'The\nbacteria we found reflects, I think, a significant environmental\ninfluence.' While the researchers have not yet proven that these\nbacterial infections are the cause of the devastating hydrocephalus\noccurrences, they believe that in part, bacterial infections from\nanimals are the cause.\n\nHistorically, certain East African peoples have applied cow dung to\nstem bleeding in umbilical cord stumps, which caused newborn\ninfections. Although such infections are now rare, the scope of\nnewborn bacterial infections related to living in close proximity to\ndomestic animals remains poorly categorized.\n\n'As far as we can tell, these types of environmental newborn\ninfections are the dominant cause of hydrocephalus on the planet,'\nsaid Schiff. 'We may be dealing with bacteria that we can't culture,\nviruses or parasites, and we may be dealing with different organisms\nin different locations.'\n\nThe researchers are continuing their work and forming an African\nHydrocephalus Consortium with Rwanda, Kenya, Tanzania and Zambia.\nThey are conducting follow-up clinical trials at the Mbarara\nUniversity of Science and Technology in southwest Uganda on\nmother-infant pairs with new neonatal infections, and at the CURE\nChildren's Hospital of Uganda on older infants with postinfectious\nhydrocephalus. These trials use next-generation technologies and high\nquality microbiology to sort out the causative agents affecting these\ninfants. They are also continuing to explore the environmental\nconnection so that public health strategies toward preventing the\ninitial infections might be found.\n\n[Byline: A'ndrea Elyse Messer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nThomas James Allen\n<tjallen@pipeline.com>\n\n[Hydrocephalus, which is an abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal\nfluid (CSF) in the brain, is a recognized post-infectious\ncomplication in survivors of neonatal meningitis. The investigators\ncited in the news release above (Lingling L, et al. Association of\nbacteria with hydrocephalus in Ugandan infants. J Neurosurg\nPediatrics 2011; 70:703--00807. Available at:\n<http://www.esm.psu.edu/wiki/_media/research:sjs49:li_et_al_association_of_bacteria_with_hydrocephalus_in_ugandan_infants_j_neurosurg_peds_2011.pdf>)\nfound most commonly _Acinetobacter_ and _Burkholderia_ DNA by PCR\n(polymerase chain reaction) amplification in CSF samples obtained\nfrom Ugandan infants. The children were under one year of age with no\nhistory of hydrocephalus at birth and with either a history of\nfebrile illness and/or seizures preceding the onset of hydrocephalus,\nor endoscopic or imaging findings indicative of prior ventriculitis.\n\nAlthough post-neurosurgical nosocomial _Acinetobacter_ meningitis is\na known problem (<http://www.jstor.org/pss/4457446>), widespread\ncommunity-acquired _Acinetobacter_ meningitis in infants is not a\ncommon problem in developed countries. However, Lingling et al cite\nWHO data on _Acinetobacter_ meningitis in community-acquired\nmeningitis occurring in infants in developing countries.\nNevertheless, they acknowledge that _Burkholderia_ species have been\nthought to be a very rare cause of community-acquired meningitis.\n\nLingling et al state that their cases in Uganda originated south of\nthe seasonal African meningococcal meningitis belt, and they found no\nbacterial DNA consistent with the prior presence of the usually more\ncommon meningitis pathogen _Neisseria meningitidis_ in any of the\nsamples and rarely encountered that of streptococcal meningitis\npathogens (e.g., Group B streptococcus or _Streptococcus pneumoniae_).\n\nThese data raise the issue of possible contamination when trying to\ninterpret the finding of bacterial DNA in CSF in the absence of\nviable organisms. PCR amplifies a single or a few copies of a piece\nof DNA, generating thousands to millions of copies of a particular\nDNA sequence and, therefore, is especially vulnerable to\ncontamination. In addition, _Acinetobacter_\n(<http://epinews.com/Newswire/2010/06/11/acinetobacter-infests-hospital-worker-gloves-gowns/>)\nand _Burkholderia_\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm53d827a1.htm>) are\ncommon contaminants frequently found in moist environments. Lingling\net al say they made efforts to avoid contamination with ubiquitous\nenvironmental microorganisms, and genetic analyses indicated\nsufficient diversity among the _Acinetobacter_ sequences_ recovered\nto suggest that they did arise from a common origin. Nevertheless,\nconfirmatory data is needed. As Lingling et al point out in their\npaper, microbiological studies that attempt to recover viable\nmicroorganisms from CSF in neonatal sepsis and meningitis in Ugandan\ninfants need to be performed to further address these issues.\n\nMbale, a city in southeastern Uganda where the CURE Children's\nHospital is located, is approximately 245 km (152 miles) northeast of\nKampala (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mbale>). A map of Uganda\nshowing the Mbale district can be found at\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/fullmaps_af.nsf/luFullMap/6241FC691CBA85F385257194005F2E3A/$File/ocha_REF_uga30022006.pdf?OpenElement>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01ex>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nLingling et al state that their cases in Uganda originated south of\nthe seasonal African meningococcal meningitis belt, and they found no\nbacterial DNA consistent with the prior presence of the usually more\ncommon meningitis pathogen _Neisseria meningitidis_ in any of the\nsamples and rarely encountered that of streptococcal meningitis\npathogens (e.g., Group B streptococcus or _Streptococcus pneumoniae_). Source: Eurekalert.org [edited]\n<http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2011-01/ps-ihs122210.php>\n\n\nHydrocephalus in children [in Uganda] and other developing countries\nis seasonal, linked to farm animals and in part, caused by previous\nbacterial infection, according to an international team of\nresearchers from Uganda and the United States, who believe that the\nbest approach to this problem is prevention. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 3 Jan 2011\n At one time, Group B _Streptococcus_ was a\ncommon cause of postinfectious hydrocephalus in infants in\nindustrialized countries, but now physicians test mothers for the\ninfection and treat with antibiotics before they give birth, and the\ninfections are rare. Communicated by:\nThomas James Allen\n<tjallen@pipeline.com>\n\n[Hydrocephalus, which is an abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal\nfluid (CSF) in the brain, is a recognized post-infectious\ncomplication in survivors of neonatal meningitis. While the researchers have not yet proven that these\nbacterial infections are the cause of the devastating hydrocephalus\noccurrences, they believe that in part, bacterial infections from\nanimals are the cause. As Lingling et al point out in their\npaper, microbiological studies that attempt to recover viable\nmicroorganisms from CSF in neonatal sepsis and meningitis in Ugandan\ninfants need to be performed to further address these issues. Surgeons vigorously explore the use\nof new brain endoscopes to divert fluid buildup internally in such\nchildren, but this approach addresses the fluid and does not fix\nprevious infection damage to the brain. In the United States and other industrialized countries, infant\nhydrocephalus is usually due to either a congenital anomaly or, in\nlow birth weight premature infants, due to brain hemorrhages from\nimmature blood vessels. The U.S. and Ugandan researchers looked at the fluid from\nthe brains of 3 sets of 25 consecutive infant hydrocephalus patients\nduring January, July and October [2010] to try to determine the cause\nof the disease. What they\nfound were villages of huts where cow dung was pounded into the hut\nfloors to keep water and ants out and used in patios around the huts\nwhere vegetation is cleared to protect against snakes. Some sequences that appeared in the DNA\nanalysis were from unknown bacteria, and in many cases, the bacterial\nfragments were not identifiable as to the type of _Acinetobacter_\nthey represented. They are conducting follow-up clinical trials at the Mbarara\nUniversity of Science and Technology in southwest Uganda on\nmother-infant pairs with new neonatal infections, and at the CURE\n Many of\nthese children with the worst aftereffects of infection will be\nmentally deficient and survive only as long as their mothers can\nadequately care for them. Available at:\n<http://www.esm.psu.edu/wiki/_media/research:sjs49:li_et_al_association_of_bacteria_with_hydrocephalus_in_ugandan_infants_j_neurosurg_peds_2011.pdf>)\nfound most commonly _Acinetobacter_ and _Burkholderia_ DNA by PCR\n \n\nHydrocephalus in infants in sub-Saharan Africa is thought to be\ncaused most often by meningitis-type infections during the 1st month\nof life. \n\n'Hydrocephalus in infants in developing countries is a grand medical\nmystery,' said Steven Schiff, the Brush Chair professor of\nengineering and director, Penn State Center for Neural Engineering.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:16", "2011-01-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hydrocephalus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ugandan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mbale", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Proteobacteria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zambia", "country": "Zambia"}, {"location": "Rwanda", "country": "Rwanda"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "546051", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Namibia: fatal, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=546051", "date": "2010-10-07 11:00:04", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NAMIBIA: FATAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 29 Sep 2010\nSource: AllAfrica, The Namibian report [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/201009300212.html>\n\n\nThe Health Ministry will expand its meningitis vaccination campaign to\nthe rest of Windhoek [the capital and largest city of Namibia] early\nnext month [October 2010], minister Richard Kamwi said yesterday [28\nSep 2010].\n\nThe 1st vaccination campaign ended on Friday [?24 Sep 2010] in\nKatutura, but there were not enough vaccines. 'The 2nd vaccination\nphase is planned for the week of 12-15 Oct 2010 targeting the rest of\nWindhoek,' Kamwi told Parliament. 'We will continue to monitor the\nsituation in Windhoek and the rest of the country, especially at\nEngela in north-central Namibia, Katima Mulilo in the Caprivi Region,\nand the Walvis Bay district where cases of meningitis were reported,'\nKamwi added. He urged the nation to be conscious of hygiene and to\nwash hands frequently to prevent infections.\n\nLast week's [week of 20 Sep 2010] vaccinations in Katutura reached 171\n843 people. So far 43 suspected cases have been reported in Namibia of\nwhich 21 were confirmed to be meningococcal meningitis. To date 5\npeople have died during this outbreak.\n\nMeningitis is a serious infection of the lining that surrounds the\nbrain and the spinal cord. It is spread from person to person through\ndroplets of the respiratory or throat secretions. Close contact or\nliving in close contact with an infected person facilitates the spread\nof this disease. The symptoms are a stiff neck, high fever, headaches,\nvomiting, sensitivity to light, and confusion.\n\n[Byline: Brigitte Weidlich]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMichelle Sellors\nSpecialist Nurse Travel Health\nMASTA Ltd\n<michelle.sellors@masta.org>\n\n[Namibia is not in the meningitis belt in Africa; see the prior\nProMED-mail post archive number 20100426.1343 for a discussion of\nmeningococcal meningitis in the African meningitis belt. Although\nprior outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis in Namibia, reported by\nProMED-mail in 2000 and 2007, occurred in the northern regions of this\ncountry, the current outbreak is occurring in north and central\nregions of Namibia, according to the news release above. More specific\ninformation about the serogroup(s) of meningococcus responsible would\nbe appreciated.\n\nNamibia, located in southwestern Africa, is bordered on the north by\nAngola and Zambia, on the south by South Africa, on the east mainly by\nBotswana, and on the west by the Atlantic Ocean. Its capital and\nlargest city is Windhoek, located in central Namibia. The population\nof Windhoek is about 350 000 people and more than 200 000 of them live\nin the northern area of Windhoek called Katutura\n(<http://www.phillipmartin.info/webpage/travel/africa/text_namibia_katutura.htm>). In Katutura unemployment is high and a majority of the population lives in poor conditions. Walvis bay is a port located halfway down the Atlantic coast of Namibia. Caprivi region is a heavily tropical area located in northeastern Namibia and Engela is located in north-central Namibia, near the border with\nAngola.\n\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx>.\nA map showing the regions of Namibia can be found at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Namibia>\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country can be\naccessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/009K>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 29 Sep 2010\n Although\nprior outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis in Namibia, reported by\nProMED-mail in 2000 and 2007, occurred in the northern regions of this\ncountry, the current outbreak is occurring in north and central\nregions of Namibia, according to the news release above. We will continue to monitor the\nsituation in Windhoek and the rest of the country, especially at\nEngela in north-central Namibia, Katima Mulilo in the Caprivi Region,\nand the Walvis Bay district where cases of meningitis were reported,'\n A map showing the regions of Namibia can be found at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Namibia>\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country can be\naccessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/009K>. - Communicated by:\nMichelle Sellors\nSpecialist Nurse Travel Health\nMASTA Ltd\n<michelle.sellors@masta.org>\n\n The population\nof Windhoek is about 350 000 people and more than 200 000 of them live\nin the northern area of Windhoek called Katutura\n(<http://www.phillipmartin.info/webpage/travel/africa/text_namibia_katutura.htm>).
