MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NAMIBIA: FATAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-10-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Zambia", "country": "Zambia"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Engela", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Angola", "country": "Angola"}, {"location": "Katutura", "country": "Namibia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "481470", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aseptic meningitis, Toscana virus - Germany: (BW)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=481470", "date": "2010-08-02 11:00:04", "main_text": "ASEPTIC MENINGITIS, TOSCANA VIRUS - GERMANY: (BADEN-WURTTEMBERG)\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 1 Aug 2010\nSource: Short News [in German, machine trans., edited]\n<http://www.shortnews.de/id/842933/Toskana-Virus-erstmals-in-Deutschland-nachgewiesen>\n\n\nScientists at the Universities of Goettingen and Freiburg in\nBreisgau, as well as at the Pforzheim Clinical Center have for the\n1st time confirmed [the occurrence of] the Toscana virus in Baden-Wurttemberg.\n\nThe virus, probably transmitted by sandflies and originating from the\nMediterranean region, can cause mild meningitis which improves after\na few days.\n\nThe researchers examined various cases of undiagnosed inflammation\n[meningitis] cases from previous years. It was found that 10 persons\nwho had not been in southern Europe during the previous 14 days had,\nnonetheless, developed antibodies against the virus. The virus\nincubation period is 2 weeks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 1st report of aseptic meningitis cases caused by Toscana\nvirus in Germany. Toscana virus was first isolated from a sandfly\n(_Phlebotomus perniciosus_) in central Italy in 1971. The following\nabstract provides a summary of Toscana virus:\n\n'Toscana virus (TOSV) is an arthropod-borne virus which is\ntransmitted to humans by _Phlebotomus_ spp sandflies. Infection is\nthe cause of brain injuries, such as aseptic meningitis and\nmeningoencephalitis, in Italy mainly during the summer. More recently\nsome unusual clinical manifestations due to TOSV with severe\nsequelae, such as ischemic complications and hydrocephalus, have been\nreported. TOSV represents an important emerging pathogen and its\npresence is being investigated in several European countries on the\nMediterranean basin, including Italy, France, Spain, Portugal, and\nCyprus. Phylogenetic analysis has distinguished 2 genotypes of TOSV,\nA and B; the 1st is circulating mainly in Italy and the 2nd in Spain,\nindicating a different geographic distribution possibly related to\nthe vector. This distribution, evolving with the climate,\nglobalization and habitat modification, has implications for the\nepidemiology of TOSV.'\n\nReference\n----------\nCusi MG, Savellini GG, Zanelli G. 2010: Toscana virus epidemiology:\nfrom Italy to beyond. Open Virol J, 4: 22-8.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Germany can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00aX>. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 1 Aug 2010\n Source: Short News [in German, machine trans., edited]\n<http://www.shortnews.de/id/842933/Toskana-Virus-erstmals-in-Deutschland-nachgewiesen>\n\n\nScientists at the Universities of Goettingen and Freiburg in\nBreisgau, as well as at the Pforzheim Clinical Center have for the\n1st time confirmed [the occurrence of] the Toscana virus in Baden-Wurttemberg. The following\nabstract provides a summary of Toscana virus:\n\n'Toscana virus (TOSV) is an arthropod-borne virus which is\ntransmitted to humans by _Phlebotomus_ spp sandflies. More recently\nsome unusual clinical manifestations due to TOSV with severe\nsequelae, such as ischemic complications and hydrocephalus, have been\nreported. TOSV represents an important emerging pathogen and its\npresence is being investigated in several European countries on the\nMediterranean basin, including Italy, France, Spain, Portugal, and\nCyprus. \n\nThe virus, probably transmitted by sandflies and originating from the\nMediterranean region, can cause mild meningitis which improves after\na few days. It was found that 10 persons\nwho had not been in southern Europe during the previous 14 days had,\nnonetheless, developed antibodies against the virus. ASEPTIC MENINGITIS, TOSCANA VIRUS - GERMANY: (BADEN-WURTTEMBERG)\n****************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1971-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Baden - Wurttemberg", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "467020", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Mexico: (BN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=467020", "date": "2010-07-15 13:00:04", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - MEXICO: (BAJA CALIFORNIA)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 13 Jul 2010\nSource: Frontera [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\n<http://www.frontera.info/EdicionEnLinea/Notas/Noticias/13072010/458185.aspx>\n\n\nEnrique Chacon Cruz, infectious disease\nspecialist from the Department of Pediatrics at\nTijuana General Hospital, said that more than 20\ncases of meningococcal meningitis, most of whom\nare minors, have been reported in the state.\n\nThe pediatrician explained that meningococcal\nmeningitis is a sudden illness, which can lead to\ndeath within 24-48 hours of the 1st symptoms. It\naffects all ages, with greater risk in infants\nand persons between 2 and 18. Fever, headache,\nloss of appetite, malaise, drowsiness, and rash\nare some of the symptoms of this disease. He\nurged patients with these symptoms to go\nimmediately to the General Hospital where the\nstaff is trained in the diagnosis and treatment of this disease.\n\n[Byline: Celia Garc\u00eda]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Neisseria meningitidis_ causes bacterial\nmeningitis and sepsis. The bacteria are\ntransmitted from person to person via droplets of\nrespiratory secretions mostly from asymptomatic\nnasopharyngeal carriers of the microorganism. It\nis estimated that between 10 to 25 percent of the\npopulation carry _N. meningitidis_ at any given\ntime, and the carriage rate may be much higher in epidemic situations.\n\nClose and prolonged contact (such as kissing,\nsneezing, and coughing on someone, living in\nclose quarters or dormitories (military recruits,\nstudents), sharing eating or drinking utensils,\netc.) facilitates the spread of the disease. The\naverage incubation period for meningococcal\nmeningitis is 4 days, ranging between 2 and 10 days\n(see <http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>).\n\nThe decision to implement mass vaccination to\nprevent meningococcal disease depends on whether\nthe occurrence of more than one case of the\ndisease represents an outbreak. Serogrouping,\nsuch as, A, B, C, Y, or W135, and additional\nsubtyping of the meningococcal isolates allow\nidentification of an 'outbreak strain' and aid in\nbetter defining the extent of an outbreak. An\noutbreak of meningococcal disease in either an\norganization or community has been defined as the\noccurrence of 3 or more confirmed or probable\ncases during a period of less than or equal to 3\nmonths, resulting in a primary disease attack\nrate in the population at risk of at least 10\ncases per 100 000 persons, which is about 10\ntimes greater than the normal occurrence\n(see <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>).\n\nIn organization-based outbreaks, the population\nat risk is the group of persons who are linked by\na common affiliation, such as, attending the same\nschool or university. In community-based\noutbreaks, the population at risk is the smallest\ngeographically contiguous population that\nincludes all (or almost all) case-patients, such\nas, the population of a neighborhood, town, city, or county.\n\nHowever, it is not possible to calculate a\nprimary attack rate in Tijuana from the data\npresented in the news release above: we don't\nknow if a common serogroup is involved, the\nperiod of time in which the cases occurred, how\nmany of the 20 cases are primary, and the size of\nthe population at risk (that is, whether the\ncases were restricted to an organization or\nneighborhood, or were dispersed throughout the city.\n\nTijuana is the largest city in the Mexican state\nof Baja California, with a population of 1 483\n992 (2005), and is situated on the US-Mexico\nborder adjacent to the US city of San Diego,\nCalifornia\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tijuana>). It is\nestimated that the 2 border crossing stations in\nTijuana account for 300 000 daily border crossings.\n\nMaps of Mexico are available at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/mexico_pol97.jpg> and\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01Jd>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "However, it is not possible to calculate a\nprimary attack rate in Tijuana from the data\npresented in the news release above: we don't\nknow if a common serogroup is involved, the\nperiod of time in which the cases occurred, how\nmany of the 20 cases are primary, and the size of\nthe population at risk (that is, whether the\ncases were restricted to an organization or\nneighborhood, or were dispersed throughout the city.\n\n \ncases during a period of less than or equal to 3\nmonths, resulting in a primary disease attack\nrate in the population at risk of at least 10\ncases per 100 000 persons, which is about 10\ntimes greater than the normal occurrence\n(see <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 13 Jul 2010\n In community-based\noutbreaks, the population at risk is the smallest\ngeographically contiguous population that\nincludes all (or almost all) case-patients, such\nas, the population of a neighborhood, town, city, or county. \n\nClose and prolonged contact (such as kissing,\nsneezing, and coughing on someone, living in\nclose quarters or dormitories (military recruits,\nstudents), sharing eating or drinking utensils,\netc.) facilitates the spread of the disease. Infectious Diseases of Australia. Los Angeles,\nGideon Informatics, 2010. 488 pp. [edited]\n<http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-australia/>\n\n\nThe 1st Australian case of human angiostrongyliasis was reported in\n1971, in Brisbane.\n\nAt first, sporadic cases were reported only from coastal Queensland,\nnorthern New South Wales. Four cases were reported in Victoria to\n1999 (3 of these imported from Fiji; one fatal case). Seropositivity\nis common among aboriginals.\n\nReservoirs:\nThe parasite has been identified in dogs in Sydney as well as in\ngrey-headed fruit bats (_Pteropus poliocephalus_) Bennett's wallaby\n(_Macropus rufogriseus_) rufous bettongs (_Aepyprymnus rufescens_)\nand captive tamarins (_Sanguinus_ spp).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 16 May 2010\n The parasite has been identified in dogs in Sydney as well as in\ngrey-headed fruit bats (_Pteropus poliocephalus_) Bennett's wallaby\n(_Macropus rufogriseus_) rufous bettongs (_Aepyprymnus rufescens_)\nand captive tamarins (_Sanguinus_ spp). EOSINOPHILIC MENINGITIS - AUSTRALIA (02): BACKGROUND\n***********************************************\n Communicated by:\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine Four cases were reported in Victoria to\n1999 (3 of these imported from Fiji; one fatal case).", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "1971-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Brisbane", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "Sydney", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "492065", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aseptic meningitis - Latvia, Serbia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=492065", "date": "2010-08-13 16:00:04", "main_text": "ASEPTIC MENINGITIS - LATVIA, SERBIA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[The summary and conclusion sections of the following reports are posted to\nillustrate the diversity of the enteric viruses, predominantly\nenteroviruses, currently associated with outbreaks of aseptic meningitis in\nEuropean countries. Interested readers should access the full texts to view\nthe data and literature references. - Mod.CP]\n\n[1] Latvia\n[2] Serbia\n\n******\n[1] Latvia\nDate: Thu 12 Aug 2010\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2010; 15(32) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19639>\n\n\nOngoing outbreak of aseptic meningitis in south-eastern Latvia, Jun-Aug 2010\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n[authors: J Perevoscikovs, A Brila, L Firstova, T Komarova, I et al, State\nAgency Infectology Center of Latvia, Riga, Latvia]\n\nSummary\n-------\nAn outbreak of aseptic meningitis has been ongoing in several areas of\nLatgale region, in the south-eastern part of Latvia since the end of June\n2010. By 9 Aug 2010, 114 cases had been notified. Most of the cases were\nregistered in the city and amalgamated municipality of Daugavpils and\nneighbouring territories. According to current evidence, 2 types of\nenteroviruses, coxsackie A-9 virus and echovirus 30, are the causative\nagents of the outbreak.\n\nDiscussion and conclusions\n--------------------------\nA large aseptic meningitis outbreak caused by at least 2 enteroviruses\n(coxsackie A-9 virus and echovirus 30) is still ongoing in the\nsouth-eastern part of Latvia. The epidemiological pattern of the outbreak\n(age and sex distribution of cases) corresponds to the usual characteristic\nof the enteroviral infection, with the majority of cases in males and young\nchildren or adolescents. The incidence of aseptic meningitis was high in\n2006 and 2007, and low in 2008 and 2009. Although in previous non-epidemic\nyears (2007-2009), seasonal increases of enteroviral meningitis began in\nMay to June, this year [2010] the outbreak started later, at the end of June.\n\nIn view of the seasonal character (summer-autumn) of enteroviral infections\nand taking into account reopening of schools after the summer holidays,\nfurther spread, importation, and transmission of infection to other Latvian\nregions cannot be excluded. The risk of international spread is assessed as\nnot significant. Further monitoring and data analysis are to be performed\non a regular basis.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Latvia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/02yo>. - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[2] Serbia\nDate: Thu 12 Aug 2010\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2010; 15(32) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19638>\n\n\nOngoing outbreak of aseptic meningitis associated with echovirus 30 in the\ncity of Novi Sad, Autonomous province of Vojvodina, Serbia, Jun-Jul 2010\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\n[authors: G Cosic 1, P Duric 1, V Milosevic 2, J Dekic 1, G Canak 3, V\nTurkulov3\n1. Centre for Disease Control and Prevention, Institute of Public Health of\nVojvodina, Novi Sad, Autonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia\n2. Centre for Virology, Institute of Public Health of Vojvodina, Novi Sad,\nAutonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia\n3. Clinic for Infectious Diseases, Clinical Centre of Vojvodina, Novi Sad,\nAutonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia]\n\nSummary\n-------\nSince June 2010, incidence of aseptic meningitis has increased in Novi Sad,\nAutonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia. From 2 Jun to 25 Jul 2010, 80\ncases of aseptic meningitis were notified, with an incidence rate ranging\nfrom 10 to 366 per 100 000 population in different local communities. The\nmajority of cases (n=64) were aged between 2 and 15 years. Echovirus 30 was\ncultured from 2 of 4 cerebrospinal fluid specimens. The outbreak, for which\nno common source has yet been identified, is ongoing.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nOutbreaks of aseptic enteroviral meningitis are notified in the Autonomous\nProvince of Vojvodina every 4 to 5 years. The largest previous outbreak\noccurred in 2000, with 461 cases reported that year (the incidence rate in\nthe province was 23 per 100 000 population and incidence rate in the City\nof Novi Sad was 28 per 100 000 population). Outbreaks of aseptic\nenteroviral meningitis were notified in all neighbouring countries\n(Croatia, Hungary, and Romania) in the last 2 decades. In Kosovo under\nUnited Nations Security Council Resolution 1244, an outbreak with a total\nof 878 cases of acute neurological syndrome was reported in 2006 to the\nWorld Health Organization Regional Office for Europe: enteroviral origin\nwas detected. Enteroviral meningitis outbreaks involved many communities\nthroughout other countries within Europe and also other continents.\n\nAs expected in temperate climate, the ongoing outbreak has occurred in hot\nsummer months, spreading by direct or indirect contact. Although none of\nthe common sources (contaminated food or water) has yet been implicated,\nsince viral meningitis outbreaks are sometimes associated with recreational\nuse of water, the use of public swimming pools had been considered a\npotential source of infection in this outbreak but no such exposure of\ncases has been identified.\n\nPreviously reported outbreaks of enteroviral meningitis have demonstrated a\npredominance of males in child cases, with a sex ratio of 2:1. Our findings\nare consistent with this. They are also in line with these reports that\nfind a large proportion (70 per cent) of cases under 15 years of age, but\nthere was a higher incidence rate (149 per 100 000 population) in children\naged 5-15 years.\n\nAccording to its epidemiological features, this outbreak is likely to\ncontinue towards the autumn months. No specific control measures are\navailable for non-polio enteroviruses. Good personal and communal hygiene\nis recommended (thorough hand washing as a routine practice, prompt and\nsafe disposal of waste and faeces, and prompt washing or disposal of the\nsoiled articles in preschool and nursery facilities), as well as\ndisinfection of contaminated surfaces with household cleaning products, and\navoidance of shared utensils and drinking containers. All susceptible\npeople and parents of young children are advised to ask for medical help\nimmediately when there is onset of sudden headaches, fever, nausea, and\nvomiting.\n\nA 3-step model has been suggested for diagnostic procedures in order to\nensure comprehensive diagnostic investigation, including local medical\ninvestigation and usual analysis (polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and\nserology) of acute cases, then as a 2nd step, extended analysis of\nsuspected cases by a reference laboratory for commonly recognised causative\nagents (or less common agents if indicated, such as, in returning\ntravellers), and finally identification of specific pathogens in cases with\nunknown aetiology.\n\nMonitoring circulating enteroviruses is important because individual\nserotypes have different temporal patterns of circulation and the changes\nin predominant serotypes can be accompanied by large-scale outbreaks of\nenteroviral illnesses. Environmental surveillance has been used\nsuccessfully in monitoring enterovirus circulation and assessing the extent\nor duration of epidemic non-poliovirus enteroviruses in specific populations.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Serbia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/02yq>.\n\nViral ('aseptic') meningitis is serious but rarely fatal in people with\nnormal immune systems. Usually, the symptoms last from 7 to 10 days and the\npatient recovers completely. Different viral infections can lead to viral\nmeningitis. But most cases, particularly during the summer and fall months,\nare caused by enteroviruses (which include enteroviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nand echoviruses). Most people who are infected with enteroviruses either\nhave no symptoms or only get a cold, rash, or mouth sores with low-grade\nfever. And, only a small number of people with enterovirus infections\ndevelop meningitis.\n\nEnteroviruses, the most common cause of viral meningitis, are most often\nspread through direct contact with an infected person's stool. The virus is\nspread through this route mainly among small children who are not yet\ntoilet trained. It can also be spread this way to adults changing the\ndiapers of an infected infant.\n\nEnteroviruses and other viruses can also be spread through direct or\nindirect contact with respiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal\nmucus) of an infected person. This usually happens through kissing or\nshaking hands with an infected person or by touching something they have\nhandled and then rubbing your own nose or mouth. The viruses can also stay\non surfaces for days and can be transferred from objects. Viruses also can\nspread directly when infected people cough or sneeze and send droplets\ncontaining the virus into the air we breathe.\n\nThe time from when a person is infected until they develop symptoms\n(incubation period) is usually between 3 and 7 days for enteroviruses. An\ninfected person is usually contagious from the time they develop symptoms\nuntil the symptoms go away. Young children and people with low immune\nsystems may spread the infection even after symptoms have resolved. For\nmore detailed information see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/about/faq.html>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\nA 3-step model has been suggested for diagnostic procedures in order to\nensure comprehensive diagnostic investigation, including local medical\ninvestigation and usual analysis (polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and\nserology) of acute cases, then as a 2nd step, extended analysis of\nsuspected cases by a reference laboratory for commonly recognised causative\nagents (or less common agents if indicated, such as, in returning\ntravellers), and finally identification of specific pathogens in cases with\nunknown aetiology. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[The summary and conclusion sections of the following reports are posted to\nillustrate the diversity of the enteric viruses, predominantly\nenteroviruses, currently associated with outbreaks of aseptic meningitis in\nEuropean countries. Although none of\nthe common sources (contaminated food or water) has yet been implicated,\nsince viral meningitis outbreaks are sometimes associated with recreational\nuse of water, the use of public swimming pools had been considered a\npotential source of infection in this outbreak but no such exposure of\ncases has been identified. Good personal and communal hygiene\nis recommended (thorough hand washing as a routine practice, prompt and\nsafe disposal of waste and faeces, and prompt washing or disposal of the\nsoiled articles in preschool and nursery facilities), as well as\ndisinfection of contaminated surfaces with household cleaning products, and\navoidance of shared utensils and drinking containers. In Kosovo under\nUnited Nations Security Council Resolution 1244, an outbreak with a total\nof 878 cases of acute neurological syndrome was reported in 2006 to the\nWorld Health Organization Regional Office for Europe: enteroviral origin\nwas detected. The epidemiological pattern of the outbreak\n(age and sex distribution of cases) corresponds to the usual characteristic\nof the enteroviral infection, with the majority of cases in males and young\nchildren or adolescents. \n\nMonitoring circulating enteroviruses is important because individual\nserotypes have different temporal patterns of circulation and the changes\nin predominant serotypes can be accompanied by large-scale outbreaks of\nenteroviral illnesses. They are also in line with these reports that\nfind a large proportion (70 per cent) of cases under 15 years of age, but\nthere was a higher incidence rate (149 per 100 000 population) in children\n In view of the seasonal character (summer-autumn) of enteroviral infections\nand taking into account reopening of schools after the summer holidays,\nfurther spread, importation, and transmission of infection to other Latvian\nregions cannot be excluded. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< All susceptible\npeople and parents of young children are advised to ask for medical help\nimmediately when there is onset of sudden headaches, fever, nausea, and\nvomiting. From 2 Jun to 25 Jul 2010, 80\ncases of aseptic meningitis were notified, with an incidence rate ranging\nfrom 10 to 366 per 100 000 population in different local communities. A large aseptic meningitis outbreak caused by at least 2 enteroviruses\n(coxsackie A-9 virus and echovirus 30) is still ongoing in the\nsouth-eastern part of Latvia. Although in previous non-epidemic\nyears (2007-2009), seasonal increases of enteroviral meningitis began in\nMay to June, this year [2010] the outbreak started later, at the end of June. Ongoing outbreak of aseptic meningitis associated with echovirus 30 in the\ncity of Novi Sad, Autonomous province of Vojvodina, Serbia, Jun-Jul 2010\n \n\nEnteroviruses and other viruses can also be spread through direct or\nindirect contact with respiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal\nmucus) of an infected person. An outbreak of aseptic meningitis has been ongoing in several areas of\nLatgale region, in the south-eastern part of Latvia since the end of June\n2010. Outbreaks of aseptic\nenteroviral meningitis were notified in all neighbouring countries\n(Croatia, Hungary, and Romania) in the last 2 decades. According to current evidence, 2 types of\nenteroviruses, coxsackie A-9 virus and echovirus 30, are the causative\nagents of the outbreak. The largest previous outbreak\noccurred in 2000, with 461 cases reported that year (the incidence rate in\n But most cases, particularly during the summer and fall months,\nare caused by enteroviruses (which include enteroviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nand echoviruses). Most people who are infected with enteroviruses either\nhave no symptoms or only get a cold, rash, or mouth sores with low-grade\nfever. [authors: G Cosic 1, P Duric 1, V Milosevic 2, J Dekic 1, G Canak 3, V\nTurkulov3\n1. Viruses also can\nspread directly when infected people cough or sneeze and send droplets\ncontaining the virus into the air we breathe. An\ninfected person is usually contagious from the time they develop symptoms\nuntil the symptoms go away. Environmental surveillance has been used\nsuccessfully in monitoring enterovirus circulation and assessing the extent\nor duration of epidemic non-poliovirus enteroviruses in specific populations. [authors: J Perevoscikovs, A Brila, L Firstova, T Komarova, I et al, State\nAgency Infectology Center of Latvia, Riga, Latvia]\n\nSummary\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-06-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vojvodina", "country": "Serbia"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Riga", "country": "Latvia"}, {"location": "Croatia", "country": "Croatia"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "Latvia"}, {"location": "Brila", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Autonomous Province of Vojvodina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "L Firstova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hungary", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "Serbia", "country": "Serbia"}, {"location": "the Autonomous \n Province of Vojvodina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "Kosovo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "428100", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Eosinophilic meningitis - Australia: (NSW) human ex slug", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=428100", "date": "2010-05-15 13:00:04", "main_text": "Eosinophilic meningitis - Australia: (NEW SOUTH WALES) human ex slug\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 14 May 2010\nSource: Big Pond News [edited]\n<http://bigpondnews.com/articles/OddSpot/2010/05/13/Man_who_ate_slug_critically_ill_461671.html>\n\n\nAngiostrongylus meningitis in Australian man\n--------------------------------------------\nA Sydney man who ate a slug as a dare is fighting\nfor his life after contracting a rare form of\nmeningitis. The 21-year-old caught rat lungworm\ndisease after performing the stunt some time ago,\nthe ABC reported on Thursday [13 May 2010]. He is now in a critical condition.\n\nThe disease is caused by _Angiostrongylus\ncantonensis_, a parasitic worm carried by\nrodents. Slugs and snails can become infected by\neating the larvae in rat droppings. In some\ninstances, the worm can cause fatal swelling of\nthe brain and spinal chord. Dr Jeremy McAnulty\nfrom NSW Health says such cases are rare and most\npeople do recover. 'It goes away by itself\nbecause the body's immune system will eventually\nget rid of it,' he told the ABC.\n\nThe disease can also be caught by eating raw\nvegetables or fruit that have not been washed properly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks are usually seen in people where slugs\nare considered a delicacy. We have not reported\n_Angiostrongylus_ from Australia before. \u00ad Mod.EP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 14 May 2010\n The 21-year-old caught rat lungworm\ndisease after performing the stunt some time ago,\nthe ABC reported on Thursday [13 May 2010]. In 5\ndistricts the disease is at epidemic level, and 9 more districts are on\nhigh alert.\n\nThe mortality rate is particularly high at 14 per cent. Worryingly,\nchildren and young people are the most affected group, with 80 per cent of\npatients aged between 2 and 30. There is no vaccine for strain X.\n\nPlan Burkina Faso has stepped up efforts to deal with the outbreak. Funding\nis planned for antibiotics, other treatments, laboratory use, and equipment\nand vaccines against the other strains of meningitis, which are still\nkilling many. So far 5118 people nationally have been treated for the disease.\n\nThe country has never seen so many cases of this new type of meningitis,\nstrain X. As there is no vaccine for it, the focus for the moment must\nremain on antibiotic treatment.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of deaths, the number of people nationally who have been\ntreated for meningitis, and the case fatality rate in Burkina Faso since\nthe start of 2010 reported in the news release above is about the same as\nthat reported in a prior ProMED-mail post, Meningitis, meningococcal -\nAfrica (02): WHO meningitis region 20100426.1343. However, what is new is\nthe fact that _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup X is responsible for half\nof all the 718 meningitis-related deaths since the beginning of the year\n(2010).\n\nMass immunization with the appropriate polysaccharide vaccine is a useful\ncontrol measure during an epidemic. However, there is no vaccine for\nserogroup X. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended to eliminate nasopharyngeal\ncarriage of _N. meningitidis_ as soon as possible in close contacts of\npersons with invasive meningococcal disease (such as, household members,\nday-care center contacts, and persons directly exposed to the patient's\noral secretions), whose risk for acquiring meningococcal disease is 500-800\ntimes greater than among the general population (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). The rate of\nsecondary disease for close contacts is highest immediately after onset of\ndisease in the index patient.\n\nHowever, chemoprophylaxis has not generally been recommended during\nepidemics (see <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8625860>), because\nmultiple sources of exposure, prolonged risk of exposure, logistic\nproblems, and high cost make this an impractical alternative. When used,\nthe antimicrobials commonly used for chemoprophylaxis are rifampicin,\nciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and ceftriaxone, although rifampicin- and\nciprofloxacin-resistant meningococcal disease in close contacts has been\nreported following had chemoprophylaxis with these antibiotics (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol11no06/05-0143.htm> and\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm>).\n\nA map showing the regions in Burkina Faso can be seen at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Burkina_Faso>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0188>. A map of the African bacterial meningitis\nbelt can be found at <http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "However, there is no vaccine for\nserogroup X.
