The population of\nBahia in 2008 was 14 109 000; the capital is Salvador, with a population of\n2.8 million (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahia>).\n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal meningitis in Brazil in the past have been due\nto both serogroups B and C (see ProMED-mail post: Meningitis, meningococcal\n- Brazil 19960125.0182). There seems to be an ongoing outbreak of\nmeningococcal meningitis in Bahia. However, the numbers of cases and deaths\nin Bahia in 2009 reported in the news release above are different from\nthose reported in a previous ProMED-mail posting. According to a\nProMED-mail post 'Meningitis, meningococcal - Brazil (02): (BA) RFI\n20091212.4229', as of 10 Dec 2009, there were 2218 total cases of\nmeningococcal meningitis with 138 deaths, and 178 cases of serogroup C\nmeningococcal meningitis with 48 deaths (27 per cent case fatality rate) in\n2009.\n\nIn addition, the case fatality rates given in the above news release do not\nfit the reported data. The case fatality rate in 2010, using the numbers\ngiven in the above news release, is 11.8 per cent (39 deaths in 330 cases),\nnot 31.1 per cent, unless this higher rate refers to deaths from serogroup\nC disease; but then the total number of cases of serogroup C disease is not\ngiven.\n\nThe state of Bahia and its capital Salvador can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia> and\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00ZA>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "According to a\nProMED-mail post 'Meningitis, meningococcal - Brazil (02): (BA) RFI\n20091212.4229', as of 10 Dec 2009, there were 2218 total cases of\nmeningococcal meningitis with 138 deaths, and 178 cases of serogroup C\nmeningococcal meningitis with 48 deaths (27 per cent case fatality rate) in\n2009. The case fatality rate in 2010, using the numbers\ngiven in the above news release, is 11.8 per cent (39 deaths in 330 cases),\nnot 31.1 per cent, unless this higher rate refers to deaths from serogroup\nC disease; but then the total number of cases of serogroup C disease is not\ngiven. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 5 May 2010\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal meningitis in Brazil in the past have been due\nto both serogroups B and C (see ProMED-mail post: Meningitis, meningococcal\n- Brazil 19960125.0182). However, the numbers of cases and deaths\nin Bahia in 2009 reported in the news release above are different from\nthose reported in a previous ProMED-mail posting. \n\nThe state of Bahia and its capital Salvador can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia> and\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00ZA>.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-05-05 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2218-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Salvador", "country": "El Salvador"}, {"location": "Bahia", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "453174", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (CO) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=453174", "date": "2010-06-25 12:00:07", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA: (COLORADO) FATAL\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 23 Jun 2010\nSource: AOL News [edited]\n<http://www.aolnews.com/health/article/fatal-meningitis-outbreak-in-colorado-linked-to-hockey-game/19528409>\n\n\nTwo hockey players have died and 2 other people are hospitalized from\nan outbreak of a particularly virulent strain of meningitis. Health\nofficials said today [23 Jun 2010] they have traced the bacteria to a\ndeath in Denver in April [2010].\n\nOfficials are speculating that players at the end of a [9 Jun 2010]\nhockey game in Fort Collins removed their mouth guards, then shook\nhands, spreading the bacteria through saliva on their hands, said\nJane Viste, a spokeswoman for the Larimer County Department of Health\nand Environment. Since meningitis is spread through contact with\ninfected saliva or nasal fluids, it is also possible that this\noutbreak was transmitted through spitting during the game or sharing\nof water bottles, she said. 'This clustering among the hockey players\nis very unusual,' said Dr Adrienne LeBailly, the department's director.\n\n[N.S., a] 28-year-old mechanical engineer whose wife is 6 months\npregnant, died Tuesday [? 22 Jun 2010]. Another hockey player, B.W.,\na 29-year-old father of 2, died on 14 Jun 2010. A 3rd hockey player,\nW.J., remained hospitalized in critical condition in Montana, where\nhe had been vacationing, Karen Ogden, a spokeswoman for Benefis\nHealth System Hospital in Great Falls, Montana, told AOL News.\n\nThe 4th person, a Colorado State University [CSU] student who has not\nbeen publicly identified was transferred to a hospital in Denver\nafter falling ill during Memorial Day weekend [29-31 May 2010], Viste\nsaid. Although B.W.'s wife works at CSU, the connection between the\nhockey players and the ill CSU student is unknown and possibly\nremote, Viste said.\n\nWhat is known is that the bacteria responsible for 4 of the 5 cases\nare genetically identical, meaning they come from the same source.\nThe test results for W.J. haven't been sent from Montana to Fort\nCollins yet, but they are likely to be genetically identical to the\nothers, officials said.\n\n'Even with this information, we will be very unlikely to tie the\ncases together directly,' LeBailly said. 'Many people carry these\nbacteria in their throats but have no symptoms.'\n\nLess than 1 percent of the people who harbor the bacteria become ill,\nbut they can transmit it to others. The bacteria can cause either\nmeningitis, an infection of the membranes covering the brain and\nspinal cord, or sepsis, an infection of the bloodstream.\nMeningococcal sepsis has a mortality rate of up to 15 percent or\nmore, Viste said.\n\nCounty health officials are vaccinating all Fort Collins Adult Hockey\nLeague players. So far, 65 people have received preventative\nantibiotics, and about 55 have received vaccinations, Viste said.\nCollege students are routinely advised to get vaccinated for\nmeningitis before attending school.\n\nOfficials are optimistic the outbreak might be over. 'Enough time has\npassed for the incubation period, and we've seen no new cases, so\nthat's very good news for now,' Viste said.\n\nIronically, Fort Collins, a community of 120 000 residents 65 miles\n[105 km] north of Denver, is home to one of the research laboratories\nof the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\n[Byline: Karen Schwartz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fort Collins, the location for 4 of the 5 cases of meningitis due to\na genetically identical strain of _Neisseria meningitidis_ , is home\nto Colorado State University (CSU). The city is the county seat of\nLarimer County, Colorado and is located about 60 miles north of the\nColorado State Capitol in Denver\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Collins,_Colorado>). Three of the\nFort Collins cases occurred among adult hockey league players who\nparticipated in a game on 9 Jun 2010 in Fort Collins; the 4th Fort\nCollins case, apparently unrelated to hockey playing, occurred in CSU\nstudent in late May 2010. The 5th case, whose epidemiologic link to\nthe other cases is apparently unknown, occurred in Denver in April 2010.\n\n_N. meningitidis_ causes bacterial meningitis and sepsis. The\nbacteria are transmitted from person to person via droplets of\nrespiratory secretions mostly from asymptomatic nasopharyngeal\ncarriers of the microorganism. It is estimated that between 10 to 25\npercent of the population carry _N. meningitidis_ at any given time,\nand the carriage rate may be much higher in epidemic situations.\nClose and prolonged contact (such as kissing, sneezing and coughing\non someone, living in close quarters or dormitories (military\nrecruits, students), sharing eating or drinking utensils, etc.)\nfacilitates the spread of the disease. The average incubation period\nfor meningococcal meningitis is 4 days, ranging between 2 and 10 days\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>).\n\nEach year, up to 3000 people in the USA develop meningococcal\ndisease. The annual incidence generally ranges from 0.5 to 1.1 cases\nper 100 000. The incidence peaks in late winter and early spring.\nMost cases are sporadic; less than 2 percent occur in outbreaks\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm>; updated at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5631a3.htm>). Outbreaks\ntend to occur in semi-closed communities, such military recruit\ncamps, college dormitories, schools, and day-care centers.\nCommunity-based outbreaks in towns, cities, and counties may also\noccur among persons who are not close contacts of each other and who\ndo not share a common affiliation.\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease in either an organization or\ncommunity is defined as the occurrence of 3 or more confirmed or\nprobable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3 months,\nresulting in a primary disease attack rate in the population at risk\n(such as, hockey team in the outbreak in the news release above) of\nat least 10 cases per 100 000 persons, which is about 10 times\ngreater than the normal occurrence\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>).\n\nChemoprophylaxis is given to appropriate contacts whose risk for\nacquiring meningococcal disease is 500-800 times greater than among\nthe total population\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). Close\ncontacts of patients are household members, day-care center contacts,\nand persons directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions.\n\nIn an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the\nmeningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the\noutbreak as soon as possible after an outbreak has been declared\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5407.pdf>). Because available\nvaccines are not effective against _N. meningitidis_ serogroup B,\nvaccination is not considered during serogroup B outbreaks. Although\nthe serogroup is not specified for the hockey team outbreak, since\nthe hockey team was vaccinated, presumably the serogroup is not serogroup B.\n\nA quadrivalent A, C, Y, and W135 meningococcal conjugate vaccine was\nlicensed in the United States in January 2005. The conjugate vaccine\ninduces a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved immune\nresponse, providing long-lasting immunity and preventing\nnasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ and thus reducing\nbacterial transmission of this microorganism\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>).\n\nFort Collins in northern Colorado can be seen on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00-s>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease in either an organization or\ncommunity is defined as the occurrence of 3 or more confirmed or\nprobable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3 months,\nresulting in a primary disease attack rate in the population at risk\n(such as, hockey team in the outbreak in the news release above) of\nat least 10 cases per 100 000 persons, which is about 10 times\ngreater than the normal occurrence\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 23 Jun 2010\n The conjugate vaccine\ninduces a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved immune\nresponse, providing long-lasting immunity and preventing\nnasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ and thus reducing\nbacterial transmission of this microorganism\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>). \n\nOfficials are speculating that players at the end of a [9 Jun 2010]\nhockey game in Fort Collins removed their mouth guards, then shook\nhands, spreading the bacteria through saliva on their hands, said\nJane Viste, a spokeswoman for the Larimer County Department of Health\nand Environment. Three of the\nFort Collins cases occurred among adult hockey league players who\nparticipated in a game on 9 Jun 2010 in Fort Collins; the 4th Fort\nCollins case, apparently unrelated to hockey playing, occurred in CSU\nstudent in late May 2010. Although\nthe serogroup is not specified for the hockey team outbreak, since\nthe hockey team was vaccinated, presumably the serogroup is not serogroup B.\n\nA quadrivalent A, C, Y, and W135 meningococcal conjugate vaccine was\nlicensed in the United States in January 2005. \n\nIn an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the\nmeningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the\noutbreak as soon as possible after an outbreak has been declared\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5407.pdf>). \n\nThe 4th person, a Colorado State University [CSU] student who has not\nbeen publicly identified was transferred to a hospital in Denver\nafter falling ill during Memorial Day weekend [29-31 May 2010], Viste\nsaid. \n\nChemoprophylaxis is given to appropriate contacts whose risk for\nacquiring meningococcal disease is 500-800 times greater than among\nthe total population\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). Since meningitis is spread through contact with\ninfected saliva or nasal fluids, it is also possible that this\noutbreak was transmitted through spitting during the game or sharing\nof water bottles, she said. ' Close and prolonged contact (such as kissing, sneezing and coughing\non someone, living in close quarters or dormitories (military\nrecruits, students), sharing eating or drinking utensils, etc.)\nfacilitates the spread of the disease. A 3rd hockey player,\nW.J., remained hospitalized in critical condition in Montana, where\nhe had been vacationing, Karen Ogden, a spokeswoman for Benefis\nHealth System Hospital in Great Falls, Montana, told AOL News. The\nbacteria are transmitted from person to person via droplets of\nrespiratory secretions mostly from asymptomatic nasopharyngeal\ncarriers of the microorganism. The city is the county seat of\nLarimer County, Colorado and is located about 60 miles north of the\nColorado State Capitol in Denver\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Collins,_Colorado>). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fort Collins, the location for 4 of the 5 cases of meningitis due to\na genetically identical strain of _Neisseria meningitidis_ , is home\nto Colorado State University (CSU). Health\nofficials said today [23 Jun 2010] they have traced the bacteria to a\ndeath in Denver in April [2010]. Although B.W.'s wife works at CSU, the connection between the\nhockey players and the ill CSU student is unknown and possibly\nremote, Viste said. The average incubation period\nfor meningococcal meningitis is 4 days, ranging between 2 and 10 days\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). It is estimated that between 10 to 25\npercent of the population carry _N. meningitidis_ at any given time,\nand the carriage rate may be much higher in epidemic situations.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-05-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2010-04-26 00:00:00", "2010-06-23 00:00:00", "2010-06-14 00:00:00", "2005-01-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Great Falls", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "N.S.", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W.J.", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Fort Collins", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "B.W.", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "428193", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Enteroviral meningitis - Canada: (BC) ex Dominican Republic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=428193", "date": "2010-05-15 19:00:03", "main_text": "ENTEROVIRAL MENINGITIS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA) ex DOMINICAN REPUBLIC\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 14 May 2010\nFrom: David Patrick\n<david.patrick@bccdc.ca>\n\n\nOutbreak of enteroviral meningitis among high school students in\nBritish Columbia ex Dominican Republic\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nOn Sat 8 Apr 2010, a high school student from the lower mainland of\nBritish Columbia was hospitalized with signs and symptoms consistent\nwith meningitis after returning from a student trip to the Dominican\nRepublic. The trip was organized through a social networking site.\nApproximately 200 Grade 11 and 12 students departed Vancouver on 25\nMar 2010 and returned on 2 Apr 2010. Students were predominantly from\nhigh schools in the Vancouver region, although some participants were\nfrom schools in Ontario and Quebec.\n\nIn total, 23 students were reported as having presented to physician\noffices or emergency rooms between 6 Apr and 25 Apr 2010 with\nsymptoms including fever, headache, nausea, vomiting and sore neck. 5\nwere hospitalized for a period of 2 to 10 days. Severity of symptoms\nvaried substantially, but all students recovered. We undertook an\naggressive laboratory search for the etiology given the serious\nillness being seen in the affected students and the continued spread\nto non-traveler contacts. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) was obtained from\n3 patients and tested for bacterial and viral agents of meningitis.\nAll culture and PCR tests for bacterial meningitis and herpes simplex\nvirus were negative. CSF samples were positive for enterovirus by\nRT-PCR in 2 of the 3 cases. A stool sample from one of the cases was\nalso positive for enterovirus by RT-PCR.\n\nCases were 14 to 18 years old and most were males from the same high\nschool. 7 cases presenting from 6 to 13 Apr 2010 had participated in\nthe trip to the Dominican Republic. These included 2 hospitalized\ncases, one of whom was positive for enterovirus in CSF and stool\nsamples. 16 cases who had not participated in the trip were reported\nfrom 13 to 25 Apr 2010. Investigation of exposures revealed that\nthese were close contacts or schoolmates of cases who had travelled.\n\nIn particular, 8 cases were members of a sports team who attended a\ngame together on 10 Apr 2010. Among these, one case had travelled to\nthe Dominican Republic and reported sharing drinks with a team member\nwho subsequently was admitted to hospital and tested positive for\nenterovirus in a CSF sample. 6 others were likely secondary or\ntertiary transmissions within this group, and the remaining case was\nreported at another game one week later.\n\nAlthough not all students presenting with illness were found to have\nsymptoms of meningitis, they all had symptoms consistent with\nenterovirus infection. Initially, a notice recommending ill students\nto seek medical attention was sent to trip participants through the\nsocial networking site. Prevention messages recommending\nhand-washing, respiratory etiquette, avoiding contact with saliva and\nstaying home when ill were distributed to school districts and health\nauthorities on 9, 13 and 19 Apr 2010. At the school where most cases\nattended, disinfection of commonly touched surfaces began on 19 Apr 2010.\n\nThis outbreak of meningitis generated considerable anxiety among the\ntrip participants and their parents particularly when the etiology\nwas unknown and early cases were treated empirically with\nantibiotics. It highlights the need to be vigilant for clusters of\nillness in travelers and the need to search for viral and other\ncauses of infection that may be endemic or circulating in the country\nvisited, as well as local pathogens.\n\n[Byline: Claudia Rank, BC Centre for Disease Control\nDr. Larry Gustafson, Fraser Health Authority\nDr. Bonnie Henry, BC Centre for Disease Control\nDr. Patrick Tang, BC Centre for Disease Control\nDr. David Patrick, BC Centre for Disease Control]\n\n--\nDavid Patrick, MD, FRCPC, MHSc\nDirector, Epidemiology Services\nBC Centre for Disease Control and\nProfessor, School of Population and Public Health\nUniversity of British Columbia\n655 West 12 Ave\nVancouver, BC V5Z 4R4 Canada\n<david.patrick@bccdc.ca>\n\n[Meningitis is caused predominantly by microorganisms (bacteria,\nviruses, parasites, and fungi). These microorganisms infect the blood\nand the cerebrospinal fluid. Viral meningitis is generally less\nsevere and resolves without specific treatment. Viral meningitis\n(also called aseptic meningitis) is an infection that causes\ninflammation of the layers (meninges) that surround the brain and\nspinal cord. Many different viruses can cause meningitis; the most\ncommon are the enteroviruses. These viruses are present in the\nintestines and can cause colds, sore throats, stomach upsets and\ndiarrhoea. Only rarely do these viruses spread through the body to\nthe meninges causing meningitis.\n\nEnteroviruses are most often spread from person to person through\nfecal contamination, and through respiratory secretions (saliva,\nsputum, or nasal mucus) of an infected person. When an enterovirus\ncausing meningitis is identified, it is usually either a\ncoxsackievirus or an echovirus.\n\nIndividuals and parties visiting countries with less well-developed\neconomies and variable standards of personal and community hygiene\nare likely to expose themselves to common enteric viruses to which\nthey have little preexisting immunity. This is evident in the party\nof children from Canada visiting the Dominical Republic and spreading\ninfection in their home country on their return. Fortunately\nenteroviral meningitis is a mild condition generally without serious outcomes.\n\nProMED-mail is indebted to Professor David Patrick for providing this\ndetailed account of the analysis of this outbreak. It would be useful\nto know the precise identity (species of enterovirus) responsible for\nthis outbreak, if this information becomes available in due course.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/007x >, and that of the Dominican Republic at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/ 00NY>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 14 May 2010\n Dr. Larry Gustafson, Fraser Health Authority\nDr. Bonnie Henry, BC Centre for Disease Control\nDr. Patrick Tang, BC Centre for Disease Control\nDr. David Patrick, BC Centre for Disease Control]\n\n--\nDavid Patrick, MD, FRCPC, MHSc\n \n\nThis outbreak of meningitis generated considerable anxiety among the\ntrip participants and their parents particularly when the etiology\nwas unknown and early cases were treated empirically with\nantibiotics. On Sat 8 Apr 2010, a high school student from the lower mainland of\nBritish Columbia was hospitalized with signs and symptoms consistent\nwith meningitis after returning from a student trip to the Dominican\nRepublic. Viral meningitis\n(also called aseptic meningitis) is an infection that causes\ninflammation of the layers (meninges) that surround the brain and\nspinal cord. Prevention messages recommending\nhand-washing, respiratory etiquette, avoiding contact with saliva and\nstaying home when ill were distributed to school districts and health\nauthorities on 9, 13 and 19 Apr 2010. From: David Patrick\n<david.patrick@bccdc.ca>\n\n\nOutbreak of enteroviral meningitis among high school students in\nBritish Columbia ex Dominican Republic\n \n\nIndividuals and parties visiting countries with less well-developed\neconomies and variable standards of personal and community hygiene\nare likely to expose themselves to common enteric viruses to which\nthey have little preexisting immunity. Among these, one case had travelled to\nthe Dominican Republic and reported sharing drinks with a team member\nwho subsequently was admitted to hospital and tested positive for\nenterovirus in a CSF sample. We undertook an\naggressive laboratory search for the etiology given the serious\nillness being seen in the affected students and the continued spread\nto non-traveler contacts. It highlights the need to be vigilant for clusters of\nillness in travelers and the need to search for viral and other\ncauses of infection that may be endemic or circulating in the country\nvisited, as well as local pathogens. Although not all students presenting with illness were found to have\nsymptoms of meningitis, they all had symptoms consistent with\nenterovirus infection. In total, 23 students were reported as having presented to physician\noffices or emergency rooms between 6 Apr and 25 Apr 2010 with\nsymptoms including fever, headache, nausea, vomiting and sore neck. Vancouver, BC V5Z 4R4 Canada\n<david.patrick@bccdc.ca>\n\n[Meningitis is caused predominantly by microorganisms (bacteria,\nviruses, parasites, and fungi). \n\nEnteroviruses are most often spread from person to person through\nfecal contamination, and through respiratory secretions (saliva,\nsputum, or nasal mucus) of an infected person. These included 2 hospitalized\ncases, one of whom was positive for enterovirus in CSF and stool\nsamples. Initially, a notice recommending ill students\nto seek medical attention was sent to trip participants through the\nsocial networking site. When an enterovirus\ncausing meningitis is identified, it is usually either a\ncoxsackievirus or an echovirus.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-05-14 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-04-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "the Dominical Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "the Dominican Republic", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "the Dominican \n Republic", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "417389", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Undiagnosed fatalities - Uganda: (BG) meningitis susp. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=417389", "date": "2010-04-28 14:00:04", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED FATALITIES - UGANDA (BUGIRI), MENINGITIS SUSPECTED,\nREQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 28 Apr 2010\nSource: Daily Monitor (Uganda) [edited]\n<http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/-/688334/907920/-/wy0vx1/-/>\n\n\nHealth authorities in Bugiri District have dispatched a medical team\nto investigate a disease that has killed at least 72 people in the\nlast month. Officials took the decision after the disease, suspected\nto be meningitis, killed half of its victims at [Hamma] Island on\nLake Victoria and Buwongo Village, Buhemba Sub-county on the mainland\nwithin the last week alone.\n\nThe district health officer, Isaac Malinga, said the team is expected\nto report its findings within 2 days in order to help them plan how\nto stem the outbreak. He, however, added that the district is\nill-equipped to fight the disease on its own. 'The outbreak has\ncaught us unprepared but there is hope that the government will\nintervene to save the lives of the people once the cause of deaths is\nestablished,' he said.\n\nThe Buhemba Sub-county Secretary for Health, Mr John Mbiro, said 32\npeople, most of whom are children, have so far died in his area. He\nblamed the deaths on the geographical location of the affected areas,\nwhich are both difficult to reach due to distance from the mainland\nand bad roads.\n\nThe LC1 [Local Council 1] Chairman of Hamma Island, Mr Amuza Nagheje,\nsaid some of the sick have been transported to Lake Victoria and\nBondo hospitals in western Kenya to receive treatment. He said all\nthe medical personnel at the only health centre on the island had\ndeserted the facility.\n\n[Byline: Fred Siminyu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSharon Sanders\nFluTrackers\n<sharonsanders@flutrackers.com>\n\n[The lack of more specifics concerning this outbreak of suspected\nmeningitis with a 50 percent case fatality rate, where the deaths\nhave involved mainly children, in a remote region, makes a specific\ndiagnosis difficult. ProMED-mail awaits further information with interest.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the affected district in the southeastern\nportion of the country, on the coast of Lake Victoria, can be found at\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/fullmaps_af.nsf/luFullMap/6241FC691CBA85F385257194005F2E3A/$File/ocha_REF_uga30022006.pdf?OpenElement>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01ex>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Apr 2010\nSource: Daily Monitor (Uganda) [edited]\n<http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/-/688334/907920/-/wy0vx1/-/>\n\n\nHealth authorities in Bugiri District have dispatched a medical team\nto investigate a disease that has killed at least 72 people in the\nlast month. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 28 [The lack of more specifics concerning this outbreak of suspected\nmeningitis with a 50 percent case fatality rate, where the deaths\nhave involved mainly children, in a remote region, makes a specific\ndiagnosis difficult. The outbreak has\ncaught us unprepared but there is hope that the government will\nintervene to save the lives of the people once the cause of deaths is\nestablished,' he said. He\nblamed the deaths on the geographical location of the affected areas,\nwhich are both difficult to reach due to distance from the mainland\nand bad roads. Communicated by:\nSharon Sanders\nFluTrackers\n<sharonsanders@flutrackers.com>\n\n UNDIAGNOSED FATALITIES - UGANDA (BUGIRI), MENINGITIS SUSPECTED,\nREQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Buhemba Sub - county", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Hamma Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Buwongo Village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "416000", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa (02): WHO meningitis region", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=416000", "date": "2010-04-26 12:00:04", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA (02): WHO MENINGITIS REGION\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 24 Apr 2010\nCommercial Times Corporation, Xinhua News Agency report [in Chinese,\nmachine trans., edited]\n<http://www.sdshang.com/MMM/P_Show.asp?id=48095>\n\n\nThe Burkina Faso Ministry of Health released a public statement\nreporting that the meningitis epidemic is currently spreading in the\ncountry. The statement said that between 1 Jan-18 Apr 2010, national\nhealth agencies have reported 5118 suspected cases of meningitis,\nincluding 718 deaths.\n\nAccording to the Ministry of Health statistics, during the same\nperiod in 2009, there were 4000 suspected cases of meningitis,\nincluding 600 deaths.\n\nIn February 2010 the government of Burkina Faso adopted a plan to\ncombat meningitis. The program aims to increase public awareness,\neducate the population, carry out vaccination campaigns, and reduce\nthe mortality rate of meningitis.\n\nBurkina Faso, Mali, Nigeria, Chad, and Ghana have been greatly\naffected by meningitis. Several major outbreaks of meningitis have\noccurred in Burkina Faso since 1996.\n\nThe main symptoms of meningitis are fever, severe headache, and stiff\nneck; if not promptly treated, patients may lose consciousness or even die.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 23 Apr 2010\nSource: UN Integrated Regional Information Networks (IRIN) [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=88915>\n\n\nA new strain of meningitis, strain NMX, also known simply as strain\nX, has broken out in Burkina Faso, where it caused just over half the\nnew cases reported in the past week [week ending 18 Apr 2010]. Of\nBurkina Faso's 13 regions 6 are at epidemic level. Since the\nbeginning of 2010, 5118 cases of meningitis have been reported, and\n718 people have died according to the health ministry. Health\nMinister Seydou Bouda told reporters at a press conference on 22 Apr\n[2010] that strain X was not 'well-known in Burkina.' Meningitis --\ntransmitted by nose and throat secretions -- usually spreads across\nsub-Saharan West Africa in the dry months from December to June.\n\nTen cases of the strain have been reported in Niger according to Dr\nMamadou Djingarey, a World Health Organization (WHO) official in the\ncapital, Ouagadougou. Niger experienced an epidemic of strain X in\n2006. Strain X is 'no more worrying than other meningitis strains,'\nthe official told IRIN; strain A is the most lethal of the 12\nmeningitis strains, according to WHO.\n\nStrain X has been reported in 14 of Burkina Faso's 65 districts.\nBouda said the symptoms of the new strain were the same as other\nstrains -- sudden fever, headache, and vomiting -- while children\nless than one year old might experience swelling in their head\n[bulging of the anterior frontanelle].\n\nAcross West Africa, some 14 700 meningitis cases and 1650 deaths were\nreported between 1 Jan and 11 Apr 2010, according to the most recent\nWHO statistics available. This is not as critical as the same period\nin 2009, when 49 209 people were infected in an outbreak that killed\n2767. Affected countries this year [2010] include Benin, Burkina\nFaso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana,\nGuinea, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Togo, and the Democratic Republic of Congo.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-EAFR\n<promed-eafr@promedmail.org>\n\n[The emergence of a new strain (serogroup X) of meningococcal\nmeningitis in Burkina Faso this year [2010] has led to huge outbreaks\nin the country, with 46 percent (6/13) of the regions in the country\nbeing at epidemic level. The associated case fatality since the year\nstarted is equally high, that is, 14 percent (781/5118), yet it\nshouldn't exceed 10 percent for a well-managed epidemic. Serogroup X\nis reported to have caused outbreaks in Niger in 2006 and has now\nmoved to Burkina Faso as indicated in the current report. Serogroup X\nis one of those for which no vaccine exists, hence outbreak control\nrelies solely on enhanced surveillance for early case detection and\nreferral, appropriate case management using single dose oily\nchloramphenicol, and social mobilization and health education. - Mod.JFW]\n\n[The number of suspected cases of meningococcal meningitis in Burkina\nFaso has quadrupled, as has the number of deaths since the last\nreport in Feb 2010 (see ProMED-mail post, Meningitis, meningococcal -\nAfrica: WHO meningitis region 20100225.0627).\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate meningococcal vaccine, depending on availability, in\nevery involved district in an attempt to induce herd immunity\n(whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the\npopulation have been vaccinated (see\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>).\n\nThere are at least 13 serogroups of _Neisseria meningitidis_ based on\nthe antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides; disease\nis most commonly due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135. All these\nserogroup polysaccharides but B are immunogenic in humans.\n\nThere are several different types of meningococcal vaccines that use\nmeningococcal polysaccharides as the immunogen: the vaccines may\ncontain one or more of the polysaccharide serogroups alone or\nconjugated to protein. Meningococcal vaccines will only protect\nagainst meningitis due to the meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups\nthat the vaccine contains.\n\nPolysaccharide vaccines, which have been available for more than 30\nyears, exist for serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various\ncombinations (such as, a bivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a\ntetravalent ACYW-135 polysaccharide vaccine). There is a monovalent\nprotein conjugate vaccine against serogroup C and a tetravalent\nagainst serogroups A, C, Y, and, W-135. There is no vaccine for serogroup X.\n\nAlthough children as young as 3 months of age may have an immunologic\nresponse to the serogroup A antigen contained in the meningococcal\npolysaccharide vaccines, response to the other serogroup antigens is\npoor in children younger than 2 years of age. These vaccines also\nonly provide protection for up to 3 years. In contrast, the\nmeningococcal conjugate vaccines induce a T-cell-dependent response,\nresulting in an improved immune response in infants, provide\nlong-lasting immunity, and prevent nasopharyngeal carriage of _N.\nmeningitidis_, thus reducing transmission of this microorganism\nperson-to-person (see\n<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>).\n\nA preventive strategy based on conjugate vaccines could have a\nsignificantly larger and more enduring impact on attempts to control\nthe yearly recurrences of this disease that causes considerable\nmorbidity and mortality, especially among children (see\n<http://www.jidc.org/index.php/journal/article/view/19745499/102>).\n\nAll these vaccines have been proven safe and effective with\ninfrequent and mild side effects. For both the meningococcal\nconjugate and the polysaccharide vaccines, approximately 7-10 days\nare required following vaccination for development of protective\nlevels of anti-meningococcal antibodies.\n\nA prior ProMED-mail post this year (2010) said that health\nauthorities believe that meningococcus serogroup A, which has been\nresponsible for almost all outbreaks in the Burkina Faso in the past,\nis also responsible for the current outbreak, but that people who\nwere vaccinated in 2009, presumably with meningococcal serogroup A\nvaccine, still contracted the disease, that was presumed to be due to\nserogroup A meningococci. They discounted loss of vaccine potency at\nthe time. However, both the polysaccharide and the conjugate vaccines\nrequire proper refrigeration; improper storage or handling of\nvaccines may result in loss of vaccine potency and reduced immune\nresponse in vaccinees. Also, the vaccines will not prevent\nmeningococcal infection caused by meningococcal serogroups not\nrepresented in the vaccines, such as serogroup X, and will not\nprevent bacterial meningitis caused by other pathogens, such as\n_Streptococcus pneumoniae_, a pathogen also known to cause outbreaks\nin the African 'meningitis' region (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis,\npneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100213.0507). The\ndevelopment of meningococcal meningitis in some patients who were\npreviously vaccinated can now be apparently explained by these\npatients being infected with a non-vaccine meningococcal serogroup,\nspecifically serogroup X.\n\nA map showing the regions in Burkina Faso can be seen at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Burkina_Faso>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0188>. A map of the African bacterial\nmeningitis belt can be found at\n<http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Also, the vaccines will not prevent\nmeningococcal infection caused by meningococcal serogroups not\nrepresented in the vaccines, such as serogroup X, and will not\nprevent bacterial meningitis caused by other pathogens, such as\n_Streptococcus pneumoniae_, a pathogen also known to cause outbreaks\nin the African 'meningitis' region (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis,\npneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100213.0507). \n\nA prior ProMED-mail post this year (2010) said that health\nauthorities believe that meningococcus serogroup A, which has been\nresponsible for almost all outbreaks in the Burkina Faso in the past,\nis also responsible for the current outbreak, but that people who\nwere vaccinated in 2009, presumably with meningococcal serogroup A\nvaccine, still contracted the disease, that was presumed to be due to\nserogroup A meningococci. In contrast, the\nmeningococcal conjugate vaccines induce a T-cell-dependent response,\nresulting in an improved immune response in infants, provide\nlong-lasting immunity, and prevent nasopharyngeal carriage of _N.\nmeningitidis_, thus reducing transmission of this microorganism\nperson-to-person (see\n<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>). The\ndevelopment of meningococcal meningitis in some patients who were\npreviously vaccinated can now be apparently explained by these\npatients being infected with a non-vaccine meningococcal serogroup,\nspecifically serogroup X.\n\nA map showing the regions in Burkina Faso can be seen at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Burkina_Faso>. Communicated by:\nProMED-EAFR\n<promed-eafr@promedmail.org>\n\n[The emergence of a new strain (serogroup X) of meningococcal\nmeningitis in Burkina Faso this year [2010] has led to huge outbreaks\nin the country, with 46 percent (6/13) of the regions in the country\nbeing at epidemic level. \n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate meningococcal vaccine, depending on availability, in\nevery involved district in an attempt to induce herd immunity\n(whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the\npopulation have been vaccinated (see\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \n\nA preventive strategy based on conjugate vaccines could have a\nsignificantly larger and more enduring impact on attempts to control\nthe yearly recurrences of this disease that causes considerable\nmorbidity and mortality, especially among children (see\n<http://www.jidc.org/index.php/journal/article/view/19745499/102>). Serogroup X\nis one of those for which no vaccine exists, hence outbreak control\nrelies solely on enhanced surveillance for early case detection and\nreferral, appropriate case management using single dose oily\nchloramphenicol, and social mobilization and health education. There is no vaccine for serogroup X.\n\nAlthough children as young as 3 months of age may have an immunologic\nresponse to the serogroup A antigen contained in the meningococcal\npolysaccharide vaccines, response to the other serogroup antigens is\npoor in children younger than 2 years of age. \n\nThere are several different types of meningococcal vaccines that use\nmeningococcal polysaccharides as the immunogen: the vaccines may\ncontain one or more of the polysaccharide serogroups alone or\nconjugated to protein. \n\nPolysaccharide vaccines, which have been available for more than 30\nyears, exist for serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various\ncombinations (such as, a bivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a\ntetravalent ACYW-135 polysaccharide vaccine). For both the meningococcal\nconjugate and the polysaccharide vaccines, approximately 7-10 days\nare required following vaccination for development of protective\nlevels of anti-meningococcal antibodies. However, both the polysaccharide and the conjugate vaccines\nrequire proper refrigeration; improper storage or handling of\nvaccines may result in loss of vaccine potency and reduced immune\nresponse in vaccinees. Bouda said the symptoms of the new strain were the same as other\nstrains -- sudden fever, headache, and vomiting -- while children\nless than one year old might experience swelling in their head\n Apr 2010\nCommercial Times Corporation, Xinhua News Agency report [in Chinese,\nmachine trans., edited]\n<http://www.sdshang.com/MMM/P_Show.asp?id=48095>\n\n\n A new strain of meningitis, strain NMX, also known simply as strain\nX, has broken out in Burkina Faso, where it caused just over half the\nnew cases reported in the past week [week ending 18 Apr 2010]. Meningococcal vaccines will only protect\nagainst meningitis due to the meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups\nthat the vaccine contains. \n\nThe main symptoms of meningitis are fever, severe headache, and stiff\nneck; if not promptly treated, patients may lose consciousness or even die.\n\n--\n Strain X is 'no more worrying than other meningitis strains,'\nthe official told IRIN; strain A is the most lethal of the 12\nmeningitis strains, according to WHO.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2767-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "1996-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1650-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-02-26 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "Guinea"}, {"location": "Burkina", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Ouagadougou", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "Mali"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "415207", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Russia: (KN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=415207", "date": "2010-04-24 14:00:06", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - RUSSIA: KALININGRAD\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 20 Apr 2010\nSource: News agency 'Zapadnaya pressa' [in Russian; trans. ATS; edited]\n<http://www.klops.ru/news/22479.html>\n\n\nA total of 10 cases of meningococcal infection have been registered in\nKaliningrad oblast in the past 4 months. Rospotrebnadzor [Russian Federal\nAgency for Protection of Customer Rights and Human Welfare] media services\nhave reported that there were half as many cases last year [2009] during\nthe same period of time.\n\nAll cases were children from Kaliningrad and Svetly, Zelenogradskiy,\nKrasnoznamenskiy, and Gvardeyskiy rayons [rayon is a type of administrative\nunit]. A 15 year old schoolgirl from Kaliningrad died from meningitis on 15\nApr 2010. Rospotrebnadzor reported that the cause of her death was severe\nfulminating meningococcal infection and that infection control measures\nhave been taken.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are 2-20 000 meningococcal nasopharyngitis and carrier cases\n(localized forms) for each case of generalized meningococcal infection.\nThis ratio is as high as 45-50 000 to one in big cities. The increase of\nmorbidity in generalized forms of meningococcal infection requires\nserogroup A and B vaccination of all susceptible children, teenagers, and\nadults. Children and teenagers from preschools, schools, and boarding\nschools are at special risk. - Mod.NP\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_, the cause of meningococcal disease, is\ntransmitted from person to person via droplets of respiratory secretions\nmostly from asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers of the microorganism. It\nis estimated that between 10 and 25 per cent of the population carry _N.\nmeningitidis_ at any given time, and the carriage rate may be much higher\nin epidemic situations. Close and prolonged contact (such as kissing,\nsneezing, and coughing on someone, living in close quarters or dormitories\n(military recruits, students), sharing eating or drinking utensils, etc)\nfacilitates the spread of the disease. The average incubation period for\nmeningococcal meningitis is 4 days, ranging between 2 and 10 days\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). Outbreaks tend to\noccur in semi-closed communities, such military recruit camps, college\ndormitories, schools, and day-care centers. Community-based outbreaks in\ntowns, cities, and counties may also occur among persons who are not close\ncontacts of each other and who do not share a common affiliation.\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease is defined as the occurrence of 3 or\nmore confirmed or probable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3\nmonths, resulting in a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per\n100 000 persons, which is about 10-20 times greater than the normal\noccurrence (for calculation of attack rates see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). Chemoprophylaxis\nis given to appropriate contacts whose risk for acquiring meningococcal\ndisease is 500-800 times greater than among the total population\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). Close contacts\nof patients are household members, day-care center contacts, and persons\ndirectly exposed to the patient's oral secretions. Administering\nchemoprophylaxis to persons who are not close contacts of patients usually\nis not recommended. Neither oropharyngeal nor nasopharyngeal cultures for\n_N. meningitidis_ are useful in deciding who should receive chemoprophylaxis.\n\nIn an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the\nmeningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the outbreak as\nsoon as possible after an outbreak has been declared\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). Mass\nimmunization campaigns are labor-intensive and costly. Meningococcal\npolysaccharide vaccines do not protect very young children, do not protect\nunvaccinated population groups, and only provide protection for up to 3\nyears. As a result, repetitive meningitis outbreak responses can deplete a\ncountry's scarce health care finances with comparably little impact.\n\nA preventive strategy based on conjugate vaccines could have a\nsignificantly larger and more enduring impact. A quadrivalent A, C, Y, and\nW135 conjugate vaccine was licensed in the United States in January 2005.\nThe meningococcal conjugate vaccines induce a T-cell-dependent response,\nresulting in an improved immune response in infants, providing long-lasting\nimmunity and preventing nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ and\nthus reducing bacterial transmission of this microorganism\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>).\n\nKaliningrad Oblast, the northern part of the former East Prussia, is a\nfederal district of Russia situated between Poland and Lithuania on the\nBaltic coast and is geographically separated from the rest of Russia. It\nhas a population of 955 281 (2002 census)\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaliningrad_Oblast>). The combined\npopulation of Kaliningrad, Svetly, Zelenogradskiy, Krasnoznamenskiy, and\nGvardeyskiy rayons is about 500 000 (<http://www.statoids.com/yru.html>).\nThe attack rate of 10 cases in 500 000 people is below the outbreak\nthreshold for meningococcal disease of 10 per 100 000.\n\nA map of Kaliningrad Oblast can be found at\n<http://www.travelpost.com/AS/Russia/Kaliningrad/Kaliningrad/map/1475049>.\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Russia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=Russia&g=6301021&v=56.23,43.784,5>. -\nMod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease is defined as the occurrence of 3 or\nmore confirmed or probable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3\nmonths, resulting in a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per\n100 000 persons, which is about 10-20 times greater than the normal\noccurrence (for calculation of attack rates see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). Rospotrebnadzor reported that the cause of her death was severe\nfulminating meningococcal infection and that infection control measures\nhave been taken.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n< A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 20 Apr 2010\n The meningococcal conjugate vaccines induce a T-cell-dependent response,\nresulting in an improved immune response in infants, providing long-lasting\nimmunity and preventing nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ and\nthus reducing bacterial transmission of this microorganism\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>). Chemoprophylaxis\nis given to appropriate contacts whose risk for acquiring meningococcal\ndisease is 500-800 times greater than among the total population\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). [As of] Thursday [10 Dec 2009], there were\n2218 cases reported to the Directorate of Health Information by the\nSecretary of Health of the State (Sesab). The capital of Bahia\n[Salvador] leads the notifications, with 1445 [cases], followed by\nVitoria da Conquista, with 157 and Irece, with 103. With the increase\nof cases, the number of deaths also increased accordingly. In Bahia,\n138 deaths were reported.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological bulletin of Sesab in 2009, [as of]\nthe 5th of this month [December 2009], there were 178 cases of\nmeningococcal disease (serogroup C), with 48 deaths confirmed in the\nstate. In the previous year [2008], were 137 cases of meningitis,\nwith 26 deaths. Salvador [the capital of the state] is experiencing\nan increase in the number of cases of [serogroup] C disease, with 56\ncases and 15 deaths reported in 2008 and 100 cases and 25 deaths\nreported in 2009, 44 percent more than in 2008, according to the\nepidemiological bulletin.\n\nConfirmed cases of meningitis in Bahia in 2009 occurred in 43\nmunicipalities, with the highest incidences reported in: Nazareth,\nPorto Seguro, Formosa do Rio Preto, Antonio Cardoso e Itacare.\n\nAccording to Sesab, meningitis is an inflammation of the lining of\nthe brain, which may be caused by various infectious agents like\nbacteria, viruses, fungi, and noninfectious agents and some\nchemicals. It occurs throughout the year with predominance during the\ncolder periods.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[The state of Bahia is one of 26 states of Brazil and is located in\nthe northeastern part of the country on the Atlantic coast; it can be\nseen on the map at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg>. The population\nof Bahia in 2008 was 14 109 000; about 70 percent live in cities, the\nlargest of which is the capital, Salvador, with a population of 2.8\nmillion (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahia>). The population of\nVitoria da Conquista is 300 000.\n\nAssuming meningococcus serogroup C is the cause of meningitis in the\nunconfirmed cases, then the attack rate for Bahia is 15.7 per 100\n000; and for Salvador, 51.6 per 100 000; and for Vitoria da\nConquista, 52.3 per 100 000. For those with confirmed serogroup C\nmeningitis, the attack rate for Bahia is 1.26 per 100 000 and for\nSalvador, 3.6 per 100 000. However, the time period over which these\ncases occurred is not specified in the news release, other than that\nthey occurred in 2009.\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease has been defined as the\noccurrence of 3 or more confirmed or probable cases during a period\nof less than or equal to 3 months, resulting in a primary disease\nattack rate of at least 10 cases per 100 000 persons, which is about\n10 times greater than the normal occurrence\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>. Further\ninformation would be appreciated as to the time line during which the\ncases of meningitis occurred in Bahia and probable etiologies in the\nunconfirmed cases.\n\nThe state of Bahia and its capital, Salvador can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia> and\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00ZA>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease has been defined as the\noccurrence of 3 or more confirmed or probable cases during a period\nof less than or equal to 3 months, resulting in a primary disease\nattack rate of at least 10 cases per 100 000 persons, which is about\n10 times greater than the normal occurrence\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>.
