[The state of Bahia is one of 26 states of Brazil and is located in\nthe northeastern part of the country on the Atlantic coast; it can be\nseen on the map at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg>. \n\nConfirmed cases of meningitis in Bahia in 2009 occurred in 43\nmunicipalities, with the highest incidences reported in: Nazareth,\nPorto Seguro, Formosa do Rio Preto, Antonio Cardoso e Itacare.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2218-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "1445-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-12-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Salvador", "country": "El Salvador"}, {"location": "Bahia", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "386214", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Chad: (LR,MA) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=386214", "date": "2010-02-23 04:00:03", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - CHAD: (LOGONE ORIENTAL, MANDOUL) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 22 Feb 2010\nSource: Diario Siglo XXI, Europa Press report [in Spanish, machine trans.,\nedited]\n<http://www.diariosigloxxi.com/texto-ep/mostrar/20100222111506>\n\n\nAccording to the health minister of Chad, Ngombaye Djaibe, a meningitis\nepidemic has killed 56 people [during] a little over 2 weeks in Logone\nOriental and Mandoul regions, in southern Chad.\n\nThe minister added that medical services have treated 517 people suffering\nfrom this disease, 56 of whom have died. Nevertheless, more than 40 000\npeople have been vaccinated and the situation is under control. Chad is\npart of a 'meningitis belt' stretching from Senegal to Djibouti.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is extracted from ProMED-mail moderator ML's comments in\nMeningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100213.0507:\n\n'Numerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the sub-Saharan\nAfrican region known as the 'meningitis belt' each year during the hot, dry\nseason, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large outbreaks\noccur (<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>).\n\n'The 'Meningitis Belt' extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\nAttack rates during these cyclic epidemics of meningitis range from 100 to\n800 per 100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates\nas high as 1000 per 100 000 (World Health Organization: Meningococcal\nmeningitis fact sheet;\n<http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/pdf/FactSheet-Meningitis.pdf>). While in\nendemic disease the highest attack rates are observed in young children,\nduring epidemics, older children, teenagers and adults are also affected.\n\n'Although epidemics of meningitis are mostly associated with the\nmeningococcus, there is evidence that increases in pneumococcal meningitis\ncases occur in parallel in sub-Saharan Africa during the hot and dry season\n\n'[Mar ID, et al. Epidemiologic features of pneumococcal meningitis in\nAfrica. Clinical and serotypical aspects (author's transl). Pathol Biol\n(Paris) 1979; 27: 543-8; abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/44737>.\nLeimkugel J, et al. An outbreak of serotype 1 _Streptococcus pneumoniae_\nmeningitis in northern Ghana with features that are characteristic of\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ meningitis epidemics. J Infect Dis 2005; 192:\n192-9; available at\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/431151>.\nYaro S, et al. Epidemiological and molecular characteristics of a highly\nlethal pneumococcal meningitis epidemic in Burkina Faso. Clin Infect Dis\n2006; 43: 693-700; available at\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/506940>.\nAntonio M, et al. Seasonality and outbreak of a predominant _Streptococcus\npneumoniae_ serotype 1 clone from The Gambia: expansion of ST217\nhypervirulent clonal complex in West Africa. BMC Microbiol 2008; 8: 198;\navailable at <http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2180/8/198>].\n\n'Bacterial meningitis in Africa is associated with high mortality and risk\nof neuropsychological sequelae. The 3 leading causes of bacterial\nmeningitis (_S. pneumoniae_, _Haemophilus influenzae_, and _N.\nmeningitidis_) are vaccine preventable, and routine use of conjugate\nvaccines in African children could provide substantial health and economic\nbenefits through the prevention of childhood meningitis cases\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2005/s03/en/index.html>;\nPeltola H. Burden of meningitis and other severe bacterial infections of\nchildren in Africa: implications for prevention. Clin Infect Dis 2001; 32:\n64-75; available at\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/317534>).'\n\nProMED-mail posted a report that an outbreak of meningitis in Chad last\nyear (2009) involved _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A and W135 (see\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544); meningitis due to\nthese serogroups is potentially vaccine-preventable. The news release above\ndoes not specify the microbial etiology of the current meningitis outbreak\nin Chad.\n\nChad is divided into 18 regions. The 2 southern regions of Logone Oriental,\nand Mandoul can be found on a map of Chad at\n<http://www.absoluteastronomy.com/topics/Regions_of_Chad>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Chad is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/017X>. Maps of the African bacterial meningitis\nbelt can be found at <http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "The 3 leading causes of bacterial\nmeningitis (_S. pneumoniae_, _Haemophilus influenzae_, and _N.\nmeningitidis_) are vaccine preventable, and routine use of conjugate\nvaccines in African children could provide substantial health and economic\nbenefits through the prevention of childhood meningitis cases\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2005/s03/en/index.html>;\nPeltola H. Burden of meningitis and other severe bacterial infections of\nchildren in Africa: implications for prevention. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is extracted from ProMED-mail moderator ML's comments in\nMeningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100213.0507:\n\n'Numerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the sub-Saharan\nAfrican region known as the 'meningitis belt' each year during the hot, dry\nseason, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large outbreaks\noccur (<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 22 Feb 2010\n Attack rates during these cyclic epidemics of meningitis range from 100 to\n800 per 100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates\nas high as 1000 per 100 000 (World Health Organization: Meningococcal\nmeningitis fact sheet;\n<http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/pdf/FactSheet-Meningitis.pdf>). \n\nProMED-mail posted a report that an outbreak of meningitis in Chad last\nyear (2009) involved _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A and W135 (see\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544); meningitis due to\nthese serogroups is potentially vaccine-preventable. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< \n\n'Although epidemics of meningitis are mostly associated with the\nmeningococcus, there is evidence that increases in pneumococcal meningitis\ncases occur in parallel in sub-Saharan Africa during the hot and dry season An outbreak of serotype 1 _Streptococcus pneumoniae_\nmeningitis in northern Ghana with features that are characteristic of\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ meningitis epidemics. According to the health minister of Chad, Ngombaye Djaibe, a meningitis\nepidemic has killed 56 people [during] a little over 2 weeks in Logone\nOriental and Mandoul regions, in southern Chad. The news release above\ndoes not specify the microbial etiology of the current meningitis outbreak\nin Chad. Maps of the African bacterial meningitis\nbelt can be found at <http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>. While in\nendemic disease the highest attack rates are observed in young children,\nduring epidemics, older children, teenagers and adults are also affected. Seasonality and outbreak of a predominant _Streptococcus\npneumoniae_ serotype 1 clone from The Gambia: expansion of ST217\nhypervirulent clonal complex in West Africa.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "1979-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MANDOUL", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Djibouti", "country": "Djibouti"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Mandoul", "country": "Chad"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "380725", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=380725", "date": "2010-02-13 12:00:03", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, PNEUMOCOCCAL - AFRICA: WHO MENINGITIS REGION\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 10 Feb 2010\nSource: Reliefweb [edited]\n<http://reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/MGAE-82KD9Q?OpenDocument>\n\n\nBackground: Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine strategies in GAVI [Global\nAlliance for Vaccines and Immunization]-eligible countries are\nfocusing on infant immunization but this strategy may not be optimal\nin all settings. We aimed to collect all available population based\ndata on pneumococcal meningitis throughout life in the African\nmeningitis belt and then to model overall meningitis risk to help\ninform vaccine policy.\n\nMethods: After a systematic review of literature published from 1970\nthrough the present, we found robust population-based _Streptococcus\npneumoniae_ (Sp) meningitis data across age strata for 4 African\nmeningitis belt countries that included 35 surveillance years\nspanning from 1970 to 2005. Using these data we modeled disease risk\nfor a hypothetical cohort of 100 000 persons followed throughout life.\n\nResults: Similar to meningococcal meningitis, laboratory-confirmed\npneumococcal meningitis was seasonal, occurring primarily in the dry\nseason. The mean annual Sp meningitis incidence rates were 98, 7.8 to\n14, and 5.8 to 12 per 100 000 among persons <1, 1 through 19, and 20\nto 99 years of age, respectively, which (in the absence of major\nepidemics) were higher than meningococcal meningitis incidences for\npersons less than 1 and over 20 years of age. Mean Sp meningitis case\nfatality ratios (CFR) among hospitalized patients ranged from 36-66\npercent depending on the age group, with CFR exceeding 60 percent for\nall age groups beyond 40 years; depending on the age group, Sp\nmeningitis mortality incidences were 2- to 12-fold greater than those\nfor meningococcal meningitis.\n\nThe lifetime risks of pneumococcal meningitis disease and death were\n0.6 percent (1 in 170) and 0.3 percent (1 in 304), respectively. The\nincidences of these outcomes were highest among children age <1 year.\nHowever, the cumulative risk was highest among persons age 5 to 59\nyears who experienced 59 percent of pneumococcal meningitis outcomes.\nAfter age 5 years and depending on the country, 59-79 percent of\nmeningitis cases were caused by serotype 1.\n\nConclusions: In the African meningitis belt, Sp is as important a\ncause of meningitis as _Neisseria meningitidis_, particularly among\nolder children and working age adults. The meningitis belt population\nneeds an effective serotype 1 containing vaccine and policy\ndiscussions should consider vaccine use outside of early childhood.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Numerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nsub-Saharan African region known as the 'Meningitis Belt' each year\nduring the hot, dry season, between December and June, and every 8-12\nyears large outbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>).\n\nThe 'Meningitis Belt' extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia\nand Eritrea in the east\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>). Attack rates\nduring these cyclic epidemics of meningitis range from 100 to 800 per\n100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates as\nhigh as 1000 per 100 000. [World Health Organization: Meningococcal\nmeningitis fact sheet.\n[<http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/pdf/FactSheet-Meningitis.pdf>]. While\nin endemic disease the highest attack rates are observed in young\nchildren, during epidemics, older children, teenagers and adults are\nalso affected.\n\nAlthough epidemics of meningitis are mostly associated with the\nmeningococcus, there is evidence that increases in pneumococcal\nmeningitis cases occur in parallel in sub-Saharan Africa during the\nhot and dry season [Mar ID, Denis F, Cadoz M. Epidemiologic features\nof pneumococcal meningitis in Africa. Clinical and serotypical\naspects (author's transl). Pathol Biol (Paris). 1979; 27(9):543-8;\nLeimkugel J, et al. An outbreak of serotype 1 _Streptococcus\npneumoniae_ meningitis in northern Ghana with features that are\ncharacteristic of _Neisseria meningitidis_ meningitis epidemics. _J\nInfect Dis 2005, 192:192-199; Yaro S, et al. Epidemiological and\nmolecular characteristics of a highly lethal pneumococcal meningitis\nepidemic in Burkina Faso. _Clin Infect Dis 2006, 43:693-700; and\nAntonio M, et al. Seasonality and outbreak of a predominant\n_Streptococcus pneumoniae_ serotype 1 clone from The Gambia:\nexpansion of ST217 hypervirulent clonal complex in West Africa. _BMC\nMicrobiol 2008, 8:198]\n\nBacterial meningitis in Africa is associated with high mortality and\nrisk of neuropsychological sequelae. The 3 leading causes of\nbacterial meningitis (_S. pneumoniae_, _Hemophilus influenzae_, and\n_N. meningitidis_) are vaccine preventable, and routine use of\nconjugate vaccines in African children could provide substantial\nhealth and economic benefits through the prevention of childhood\nmeningitis cases\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2005/s03/en/index.html>;\nPeltola H. Burden of meningitis and other severe bacterial infections\nof children in Africa: implications for prevention. Clin Infect Dis.\n2001;32(1):64-75).\n\nThe predominant pneumococcal serotype in sub-Saharan Africa has been\nfound to be serotype 1; this serotype is not included in the\nheptavalent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) (that contains\nserotypes 4, 6B, 9V, 14, 18C, 19F, and 23), but it is included in the\ndecavalent PCV (that contains serotypes 1, 4, 5, 6B, 7F, 9V, 14, 18C,\n19F, and 23F).\n\nMaps of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "The 3 leading causes of\nbacterial meningitis (_S. pneumoniae_, _Hemophilus influenzae_, and\n_N. meningitidis_) are vaccine preventable, and routine use of\nconjugate vaccines in African children could provide substantial\nhealth and economic benefits through the prevention of childhood\nmeningitis cases\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2005/s03/en/index.html>;\nPeltola H. Burden of meningitis and other severe bacterial infections\nof children in Africa: implications for prevention. Mean Sp meningitis case\nfatality ratios (CFR) among hospitalized patients ranged from 36-66\npercent depending on the age group, with CFR exceeding 60 percent for\nall age groups beyond 40 years; depending on the age group, Sp\nmeningitis mortality incidences were 2- to 12-fold greater than those\nfor meningococcal meningitis. \n\nThe predominant pneumococcal serotype in sub-Saharan Africa has been\nfound to be serotype 1; this serotype is not included in the\nheptavalent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) (that contains\nserotypes 4, 6B, 9V, 14, 18C, 19F, and 23), but it is included in the\ndecavalent PCV (that contains serotypes 1, 4, 5, 6B, 7F, 9V, 14, 18C,\n19F, and 23F). The mean annual Sp meningitis incidence rates were 98, 7.8 to\n14, and 5.8 to 12 per 100 000 among persons <1, 1 through 19, and 20\nto 99 years of age, respectively, which (in the absence of major\nepidemics) were higher than meningococcal meningitis incidences for\npersons less than 1 and over 20 years of age. \n\nAlthough epidemics of meningitis are mostly associated with the\nmeningococcus, there is evidence that increases in pneumococcal\nmeningitis cases occur in parallel in sub-Saharan Africa during the\nhot and dry season [Mar ID, Denis F, Cadoz M. Epidemiologic features\nof pneumococcal meningitis in Africa. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Numerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nsub-Saharan African region known as the 'Meningitis Belt' each year\nduring the hot, dry season, between December and June, and every 8-12\nyears large outbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 10 Feb 2010\n We aimed to collect all available population based\ndata on pneumococcal meningitis throughout life in the African\nmeningitis belt and then to model overall meningitis risk to help\ninform vaccine policy. Source: Reliefweb [edited]\n<http://reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/MGAE-82KD9Q?OpenDocument>\n\n\nBackground: Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine strategies in GAVI [Global\nAlliance for Vaccines and Immunization]-eligible countries are\nfocusing on infant immunization but this strategy may not be optimal\nin all settings. Attack rates\nduring these cyclic epidemics of meningitis range from 100 to 800 per\n100 000 population, but individual communities have reported rates as\nhigh as 1000 per 100 000. While\nin endemic disease the highest attack rates are observed in young\nchildren, during epidemics, older children, teenagers and adults are\nalso affected. \n\nConclusions: In the African meningitis belt, Sp is as important a\ncause of meningitis as _Neisseria meningitidis_, particularly among\nolder children and working age adults. (Sp) meningitis data across age strata for 4 African\nmeningitis belt countries that included 35 surveillance years\nspanning from 1970 to 2005. An outbreak of serotype 1 _Streptococcus\npneumoniae_ meningitis in northern Ghana with features that are\ncharacteristic of _Neisseria meningitidis_ meningitis epidemics.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "1970-03-26 00:00:00", "1979-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-02-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Eritrea", "country": "Eritrea"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "7f", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "387790", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=387790", "date": "2010-02-25 16:00:03", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA: WHO MENINGITIS REGION\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] Meningitis belt\n[2] Ghana (Upper West)\n[3] Burkina Faso\n\n******\n[1] Meningitis belt\nDate: Tue 22 Feb 2010\nSource: Thomson Reuters Foundation AlertNet, UN-OCHA IRIN (Integrated\nRegional Information Networks) [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/c712b3308558e42473603e4bf274f193.htm>\n\n\nA meningitis epidemic has struck earlier than usual and is spreading across\nsub-Saharan Africa's 'meningitis belt' from Senegal to Ethiopia, according\nto health ministries in the region. The disease occurs during the dry\nseason, with most cases reported in mid-April.\n\nAs of 7 Feb [2010], health ministries in high-risk countries reported 2298\ncases, with a 13 per cent fatality rate. Burkina Faso has reported the\nhighest number of cases, but Togo has experienced the highest fatality\nrate, where 25 of 108 infected people died [23 percent fatality rate]. The\nWorld Health Organization (WHO) described the situation as 'alarming.'\n\nMamoudou Harouna Djingarey, a WHO epidemiologist and meningitis expert,\ntold IRIN it was still not clear why infections were spreading earlier than\nexpected. 'This [timing] is a sign of a major epidemic risk if no action is\ntaken,' he warned. Extensive meningitis outbreaks tended to occur every 8\nto 10 years, he said, but were now occurring about every 4 years. In the\n2009 meningitis season, 14 African countries reported a total of 78 416\nsuspected cases, including 4053 deaths, the largest number of infections\nsince the 1996 epidemic.\n\nStudies are being carried out to determine whether climatic and\nenvironmental factors might be influencing the extent of the current\nepidemic. Djingarey told IRIN that infections had also been reported\nfurther south than usual, including in Uganda, Kenya, and Democratic\nRepublic of Congo.\n\nBurkina Faso: on 17 Feb 2010 the Health Ministry in Burkina Faso reported\n1251 meningitis cases, with a 15.4 per cent fatality rate. This time last\nyear [2009] there were 25 per cent less infections, but a similar\npercentage of deaths. The disease has reached epidemic proportions in Pama\nin the east, Titao in the north, Sapouy in the centre west, and Batie in\nthe south east, defined by WHO as areas where at least 10 out of 100 000\npeople are infected. 3 other districts with half as many reported\ninfections are on alert, according to Burkina Faso's Ministry of Health.\n\nVaccinations have been carried out in Pama and Titao, and more are\nscheduled to take place in the centre west on 20 Feb 2010. 'If we can react\nquickly the numbers will drop,' Health Ministry epidemiologist Jean Ludovic\nKambou told IRIN.\n\nWHO recommends vaccinating everyone aged from 2 to 29 years and living in\nan epidemic zone, as well as people in neighbouring areas that are on\n'alert'. If the country does not have enough vaccine, it can request\nno-cost or minimal-cost vaccines from a meningitis vaccine stock managed by\nWHO. Alejandro Costa, a WHO vaccine scientist, told IRIN no countries have\nrequested vaccines as of 19 Feb 2010.\n\nCosta told IRIN 100 000 doses of vaccine from the stockpile had been sent\nto Chad, which did not have vaccines on hand but was facing an epidemic in\nthe southern regions of Mandoul and Logone Orientale [see ProMED-mail post\nMeningitis - Chad: (LR,MA) RFI 20100223.0600]. Chad's Ministry of Health\nsaid 42 000 people in the southern town of Doba needed vaccination.\n\nOn 19 Feb 2010 the government reported 507 meningitis infections that have\nled to 56 deaths, an 11 per cent fatality rate.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail posted a report of an outbreak of meningitis in Chad last year\n(2009) that involved _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A and W135 (see\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544); meningitis due to\nthese serogroups is potentially vaccine-preventable. In a recent\nProMED-mail post, the news release did not specify the microbial etiology\nof the current meningitis outbreak in Chad or the serogroup specificity of\nthe meningococcal vaccine that is being used (see Meningitis - Chad:\n(LR,MA) RFI 20100223.0600). The news release above also fails to identify\nwhich serogroups are involved in the current outbreaks in Burkina Faso or\nChad or the serogroup specificities of the meningococcal vaccines that are\nbeing used.\n\nMaps of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>.\n- Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Ghana (Upper West)\nDate: Tue 23 Feb 2010\nSource: Ghana News Agency (GNA) [edited]\n<http://www.ghananewsagency.org/s_health/r_12822/>\n\n\nDr Alexis Nang-beifubah, regional director of health services, told GNA\n[Ghana News Agency] on Tuesday [23 Feb 2010] that 17 people have died from\nan outbreak of a new strain of cerebrospinal meningitis in the Upper West\nRegion since January 2010. He said 15 out of the 96 cases reported have\nbeen confirmed to be [_Neisseria] meningitidis_ [serogroup] W135, which is\nbeing seen for the 1st [time] in Ghana.\n\nJirapa District has recorded 53 cases of the disease with 8 deaths; Wa\nMunicipality, 17 cases with 5 deaths; Nadowli District 14 cases with 4\ndeaths while Lawra and Wa East Districts have registered 11 cases and a\ncase, respectively, with no deaths.\n\nDr Nang-beifubah, who updated the GNA on the disease situation in an\ninterview, said the W135 type is common in neighbouring Burkina Faso and\ndifferent from the _Neisseria [meningitidis]_ type, [serogroup] 'A,' which\nis known in the Region. He said the health directorate had no vaccines for\nthe W135 type [?] A, which was emerging in the area for the first time. Dr\nNang-beifubah said 8 cases were initially reported in Jirapa but the number\nrose to 13 the following week.\n\nThe Health Directorate has mobilized personnel, vaccines and other\nlogistics to the Districts to vaccinate the people against type A, while\nmonitoring the trend in all the 9 districts of the Region. Dr Nang-beifubah\nsaid the situation was under control as all Epidemic Management Committees\nin the Districts had been reactivated to help to strengthen local\nsurveillance on the disease. He said Sissala West; Sissala East; Wa West\nand Lambussie/Karni Districts have not yet recorded cases of the disease.\nHe advised people in the Region to avoid overcrowding and to sleep in\nventilated rooms, as well as drink sufficient water and fluids.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the news release above says that the meningococcal serogroup\ninvolved in the Ghana meningitis outbreak is W135, for which no specific\nvaccine is currently available in Ghana, they are, nevertheless,\nvaccinating the population at risk with meningococcal serogroup A vaccine,\nwhich, of course, will be ineffective for preventing infection due to\nserogroup W135. - Mod.ML\n\nMaps showing the regions and districts of Ghana can be seen at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghana#Regions_and_districts>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0182>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Burkina Faso\nDate: Fri 19 Feb 2010\nSource: AllAfrica, Sidwaya Quotidien report [in French, trans.\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\n<http://fr.allafrica.com/stories/201002190145.html>\n\n\nSince the beginning of the year [2010], meningitis has already killed over\n100 people. The Ministry of Health provided an update and announced new\nmeasures.\n\nMeningitis is still present, with its grisly statistics: 4 health districts\nare experiencing an epidemic and 193 people of the 1252 suspected cases\nreported from 1 Jan to 14 Feb 2010 have died, according to data from the\nNational Committee on the Management of Epidemics, which met Wednesday [17\nFeb 2010] evening with minister Seydou Bouda. The victims include people\nwho have been vaccinated. 7 health districts have reached the alert\nthreshold for meningitis. Among them 4 are facing an epidemic situation.\n\nOf note are the health districts of Titao with an attack rate of 20.2 per\n1000 inhabitants, Pama (13.3 per 1000), Batie (11.5 per 1000), and Sapouy\n(11 per 1000). The health districts of Kongoussi, Nanoro, and Leo have\ncrossed the alert threshold. The causative agent of this epidemic is\nmeningococcus serogroup A.\n\nThe Ministry of Health claims to have already taken action to contain the\nepidemic. Vaccination campaigns have been effective in some localities. 'We\nhave already begun reactive vaccination campaigns in the health districts\nof Pama and Titao,' said the director of control of the disease, Sylvester\nR Tiendrebeogo. [The Ministry] is also making available drugs and\nconsumables in the 13 health regions, university hospitals, and regional\nhospitals, at no cost, as well as disseminating awareness messages in the\nlocal languages.\n\nIn the presence of certain technical and financial partners, the minister\nasked the regional directors of health and executives involved in the\nmanagement of epidemics to examine 'what went wrong' in order to control\nthe disease in the future, especially since the situation has slightly\nworsened this year [2010] as compared to the same period in 2009. For 948\ndeaths, the fatality rate of meningitis was 14.56 per cent from the 1st to\nthe 6th week [29 Dec 2009 - 11 Feb 2010] of 2009, against 15.43 per cent\nthis year [28 Dec 2009-14 Feb 2010]. Minister Seydou Bouda considers these\nnumbers 'still too high' for the expectations and everyone should share\nresponsibility and include in their plans the epidemics and in particular\nmeningitis epidemics. Technicians should seek to reduce as much as possible\nthe processing of samples and to remove all obstacles to the prompt access\nto vaccines in areas of need as well as review the chain of coordination of\nreactive control.\n\nThe current system is such that persons in a district facing an epidemic\nmust travel to Ouagadougou to obtain the necessary vaccines. In addition\nthere are formalities that at certain levels must be fulfilled during a\nworking day, the vehicles are not necessarily available in the provinces,\nand neither are the financial resources to pay the persons in charge of\nvaccination. Some have proposed that the alert team at the central level\nwork day and night, transport the vaccines to epidemic areas, and at the\nsame time deal with the formalities.\n\nThe idea to place a sufficient amount of vaccine in the districts is not\ncurrently feasible. The existing amount of vaccines will allow for a\n'dusting' in small quantities and unable to cope with a large-scale\nvaccination where necessary. In other words, it will be difficult to\ncollect these vaccines once they have been distributed across 63 districts,\nif there is an emergency in a given region. Earlier this season, the\nMinistry of Health had about 850 000 doses of vaccine in stock. To date,\n'there is a stock of about 730 000 (728 370) doses,' says Dr Tiendrebeogo.\nA new order has been placed,' he said.\n\nThe quality of the meningococcal vaccine is not in question at the moment.\nThe new concern for this 'epidemic season' of meningitis is that people who\nwere vaccinated in 2009 still contracted the disease. This is the case in\nTitao in the Nord Region. 'People vaccinated in 2009 as well as those who\nweren't have contracted the disease,' says a report of the epidemiological\nsurveillance service. The report states that of 54 patients, more than half\n(51.9 per cent) reported having been vaccinated.\n\nFor the director of disease control, it is possible that the bodies of\nvaccinated people were debilitated by other reasons, which would prevent\nthe development of the necessary immunity to counteract the infection. He\nadded, 'We are in a context where there is malnutrition, which might\nexplain why persons vaccinated do not develop satisfactory immunity.\n\nHe emphasized that the vaccine available against serogroup A meningococcus\nhas a success rate of 95 per cent. In his view, the effectiveness of the\nvaccine 'may arise' as a question of scientific rigor. But he wants the\nBurkinabe to understand that people can miss a vaccination campaign given\nthe population movements, and that they may still contract the disease upon\nreturning to an already vaccinated area.\n\nFor her part, Professor Ramata Ouedraogo, microbiologist, said that the\ncurrent vaccine against meningococcus A does not protect from other types\nof meningitis and pointed out that 'people can acquire another type of\nmeningitis next year even when they say they have been vaccinated.' Health\nauthorities have given priority to meningococcus A, which according to\nexperts is responsible for almost all outbreaks in the country.\nNonetheless, treatment for other types of meningitis is also available.\nThus, 20 000 doses of [ACW135Y vaccine against 4 strains of meningococcus]\nare ready. For financial reasons, the government lacks sufficient doses of\nvaccines against all strains of the bacterium.\n\nThe technicians commented on the case of Titao. Of a total of 62 reported\ncases, 42 cases (68 per cent) were in people from villages neighboring\nMali, and others directly from Malian villages.\n\nMinister Seydou Bouda issued an order for everyone to be vaccinated, no\nmatter how transient, or whether they come from neighboring Mali. 'Anyone\nwho comes to you must be vaccinated in order to break the chain of the\nepidemic,' he said.\n\nThe Committee on the Management of Epidemics has recommended the\norganization of a cross-border meeting with health authorities in Mali and\nthat samples of cerebrospinal fluid continue to be taken for monitoring the\nbacteria.\n\nWHO, in partnership with the European Union, is considering the possibility\nof a vaccination campaign at a regional level (Economic Community Of West\nAfrican States - ECOWAS). 'We are in the process of discussing the issue,'\nsays Henriette Nikiema, representing the EU on this occasion. UNICEF has\npledged some 63 million francs CFA [approx. USD 130 000] to facilitate the\nacquisition of doses of vaccine, but also to strengthen the capacity of\nlaboratory technicians, the laboratory technical platform, and the\ntransport of samples.\n\nThough not the most deadly, meningitis is the disease most feared by the\npeople of Burkina Faso, by the authorities, and even by the technical\npartners. Despite monitoring and response systems repeatedly corrected, the\ndisease always manages to strike. The new announced conjugate vaccine\nprovides great hope.\n\n[byline: Aime Mouor Kambire]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are at least 13 serogroups of _Neisseria meningitidis_ based on the\nantigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides; disease is most\ncommonly due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135. All serogroup\npolysaccharides but B are immunogenic in humans.\n\nThere are several different types of meningococcal vaccines that use\nmeningococcal polysaccharides as the immunogen: the vaccines may contain\none or more of the polysaccharide serogroups alone or conjugated to\nprotein. Meningococcal vaccines will only protect against meningitis due to\nthe meningococcal polysaccharide serogroups that the vaccine contains.\nPolysaccharide vaccines, which have been available for more than 30 years,\nexist for serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various combinations (such as, a\nbivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a tetravalent ACYW-135 polysaccharide\nvaccine). There is a monovalent protein conjugate vaccine against serogroup\nC and a tetravalent against serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135.\n\nAlthough children as young as 3 months of age may have an immunologic\nresponse to the serogroup A antigen contained in the meningococcal\npolysaccharide vaccines, response to the other serogroup antigens is poor\nin children younger than 2 years of age. These vaccines also only provide\nprotection for up to 3 years. In contrast, the meningococcal conjugate\nvaccines induce a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved\nimmune response in infants, provide long-lasting immunity, and prevent\nnasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_, thus reducing transmission of\nthis microorganism person-to-person\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>).\n\nA preventive strategy based on conjugate vaccines could have a\nsignificantly larger and more enduring impact on attempts to control the\nyearly recurrences of this disease that causes considerable morbidity and\nmortality, especially among children\n(<http://www.jidc.org/index.php/journal/article/view/19745499/102>).\n\nAll these vaccines have been proven safe and effective with infrequent and\nmild side effects. For both the meningococcal conjugate and the\npolysaccharide vaccines, approximately 7-10 days are required following\nvaccination for development of protective levels of anti-meningococcal\nantibodies.\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate vaccine, depending on availability, in every involved district\nin an attempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is blocked when\na critical percentage of the population have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>).\n\nThe news release above says that health authorities believe that\nmeningococcus serogroup A, which has been responsible for almost all\noutbreaks in the Burkina Faso, is also responsible for the current\noutbreak, but that people who were vaccinated in 2009, presumably with\nmeningococcal serogroup A vaccine, still contracted the disease, presumably\ndue to serogroup A meningococci. They discount loss of vaccine potency.\nHowever, both the polysaccharide and the conjugate vaccines require proper\nrefrigeration; improper storage or handling of vaccines may result in loss\nof vaccine potency and reduced immune response in vaccinees. Also, they\nwill not prevent meningococcal infection caused by meningococcal serogroups\nnot represented in the vaccines and will not prevent meningitis caused by\nother pathogens, such as _Streptococcus pneumoniae_, a pathogen also known\nto cause outbreaks in the African 'meningitis' region (see ProMED-mail post\nMeningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100213.0507). -\nMod.ML\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Burkina Faso is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0188>. The departments mentioned can be located via\nthe maps at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communes_of_Burkina_Faso>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "\n\nThe news release above says that health authorities believe that\nmeningococcus serogroup A, which has been responsible for almost all\noutbreaks in the Burkina Faso, is also responsible for the current\noutbreak, but that people who were vaccinated in 2009, presumably with\nmeningococcal serogroup A vaccine, still contracted the disease, presumably\ndue to serogroup A meningococci. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the news release above says that the meningococcal serogroup\ninvolved in the Ghana meningitis outbreak is W135, for which no specific\nvaccine is currently available in Ghana, they are, nevertheless,\nvaccinating the population at risk with meningococcal serogroup A vaccine,\nwhich, of course, will be ineffective for preventing infection due to\nserogroup W135. - Also, they\nwill not prevent meningococcal infection caused by meningococcal serogroups\nnot represented in the vaccines and will not prevent meningitis caused by\nother pathogens, such as _Streptococcus pneumoniae_, a pathogen also known\nto cause outbreaks in the African 'meningitis' region (see ProMED-mail post\nMeningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100213.0507). For 948\ndeaths, the fatality rate of meningitis was 14.56 per cent from the 1st to\nthe 6th week [29 Dec 2009 - 11 Feb 2010] of 2009, against 15.43 per cent\nthis year [28 Dec 2009-14 Feb 2010]. For her part, Professor Ramata Ouedraogo, microbiologist, said that the\ncurrent vaccine against meningococcus A does not protect from other types\nof meningitis and pointed out that 'people can acquire another type of\nmeningitis next year even when they say they have been vaccinated.' Polysaccharide vaccines, which have been available for more than 30 years,\nexist for serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various combinations (such as, a\nbivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a tetravalent ACYW-135 polysaccharide\nvaccine). The disease has reached epidemic proportions in Pama\nin the east, Titao in the north, Sapouy in the centre west, and Batie in\nthe south east, defined by WHO as areas where at least 10 out of 100 000\npeople are infected. Dr Nang-beifubah\nsaid the situation was under control as all Epidemic Management Committees\nin the Districts had been reactivated to help to strengthen local\nsurveillance on the disease. We\nhave already begun reactive vaccination campaigns in the health districts\nof Pama and Titao,' said the director of control of the disease, Sylvester\nR Tiendrebeogo. But he wants the\nBurkinabe to understand that people can miss a vaccination campaign given\nthe population movements, and that they may still contract the disease upon\nreturning to an already vaccinated area. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< USD 130 000] to facilitate the\nacquisition of doses of vaccine, but also to strengthen the capacity of\nlaboratory technicians, the laboratory technical platform, and the\ntransport of samples. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA: WHO MENINGITIS REGION\n*********************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-02-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2009-02-11 20:10:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2010-02-17 00:00:00", "2010-01-26 00:00:00", "2010-02-23 00:00:00", "1251-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "2010-02-20 00:00:00", "2010-02-22 00:00:00", "1996-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-02-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Jirapa", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Pama and Titao", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kongoussi", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "Mali"}, {"location": "Mandoul", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Nanoro", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Pama", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "330933", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (04): (MA) lab-acquired", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=330933", "date": "2009-11-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (04): (MASSACHUSETTS) LABORATORY-ACQUIRED\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 10 Nov 2009\nSource: The Boston Globe [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2009/11/10/bu_student_caught_bacterial_infection_from_lab_tests_show/>\n\n\nSophisticated genetic fingerprinting confirmed that a laboratory\nexperiment was the source of a bacterial infection that sickened a\ngraduate student on Boston University's [BU] medical campus, city\ndisease investigators said yesterday [9 Nov 2009].\n\nThe genetic tests, conducted at the state laboratory in Jamaica Plain,\ncompared a blood sample from the researcher with bacterial matter\nrecovered from the lab where he was working on BU's South End campus.\n'The bottom line,'' said Dr Anita Barry, top disease tracker at the\nBoston Public Health Commission, 'is they matched.'' The analysis\nerased any doubt about what caused the researcher to become sick last\nmonth [October 2009] and intensified investigations into precisely how\nhe was exposed to a germ known as _Neisseria meningitides_, which can\ncause meningitis.\n\nThe city's biological lab safety division will review safety\nprocedures in BU's medical labs, to ensure that the school is doing\neverything possible to minimize researchers' exposure to pathogens,\nBarry said. Investigators will examine what kind of protective gear\nthe researcher was wearing, what kind of training he received, and how\nthoroughly he was supervised, Barry said.\n\nThe city strengthened its regulation of labs after 3 BU scientists\nbecame infected with tularemia in 2004, an episode that revealed\nsloppy lab practices and a failure to report those illnesses in a\ntimely fashion. This time, the university has pledged to operate\ntransparently, promising to share findings of an internal\ninvestigation with scientists across the university and even\nresearchers at other schools. 'We want others to learn if there are\nways we identify that this could be prevented,'' said Ara Tahmassian,\nassociate vice president for research compliance at Boston University\nSchool of Medicine. 'When I look at this incident, it's one too\nmany,'' said Tahmassian, who joined BU after the tularemia cases. 'But\nif some of the other institutions can utilize what went wrong and hear\nthe lessons learned, fantastic.'' Tahmassian has convened a panel of\nspecialists to review the incident and said he expects them to report\nexpeditiously. 'This is not going to be months,'' he said. 'This is\ngoing to be within a week or 2, pinpointing the best we can.''\n\nThe infection of the researcher, who has recovered, came at an awkward\nmoment for BU. A federal health agency is conducting what is probably\nthe final safety review of a controversial USD 200 million lab project\nthe university has built to work with the world's deadliest agents,\nincluding [_Ebolavirus_] and plague. The centerpiece of that project,\na high-security biosafety level-4 lab, is in a completed but\nunoccupied building on Albany Street.\n\nThe exposure of the graduate student -- the university has not\nidentified him, citing patient confidentiality rules -- happened in a\nbuilding next door to the contentious project. He was participating in\nthe hunt for a vaccine against the form of meningitis caused by the\ngerm.\n\nThe researcher was working in a biosafety level-2 lab, which has less\nstringent safety procedures than level-4 labs. When he became ill, the\ngraduate student sought medical attention and notified the director of\nthe lab, concerned that his symptoms might be related to his research.\nUnlike with the tularemia infections, BU alerted city disease\ninvestigators of their suspicions about the student within hours of\nlearning about his illness. He is the only person who has become sick,\nBarry said.\n\n[Byline: Stephen Smith]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following was extracted from a Journal Watch report on\nlaboratory-acquired meningococcal disease\n(<http://infectious-diseases.jwatch.org/cgi/content/full/2002/322/1>):\n\n'_Neisseria meningitides_ causes bacterial meningitis and sepsis.\nDiagnosis is usually made by culturing the organisms on standard\nmicrobiologic media. Disease is most often acquired by inhalation, and\nmicrobiology personnel may be exposed when processing lab isolates.\nFollowing the deaths of 2 microbiologists in 2000 from meningococcal\ndisease after occupational exposure, the CDC posted an Internet\nrequest for reports of similar cases of occupationally acquired\nmeningococcal disease [see Laboratory-acquired meningococcal disease -\nUnited States, 2000. CDC MMWR 2002 Feb 22; 51(7): 141-4; available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5107a1.htm> &\nSejvar JJ, et al: Assessing the risk of laboratory-acquired\nmeningococcal disease. J Clin Microbiol 2005; 43(9): 4811-4; available\nat\n<http://jcm.asm.org/cgi/reprint/43/9/4811.pdf>].\n\nA total of 16 cases were reported; 8 were from the USA. 9 (56 percent)\nwere caused by _N. meningitidis_ serogroup B and 7 (44 percent) by\nserogroup C. 8 patients (50 percent) died. Patients were exposed by\nreading plates (50 percent), making subcultures (50 percent), and\nperforming serogroup identification (38 percent). All patients worked\nin microbiology labs. The risk for infection among microbiologists is\nestimated to be 7 times that among the general population (95 percent\nconfidence interval, 1-19).\n\nComment: Although meningococcal disease is uncommon, microbiologists\nworking with _N. meningitidis_ should take special care, because their\ninfection risk is elevated, and the case-fatality rate is high. Most\nrisk is likely associated with exposure to pure cultures rather than\nto patient samples. Precautions should include using a biosafety hood\nwhen manipulating isolates and wearing splash-guards and masks. When\nsuch protections are not available, isolates should be referred to\nother labs for serotyping. Vaccination of personnel may also be\nconsidered, but current meningococcal vaccines do not protect against\ndisease from _N. meningitidis_ type B and thus will not eliminate risk\nfor infection.\n- C Robert Horsburgh Jr, MD'\n\nThe state of Massachusetts can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the USA at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00_U>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 10 Nov 2009\n Following the deaths of 2 microbiologists in 2000 from meningococcal\ndisease after occupational exposure, the CDC posted an Internet\nrequest for reports of similar cases of occupationally acquired\nmeningococcal disease [see Laboratory-acquired meningococcal disease -\nUnited States, 2000. The genetic tests, conducted at the state laboratory in Jamaica Plain,\ncompared a blood sample from the researcher with bacterial matter\nrecovered from the lab where he was working on BU's South End campus.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2004-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00", "2009-10-26 00:00:00", "2021-02-22 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jamaica Plain", "country": "Jamaica"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "324549", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Brazil: (BA) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=324549", "date": "2009-11-04 15:00:03", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BRAZIL: (BAHIA) RFI\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 2 Nov 2009\nSource: Tudo Agora [in Portuguese, machine trans., edited]\n<http://www.tudoagora.com.br/noticia/23489/Bahia-tem-5a-morte-por-meningite-em-Porto-Seguro.html>\n\n\nThe Department of Health of Bahia recorded the death of another person\ncaused by meningitis in Porto Seguro. The total number of deaths from the\ndisease in the southern part of the state has reached 5.\n\nThe [latest] victim is a woman, 26, who died on Sunday night [1 Nov 2009].\nThe patient had been in hospital since 23 Oct 2009, with fever, vomiting,\nand pain in the neck and head.\n\nIn total, 9 cases were reported in the region of Porto Seguro and 4 people\nremain hospitalized. All patients had been infected at a party in the\nvillage of Trancoso, on 18 Oct 2009, according to the Department of Health.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 2 Nov 2009\nSource: Sidney Rezende [in Portuguese, machine trans., edited]\n<http://www.sidneyrezende.com/noticia/62602>\n\n\nOne more person died in Bahia after contracting meningitis. The victim this\ntime is a woman of 26 years, who died Sunday night [1 Nov 2009] in Porto\nSeguro. She had been in hospital since 23 Oct 2009 with symptoms of the\ndisease: pain in the neck and head, fever, and vomiting.\n\nWith one more death, the number of deaths from meningitis in the state\ncomes to 9. 4 people are still hospitalized. According to the Department of\nHealth, the victims of the disease were infected at a festivity in\nTrancoso, on 18 Oct 2009.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 28 Oct 2009\nSOURCE: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-10/28/content_12345899.htm>\n\n\nAn outbreak of meningitis type C resulted in 4 deaths in the [state of]\nBahia in north eastern Brazil, local health secretary Messias Boaventura\nsaid on Tuesday 27 Oct 2009].\n\nAnother 4 people have been hospitalized, and 2 of them are confirmed to\nhave been infected. Boaventura said the victims attended a party in\nTrancoso of Bahia on 18 Oct 2009 and did not know each other. Health\nofficials said an ambulance would be kept at the Trancoso health center to\nrespond to emergencies and prevent the spreading of the disease. Trancoso's\ncentral laboratory will also work on a continuous basis to receive and\nprocess the biological samples to diagnose disease.\n\nSo far this year [2009], Bahia has recorded 770 cases of meningitis, 60 per\ncent more than the number identified last year [2008].\n\n[editor: Li Xianzhi]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nThere is some confusion about the number of recent deaths due to\nmeningococcal meningitis in Porto Seguro as reported in the 3 news releases\nabove.\n\nThe 3rd news release states that the deaths have been attributed to\nmeningococcal serogroup C. Outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis in Brazil\nin the past have been both B and C (see ProMED-mail posting Meningitis,\nmeningococcal - Brazil 19960125.0182).\n\nThe 3rd news release also states that Bahia has experienced an increased\nnumber of cases of meningitis this year (2009). We request more information\non this apparently ongoing outbreak of meningococcal meningitis in Bahia.\n\nThe Brazilian state of Bahia, in the north eastern part of the country, on\nthe Atlantic coast, can be seen on the map at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg>. Porto Seguro is a\nmunicipality in the southern part of the state with a population in 2006 of\n140 000. It is located 707 km (440 mi) south of Salvador, the state\ncapital, and can be seen on the maps at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porto_Seguro> and\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00ZA>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n The 3rd news release states that the deaths have been attributed to\nmeningococcal serogroup C. Outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis in Brazil\nin the past have been both B and C (see ProMED-mail posting Meningitis,\nmeningococcal - Brazil 19960125.0182). \n\n[editor: Li Xianzhi]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< It is located 707 km (440 mi) south of Salvador, the state\ncapital, and can be seen on the maps at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porto_Seguro> and\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\nThere is some confusion about the number of recent deaths due to\nmeningococcal meningitis in Porto Seguro as reported in the 3 news releases\nabove. According to the Department of\nHealth, the victims of the disease were infected at a festivity in\nTrancoso, on 18 Oct 2009. The victim this\ntime is a woman of 26 years, who died Sunday night [1 Nov 2009] in Porto\n Health\nofficials said an ambulance would be kept at the Trancoso health center to\nrespond to emergencies and prevent the spreading of the disease. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BRAZIL: (BAHIA) RFI\n***********************************************\n Porto Seguro is a\nmunicipality in the southern part of the state with a population in 2006 of\n140 000. \n\nThe 3rd news release also states that Bahia has experienced an increased\nnumber of cases of meningitis this year (2009).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-10-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Salvador", "country": "El Salvador"}, {"location": "Bahia", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "308848", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - New Zealand: (North Island)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=308848", "date": "2009-10-13 18:00:03", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NEW ZEALAND: (NORTH ISLAND)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 12 Oct 2009\nSource: Manawatu Standard [edited]\n<http://www.stuff.co.nz/manawatu-standard/news/2953948/Cases-bring-meningitis-warning>\n\n\nA total of 6 cases of meningococcal disease in as many weeks around the\nMidCentral health district [of the North Island] have prompted a warning\nfrom medical officer of health Jill McKenzie to take symptoms seriously.\n\nWhile the MenzB vaccination blitz that reached more than 1 million children\nand young people in 2005 helped stop New Zealand's epidemic of the disease,\nthe cases presenting now have been caused by other strains of the bacteria.\nAll of those affected were aged under 20, and all of them were recovering\nas a result of being diagnosed and receiving antibiotics in time. Dr\nMcKenzie said it was the time of year when meningococcal cases were most\nlikely to occur, but in the district's best year in the past 5 years, 2007,\nthere was only one case during the whole year. In 2005, there were 15.\n\nThis season's spike in numbers means that people should be alert to the\nsymptoms and get help without delay. At first the symptoms can be confused\nwith flu, but are more severe, and a tell-tale bruise-like rash that will\nnot fade when pressed develops. 'Anyone with these symptoms should be taken\nto a doctor immediately,' she said. 'Early recognition of the symptoms, and\ntreatment with antibiotics, is the key to stopping the potentially serious\noutcomes from blood poisoning (septicaemia) or meningitis (inflammation of\nthe spinal cord and brain lining).'\n\nThe bugs that cause the disease can live quite harmlessly in the back of\nthe nose or throat of well people, and are passed on to others through\nspit. The key to prevention is not sharing spit. People should not share\nlip balms, drinks or drink bottles or toothbrushes. People most at risk are\nthose under 20, including the very young, and people who live closely\ntogether. Maori and Pacific communities are more frequently affected.\n\nAround New Zealand there were 25 cases of meningococcal disease in August\n[2009], including just one in MidCentral.\n\n[byline: Janine Rankin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Meningococcal disease is caused by the bacterium _Neisseria meningitidis_,\nwhich is carried in the nasopharynx. The peak incidence of invasive\nmeningococcal disease is between the ages of 6 months and 2 years, and\nranges from mild disease to fulminant septicemia that can lead to death\nwithin a few hours of onset. Immunosuppressed individuals, those with\ncomplement deficiency or hyposplenism and those living in crowded\nconditions (for example, barracks and dormitories) are at increased risk of\ndeveloping meningococcal disease.\n\nThere are at least 13 serogroups of _N. meningitidis_ based on the\nantigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides; disease due to\nserogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135 are most common. There are significant\ndifferences in the geographic distribution of serogroups. For instance,\nmeningococci of serogroups B and C cause most disease episodes in Europe,\nwhile serogroup A is commoner in China and among Haj pilgrims. In the\n'meningitis belt' of Africa, group A and C meningococci cause most of the\noutbreaks. Group W135 meningococci have caused several recent epidemics in\nsub-Saharan Africa and during the Haj.\n\nFor about 10 years, beginning in 1991, meningococcal disease activity that\nwas due primarily to a particular strain of serogroup B increased in New\nZealand (<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). During the\noutbreak, the number of cases grew to about 400 cases each year, with 80 of\nevery 100 cases caused by the epidemic strain. However, the news release\nabove states that the current cases in the MidCentral district of New\nZealand are caused by other 'strains' of _N. meningitidis_.\n\nMeningococcal vaccines that use serogroup-specific meningococcal capsular\npolysaccharide as the immunogen exist for serogroups A, C, W135, and Y.\nDevelopment of a vaccine against group B meningococci has proven difficult,\nbecause its capsular polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic and antibodies\nelicited may cross-react with neural tissue\n(<http://www.jimmunol.org/cgi/reprint/160/10/5028>).\n\nSome countries (for example, New Zealand, Cuba, Norway, and Chile)\ndeveloped vaccines against local strains of serogroup B meningococci that\nuse strain-specific outer membrane vesicle protein rather than capsular\npolysaccharide. One such vaccine, the New Zealand MeNZB vaccine only\nprotects against the specific outbreak New Zealand B strain, and will not\nprotect against meningococcal A, C, Y, or W135 or other strains of B\n(<http://www.moh.govt.nz/meningococcal>). From 2004-2006, a 3-dose MeNZB\nvaccination campaign in New Zealand reached about one million people, from\ninfants to age 20, and was associated with an end to the outbreak\n(<http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/49142.php>), which some have\nspecifically attributed to use of the MeNZB vaccine. Novartis is also\ndeveloping a polyvalent serogroup B vaccine that contains multiple\nbacterial surface proteins believed to be found in most meningococcal B\nstrains responsible for the disease globally\n(<http://www.novartis.com/newsroom/media-releases/en/2008/1218899.shtml>).\n\nDistrict health boards (DHBs) in New Zealand are organisations responsible\nfor ensuring health and disability services to populations within a defined\ngeographical area. MidCentral DHB's district stretches across the North\nIsland of New Zealand from the west to the east coast with a population of\n165 000\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/District_Health_Board_(New_Zealand)>). An\noutbreak of meningococcal disease is defined as the occurrence of 3 or more\nconfirmed or probable cases during a period of 3 months or less, resulting\nin a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per 100 000 persons,\nwhich is about 10 times greater than the usual occurrence (about 1 per 100\n000) (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). The attack\nrate of 6 cases of meningococcal disease in MidCentral in 6 weeks in a\npopulation of 165 000 is less than what is recognized as an outbreak of\nmeningococcal disease.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Zealand can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=-42.4,172.7,5>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "An\noutbreak of meningococcal disease is defined as the occurrence of 3 or more\nconfirmed or probable cases during a period of 3 months or less, resulting\nin a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per 100 000 persons,\nwhich is about 10 times greater than the usual occurrence (about 1 per 100\n000) (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). \n\nMeningococcal vaccines that use serogroup-specific meningococcal capsular\npolysaccharide as the immunogen exist for serogroups A, C, W135, and Y.\nDevelopment of a vaccine against group B meningococci has proven difficult,\nbecause its capsular polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic and antibodies\nelicited may cross-react with neural tissue\n(<http://www.jimmunol.org/cgi/reprint/160/10/5028>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 12 Oct 2009\n Novartis is also\ndeveloping a polyvalent serogroup B vaccine that contains multiple\nbacterial surface proteins believed to be found in most meningococcal B\nstrains responsible for the disease globally\n(<http://www.novartis.com/newsroom/media-releases/en/2008/1218899.shtml>). From 2004-2006, a 3-dose MeNZB\nvaccination campaign in New Zealand reached about one million people, from\ninfants to age 20, and was associated with an end to the outbreak\n(<http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/49142.php>), which some have\nspecifically attributed to use of the MeNZB vaccine. The attack\nrate of 6 cases of meningococcal disease in MidCentral in 6 weeks in a\npopulation of 165 000 is less than what is recognized as an outbreak of\nmeningococcal disease. The peak incidence of invasive\nmeningococcal disease is between the ages of 6 months and 2 years, and\nranges from mild disease to fulminant septicemia that can lead to death\nwithin a few hours of onset. Dr\nMcKenzie said it was the time of year when meningococcal cases were most\nlikely to occur, but in the district's best year in the past 5 years, 2007,\nthere was only one case during the whole year. Immunosuppressed individuals, those with\ncomplement deficiency or hyposplenism and those living in crowded\nconditions (for example, barracks and dormitories) are at increased risk of\ndeveloping meningococcal disease. Some countries (for example, New Zealand, Cuba, Norway, and Chile)\ndeveloped vaccines against local strains of serogroup B meningococci that\nuse strain-specific outer membrane vesicle protein rather than capsular\npolysaccharide. One such vaccine, the New Zealand MeNZB vaccine only\nprotects against the specific outbreak New Zealand B strain, and will not\nprotect against meningococcal A, C, Y, or W135 or other strains of B\n \n\n[byline: Janine Rankin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< Early recognition of the symptoms, and\ntreatment with antibiotics, is the key to stopping the potentially serious\noutcomes from blood poisoning (septicaemia) or meningitis (inflammation of\nthe spinal cord and brain lining).'
