This disease is\nmost dangerous for small children. Since the beginning of this year [2009]\n200 preschool children have fallen ill with this disease. Currently 80\nchildren are being treated in local hospitals. 44 local kindergartens have\nbeen closed as a quarantine measure.\n\nDoctors say that the main reason for the spread of infection is lack of\nadherence to elementary rules of hygiene. However Rospotrepnadzor [public\nhealth] officials suggested that the spread of infection is a consequence\nof lowered immunity. In most cases the disease is mild and presumed to be a\nconsequence of enteroviral infection. The deputy head of the Chelyabinsk\nOblast Rospotrebnadzor stated on NTV television that a diagnosis of\nenteroviral meningitis had been confirmed only in 15 cases.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The rise in serous meningitis morbidity at the end of the summer and start\nof the fall is a usual seasonal phenomenon as a consequence of enterovirus\ninfection. Transmission 1st occurs during the swimming season, and then\nshifts to person-to-person contacts. The latter occurs most frequently in\nschools. - Mod.NP\n\nChelyabinsk Oblast can be located using the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of Russia at <http://healthmap.org/r/00JZ>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 27 Aug 2009\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n The NTV [television] channel has reported the occurrence of an outbreak of\nserous meningitis [acute meningitis with secondary external\nhydrocephalus/viral meningitis] in the Chelyabinsk Oblast. [The rise in serous meningitis morbidity at the end of the summer and start\nof the fall is a usual seasonal phenomenon as a consequence of enterovirus\ninfection. AS, edited]\n<http://www.k2kapital.com/news/fin/687643.html>\n\n\n200 children have contracted serous meningitis in Chelyabinsk Oblast\n The deputy head of the Chelyabinsk\nOblast Rospotrebnadzor stated on NTV television that a diagnosis of\nenteroviral meningitis had been confirmed only in 15 cases. However Rospotrepnadzor [public\nhealth] officials suggested that the spread of infection is a consequence\nof lowered immunity. \n\nDoctors say that the main reason for the spread of infection is lack of\nadherence to elementary rules of hygiene. Since the beginning of this year [2009]\n200 preschool children have fallen ill with this disease. In most cases the disease is mild and presumed to be a\nconsequence of enteroviral infection. Transmission 1st occurs during the swimming season, and then\nshifts to person-to-person contacts. NP\n\nChelyabinsk Oblast can be located using the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of Russia at <http://healthmap.org/r/00JZ>. - Mod. This disease is\nmost dangerous for small children. Currently 80\nchildren are being treated in local hospitals. SEROUS MENINGITIS - RUSSIA: (CHELYABINSK OBLAST)\n 44 local kindergartens have\nbeen closed as a quarantine measure. The latter occurs most frequently in\nschools. **\n \n Source: K2Kapital News Service [translated by Correspondent.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "350566", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR: (HC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=350566", "date": "2009-12-13 21:00:02", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CONGO DR: (ORIENTALE)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 12 Dec 2009\nSource: China View [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/02/content_12574856.htm>\n\n\nTen students at Maikazo Institute in Tshopo district in Kisangani,\nthe main town in Orientale province of the Democratic Republic of\nCongo (DRC), died in one week from an unknown disease, with\nmeningitis-like symptoms, the Congolese radio reported on Tuesday [1\nDec 2009?]. The last case of death came on Tuesday morning at the\nMangobo general hospital, where 3 of these students had been admitted\nsince Saturday [28 Nov 2009?], when 9 others died a few hours after\nthey had been taken to the hospital, Dr. Cecile Edambulu, chief\nmedical doctor in Tshopo zone, told the radio.\n\n'The children had symptoms of headache, fever and convulsions. Upon\narrival at the health center, they died. The symptoms that they\nshowed made us think they were suffering from meningitis,' Edambulu\nexplained. According to hospital sources, similar cases were\nidentified in Makiso and Mangobo districts in the neighborhood of\nTshopo. The children had been taken to Mangobo and Kisangani\nhospitals, they reported.\n\nThe provincial education minister, Polydore Latigo, has decided to\nmomentarily close down Maikazo Institute. 'This is a preventive\nmeasure to allow the administrative and medical authorities to carry\nout investigation on the situation,' he said. The mayor of Kisangani\nhas brought together all education and health partners in the town to\nfind a way to curb the spread of the disease while awaiting the\nresults of tests on the samples taken to the capital Kinshasa and\nSouth Africa to determine the type of the virus.\n\n[Byline: Xiong Tong]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 8 Dec 2009\nSource: Irin (UN Integrated Regional Information Ne2rks) Africa [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportID=87364>\n\n\nAn outbreak of meningitis that killed more than a dozen students from\nthe same school last week has spread throughout the city of\nKisangani, in central Democratic Republic of Congo, officials said\nMonday [30 Nov 2009?]. The strain of the meningococcal [serogroup] C,\nwhich was confirmed last week, had infected at least 100 people\nthroughout the port city on the Congo River, said the Minister of\nHealth, August Mopipi, on 7 Dec 2009. He visited the city to assess\nwhat local leaders have called an 'epidemic'. By 6 Dec 2009,\naccording to hospital officials and the UN radio service in\nKisangani, 17 had died from the bacterial infection, all students at\nthe local Maikazo Technical Institute.\n\n'It's a source of hope that this deadly disease remains curable,'\nMopipi said, adding that more than 40 of the cases had been cured.\nThe minister said the government was working on distributing\nvaccinations but warned they could be 'prohibitively' expensive.\nAccording to Kisangani mayor Guy Shilton, crisis meetings between\nhospitals, local government authorities and religious leaders had\nbeen organized and an 'emergency protocol' had been put in place,\nproviding for the distribution of drugs. 'Once the epidemic is\ndeclared, we will attack it in every way possible,' Shilton said.\n\nThe 1st fatalities took place at the Maikazo Technical Institute,\nwhen 9 students from the school died at end-November 2009 after being\nchecked into the local hospital. According to the UN, doctors said\nthe patients all had signs of meningitis, but it could not be\nconfirmed. A 10th student died a week ago, and the school was closed\ndown by the state minister of education. 'It's a preventative and\ntemporary measure,' said Minister Polydor Latigo, 'but we need to\ninvestigate the problem safely.' Andre Kitenge, a press officer for\nthe UN in Kisangani, said that while all deaths related to the\noutbreak were from the school, cases in other parts of Kisangani were\n'prevalent'.\n\nKisangani, one of the largest cities in the Congo, lies in the middle\nof Africa's 'meningitis belt'. During the dry season, it infects\nhundreds more people than the global average of 3 per 100 000.\nAccording to the World Health Organization, an affordable vaccine is\nsupposed to be on the way, but for poor and densely populated areas\nsuch as Kisangani, it still poses a serious threat. An outbreak of\nmeningitis at the beginning of 2009 across the 'belt' infected nearly\n25 000, according to the UN, and killed more than 1500.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Orientale is a province in the northeastern corner of the Democratic\nRepublic of Congo (DRC). The 2005 Constitution divided Orientale\nProvince into 4 new provinces: Ituri, Haut-Uele, Tshopo, and Bas-Uele\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo>).\nThe provincial capital of Tshopo is Kisangani.\n\nEastern DRC has been the site of ongoing civil unrest. From an USAID\nreport: 'regional armed conflict across the Democratic Republic of\nthe Congo (DRC) has resulted in an estimated 5.4 million deaths since\n1998. Most deaths occurred due to indirect consequences of fighting,\nsuch as disease, malnutrition, and neonatal- and pregnancy-related\ncomplications. Overall, the decade of fighting displaced more than 3\nmillion Congolese across eastern and southern DRC and hindered access\nto agricultural land and traditional markets. Poverty continues to be\nwidespread, and the Congolese health care system has eroded due to a\nlack of resources and looting of medical assets'\n(<http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/humanitarian_assistance/disaster_assistance/countries/drc/template/fs_sr/fy2009/drc_ce_sr04_08-06-2009.pdf>).\n\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the 'Meningitis Belt' each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). The\n'Meningitis Belt' extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nDuring the 1st 11 weeks of 2009 (1 Jan-15 Mar 2009), a total of 24\n868 suspected cases, including 1513 deaths were reported to WHO by\ncountries of the meningitis belt. The current epidemic has been the\ndeadliest outbreak since 1996, and 1/3rd of the world's emergency\nvaccine stockpile for meningococcal vaccine has been consumed\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_West_African_meningitis_outbreak#cite_note-reuter-1>).\nMore than 85 percent of the cases occurred in one epidemic focus that\nencompasses Northern Nigeria and Niger and is due primarily to\n_Neisseria meningitides_ serogroup A\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_25/en/index.html>).\n\nAlthough, the DRC is not considered a part of the usual African\nmeningitis belt\n(<20090124.0310,Y'>http://www.promedmail.org/pls/otn/f?p=2400:1001:1989031435171910::::F2400_P1001_BACK_PAGE,F2400_P1001_ARCHIVE_NUMBER,F2400_P1001_USE_ARCHIVE:1202,20090124.0310,Y>),\noutbreaks of meningococcal meningitis, some of which have been\nconfirmed to be due to meningococcus serogroup A, have occurred in\nthe past (see ProMED posts listed below).\n\nA map of the DRC is available at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/drcongo.pdf>. Maps\nof the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nAlthough, the DRC is not considered a part of the usual African\nmeningitis belt\n(<20090124.0310,Y'>http://www.promedmail.org/pls/otn/f?p=2400:1001:1989031435171910::::F2400_P1001_BACK_PAGE,F2400_P1001_ARCHIVE_NUMBER,F2400_P1001_USE_ARCHIVE:1202,20090124.0310,Y>),\noutbreaks of meningococcal meningitis, some of which have been\nconfirmed to be due to meningococcus serogroup A, have occurred in\nthe past (see ProMED posts listed below). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \n\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the 'Meningitis Belt' each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n( The last case of death came on Tuesday morning at the\nMangobo general hospital, where 3 of these students had been admitted\nsince Saturday [28 Nov 2009?], when 9 others died a few hours after\nthey had been taken to the hospital, Dr. Cecile Edambulu, chief\nmedical doctor in Tshopo zone, told the radio. The mayor of Kisangani\nhas brought together all education and health partners in the town to\nfind a way to curb the spread of the disease while awaiting the\nresults of tests on the samples taken to the capital Kinshasa and\nSouth Africa to determine the type of the virus. The strain of the meningococcal [serogroup] C,\nwhich was confirmed last week, had infected at least 100 people\nthroughout the port city on the Congo River, said the Minister of\nHealth, August Mopipi, on 7 Dec 2009. An outbreak of meningitis that killed more than a dozen students from\nthe same school last week has spread throughout the city of\nKisangani, in central Democratic Republic of Congo, officials said\nMonday By 6 Dec 2009,\naccording to hospital officials and the UN radio service in\nKisangani, 17 had died from the bacterial infection, all students at\nthe local Maikazo Technical Institute. Andre Kitenge, a press officer for\nthe UN in Kisangani, said that while all deaths related to the\noutbreak were from the school, cases in other parts of Kisangani were\n'prevalent'. According to Kisangani mayor Guy Shilton, crisis meetings between\nhospitals, local government authorities and religious leaders had\nbeen organized and an 'emergency protocol' had been put in place,\nproviding for the distribution of drugs. ' The current epidemic has been the\ndeadliest outbreak since 1996, and 1/3rd of the world's emergency\nvaccine stockpile for meningococcal vaccine has been consumed\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_West_African_meningitis_outbreak#cite_note-reuter-1>). More than 85 percent of the cases occurred in one epidemic focus that\nencompasses Northern Nigeria and Niger and is due primarily to\n_Neisseria meningitides_ serogroup A\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_25/en/index.html>). Maps\nof the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>. Source: China View [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/02/content_12574856.htm>\n\n\nTen students at Maikazo Institute in Tshopo district in Kisangani,\nthe main town in Orientale province of the Democratic Republic of\n Poverty continues to be\nwidespread, and the Congolese health care system has eroded due to a\nlack of resources and looting of medical assets'\n(<http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/humanitarian_assistance/disaster_assistance/countries/drc/template/fs_sr/fy2009/drc_ce_sr04_08-06-2009.pdf>). From an USAID\nreport: 'regional armed conflict across the Democratic Republic of\nthe Congo (DRC) has resulted in an estimated 5.4 million deaths since\n1998. During the 1st 11 weeks of 2009 (1 Jan-15 Mar 2009), a total of 24\n868 suspected cases, including 1513 deaths were reported to WHO by\ncountries of the meningitis belt. \n\nThe 1st fatalities took place at the Maikazo Technical Institute,\nwhen 9 students from the school died at end-November 2009 after being\nchecked into the local hospital. An outbreak of\nmeningitis at the beginning of 2009 across the 'belt' infected nearly\n25 000, according to the UN, and killed more than 1500. Congo (DRC), died in one week from an unknown disease, with\nmeningitis-like symptoms, the Congolese radio reported on Tuesday [1\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1513-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-12-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2009-12-07 00:00:00", "2021-08-26 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kisangani", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Tshopo", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Makiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of \n the Congo", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Orientale province", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "234917", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - India (06): (ML)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=234917", "date": "2009-07-06 16:00:06", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - INDIA (06): (MEGHALAYA)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 3 Jul 2009\nSource: Times of India [edited]\n<http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/India/Meningitis-claims-257-lives-since-2008-in-Meghalaya-/articleshow/4734597.cms>\n\n\nA total of 257 people have lost their lives due to suspected\nmeningococcal meningitis in Meghalaya since 2008, the state government\nsaid on Friday. In 2008, 130 people (10 of them confirmed) died of the\ndisease. This year, so far, 127 (4 confirmed) people have succumbed to\nthe disease. However, more than 2000 cases have so far been reported\nfrom the state, health minister Mukul Sangma told the Assembly.\n\n'But the situation is under control and preventive measures are being\ncarried out,' he said. Around 10 lakh [one million] doses of vaccines\nfrom the World Health Organisation (WHO) have been procured till now\nand a free vaccination campaign in 3 affected districts is being\norganised by the state government. Response teams have been\nconstituted to identify places where the vaccination campaign would be\ntaken up in due course, he added.\n\n'Extensive awareness programmes have been taken up and preventive\nmedicines are being distributed free,' the health minister said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMed-mail in mid-February 2009 (Meningitis,\nmeningococcal - India (04): (NE) 20090217.0661), there were said to\nbe 165 deaths in Meghalaya in just the 1st month of 2009; whereas, the\ncurrent report above says that there were only 127 deaths in Meghalaya\nin all of the 1st 6 months of 2009. In mid-February 2009, the epidemic\nalso involved neighboring Indian states of Tripura and Mizoram, as\nwell as an adjacent region (Chittagong Hill Tracts) of Bangladesh.\nMeningococcal serogroup A was said to be the culprit. At that time,\nProMED-mail reported that a vaccination program was underway, and from\nthe current report is still underway.\n\nMeghalaya, a mountainous Indian state, is located between the\nnortheastern border of Bangladesh and the Indian state of Assam. A\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India that shows the states\nof Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram can be found at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=22.9,79.6,5>.\nA map of Bangladesh showing the location of the Chittagong Hill Tracts\nthat borders the Indian state of Mizoram can be found at\n<http://www.traveljournals.net/explore/bangladesh/map/m3773498/chittagong_hill_tract.html>. -\nMod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 3 Jul 2009\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMed-mail in mid-February 2009 (Meningitis,\nmeningococcal - India (04): (NE) 20090217.0661), there were said to\nbe 165 deaths in Meghalaya in just the 1st month of 2009; whereas, the\ncurrent report above says that there were only 127 deaths in Meghalaya\nin all of the 1st 6 months of 2009. Around 10 lakh [one million] doses of vaccines\nfrom the World Health Organisation (WHO) have been procured till now\nand a free vaccination campaign in 3 affected districts is being\norganised by the state government. A\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India that shows the states\nof Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram can be found at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=22.9,79.6,5>. A total of 257 people have lost their lives due to suspected\nmeningococcal meningitis in Meghalaya since 2008, the state government\nsaid on Friday. At that time,\nProMED-mail reported that a vaccination program was underway, and from\nthe current report is still underway. A map of Bangladesh showing the location of the Chittagong Hill Tracts\nthat borders the Indian state of Mizoram can be found at\n<http://www.traveljournals.net/explore/bangladesh/map/m3773498/chittagong_hill_tract.html>.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Mizoram", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tripura", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "208450", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (03): (OH) susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=208450", "date": "2009-05-29 15:00:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (03): (OHIO) SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 27 May 2009\nSource: The Columbus Dispatch [edited]\n<http://www.columbusdispatch.com/live/content/local_news/stories/2009/05/27/MARYHOSP.ART_ART_05-27-09_A1_0CE037A.html?sid=101>\n\n\nOfficials at Mary Rutan Hospital in Bellefontaine [Ohio] say they don't\nknow how 2 women in separate rooms of the maternity ward -- one of whom\nlater died -- contracted bacterial meningitis late last week. But they say\nthere is no threat of an outbreak and that expectant mothers ready to\ndeliver their babies at the Logan County [Ohio] hospital have no cause for\nconcern. The hospital has pulled batches of any medications the women may\nhave been given and what remains of any supplies that were used and they\nwill be tested as a possible source, said hospital spokeswoman Tammy\nAllison. She did not know whether hospital employees would be tested for\nthe bacteria.\n\nThe 2 women delivered babies on Thursday [?21 May 2009] and showed signs of\nbacterial meningitis on Friday [?22 May, 2009], Allison said. They both\nwere transferred to Riverside Methodist Hospital in Columbus [Ohio] on\nFriday afternoon, and one died, Allison said. She said the other woman\nremains in critical condition. Both infants were transferred to Nationwide\nChildren's Hospital in Columbus as a precaution, Allison said. She said\nfederal privacy regulations prevent her from releasing the women's names or\nthe condition of the babies.\n\nRiverside spokesman Mark Hopkins said [one of the women], 30, of Huntsville\n[Ohio], was transferred from Mary Rutan and died on Friday. Her daughter,\nwas in good condition yesterday [26 May 2009] at Children's, a spokeswoman\nsaid.\n\nAllison said the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as well as the\nlocal and state health departments, have been contacted and an internal\ninvestigation is under way. The maternity unit is licensed for 12 beds,\naccording to the Ohio Department of Health. It remains open, though Allison\nwould not say how many mothers and babies were there yesterday [26 May 2009].\n\nBacterial meningitis is spread from person to person through respiratory\ndroplets. It infects the fluid surrounding the brain and spinal cord and\ncan be fatal without early treatment. If detected early, it can be\nsuccessfully treated with strong antibiotics. Serious after-effects can\ninclude brain damage, hearing loss, limb amputation, and learning\ndisabilities. However, Allison said that Logan County health commissioner\nDr Boyd Hoddinott advised the hospital that the illness is not contagious\nand represents no danger to patients. Hoddinott was out of the office late\nyesterday [26 May 2009] and could not be reached for comment. Symptoms\ninclude fever, vomiting, an intense headache, and stiffness of the neck.\n\nAbout 2600 people in the United States contract bacterial meningitis each\nyear, according to CDC. In 2006, 634 people died of meningitis, according\nto the latest data from CDC. There were about 58 cases in Ohio last year\n[2008], according to preliminary numbers from the state, said spokesman\nKristopher Weiss. This year [2009], the department has logged 21 cases, not\nincluding the 2 in Logan County. At any given time, an estimated 5 per cent\nto 25 per cent of people are carrying the bacteria but have no symptoms.\nThose people play a major role in transmitting the disease.\n\nTwo vaccines are available for protection against meningitis, and federal\nhealth officials recommend vaccination for young people, especially college\nstudents. The disease is most common in infants, but no vaccine is approved\nfor use in people younger than 2 years old.\n\n[byline: H Zachariah, M Crane]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not specified in the news report, the cause of meningitis in the\n2 cases in Bellefontaine, Ohio, from the limited information presented, is\npresumably _Neisseria meningitidis_. The bacteria are transmitted from\nperson to person via droplets of respiratory secretions mostly from\nasymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers of the microorganism. It is estimated\nthat between 10 to 25 per cent of the population carry _N. meningitidis_ at\nany given time, and the carriage rate may be much higher in epidemic\nsituations. Close and prolonged contact (such as kissing, sneezing and\ncoughing on someone, living in close quarters or dormitories (military\nrecruits, students), sharing eating or drinking utensils, etc.) facilitate\nthe spread of the disease. The average incubation period for meningococcal\nmeningitis is 4 days, ranging between 2 and 10 days\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>), so that\ntransmission within the hospital setting to these 2 obstetrics patients,\nwho showed signs of bacterial meningitis within 24 hours of delivery, is\nunlikely. Although details about lengths of hospital stay prior to delivery\nare not given in the news report for the 2 meningitis cases, it would seem\nmore likely that the microorganism was transmitted from asymptomatic\nnasopharyngeal carriers in the community.\n\nA quadrivalent A, C, Y, and W135 meningococcal conjugate vaccine (Menactra)\nwas licensed in the United States in January 2005. The conjugate vaccine\ninduces a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved immune\nresponse, providing long-lasting immunity and preventing nasopharyngeal\ncarriage of _N. meningitidis_ and thus reducing bacterial transmission of\nthis microorganism\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>). On 18 Oct\n2007, the FDA approved expanding the age range for Menactra, a bacterial\nmeningitis vaccine, to include children ages 2 to 10 years. Previously, the\nvaccine was approved by the FDA for people ages 11 to 55 years. See also\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm> and\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5631a3.htm>.\n\nConfirmation of the identity of the pathogen involved would be appreciated.\nDNA fingerprinting of the isolates would help in epidemiologic linkage.\n\nThe town of Bellefontaine, Ohio lies north of the city of Columbus, Ohio.\nThe Mary Rutan Hospital in Bellefontaine, Ohio can be located on\n<http://maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&ie=UTF8&q=Mary+Rutan+Hospital+in+Bellefontaine&fb=1&split=1&gl=us&view=map&ei=a1kfSpKEJeGLtgfS0t3sAw&cd=1>\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00dt>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (03): (OHIO) SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 27 May 2009\n The average incubation period for meningococcal\nmeningitis is 4 days, ranging between 2 and 10 days\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>), so that\ntransmission within the hospital setting to these 2 obstetrics patients,\nwho showed signs of bacterial meningitis within 24 hours of delivery, is\nunlikely. The conjugate vaccine\ninduces a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved immune\nresponse, providing long-lasting immunity and preventing nasopharyngeal\ncarriage of _N. meningitidis_ and thus reducing bacterial transmission of\nthis microorganism\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>). Source: The Columbus Dispatch [edited]\n<http://www.columbusdispatch.com/live/content/local_news/stories/2009/05/27/MARYHOSP.ART_ART_05-27-09_A1_0CE037A.html?sid=101>\n\n\nOfficials at Mary Rutan Hospital in Bellefontaine [Ohio] say they don't\nknow how 2 women in separate rooms of the maternity ward -- one of whom\nlater died -- contracted bacterial meningitis late last week. The Mary Rutan Hospital in Bellefontaine, Ohio can be located on\n<http://maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&ie=UTF8&q=Mary+Rutan+Hospital+in+Bellefontaine&fb=1&split=1&gl=us&view=map&ei=a1kfSpKEJeGLtgfS0t3sAw&cd=1>\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00dt>. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not specified in the news report, the cause of meningitis in the\n2 cases in Bellefontaine, Ohio, from the limited information presented, is\npresumably _Neisseria meningitidis_. Close and prolonged contact (such as kissing, sneezing and\ncoughing on someone, living in close quarters or dormitories (military\nrecruits, students), sharing eating or drinking utensils, etc.)", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2005-01-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2009-05-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bellefontaine", "country": "Martinique"}, {"location": "Logan County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Columbus", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "193618", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=193618", "date": "2009-05-09 15:00:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (03)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu May 7 2009\nSource: Reuters [edited]\n<http://in.reuters.com/article/health/idINTRE5456R120090506>\n\n\nA meningitis outbreak in Nigeria is more serious than initially\nfeared with the death toll rising more than 6-fold over the past 2\nmonths, the Health Ministry said on Wednesday.\n\nDeaths from the epidemic have risen to 2148 since the 1st case was\nrecorded in December [2008] from 333, announced by the health\nminister in early March [2009]. The number of reported cases has\nclimbed more than 8-fold to 47 902 over the same period. About 2-3rds\nof Nigeria's 36 states are affected by the epidemic, the ministry\nsaid. Nigeria is Africa's most populous country with a population of\nmore than 140 million.\n\nUNICEF said last month [April 2009] that more than 2500 people had\nbeen killed by meningitis this year in West and Central Africa in\nwhat could be the worst epidemic for 5 years. Nigeria, Niger, Burkina\nFaso and Chad are considered Africa's high-risk zone.\n\nMeningitis is the inflammation of the tissue surrounding the brain\nand spinal cord, and can be caused by viral or bacterial infections.\nIt spreads mainly through kisses, sneezes, coughs and in close living quarters.\n\nThe meningitis death toll in Nigeria since December [2008] is almost\n50 times the number of people killed worldwide by the H1N1 swine flu\nvirus. But the speed with which it has spread underscores the\npotential dangers if swine flu reaches Africa. Basic healthcare is\nlimited in rural parts of Nigeria, where most people live on less\nthan USD 2.00 a day, despite the country's huge oil resources. Many\nNigerians fear that an outbreak of swine flu would be devastating.\nThe Health Ministry said no suspected case of swine flu had been\nrecorded in the country but that it had taken steps to contain any outbreak.\n\nThe worst recent meningitis epidemic in West and Central Africa\noccurred in 1996-97 when an estimated 100 000 people were infected in\nNigeria and 50 000 in Niger.\n\n[Byline: Camillus Eboh, Tume Ahemba, and Nick Tattersall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Numerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the 'Meningitis Belt' each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). The\n'Meningitis Belt' extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east, and includes Nigeria\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nNigeria seems to have been hit hardest by the outbreak this year. WHO\nreported on 11 Mar 2009 that in Nigeria there were 9086 cases with\n562 deaths from meningococcal meningitis (see ProMED post Meningitis,\nbacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038) and that both serogroup A and W135 were involved. The\nnumber of cases of meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria have now\nincreased 5-fold and the number of deaths, 3.8-fold.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Numerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the 'Meningitis Belt' each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n( A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu May 7 2009\n WHO\nreported on 11 Mar 2009 that in Nigeria there were 9086 cases with\n562 deaths from meningococcal meningitis (see ProMED post Meningitis,\nbacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038) and that both serogroup A and W135 were involved. The\n'Meningitis Belt' extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east, and includes Nigeria\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>). \n\nUNICEF said last month [April 2009] that more than 2500 people had\nbeen killed by meningitis this year in West and Central Africa in\nwhat could be the worst epidemic for 5 years. The meningitis death toll in Nigeria since December [2008] is almost\n50 times the number of people killed worldwide by the H1N1 swine flu\nvirus. The\nnumber of cases of meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria have now\nincreased 5-fold and the number of deaths, 3.8-fold. A meningitis outbreak in Nigeria is more serious than initially\nfeared with the death toll rising more than 6-fold over the past 2\nmonths, the Health Ministry said on Wednesday. \n\nDeaths from the epidemic have risen to 2148 since the 1st case was\nrecorded in December [2008] from 333, announced by the health\nminister in early March [2009]. Basic healthcare is\nlimited in rural parts of Nigeria, where most people live on less\nthan USD 2.00 a day, despite the country's huge oil resources.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-12-26 00:00:00", "2009-04-26 00:00:00", "2148-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "177618", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=177618", "date": "2009-04-24 16:01:01", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CHAD (02)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 23 Apr 2009\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) Disease Outbreak\nNews [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_04_23/en/index.html>\n\n\nMeningococcal disease in Chad\n-----------------------------\nFrom 29 Dec 2008 to 5 Apr [2009], the Ministry of Health of Chad reported\n922 suspected cases of meningococcal disease, including 105 deaths (case\nfatality rate: 11.4 per cent). So far, 3 districts have crossed the\nepidemic threshold, including a district in the capital, N'Djamena, while 5\ndistricts are on alert.\n\nSo far, 33 specimens of cerebrospinal fluid have been found positive for\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup W135 and 30 specimens for _N.\nmeningitidis_ serogroup A, by latex, culture, and PCR, suggesting that both\nserogroups are responsible for the epidemic.\n\nThe International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for\nEpidemic Meningitis Control has provided 164 000 doses of trivalent ACW\nvaccine for a mass vaccination campaign in affected areas of Dourbali,\nGoundi, and Pala district. In addition, 704 300 doses of trivalent vaccine\nhave been released this week [week of 20 Apr 2009], which will be used for\nan immunization campaign in the capital, planned to start next week. WHO,\nUNICEF, Medecins sans Frontieres, and the International Federation of Red\nCross (IFRC) are working with the Ministry of Health, Chad to implement\nvaccination campaigns as well as other emergency control measures,\nincluding case management and surveillance in neighbouring districts.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the last ProMED-mail post on the meningococcal outbreak in Chad\n(archive number 20090416.1439), there have been 51 more cases of\nmeningococcal meningitis cases and 3 more deaths. The news release confirms\nthat this outbreak in Chad involves both serogroups A and W135.\n\nSee prior ProMED-mail posts listed below for more information on\nmeningococcal meningitis in Africa.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Chad is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/009u>. A map of the African bacterial meningitis\nbelt can be found at <http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 23 Apr 2009\n WHO,\nUNICEF, Medecins sans Frontieres, and the International Federation of Red\nCross (IFRC) are working with the Ministry of Health, Chad to implement\nvaccination campaigns as well as other emergency control measures,\nincluding case management and surveillance in neighbouring districts. \n\nThe International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for\nEpidemic Meningitis Control has provided 164 000 doses of trivalent ACW\nvaccine for a mass vaccination campaign in affected areas of Dourbali,\nGoundi, and Pala district. Source: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) Disease Outbreak\nNews [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_04_23/en/index.html>\n\n\nMeningococcal disease in Chad\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< From 29 Dec 2008 to 5 Apr [2009], the Ministry of Health of Chad reported\n922 suspected cases of meningococcal disease, including 105 deaths (case\nfatality rate: 11.4 per cent).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-12-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "174847", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Chad", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=174847", "date": "2009-04-16 10:00:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CHAD\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 14 Apr 2009\nSource: News24.com [edited]\n<http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,,2-11-1447_2501118,00.html>\n\n\nMeningitis has claimed 102 lives in Chad since the beginning of the\nyear, Health Minister Ngombaye Djaibe said on Tuesday [14 Apr 2009],\nwarning that the outbreak had reached epidemic proportions. 'We're\ndeclaring a meningitis outbreak in Chad,' he told a press conference.\n'At present, the cumulative number of cases is 871 (since 1 Jan\n2009), of whom 102 have died, giving a mortality rate of 11.7\npercent.'\n\nThe health minister of the poor, mainly arid central African nation\nsaid that medical workers had managed to identify different strains\nof meningitis, including 'W 135, a strain held to be very virulent'.\n\nThe infectious disease causes inflammation of the tissues surrounding\nthe brain or spinal cord, with symptoms including fever, nausea,\nstrong headaches and a stiff neck. In its most severe bacterial form,\nit can lead to a coma and death.\n\nMeningitis is widespread in west and central Africa, though it can be\nprevented by vaccination campaigns. In 2005-2006, more than 100\npeople died in an epidemic in Chad, but had been relatively spared\nuntil this latest outbreak.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Meningitis due to the _Neisseria meningitidis_ occurs sporadically\nor as epidemics in sub-Saharan Africa, which is known as the\n'Meningitis Belt,' an area that stretches from Senegal in the west to\nEthiopia and Eritrea in the east and that includes Chad\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). Numerous\ncases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in this region of\nAfrica each year during the dry season, between December and June,\nand every 6-12 years a large outbreak occurs\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nThere are at least 13 serogroups of _Neisseria meningitidis_ based on\nthe antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides; disease\ndue serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135 are most common. All serogroup\npolysaccharides but B, are immunogenic in humans.\n\nFrom a prior ProMED-mail post (archive number 20071207.3954): To\ncontrol an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate vaccine, depending availability, in every involved\ndistrict in an attempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission\nis blocked when a critical percentage of the population have been\nvaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>).\n\nThere are several different types of meningococcal vaccines.\nPolysaccharide vaccines, which have been available for more than 30\nyears, exist against serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various\ncombinations (such as, a bivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a\ntetravalent ACYW-135 polysaccharide vaccine). There is a monovalent\nconjugate vaccine against serogroup C and a tetravalent against\nserogroups A, C, Y, and W-135. The conjugate vaccines are immunogenic\nfor children under 2 years of age, whereas polysaccharide vaccines\nare not. All these vaccines have been proven safe and effective with\ninfrequent and mild side effects. For both the meningococcal\nconjugate and the polysaccharide vaccines, approximately 7-10 days\nare required following vaccination for development of protective\nlevels of anti-meningococcal antibodies.\n\nDuring the 1st 10 weeks of the 2006 meningitis season, outbreaks in\neastern Africa were mainly caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup W-135, whereas in West Africa the outbreak was due to\nmainly serogroup A.\n\nSee prior ProMED-mail posts listed below for more information. A map\nof the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "From a prior ProMED-mail post (archive number 20071207.3954): To\ncontrol an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate vaccine, depending availability, in every involved\ndistrict in an attempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission\nis blocked when a critical percentage of the population have been\nvaccinated\n( In 2005-2006, more than 100\npeople died in an epidemic in Chad, but had been relatively spared\nuntil this latest outbreak.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 14 Apr 2009\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Meningitis due to the _Neisseria meningitidis_ occurs sporadically\nor as epidemics in sub-Saharan Africa, which is known as the\n'Meningitis Belt,' an area that stretches from Senegal in the west to\nEthiopia and Eritrea in the east and that includes Chad\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). Numerous\ncases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in this region of\nAfrica each year during the dry season, between December and June,\nand every 6-12 years a large outbreak occurs\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>). During the 1st 10 weeks of the 2006 meningitis season, outbreaks in\neastern Africa were mainly caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup W-135, whereas in West Africa the outbreak was due to\nmainly serogroup A.\n\nSee prior ProMED-mail posts listed below for more information. Source: News24.com [edited]\n<http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,,2-11-1447_2501118,00.html>\n\n\nMeningitis has claimed 102 lives in Chad since the beginning of the\nyear, Health Minister Ngombaye Djaibe said on Tuesday [14 Apr 2009],\nwarning that the outbreak had reached epidemic proportions. ' Polysaccharide vaccines, which have been available for more than 30\nyears, exist against serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various\ncombinations (such as, a bivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a\ntetravalent ACYW-135 polysaccharide vaccine).", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Eritrea", "country": "Eritrea"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "168079", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - USA (02): (HI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=168079", "date": "2009-03-26 11:19:53", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - USA (02): (HAWAII)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 22 Mar 2009\nSource: KPUA Hawaii News, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://www.kpua.net/news.php?id=17462>\n\n\nRat lungworm patients recovering\n--------------------------------\nTwo Big Island victims of a rare disease spread through homegrown\nvegetables have emerged from their comas.\n\n[The 38-year-old woman] has come out of the coma caused by rat\nlungworm disease enough to respond to friends and her parents. She\nhas been hospitalized since 8 Dec 2008. [The 24-year-old man] is now\nconscious and able to track people with his eyes. He was put in\nintensive care in January [2009].\n\nBoth remain at Hilo Medical Center, where they are breathing with the\nassistance of a machine. The disease is spread through vegetables\ncontaining larvae of a slug that carries the rat lungworm. A 3rd\nperson who contracted rat lungworm disease has recovered enough to\nwalk and live at home.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Brent Barrett for the follow up report on the 3\npatients. The CDC fact sheet on angiostrongyliasis can be found at\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Hawaii is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/007B>. - Mod.EP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 22 Mar 2009\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Brent Barrett for the follow up report on the 3\npatients. A 3rd\nperson who contracted rat lungworm disease has recovered enough to\nwalk and live at home. Rat lungworm patients recovering\n--------------------------------\n ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - USA (02): (HAWAII)\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-01-26 00:00:00", "2008-12-08 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hawaii", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "168758", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - Taiwan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=168758", "date": "2009-03-27 23:01:04", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - TAIWAN\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 27 Mar 2009\nSource: Taipei Times [edited]\n<http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2009/03/27/2003439499>\n\n\nAngiostrongylus in Thai workers after consuming raw snails\n----------------------------------------------------------\nEarlier this month (March 2009), 4 out of 5 Thai workers who ate raw\nsnails became infected with a potentially deadly parasite\n[_Angiostrongylus_], the Department of Health (DOH) said on Wednesday\n[25 Mar 2009]. Centers for Disease Control Deputy Director Chou\nJih-Haw said that 3 of the workers were in stable condition, while one\nhad left Taiwan and the other had not shown any symptoms of illness.\n\nThree of the workers were reported to have been infected with the\nparasitic nematode Angiostrongylus cantonensis -- an elongated\ncylindrical worm -- early this month and developed symptoms of\neosinophilic meningitis, including headaches, fever and vomiting, Chou\nsaid. The DOH discovered that the trio and some of their friends had\ncaught apple snails (_Pomacea canaliculata_) in fish ponds in southern\nTaiwan and eaten them raw with sauce.\n\nSnails are usually the primary host of the worm, also known as the rat\nlungworm -- a parasite endemic to Southeast Asia and the Pacific\nregion. Humans become infected by ingesting the parasite's larvae,\nwhich are then carried in the blood to the central nervous system.\nThis can result in eosinophilic meningitis, which is characterized in\nthe early stages by severe and acute headaches, fever, nausea and\nvomiting, and stiffness of the neck, and can result in death or\npermanent brain damage.\n\nChou said that it was once believed that eating giant African snails\ncould cure certain illnesses and that there were frequent reports in\nTaiwan of infections of this type of roundworm.\n\nA 70-year-old man in Kaohsiung was treated for the same conditions in\n2007 after eating raw frogs in an effort to cure back pain. Another\ncase in 2005 saw Hualien's Tzu-Chi Buddhist General Hospital treat a\n48-year-old man who had become infected with the parasite after eating\nraw snails. In 1998, 8 Thai workers came down with eosinophilic\nmeningitis as result of eating raw snails and in 1999, Kaohsiung\nVeterans General Hospital reported that 9 Thai laborers had been\ninfected with rat lungworms.\n\nIn light of the recent case, the DOH said it would contact Thai\nauthorities to step up health education to avoid a recurrence of the\nproblem.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is transmitted to humans eating raw\nfresh water snails and lettuce contaminated with infected slugs. Human\ninfection with _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is common in Thailand and\nis seen especially in the northeastern region, where it is associated\nwith the habit of eating koi-hoi, which contains raw snail meat\n(Eamsobhana P et al. Thai Koi-Hoi Snail Dish and Angiostrongyliasis\nDue to Angiostrongylus cantonensis: Effects of Food Flavoring and\nAlcoholic Drink on the Third-Stage Larvae in Infected Snail Meat.\nFoodborne Pathog. Dis. 2009 Mar 9).\n\nOcular Angiostrongylus has also been described from Thailand (Sinawat\nS et al. Ocular angiostrongyliasis: clinical study of 3 cases. Eye\n2008;22:1446-8).\n\nSee Life Cycle at:\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm> - Mod.EP\n\nImages of _Angiostrongylus_ at:\n<http://www.petdoctors.co.uk/upload/image/thumb_300_70_angiostrongylus_200x_dup27p.jpg>\n<http://ecurriculum.mv.ac.th/health/m.5/lesson5/liver5/angiostrongylus_adult.gif>\nApple snail _Pomacea canaliculata_:\n<http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/006/Y5098E/y5098e0m.jpg>\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 27 Mar 2009\n Three of the workers were reported to have been infected with the\nparasitic nematode Angiostrongylus cantonensis -- an elongated\ncylindrical worm -- early this month and developed symptoms of\neosinophilic meningitis, including headaches, fever and vomiting, Chou\nsaid. Human\ninfection with _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is common in Thailand and\nis seen especially in the northeastern region, where it is associated\nwith the habit of eating koi-hoi, which contains raw snail meat\n Another\ncase in 2005 saw Hualien's Tzu-Chi Buddhist General Hospital treat a\n48-year-old man who had become infected with the parasite after eating\nraw snails. This can result in eosinophilic meningitis, which is characterized in\nthe early stages by severe and acute headaches, fever, nausea and\nvomiting, and stiffness of the neck, and can result in death or\npermanent brain damage. EP\n\nImages of _Angiostrongylus_ at:\n<http://www.petdoctors.co.uk/upload/image/thumb_300_70_angiostrongylus_200x_dup27p.jpg>\n<http://ecurriculum.mv.ac.th/health/m.5/lesson5/liver5/angiostrongylus_adult.gif>\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is transmitted to humans eating raw\nfresh water snails and lettuce contaminated with infected slugs. Earlier this month (March 2009), 4 out of 5 Thai workers who ate raw\nsnails became infected with a potentially deadly parasite\n \n\nChou said that it was once believed that eating giant African snails\ncould cure certain illnesses and that there were frequent reports in\nTaiwan of infections of this type of roundworm. In 1998, 8 Thai workers came down with eosinophilic\nmeningitis as result of eating raw snails and in 1999, Kaohsiung\n \n\nSnails are usually the primary host of the worm, also known as the rat\nlungworm -- a parasite endemic to Southeast Asia and the Pacific\nregion. Source: Taipei Times [edited]\n<http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2009/03/27/2003439499>\n\n\nAngiostrongylus in Thai workers after consuming raw snails\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "1999-03-26 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kaohsiung", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Hualien", "country": "Taiwan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "164725", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=164725", "date": "2009-03-13 15:00:54", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, BACTERIAL - AFRICA (02): NIGERIA, WHO MENINGITIS REGION\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] Nigeria\n[2] Africa: WHO Meningitis Region\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Thu 12 Mar 2009\nSource: Agence France-Presse (AFP) [edited]\n<http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jnqZygqNJdnANb_ojvfZI38jb5vg>\n\n\nA meningitis outbreak has killed 931 people [with a total of 13 516\ncases affected] in 4 West African countries since January [2009],\nwith most deaths occurring in the continent's most populous nation\nNigeria, the United Nations said Wednesday [11 Mar 2009]. 'Nigeria is\nthe most affected with 9086 cases and 562 deaths. Niger reports 2620\ncases and 113 deaths. Burkina Faso reports 1756 cases and 250 deaths.\nMali reports 54 cases and 6 deaths.'\n\nUNICEF warned that the authorities in Nigeria, where public health\nfacilities are abysmal and poverty rampant despite its huge oil\nriches, faced an uphill task in tackling the crisis. 'In Nigeria,\ncase management and a mass vaccination campaign are underway. The\nstock of vaccine may be insufficient regarding the epidemiological\ntrends, especially in the districts in the north,' it warned.\n\nHealth authorities placed northern Nigeria on a state of high alert\nin January [2009] following a meningitis outbreak in the town of\nZinder in neighbouring Niger. Nigeria's largest northern state of\nKano has been the worst hit thus far.\n\nMeningitis causes inflammation of the lining of the brain and spinal\ncord and has long wracked Africa, the world's poorest region.\nAccording to UNICEF, it can spread through sneezing and coughing. The\ndisease mainly affects children and young adults aged 1-30, it said.\n'The so-called African meningitis belt stretches from Mauritania in\nthe west to Ethiopia in the east and is home to about 350 million\npeople,' UNICEF said. 'Outbreaks occur every year between December\nand May. The dry season, with strong dusty winds and cold nights make\npeople more prone to respiratory infections and facilitates the\nspread of bacteria.'\n\nThe biggest recorded outbreak of epidemic meningitis in Africa\noccurred in 1996 with over 250 000 cases and 25 000 deaths. Even when\nthe disease is diagnosed early, 5 to 10 percent of patients die,\ntypically within one or 2 days of the onset of symptoms, according to\nthe World Health Organisation. Most victims suffer irreversible\nneurological consequences.\n\nThe current WHO recommendation for outbreak control is to mass\nvaccinate every district in an epidemic phase, as well as nearby\nareas in alert phase. It estimates that a mass immunisation campaign\ncan avoid 70 percent of cases. Outbreak response also includes active\nsurveillance and case management and support to community awareness programmes.\n\nOnce the disease is contracted, it can be treated in its early stages\nwith antibiotics. WHO recommends oily chloramphenicol as the drug of\nchoice in areas with limited health facilities.\n\nUNICEF said mass vaccination drives were currently underway in Niger\nand Burkina Faso.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Africa: WHO Meningitis Region\nDate: Wed 11 Mar 2009\nSource: WHO MDSC (Multidisease Surveillance Centre) Meningitis Weekly\nBulletin Week 08 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/Bulletin%20Meningite%202009_S8.pdf>\n\n\nTable 1: Epidemiological Situation Week 8 (16-22 Feb 2009)\nCountry / Case / Death / Lethality (percent) / District in alert /\nDistrict in epidemic / Complet (percent) / NmA / NmW135 / Other Nm /\nPneum / Hib\nBenin / 11 / 0 / 0.0 / 0 / 0 / 98.7 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 3 / 0\nBurkina Faso / 266 / 35 / 13.2 / 4 / 1 / 100.0\nCameroon / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nCentral African Rep / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nCote d'Ivoire / 7 / 0 / 0.0 / 0 / 0 / 86.0 / - / - / - / - / -\nEthiopia / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nGhana / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nGuinea / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nMali / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nNiger / 621 / 21 / 3.4 / 7 / / 6 / 100.0\nNigeria / 1817 105 / 5.8 / 29 / / 28 / 70.8 / 37 / 7 / 0 / 2 / 0\nCongo DR** / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nChad / 25 / 4 / 16.0 / 0 / 0 / 92.9 / - / - / - / - / -\nTogo / 12 / 0 / 0.0 / 0 / 0 / 100.0 / - / - / - / - / -\nTotal / 2759 / 165 / 6.0 / 40 / 35 / 59.6 / 37 / 7 / 0 / 5 / 0\n* identification by: PCR, latex, culture\n** definition of alert/epidemic thresholds not applicable to this\ncountry outside the meningitis belt.\n\nComments\n--------\nBurkina Faso:\n- district in alert: Toma, Titao, and Ziniare\n- district in epidemic: Solenzo\nNiger:\n- district in alert: Gaya, Loga, Guidan-Roumdji, Magaria, Mirriah,\nKeita, and Zinder\n- district in epidemic: Bilma, Dogon-Doutchi, illela, Matameye\nMadarounfa, and Tessaoua\nNigeria: 28 LGAs [local government areas] in epidemic and 29 LGAs in\nalert (see details on page 3 of the original at the source URL). The\n7 cases of NmW135 have been isolated in Adamawa State where no LGA\nreached alert or epidemic threshold as of week 8 [16-22 Feb 2009]\n\nTable 2. Synthesis of the Epidemiological Situation 2009 (reported weeks 1-8)\nCountry / Case / Death / Lethality (percent) / District in alert /\nDistrict in epidemic / Reported weeks / In districts (percent) / In\nweeks (percent)\nBenin / 109 / 15 / 13.8 / 1 / 0 / 01-08 / 98.7 / 100.0\nBurkina Faso / 1514 / 213 / 14.1 / 7 / 3 / 01-08 / 100.0 / 100.0\nCameroon / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nCentral African Rep / 41 / 17 / 41.5 / 1 / 0 / 01-07 / 100.0 / 100.0\nCote d'Ivoire / 120 / 27 / 22.5 / 0 / 0 / 01-08 / 90.0 / 90.0\nEthiopia / 32 / 6 / 18.8 / 0 / 0 / 01-07 / -\nGhana / 61 / 13 / 21.3 / 0 / 0 / 01-06 / - / -\nGuinea / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nMali / 31 / 2 / 6.5 / 0 / 0 / 01-04 / 100.0 / 100.0\nNiger / 1897 / 84 / 4.4 / 6 / 7 / 01-08 / 100.0 / 100.0\nNigeria / 5323 / 333 / 6.3 / 37 / 52 / 01-08 / 70.8 / 99.9\nCongo DR **/ - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nChad / 259 / 33 / 12.7 / 2 / 0 / 01-08 / 108.9 / 95.9\nTogo / 105 / 16 / 15.2 / 1 0 / 01-08 / 100.0 / 99.3\nTotal / 9492 / 759 / 8.0 / 55 / 62 / 01-08 / 65.0 / 99.5\n** definition of alert/epidemic thresholds not applicable to this\ncountry outside the meningitis belt\n\nComments\n--------\nThe epidemic trend is on the rise in Nigeria and Niger. The ascending\ntrend of the epidemic curve is still above those of 2007 and 2008. As\nopposed to 2008 where the epidemic was located in northern West of\nNigeria, the epidemic of 2009 is mainly located in the Northern\nCentral region with eastward extension. The case fatality rates are\nhowever low in the 2 countries. If in Niger the vaccine is still\navailable, in Nigeria, the 1st supplies of vaccines have just arrived\nthis week 8 [16-22 Feb 2009]. WHO missions are on the ground in\nNigeria to support local authorities.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Mandy Kader Konde\nDirector\nWHO-Multidisease Surveillance Center (MDSC)\nWHO-Meningitis Vaccine Project (MVP) Focal Point\n1473 Avenue Naba Zombre, 01 BP 549 Ouagadougou 01\nBurkina Faso\n<kondek@oncho.afro.who.int>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Kader Konde of the WHO Multidisease\nSurveillance Centre (MDSC) in Ouagadougou (Burkina Faso) for alerting\nProMED to the latest WHO data on bacterial meningitis in countries\nunder enhanced surveillance of meningitis in the WHO Africa Region.\n\nThe meningococcal meningitis epidemic in Nigeria and Niger continues\nto expand, but the 1st supplies of meningococcal vaccines have just\narrived in Nigeria in week 8 (16-22 Feb) of 2009. The serogroups\ncovered by the meningococcal vaccine are not specified in the reports\nabove; in Nigeria, both serogroup A and W135 are involved.\n\nTable 1 above is a summary of the reports on cerebrospinal meningitis\nreceived by country for week 8 of 2009. ' As\nopposed to 2008 where the epidemic was located in northern West of\nNigeria, the epidemic of 2009 is mainly located in the Northern\nCentral region with eastward extension. Even when\nthe disease is diagnosed early, 5 to 10 percent of patients die,\ntypically within one or 2 days of the onset of symptoms, according to\nthe World Health Organisation. The current WHO recommendation for outbreak control is to mass\nvaccinate every district in an epidemic phase, as well as nearby\nareas in alert phase.
