' The so-called African meningitis belt stretches from Mauritania in\nthe west to Ethiopia in the east and is home to about 350 million\npeople,' UNICEF said. ' MENINGITIS, BACTERIAL - AFRICA (02): NIGERIA, WHO MENINGITIS REGION\n************************************************************************\n The dry season, with strong dusty winds and cold nights make\npeople more prone to respiratory infections and facilitates the\nspread of bacteria.' The serogroups\ncovered by the meningococcal vaccine are not specified in the reports\nabove; in Nigeria, both serogroup A and W135 are involved.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "1996-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-26 00:00:00", "2009-08-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2009-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dogon - Doutchi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Magaria", "country": "Niger"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Adamawa State", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "Mauritania"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "197303", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Malaysia: (ME,PG) susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=197303", "date": "2009-05-14 17:00:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - MALAYSIA (MALACCA, PENANG) SUSPECTED, REQUEST\nFOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Sun 10 May 2009\nSource: The Malaysian Insider [edited]\n<http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/26052-meningitis-outbreak-caused-by-diplococci-bacteria>\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has identified the diplococci bacteria [presumably\n_Neisseria meningitidis_] as the cause of the meningitis afflicting\ntrainees of the Road Transport Department (JPJ) Academy in Tiang Dua,\n[Malacca], resulting in one death last week [week of 4 May 2009].\n\nHealth minister Datuk Seri Liow Tiong Lai said that until 2 pm today [10\nMay 2009], 20 trainees were warded at [Malacca] Hospital, 2 in the\nintensive care unit and 18 at the isolation ward. He said 6 new patients\nwere warded at the same hospital yesterday evening [9 May 2009] and one\ntoday. 'However, we believe the bacterial infection can be controlled with\nthe preventive and rehabilitative measures taken by Malacca Hospital,' he\nsaid after visiting the patients at the hospital, today. Also present was\nMalacca Health director Dr Ghazali Othman.\n\nLiow said the 93 JPJ Academy trainees quarantined were being closely\nobserved by a 7 member special task force headed by a doctor for immediate\nmeasures to be taken in an emergency. He said the trainees quarantined had\nbeen given ciprofloxacin, an antibiotic while those being treated at the\nhospital were given ceftriaxone to recover from the infection. 'I saw that\nthe patients at the ICU and isolation ward were okay. The antibiotics given\nseemed to be working and they (patients) would need 7 days of treatment\nbefore the next step.'\n\nHe said residents, especially in Tiang Dua, should not panic over the\nmeningitis situation as the infection could only be spread by droplets when\nthe carrier coughed or sneezed within a one-metre range. 'The meningitis\nbacteria will not cause an uncontrollable epidemic,' he assured. Liow said\nsamples of the diplococci bacteria had been sent to the microbiology\nlaboratory in Sungai Buloh to ascertain the type as the bacteria had\ndifferent strains.\n\n'We are also investigating the source of the bacteria by obtaining samples\nfrom where the trainees had their practical training, namely in Pedas\n(Negeri Sembilan), Muar (Johor), and Bukit Katil (Malacca).' He said all\ntrainees and staff of the JPJ Academy in Tiang Dua were given antibiotics\nto control the spread of the meningitis bacterial infection.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nJack Soo\n<jack.soo@kyip.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 12 May 2009\nSource: The Star online [edited]\n<http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/5/12/nation/3884441&sec=nation>\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has given an assurance that the diplococci meningitis\noutbreak in [Malacca] is under control. The infection was contained within\nthe Road Transport Department training academy and would not be a threat to\nthe country, said health minister Datuk Seri Liow Tiong Lai.\n\nOn [4 May 2009], a trainee at the academy in Tiang Dua, Malacca, died of\nthe infection while being rushed to hospital. Liow said the outbreak was\ninvestigated as soon as possible and it was then discovered that it was not\na viral infection. This enabled the ministry to give the right medication\nto the patients.\n\nAs of yesterday [11 May 2009], there were 32 patients hospitalised with 2\nin intensive care and 29 in the isolation ward in Malacca and another\npatient in Kepala Batas, Penang. The number of trainees in the isolation\nward increased from 18 from the day before [10 May 2009], he said. 'They\nare all in stable condition,' said Liow, adding that they were being put on\ntreatment and each treatment cycle takes one week.\n\nThe ministry would know in a day or 2 the subtype of the diplococci\nbacteria that infected the trainees, said Liow. Water samples were taken\nfrom 3 training places in Negeri Sembilan, Johor, and Malacca, and from a\npond in Pedas, Negeri Sembilan, where some of them had swum in, he said.\nLiow also said that the infection was spread through droplets and people\nare advised to close their mouths when they cough or sneeze.\n\nAt present, there are 89 people who are still quarantined. Another 234\ntrainees returned to their hostels but were not allowed to leave the academy.\n\nMeanwhile Bernama [Malaysian National News Agency] quoted Kelantan Health\nDepartment director Dr Lila Mohamed Meeran as saying that the outbreak of\nmeningitis did not originate from the East Coast state [Kelantan]. She said\n[the patient] was down with fever and brain membrane infection a day before\nhe returned to Kota Baru for a holiday on 1 May 2009.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 13 May 2009\nSource: The Star online [edited]\n<http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/5/13/nation/3887702&sec=nation>\n\n\nThe number of people hospitalised with suspected meningitis in Malacca\nHospital rose to 38 on Tuesday [12 May 2009], from 31 the day before. This\nbrings the number hospitalised nationwide to 39 including one Road\nTransport Department (JPJ) academy trainee hospitalised in Kepala Batas\n[Penang] who is in stable condition.\n\nHealth minister Datuk Seri Liow Tiong Lai said 4 of the new patients who\ndeveloped symptoms were trainees who had been quarantined at the academy\nhostel in Tiang Dua, Malacca. Two more are radiographers, while another is\nthe fiancee of one of the trainees, he said, adding that all of them were\nin the isolation ward while the 2 trainees in intensive care unit were now\nable to walk.\n\n'The source of infection has not been discovered and we are working hard to\nfind the carrier,' he said yesterday [12 May 2009] after the International\nNurses' Day celebration.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not specified in the news reports, the cause of the outbreak of\nmeningitis in Malaysia is presumably _N. meningitidis_. ProMED-mail has\nrecently reported on outbreaks of presumably meningococcal meningitis in\nMyanmar and confirmed meningococcal meningitis in Northeastern India and\nBangladesh, an area that borders western Myanmar.\n\nThe following has been extracted from Mod.ML's comments in ProMED-mail post\narchive number 20090218.0674:\n\nMost cases meningococcal meningitis are sporadic; outbreaks tend to occur\nin semi-closed communities, such military recruit camps, college\ndormitories (as in the trainee hostel of the Malaysian Transport Department\n(JPJ) academy in Malacca above), schools, and day-care centers.\n\nAlthough the incidence of meningococcal disease in general is highest in\nchildren less than 2 years of age\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm> [updated at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5631a3.htm>]), more cases arise\namong the 5 to 19 year old group during outbreaks than during non-outbreaks.\n\nCurrently, serogroups B, C, and Y cause the majority of infections in the\nUSA; serogroup A is rare in the USA, and W135 causes a very small\nproportion of infections; serogroup B is the most common serogroup in\ninfants, while serogroup Y causes the majority of cases in those aged 65\nyears and older\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/meningitis/FINALChanging_Epidemiology_of_Meningococcal_Disease.pdf>).\nSerogroup A was identified as the cause of meningococcal disease in\nNortheastern India (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - India\n(05): (NE, DL) 20090217.0667).\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease is defined as the occurrence of 3 or\nmore confirmed or probable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3\nmonths, resulting in a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per\n100 000 persons, which is about 10 times greater than the normal occurrence\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>).\n\nChemoprophylaxis is given to appropriate contacts whose risk for acquiring\nmeningococcal disease is 500-800 times greater than among the total\npopulation (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). Close\ncontacts of patients are household members, day-care center contacts, and\npersons directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions. Administering\nchemoprophylaxis to persons who are not close contacts of patients usually\nis not recommended. Neither oropharyngeal nor nasopharyngeal cultures for\n_N. meningitidis_ are useful in deciding who should receive chemoprophylaxis.\n\nIn an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the\nmeningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the outbreak as\nsoon as possible after an outbreak has been declared\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>).\n\nHow one case in Penang on the northwestern coast of Malaysia relates to the\nother cases in Malacca on the southwestern coast is not explained.\nConfirmation of the identity of the pathogen involved in the Malaysian\nbacterial meningitis outbreak would be appreciated. DNA fingerprinting of\nthe isolates would help in epidemiologic linkage. - Mod.ML\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map can be used to locate Malacca\n(Melaka) at <http://healthmap.org/r/00b-> and Penang (Pulau Pinang) at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00c0>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "\n\nCurrently, serogroups B, C, and Y cause the majority of infections in the\nUSA; serogroup A is rare in the USA, and W135 causes a very small\nproportion of infections; serogroup B is the most common serogroup in\ninfants, while serogroup Y causes the majority of cases in those aged 65\nyears and older\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/meningitis/FINALChanging_Epidemiology_of_Meningococcal_Disease.pdf>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease is defined as the occurrence of 3 or\nmore confirmed or probable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3\nmonths, resulting in a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per\n100 000 persons, which is about 10 times greater than the normal occurrence\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). ML's comments in ProMED-mail post\narchive number 20090218.0674:\n\nMost cases meningococcal meningitis are sporadic; outbreaks tend to occur\nin semi-closed communities, such military recruit camps, college\ndormitories (as in the trainee hostel of the Malaysian Transport Department\n(JPJ) academy in Malacca above), schools, and day-care centers. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nJack Soo\n<jack.soo@kyip.com>\n\n******\n Two more are radiographers, while another is\nthe fiancee of one of the trainees, he said, adding that all of them were\nin the isolation ward while the 2 trainees in intensive care unit were now\nable to walk. ProMED-mail has\nrecently reported on outbreaks of presumably meningococcal meningitis in\nMyanmar and confirmed meningococcal meningitis in Northeastern India and\nBangladesh, an area that borders western Myanmar. In an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the\nmeningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the outbreak as\nsoon as possible after an outbreak has been declared\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). The Health Ministry has identified the diplococci bacteria [presumably\n_Neisseria meningitidis_] as the cause of the meningitis afflicting\ntrainees of the Road Transport Department (JPJ) Academy in Tiang Dua,\n Liow said\nsamples of the diplococci bacteria had been sent to the microbiology\nlaboratory in Sungai Buloh to ascertain the type as the bacteria had\ndifferent strains. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< This\nbrings the number hospitalised nationwide to 39 including one Road\nTransport Department (JPJ) academy trainee hospitalised in Kepala Batas\n MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - MALAYSIA (MALACCA, PENANG) SUSPECTED, REQUEST\nFOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\n \n\nHealth minister Datuk Seri Liow Tiong Lai said that until 2 pm today [10\nMay 2009], 20 trainees were warded at [Malacca] Hospital, 2 in the\nintensive care unit and 18 at the isolation ward. [Penang] who is in stable condition.\n\nHealth minister Datuk Seri Liow Tiong Lai said 4 of the new patients who\ndeveloped symptoms were trainees who had been quarantined at the academy\nhostel in Tiang Dua, Malacca. \n\n'The source of infection has not been discovered and we are working hard to\nfind the carrier,' he said yesterday [12 May 2009] after the International\nNurses' Day celebration. \n\nLiow said the 93 JPJ Academy trainees quarantined were being closely\nobserved by a 7 member special task force headed by a doctor for immediate\nmeasures to be taken in an emergency. He said all\ntrainees and staff of the JPJ Academy in Tiang Dua were given antibiotics\nto control the spread of the meningitis bacterial infection. \n\nChemoprophylaxis is given to appropriate contacts whose risk for acquiring\nmeningococcal disease is 500-800 times greater than among the total\npopulation (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). He said the trainees quarantined had\nbeen given ciprofloxacin, an antibiotic while those being treated at the\nhospital were given ceftriaxone to recover from the infection. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-05-01 00:00:00", "2009-05-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2009-05-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2009-05-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "DL", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kelantan", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kepala", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Batas", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Pedas", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Negeri Sembilan", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Johor", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Penang", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Malacca", "country": "Malaysia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "177714", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (FL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=177714", "date": "2009-04-24 18:00:55", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA: (FLORIDA)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Tue 21 Apr 2009\nFrom: Fermin Leguen, MD, MPH (chief physician) and Vincent Conte, MD, MPH\n(deputy director surveillance epidemiology), Disease Control and\nImmunization Services, Miami-Dade County Health Department [edited]\n\n\nEarly in 2009, the Miami-Dade County Health Department (MDCHD), Office of\nEpidemiology, Disease Control and Immunization Services (EDCIS)\ninvestigated several sporadic cases of meningococcal disease and noted an\nunusually high number of cases [of infection] with _Neisseria meningitidis_\nof the W135 serogroup. A [pulse field gel electrophoresis] PFGE analysis\nconducted by the Department of Health State Lab on all meningococcal\nisolates of W135 serogroup reported from 2007 to present identified\nmatching PFGE patterns in 9 sporadic cases from Miami-Dade (all reported\nduring the last 6 months), 2 cases from Broward, 1 case from West Palm\nBeach, and 1 case from England (a Miami-Dade visitor). The laboratory\nanalysis also identified 4 other cases of serogroup W135 inefction with\nunrelated PFGE patterns reported in 2007 and 2008 in central and northern\nFlorida.\n\nSummary characteristics of the 13 South Florida cases include:\n- 8 of 13 (61.5 per cent) patients were female;\n- 7 of 13 (53.8 per cent) were white Hispanic, 4 of 13 (30.7 per cent)\nblack non-Hispanic; and 2 (15.4 per cent) white non-Hispanic.\n- age distribution: 1 infant, 3 cases aged 20-30 years old, 3 cases 50-70\nyears old; and 4 were over 70 years old.\n- 4 (30.7 per cent) patients died; 2 were 20-30 years old, and 2 were older\nthan 50 years old.\n- only 2 cases had signs and symptoms of meningitis; all other cases had\npositive blood cultures without prominent signs of meningitis. This\npresentation is similar to a study where patients with serogroup W135 were\nmore likely to have pure bacteremia without meningitis. (Source: BMC\nInfectious Diseases 2006, 6:7 doi: 10.1186/1471-2334-6-7\n<http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2334/6/7>)\n- symptom frequencies for the 13 cases were: fever/chills 54 per cent,\nheadache 54 per cent, photophobia 38 per cent, stiff neck 38 per cent,\nconfusion 38 per cent, drowsiness 31 per cent, nausea 8 per cent, and\nvomiting 8 per cent.\n\nBased on information from case interviews, no further associations were\nestablished among these 13 individuals or the British tourist, who became\nill while visiting Miami.\n\nIn the United States and Florida, the most common _N. meningitidis_\nserogroups are B, C, and Y. Serogroup W135 represents about 3 per cent of\ninvasive isolates nationally and is generally considered to have low\npotential to cause invasive disease or outbreaks. However, in 2000, a large\nmulti-country outbreak of more than 400 cases of serogroup W135 occurred\namong religious pilgrims to Saudi Arabia.\n\nMany serogroup W135 meningococcal disease cases in the United States are\nassociated with recent foreign travel; none of the latest 13 cases reported\namong US residents in South Florida had travel history. [It should be\nnoted, though, that one of the 13 cases was a Miami-Dade visitor from\nEngland]. Only 2 of the 67 meningococcal disease cases reported in Florida\nduring 2007 were serogroup W135.\n\nThis is an ongoing cluster investigation, therefore we request your\nassistance; please send the specimens of suspect meningococcal disease\ncases to the State Laboratory, Miami Branch for confirmation, serogrouping,\nand further PFGE study.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nLarry M Bush, MD\nChief, Division of Infectious Diseases\nJFK Hospital\nAtlantis\nFlorida\n<drlarry561@aol.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 23 Apr 2009\nSource: Miami Herald [edited]\n<http://www.miamiherald.com/news/breaking-news/story/1014181.html>\n\n\nThe outbreak of the W135 form of meningitis that has killed 4 people in\nSouth Florida is a 'unique situation,' an expert at the US Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention (CDC) said on Thursday morning [23 Apr\n2009]. 'We've never had a transmission like this in the United States,'\nsaid Amanda Cohn, a physician who specializes in studying meningitis.\n\nCDC has seen individual cases in the United States of the deadly,\nfast-moving strain, and there have been outbreaks in other parts of the\nworld, including one that hit Muslims on the pilgrimage to Mecca and in the\nAfrican country of Burkina Faso, Cohn said. But the CDC has never seen a\ncase in which 4 people have died and 8 others made ill during a 6-month\nperiod in one area, as has happened in South Florida.\n\nThey're particularly puzzled because there are no obvious connections\nbetween the patients. 'This is very interesting,' said Cohn, an\nAtlanta-based researcher. 'We don't know what's happening.' The strain can\nkill within hours, and anyone experiencing severe headache, fever, nausea,\nvomiting and stiff neck should see a doctor immediately, health officials\nwarned. It's a very scary disease,' when someone gets it, said Cohn, but\n'people don't need to be scared. ... It's not incredibly infectious. You're\nnot going to see hundreds and hundreds of cases.'\n\nW135 is one of the strains covered by the meningitis vaccine, but Cohn said\nshe saw no need for the general population to rush to get a shot. If there\nare certain subgroups that are at high risk and need to be vaccinated, the\nlocal health departments would make that announcement.\n\nMany people may carry one of 13 strains of meningitis within them but not\nget sick. 'We don't understand why some people develop the disease,' Cohn\nsaid. People with colds or the flu might be more susceptible, but the\nconnections are still unclear. 15 or 20 percent of those who get the W135\nstrain will die, Cohn said. 'That's high. This is a very serious disease.'\n\nMiami-Dade health officials revealed the W135 problem at a hastily called\nnews conference Wednesday [22 Apr 2009]. They said the strain could be\ncurable with antibiotics -- but only if patients seek treatment quickly.\n\n[byline: John Dorschner]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is extracted from Mod.ML's comments in ProMED-mail post\narchive number 20090218.0674:\n\nEach year, up to 3000 people in the USA develop meningococcal disease. The\nannual incidence generally ranges from 0.5 to 1.1 cases per 100 000. The\nincidence peaks in late winter and early spring. Most cases are sporadic;\nless than 2 per cent occur in outbreaks\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm> [updated at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5631a3.htm>]. Outbreaks tend to\noccur in semi-closed communities, such military recruit camps, college\ndormitories, schools, and day-care centers. Community-based outbreaks in\ntowns, cities, and counties may also occur among persons who are not close\ncontacts of each other and who do not share a common affiliation.\n\nAlthough the incidence of meningococcal disease in general is highest in\nchildren less than 2 years of age\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm> [updated at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5631a3.htm>, more cases arise\namong the 5 to 19 year old group during epidemics than during non-epidemic\nperiods. Currently, serogroups B, C and Y cause the majority of infections\nin the USA; serogroup A is rare in the USA, and W135 causes a very small\nproportion of infections; serogroup B is the most common serogroup in\ninfants, while serogroup Y causes the majority of cases in those aged 65\nyears and older\n<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/meningitis/FINALChanging_Epidemiology_of_Meningococcal_Disease.pdf>.\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease is defined as the occurrence of 3 or\nmore confirmed or probable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3\nmonths, resulting in a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per\n100 000 persons, which is about 10 times greater than the normal occurrence\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>.\n\nChemoprophylaxis is given to appropriate contacts whose risk for acquiring\nmeningococcal disease is 500-800 times greater than among the total\npopulation <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>. Close\ncontacts of patients are household members, day-care center contacts, and\npersons directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions. Administering\nchemoprophylaxis to persons who are not close contacts of patients usually\nis not recommended. Neither oropharyngeal nor nasopharyngeal cultures for\n_N. meningitidis_ are useful in deciding who should receive chemoprophylaxis.\n\nIn an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the\nmeningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the outbreak as\nsoon as possible after an outbreak has been declared\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>. Mass immunization\ncampaigns are labor-intensive and costly. Meningococcal polysaccharide\nvaccines do not protect very young children, do not protect unvaccinated\npopulation groups, and only provide protection for up to 3 years. As a\nresult, repetitive meningitis outbreak responses can deplete a country's\nscarce health care finances with comparably little impact. A preventive\nstrategy based on conjugate vaccines could have a significantly larger and\nmore enduring impact.\n\nA quadrivalent A, C, Y and W135 conjugate vaccine was licensed in the\nUnited States in January 2005. The meningococcal conjugate vaccines induce\na T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved immune response in\ninfants, providing long-lasting immunity and preventing nasopharyngeal\ncarriage of _N. meningitidis_ and thus reducing bacterial transmission of\nthis microorganism\n<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>. CDC in any\ncase now recommends the meningococcal conjugate vaccination for college\nstudents and any persons aged 11 to 18 years, military recruits,\nmicrobiologists who are routinely exposed to isolates of _N. meningitidis_,\npersons who travel to Mecca during the annual Haj or to countries in which\n_N. meningitidis_ is hyperendemic or epidemic, particularly if contact with\nthe local population will be prolonged, persons who have terminal\ncomplement component deficiencies, and persons who have anatomic or\nfunctional asplenia <http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/559807>\n[registration required],\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm> [updated at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5631a3.htm>].\n\nThe populations for Miami-Dade and Broward counties are about 2.4 and 1.8\nmillion, respectively, and for the city of West Palm Beach about 100 000\n(<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/12/1276600.html>). The state of\nFlorida can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/009*>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "CDC in any\ncase now recommends the meningococcal conjugate vaccination for college\nstudents and any persons aged 11 to 18 years, military recruits,\nmicrobiologists who are routinely exposed to isolates of _N. meningitidis_,\npersons who travel to Mecca during the annual Haj or to countries in which\n_N. meningitidis_ is hyperendemic or epidemic, particularly if contact with\nthe local population will be prolonged, persons who have terminal\ncomplement component deficiencies, and persons who have anatomic or\nfunctional asplenia <http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/559807>\n Summary characteristics of the 13 South Florida cases include:\n- 8 of 13 (61.5 per cent) patients were female;\n- 7 of 13 (53.8 per cent) were white Hispanic, 4 of 13 (30.7 per cent)\nblack non-Hispanic; and 2 (15.4 per cent) white non-Hispanic.\n- age distribution: 1 infant, 3 cases aged 20-30 years old, 3 cases 50-70\nyears old; and 4 were over 70 years old. Infectious Diseases 2006, 6:7 doi: 10.1186/1471-2334-6-7\n<http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2334/6/7>)\n- symptom frequencies for the 13 cases were: fever/chills 54 per cent,\nheadache 54 per cent, photophobia 38 per cent, stiff neck 38 per cent,\nconfusion 38 per cent, drowsiness 31 per cent, nausea 8 per cent, and\nvomiting 8 per cent.\n\n A [pulse field gel electrophoresis] PFGE analysis\nconducted by the Department of Health State Lab on all meningococcal\nisolates of W135 serogroup reported from 2007 to present identified\nmatching PFGE patterns in 9 sporadic cases from Miami-Dade (all reported\nduring the last 6 months), 2 cases from Broward, 1 case from West Palm\nBeach, and 1 case from England (a Miami-Dade visitor). Currently, serogroups B, C and Y cause the majority of infections\nin the USA; serogroup A is rare in the USA, and W135 causes a very small\nproportion of infections; serogroup B is the most common serogroup in\ninfants, while serogroup Y causes the majority of cases in those aged 65\nyears and older\n<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/meningitis/FINALChanging_Epidemiology_of_Meningococcal_Disease.pdf>. The meningococcal conjugate vaccines induce\na T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved immune response in\ninfants, providing long-lasting immunity and preventing nasopharyngeal\ncarriage of _N. meningitidis_ and thus reducing bacterial transmission of\nthis microorganism\n<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n \n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease is defined as the occurrence of 3 or\nmore confirmed or probable cases during a period of less than or equal to 3\nmonths, resulting in a primary disease attack rate of at least 10 cases per\n100 000 persons, which is about 10 times greater than the normal occurrence\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>. Early in 2009, the Miami-Dade County Health Department (MDCHD), Office of\nEpidemiology, Disease Control and Immunization Services (EDCIS)\ninvestigated several sporadic cases of meningococcal disease and noted an\nunusually high number of cases [of infection] with _Neisseria meningitidis_\nof the W135 serogroup. Communicated by:\nLarry M Bush, MD\nChief, Division of Infectious Diseases\nJFK Hospital\n \n\nThis is an ongoing cluster investigation, therefore we request your\nassistance; please send the specimens of suspect meningococcal disease\ncases to the State Laboratory, Miami Branch for confirmation, serogrouping,\nand further PFGE study. \n\nCDC has seen individual cases in the United States of the deadly,\nfast-moving strain, and there have been outbreaks in other parts of the\nworld, including one that hit Muslims on the pilgrimage to Mecca and in the\nAfrican country of Burkina Faso, Cohn said. Most cases are sporadic;\nless than 2 per cent occur in outbreaks\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm> [updated at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5631a3.htm>]. In an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the\nmeningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the outbreak as\nsoon as possible after an outbreak has been declared\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>. The outbreak of the W135 form of meningitis that has killed 4 people in\nSouth Florida is a 'unique situation,' an expert at the US Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention (CDC) said on Thursday morning [23 Apr\n2009]. ' The laboratory\nanalysis also identified 4 other cases of serogroup W135 inefction with\nunrelated PFGE patterns reported in 2007 and 2008 in central and northern\nFlorida. \n\n[byline: John Dorschner]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< [updated at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5631a3.htm>, more cases arise\namong the 5 to 19 year old group during epidemics than during non-epidemic\nperiods. The strain can\nkill within hours, and anyone experiencing severe headache, fever, nausea,\nvomiting and stiff neck should see a doctor immediately, health officials\nwarned. Many serogroup W135 meningococcal disease cases in the United States are\nassociated with recent foreign travel; none of the latest 13 cases reported\namong US residents in South Florida had travel history. \n- 4 (30.7 per cent) patients died; 2 were 20-30 years old, and 2 were older\nthan 50 years old. \n- only 2 cases had signs and symptoms of meningitis; all other cases had\npositive blood cultures without prominent signs of meningitis. \n\nChemoprophylaxis is given to appropriate contacts whose risk for acquiring\nmeningococcal disease is 500-800 times greater than among the total\npopulation <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>. Y. Serogroup W135 represents about 3 per cent of\ninvasive isolates nationally and is generally considered to have low\npotential to cause invasive disease or outbreaks. Although the incidence of meningococcal disease in general is highest in\nchildren less than 2 years of age\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm> However, in 2000, a large\nmulti-country outbreak of more than 400 cases of serogroup W135 occurred\namong religious pilgrims to Saudi Arabia. A monk in Pakokku, in central Burma [Myanmar], told\nDVB that local residents are growing increasingly nervous following\nthe man's death. 'People are now taking these pills which they\nthought could prevent the meningitis,' said the monk. 'They said you\ncan't have the condition after taking the medicine once and have been\ngiving each other advice to take it.'\n\nA doctor in central Burma [Myanmar] said meningitis was a common\nmedical condition in the region during the hot summer season when the\ndust level in the air becomes dense. He said the condition is caused\nby infection in respiratory system, which can lead to inflammation of\nthe protective membranes covering the brain, possibly leading to\ndeath. 'The best thing to [do] when it starts showing symptoms is to\nrush to a nearest hospital,' said the doctor. 'At times like this,\npeople should avoid hanging around in crowded places and also should\ntake care of their personal hygiene.'\n\n[Byline: Nan Kham Kaew]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not specified in the news report, the cause of the outbreak\nof meningitis in central Myanmar is presumably _N. meningitidis_.\nProMED-mail has recently reported on an outbreak of meningococcal\nmeningitis in Northeastern India and Bangladesh, an area that borders\nwestern Myanmar. Serogroup A has been identified as the cause of\nmeningococcal disease in Northeastern India (see ProMED-mail post\nMeningitis, meningococcal - India (05): (NE, DL) 20090217.0667).\nPerhaps the outbreak in Myanmar is an extension of the outbreak of\nmeningococcal disease in India and Bangladesh.\n\nMagwe (or Magway) Division, the largest of Myanmar's 7 divisions, is\nlocated in central Myanmar. The capital is the city of Magwe. Pokokku\nis one of the other major towns.\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magway_Division>).\nFor a map of Myanmar, see\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/burma_pol_96.jpg>.\nFor the interactive HealthMap/ProMED map of Myanmar, with links to\nother recent ProMED-mail and PRO/MBDS postings in Myanmar and\nsurrounding areas, see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=21.2,96.5,5>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 6 Mar 2009\n \nProMED-mail has recently reported on an outbreak of meningococcal\nmeningitis in Northeastern India and Bangladesh, an area that borders\nwestern Myanmar. He said the condition is caused\nby infection in respiratory system, which can lead to inflammation of\nthe protective membranes covering the brain, possibly leading to\ndeath. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "DL", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Magwe", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "pokokku", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "158682", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=158682", "date": "2009-02-20 17:00:46", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - UGANDA (04)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 19 Feb 2009\nSource: The New Vision [edited]\n<http://www.newvision.co.ug/PA/8/16/672024>\n\n\nThe health ministry has contained the meningitis outbreak in the country.\n'We are on top of the situation. No new cases have been reported since 28\nJan [2009],' said Dr Sam Zaramba, the director general of health services.\nHe said there was increased awareness about the disease in the affected\nareas, which saw many people receive treatment and vaccination.\n\nThe outbreak hit the country in December [2008]. Uganda is one of the\ncountries in the African meningitis belt. The epidemic that started in\nHoima and Arua districts also spread to Masindi, Adjumani and Moyo. By 3\nFeb 2009, 336 people had been affected, while 42 had died.\n\nLast month [January 2009], the ministry delivered drugs and financial\nsupport to the affected areas. Dr Nathan Kenya Mugisha, the director for\nclinical services, said the ministry and the World Health Organization had\nvaccinated people aged between 2 and 30 years in the affected districts.\n'This age group is more vulnerable to meningitis and our assessment teams\ncontinue doing their work. We have also advised people to avoid congestion\nespecially in the affected districts,' Mugisha said. 'We allowed the\nschools in the affected districts to open for the new academic year because\nour assessment teams have reported no new cases. This is also one of the\nsigns that we are managing the epidemic,' he added.\n\nMeningitis is an inflammation of the meninges, the lining surrounding the\nbrain and spinal cord. The disease is caused by bacteria and is transmitted\nthrough contact with the respiratory or throat secretions from an infected\nperson.\n\nLast year [2008], the country also suffered cholera, botulism, Ebola,\nMarburg, typhoid, measles, and hepatitis E outbreaks. While presenting the\nstatus report on major disease outbreaks to Parliament last week [9-13 Feb\n2009], health state minister Richard Nduhura said all the diseases had been\ncontrolled, save for hepatitis E.\n\n[byline: Anthony Bugembe]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is heartening to hear that the meningococcal meningitis epidemic in\nUganda has waned. Controlling meningitis epidemics consists of early\ndetection of clinical cases, prompt case management, limiting social\ngatherings -- for example, by closing schools in an attempt to diminish\ntransmission of _Neisseria meningitidis_, and meningococcal vaccination of\nthe people living in the epidemic area.\n\nMeningococcal meningitis epidemics in the 'African meningitis belt' when\nstudied in Mali usually begin soon after the onset of dusty dry weather,\ndiminish about 8 weeks later and end on average about another 8 weeks later\n(<http://medicine.plosjournals.org/perlserv/?request=get-document&doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0020006>).\nSimilar meningococcal meningitis epidemic curves were found in 2006 in\nGulu, Uganda\n(<http://www.who.int/hac/crises/uga/sitreps/Gulu%20Meningitis%20Report_7th%20March.pdf>),\nand now in the current Ugandan epidemic, which the above news report says\nbegan in December 2008.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the affected districts can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf> and a map of\nthe African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=443351&v=1.417,33.083,6>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "While presenting the\nstatus report on major disease outbreaks to Parliament last week [9-13 Feb\n2009], health state minister Richard Nduhura said all the diseases had been\ncontrolled, save for hepatitis E.\n\n[byline: Anthony Bugembe]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 19 Feb 2009\n Controlling meningitis epidemics consists of early\ndetection of clinical cases, prompt case management, limiting social\ngatherings -- for example, by closing schools in an attempt to diminish\ntransmission of _Neisseria meningitidis_, and meningococcal vaccination of\nthe people living in the epidemic area. Similar meningococcal meningitis epidemic curves were found in 2006 in\nGulu, Uganda\n(<http://www.who.int/hac/crises/uga/sitreps/Gulu%20Meningitis%20Report_7th%20March.pdf>),\nand now in the current Ugandan epidemic, which the above news report says\nbegan in December 2008. \n\nMeningococcal meningitis epidemics in the 'African meningitis belt' when\nstudied in Mali usually begin soon after the onset of dusty dry weather,\ndiminish about 8 weeks later and end on average about another 8 weeks later\n(<http://medicine.plosjournals.org/perlserv/?request=get-document&doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0020006>). \n\nA map of Uganda showing the affected districts can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf> and a map of\nthe African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. Dr Nathan Kenya Mugisha, the director for\nclinical services, said the ministry and the World Health Organization had\nvaccinated people aged between 2 and 30 years in the affected districts. 'We allowed the\nschools in the affected districts to open for the new academic year because\nour assessment teams have reported no new cases. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - UGANDA (04)\n***************************************\n The disease is caused by bacteria and is transmitted\nthrough contact with the respiratory or throat secretions from an infected\nperson.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism", "cholera", "hepatitis e", "measles"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-02-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-12-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-01-26 00:00:00", "2009-02-19 00:00:00", "2021-09-13 00:00:00", "2008-12-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "162764", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=162764", "date": "2009-03-05 23:00:50", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (02): WHO\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 4 March 2009\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) Disease\nOutbreak News [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_04/en/index.html>\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health of the Federal Republic of Nigeria has\nreported 5323 suspected cases of meningococcal disease, including 333\ndeaths (case-fatality rate: 6.3 percent) from 1 Jan to 22 Feb 2009.\nSuspected cases have been reported from 22 of 37 states. So far 89\nLocal Government Areas (LGA) across 12 states have crossed the alert\nor the epidemic threshold. In the last week alone, 1817 suspected\ncases including 105 deaths (case-fatality rate: 5.8 percent) have\nbeen reported, with 28 LGAs crossing the epidemic threshold, and 29\nthe alert threshold.\n\nCerebrospinal fluid specimens collected from Gombe, Jigawa, Kano, and\nKatsina states have tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup A by latex test and/or culture. The International\nCoordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis\nControl has approved the release of 1 010 000 doses of polysaccharide\nvaccine for mass vaccination campaigns in affected LGAs of Jigawa and\nKatsina states. Immunization campaigns will be implemented by Federal\nand National Ministry of Health with the support of WHO and partners,\nincluding the European Commission Humanitarian Aid Department (ECHO),\nMedecins sans Frontieres, and UNICEF.\n\nGiven the large population at risk, the early start of epidemics, and\ncurrent moderate global vaccine levels, a sound vaccination strategy\nis of particular importance. WHO is supporting the Federal and\nNational Ministry of Health in the assessment of vaccine needs. WHO\nis also providing technical and material support to the Ministry of\nHealth to strengthen epidemiological and laboratory surveillance,\nincluding provision of laboratory confirmation supplies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The number of cases of suspected meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria\nhas approximately quadrupled and the number of deaths tripled since\nthe last ProMED-mail post (Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO\n20090220.0709). The plan is to use meningococcal polysaccharide\nvaccine in the population at risk, but it is unclear if any vaccine\nhas actually been given out as yet.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 4 March 2009\n The International\nCoordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis\nControl has approved the release of 1 010 000 doses of polysaccharide\nvaccine for mass vaccination campaigns in affected LGAs of Jigawa and\nKatsina states. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The number of cases of suspected meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria\nhas approximately quadrupled and the number of deaths tripled since\nthe last ProMED-mail post (Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: In the last week alone, 1817 suspected\ncases including 105 deaths (case-fatality rate: 5.8 percent) have\nbeen reported, with 28 LGAs crossing the epidemic threshold, and 29\nthe alert threshold. WHO\nis also providing technical and material support to the Ministry of\nHealth to strengthen epidemiological and laboratory surveillance,\nincluding provision of laboratory confirmation supplies. Immunization campaigns will be implemented by Federal\nand National Ministry of Health with the support of WHO and partners,\nincluding the European Commission Humanitarian Aid Department (ECHO),\nMedecins sans Frontieres, and UNICEF. The Ministry of Health of the Federal Republic of Nigeria has\nreported 5323 suspected cases of meningococcal disease, including 333\ndeaths (case-fatality rate: 6.3 percent) from 1 Jan to 22 Feb 2009.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-02-26 00:00:00", "5323-03-26 00:00:00", "1817-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jigawa", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "158654", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=158654", "date": "2009-02-20 16:00:47", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA: WHO\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 19 Feb 2009\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) disease outbreak\nnews [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_02_19/en/index.html>\n\n\nAs of 8 Feb 2009, the Ministry of Health of the Federal Republic of Nigeria\nhas reported 1364 suspected cases of meningococcal disease including 108\ndeaths (case fatality rate: 7.9 per cent) in 19 out of 35 states and Abuja.\nSo far 30 local government areas (LGA) in 8 states have crossed the alert\nor the epidemic threshold. In the last week, 11 LGAs crossed the epidemic\nthreshold, and 600 suspected cases including 40 deaths were reported across\nthe country.\n\nCerebrospinal fluid specimens collected from Jigawa state have tested\npositive for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A by latex test. The\nInternational Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic\nMeningitis Control has approved the release of 268 750 doses of\npolysaccharide vaccine for a mass vaccination campaign in two affected LGAs\nin Jigawa state.\n\nWHO is supporting the Federal and National Ministry of Health in the\nsubmission of additional requests to the ICG to secure vaccine for the\nremaining affected areas. WHO is supporting the Ministry of Health to\nstrengthen epidemiological and laboratory surveillance and data management.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Meningococcal meningitis occurs sporadically or as epidemics in\nsub-Saharan Africa, which is known as the 'Meningitis Belt,' an area that\nstretches from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and Eritrea in the east and\nthat includes Nigeria (<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>).\n\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in this region of\nAfrica each year during the dry season, between December and June, and\nevery 6-12 years a large outbreak occurs\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>). Serogroup A\npredominates, but recently, serogroups X and W135 have also been associated\nwith meningococcal disease in sub-Saharan Africa.\n\nIn countries where meningococcal disease is highly endemic, there is a need\nto distinguish an emerging epidemic of meningitis from a simple seasonal\nrise in incidence, in order to implement control measures. Epidemic\nthresholds are used to confirm the emergence of an epidemic in order to\nstep up control measures, that is, mass vaccination and appropriate case\nmanagement. For definitions of epidemic thresholds, see\n<http://www.who.int/disasters/repo/6618.doc>.\n\nMass immunization campaigns are labor-intensive and costly. The news report\nabove does not specify the type of meningococcal vaccine that is being\nused, but meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines do not protect very young\nchildren, do not protect unvaccinated population groups, and only provide\nprotection for up to 3 years. As a result, repetitive meningitis outbreak\nresponses can deplete a country's scarce health care finances with\ncomparably little impact.\n\nIn contrast, the meningococcal conjugate vaccines induce a T-cell-dependent\nresponse, resulting in an improved immune response in infants, provide\nlong-lasting immunity, and prevent nasopharyngeal carriage of _N.\nmeningitidis_, thus reducing bacterial transmission of this microorganism\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>). A\npreventive strategy based on conjugate vaccines could have a significantly\nlarger and more enduring impact on attempts to control the yearly\nrecurrences of this disease that causes considerable morbidity and\nmortality, especially among children\n(<http://www.jidc.org/files/vol02_no05/PDF/jidc-02-335.pdf>).\n\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>, and the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Meningococcal meningitis occurs sporadically or as epidemics in\nsub-Saharan Africa, which is known as the 'Meningitis Belt,' an area that\nstretches from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and Eritrea in the east and\nthat includes Nigeria (<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). A\npreventive strategy based on conjugate vaccines could have a significantly\nlarger and more enduring impact on attempts to control the yearly\nrecurrences of this disease that causes considerable morbidity and\nmortality, especially among children\n(<http://www.jidc.org/files/vol02_no05/PDF/jidc-02-335.pdf>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 19 Feb 2009\n \n\nIn contrast, the meningococcal conjugate vaccines induce a T-cell-dependent\nresponse, resulting in an improved immune response in infants, provide\nlong-lasting immunity, and prevent nasopharyngeal carriage of _N.\nmeningitidis_, thus reducing bacterial transmission of this microorganism\n(<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>). The news report\nabove does not specify the type of meningococcal vaccine that is being\nused, but meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines do not protect very young\nchildren, do not protect unvaccinated population groups, and only provide\nprotection for up to 3 years. The\nInternational Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic\nMeningitis Control has approved the release of 268 750 doses of\npolysaccharide vaccine for a mass vaccination campaign in two affected LGAs\nin Jigawa state. \n\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in this region of\nAfrica each year during the dry season, between December and June, and\nevery 6-12 years a large outbreak occurs\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>). Epidemic\nthresholds are used to confirm the emergence of an epidemic in order to\nstep up control measures, that is, mass vaccination and appropriate case\nmanagement.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-02-08 00:00:00", "2009-02-19 00:00:00", "1364-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eritrea", "country": "Eritrea"}, {"location": "Abuja", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Jigawa", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "157697", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - India (05): (NE, DL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=157697", "date": "2009-02-17 23:01:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - INDIA (05): (NORTH EASTERN, DELHI)\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 13 Feb 2009\nFrom: Sunil Gupta [edited]\n<sunil_guptadoc@yahoo.co.uk>\n\n\nThis is regarding information on meningococcal disease in India and\nis to inform you that in the cases of meningococcal disease that are\nbeing reported in Delhi and Meghalaya states of the country, the\ncausative microorganism in both the places has been identified as\nGroup A meningococcus.\n\n--\nDr Sunil Gupta\nJoint Director\nNational Institute of Communicable Diseases, Delhi\n<sunil_guptadoc@yahoo.co.uk>\n\n[_Neisseria meningitidis_ is divided into 13 serogroups, defined by\nspecific capsular polysaccharides, of which 4 are known to cause\nepidemics: A, B, C and W135. Group A strains have caused epidemics of\nmeningococcal meningitis throughout the world. Serogroups A and C\npredominate throughout Asia and Africa and serogroups B and C are\nresponsible for the majority of cases in Europe and the Americas.\nRecently, serogroup W135 has been associated with meningococcal\ndisease amongst Hajj pilgrims and in sub-Saharan Africa. In India\nserogroup A has been associated with all outbreaks of meningococcal\ndisease, although serogroup B and C have been detected in a few sporadic cases.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India that shows the\nstates of Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram can be found at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=1263207&g=1254169&g=1262963&&v=23,93,5>.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "Dr Sunil Gupta\nJoint Director\nNational Institute of Communicable Diseases, Delhi\n<sunil_guptadoc@yahoo.co.uk>\n\n[_Neisseria meningitidis_ is divided into 13 serogroups, defined by\nspecific capsular polysaccharides, of which 4 are known to cause\nepidemics: A, B, C and W135. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 13 Feb 2009\n This is regarding information on meningococcal disease in India and\nis to inform you that in the cases of meningococcal disease that are\nbeing reported in Delhi and Meghalaya states of the country, the\ncausative microorganism in both the places has been identified as\nGroup A meningococcus.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Delhi", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mizoram", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "158038", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (PA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=158038", "date": "2009-02-18 18:00:47", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA: (PENNSYLVANIA)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 17 Feb 2009\nSource: MSNBC [edited]\n<http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29226512/>\n\n\nThe Philadelphia Health Department is investigating a 4th possible\ncase of meningococcal meningitis at the University of Pennsylvania,\nofficials said Monday [16 Feb 2009]. The university would not comment\non the investigation but did release a statement saying the 3\nstudents who were hospitalized with the disease last week are showing\nimprovement.\n\nTwo additional students who are from the same social circle were\nhospitalized over the weekend with flu-like symptoms. Their\nconditions are also improving, officials said. Doctors have been\nclosely monitoring their conditions to ensure they did not in fact\ncontract meningitis.\n\nPenn officials believe the disease has been spread through the\nuniversity's Greek [fraternity/sorority] system. As a precaution, all\non and off-campus parties were shut down this past weekend.\n\nMeningitis is spread through close, prolonged contact like sharing\ntoothbrushes or utensils, kissing, or sexual contact. University\nofficials say it is not uncommon for more than one case to pop up on\ncampuses. Early symptoms of infection include fever, severe headache,\nstiff neck, nausea, vomiting, rash, lethargy and sensitivity to bright light.\n\nMore than 2100 students have received preventive antibiotics since\nthe 1st report of a meningitis outbreak was released.\n\n[Byline: Vince Lattanzio]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Each year, up to 3000 people in the USA develop meningococcal\ndisease. The annual incidence generally ranges from 0.5 to 1.1 cases\nper 100 000. The incidence peaks in late winter and early spring.\nMost cases are sporadic; less than 2 percent occur in outbreaks\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm>.\nOutbreaks tend to occur in semi-closed communities, such military\nrecruit camps, college dormitories, schools, and day-care centers.\nCommunity-based outbreaks in towns, cities, and counties may also\noccur among persons who are not close contacts of each other and who\ndo not share a common affiliation.\n\nAlthough the incidence of meningococcal disease in general is highest\nin children less than 2 years of age\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm>,\nmore cases arise among the 5 to 19-year-old group during epidemics\nthan during non-epidemic periods. Currently, serogroups B, C and Y\ncause the majority of infections in the USA; serogroup A is rare in\nthe USA, and W-135 causes a very small proportion of infections;\nserogroup B is the most common serogroup in infants, while serogroup\nY causes the majority of cases in those aged 65 years and older\n<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/meningitis/FINALChanging_Epidemiology_of_Meningococcal_Disease.pdf>.\n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease is defined as the occurrence of\n3 or more confirmed or probable cases during a period of less than or\nequal to 3 months, resulting in a primary disease attack rate of at\nleast 10 cases per 100 000 persons, which is approximately 10-fold\ngreater than the normal occurrence\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>.\n\nChemoprophylaxis is given to appropriate contacts whose risk for\nacquiring meningococcal disease is 500-800 times greater than among\nthe total population\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>.\nClose contacts of patients are household members, day care center\ncontacts, and persons directly exposed to the patient's oral\nsecretions. Administering chemoprophylaxis to persons who are not\nclose contacts of patients usually is not recommended. Neither\noropharyngeal nor nasopharyngeal cultures for _N. meningitidis_ are\nuseful in deciding who should receive chemoprophylaxis.\n\nIn an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the\nmeningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the\noutbreak as soon as possible after an outbreak has been declared\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>.\nMass immunization campaigns are labor-intensive and costly.\nMeningococcal polysaccharide vaccines do not protect very young\nchildren, do not protect unvaccinated population groups, and only\nprovide protection for up to 3 years. As a result, repetitive\nmeningitis outbreak responses can deplete a country's scarce health\ncare finances with comparably little impact. A preventive strategy\nbased on conjugate vaccines could have a significantly larger and\nmore enduring impact.\n\nA quadrivalent A, C, Y and W-135 conjugate vaccine was licensed in\nthe United States in January 2005. The meningococcal conjugate\nvaccines induce a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved\nimmune response in infants, providing long-lasting immunity and\npreventing nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ and thus\nreducing bacterial transmission of this microorganism\n<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>.\nThe CDC in any case now recommends the meningococcal conjugate\nvaccination for college students and any persons aged 11 to 18 years,\nmilitary recruits, microbiologists who are routinely exposed to\nisolates of _N. meningitidis_, persons who travel to Mecca during the\nannual Hajj or to countries in which _N. meningitidis_ is\nhyperendemic or epidemic, particularly if contact with the local\npopulation will be prolonged, persons who have terminal complement\ncomponent deficiencies, and persons who have anatomic or functional asplenia\n<http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/559807>,\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm>.\n\nDr. Caroline Johnson, Director of the Division of Disease Control for\nthe Philadelphia Department of Public Health reports: That the 3\nculture-confirmed cases were caused by meningococcus serogroup B, for\nwhich there is no effective vaccine; that the 3 isolates were\nciprofloxacin-susceptible (ciprofloxacin-resistant meningococcal\nisolates have been reported in the past, see ProMED-mail Meningitis,\nmeningococcal, drug resistant - USA (MN, ND) 20080215.0601); and that\nthe population at risk is the student population of about 3000\ninvolved in the campus fraternity/sorority system. The attack rate of\n3 confirmed cases and one case that is probable in 3000 is over the\noutbreak threshold of 10 per 100 000. Dr. Johnson also reports that\nthe fraternity/sorority campus population was given preventive\nciprofloxacin and that 99 percent of University of Pennsylvania\nstudents were vaccinated against meningococcal disease prior to\nadmission, but serogroup B disease, unfortunately, is not vaccine-preventable.\n\nPhiladelphia, Pennsylvania can be found on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the USA at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "The CDC in any case now recommends the meningococcal conjugate\nvaccination for college students and any persons aged 11 to 18 years,\nmilitary recruits, microbiologists who are routinely exposed to\nisolates of _N. meningitidis_, persons who travel to Mecca during the\nannual Hajj or to countries in which _N. meningitidis_ is\nhyperendemic or epidemic, particularly if contact with the local\npopulation will be prolonged, persons who have terminal complement\ncomponent deficiencies, and persons who have anatomic or functional asplenia\n<http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/559807>,\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm>. the Philadelphia Department of Public Health reports: That the 3\nculture-confirmed cases were caused by meningococcus serogroup B, for\nwhich there is no effective vaccine; that the 3 isolates were\nciprofloxacin-susceptible (ciprofloxacin-resistant meningococcal\nisolates have been reported in the past, see ProMED-mail Meningitis,\nmeningococcal, drug resistant - USA (MN, ND) 20080215.0601); and that\nthe population at risk is the student population of about 3000\ninvolved in the campus fraternity/sorority system. \n\nAn outbreak of meningococcal disease is defined as the occurrence of\n3 or more confirmed or probable cases during a period of less than or\nequal to 3 months, resulting in a primary disease attack rate of at\nleast 10 cases per 100 000 persons, which is approximately 10-fold\ngreater than the normal occurrence\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>. Currently, serogroups B, C and Y\ncause the majority of infections in the USA; serogroup A is rare in\nthe USA, and W-135 causes a very small proportion of infections;\nserogroup B is the most common serogroup in infants, while serogroup\nY causes the majority of cases in those aged 65 years and older\n<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/meningitis/FINALChanging_Epidemiology_of_Meningococcal_Disease.pdf>. The meningococcal conjugate\nvaccines induce a T-cell-dependent response, resulting in an improved\nimmune response in infants, providing long-lasting immunity and\npreventing nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ and thus\nreducing bacterial transmission of this microorganism\n<http://www.nfid.org/pdf/publications/meningococcalepid.pdf>. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 17 Feb 2009\n Dr. Johnson also reports that\nthe fraternity/sorority campus population was given preventive\nciprofloxacin and that 99 percent of University of Pennsylvania\nstudents were vaccinated against meningococcal disease prior to\nadmission, but serogroup B disease, unfortunately, is not vaccine-preventable. Although the incidence of meningococcal disease in general is highest\nin children less than 2 years of age\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5407a1.htm>,\nmore cases arise among the 5 to 19-year-old group during epidemics\nthan during non-epidemic periods. \n\nChemoprophylaxis is given to appropriate contacts whose risk for\nacquiring meningococcal disease is 500-800 times greater than among\nthe total population\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>. In an outbreak, the population at risk should be vaccinated with the\nmeningococcal vaccine appropriate for the serogroup causing the\noutbreak as soon as possible after an outbreak has been declared\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>. The university would not comment\non the investigation but did release a statement saying the 3\nstudents who were hospitalized with the disease last week are showing\nimprovement. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Each year, up to 3000 people in the USA develop meningococcal\ndisease. The attack rate of\n3 confirmed cases and one case that is probable in 3000 is over the\noutbreak threshold of 10 per 100 000. Cases come\nform the subdistrict of Ouelessebougou comprising\n5 health facilities. However, the sub-district comprising 4 HF\ncatchment areas crossed the epidemic threshold. 9\nNmA were isolated out of 14 CSF.
