Togo / 413 / 63 / 15.3 / 1 / 0 / 01-50 / 100.0 / 96.9\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2051-03-26 00:00:00", "2052-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-01-22 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mali", "country": "Mali"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "157324", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - India (03): (NE), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=157324", "date": "2009-02-16 19:00:46", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - INDIA (03): (NORTH EASTERN), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 14 Feb 2009\nSource: Bengal News [edited]\n<http://bengalnewz.blogspot.com/2009/02/news-of-moment_14.html>\n\n\nHealth authorities have put Dhalai district in Tripura on high alert\nafter nearly a dozen people died mysteriously in the last fortnight.\nThe state health department has sent a medical team to the affected areas.\n\nThe medical officers have reported that the disease was marked by a\nsudden onset of fever. 'When we went for field visit, we found that\npeople died within 10 to 24 hours after experiencing high fever and\nsome red spots on their bodies,' said Paul N Darlong, a medical\nofficer. The epidemic is affecting the people living in impoverished\ntribal hamlets with scant health facilities. At least 70 more people\nare suffering from a similar disease in Longhthorai Valley, an\ninaccessible area dominated by tribal people, which is some 90 km\naway from the state capital Agartala.\n\nThe federal health department has reported that at least 165 people\nhave died of meningocococcal meningitis, a contagious disease, in 3\nof India's northeastern states -- Meghalaya, Tripura and Mizoram --\nin the past one month.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[ProMED-mail has heard unofficially that the cause of the meningitis\nepidemic in the northeastern Indian states of Tripura, Mizoram and\nMeghalaya, as well as Delhi, is said to be serogroup A _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_.\n\nHowever, the cause of the outbreak in Tripura of a rapidly fatal\nillness with fever and 'red spots' (i.e., petechial rash) that is\nmentioned in the news report above could be due to either certain\nviral infections, rickettsial infections, or bloodstream infection\nwith a variety of bacteria, for example, commonly _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_. ProMED requests information about any laboratory tests\ndone in these cases in Tripura and further information about the\noutbreak as it becomes available.\n\nPatients with acute meningococcal infection can present clinically\nwith meningitis, meningitis with meningococcemia, or meningococcemia\nwithout obvious meningitis. Up to 95 percent of patients with\nmeningococcal disease have meningococcemia and/or meningitis. The\ncase-fatality rate is up to 10 percent for meningococcal meningitis\nand up to 20 percent for meningococcemia despite therapy with\nantimicrobial agents\n(<http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/221473-overview>).\n\nFulminant meningococcemia with bleeding into the skin (purpura\nfulminans) and elsewhere, low blood pressure, and multi-organ failure\noccurs in up to 15 percent of individuals with meningococcal disease\n(<http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/221321-overview>)\nand has a mortality rate that can be as high as 70 percent in\ndeveloping countries.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India that shows the\nstates of Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram can be found at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=22.9,79.6,5>.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nFulminant meningococcemia with bleeding into the skin (purpura\nfulminans) and elsewhere, low blood pressure, and multi-organ failure\noccurs in up to 15 percent of individuals with meningococcal disease\n(<http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/221321-overview>)\nand has a mortality rate that can be as high as 70 percent in\ndeveloping countries. However, the cause of the outbreak in Tripura of a rapidly fatal\nillness with fever and 'red spots' (i.e., petechial rash) that is\nmentioned in the news report above could be due to either certain\nviral infections, rickettsial infections, or bloodstream infection\nwith a variety of bacteria, for example, commonly _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 14 Feb 2009\n The\ncase-fatality rate is up to 10 percent for meningococcal meningitis\nand up to 20 percent for meningococcemia despite therapy with\nantimicrobial agents\n(<http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/221473-overview>). \n\nThe federal health department has reported that at least 165 people\nhave died of meningocococcal meningitis, a contagious disease, in 3\nof India's northeastern states -- Meghalaya, Tripura and Mizoram --\nin the past one month. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[ProMED-mail has heard unofficially that the cause of the meningitis\nepidemic in the northeastern Indian states of Tripura, Mizoram and\nMeghalaya, as well as Delhi, is said to be serogroup When we went for field visit, we found that\npeople died within 10 to 24 hours after experiencing high fever and\nsome red spots on their bodies,' said Paul N Darlong, a medical\nofficer.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dhalai", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tripura", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "India"}, {"location": "tripura", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mizoram", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Longhthorai Valley", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "157586", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - India (04): (NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=157586", "date": "2009-02-17 16:00:45", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - INDIA (04): (NORTH EASTERN)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 16 Feb 2009\nSource: Sify News [edited]\n<http://sify.com/news/fullstory.php?id=14857020>\n\n\nAt least 230 people have died of meningitis in the north eastern\nstates of Tripura, Meghalaya, and Mizoram, officials said on Monday\n[16 Feb 2009]. The situation is alarming in Meghalaya and Tripura,\nthey said. 'We have asked the National Institute of Communicable\nDiseases (NICD) in New Delhi to send necessary vaccine and drugs to\ncontrol the disease that has assumed an epidemic proportion in the\nLongtharai Valley tribal areas of Dhalai district,' said Tripura\nhealth service director Satya Ranjan Debbarma.\n\nThe NICD last week asked the 3 north eastern states to keep a close\nsurveillance in remote locations, especially where the outbreak of\nmeningococcal meningitis was reported. 'Over 230 people including\nchildren and women died in the disease in Meghalaya (165 deaths),\nTripura (55 deaths), and Mizoram (10 deaths) over the past one\nmonth,' a senior health official told reporters [in Agartala,\nTripura]. Over 2500 people, including children and women, were taken\nill in the 3 states.\n\n'The 3 north eastern states have borders with the Chittagong Hill\nTracts (CHT) of south east Bangladesh where meningococcal meningitis\nis spreading in an epidemic form,' said an official of the NICD.\n\nThe Tripura government has taken a slew of measures to control the\ndisease by setting up makeshift health centres in the affected\nLongtharai Valley, 135 km [84 mi] north of the capital Agartala.\n'Several medical teams [are] working in the affected areas\nround-the-clock and preventive medicines were being given to 140 000\npeople in the tribal dominated areas,' said RK Dhar, director of the\nfamily welfare and preventive medicine.\n\nA 2-member team of NICD led by joint director Jagdir Singh visited\nthe affected East Khasi Hills and Garo Hills areas of Meghalaya and\nhelped doctors in the region deal with the disease. 'We have enough\nanti-meningococcal meningitis vaccines and a number of medical teams\nare working round-the-clock to deal with the situation,' said\nMeghalaya health service director A Kynjing. 'Like the other north\neastern states, we have launched a massive public awareness campaign\non the need for cleanliness as it is an airborne disease,' said YP\nSingh, principal secretary of the Tripura government in-charge of\nhealth department.\n\nAfter visiting the affected areas, RK Dhar, an expert on communicable\ndiseases, said: 'Meningococcal meningitis is a communicable disease\nthat is spread through droplets of respiratory or throat secretions.\nThe most common symptoms are stiff neck, high fever, headache, and\nvomiting. Even when the disease is diagnosed early and adequate\ntherapy instituted, 5 to 10 percent of the patients die typically\nwithin 24 to 48 hours of onset of symptoms,' he said. Tripura Health\nMinister Tapan Chakraborty, who is also camping in the affected\ntribal areas for the past few days, held meetings with the village\nheads of 40 affected villages and asked them to help health officials\nand paramedics.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An outbreak of a rapidly fatal illness in remote, impoverished\ntribal areas of the Indian state of Tripura was characterized as\nmysterious in a news release reported in the previous ProMED-mail\npost Meningitis, meningococcal - India (03): (NE), RFI 20090216.0657.\nFrom the news report above, it is apparent that this outbreak is now\nthought to be part of the ongoing epidemic of meningococcal disease\nin north eastern Indian states of Tripura, Mizoram, and Meghalaya\nthat has spread to neighboring Chittagong Hill Tracts of Bangladesh.\nProMED-mail has heard unofficially that the cause of the meningitis\nepidemic in the north eastern Indian states of Tripura, Mizoram, and\nMeghalaya, as well as Delhi, is said to be serogroup A _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India that shows the\nstates of Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram can be found at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=1263207&g=1254169&g=1262963&&v=23,93,5>.\nA map of Bangladesh showing the location of the Chittagong Hill\nTracts that borders the Indian state of Mizoram can be found at\n<http://www.traveljournals.net/explore/bangladesh/map/m3773498/chittagong_hill_tract.html>.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 16 Feb 2009\n Tripura Health\nMinister Tapan Chakraborty, who is also camping in the affected\ntribal areas for the past few days, held meetings with the village\nheads of 40 affected villages and asked them to help health officials\nand paramedics. India (02): (NE), Bangladesh spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=155819", "date": "2009-02-11 17:00:49", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - INDIA (02): (NORTH EASTERN), BANGLADESH SPREAD\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 10 Feb 2009\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-02/10/content_10796190.htm>\n\n\nAt least 165 people have died of meningitis and over 2000 were taken ill\nwith the contagious disease in north eastern India bordering Bangladesh and\nMyanmar over the past one month, the local Indo-Asian News Service said on\nTuesday [10 Feb 2009].\n\nThe epidemic has taken place in the states of Meghalaya, Tripura, and\nMizoram, with Meghalaya reporting 140 death cases, said the report. The 3\nnorth eastern states have borders with the Chittagong Hill Tracts of\nBangladesh, where meningococcal meningitis is spreading in an epidemic\nform, the report quoted the National Institute of Communicable Diseases as\nsaying. Two doctors from New Delhi have been dispatched by the authorities\nto the disease-stricken areas in Meghalaya to help doctors deal with the\ndisease on a through vaccinations and treatment on a round-the-clock basis,\nsaid the report.\n\n[byline: Deng Shasha]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak of meningococcal meningitis in the Indian state of Meghalaya\nthis year (2009) was recently reported by ProMED-mail (Meningitis,\nmeningococcal - India: (ML) 20090117.0206). At that time the outbreak was\nsaid to have claimed 132 lives 'according to the health department.\nHowever, unconfirmed reports put the death toll much higher.'\n\nFrom the news report above, the number of deaths in Meghalaya has\nincreased slightly to 140, but the outbreak has now been reported to have\nspread to neighboring Indian states of Tripura and Mizoram, and the\nChittagong Hill Tracts in Bangladesh, which borders Mizoram. The serogroup\nof _Neisseria meningitidis_ is still not specified.\n\nFrom Mod.ML's comments in the prior ProMED-mail post (Meningitis,\nmeningococcal - India: (ML) 20090117.0206): 'In April 2008 a meningococcal\nmeningitis outbreak in Meghalaya] involved 300 cases with 30 deaths\n(<http://www.shillongonline.com/index.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1446>).\nIn an undated article from the same website\n(<http://www.theshillongtimes.com/shillong.html>), the state Health\nDepartment was said to be 'considering the option of mass vaccination to\ncontrol this disease, but added that it would involve huge financial\nimplications and manpower. In view of limited supply of vaccines in the\nmarket, the government may provide vaccines only to the age group that has\nbeen worst affected by meningococcal meningitis. 'So far, preventive\nmedicines [chemoprophylaxis] have been provided only to those families\nhaving one of its members infected with the virus. To a certain extent,\npreventive medicines have also been provided in a number of schools,'\nsources said.''\n\nMeghalaya, a mountainous Indian state, is located between the north eastern\nborder of Bangladesh and the Indian state of Assam. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of India that shows the states of Meghalaya, Tripura, and\nMizoram can be found at <http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=22.9,79.6,5>. ML's comments in the prior ProMED-mail post (Meningitis,\nmeningococcal - India: (ML) 20090117.0206): 'In April 2008 a meningococcal\nmeningitis outbreak in Meghalaya] involved 300 cases with 30 deaths\n(<http://www.shillongonline.com/index.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1446>). \n\nFrom the news report above, the number of deaths in Meghalaya has\nincreased slightly to 140, but the outbreak has now been reported to have\nspread to neighboring Indian states of Tripura and Mizoram, and the\nChittagong Hill Tracts in Bangladesh, which borders Mizoram. Two doctors from New Delhi have been dispatched by the authorities\nto the disease-stricken areas in Meghalaya to help doctors deal with the\ndisease on a through vaccinations and treatment on a round-the-clock basis,\nsaid the report. \n\n[byline: Deng Shasha]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< A\nmap of Bangladesh showing the location of the Chittagong Hill Tracts that\nborders the Indian state of Mizoram can be found at\n<http://www.traveljournals.net/explore/bangladesh/map/m3773498/chittagong_hill_tract.html>.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-02-10 00:00:00", "2008-04-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mizoram", "country": "India"}, {"location": "New Delhi", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Meghalaya", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tripura", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "149285", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (03): (AW, HO, MC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=149285", "date": "2009-01-23 23:57:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - UGANDA (03): (ARUA, HOIMA, MASINDI)\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 22 Jan 2009\nSource: Reuters AlertNet [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/ef5f826ebe7a3ae18d5e3490cd33b7f5.htm>\n\n\nAt least 35 people have died in a meningitis epidemic that has hit\nseveral districts in western and north-western Uganda over the past 2\nweeks, a health ministry official said. 'Cumulatively we have\nrecorded 47 cases of meningitis with 13 dead in Hoima District,' Paul\nKaggwa, a spokesman for the ministry, said. 'Another 150 cases have\nbeen reported in Arua, with 18 dead, and 14 in Masindi, with 4 deaths.'\n\nIn its Africa weekly emergency situation update issued on 19 Jan\n2009, the World Health Organization (WHO) said one sub-county in\nHoima had crossed the meningitis epidemic threshold. There was also\nconcern about Karamoja region [located in northeastern Uganda] where\ndry weather had set in.\n\nKaggwa said the latest reports indicated Arua had also crossed the\nthreshold of 5 cases per 1000 people. 'The immediate intervention we\nare embarking on is to carry out vaccination in Arua and Hoima,' he\ntold IRIN [Integrated Regional Information Networks] on 22 Jan 2009.\n'We are still determining whether the situation in Masindi justifies\na vaccination [drive]. We are engaged in active surveillance and case\nmanagement [and] are sending teams to the areas to support\ncommunity-awareness programmes,' he added. 'We have deployed film\nvans to help in the campaign.'\n\nThe Uganda Red Cross (URC) in a 14 Jan 2009 statement said most\npatients in Arua were from Dadama and Oluko sub-counties while those\nin Hoima were from Kigorobya sub-county.\n\nAccording to the URC, the outbreak in Hoima occurred in an area with\nno history of vaccination for meningitis and few health units. The\naffected homes were also congested. Medical experts said dust, which\nis common during the dry season, leads to an increase in respiratory\ninfections and helps spread meningitis because the bacteria attach\nthemselves to dust particles.\n\nUganda lies within the African meningitis belt, stretching from\nSenegal in the west to Ethiopia in the east, according to the WHO.\nThe region, home to about 350 million people, experiences meningitis\ncycles whenever the dry season sets in.\n\nUp to 30 000 people suffer from the disease each year in Uganda. Last\nyear [2008], the government introduced a vaccine, which it said\nsignificantly reduced mortality rates from the deadly disease.\nExperts, however, say preparedness for meningitis epidemics is\ndifficult because vaccines cannot be administered until it is known\nwhich of the many different forms of the bacterium is spreading. As a\nresult, 5-10 percent of patients die, typically within 24 to 48\nhours, while some survivors suffer brain damage, hearing loss or\nlearning disabilities.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The above news release confirms that the number of cases\nmeningococcal meningitis and deaths continue to increase in 3\nnorthwestern districts (Arua, Hoima, and Masindi), but also mentions\nthat there was 'concern' about the Karamoja region, which lies in\nnortheastern Uganda, but does not indicate if any cases of meningitis\nactually occurred in this region. The meningococcal serogroups\ncausing the outbreak in Uganda have not as yet been specified.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the affected districts can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf> and a\nmap of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=443351&v=1.417,33.083,6>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The above news release confirms that the number of cases\nmeningococcal meningitis and deaths continue to increase in 3\nnorthwestern districts (Arua, Hoima, and Masindi), but also mentions\nthat there was 'concern' about the Karamoja region, which lies in\nnortheastern Uganda, but does not indicate if any cases of meningitis\nactually occurred in this region. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 22 Jan 2009\n \n\nA map of Uganda showing the affected districts can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf> and a\nmap of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. Medical experts said dust, which\nis common during the dry season, leads to an increase in respiratory\ninfections and helps spread meningitis because the bacteria attach\nthemselves to dust particles. As a\nresult, 5-10 percent of patients die, typically within 24 to 48\nhours, while some survivors suffer brain damage, hearing loss or\nlearning disabilities. \n\nIn its Africa weekly emergency situation update issued on 19 Jan\n2009, the World Health Organization (WHO) said one sub-county in\nHoima had crossed the meningitis epidemic threshold. At least 35 people have died in a meningitis epidemic that has hit\nseveral districts in western and north-western Uganda over the past 2\nweeks, a health ministry official said. ' \n\nThe Uganda Red Cross (URC) in a 14 Jan 2009 statement said most\npatients in Arua were from Dadama and Oluko sub-counties while those\nin Hoima were from Kigorobya sub-county. Cumulatively we have\nrecorded 47 cases of meningitis with 13 dead in Hoima District,' Paul\nKaggwa, a spokesman for the ministry, said. ' There was also\nconcern about Karamoja region [located in northeastern Uganda] where\ndry weather had set in.\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-01-22 00:00:00", "2009-01-14 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hoima District", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Hoima", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "147812", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=147812", "date": "2009-01-20 15:00:42", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - UGANDA (02): (MASINDI)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jan 2009\nSource: The New Vision (Uganda) [edited]\n<http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/668614>\n\n\nThe health ministry has reported an outbreak of meningitis in Masindi\ndistrict, a week after the deadly disease was reported in Hoima and\nArua districts. The director of clinical services in the ministry, Dr\nKenya Mugisha told The New Vision yesterday [19 Jan 2009] that 15\ncases of meningitis had been reported in Masindi, with 4 deaths. He\nsaid the outbreak had affected Pakanyi sub-county. 'There are fears\nthat it may be spreading to Kigumba,' said Mugisha. He said rapid\ntests had been carried out on patients, which confirmed meningitis.\n\nThe outbreak in Masindi follows reported outbreaks in Dadama and\nOluko sub-counties in Arua and Kigorobya sub-county in Hoima. Mugisha\nsaid the ministry was preparing to carry out a mass vaccination\nexercise in the affected districts.\n\nThe ministry identified the outbreak to be the meningococcal\nmeningitis, which is caused by bacteria transmitted from\nperson-to-person through contact with throat secretions.\n\nMeningitis is an inflammation of the meninges, which is the lining\nsurrounding the brain and spinal cord. The disease is also spread by\nbeing in close contact with a patient. Living in congested and poorly\nventilated premises with an infected person increases the risk of the\nspread of the disease. The most common symptoms of bacterial\nmeningitis are fever, headache, neck stiffness, sensitivity to light,\nmental confusion, and vomiting.\n\nDr John Turyagaruka, the Masindi district health officer, said the\ndistrict lies in the meningitis belt that covers the areas of\nsouthern Sudan and northern Uganda and outbreaks are normally\nanticipated during this time of the year. He also said the district\nwas using stocks of drugs that were earlier dispatched to the\ndistrict following a meningitis scare in November [2008]. The\ndistrict health department is carrying out public sensitisation on\nthe outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Raymond Baguma]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Ugandan meningococcal meningitis outbreak continues to spread,\nnow involving the Masindi district, which lies between the Arua\ndistrict to the north and the Hoima district to the south, where the\ndisease was previously reported. The meningococcal serogroups causing\nthis outbreak have not as yet been specified.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the affected districts can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf> and a\nmap of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=443351&v=1.417,33.083,6>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jan 2009\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Ugandan meningococcal meningitis outbreak continues to spread,\nnow involving the Masindi district, which lies between the Arua\ndistrict to the north and the Hoima district to the south, where the\ndisease was previously reported. \n\nDr John Turyagaruka, the Masindi district health officer, said the\ndistrict lies in the meningitis belt that covers the areas of\nsouthern Sudan and northern Uganda and outbreaks are normally\nanticipated during this time of the year. \n\nA map of Uganda showing the affected districts can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf> and a\nmap of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. The health ministry has reported an outbreak of meningitis in Masindi\ndistrict, a week after the deadly disease was reported in Hoima and\nArua districts. He also said the district\nwas using stocks of drugs that were earlier dispatched to the\ndistrict following a meningitis scare in November [2008]. The ministry identified the outbreak to be the meningococcal\nmeningitis, which is caused by bacteria transmitted from\nperson-to-person through contact with throat secretions. The director of clinical services in the ministry, Dr\nKenya Mugisha told The New Vision yesterday [19 Jan 2009] that 15\ncases of meningitis had been reported in Masindi, with 4 deaths. The\ndistrict health department is carrying out public sensitisation on\nthe outbreak.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-01-19 00:00:00", "2021-11-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hoima", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Mugisha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Masindi", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "146041", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU,HOI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=146041", "date": "2009-01-15 16:00:42", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - UGANDA: (ARUA, HOIMA)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 13 Jan 2009\nSource: The New Vision (Uganda) [edited]\n<http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/18/667975>\n\n\nThe number of patients admitted in Hoima district with suspected meningitis\nhas increased to 34 since the outbreak was first reported last week [week\nof 5 Jan 2009]. Paul Kaggwa, the assistant commissioner for health\neducation and promotion in the Ministry of Health, on Monday [12 Jan 2009]\nsaid 27 cases were first reported last Monday [?Mon 5 Jan 2009] in\nKigorobya sub-county [the affected sub county in Hoima]. Kaggwa added that\n3 cases had been confirmed to be meningitis, while 9 deaths had been reported.\n\nHe added that 42 people were admitted with meningitis in Arua district\n[Dadama and Oluko are the affected sub counties of Arua according to\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/KHII-7NB8FJ?OpenDocument>. -\nMod.ML]. Kaggwa said 2 cases were confirmed to be meningitis, while 9\ndeaths had occurred. He added, however, that the ministry could not confirm\nwhether the deaths were due to meningitis.\n\nLast week, the health ministry identified the Hoima outbreak to be the\nmeningococcal meningitis, which is caused by a bacterium and is transmitted\nfrom person-to-person through contact with throat secretions.\n\nMeningitis is an inflammation of the meninges, which is the lining\nsurrounding the brain and spinal cord. The ministry said overcrowding,\nkeeping in close contact with patients, living in congested and poorly\nventilated premises aids the spread of the disease. Kaggwa said the\nMinistry of Health had embarked on a mobilisation drive to sensitise the\ncommunities in the 2 districts to avoid congestion within their homes. 'We\nare on an active surveillance and the situation is being observed\nseriously,' Kaggwa said.\n\nMeningitis last broke out in Hoima in February 2008. During the last\noutbreak, 6 people died and many people were admitted in hospitals.\n\n[byline: Raymond Baguma]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is extracted from Mod.ML's comments in a prior ProMED-mail\npost [Meningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954].\n\n'Meningococcal meningitis occurs sporadically or as epidemics in\nsub-Saharan Africa, which is known as the 'Meningitis Belt', an area that\nstretches from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and Eritrea in the east and\nthat includes northern Uganda\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). Numerous cases of\nmeningococcal meningitis are reported in this region of Africa each year\nduring the dry season, between December and June, and every 6-12 years a\nlarge outbreak occurs (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\n'During the 1st 10 weeks of the 2006 meningitis season, outbreaks in\neastern Africa were mainly caused by _Neisseria meningitides_ serogroup\nW-135, whereas in West Africa the outbreak was due to mainly serogroup A.\nIn the Gulu district of Uganda the predominant serogroup was W-135, but\nserogroup A predominated in Uganda outside this district. Gulu is located\nin the center of the northern region, bordering Sudan and east of Arua\n(<http://www.ugpulse.com/images/articles/daily/20060307_100_447.jpg>).\n\n'In the Gulu district, the disease was noted in 'Internally Displaced\nPersons' camps. Overcrowded housing and large population displacements that\nundoubtedly characterized these camps likely favored the transmission of\n_N. meningitides_. At that time, the International Coordinating Group (ICG)\non Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control provided 360 000 doses\nof trivalent vaccine (polysaccharide vaccine for serotypes A, C, and W135)\nin an attempt to control the outbreak\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_03_21/en/index.html>).\n\n'In January 2007, a meningitis outbreak was again reported in Uganda,\naccording to the WHO\n(<http://mediaglobal.org/article/2007-01-26/deadly-outbreak-in-africas-meningitis-belt>)\nin an 'area, which borders southern Sudan and the Democratic Republic of\nCongo... [among] both refugees and nationals living in 'rural, densely\npopulated settlements.' The most affected district was said to be Arua. At\nthe time, the meningitis outbreak in South Sudan was reportedly caused by\nserotype A, but the serotype causing the meningitis outbreak in Uganda was\nnot given. The current outbreak is again occurring in the Arua district,\nbut 'this time round, it is counties like Vurra in Arua, which were not\ncovered during the [prior] immunization [program].\n\n'To control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate vaccine, depending on availability, in every involved district\nin an attempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is blocked when\na critical percentage of the population have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). There are several\ndifferent types of meningococcal vaccines. Polysaccharide vaccines, which\nhave been available for over 30 years, exist against serogroups A, C, Y,\nand W-135 in various combinations (such as, a bivalent AC, trivalent\nACW-135, and a tetravalent ACYW-135 polysaccharide vaccine). There is a\nmonovalent conjugate vaccine against serogroup C and a tetravalent against\nserogroups A, C, Y and W-135. The conjugate vaccines are immunogenic for\nchildren under 2 years of age whereas polysaccharide vaccines are not. All\nthese vaccines have been proven safe and effective with infrequent and mild\nside effects. For both the meningococcal conjugate and the polysaccharide\nvaccines, approximately 7-10 days are required following vaccination for\ndevelopment of protective levels of anti-meningococcal antibodies.'\n\nAccording to another recent news release concerning the Ugandan current\nmeningitis outbreak date Jan 14 2009\n(<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/KHII-7NB8FJ?OpenDocument>),\nthe Ugandan Red Cross 'discovered that the [meningitis] epidemic broke out\nin an area with no history of vaccination for meningitis and that the case\nfatality is high mainly due to the limited number of health units in the\narea. It was also found that the affected homesteads are congested which\neasily leads to the spread of the disease.'\n\nA map of Uganda showing the affected districts can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf> and a map of\nthe African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=443328&g=443332&v=1.417,33.083,6>. -\nCopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 13 Jan 2009\n \n\n'Meningococcal meningitis occurs sporadically or as epidemics in\nsub-Saharan Africa, which is known as the 'Meningitis Belt', an area that\nstretches from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and Eritrea in the east and\nthat includes northern Uganda\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). \n\n'To control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate vaccine, depending on availability, in every involved district\nin an attempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is blocked when\na critical percentage of the population have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). At that time, the International Coordinating Group (ICG)\non Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis Control provided 360 000 doses\nof trivalent vaccine (polysaccharide vaccine for serotypes A, C, and W135)\nin an attempt to control the outbreak\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_03_21/en/index.html>). (<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/KHII-7NB8FJ?OpenDocument>),\nthe Ugandan Red Cross 'discovered that the [meningitis] epidemic broke out\nin an area with no history of vaccination for meningitis and that the case\nfatality is high mainly due to the limited number of health units in the\narea. At\nthe time, the meningitis outbreak in South Sudan was reportedly caused by\nserotype A, but the serotype causing the meningitis outbreak in Uganda was\nnot given. Numerous cases of\nmeningococcal meningitis are reported in this region of Africa each year\nduring the dry season, between December and June, and every 6-12 years a\nlarge outbreak occurs (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>). \n\nA map of Uganda showing the affected districts can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf> and a map of\nthe African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. \n\n[byline: Raymond Baguma]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Polysaccharide vaccines, which\nhave been available for over 30 years, exist against serogroups A, C, Y,\nand W-135 in various combinations (such as, a bivalent AC, trivalent\nACW-135, and a tetravalent ACYW-135 polysaccharide vaccine). \n\nLast week, the health ministry identified the Hoima outbreak to be the\nmeningococcal meningitis, which is caused by a bacterium and is transmitted\nfrom person-to-person through contact with throat secretions. \n\n'During the 1st 10 weeks of the 2006 meningitis season, outbreaks in\neastern Africa were mainly caused by _Neisseria meningitides_ serogroup\n \n\n'In January 2007, a meningitis outbreak was again reported in Uganda,\naccording to the WHO\n According to another recent news release concerning the Ugandan current\nmeningitis outbreak date Jan 14 2009\n For both the meningococcal conjugate and the polysaccharide\nvaccines, approximately 7-10 days are required following vaccination for\ndevelopment of protective levels of anti-meningococcal antibodies.' Paul Kaggwa, the assistant commissioner for health\neducation and promotion in the Ministry of Health, on Monday [12 Jan 2009]\nsaid 27 cases were first reported last Monday [? The current outbreak is again occurring in the Arua district,\nbut 'this time round, it is counties like Vurra in Arua, which were not\ncovered during the [prior] immunization [program].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-01-13 00:00:00", "2009-01-05 00:00:00", "2009-01-12 00:00:00", "2007-01-26 00:00:00", "2008-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eritrea", "country": "Eritrea"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Hoima", "country": "Uganda"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "142879", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - US: (HI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=142879", "date": "2009-01-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS \u00ad UNITED STATES: (HAWAII)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 6 Jan 2009\nSource: Star Bulletin [edited]\n<http://www.starbulletin.com/news/20090105_parasites_cause_intense_pain_for_big_isle_victims.html>\n\n\nAngiostrongylus in Hawaii\n-------------------------\nThe pain was so bad he screamed for hours. 'It\njust got so intense, nothing took the pain away,'\nsaid a Big Island resident, 36 [patient 1]. 'It\nfelt like they were doing surgery on me and\nripping out my organs.' The patient was a victim\nof what is commonly called rat lungworm disease,\na rare ailment that has inexplicably hit 3 Big\nIsland residents hard in the last few weeks.\n\nDr. Jon Martell, the attending physician at Hilo\nMedical Center, said the 3 patients are the worst\nhe has seen in his 14 years of treating such cases.\n\nThe disease arises from parasitic worms,\nAngiostrongylus cantonensis, sometimes ingested\ninadvertently by eating raw produce that contains\na small snail or slug. The worms migrate through\nthe human body and usually die after several\nweeks. Most people recover fully without\ntreatment, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nBut sometimes the larvae migrate into cerebral\nfluid, causing inflammation in the brain and\nspinal cord membrane and a form of meningitis,\naccording to a study by the state and CDC\npublished in 2007. In some cases, rat lungworm\ndisease can cause significant pain and trauma,\nincluding paralysis, blindness and death, as\noccurred in a fatal case in Taiwan in 1944, according to the study.\n\nThe study identified 24 rat lungworm cases in\nHawaii from January 2001 to February 2005,\nincluding 11 on Oahu, 9 on the Big Island, 3 on\nMaui and one on Lanai. Patients usually became\nsick in 3 days, but one took as long as 48 days, according to the study.\n\nThe patient 1, quoted above, said he and a friend\n[patient 2], who live in Black Sands between\nPahoa and Kalapana, have been eating raw\nvegetables and taking precautions by cleaning the\nproduce with a peroxide rinse. He suspects they\nmay have accidentally consumed tiny larvae of\nslugs lodged in the deep folds of peppers.\n\nPatient 1 said [patient 2] came down with\nagonizing pain, but no one at Hilo Medical Center\ncould find anything wrong with her initially and\nshe was not admitted to the hospital. 'I had to\ntake her home ... 3 separate times,' he said. 'No\none should have to be turned away.'\n\n[Patient 2] has been in a coma for several days, he said.\n\nDr. Sarah Park, state epidemiologist, said there\nis no diagnostic test that confirms the presence\nof rat lungworm disease, short of finding the\nparasite, and physicians have to rely partially\non the likelihood of possible exposure through a\npatient's food history. She said in certain\ninstances, an analysis of spinal fluid can\nindicate the likelihood of rat lungworm disease.\nPark said there is no medical treatment for the\ndisease, and physicians treat the symptoms with\npain relievers for aches and steroids for inflammation.\n\nA 24-year-old Puna man was admitted to Hilo\nMedical Center with a case last week. She said\nothers have contracted the disease but have not\ngone to the hospital because they do not have medical insurance.\n\nPark said the movement to consume home-grown\nproduce is great and that people simply dunk\nproduce in water and assume it is clean. 'You've\ngot to clean each leaf,' she said. 'Our biggest\nchallenge is constantly reminding people about\nthe risks.' Park said a species of slug on the\nBig Island has tiny larvae, about 1 to 2 millimeters long.\n\nThe presence of the Southeast Asian slug,\nParmarion martens, was noticed about 10 years ago\nand has spread rapidly, said Robert\nHollingsworth, an entomologist with the U.S.\nPacific Basin Agricultural Research Center. 'The\nconcern is when it's very small and hard to see,' he said.\n\n[Byline: Gary Kubota\nStar Bulletin]\n\n--\nProMED\npromed@promedmail.org\n\n\n[Angiostrongylus cantonensis is spreading in\ncountries of the Pacific rim including Hawaii\nprobably spread by rats carried on ships.\nAccording the CDC: 'People can get infected by\neating raw or undercooked snails or slugs that\nare infected with this parasite. In some\ncultures, snails are commonly eaten. Some\nchildren, in particular, have gotten infected by\nswallowing snails/slugs 'on a dare.' People also\ncan get infected by accident, by eating raw\nproduce (such as lettuce) that contains a small snail or slug or part of one'\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dpd/parasites/angiostrongylus/factsht_angiostrongylus.htm>).\n\nThe article refer to a sudy by Hochberg et al.\n(Distribution of eosinophilic meningitis cases\nattributable to Angiostrongylus cantonensis,\nHawaii. Park said there is no medical treatment for the\ndisease, and physicians treat the symptoms with\npain relievers for aches and steroids for inflammation.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2001-01-26 00:00:00", "1944-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-01-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hawaii", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Big Island", "country": "Antarctica"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "131507", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, children - Russia: (RYA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=131507", "date": "2008-11-30 13:00:38", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, CHILDREN - RUSSIA: (RYAZANSKKAYA)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 25 Nov 2008\nSource: Komsomolskaya Pravda, Regions.ru [trans. Corr.BA, edited]\n<http://www.regions.ru/news/health/2181438>\n\n\nPhysicians in the Ryazanskaya Oblast are concerned about an outbreak\nof meningitis in children. At the moment, 7 cases of serous [aseptic]\nmeningitis have been reported, which is equivalent to the number\ncases reported during the whole of last year [2007].\n\nChildren, including newborns, are the group at greatest risk of\nserous [aseptic] meningitis. So far in 2008, a total of 60 cases of\nserous [aseptic] meningitis has been recorded in the Ryazanskaya\nOblast.\n\nThe causes of the 7 meningitis cases remain undetermined, and there\nhas been no laboratory confirmation. All 7 children have recovered.\n\nTreatment duration depends on meningitis severity: mild cases recover\nwithin 2 weeks, whereas severe disease may be prolonged for a month\nor more. Self-medication or treatment should be avoided.\nComplications of serous [aseptic] meningitis can be very severe and\neven fatal.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail-RUS <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Meningitis is usually caused by a viral or bacterial infection.\nKnowing whether meningitis is caused by a virus or bacterium is\nimportant because the severity of illness and the treatment differ.\nViral ('aseptic') meningitis is serious but rarely fatal in persons\nwith normal immune systems. Usually, the symptoms last from 7 to 10\ndays, and the patient recovers completely.\n\nMany different viruses can cause meningitis. About 90 percent of\ncases of viral meningitis are caused by enteroviruses. These viruses\nare more common during summer and autumn months. Herpesvirus and\nmumps virus infection can also cause meningitis. Viral meningitis is\nusually diagnosed by laboratory tests of spinal fluid obtained with a\nspinal tap. The specific cause of viral meningitis can be determined\nby tests that identify the virus in specimens collected from the\npatient, but these tests are rarely done. No specific treatment for\nviral meningitis exists at this time. Most patients completely\nrecover on their own. Enteroviruses, the most common cause of viral\nmeningitis, are most often spread through direct contact with the\nrespiratory secretions (e.g., saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus) of an\ninfected person or via fecal contamination of the person and the\nenvironment.\n\nInformation on the identity of the agent responsible for this\noutbreak would be welcomed.\n\nThe Ryazanskaya Oblast can be located using the interactive map of Russia at\n<http://map.rin.ru/cgi-bin/main_e.pl?Region=razan>,\nand the HealthMap/ ProMED-mail interactive map of Russia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=499068&v=57,50,4>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 25 Nov 2008\n Enteroviruses, the most common cause of viral\nmeningitis, are most often spread through direct contact with the\nrespiratory secretions (e.g., saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus) of an\ninfected person or via fecal contamination of the person and the\nenvironment. The Ryazanskaya Oblast can be located using the interactive map of Russia at\n<http://map.rin.ru/cgi-bin/main_e.pl?Region=razan>,\nand the HealthMap/ ProMED-mail interactive map of Russia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=499068&v=57,50,4>. At the moment, 7 cases of serous [aseptic]\nmeningitis have been reported, which is equivalent to the number\ncases reported during the whole of last year [2007]. \n\nTreatment duration depends on meningitis severity: mild cases recover\nwithin 2 weeks, whereas severe disease may be prolonged for a month\nor more. The specific cause of viral meningitis can be determined\nby tests that identify the virus in specimens collected from the\npatient, but these tests are rarely done. So far in 2008, a total of 60 cases of\nserous [aseptic] meningitis has been recorded in the Ryazanskaya\nOblast. Viral meningitis is\nusually diagnosed by laboratory tests of spinal fluid obtained with a\nspinal tap. BA, edited]\n<http://www.regions.ru/news/health/2181438>\n\n\nPhysicians in the Ryazanskaya Oblast are concerned about an outbreak\nof meningitis in children. MENINGITIS, CHILDREN - RUSSIA: (RYAZANSKKAYA)\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "142441", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - US: [HI]", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=142441", "date": "2009-01-06 15:00:43", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS \u00ad UNITED STATES: (HAWAII)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 6 Jan 2009\nSource: Star Bulletin [edited]\n<http://www.starbulletin.com/news/20090105_parasites_cause_intense_pain_for_big_isle_victims.html>\n\n\nAngiostrongylus in Hawaii\n-------------------------\nThe pain was so bad he screamed for hours. 'It\njust got so intense, nothing took the pain away,'\nsaid a Big Island resident, 36 [patient 1]. 'It\nfelt like they were doing surgery on me and\nripping out my organs.' The patient was a victim\nof what is commonly called rat lungworm disease,\na rare ailment that has inexplicably hit 3 Big\nIsland residents hard in the last few weeks.\n\nDr. Jon Martell, the attending physician at Hilo\nMedical Center, said the 3 patients are the worst\nhe has seen in his 14 years of treating such cases.\n\nThe disease arises from parasitic worms,\nAngiostrongylus cantonensis, sometimes ingested\ninadvertently by eating raw produce that contains\na small snail or slug. The worms migrate through\nthe human body and usually die after several\nweeks. Most people recover fully without\ntreatment, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nBut sometimes the larvae migrate into cerebral\nfluid, causing inflammation in the brain and\nspinal cord membrane and a form of meningitis,\naccording to a study by the state and CDC\npublished in 2007. In some cases, rat lungworm\ndisease can cause significant pain and trauma,\nincluding paralysis, blindness and death, as\noccurred in a fatal case in Taiwan in 1944, according to the study.\n\nThe study identified 24 rat lungworm cases in\nHawaii from January 2001 to February 2005,\nincluding 11 on Oahu, 9 on the Big Island, 3 on\nMaui and one on Lanai. Patients usually became\nsick in 3 days, but one took as long as 48 days, according to the study.\n\nThe patient 1, quoted above, said he and a friend\n[patient 2], who live in Black Sands between\nPahoa and Kalapana, have been eating raw\nvegetables and taking precautions by cleaning the\nproduce with a peroxide rinse. He suspects they\nmay have accidentally consumed tiny larvae of\nslugs lodged in the deep folds of peppers.\n\nPatient 1 said [patient 2] came down with\nagonizing pain, but no one at Hilo Medical Center\ncould find anything wrong with her initially and\nshe was not admitted to the hospital. 'I had to\ntake her home ... 3 separate times,' he said. 'No\none should have to be turned away.'\n\n[Patient 2] has been in a coma for several days, he said.\n\nDr. Sarah Park, state epidemiologist, said there\nis no diagnostic test that confirms the presence\nof rat lungworm disease, short of finding the\nparasite, and physicians have to rely partially\non the likelihood of possible exposure through a\npatient's food history. She said in certain\ninstances, an analysis of spinal fluid can\nindicate the likelihood of rat lungworm disease.\nPark said there is no medical treatment for the\ndisease, and physicians treat the symptoms with\npain relievers for aches and steroids for inflammation.\n\nA 24-year-old Puna man was admitted to Hilo\nMedical Center with a case last week. She said\nothers have contracted the disease but have not\ngone to the hospital because they do not have medical insurance.\n\nPark said the movement to consume home-grown\nproduce is great and that people simply dunk\nproduce in water and assume it is clean. 'You've\ngot to clean each leaf,' she said. 'Our biggest\nchallenge is constantly reminding people about\nthe risks.' Park said a species of slug on the\nBig Island has tiny larvae, about 1 to 2 millimeters long.\n\nThe presence of the Southeast Asian slug,\nParmarion martens, was noticed about 10 years ago\nand has spread rapidly, said Robert\nHollingsworth, an entomologist with the U.S.\nPacific Basin Agricultural Research Center. 'The\nconcern is when it's very small and hard to see,' he said.\n\n[Byline: Gary Kubota\nStar Bulletin]\n\n--\nProMED\npromed@promedmail.org\n\n\n[Angiostrongylus cantonensis is spreading in\ncountries of the Pacific rim including Hawaii\nprobably spread by rats carried on ships.\nAccording the CDC: 'People can get infected by\neating raw or undercooked snails or slugs that\nare infected with this parasite. In some\ncultures, snails are commonly eaten. Some\nchildren, in particular, have gotten infected by\nswallowing snails/slugs 'on a dare.' People also\ncan get infected by accident, by eating raw\nproduce (such as lettuce) that contains a small snail or slug or part of one'\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dpd/parasites/angiostrongylus/factsht_angiostrongylus.htm>).\n\nThe article refer to a sudy by Hochberg et al.\n(Distribution of eosinophilic meningitis cases\nattributable to Angiostrongylus cantonensis,\nHawaii. Emerg Infect Dis. 2007;13:1675-80). The\nstudy identified 24 cases of eosinophilic\nmeningitis attributable to A.catonensis, but did\nnot discuss the transmission routes.\n\nLife cycle:\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>. - Mod.EP]", "summary": "\n\nDr. Sarah Park, state epidemiologist, said there\nis no diagnostic test that confirms the presence\nof rat lungworm disease, short of finding the\nparasite, and physicians have to rely partially\non the likelihood of possible exposure through a\npatient's food history. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 6 Jan 2009\n \n\nThe presence of the Southeast Asian slug,\nParmarion martens, was noticed about 10 years ago\nand has spread rapidly, said Robert\nHollingsworth, an entomologist with the U.S.\nPacific Basin Agricultural Research Center. Park said there is no medical treatment for the\ndisease, and physicians treat the symptoms with\npain relievers for aches and steroids for inflammation.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1944-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-01-06 00:00:00", "2001-01-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hawaii", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Big Island", "country": "Antarctica"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "146655", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - India: (ML)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=146655", "date": "2009-01-17 18:00:43", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - INDIA: (MEGHALAYA)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 13 Jan 2009\nSource: The Assam Tribune [edited]\n<http://www.assamtribune.com/scripts/details.asp?id=jan1409/ne4>\n\n\nAfter meningococcal meningitis claimed 132 lives in Meghalaya, the Centre\nhas rushed in a team from the National Institute of Communicable Diseases\n(NICD) to assist the health officials. The NICD team is being led by joint\ndirector[s? - Mod.SH] Jagdir Singh and S Gupta to help the Meghalaya Health\ndepartment to combat the disease.\n\n'NICD with its expertise would help the State Health department to tackle\nthe disease,' director of health services (DHS) Dr A Kynjing said.\n\nCases of meningococcal meningitis have been reported from all parts of the\nstate but mostly from areas like Jhalupara, Mawlai, Lumparing and\nNongmynsong in East Khasi Hills here and in areas in Garo Hills from last\nyear [2008]. The death toll has reached 132 according to the health\ndepartment. However, unconfirmed reports put the death toll much higher.\n\nMeningitis affects the membrane around the brain called the meninges.\nInfected fluid from meninges run into the spinal cord causing stiff neck,\nfever and rash. If left untreated the disease can be fatal.\n\nThe health department has been accused of not keeping enough stock of the\nanti-meningococcal meningitis vaccines for the affected people. The vaccine\ncosts about Rs 360 [USD 7.38] in private hospitals.\n\nDr Kynjing refuted the allegation, saying there were 'enough stock of the\nvaccines' in the health department. 'We get the vaccines from the Centre\nand as of now we have enough stock and people should not panic,' he\nassured. The health official added that a massive public awareness campaign\nhas been launched to emphasise the importance of cleanliness to prevent\nspread of this airborne disease. Dr Kynjing further urged the public to\njoin in and help the Health department to help prevent further spread of\nthe disease.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An outbreak of meningococcal meningitis was previously reported in\nMeghalaya in April 2008 that involved 300 cases with 30 deaths\n(<http://www.theshillongtimes.com/a-29-April.htm>). In an undated article\nfrom the same website (<http://www.theshillongtimes.com/shillong.html>),\nthe state Health Department was said to be 'considering the option of mass\nvaccination to control this disease but added that it would involve huge\nfinancial implications and manpower. In view of limited supply of vaccines\nin the market, the government may provide vaccines only to the age group\nthat has been worst affected by meningococcal meningitis. 'So far,\npreventive medicines [chemoprophylaxis] have been provided only to those\nfamilies having one of its members infected with the virus. To a certain\nextent, preventive medicines have also been provided in a number of\nschools,' sources said.'\n\nChemoprophylaxis is used to prevent secondary cases of _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_ infection, which usually occur within 10 days of the primary\ncases among certain high-risk groups. These groups include household\ncontacts, closed populations living with cases in college dormitories,\nlong-term care institutions, nursery schools, or military barracks, and\nclose social contacts who are directly exposed to a case's oral secretions,\nfor example by kissing, sharing eating utensils, or toothbrushes, in the\nweek prior to onset of illness in the primary case. Appropriate\nchemoprophylactic drugs include rifampin, ciprofloxacin, or ceftriaxone.\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate serogroup-specific meningococcal vaccine, depending on\navailability, in every involved district in an attempt to induce herd\nimmunity (whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the\npopulation have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). However, the\nserogroup(s) of _N. meningitidis_ involved in the current or past outbreaks\nin Meghalaya is not specified in the above news releases.\n\nOutbreaks of serogroup A meningococcal meningitis in and around Delhi,\nIndia, have been documented in 1966, 1985, and 2005\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2005_05_09/en/index.html>). To the north,\nthere was an epidemic of serogroup A meningococcal meningitis in the\nKathmandu valley of Nepal from 1982-84\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2005_05_09/en/index.html>). In 1984, a\nwidespread vaccination program prevented a 2nd epidemic\n(<http://ije.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/16/1/91>). Cases of\nmeningococcal meningitis occurred in foreigners in Nepal at the time,\nmostly in trekkers that led to the CDC to issue a travel advisory notice\nrecommending the meningococcal meningitis vaccine for all travelers to\nNepal that was later lifted\n(<http://wonder.cdc.gov/wonder/prevguid/p0000259/p0000259.asp>).\nMeningococcal meningitis was also noted in Bhutan from 1985-1986\n(<http://web.gideononline.com/abstract.php?module=epidemiology&disease=11480&view=Distribution&country=G122>).\nMeghalaya, a mountainous Indian state, is located between the north eastern\nborder of Bangladesh and the Indian state of Assam. Meghalaya consists of\nthe 7 districts: East Garo Hills, East Khasi Hills, Jaintia Hills, Ri-Bhoi,\nSouth Garo Hills, West Garo Hills and the West Khasi Hills\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meghalaya>). Its capital and largest city is\nShillong. A map of India can be found at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=22.9,79.6,5>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Cases of\nmeningococcal meningitis occurred in foreigners in Nepal at the time,\nmostly in trekkers that led to the CDC to issue a travel advisory notice\nrecommending the meningococcal meningitis vaccine for all travelers to\nNepal that was later lifted\n(<http://wonder.cdc.gov/wonder/prevguid/p0000259/p0000259.asp>). \n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the\nappropriate serogroup-specific meningococcal vaccine, depending on\navailability, in every involved district in an attempt to induce herd\nimmunity (whereby transmission is blocked when a critical percentage of the\npopulation have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). These groups include household\ncontacts, closed populations living with cases in college dormitories,\nlong-term care institutions, nursery schools, or military barracks, and\nclose social contacts who are directly exposed to a case's oral secretions,\nfor example by kissing, sharing eating utensils, or toothbrushes, in the\nweek prior to onset of illness in the primary case. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 13 Jan 2009\n In an undated article\nfrom the same website (<http://www.theshillongtimes.com/shillong.html>),\nthe state Health Department was said to be 'considering the option of mass\nvaccination to control this disease but added that it would involve huge\nfinancial implications and manpower. \n\nCases of meningococcal meningitis have been reported from all parts of the\nstate but mostly from areas like Jhalupara, Mawlai, Lumparing and\nNongmynsong in East Khasi Hills here and in areas in Garo Hills from last\nyear [2008]. To the north,\nthere was an epidemic of serogroup A meningococcal meningitis in the\nKathmandu valley of Nepal from 1982-84\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< Meghalaya consists of\nthe 7 districts: East Garo Hills, East Khasi Hills, Jaintia Hills, Ri-Bhoi,\nSouth Garo Hills, West Garo Hills and the West Khasi Hills\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meghalaya>). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An outbreak of meningococcal meningitis was previously reported in\nMeghalaya in April 2008 that involved 300 cases with 30 deaths\n(<http://www.theshillongtimes.com/a-29-April.htm>). \n\nOutbreaks of serogroup A meningococcal meningitis in and around Delhi,\nIndia, have been documented in 1966, 1985, and 2005\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2005_05_09/en/index.html>). In view of limited supply of vaccines\nin the market, the government may provide vaccines only to the age group\nthat has been worst affected by meningococcal meningitis. ' \n\nChemoprophylaxis is used to prevent secondary cases of _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_ infection, which usually occur within 10 days of the primary\ncases among certain high-risk groups.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-04-26 00:00:00", "1966-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-01-13 00:00:00", "1985-03-26 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00", "1984-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jaintia Hills", "country": "India"}, {"location": "South Garo Hills", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "East Garo Hills", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Meghalaya", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kathmandu", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "Bhutan", "country": "Bhutan"}, {"location": "East Khasi Hills", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Garo Hills", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "109374", "headline": "PRO> Meningitis, meningococcal - Brazil (02): (SP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=109374", "date": "2008-09-05 14:00:35", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BRAZIL (02): (SAO PAULO)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 4 Sep 2008\nFrom: Luiz Jacintho da Silva <luiz_jacintho@uol.com.br>\n\n\n[_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup] C predominates [in the recent\noutbreak] not only in [the city of] Sao Jose, but also in [the\nBrazilian state of] Sao Paulo as a whole. As far as I know they were\nnot going to vaccinate because the cases had stopped.\n\n--\nLuiz Jacintho da Silva\nProMED-PORT\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[We are grateful to Luiz Jacintho da Silva, ProMED-PORT moderator for\nthe information above. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 4 Sep 2008\n \n\n--\nLuiz Jacintho da Silva\nProMED-PORT\n< MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BRAZIL (02): (SAO PAULO)\n****************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sao Jose", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Sao Paulo", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "127445", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - Viet Nam", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=127445", "date": "2008-11-13 17:00:36", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - VIET NAM\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[The below posting appeared on PRO/MBDS and is being reproduced for\nthe general ProMED-mail list. - Mod.MPP]\n\nDate: Wed 12 Nov 2008\nSource: VietNamNet Bridge [edited]\n<http://english.vietnamnet.vn/tech/2008/11/813229/>\n\n\nRare meningitis discovered in 5 kids\n------------------------------------\nMeningitis caused by _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_, a very rare\ndisease, is becoming increasingly common in Viet Nam, said Dr Nguyen\nVan De, chief of the Parasitology Faculty of Hanoi Medical University.\n\nFrom 1995-2000, Viet Nam recorded only 15 cases, but so far this\nyear [2008], the number is 5. All are children under 15 years old in Hanoi.\n\nThe children caught the disease when the _Angiostrongylus\ncantonensis_ worm got into their brain, causing meningitis. Typical\nsymptoms include fever, headache, vomiting, convulsions, and squinty eyes.\n\n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ can appear in [cerebrospinal fluid] and\nalso in lens crystallins and lung arteries.\n\nThere are over 20 species of _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_, which\nparasitise mice, 2 of which cause meningitis in humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Background information on _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ infection\nwas excerpted from the parasitic disease information fact sheet of\nthe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) website at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dpd/parasites/angiostrongylus/factsht_angiostrongylus.htm>.\n\n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is a nematode (parasitic worm) of rats,\nwhich is also called the rat lungworm. The adult form of the parasite\ncan be found only in rodents. Infected rats pass larvae of the\nparasite in their feces. By ingesting the rat feces, snails and slugs\nget infected with the larvae. Then, the larvae mature in snails and\nslugs but do not develop into adult worms. When rats eat infected\nsnails or slugs, the larvae mature into adult worms in the rats. An\nexcellent diagram demonstrating the life cycle of the nematode can be\nfound at <http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>,\nwith additional more detail on the organism and clinical manifestations.\n\nPeople can become infected by eating raw or undercooked snails,\nslugs, freshwater prawns, crabs, or frogs infected with this\nparasite, but fish cannot transmit this parasite to humans. There is\nno known human-to-human transmission of this parasite either.\n\nMost of the infected cases do not show any symptoms or have only mild\nsymptoms of short duration. Sometimes, the infection can render a\nrare type of eosinophilic meningitis. The clinical symptoms of\neosinophilic meningitis are caused by the presence of larvae in the\nbrain and by local host reactions. The symptoms of eosinophilic\nmeningitis include headache, stiff neck, tingling or painful\nsensation in the skin, low-grade fever, nausea, and vomiting.\n\nThe majority of people can fully recover spontaneously with\nsymptomatic treatment. Antibiotics have not been shown to be\neffective for the treatment of eosinophilic meningitis.\n\nSelected references\n-------------------\n1. Li H, Xu F, Gu JB, Chen XG: A severe eosinophilic\nmeningoencephalitis caused by infection of _Angiostrongylus\ncantonensis_. Am J Trop Med Hyg, Oct 2008; 79: 568-570 (no abstract available)\n2. Kuberski T, Bart RD, Briley JM, Rosen L: Recovery of\n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ from cerebrospinal fluid of a child\nwith eosinophilic meningitis. J. Clin. Microbiol., May 1979; 9: 629 -\n631 (full article available at\n<http://jcm.asm.org/cgi/reprint/9/5/629?maxtoshow=&HITS=&hits=&RESULTFORMAT=&fulltext=Angiostrongylus+cantonensis&andorexactfulltext=or&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=10&resourcetype=HWCIT>).\n3. Tsai HC, et al: Eosinophilic meningoencephalitis caused by\n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ associated with eating raw snails:\ncorrelation of brain magnetic resonance imaging scans with clinical\nfindings. Am J Trop Med Hyg, Mar 2003; 68: 281-5 (full article available at\n<http://www.ajtmh.org/cgi/content/full/68/3/281?maxtoshow=&HITS=&hits=&RESULTFORMAT=&fulltext=Angiostrongylus+cantonensis&andorexactfulltext=or&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=0&resourcetype=HWCIT>).\n4. Weir E, Travel warning: Eosinophilic meningitis caused by rat\nlungworm. Can. Med. Assoc. J., Apr 2002; 166: 1184 (full article available at\n<http://www.cmaj.ca/cgi/reprint/166/9/1184>).\n5. Thu TP, Nguyen NX, Lan LT, Kuchle M: Ocular _Angiostrongylus\ncantonensis_ in a female Vietnamese patient: case report. Klin\nMonatsbl Augenheilkd, Dec 2002; 219(12): 892-5 (abstract available at\n<http://highwire.stanford.edu/cgi/medline/pmid;12548476?maxtoshow=&HITS=&hits=&RESULTFORMAT=1&andorexacttitle=and&fulltext=Angiostrongylus+cantonensis+&andorexactfulltext=and&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=20&sortspec=relevance&resourcetype=HWCIT>).\n6. Nitidandhaprabhas P, Harnsomburana K, Thepsitthar P:\n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ in the cerebrospinal fluid of an adult\nmale patient with eosinophilic meningitis in Thailand. Am J Trop Med\nHyg, Jul 1975; 24: 711-2 (abstract available at\n<http://www.ajtmh.org/cgi/content/abstract/24/4/711?maxtoshow=&HITS=&hits=&RESULTFORMAT=1&andorexacttitle=and&fulltext=Angiostrongylus+cantonensis+&andorexactfulltext=and&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=40&sortspec=relevance&resourcetype=HWCIT>).\n\nFor maps of Viet Nam with provinces, see\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/vietnam_admin01.jpg>\nand <http://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html>.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Viet Nam can be accessed\nat <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=14.9,108.5,5>. This map shows other\noutbreaks in Viet Nam and surrounding countries that have been\nreported on ProMED-mail and PRO/MBDS. The postings can be directly\naccessed through this map. - Mods.YMA/MPP]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Background information on _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ infection\nwas excerpted from the parasitic disease information fact sheet of\nthe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) website at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dpd/parasites/angiostrongylus/factsht_angiostrongylus.htm>. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[The below posting appeared on PRO/MBDS and is being reproduced for\nthe general ProMED-mail list. Tsai HC, et al: Eosinophilic meningoencephalitis caused by\n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ associated with eating raw snails:\ncorrelation of brain magnetic resonance imaging scans with clinical\nfindings. \nMeningitis caused by _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_, a very rare\ndisease, is becoming increasingly common in Viet Nam, said Dr Nguyen\nVan De, chief of the Parasitology Faculty of Hanoi Medical University. An\nexcellent diagram demonstrating the life cycle of the nematode can be\nfound at <http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>,\nwith additional more detail on the organism and clinical manifestations. \n\nPeople can become infected by eating raw or undercooked snails,\nslugs, freshwater prawns, crabs, or frogs infected with this\nparasite, but fish cannot transmit this parasite to humans.
