Source: VietNamNet Bridge [edited]\n<http://english.vietnamnet.vn/tech/2008/11/813229/>\n\n\nRare meningitis discovered in 5 kids\n------------------------------------ Microbiol., May 1979; 9: 629 -\n631 (full article available at\n<http://jcm.asm.org/cgi/reprint/9/5/629?maxtoshow=&HITS=&hits=&RESULTFORMAT=&fulltext=Angiostrongylus+cantonensis&andorexactfulltext=or&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=10&resourcetype=HWCIT>). This map shows other\noutbreaks in Viet Nam and surrounding countries that have been\nreported on ProMED-mail and PRO/MBDS. ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - VIET NAM\n*************************************\n For maps of Viet Nam with provinces, see\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/vietnam_admin01.jpg>\nand <http://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html>. \n\nThe children caught the disease when the _Angiostrongylus\ncantonensis_ worm got into their brain, causing meningitis. \n\nThere are over 20 species of _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_, which\nparasitise mice, 2 of which cause meningitis in humans. \n\n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is a nematode (parasitic worm) of rats,\nwhich is also called the rat lungworm. \n\n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ can appear in [cerebrospinal fluid] and\nalso in lens crystallins and lung arteries.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1979-05-26 00:00:00", "2002-12-26 00:00:00", "1184-03-26 00:00:00", "0892-05-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "background", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Nitidandhaprabhas p", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "143632", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aseptic meningitis, Toscana virus - Switzerland ex Italy (Elba)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=143632", "date": "2009-01-08 21:00:42", "main_text": "ASEPTIC MENINGITIS TOSCANA VIRUS - SWITZERLAND ex ITALY (ELBA)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 8 Jan 2009\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Vol. 14, Issue 1 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19079>\n\n\nImported aseptic meningitis due to Toscana virus acquired on the\nisland of Elba, Italy, August 2008\n-----------------------------------------------\nBy B Sonderegger 1, H Hachler2, G Dobler3, M Frei4\n1 Department of Medicine, Hospital of Lucerne, Switzerland\n2 Institute of Medical Microbiology, Hospital of Lucerne, Switzerland\n3 Institute of Microbiology of the Bundeswehr, Munich, Germany\n4 Medical Practice for Tropical and Travel Medicine, Lucerne, Switzerland\n\nWe describe a case of aseptic meningitis due to Toscana virus\nimported to Switzerland and discuss the epidemiological situation. To\nour knowledge, this is the 1st description of this infection acquired\non the island of Elba.\n\nIntroduction\n------------\nIn Switzerland, aseptic meningitis is frequently encountered and most\noften caused by enteroviruses, flaviviruses (tick-borne\nencephalitis), herpes simplex virus type 1 and 2, varicella-zoster\nvirus or mumps and measles viruses. Other arthropod-borne viruses\nthat can cause clinical signs of meningoencephalitis, such as West\nNile virus, have been detected in other parts of Europe and also in\ncountries around Switzerland (e.g. Italy, France), but not as yet in\nSwitzerland itself. Toscana virus (TOSV) was 1st isolated from a\nsandfly (_Phlebotomus peniciosus_) in central Italy in 1971 and\nidentified as a common cause of aseptic meningitis in this country.\nSince then, it has been detected in other countries around the\nMediterranean. Studies carried out in Italy have shown that the virus\ncirculates not only in Tuscany but also in other regions such as\nEmilia Romagna, Marches, Umbria and Piedmont [1]. So far, no data can\nbe found about infections acquired on the islands off the coast of\nTuscany, including Elba.\n\nCase Report\n---------\nOn 10 Aug 2008, a man in his 20s was admitted to the emergency\ndepartment of the Hospital of Lucerne, based in the central part of\nSwitzerland. He suffered from a pronounced headache since the\nprevious day and recurrent vomiting. He had stayed on the island of\nElba for 2 weeks and returned home on 8 Aug 2008. From 27 to 31 Jul\n2008, he had stayed at a campsite east of Portoferraio before moving\nto the southern part of the island (near Marina di Campo) for the\nremaining week. The entire holiday was spent exclusively on Elba,\nwith no major stopovers on the way home from Piombino, the mainland\nport for the ferry to Elba. At the campsite, the patient usually\nslept outside the tent on a canvas chair; the ground was sandy and hard.\n\nOn admission, the patient had neck rigidity without clinical signs of\nencephalitis or fever. White blood cell count and C-reactive protein\nlevels were normal. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), taken on the day of\nadmission, was clear and showed a white blood cell count of 196/mm3\n(85 percent mononuclear cells), protein levels of 0.75 g/L, and\nglucose levels of 3.7 mmol/L (the glucose level in the blood was 6.9\nmmol/L). Gram stain was negative, and culture showed no\nmicroorganisms. PCRs for herpes simplex virus type 1 and 2,\nvaricella-zoster virus and enteroviruses were negative. Serology for\n_Borrellia burgdorferi_ and tick-borne encephalitis virus showed no\nsigns of active infection.\n\nBecause the patient had stayed on the island of Elba, TOSV meningitis\nwas considered and confirmed by indirect immunofluorescence that\nshowed high titres of anti-TOSV IgM and IgG, antibodies\n('Sandfliegenfieber-Viren-Mosaik,' Euroimmun, Lubeck, Germany).\nAntibody titres against other sandfly fever viruses (sandfly fever\nNaples virus (SFNV), sandfly fever Sicilian virus (SFSV), and sandfly\nfever Cyprus virus (SNCV)) were found to be low or negative. Although\na PCR of the CSF taken on the day of admission could not detect TOSV\ngenome, the negative PCR result does not exclude an acute infection\nwith TOSV, as the virus rapidly becomes undetectable after the\nappearance of antibodies.\n\nThe patient recovered completely within 3 days. Apart from analgetic\nmedication, no further treatment was necessary.\n\nDiscussion\n---------\nTOSV belongs to the genus _Phlebovirus_, family _Bunyaviridae_. The\ngenus _Phlebovirus_ currently comprises 68 antigenically distinct\nserotypes, 8 of which have been linked to diseases in humans. Three\n_Phlebovirus_serotypes are of importance in Europe: SFSV, SFNV and\nTOSV. While the 1st 2 cause a febrile illness, TOSV is characterized\nby its neurotropism and the clinical characteristics of meningitis,\nmeningoencephalitis and influenza-like illness. As stated in several\nstudies and case reports, TOSV is circulating not only in Italy but\nalso in Algeria, Spain, Portugal, France and Cyprus [2-9]. In central\nItaly, a seroprevalence of approximately 20 percent could be detected\n[10], whereas in Granada, southern Spain, the overall prevalence of\nanti-TOSV IgG antibodies was almost 25 percent [11]. In both\ncountries, the seroprevalence was significantly higher in older age\ngroups and in the rural population, indicating exposure throughout\nlife and a higher vector density in the rural areas.\n\nTransmission of the virus to humans results from the bite of small\nfemale phlebotomine sandflies (_P. perniciosus_ and _P. perfiliewi_).\nThe activity of sandflies is mainly crepuscular or nocturnal. During\nthe summer months, concomitant with the period of maximum activity of\nthe sandfly vectors in August, TOSV appears to be one of the major\nviral pathogens causing aseptic meningitis in tourists as well as in\nthe local population of the Mediterranean countries [12].\n\nTOSV infections have an incubation period of 3 to 6 days. The\nclinical picture is variable: In addition to meningitis and\nmeningoencephalitis, few cases of encephalitis without meningitis\nhave been described [13]. The high seroprevalence suggests that\nasymptomatic infection is rather common and TOSV, therefore, probably\nunder-recognized. In a study performed in the area around Florence,\nSiena and Arezzo, forestry workers with high occupational risk of\nTOSV infection showed a seropositivity rate of over 75 percent, with\nnegative history of neurological symptoms. This confirms that TOSV\ninfection can be very mild or even completely free of symptoms [10].\n\nTo our knowledge, this is the 1st description of TOSV meningitis\nacquired on the island of Elba. However, the geographic proximity to\nareas where the disease is endemic and which have a very similar\nclimate, suggest that phlebotomes occur on Elba. Despite millions of\nvisiting tourists and an increasing number of TOSV infections around\nthe Mediterranean Basin, TOSV is still rarely considered as the cause\nof aseptic meningitis in returning travelers. Either it is not\ndiagnosed, or the manifestation rate of severe infections is very\nlow. Patients returning from the Mediterranean and also from the\nisland of Elba and complaining of CNS symptoms should be tested for\nTOSV infection.\n\nReferences\n--------\n[1] Portolani M, Sabbatini AM, Beretti F, Gennari W, Tamassia MG,\nPecorari M. Symptomatic infections by Toscana virus in the Modena\nprovince in the triennium 1999-2001. New Microbiol. 2002;25(4);485-8.\n\n[2] Mendoza-Montero J, Gamez-Rueda MI, Navarro-Mari JM, de la Rosa-\nFraile M, Oyonarte-Gomez S. Infections due to sandfly fever virus\nserotype Toscana in Spain. Clin Infec Dis. 1998;27(3):434-6.\n\n[3] Ehrnst A, Peters CJ, Niklasson B, Svedmyr A, Holmgren B.\nNeurovirulent Toscana virus (a sandfly fever virus) in Swedish man\nafter visit to Portugal. Lancet 1985;1(8439): 1212-3.\n\n[4] Calisher CH, Weinberg AN, Muth DJ, Lazuick JS. Toscana virus\ninfection in United States citizen returning from Italy. Lancet.\n1987;1(8525):165-6.\n\n[5] Endris RG, Perkins PV. Transmission of Toscana virus by sandflies\nin Italy. Lancet 1987;1(8536):808-9.\n\n[6] Eitrem R, Vene S, Niklasson B. Incidence of sand fly fever among\nSwedish United Nations soldiers on Cyprus during 1985. Am J Trop Med\nHyg. 1990;43(2):207-11.\n\n[7] Eitrem R, Niklasson B, Weiland O. Sandfly fever among Swedish\ntourists (1991). Scand J Infect Dis. 1991;23(4):451-7.\n\n[8] Schwarz TF, Gilch S, Jager G. Travel-related Toscana virus\ninfection. Lancet. 1993; 342(8874):803-4.\n\n[9] Dobler G, Treib J, Haass A, Frosner G, Woesner R, Schimrigk K.\nToscana virus infection in German travellers returning from the\nMediterranean. Infection. 1997;25(5):325.\n\n[10] Valassina M, Valentini M, Pugliese A, Valensin PE, Cusi MG.\nSerological survey of Toscana virus infections in high risk\npopulation in Italy. Clin Diagn Lab Immunol. 2003;10(3):483-4.\n\n[11] Sanbonmatsu-Gamez S, Perez-Ruiz M, Collao X, Sanchez-Seco MP,\nMorillas-Marquez F, de la Rosa-Fraile M, et al. Toscana Virus in\nSpain. Emerg Infect Dis. 2005;11(11):1701-7.\n\n[12] Valassina M, Meacci F, Valensin PE, Cusi MG. Detection of\nneurotropic viruses circulating in Tuscany: the incisive role of\nToscana virus. J Med Virol. 2000;60(1):86-90.\n\n[13] Dionisio D, Valassina M, Ciufolini MG, Vivarelli A, Esperti F,\nCusi MG, et al. Encephalitis without meningitis due to fever virus\nserotype Toscana. Clin Infect Dis. 2001;32(8):1241-3.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[TOSV infection may be one of the arboviral diseases extending its\nrange into Europe as a consequence of climatic change. In view of the\nincreasing prevalence of the virus and its vector, TOSV infection\nshould be considered increasingly as cause of aseptic meningitis in\nresidents and travelers returning from the Mediterranean region.\n\nA map of the island of Elba is available at:\n<http://www.planetware.com/i/map/I/island-of-elba-map.jpg>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Italy is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=42.8,12.1,5>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "By B Sonderegger 1, H Hachler2, G Dobler3, M Frei4\n1 Department of Medicine, Hospital of Lucerne, Switzerland\n2 Institute of Medical Microbiology, Hospital of Lucerne, Switzerland\n3 Institute of Microbiology of the Bundeswehr, Munich, Germany\n4 Medical Practice for Tropical and Travel Medicine, Lucerne, Switzerland\n\nWe describe a case of aseptic meningitis due to Toscana virus\nimported to Switzerland and discuss the epidemiological situation. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 8 Jan 2009\n Although\na PCR of the CSF taken on the day of admission could not detect TOSV\ngenome, the negative PCR result does not exclude an acute infection\nwith TOSV, as the virus rapidly becomes undetectable after the\nappearance of antibodies. Other arthropod-borne viruses\nthat can cause clinical signs of meningoencephalitis, such as West\nNile virus, have been detected in other parts of Europe and also in\ncountries around Switzerland (e.g. Italy, France), but not as yet in\nSwitzerland itself. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), taken on the day of\nadmission, was clear and showed a white blood cell count of 196/mm3\n(85 percent mononuclear cells), protein levels of 0.75 g/L, and\nglucose levels of 3.7 mmol/L (the glucose level in the blood was 6.9\nmmol/L). In Switzerland, aseptic meningitis is frequently encountered and most\noften caused by enteroviruses, flaviviruses (tick-borne\nencephalitis), herpes simplex virus type 1 and 2, varicella-zoster\nvirus or mumps and measles viruses. In view of the\nincreasing prevalence of the virus and its vector, TOSV infection\nshould be considered increasingly as cause of aseptic meningitis in\nresidents and travelers returning from the Mediterranean region. \n\nBecause the patient had stayed on the island of Elba, TOSV meningitis\nwas considered and confirmed by indirect immunofluorescence that\nshowed high titres of anti-TOSV IgM and IgG, antibodies\n 14, Issue 1 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19079>\n\n\nImported aseptic meningitis due to Toscana virus acquired on the\nisland of Elba, Italy, August 2008\n the summer months, concomitant with the period of maximum activity of\nthe sandfly vectors in August, TOSV appears to be one of the major\nviral pathogens causing aseptic meningitis in tourists as well as in\nthe local population of the Mediterranean countries [12]. Despite millions of\nvisiting tourists and an increasing number of TOSV infections around\nthe Mediterranean Basin, TOSV is still rarely considered as the cause\nof aseptic meningitis in returning travelers. In a study performed in the area around Florence,\nSiena and Arezzo, forestry workers with high occupational risk of\nTOSV infection showed a seropositivity rate of over 75 percent, with\nnegative history of neurological symptoms. In both\ncountries, the seroprevalence was significantly higher in older age\ngroups and in the rural population, indicating exposure throughout\nlife and a higher vector density in the rural areas. From 27 to 31 Jul\n2008, he had stayed at a campsite east of Portoferraio before moving\nto the southern part of the island (near Marina di Campo) for the\nremaining week. Toscana virus (TOSV) was 1st isolated from a\nsandfly (_Phlebotomus peniciosus_) in central Italy in 1971 and\nidentified as a common cause of aseptic meningitis in this country. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[TOSV infection may be one of the arboviral diseases extending its\nrange into Europe as a consequence of climatic change. While the 1st 2 cause a febrile illness, TOSV is characterized\nby its neurotropism and the clinical characteristics of meningitis,\nmeningoencephalitis and influenza-like illness. [1] Portolani M, Sabbatini AM, Beretti F, Gennari W, Tamassia MG,\nPecorari M. Symptomatic infections by Toscana virus in the Modena\nprovince in the triennium 1999-2001. \nSerological survey of Toscana virus infections in high risk\npopulation in Italy. Studies carried out in Italy have shown that the virus\ncirculates not only in Tuscany but also in other regions such as\nEmilia Romagna, Marches, Umbria and Piedmont [1]. In addition to meningitis and\nmeningoencephalitis, few cases of encephalitis without meningitis\nhave been described [13]. Detection of\nneurotropic viruses circulating in Tuscany: the incisive role of\nToscana virus. To\nour knowledge, this is the 1st description of this infection acquired\non the island of Elba. Patients returning from the Mediterranean and also from the\nisland of Elba and complaining of CNS symptoms should be tested for\nTOSV infection. VIRUS - SWITZERLAND ex ITALY (ELBA)\n***********************************************\n The high seroprevalence suggests that\nasymptomatic infection is rather common and TOSV, therefore, probably\nunder-recognized. On 10 Aug 2008, a man in his 20s was admitted to the emergency\ndepartment of the Hospital of Lucerne, based in the central part of\nSwitzerland. The\ngenus _Phlebovirus_ currently comprises 68 antigenically distinct\nserotypes, 8 of which have been linked to diseases in humans. So far, no data can\nbe found about infections acquired on the islands off the coast of\nTuscany, including Elba. As stated in several\nstudies and case reports, TOSV is circulating not only in Italy but\nalso in Algeria, Spain, Portugal, France and Cyprus [2-9]. The entire holiday was spent exclusively on Elba,\nwith no major stopovers on the way home from Piombino, the mainland\nport for the ferry to Elba. Either it is not\ndiagnosed, or the manifestation rate of severe infections is very\nlow. However, the geographic proximity to\nareas where the disease is endemic and which have a very similar\nclimate, suggest that phlebotomes occur on Elba. Three\n_Phlebovirus_serotypes are of importance in Europe: SFSV, SFNV and\nTOSV. Infections due to sandfly fever virus\nserotype Toscana in Spain.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "varicella"], "syndromes": ["influenza-like illness", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-01-08 00:00:00", "1212-03-26 00:00:00", "1985-03-26 00:00:00", "1991-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-08-26 00:00:00", "1993-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-08-26 00:00:00", "2008-08-08 00:00:00", "2008-08-10 00:00:00", "1971-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tamassia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Elba", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Modena", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Piombino", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "Grenada"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "Algeria"}, {"location": "Lucerne", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Lubeck , Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Munich", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Sanchez", "country": "Dominican Republic"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "108146", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Brazil: (SP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=108146", "date": "2008-09-03 03:00:31", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BRAZIL: (SAO PAULO)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 29 Aug 2008\nSource: Regiao Noroeste [in Portuguese, trans. & summ. Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.regiaonoroeste.com/home.php?content=materias&id=15623>\n\n\nThe region of Sao Jose do Rio Preto, to which Catanduva belongs, had twice\nthe number of confirmed cases of meningococcal meningitis, the most serious\ntype, in the 1st 8 months of this year [2008] as were seen throughout 2007.\nIn 2007 there were 12 cases altogether; this year 24 already, 7 of them in\nSao Jose do Rio Preto.\n\nAccording to the State of Sao Paulo secretary of health, up to 26 Aug 2008,\n264 cases of [meningitis] were registered in the region, 24 of which were\nthe meningococcal type. Last year [2007], from January to December, there\nwere 362 cases of the disease, 12 of which were the meningococcal type.\n\nOnly this month [August 2008], in Novo Horizonte there was one confirmed\ncase of meningococcal meningitis type C and in Urupes one death.\n\nThe secretaries of health are not planning mass vaccination.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Making a quick calculation, the region shows no difference from the rest\nof the state [in the overall meningitis rate], around 1.75 cases per 100\n000 inhabitants, a rate consistent with historical values for the state.\nIf, however, further analysis of strains shows they are all the same\nphenotype or genotype, then measures should be reconsidered. - Mod.LJS\n\nThere are at least 13 _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the\nantigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides; infections due\nserogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135 are most common.\n\nInvasive meningococcal disease (bacteremia and meningitis) is a contagious\nbacterial infection caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_. _N. meningitidis_\ncolonizes the nasopharynx, and is spread by respiratory droplets. Household\nmembers and other close contacts who may be exposed to the index case's\nrespiratory excretions have the highest documented risk of secondary\ndisease during the 1st 7 days of a case being detected. Chemoprophylaxis is\nrecommended for those in close contact with a person with a meningococcal\ninfection to prevent secondary cases by eradicating _N. meningitidis_ from\nthe nasopharynx. Chemoprophylactic agents include rifampin, ciprofloxacin,\nand ceftriaxone.\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO (World Health Organization) recommends mass\nvaccination with the appropriate vaccine in every involved district in an\nattempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is blocked when a\ncritical percentage of the population have been vaccinated\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>).\n\nImmunity following meningococcal vaccination is serogroup-specific. All\nserogroup polysaccharides, except B, are immunogenic in humans. There are\nseveral different types of meningococcal vaccines. Polysaccharide vaccines,\nwhich have been available for more than 30 years, exist against serogroups\nA, C, Y, and W-135 in various combinations (such as, a bivalent AC,\ntrivalent ACW-135, and a tetravalent ACYW-135 polysaccharide vaccine).\nThere is a monovalent conjugate vaccine against serogroup C and a\ntetravalent against serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135.\n\nExcept for one patient, the serogroups of meningococcus involved in the\ncurrent Brazilian outbreak are not specified in the report above, but\noutbreaks in Brazil in the past have been both B and C (see ProMED-mail:\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Brazil 19960125.0182). Perhaps no mass\nvaccination program is being planned at present because serogroup B is the\nmain pathogen. We await more information on the nature of the serogroups\ninvolved in this outbreak.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Brazil, showing Sao Jose do\nRio Preto and Novo Horizonte in the north western region of the state of\nSao Paulo, can be found at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=-10.8,-53.1,4>. -\nMod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 29 Aug 2008\n \n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO (World Health Organization) recommends mass\nvaccination with the appropriate vaccine in every involved district in an\nattempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is blocked when a\ncritical percentage of the population have been vaccinated\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). Except for one patient, the serogroups of meningococcus involved in the\ncurrent Brazilian outbreak are not specified in the report above, but\noutbreaks in Brazil in the past have been both B and C (see ProMED-mail:\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Brazil 19960125.0182). Chemoprophylaxis is\nrecommended for those in close contact with a person with a meningococcal\ninfection to prevent secondary cases by eradicating _N. meningitidis_ from\nthe nasopharynx. Household\nmembers and other close contacts who may be exposed to the index case's\nrespiratory excretions have the highest documented risk of secondary\ndisease during the 1st 7 days of a case being detected. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Making a quick calculation, the region shows no difference from the rest\nof the state [in the overall meningitis rate], around 1.75 cases per 100\n000 inhabitants, a rate consistent with historical values for the state. MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BRAZIL: (SAO PAULO)\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-08-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sao Paulo", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Sao Jose", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Urupes", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "141083", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - Ecuador: (Los Rios)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=141083", "date": "2008-12-31 15:00:41", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS \u0096 ECUADOR: (LOS RIOS)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 30 Dec 2008\nSource: El Comercio, Ecuador [in Spanish, trans. & summ. Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.elcomercio.com/noticiaEC.asp?id_noticia=246645&id_seccion=8>\n\n\nA study by researcher Luiggi Martini has confirmed that consumption of\nraw snails caused an outbreak in the area of La Ercilia, San Eduardo,\nZapotal parish, Ventanas canton, in Los R\u00edos province. The inquiry by\nMartini, an official and former director of the Izquieta Perez\nInstitute of Hygiene, began after 10 patients were diagnosed with\neosinophilic meningoencephalitis, caused by a parasite found in snails.\n\nThe symptoms were: neurological disorders, constipation, vomiting,\nnausea, abdominal pain (see graphics in original). The 1st to be\naffected were from the coastal province. The provincial director of\nLos Rios province, Carlos Paz, confirmed to this newspaper that 10\npeople had been affected, and another 25-year-old man died [of it] in\nthe Luis Vernaza hospital of Guayaquil on 22 Jul 2008. Martini\nmaintains in his 21-page report that this is the 1st record of\ninfection in rats by the parasite _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ in\nEcuador and in South America. [Not the 1st for S. America -- see\ncomment below. - Mod.JW]\n\nAccording to history, the parasite was 1st described by HT Chen in\n1935 and was the 1st rat lungworm. In 1937, another worm was obtained\nfrom a rat in Taiwan, a new species. This infection has also appeared\nin Egypt and in Southeast Asia, in Pacific Rim countries such as\nThailand, Vietnam, Japan, and in Hawaii.\n\nOn Mon 22 Dec 2008 there was a meeting of all health authorities to\ndetermine what action to take, because the problem also involves\ncommerce, the export of snails. Paz denied that the species which is\nused for human consumption is involved, because only wild-caught\nsnails were infected. Therefore, the official cautioned that he has\nset up an 'epidemiological barrier' to prevent spread of the parasite.\n\nUsually, it lives in the pulmonary arteries of rats. Martini does not\nknow exactly how it came into the country. 'It most likely came in\nsnails imported by the domestic industry. When improperly handled on\nfarms, they were accessible to wild rats which became infected for the\n1st time.'\n\nLos Rios is not only affected but also Santo Domingo de las Tsachilas.\nThe director of the Eugenio Espejo hospital in Quito [the capital],\nMarco Ortega, confirmed yesterday that 3 weeks ago 2 people in that\njurisdiction had this health problem. On 18 Nov 2008, 3 people were\nvisiting an area near Santo Domingo, where they collected at least 3\npounds of snails, which they ate raw with lemon and salt.\n\nDays later, one of them, a 20-year-old man, had abdominal pain, fever\nand pain in knees and hips. He was admitted to Eugenio Espejo hospital\non 26 Nov 2008. After 12 days his symptoms worsened, adding slightly\nstiff neck and alteration of consciousness. Doctors diagnosed severe\nmeningitis caused by the parasite, _A. cantonensis_, which lives in\nsnails. He remains hospitalized.\n\nHis brother, aged 17, entered this hospital on 1 Dec 2008, with\nsimilar symptoms. He, according to Flores, ate fewer snails. 'He was\ndischarged 15 days ago and is out of danger,' doctors said. 'But he\nhas a lot of pain when walking.' The 3rd person was not admitted to\nhospital; he had only tasted the flavored juice of the snails.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are the 1st human cases of angiostrongyliasis in humans from\nEcuador. All had been eating snails. Previously, the parasite has been\ndemonstrated in naturally infected snails of various genera and\nspecies in northeastern Brazil, which has also reported cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the same areas. As is well known, _A.\ncantonensis_ has repeatedly been reported as a cause of human disease\nin the Caribbean, particularly in Cuba, and reported previously by\nProMED from Dominica, Brazil, and the USA. It is a potential risk in\nNorth and Central America, where there are snails and rodents infected\nwith the parasite.\n\nPicture and life cycle of Agiostrongylus:\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>\n- Mods.JT/EP]\n\n[A map showing the location of Ecuador in South America is available at:\n<http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcecuador.htm>\n- CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 30 Dec 2008\n Previously, the parasite has been\ndemonstrated in naturally infected snails of various genera and\nspecies in northeastern Brazil, which has also reported cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the same areas. The provincial director of\nLos Rios province, Carlos Paz, confirmed to this newspaper that 10\npeople had been affected, and another 25-year-old man died [of it] in\nthe Luis Vernaza hospital of Guayaquil on 22 Jul 2008. The inquiry by\nMartini, an official and former director of the Izquieta Perez\nInstitute of Hygiene, began after 10 patients were diagnosed with\neosinophilic meningoencephalitis, caused by a parasite found in snails. Communicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are the 1st human cases of angiostrongyliasis in humans from\nEcuador. JT/EP]\n\n[A map showing the location of Ecuador in South America is available at:\n<http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcecuador.htm>\n- CopyEd.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-11-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2008-12-26 00:00:00", "1935-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2008-12-01 00:00:00", "2008-11-26 00:00:00", "1937-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "El Comercio", "country": "Honduras"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Dominica", "country": "Dominica"}, {"location": "Ventanas", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "Quito", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "Domingo", "country": "Dominican Republic"}, {"location": "Los R\u00edos", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "Cuba", "country": "Cuba"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Los Rios", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "San Eduardo", "country": "Colombia"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "Ecuador"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "107499", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Enterovirus infection, meningitis - Russia: (Vladivostok)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=107499", "date": "2008-08-31 13:00:31", "main_text": "ENTEROVIRUS INFECTION, MENINGITIS - RUSSIA: (VLADIVOSTOK)\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 27 Aug 2008\nSource: MKRU Srochno online (translated by correspondent AS) [edited]\n<http://www.mk.ru/blogs/MK/2008/08/27/srochno/367979/>\n\n\nAn outbreak of enterovirus infection in Vladivostok\n---------------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of enterovirus infection has occurred in the city of\nVladivostok. About 300 cases have been registered, 269 of whom are\nchildren. In half of the cases the disease developed into serous (aseptic)\nmeningitis, which can have serious consequences. Galina Shklyar, the senior\ninfectious diseases specialist in Vladivostok, said that all the infections\noccurred as a consequence of people swimming in the sea around the shores\nof the territory.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Enteroviral infections are common in childhood. The enteroviruses include\nnumerous strains of coxsackievirus, echovirus, enterovirus, and poliovirus.\nEnteroviral infections are most common in communities living in conditions\nof poor hygiene.\n\nThe infection begins when material contaminated with the virus is\nswallowed. The virus then reproduces in the digestive tract. The body's\nimmune defenses stop many infections at this stage, and the result is few\nor no symptoms. Colds and upper respiratory infections are common outcomes\nof infection with enteroviruses. Sometimes the virus survives and spreads\ninto the bloodstream, resulting in fever, headache, sore throat, and, at\ntimes, vomiting.\n\nSerous (aseptic) meningitis affects the membranes covering the brain and\nspinal cord (meninges), causing severe headache, stiff neck, and\nsensitivity to light. Enteroviral infections usually resolve completely,\nbut infections of the heart or central nervous system are occasionally fatal.\n\nA map of Russia showing the city of Vladivostok in the extreme east can be\naccessed at <http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/asia/rularge.htm>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 27 Aug 2008\n Galina Shklyar, the senior\ninfectious diseases specialist in Vladivostok, said that all the infections\noccurred as a consequence of people swimming in the sea around the shores\nof the territory. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n< \n\nSerous (aseptic) meningitis affects the membranes covering the brain and\nspinal cord (meninges), causing severe headache, stiff neck, and\nsensitivity to light. The body's\nimmune defenses stop many infections at this stage, and the result is few\nor no symptoms. Sometimes the virus survives and spreads\ninto the bloodstream, resulting in fever, headache, sore throat, and, at\ntimes, vomiting. ENTEROVIRUS INFECTION, MENINGITIS - RUSSIA: (VLADIVOSTOK)\n*********************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "66207", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=66207", "date": "2008-03-14 04:57:18", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BURKINA FASO\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Mar 2008\nSource: AFP [edited]\n<http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gmr_qpwl3yxumZyJNui2s7exTXkg>\n\n\nA meningitis outbreak in Burkina Faso has infected thousands of people,\nkilling hundreds, in the past 2 months, the health ministry told the AFP\nThursday [6 March 2008]. 'We have identified 3181 suspected cases of\nmeningitis from 1 Jan 2008 until 2 Mar 2008, of whom 366 have died,' said\nDoctor Ousmane Badolo, head of epidemiology surveillance at the ministry of\nhealth.\n\nFourteen districts are affected, 5 of which have declared a state of\nepidemic. Of those, 2 have been downgraded following vaccination campaigns.\nBadolo said Burkina Faso had enough vaccines to cover all infected\ndistricts although needs could change if the outbreak worsens.\n\nMeningitis is very contagious, causing fever, dizziness, vomiting, and a\nstiff neck. It becomes an epidemic when 10 out of 100 000 inhabitants have\ncontracted it. Health minister Alain Bedouma announced Wednesday [5 Mar\n2008] that Burkina Faso managed to raise over 4.5 million euros [7 025\n217.87 USD] from numerous international donor countries and organisations\nfor a plan to fight the disease that was set up in 2007. In 2007 an\nepidemic killed more than 2000 people in 9 West African countries, 75 per\ncent of them in Burkina Faso, according to United Nations agencies.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The meningococcal meningitis outbreak in Burkina Faso continues to worsen.\nAccording to a prior ProMED-mail post (Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa:\nmeningitis belt 20080225.0756), Burkina Faso was the most affected country\nwith a total of 1422 cases, including 204 deaths (case fatality rate 14.3\nper cent) reported from 1 Jan to 10 Feb 2008. At that time these cases\nrepresent more than 61 per cent of all cases reported to the WHO\nMulti-Disease Surveillance Centre in 2008 (against 64 per cent for the same\nperiod in 2007). _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A was identified as the\ncausative agent in 2 of the Burkina Faso districts, where vaccination\ntargeted the 2 to 29 year old population. See prior ProMED-mail posts\nlisted below for more information.\n\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Mar 2008\n According to a prior ProMED-mail post (Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa:\nmeningitis belt 20080225.0756), Burkina Faso was the most affected country\nwith a total of 1422 cases, including 204 deaths (case fatality rate 14.3\nper cent) reported from 1 Jan to 10 Feb 2008. 'We have identified 3181 suspected cases of\nmeningitis from 1 Jan 2008 until 2 Mar 2008, of whom 366 have died,' said\nDoctor Ousmane Badolo, head of epidemiology surveillance at the ministry of\nhealth. Health minister Alain Bedouma announced Wednesday [5 Mar\n2008] that Burkina Faso managed to raise over 4.5 million euros [7 025\n217.87 USD] from numerous international donor countries and organisations\nfor a plan to fight the disease that was set up in 2007. A meningitis outbreak in Burkina Faso has infected thousands of people,\nkilling hundreds, in the past 2 months, the health ministry told the AFP\n _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup A was identified as the\ncausative agent in 2 of the Burkina Faso districts, where vaccination\ntargeted the 2 to 29 year old population. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-01-01 00:00:00", "1422-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2008-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "52270", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=52270", "date": "2008-01-25 11:00:15", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA: WEST AFRICA (BURKINA FASO,\nNIGERIA, NIGER), CONGO DR\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 17 Jan 2008\nFrom: AllAfrica, IRIN (UN Integrated Regional Information Networks)\nreport [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200801170957.html>\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) has confirmed outbreaks of the\ndeadly meningitis bacterium [_Neisseria meningitidis_] in 3 West\nAfrican countries, marking the start of what experts have warned\nmight be the worst meningitis epidemic to hit Africa in a decade.\n'One district is on alert in Burkina Faso, an epidemic has been\nreported in a region of Nigeria, and there are 2 cases in Niger, as\nwell as cases in the Democratic Republic of Congo,' Professor Kader\nKonde, director of WHO's Ouagadougou [the capital of Burkina\nFaso]-based Multi-Disease Surveillance Centre (MDSC) told IRIN\n[Integrated Regional Information Networks, commonly known as IRIN, is\na project of the United Nations Office for the Coordination of\nHumanitarian Affairs].\nThe WHO warned in October [2007] that 80 million people out of\nroughly 350 million who live in 21 African countries stretching from\nEthiopia in the east to Mauritania in the west might need to be\nvaccinated against the bacterium [_Neisseria meningitidis] this year\n[2008]. Meningococcal meningitis, which usually reaches epidemic\nlevels in the region often referred to as Africa's 'meningitis belt'\nbetween December and May, could be especially severe this year [2008]\nas the region is heading toward the peak of a 10- to 12-year cycle of\nmeningitis crises, health forecasters say.\nBetween 1995 and 1997, the last time there was a major epidemic in\nthe region, at least 25 000 people died and 250 000 people were\ninfected. From December 2006 to May 2007, 53 000 cases of meningitis\nwere reported and an estimated 4000 people died across the region.\nSemi-arid Sahelian countries are hit each year by outbreaks during\nthe dry seasons between December and June when strong, dust-laden\nwinds and cold nights make people more prone to respiratory\ninfections. The meningitis bacterium is transmitted by sneezing or\ncoughing. According to Konde, the situation could be worse this year\n[2008] because of high dust levels in the region and the low level of\nimmunity among populations. He said new research by WHO and national\nresearch centres also appears to have shown a new strain of the\nbacterium. 'If you take into account all these factors we find\nourselves in a situation where the risk [of epidemics] is high,' Konde said.\nPreparedness for meningitis epidemics is notoriously difficult\nbecause vaccines cannot be administered until it is known which of\nthe many different forms of the bacterium are spreading. In\n2006-2007, the humanitarian response was further hindered by a\nshortfall of the cheaper vaccines usually used in the region as\nEuropean producers focused on producing newer, longer-lasting but\nmore expensive vaccines. Just 7 million doses were available. In\n2008, between 25 million and 30 million doses could be available,\naccording to WHO. 'We do find ourselves in a more favourable\nsituation than last year [2007],' Konde said.\nEmergency health officials are due to meet in Dakar next week [21-27\nJan 2008] to coordinate responses to the expected epidemic. Hans\nHebbing, regional health coordinator of the International Federation\nof the Red Cross, told IRIN the Federation has already started\ntraining 25 000 volunteers across the region, and is educating people\nabout how to recognise meningitis and the dangers. 'We know this is\nnot really going to prevent a major outbreak. But we're hoping that\nearly activity can prevent some spread of the disease and we do know\nthat training and preparedness can make the response faster,' he said.\nMeningitis is an infection of the thin lining around the brain and\nspinal cord. Even when meningitis is diagnosed early and adequate\ntherapy is available, between 5 and 10 percent of patients die,\ntypically within 24 and 48 hours of experiencing the 1st symptoms.\nMany thousands of survivors are left with brain damage, hearing loss,\nor learning disabilities.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSidi Coulibaly\n<sidi_couly@yahoo.ca>\n[Meningitis due to the _Neisseria meningitidis_ occurs both\nsporadically and as epidemics. There are at least 13 serogroups,\nbased on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides;\ndisease due serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135 are most common. All\nserogroup polysaccharides but B, are immunogenic in humans.\nFrom a prior ProMED-mail post (20071207.3954): To control an\noutbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate\nvaccine, depending availability, in every involved district in an\nattempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is blocked when\na critical percentage of the population have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>).\nThere are several different types of meningococcal vaccines.\nPolysaccharide vaccines, which have been available for more than 30\nyears, exist against serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various\ncombinations (such as, a bivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a\ntetravalent ACYW-135 polysaccharide vaccine). There is a monovalent\nconjugate vaccine against serogroup C and a tetravalent against\nserogroups A, C, Y, and W-135. The conjugate vaccines are immunogenic\nfor children under 2 years of age whereas polysaccharide vaccines are\nnot. All these vaccines have been proven safe and effective with\ninfrequent and mild side effects. For both the meningococcal\nconjugate and the polysaccharide vaccines, approximately 7-10 days\nare required following vaccination for development of protective\nlevels of anti-meningococcal antibodies.\nDuring the 1st 10 weeks of the 2006 meningitis season, outbreaks in\neastern Africa were mainly caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup W-135, whereas in West Africa the outbreak was due to\nmainly serogroup A. The serogroups currently spreading in sub-Saharan\nAfrica are not stated in the news release above.\nFor a map of the African meningitis belt, see\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "From: AllAfrica, IRIN (UN Integrated Regional Information Networks)\nreport [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200801170957.html>\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) has confirmed outbreaks of the\ndeadly meningitis bacterium [_Neisseria meningitidis_] in 3 West\nAfrican countries, marking the start of what experts have warned\nmight be the worst meningitis epidemic to hit Africa in a decade. From a prior ProMED-mail post (20071207.3954): To control an\noutbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate\nvaccine, depending availability, in every involved district in an\nattempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is blocked when\na critical percentage of the population have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Meningococcal meningitis, which usually reaches epidemic\nlevels in the region often referred to as Africa's 'meningitis belt'\nbetween December and May, could be especially severe this year [2008]\nas the region is heading toward the peak of a 10- to 12-year cycle of\nmeningitis crises, health forecasters say. The WHO warned in October [2007] that 80 million people out of\nroughly 350 million who live in 21 African countries stretching from\nEthiopia in the east to Mauritania in the west might need to be\nvaccinated against the bacterium [_Neisseria meningitidis] this year\n In\n2006-2007, the humanitarian response was further hindered by a\nshortfall of the cheaper vaccines usually used in the region as\nEuropean producers focused on producing newer, longer-lasting but\nmore expensive vaccines. Hans\nHebbing, regional health coordinator of the International Federation\nof the Red Cross, told IRIN the Federation has already started\ntraining 25 000 volunteers across the region, and is educating people\nabout how to recognise meningitis and the dangers. ' \nCommunicated by:\nSidi Coulibaly\n<sidi_couly@yahoo.ca>\n During the 1st 10 weeks of the 2006 meningitis season, outbreaks in\neastern Africa were mainly caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup W-135, whereas in West Africa the outbreak was due to\nmainly serogroup A. For both the meningococcal\nconjugate and the polysaccharide vaccines, approximately 7-10 days\nare required following vaccination for development of protective\nlevels of anti-meningococcal antibodies. Polysaccharide vaccines, which have been available for more than 30\nyears, exist against serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various\ncombinations (such as, a bivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a\ntetravalent ACYW-135 polysaccharide vaccine). Semi-arid Sahelian countries are hit each year by outbreaks during\nthe dry seasons between December and June when strong, dust-laden\nwinds and cold nights make people more prone to respiratory\ninfections. One district is on alert in Burkina Faso, an epidemic has been\nreported in a region of Nigeria, and there are 2 cases in Niger, as\nwell as cases in the Democratic Republic of Congo,' Professor Kader\nKonde, director of WHO's Ouagadougou (BURKINA FASO,\nNIGERIA, NIGER), CONGO DR\n*********************************************************\n Between 1995 and 1997, the last time there was a major epidemic in\nthe region, at least 25 000 people died and 250 000 people were\ninfected. Preparedness for meningitis epidemics is notoriously difficult\nbecause vaccines cannot be administered until it is known which of\nthe many different forms of the bacterium are spreading. Even when meningitis is diagnosed early and adequate\ntherapy is available, between 5 and 10 percent of patients die,\ntypically within 24 and 48 hours of experiencing the 1st symptoms. The conjugate vaccines are immunogenic\nfor children under 2 years of age whereas polysaccharide vaccines are\nnot.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-10-26 00:00:00", "2008-01-17 00:00:00", "2006-12-26 00:00:00", "2007-05-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "Mauritania"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "WEST AFRICA", "country": "Somalia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "72020", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=72020", "date": "2008-04-12 12:00:19", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BURKINA FASO (02): VACCINATED AREAS\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 11 Apr 2008\nSource: allAfrica.com [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200804110048.html>\n\n\nPeople vaccinated against meningitis are supposed to have protection\nfor 3 years but health officials have announced that meningitis\nepidemics have occurred in several areas where populations had\nrecently been immunized.\n\n'[Health researchers] are currently collecting information so as to\nidentify the factors explaining the recurrence of the epidemic in\ndistricts where populations have been vaccinated', Ousmane Badolo,\nhead of the epidemiologic surveillance department at the ministry of\nhealth, told IRIN. Vaccination campaigns target people between 2 to\n30 years old; according to the ministry of health, 80 to 90 percent\nof the victims of meningitis belong to that age group.\n\nA total of 714 people have died since 1 January out of 7184 cases.\n\nSeveral different bacteria can cause meningitis which is an\ninflammation of the protective membranes covering the central nervous\nsystem. The Neisseria sero-group is one of the most important to\nwatch because it often leads to epidemics, experts say. Badolo, the\nepidemiologist, said that health research teams from the UN World\nHealth Organization and US-based Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention have come to Burkina Faso to investigate.\n\n'This is the first time that such research is being conducted,'\nBadolo said, adding that at this stage he could only guess why the\nvaccination programmes have not worked. 'Perhaps it is because of\npopulation displacement,' he said, 'for instance in gold mining areas\npeople are often coming and going.'\n\nThe health researchers will focus their work on the districts of Reo\nin the central west of the country, Boulsa in the central north,\nTitao in the north and in Sig-nonghin a district in the north of the\ncapital Ouagadougou. The populations in each of those 4 districts\nwere vaccinated last year [2007]; yet each has reached epidemic\nthresholds. A total of 5 out of the country's 55 districts have\nreached the epidemic threshold and 14 others are on alert.\n\nMeanwhile, 3.5 million people have been vaccinated this year [2008]\nout of a population of 14 million. The government said it is in the\nprocess of procuring a million more vaccines with the help of UN\nChildren's Agency UNICEF.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nCoulibaly Sidi\n<sidi_couly@yahoo.ca>\n\n[The number of total cases of meningitis in Burkina Faso has more\nthan doubled and the number of deaths has about doubled since the\nlast report (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Burkina\nFaso 20080314.1017).\n\nThere are at least 13 _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on\nthe antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides; disease\ndue serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135 are most common. According to a\nprior ProMED post Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis\nbelt 20080225.0756, _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was identified as\nthe presumptive causative agent of this outbreak in 2 of the Burkina\nFaso districts. Serogroup A has been the predominant cause of\nmeningitis outbreaks in the African meningitis belt (in which Burkina\nFaso is located) that recur at intervals of 7-14 years and result in\nexcessive morbidity and mortality among children and young adults. In\nrecent years, group W135 meningococci have also caused outbreaks in\nthis region.\n\nAll serogroup polysaccharides but B, are immunogenic in humans. There\nare several different types of meningococcal vaccines. Polysaccharide\nvaccines, which have been available for more than 30 years, exist\nagainst serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various combinations (such\nas, a bivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a tetravalent ACYW-135\npolysaccharide vaccine). There is a monovalent conjugate vaccine\nagainst serogroup C and a tetravalent against serogroups A, C, Y, and\nW-135. The type of meningococcal vaccine used in the current outbreak\nin Burkina Faso is not specified.\n\nImmunity following meningococcal vaccination is serogroup-specific.\nOne possible explanation of vaccine failure is a mismatch in the\npredominant meningococcal serogroup causing the Burkina Faso outbreak\nand the serogroup specificity of the vaccine. Another possibility is\nthe outbreak is due to an organism other than _N. meningitidis_.\n\nVaccine stability could be an additional problem. There had been a\nrecall in 2002 of Menomune-A/C/Y/W-135 (Meningococcal Polysaccharide\nVaccine, groups A, C, Y and W-135 Combined) because of loss of\nserogroup A potency in this multivalent vaccine. Inability to\nvaccinate enough of the susceptible population to induce herd\nimmunity may be another explanation. We await the results of the WHO\nand U.S. CDC investigation.\n\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nCoulibaly Sidi\n<sidi_couly@yahoo.ca>\n\n[The number of total cases of meningitis in Burkina Faso has more\nthan doubled and the number of deaths has about doubled since the\nlast report (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Burkina\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 11 Apr 2008\n Source: allAfrica.com [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200804110048.html>\n\n\nPeople vaccinated against meningitis are supposed to have protection\nfor 3 years but health officials have announced that meningitis\nepidemics have occurred in several areas where populations had\nrecently been immunized. According to a\nprior ProMED post Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis\nbelt 20080225.0756, _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A was identified as\nthe presumptive causative agent of this outbreak in 2 of the Burkina\n [Health researchers] are currently collecting information so as to\nidentify the factors explaining the recurrence of the epidemic in\ndistricts where populations have been vaccinated', Ousmane Badolo,\nhead of the epidemiologic surveillance department at the ministry of\nhealth, told IRIN. Polysaccharide\nvaccines, which have been available for more than 30 years, exist\nagainst serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various combinations (such\nas, a bivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a tetravalent ACYW-135\npolysaccharide vaccine). Serogroup A has been the predominant cause of\nmeningitis outbreaks in the African meningitis belt (in which Burkina\nFaso is located) that recur at intervals of 7-14 years and result in\nexcessive morbidity and mortality among children and young adults. \n\nThe health researchers will focus their work on the districts of Reo\nin the central west of the country, Boulsa in the central north,\nTitao in the north and in Sig-nonghin a district in the north of the\ncapital Ouagadougou. There had been a\nrecall in 2002 of Menomune-A/C/Y/W-135 (Meningococcal Polysaccharide\nVaccine, groups A, C, Y and W-135 Combined) because of loss of\nserogroup A potency in this multivalent vaccine. Badolo, the\nepidemiologist, said that health research teams from the UN World\nHealth Organization and US-based Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention have come to Burkina Faso to investigate. One possible explanation of vaccine failure is a mismatch in the\npredominant meningococcal serogroup causing the Burkina Faso outbreak\nand the serogroup specificity of the vaccine. Vaccination campaigns target people between 2 to\n30 years old; according to the ministry of health, 80 to 90 percent\nof the victims of meningitis belong to that age group. \n\nSeveral different bacteria can cause meningitis which is an\ninflammation of the protective membranes covering the central nervous\nsystem.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-01-01 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Ouagadougou", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "58468", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal, drug resistant - USA (MN, ND)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=58468", "date": "2008-02-15 18:00:15", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - DRUG-RESISTANT - USA (MINNESOTA, NORTH DAKOTA)\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 9 Feb 2008\nSource: Pioneer Press [edited]\n<http://www.twincities.com/ci_8213242?source=rss>\n\n\nThe nation's 1st known cases of antibiotic-resistant meningococcal\ndisease surfaced in northwest Minnesota and eastern North Dakota over\nthe past year [2007], according to the Minnesota Department of Health.\nHealth authorities on Friday [8 Feb 2008] asked doctors in the Fargo\n[North Dakota]/Moorhead [Minnesota] area to stop using ciprofloxacin\nfor preventive treatment of people in close contact with\nmeningococcal patients and to use antibiotics outside the quinolone family.\n\nThe drug-resistant strains are the latest evidence of antibiotic\noveruse, particularly in patients whose colds are viral and not\nbacterial. 'Even though there are other drugs that can be used to\nprevent meningococcal disease, having one less weapon in our arsenal\nreminds us of the importance of appropriate antibiotic use,' said\nDr. Ruth Lynfield, state epidemiologist.\n\nThe 2 Minnesota cases turned up last month [January 2008], one\ninvolving a 53-year-old from Marshall County [Minnesota] who died and\na 2nd involving a 22-year-old student at Minnesota State\nUniversity-Moorhead. The North Dakota case in January 2007 involved a\nchild at a Fargo daycare facility. The bacterial strains in all 3\ncases are similar, but the patients had no known connections. Health\nofficials believe these strains are simply circulating in the region.\nAs many as 15 percent of people can have a meningococcal bacteria in\ntheir throats or noses at any given time, but only a few suffer\nsevere infections.\n\nFederal officials have been anticipating such a case. An official\nfrom the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)\ntraveled to the region Thursday [7 Feb 2008] and was taking random\nthroat swabs in an attempt to find someone carrying the\ndrug-resistant bacteria.\n\nClose friends of the patients have been treated as a precaution, so\nthe CDC official will go to college campuses, bars and other\nhigh-traffic locations. The infected student took music lessons, so\nother music students might be tested, said Richard Danila, assistant\nstate epidemiologist. Danila stressed that these 1st cases are\nsignificant but shouldn't worry the general public or cause people to\ndemand preventive treatment.\n\nThat the strain in the 53-year-old who died was drug-resistant didn't\nfactor into the fatality, Danila said, as patients with the infection\naren't treated with ciprofloxacin. All 3 patients developed\nmeningitis, a swelling of the brain and spinal cord, and required\nhospital care. Minnesota is one of a dozen or so states that test\nmeningococcal strains for antibiotic resistance. That partly explains\nwhy the 1st case was discovered here.\n\n[Vaccination for meningococcal meningitis is] recommended for the\n11-18 age group and for college freshmen [age 18-20. - Mod.JW]. While\na vaccine protects against two-thirds of these bacterial infections,\nit wouldn't have worked against this particular strain. The vaccine is\nrecommended for children ages 11 to 18 and college freshmen.\nMeningitis cases are somewhat rare, with an average of 24 per year\nsince 2000 in Minnesota. A total of 22 deaths have been linked to the\nbacterial infection from 2000 through 2006 in the state, 10 of them\ninvolving people 23 or younger.\n\n****The antibiotic-resistant cases reported Friday [8 Feb 2008] were\nthe 1st on\nrecord in the USA.*****\n\n[Byline: Jeremy Olson]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Invasive meningococcal disease (bacteremia and meningitis) is a\ncontagious bacterial infection caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_.\n_N. meningitidis_ colonizes the nasopharynx, and is spread by\nrespiratory droplets. Household members and other close contacts who\nmay be exposed to the index case's respiratory excretions have the\nhighest documented risk of secondary disease during the 1st 7 days of\na case being detected. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended for those in\nclose contact with a person with a meningococcal infection to prevent\nsecondary cases by eradicating _N. meningitidis_ from the\nnasopharynx. Chemoprophylaxis is also used to cover the delay between\nvaccination and the development of protective antibodies.\n\nChemprophylactic agents include rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and\nceftriaxone. Emergence of rifampin-resistance has been reported\nfollowing chemoprophylactic use of rifampin (Fraser A, et al.\nAntibiotics for preventing meningococcal infections. Cochrane\nDatabase Syst Rev. 2006 Oct 18;(4):CD004785). These authors raised\nconcerns about the clonal spread of these resistant isolates;\nhowever, rifampin-resistant isolates are rarely reported (Taha M-K,\net al. Rifampin-resistant Neisseria meningitidis. (LETTERS). Emerging\nInfectious Diseases 2006; 12:859-60).\n\nFluoroquinolone-resistance is usually due to accumulation of point\nmutations in the genes (e.g., gyrA and parC genes) encoding DNA\ngyrase and topoisomerase IV, the targets for these antimicrobial\nagents. There are 5 previous reports of sporadic instances of\ndecreased susceptibility to ciprofloxacin due to point mutations in\nthe quinolone resistance determining region (QRDR) of the gyrA gene:\n1) Serogroup B isolate with decreased susceptibility to ciprofloxacin\nin the nasopharynx of a Parisian STD clinic patient in 1999 and 2) in\nthe CSF of a child in Spain in 2002 (Alcala B, et al. _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_ showing decreased susceptibility to ciprofloxacin: 1st\nreport in Spain. J Antimicrob Chemother. 2004;53:409); 3) Serogroup C\nisolate in blood and CSF of a nursing student in Australia in 1998\n(Shultz TR et al. Antimicrob Agents Chemother 2000; 44:1116); 4)\nSerogroup Y and B from 2 patients in Argentina in 2002 (Corso A, et\nal. Emergence of _Neisseria meningitidis_ with decreased\nsusceptibility to ciprofloxacin in Argentina. J Antimicrob Chemother\n2005;55:596-7); and 5) Serogroup A in 12 of 14 strains from a 2005\noutbreak in Delhi, India\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/EID/content/13/10/1614.htm>).\n\nThe above news release states that infection due to the strain\ninvolved in the 3 U.S.A. cases could not be prevented by vaccination.\nBecause vaccines are available for serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135, we\ncan assume that the strain involved in these 3 cases was serogroup B\nfor which there is no an effective vaccine. The news release also\nstates that the 3 strains were 'similar;' but does not say if this\nwas on the basis of DNA fingerprinting, which would be helpful to\nidentify an expansion of a single clone in the community.\n\nThe news release intimates that the strains were susceptible to drugs\nused to treat meningococcal meningitis, which include the 3rd\ngeneration cephalosporins (ceftriaxone and cefotaxime), penicillin,\nand chloramphenicol. Relative resistance to penicillin has been\ninfrequently reported due to decreased affinity of target\npenicillin-binding proteins for penicillin and less commonly to\nbeta-lactamase production. Rare isolates that are\nchloramphenicol-resistance have been reported (N Engl J Med 1998;\n339:368-74 & 917-8).\n\nHorizontal exchange of genes that encode resistance for penicillin,\nrifampin and the fluoroquionolones from other _Neisseria_ species\nthat share a common ecological niche with _N. meningitidis_ in the\nnasopharynx has been proposed as one possible mechanism acquisition\nof meningococcal antibiotic resistance\n(<http://jac.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/49/3/545>).\n\nA map that locates Fargo, ND, and northwest Minnesota can be found at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "There are 5 previous reports of sporadic instances of\ndecreased susceptibility to ciprofloxacin due to point mutations in\nthe quinolone resistance determining region (QRDR) of the gyrA gene:\n1) Serogroup B isolate with decreased susceptibility to ciprofloxacin\nin the nasopharynx of a Parisian STD clinic patient in 1999 and 2) in\nthe CSF of a child in Spain in 2002 (Alcala B, et al. Horizontal exchange of genes that encode resistance for penicillin,\nrifampin and the fluoroquionolones from other _Neisseria_ species\nthat share a common ecological niche with _N. meningitidis_ in the\nnasopharynx has been proposed as one possible mechanism acquisition\nof meningococcal antibiotic resistance\n(<http://jac.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/49/3/545>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 9 Feb 2008\n An official\nfrom the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)\ntraveled to the region Thursday [7 Feb 2008] and was taking random\nthroat swabs in an attempt to find someone carrying the\ndrug-resistant bacteria. \n\nThe 2 Minnesota cases turned up last month [January 2008], one\ninvolving a 53-year-old from Marshall County [Minnesota] who died and\na 2nd involving a 22-year-old student at Minnesota State\nUniversity-Moorhead. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended for those in\nclose contact with a person with a meningococcal infection to prevent\nsecondary cases by eradicating _N. meningitidis_ from the\nnasopharynx. These authors raised\nconcerns about the clonal spread of these resistant isolates;\nhowever, rifampin-resistant isolates are rarely reported (Taha M-K,\net al. The news release intimates that the strains were susceptible to drugs\nused to treat meningococcal meningitis, which include the 3rd\ngeneration cephalosporins (ceftriaxone and cefotaxime), penicillin,\nand chloramphenicol. \n\nFluoroquinolone-resistance is usually due to accumulation of point\nmutations in the genes (e.g., gyrA and parC genes) encoding DNA\ngyrase and topoisomerase IV, the targets for these antimicrobial\nagents. Even though there are other drugs that can be used to\nprevent meningococcal disease, having one less weapon in our arsenal\nreminds us of the importance of appropriate antibiotic use,' said\nDr. Ruth Lynfield, state epidemiologist. Household members and other close contacts who\nmay be exposed to the index case's respiratory excretions have the\nhighest documented risk of secondary disease during the 1st 7 days of\na case being detected. The news release also\nstates that the 3 strains were 'similar;' but does not say if this\nwas on the basis of DNA fingerprinting, which would be helpful to\nidentify an expansion of a single clone in the community. The nation's 1st known cases of antibiotic-resistant meningococcal\ndisease surfaced in northwest Minnesota and eastern North Dakota over\nthe past year [2007], according to the Minnesota Department of Health. \n\nThe above news release states that infection due to the strain\ninvolved in the 3 U.S.A. cases could not be prevented by vaccination.\n Communicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Invasive meningococcal disease (bacteremia and meningitis) is a\ncontagious bacterial infection caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_. That the strain in the 53-year-old who died was drug-resistant didn't\nfactor into the fatality, Danila said, as patients with the infection\naren't treated with ciprofloxacin.
