Neisseria\nmeningitidis_ showing decreased susceptibility to ciprofloxacin: 1st\nreport in Spain.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-01-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-02-08 00:00:00", "2008-01-26 00:00:00", "1999-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-02-07 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "North Dakota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "India"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "MINNESOTA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Marshall County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "57592", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=57592", "date": "2008-02-12 23:00:16", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 11 Feb 2008\nSource: AllAfrica [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200802120003.html>\n\n\nUp to one million people in the Central African Republic (CAR) are at\nrisk from a meningitis epidemic sweeping across the northwest of\ntheir country, and overwhelmed local health authorities do not have\nenough vaccine stocks to meet demands, the United Nations Office for\nthe Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) warned today [11 Feb 2008].\n\nAn outbreak was declared after numerous deaths were reported in the\ndistricts of Ouham, Ouham Pende and Nana-Grebizi in the first 5 weeks\nof this year, OCHA said in a press statement. UN agencies,\nnon-governmental organizations (NGOs) and the country's government\nare working together to try to combat the epidemic. Following a\nrequest from the World Health Organization (WHO), some USD 100 000\nhas been released from the UN's Emergency Response Fund (ERF) for the\nCAR so that enough vaccines can be bought to protect about 80 000 people.\n\nJohn Holmes, the Under-Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and\nEmergency Relief Coordinator, said that 'protecting the people in the\nnorth of the Central African Republic will prevent meningitis from\nspreading to the rest of the country and into neighbouring Chad.'\n\nToby Lanzer, the UN Humanitarian Coordinator in the country, said the\nERF injection has ensured that aid workers can immediately help many\nof those who need vaccines. 'We count on donors to continue\nsupporting our efforts so that more lives can be saved,' he said.\n\nThe meningitis epidemic is the latest crisis to hit the CAR, which\nhas been buffeted by deadly fighting between government forces and\narmed rebels and also by widespread bandit attacks against civilians.\nLife expectancy in the impoverished, landlocked nation stands at just\n43 [years].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nCoulibaly Sidi\n<sidi_couly@yahoo.ca>\n\n[The above news release presumably refers to a meningococcal\nmeningitis outbreak. According to a prior ProMED post, archive\nnumber 20080125.0309, the WHO warned in October 2007 that 80 million\npeople out of roughly 350 million who live in 21 African countries\nthat constitutes the so-called meningococcal meningitis belt,\nstretching from Ethiopia and Eritrea in the east to Senegal and\nMauritania in the west, might need to be vaccinated against the\nbacterium, _Neisseria meningitides_, in 2008. The African\nmeningococcal meningitis belt includes the northern portion of the\nCentral African Republic (CAR). A map of the African bacterial\nmeningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>.\n\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in this\nregion of Africa each year during the dry season, between December\nand June, and every 6-12 years a large outbreak occurs\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nWHO warned that meningitis could be especially severe in 2008 as the\nregion is anticipated to be heading toward the peak of a 6- to\n12-year cycle of meningococcal meningitis (see ProMED post, archive\nnumber 20080125.0309). Mass vaccination with the appropriate\nserogroup-spcific meningococcal vaccine is used in involved districts\nin an attempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is\nblocked when a critical percentage of the population have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). The\nserogroups of _N. meningitides_ involved in the current outbreak in\nthe CAR are not specified in the above news release, although\noutbreaks reported in surrounding countries have been due to\nserogroups A and W135 (see prior ProMED posts below).\n\nThe CAR, a former French colony, is a sparsely populated (about 4.3\nmillion people), landlocked country, bordered on the north and east\nby Chad and Sudan, on the west by Cameroon and on the south by the\nDemocratic Republic of the Congo and the Republic of the Congo. The\nCAR is one of the world's least developed countries, with a 2002\nannual per capita income of USD 260; agriculture accounts for 55\npercent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP), with most of\nthe population engaged in subsistence farming. There are more than 80\nethnic groups in the Central African Republic, each with its own\nlanguage. The CAR is beset by ethnic tensions and continued civil\nunrest, as are its neighbors. The U.S. Department of State has\nstrongly advised American citizens not to travel to the CAR because\nof heightened security concerns as a result of fighting between\nrebels and government forces in the north prefectures of the country\n(<http://www.travel.state.gov/travel/cis_pa_tw/tw/tw_940.html>). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "According to a prior ProMED post, archive\nnumber 20080125.0309, the WHO warned in October 2007 that 80 million\npeople out of roughly 350 million who live in 21 African countries\nthat constitutes the so-called meningococcal meningitis belt,\nstretching from Ethiopia and Eritrea in the east to Senegal and\nMauritania in the west, might need to be vaccinated against the\nbacterium, _Neisseria meningitides_, in 2008. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 11 Feb 2008\n Up to one million people in the Central African Republic (CAR) are at\nrisk from a meningitis epidemic sweeping across the northwest of\ntheir country, and overwhelmed local health authorities do not have\nenough vaccine stocks to meet demands, the United Nations Office for\nthe Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) warned today The\nCAR is one of the world's least developed countries, with a 2002\nannual per capita income of USD 260; agriculture accounts for 55\npercent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP), with most of\nthe population engaged in subsistence farming. Mass vaccination with the appropriate\nserogroup-spcific meningococcal vaccine is used in involved districts\nin an attempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is\nblocked when a critical percentage of the population have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). The\nserogroups of _N. meningitides_ involved in the current outbreak in\nthe CAR are not specified in the above news release, although\noutbreaks reported in surrounding countries have been due to\nserogroups A and W135 (see prior ProMED posts below). The U.S. Department of State has\nstrongly advised American citizens not to travel to the CAR because\nof heightened security concerns as a result of fighting between\nrebels and government forces in the north prefectures of the country\n(<http://www.travel.state.gov/travel/cis_pa_tw/tw/tw_940.html>). \n\nWHO warned that meningitis could be especially severe in 2008 as the\nregion is anticipated to be heading toward the peak of a 6- to\n12-year cycle of meningococcal meningitis (see ProMED post, archive\nnumber 20080125.0309). \n\nJohn Holmes, the Under-Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and\nEmergency Relief Coordinator, said that 'protecting the people in the\nnorth of the Central African Republic will prevent meningitis from\nspreading to the rest of the country and into neighbouring Chad.'", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-10-26 00:00:00", "2008-02-11 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "the \n Democratic Republic of the", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Eritrea", "country": "Eritrea"}, {"location": "Ouham", "country": "Central African Republic"}, {"location": "the Republic of the Congo", "country": "DR Congo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "61103", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=61103", "date": "2008-02-25 03:00:16", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA: MENINGITIS BELT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Feb 2008\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2008_02_22a/en/index.html>\n\n\nThe WHO Multi-Disease Surveillance Centre in Ouagadougou (MDSC - Burkina\nFaso) is monitoring the meningitis situation in the African meningitis belt\nthroughout the epidemic season and, in particular, in 13 countries under\nenhanced seasonal surveillance: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, the Central\nAfrican Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the\nCongo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger, Nigeria and Togo.\n\nPreliminary reports from these countries are of a total of 2312 cases (324\ndeaths) occurring between 1 Jan and 10 Feb 2008. These figures are 29 per\ncent lower than those reported in the same 6 week period in 2007 (3274\ncases, 413 deaths) indicating lower levels of meningitis activity so far in\n2008.\n\nAmong countries reporting cases to the MDSC, Burkina Faso, the Central\nAfrican Republic and the Democratic Republic of the Congo have been\nreporting outbreaks since the beginning of the season. Other countries\nreporting meningitis activity without reaching the epidemic threshold at\ndistrict level include Benin, Cote d'Ivoire, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger,\nNigeria and Togo. Cameroon and Chad have not reported any cases. Burkina\nFaso is the most affected country with a total of 1422 cases, including 204\ndeaths (case fatality ratio [CFR] 14.3 per cent) reported from 1 Jan to 10\nFeb 2008. These cases represent more than 61 per cent of all cases reported\nto MDSC in 2008 (against 64 per cent for the same period in 2007).\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ [seogroup] A (Nm A) was identified as the\ncausative agent in Mangodara and Sapouy districts. Vaccination was carried\nout in these districts as well as in Gaoua, targeting the 2 to 29 year old\npopulation. A cross border assessment is being carried out on the situation\nin Ivory Coast in the area neighboring Mangodara district. Although the\nepidemiological trend in Burkina Faso is similar to the one observed last\nyear [2007], the 1st 6 weeks of 2007 saw more cases reported in total as\nwell as more districts reaching the epidemic threshold (8 as against 2 in\n2008).\n\nThe Ministry of Health in the Central African Republic is launching\nreactive mass vaccination campaigns in some of the communes that have\nreached the epidemic threshold in the northern prefecture of Nana-Gribizi.\nA total of 45 cases, including 5 deaths (CFR 11.1 per cent) had been\nreported by the end of week 6, and Nm A has been identified as the\nresponsible pathogen. International partners including WHO and the\nInternational Coordination Group (ICG) are providing support for the\nvaccination campaigns.\n\nIn the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a situation assessment is being\ncarried out in Aru district (that neighbours Arua district in Uganda),\nwhere 167 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 10.2 per cent) were reported\nduring the period from 1 Jan to 10 Feb 2008. The most affected areas\ninclude Laybo, Ariwara and Aungba health zones. The Aru district also\nexperienced an outbreak in early 2007.\n\nIn southern Sudan, a situation assessment is being carried out in areas\nwhere suspected cases were reported, including in Awerial, Bor, Jur River\nand Torit Counties. Uganda experienced an outbreak in Arua district, West\nNile region, with a total of 380 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 4.5 per\ncent) reported from 13 Dec 2007 to 28 Jan 2008. A sharp decline in the\nweekly case count was observed following a mass vaccination campaign that\nwas implemented in week 4. No suspected cases have been reported from other\ncountries within the meningitis belt, namely Eritrea, Guinea, the Gambia,\nKenya, Mauritania and Senegal.\n\nSo far in 2008, the ICG has provided 40 000 vaccine doses, injection\nmaterial and safety disposal boxes for vaccination campaigns in the Central\nAfrican Republic. The current ICG stockpile, available for outbreak\nresponse in this meningitis season stands at 7 million doses of bivalent\npolysaccharide A/C vaccine and 3.3 million doses of trivalent\npolysaccharide vaccine A/C/W135.\n\nFor more information on submitting requests for vaccines through the ICG\nand regional meningitis surveillance, see links below.\n- International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic\nMeningitis Control\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/icg/en/index.html>\n- Epidemiological information\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/epidemiological/en/index/html>.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a nice up to date summary from WHO concerning the ongoing\nmeningococcal meningitis outbreak in the African bacterial meningitis belt.\nSee prior ProMED-mail posts listed below for more information. A map of the\nAfrican bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n- International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic\nMeningitis Control\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/icg/en/index.html>\n- Epidemiological information\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/epidemiological/en/index/html>.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a nice up to date summary from WHO concerning the ongoing\nmeningococcal meningitis outbreak in the African bacterial meningitis belt. The WHO Multi-Disease Surveillance Centre in Ouagadougou (MDSC - Burkina\nFaso) is monitoring the meningitis situation in the African meningitis belt\nthroughout the epidemic season and, in particular, in 13 countries under\nenhanced seasonal surveillance: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, the Central\nAfrican Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Feb 2008\n Although the\nepidemiological trend in Burkina Faso is similar to the one observed last\nyear [2007], the 1st 6 weeks of 2007 saw more cases reported in total as\nwell as more districts reaching the epidemic threshold (8 as against 2 in\n2008). In the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a situation assessment is being\ncarried out in Aru district (that neighbours Arua district in Uganda),\nwhere 167 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 10.2 per cent) were reported\nduring the period from 1 Jan to 10 Feb 2008. These figures are 29 per\ncent lower than those reported in the same 6 week period in 2007 (3274\ncases, 413 deaths) indicating lower levels of meningitis activity so far in\n2008. The current ICG stockpile, available for outbreak\nresponse in this meningitis season stands at 7 million doses of bivalent\npolysaccharide A/C vaccine and 3.3 million doses of trivalent\npolysaccharide vaccine A/C/W135. Other countries\nreporting meningitis activity without reaching the epidemic threshold at\ndistrict level include Benin, Cote d'Ivoire, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger,\nNigeria and Togo. Uganda experienced an outbreak in Arua district, West\nNile region, with a total of 380 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 4.5 per\ncent) reported from 13 Dec 2007 to 28 Jan 2008. Faso is the most affected country with a total of 1422 cases, including 204\ndeaths (case fatality ratio [CFR] 14.3 per cent) reported from 1 Jan to 10\nFeb 2008. A total of 45 cases, including 5 deaths (CFR 11.1 per cent) had been\nreported by the end of week 6, and Nm A has been identified as the\nresponsible pathogen. In southern Sudan, a situation assessment is being carried out in areas\nwhere suspected cases were reported, including in Awerial, Bor, Jur River\nand Torit Counties. No suspected cases have been reported from other\ncountries within the meningitis belt, namely Eritrea, Guinea, the Gambia,\nKenya, Mauritania and Senegal.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2312-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-01-28 00:00:00", "1422-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ouagadougou", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Eritrea", "country": "Eritrea"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "Mali"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Ariwara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Mangodara", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Gaoua", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "Mauritania"}, {"location": "Awerial", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "Guinea"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Gambia", "country": "Gambia"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the Congo", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Laybo", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Ivory Coast", "country": "Ivory Coast"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "44557", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (Veneto)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=44557", "date": "2007-12-22 22:00:26", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - ITALY (VENETO)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 21 Dec 2007\nFrom: Giuseppe Michieli [edited]\n<gimi69@libero.it>\n\nCases [of meningococcal meningitis] 1st appeared a week ago with an\ninitial cluster of 7 cases localized in several small towns near\nTreviso (Montebelluna, Conegliano Veneto, Pederobba), involving young\nadults (age 15-33 years old), most from Latin American countries who\nattended a dance party. Of these cases, 3 died (a 15-year-old boy, a\n30-year-old African migrant, and a local woman). All, except the\nAfrican migrant who died at home, were admitted to an ICU in critical\ncondition with meningitis and septic shock.\nAround 1000 inhabitants of the towns and immediate contacts [of the\npatients with meningitis were given] post-exposure antibiotic\nprophylaxis and none developed illness.\nA 25-year-old male student at Padua University has been hospitalized\nin critical condition after developing meningococcal meningitis.\n[This student] is from Conegliano Veneto and spent last week-end\n[15-16 Dec 2007] in his town. No obvious epidemiological link with\nother patients exists.\nLaboratory tests conducted at microbiological facility in Padua\n(Professor Palu) detected serotype C meningococcus.\nCase contacts (roomates, parents, friends, other students and\nteachers) received post-exposure prophylaxis with antibiotic.\nMinistry of Health dispatched to Veneto at least 50 000 doses of\nspecific vaccine to be administered to residents in Treviso province\n15- to 29-year [of age]. Childhood vaccination is already mandatory\nin Veneto for meningococcal meningitis.\nMinistry of Health sent communications regarding this outbreak to\nEuropean Health authorities and WHO GOARN.\nSee more at:\n<http://www.iss.it> (Istituto Superiore di Sanit=E0),\n<http://www.epicentro.iss.it> (EPICENTRO), and\n<http://www.ministerosalute.it> (Ministry of Health).\n--\nGiuseppe Michieli - Non-Health Care Worker\nVia Vittorio Saetta no. 26A\n35132 Padova - Italia\n<gimi69@libero.it>\n<giuseppe.michieli@gmail.com>\n[Meningitis due to the _Neisseria meningitidis_ occurs both\nsporadically and as epidemics. There are at least 13 serotypes, based\non the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides;\ndisease due serotypes A, B, C, Y and W-135 are most common. All\nserotype polysaccharides but B, are immunogenic in humans.\nFrom a prior ProMED-mail post (20071207.3954): To control an\noutbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate\nvaccine, depending availability, in every involved district in an\nattempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is blocked when\na critical percentage of the population have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). There are\nseveral different types of meningococcal vaccines. Polysaccharide\nvaccines, which have been available for more than 30 years, exist\nagainst serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various combinations (e.g.,\na bivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a tetravalent ACYW-135\npolysaccharide vaccine). There is a monovalent conjugate vaccine\nagainst serogroup C and a tetravalent against serogroups A, C, Y and\nW-135. The conjugate vaccines are immunogenic for children under 2\nyears of age whereas polysaccharide vaccines are not. All these\nvaccines have been proven to be safe and effective with infrequent\nand mild side effects. For both the meningococcal conjugate and the\npolysaccharide vaccines, approximately 7-10 days are required\nfollowing vaccination for development of protective levels of\nanti-meningococcal antibodies.\nSecondary cases of _N. meningitides_ infection usually occur within\n10 days of the primary cases among certain high-risk groups for which\nchemoprophylaxis is recommended. These groups include household\ncontacts, closed populations living with cases in college\ndormitories, long-term care institutions, nursery schools, or\nmilitary barracks, and close social contacts who are directly exposed\nto a case's oral secretions, for example by kissing, sharing eating\nutensils, or toothbrushes, in the week prior to onset of illness in\nthe primary case. Appropriate chemoprophylactic drugs include\nrifampin, ciprofloxacin or ceftriaxone. The nature of the exposure to\nthe primary cases of the 1000 inhabitants of the towns near Treviso\nwho received antibiotic chemoprophylaxis is not specified in the above report.\nA map of the Veneto region that includes the towns of Treviso,\nMontebelluna, Conegliano Veneto, and Pederobba of can be found at\n<http://en.comuni-italiani.it/026/mappa.html>. - Mod.ML]\n[ProMED-mail thanks to Maurizio Marcorelli <mkimar@tin.it> for\nsending information on the 3 fatal cases, mentioning that the 1st\ndeath occurred in an individual from Senegal. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "These groups include household\ncontacts, closed populations living with cases in college\ndormitories, long-term care institutions, nursery schools, or\nmilitary barracks, and close social contacts who are directly exposed\nto a case's oral secretions, for example by kissing, sharing eating\nutensils, or toothbrushes, in the week prior to onset of illness in\nthe primary case. From: Giuseppe Michieli [edited]\n<gimi69@libero.it>\n\nCases [of meningococcal meningitis] 1st appeared a week ago with an\ninitial cluster of 7 cases localized in several small towns near\nTreviso (Montebelluna, Conegliano Veneto, Pederobba), involving young\nadults (age 15-33 years old), most from Latin American countries who\nattended a dance party. From a prior ProMED-mail post (20071207.3954): To control an\noutbreak, WHO recommends mass vaccination with the appropriate\nvaccine, depending availability, in every involved district in an\nattempt to induce herd immunity (whereby transmission is blocked when\na critical percentage of the population have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Polysaccharide\nvaccines, which have been available for more than 30 years, exist\nagainst serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in various combinations (e.g.,\na bivalent AC, trivalent ACW-135, and a tetravalent ACYW-135\npolysaccharide vaccine). \nSee more at:\n<http://www.iss.it> (Istituto Superiore di Sanit=E0),\n<http://www.epicentro.iss.it> (EPICENTRO), and\n<http://www.ministerosalute.it> (Ministry of Health). 26A\n35132 Padova - Italia\n<gimi69@libero.it>\n<giuseppe.michieli@gmail.com>\n For both the meningococcal conjugate and the\npolysaccharide vaccines, approximately 7-10 days are required\nfollowing vaccination for development of protective levels of\nanti-meningococcal antibodies. \nSecondary cases of _N. meningitides_ infection usually occur within\n10 days of the primary cases among certain high-risk groups for which\nchemoprophylaxis is recommended. Around 1000 inhabitants of the towns and immediate contacts [of the\npatients with meningitis were given] post-exposure antibiotic\nprophylaxis and none developed illness. The nature of the exposure to\nthe primary cases of the 1000 inhabitants of the towns near Treviso\nwho received antibiotic chemoprophylaxis is not specified in the above report. A 25-year-old male student at Padua University has been hospitalized\nin critical condition after developing meningococcal meningitis.\n [ProMED-mail thanks to Maurizio Marcorelli <mkimar@tin.it> for\nsending information on the 3 fatal cases, mentioning that the 1st\ndeath occurred in an individual from Senegal. All, except the\nAfrican migrant who died at home, were admitted to an ICU in critical\ncondition with meningitis and septic shock. There are at least 13 serotypes, based\non the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides;\ndisease due serotypes A, B, C, Y and W-135 are most common.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Padua", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Treviso", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "Senegal"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "41640", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (Arua)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=41640", "date": "2007-12-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - UGANDA: (ARUA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n\nDate: Thu 6 Dec 2007\nSource: AllAfrica, New Vision (Kampala) [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200712060049.html>\n\n\nMr. Patrick Anguzu, the Arua District health\nofficer said the re-emergence of meningoccocal\nmeningitis that has been on a low key since 10\nJul 2007, had killed 27 people out of 255 registered cases.\n\n'The most affected areas are Arivu Subcounty in\nVurra County and parts of Upper Madi\n(constituency),' Mr. Anguzu said on phone\nyesterday [5 Dec 2007]. Dr. Sam Zaramba, the\ndirector general of health services, had earlier\nsaid medics in West Nile region had been put on\nhigh alert over the meningitis epidemic, which\nclaimed at least 65 lives among over 2000\ninfected persons when the disease struck in December 2006 to March this year.\n\nAt the time, the government with support from the\nWorld Health Organisation and MSF - France,\nundertook partial mass vaccinations in Arua,\nKoboko, Yumbe, Moyo and Nebbi districts, but this\ntime round, it is counties like Vurra in Arua,\nwhich were not covered during the immunization\nthat are registering the renewed infections.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Meningococcal meningitis occurs sporadically or\nas epidemics in sub-Saharan Africa, which is\nknown as the 'Meningitis Belt,' an area that\nstretches from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia\nand Eritrea in the east and that includes northern Uganda\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>).\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are\nreported in this region of Africa each year\nduring the dry season, between December and June,\nand every 6-12 years a large outbreak occurs\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nDuring the 1st 10 weeks of the 2006 meningitis\nseason, outbreaks in eastern Africa were mainly\ncaused by _Neisseria meningitides_ serogroup\nW-135, whereas in West Africa the outbreak was\ndue to mainly serogroup A. In the Gulu district\nof Uganda the predominant serogroup was W-135,\nbut serogroup A predominated in Uganda outside\nthis district. Gulu is located in the center of\nthe northern region, bordering Sudan and east of Arua\n(<http://www.gulu.go.ug/>).\n\nIn the Gulu district, the disease was noted in\n'Internally Displaced Persons' camps. Overcrowded\nhousing and large population displacements that\nundoubtedly characterized these camps likely\nfavored the transmission of _N. meningitides_. At\nthat time, the International Coordinating Group\n(ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic\nMeningitis Control provided 360 000 doses of\ntrivalent vaccine (polysaccharide vaccine for\nserotypes A, C, and W135) in an attempt to\ncontrol the outbreak (<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_03_21/en/index.html>).\n\nIn January 2007, a meningitis outbreak was again\nreported in Uganda, according to the WHO\n(<http://mediaglobal.org/index.php/2007/01/26/deadly-outbreak-in-africa%e2%80%99s-%e2%80%9cmeningitis-belt%e2%80%9d/>),\nin an 'area, which borders southern Sudan and\nthe Democratic Republic of Congo\u2026..[among] both\nrefugees and nationals living in 'rural, densely\npopulated settlements.' The most affected\ndistrict was said to be Arua. At the time, the\nmeningitis outbreak in South Sudan was reportedly\ncaused by serotype A, but the serotype causing\nthe meningitis outbreak in Uganda was not given.\nThe current outbreak is again occurring in the\nArua district, but 'this time round, it is\ncounties like Vurra in Arua, which were not\ncovered during the [prior] immunization [program].'\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass\nvaccination with the appropriate vaccine,\ndepending availability, in every involved\ndistrict in an attempt to induce herd immunity\n(whereby transmission is blocked when a critical\npercentage of the population have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>).\nThere are several different types of\nmeningococcal vaccines. Polysaccharide vaccines,\nwhich have been available for over 30 years,\nexist against serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in\nvarious combinations (e.g., a bivalent AC,\ntrivalent ACW-135, and a tetravalent ACYW-135\npolysaccharide vaccine). There is a monovalent\nconjugate vaccine against serogroup C and a\ntetravalent against serogroups A, C, Y and W-135.\nThe conjugate vaccines are immunogenic for\nchildren under 2 years of age whereas\npolysaccharide vaccines are not. All these\nvaccines have been proven to be safe and\neffective with infrequent and mild side effects.\nFor both the meningococcal conjugate and the\npolysaccharide vaccines, approximately 7-10 days\nare required following vaccination for\ndevelopment of protective levels of anti-meningococcal antibodies. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nTo control an outbreak, WHO recommends mass\nvaccination with the appropriate vaccine,\ndepending availability, in every involved\ndistrict in an attempt to induce herd immunity\n(whereby transmission is blocked when a critical\npercentage of the population have been vaccinated\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs141/en/>). \n\nAt the time, the government with support from the\nWorld Health Organisation and MSF - France,\nundertook partial mass vaccinations in Arua,\nKoboko, Yumbe, Moyo and Nebbi districts, but this\ntime round, it is counties like Vurra in Arua,\nwhich were not covered during the immunization\nthat are registering the renewed infections. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Meningococcal meningitis occurs sporadically or\nas epidemics in sub-Saharan Africa, which is\nknown as the 'Meningitis Belt,' an area that\nstretches from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia\nand Eritrea in the east and that includes northern Uganda\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). Polysaccharide vaccines,\nwhich have been available for over 30 years,\nexist against serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 in\nvarious combinations (e.g., a bivalent AC,\ntrivalent ACW-135, and a tetravalent ACYW-135\npolysaccharide vaccine). The girl, whose\nidentity wasn't released, was in critical condition Monday [23 Jul\n2007] at Wesley Medical Center [Wichita, KS], a hospital spokeswoman said.\nThe teen had traveled Saturday [21 Jul 2007] from Orlando, FL, to\nAtlanta on Flight 862 and then to Wichita on Flight 687, AirTran\nspokesman Dave Hirschman said. The crew called for an ambulance to\nmeet the plane at the gate after the girl became sick on the 2nd\nflight and unresponsive, he said. The airline notified the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention on Sunday[22 Jul 2007] .\nMeningitis, a bacterial infection of the lining surrounding the brain\nand spinal cord, primarily affects children, killing about 10 percent\nof those infected. Symptoms include a stiff neck, high fever,\nheadaches and vomiting. It can be contracted by direct close contact\nwith discharges from the nose or throat of an infected person, but\nnot through casual contact or breathing the same air.\nThe planes the girl traveled on have been thoroughly cleaned and\nreturned to service, and AirTran was notifying fewer than 20 people\nwho sat in her immediate vicinity, Hirschman said. The airline is a\nsubsidiary of AirTran Holdings Inc., based in Orlando, FL.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMuswell Hill\n<MuswellHillUK@aol.com>\n[Another hazard of airline travel: The news release suggests that a\nteenager developed a rapidly progressive illness while onboard\nairplane flights from Orlando to Atlanta and then Atlanta to Wichita,\nKS, that was diagnosed as bacterial meningitis. The patient is is now\nin critical condition at a hospital in Wichita. The exact bacterial\nspecies is not specified. Preceding symptoms and co-morbid conditions\nare not given.\nFor a map of the area see:\n<http://www.mapquest.com/maps/map.adp?city=wichita&state=ks>.\nAs a result of the control of _Haemophilus influenzae_ type b\ninfections that has followed _H. influenzae_ vaccination programs,\nmeningococcus is the major cause of meningitis in children and young\nadults. The pneumococcus is another possible etiologic agent in this\nage group. Meningococcal meningitis occurs sporadically or as\nepidemics. Certain types of close contact of a case of meningococcal\nmeningitis place a person at increased risk of developing meningitis\nfor which antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis is recommended. These\ncontacts include household members, daycare center members, and\nanyone directly exposed to the patient's respiratory secretions\n(e.g., by kissing, mouth-to-mouth resuscitation or intubation of the\npatient) (see:\n<http://0-www.cdc.gov.mill1.sjlibrary.org/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046263.htm>).\nAntibiotics recommended for chemoprophylaxis are rifampin,\nciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone. Chemoprophylaxis is not recommended\nfor school or work contacts. Chemoprophylaxis for contacts of\npneumococcal meningitis is not defined.\nAccording to the CDC, for management of airline passengers exposed to\nmeningococcal disease, household members traveling with the index\npatient as well as persons traveling with the index patient who have\nprolonged close contact (e.g., roommates, members of the same sports\nteam) should be identified and the need for antimicrobial\nchemoprophylaxis evaluated. Antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should\nalso be considered for airline passengers who have had direct contact\nwith respiratory secretions from the index patient, and for\npassengers seated directly next to the index patient on prolonged\nflights (>8 hours)\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/travel/menin-guidelines.htm>).\nBecause the risk for illness is highest during the first few days\nafter infection, chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as\npossible (ideally within 24 hours) after contact with an index case-patient\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm>).\nChemoprophylaxis administered >14 days is probably of limited or no\nvalue. For both the meningococcal conjugate and the polysaccharide\nvaccines, approximately 7-10 days are required following vaccination\nfor development of protective levels of anti-meningococcal\nantibodies. Meningococcal vaccination, however, is used to control\nspread of meningitis in outbreak situations. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "According to the CDC, for management of airline passengers exposed to\nmeningococcal disease, household members traveling with the index\npatient as well as persons traveling with the index patient who have\nprolonged close contact (e.g., roommates, members of the same sports\nteam) should be identified and the need for antimicrobial\nchemoprophylaxis evaluated. Antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should\nalso be considered for airline passengers who have had direct contact\nwith respiratory secretions from the index patient, and for\npassengers seated directly next to the index patient on prolonged\nflights (>8 hours)\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nCommunicated by:\nMuswell Hill\n<MuswellHillUK@aol.com>\n Because the risk for illness is highest during the first few days\nafter infection, chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as\npossible (ideally within 24 hours) after contact with an index case-patient\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5023a2.htm>). These\ncontacts include household members, daycare center members, and\nanyone directly exposed to the patient's respiratory secretions\n As a result of the control of _Haemophilus influenzae_ type b\ninfections that has followed _H. influenzae_ vaccination programs,\nmeningococcus is the major cause of meningitis in children and young\nadults. For both the meningococcal conjugate and the polysaccharide\nvaccines, approximately 7-10 days are required following vaccination\nfor development of protective levels of anti-meningococcal\nantibodies. Certain types of close contact of a case of meningococcal\nmeningitis place a person at increased risk of developing meningitis\nfor which antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis is recommended. A teenager who fell seriously ill on an AirTran Airways flight was\ndiagnosed with bacterial meningitis, and the airline was contacting\npassengers who sat near her, a spokesman said. Health authorities did not want to confirm or\ndeny the report yesterday. 'What I am sure of is, that apart from the\n3 old cases that were reported in Onandjokwe Hospital earlier, there\nare 6 new cases, but there might be more than that even,' said a source.\nAnother reliable source who informed The Namibian about the new cases\ncould not say which villages the patients were from. 'Yes, I received\na report of alleged new meningitis cases at Onandjokwe, but I was\nalso informed that these alleged cases of meningitis have still to be\ninvestigated and verified to determine whether they are really\nmeningitis or not,' the Permanent Secretary of Health, Kahijoro\nKahuure, told The Namibian late yesterday afternoon [4 Sep 2007].\nWhen approached for comment, hospital superintendent Dr. Fillemon\nAmaambo told The Namibian that he was busy with a meeting. The matron\nof the hospital, Monika Shilongo, referred the reporter to the\nOnandjokwe Hospital's chief administrator, Julius Mtuleni, and the\ncontrol register nurse, Penina Akudhenga. Both of these officials\nreferred questions to the Director of Health, Maria Kavezimbi, who in\nturn referred the reporter to the Permanent Secretary of Health and\nSocial Services.\nLast Wednesday [29 Aug 2007], the Regional Councillor of Eengodi\nConstituency, Walde Sheyavali, announced on the NBC's Oshiwambo radio\nservice that several cases of the disease had been reported at\nOnamakulikwa and Ohambala villages in Eengodi Constituency that week\nand that he had asked the Onandjokwe health workers to go and\nfamiliarise themselves with the situation. At that time Matron\nShilongo at the Onandjokwe Hospital said they were treating children\nfrom Onamakulikwa, Ohambala, Onkumbula and Ohashipepe villages for meningitis.\nShe said a boy from Omakunde village died of the disease at the\nbeginning of last month [August 2007]. Matron Shilongo also said then\nthat health workers had been sent to those villages to investigate\nthe disease and give information to the villagers. Regional Health\nDirector Kavezimbi had confirmed to The Namibian that 3 children were\nthen being treated for meningitis at the Onandjokwe Hospital.\n[Byline: Oswald Shivute]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nCoulibaly Sidi\n<sidi_couly@yahoo.ca>\n(by way of Larry Madoff)\n[A prior outbreak of meningitis that was presumed to be due to the\nmeningococcus at the time was reported in a ProMED posting in 2000\n(Meningitis - Namibia (North) 20001214.2182). For a discussion of\nmeningitis in Namibia, please see that report. ProMED requests\nfurther information on the current outbreak [including identification\nof the strain involved].\nFor a map of Namibia, please see\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/namibia.gif>. - Mod.ML]\n[Locator map:\n<http://www.localization-translation.com/images/maps/map-namibia.jpg>\nMap of African bacterial meningitis belt:\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>\nNamibia is nowhere near the ill-famed bacterial meningitis belt of\nAfrica -- see map above -- but nevertheless reports a few cases\nnearly every year. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Yes, I received\na report of alleged new meningitis cases at Onandjokwe, but I was\nalso informed that these alleged cases of meningitis have still to be\ninvestigated and verified to determine whether they are really\nmeningitis or not,' the Permanent Secretary of Health, [Locator map:\n<http://www.localization-translation.com/images/maps/map-namibia.jpg>\nMap of African bacterial meningitis belt:\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>\n At that time Matron\nShilongo at the Onandjokwe Hospital said they were treating children\nfrom Onamakulikwa, Ohambala, Onkumbula and Ohashipepe villages for meningitis.\n Last Wednesday [29 Aug 2007], the Regional Councillor of Eengodi\nConstituency, Walde Sheyavali, announced on the NBC's Oshiwambo radio\nservice that several cases of the disease had been reported at\nOnamakulikwa and Ohambala Regional Health\nDirector Kavezimbi had confirmed to The Namibian that 3 children were\nthen being treated for meningitis at the Onandjokwe Hospital.\n The matron\nof the hospital, Monika Shilongo, referred the reporter to the\nOnandjokwe Hospital's chief administrator, Julius Mtuleni, and the\ncontrol register nurse, Penina Akudhenga. What I am sure of is, that apart from the\n3 old cases that were reported in Onandjokwe Hospital earlier, there\nare 6 new cases, but there might be more than that even,' said a source. Source: The Namibian (Windhoek) [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/printable/200709050453.html>\n\nNew Suspected Meningitis Cases\n-----------------------------------", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-08-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Onamakulikwa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eengodi Constituency", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Health", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Ohambala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Omakunde", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Penina Akudhenga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Constituency", "country": "Namibia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "17807", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - USA (MO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=17807", "date": "2007-07-16 22:00:02", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA (MISSOURI)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 16 Jul 2007\nSource: KFVS 12 Heartland News [edited]\n<http://www.kfvs12.com/global/story.asp?s=6771896>\n\nThere have been 14 confirmed cases of viral meningitis in Perry\nCounty in less than a month. Usually, experts say doctors only report\na couple of cases a year.\nViral meningitis is the less serious form of meningitis. Health\nexperts say it can be spread in a variety of ways: through water,\nthrough saliva, mucus or fecal matter of an infected person. Right\nnow, they have not isolated a common cause among the 14 cases and say\nthey are working on it. In the meantime, they hope you wash your\nhands frequently, don't eat or drink after one another [i.e. don't\nshare food and drink], and avoid swallowing water from pools, creeks\nor lakes.\nA mother in Perryville said her 8-year-old son was one of the 14\ninfected, and she immediately took him to their family doctor when he\nbegan feeling nauseous and started vomiting. 'They did a spinal tap\non him to draw out the spinal fluid and see what kind of meningitis\nhe had, and turns out, he had viral meningitis,' she said. Her son\nwas treated at a Cape Girardeau hospital and is doing fine now, but\nshe was very worried while he was ill. 'You always think of the worst\nwhen you hear the word meningitis,' she said. Her son is now back\nhome safe and sound.\nMeanwhile, a spokesperson for the Perry County Memorial Hospital said\npatients have been canceling their appointments for fear of\ncontracting the virus. She said to keep in mind that the virus is not\nairborne, so please do keep your scheduled appointment.\n[Byline: C. J. Cassidy]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Meningitis is an illness in which there is inflammation of the\ntissues that cover the brain and spinal cord. Viral or 'aseptic'\nmeningitis, which is the most common type, is caused by an infection\nwith one of several types of viruses. In the United States, there are\nbetween 25 000 and 50 000 hospitalizations due to viral meningitis\neach year. The more common symptoms of meningitis are fever, severe\nheadache, stiff neck, bright lights hurting the eyes, drowsiness or\nconfusion, and nausea and vomiting. In babies, the symptoms may\ninclude fever, fretfulness or irritability, difficulty in awakening\nthe baby, or the baby refuses to eat.\nViral meningitis is serious but rarely fatal in persons with normal\nimmune systems. Usually, the symptoms last from 7 to 10 days, and the\npatient recovers completely. Bacterial meningitis, on the other hand,\ncan be very serious and result in disability or death if not treated\npromptly. Often, the symptoms of viral meningitis and bacterial\nmeningitis are the same. For this reason, healthcare specialists\nadvise that whenever there is suspicion of meningitis in a child, a\ndoctor should be consulted without delay.\nMany different viruses can cause meningitis. About 90 percent of\ncases of viral meningitis are caused by enteroviruses, such as\ncoxsackieviruses and echoviruses. But herpesviruses and mumps virus\ncan also cause viral meningitis. There is no specific treatment for\nviral meningitis other than supportive care. Enteroviruses are\ntransmitted by contact predominantly through direct contact with\nrespiratory and other secretions (e.g., saliva, sputum, or nasal\nmucus) of an infected person. The incubation period for enteroviruses\nis usually between 3 and 7 days. Frequent and thorough hand washing\nis the best protection from infection.\nOutbreaks of viral meningitis are frequently indicative of fecal\ncontamination of food products, deficiencies in the supply of clean\ndrinking water or the inadequate treatment and disposal of sewage. In\nthe case of the Missouri outbreak, the source of the infection has\nnot been established so far.\nFurther information can be obtained from the U.S. CDC (Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention) website at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/viral_meningitis.htm>.\nFor the location of Perry County, Missouri, see:\n<http://www.perryvillemo.com>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: C. J. Cassidy]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n Enteroviruses are\ntransmitted by contact predominantly through direct contact with\nrespiratory and other secretions (e.g., saliva, sputum, or nasal\nmucus) of an infected person. They did a spinal tap\non him to draw out the spinal fluid and see what kind of meningitis\nhe had, and turns out, he had viral meningitis,' she said. Outbreaks of viral meningitis are frequently indicative of fecal\ncontamination of food products, deficiencies in the supply of clean\ndrinking water or the inadequate treatment and disposal of sewage. The more common symptoms of meningitis are fever, severe\nheadache, stiff neck, bright lights hurting the eyes, drowsiness or\nconfusion, and nausea and vomiting. Source: KFVS 12 Heartland News [edited]\n<http://www.kfvs12.com/global/story.asp?s=6771896>\n\nThere have been 14 confirmed cases of viral meningitis in Perry\nCounty in less than a month. Viral or 'aseptic'\nmeningitis, which is the most common type, is caused by an infection\nwith one of several types of viruses. About 90 percent of\ncases of viral meningitis are caused by enteroviruses, such as\ncoxsackieviruses and echoviruses. In the United States, there are\nbetween 25 000 and 50 000 hospitalizations due to viral meningitis\neach year.
