Bacterial meningitis, on the other hand,\ncan be very serious and result in disability or death if not treated\npromptly. VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA (MISSOURI)\n*********************************\n Health\nexperts say it can be spread in a variety of ways: through water,\nthrough saliva, mucus or fecal matter of an infected person.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Perryville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perry County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cape Girardeau", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "17806", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=17806", "date": "2007-07-16 22:00:02", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (KHABAROVSK)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate Fri 13 Jul 2007\nSource: Komcity News Agency [in Russian, trans. Mod.NP, edited]\n<http://www.komcity.ru/news/?id=5232>\n\nAccording to Rospotrebnadzor [Federal Service for Monitoring Consumer\nRights Protection and Human Welfare] the river Amur and other water\nsources do not satisfy norms of microbiological safety. According to\nVladimir Ott, the Healthcare Officer for [Khabarovsk Krai], an\nincreased incidence of viral meningitis morbidity has been observed\nin settlements along the Amur coast. As of 11 Jul 2007, 59 patients\nhave been admitted to Khabarovsk hospitals on suspicion of viral\nmeningitis. The diagnosis has been confirmed in 18 cases.\nAll cases of infection originated in the city of Komsomolsk-na-Amure\nand the surrounding area. Hepatitis A virus and rotaviruses have been\ndetected in samples of river water. According to a special public\nhealth commission appointed by of the Government of the Khabarovsk\nKrai, between 1 Jun and 10 Jul 2007, the number of cases of viral\nmeningitis recorded in Komsomolsk-na-Amure was more than 4 times\ngreater than the long term average. About 70 percent of the patients\nwere children between 3- and 6-years-old. The diagnosis of\nenterovirus infection was based on laboratory analysis of clinical\nsamples. Laboratory analysis for 35 percent of patient samples was\nenterovirus-positive.\nThe Water Supply Authority for the Khabarovsk Krai and the city of\nKomsomolsk-na-Amure has reorganized the microbiological quality\nmonitoring of potable water derived from the river Amur. During the\n1st 6 months of 2007, hepatitis A virus and rotavirus antigens had\nbeen detected in every 10th sample from the river Amur.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed-rus@promedmail.org>\n[Khabarovsk Krai, in the Far Eastern Federal District of Russia and\ncan be located on the map at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/commonwealth/russia_admin_1994.pdf.\nThe Amur River is one of the 10 longest rivers in the world and forms\nthe border between the Russian Far East and Northeastern China. -\nCopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n According to a special public\nhealth commission appointed by of the Government of the Khabarovsk\nKrai, between 1 Jun and 10 Jul 2007, the number of cases of viral\nmeningitis recorded in Komsomolsk-na-Amure was more than 4 times\ngreater than the long term average. \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed-rus@promedmail.org>\n According to\nVladimir Ott, the Healthcare Officer for [Khabarovsk Krai], an\nincreased incidence of viral meningitis morbidity has been observed\nin settlements along the Amur coast. The Water Supply Authority for the Khabarovsk Krai and the city of\nKomsomolsk-na-Amure has reorganized the microbiological quality\nmonitoring of potable water derived from the river Amur. 1st 6 months of 2007, hepatitis A virus and rotavirus antigens had\nbeen detected in every 10th sample from the river Amur.\n As of 11 Jul 2007, 59 patients\nhave been admitted to Khabarovsk hospitals on suspicion of viral\nmeningitis. The diagnosis of\nenterovirus infection was based on laboratory analysis of clinical\nsamples.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Khabarovsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Komsomolsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "the Amur River", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9708", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - Brazil (ES)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9708", "date": "2007-04-14 14:00:02", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - BRAZIL (ESPIRITO SANTO)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 14 Apr 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org, from ProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\nSource: Ministry of Health Brazil [Trans. from Portuguese by Mod.MPP, edited]\n<http://portal.saude.gov.br/portal/saude/visualizar_texto.cfm?idtxt=25832>\n\nIn the 2nd half of March 2007, the Secretary of Disease Surveillance\nof the Ministry of Health received a report from the State\nSecretariat of Health of Espirito Santo (ES) of 2 cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the city of Cariacica, ES.\nEosinophilic meningitis is an infection of the central nervous system\ncaused mainly by helminths, but other infectious and non-infectious\nprocesses can be associated with this clinical picture. Among the\nhelminths, of special importance is the _Angiostrongylus\ncantonenesis_, a nematode that has the rat (urban and wild) as its\ndefinitive host. The intermediary hosts in nature are mollusks, among\nwhich are conch (caramujos) and slugs (lesmas). Humans are accidental\nhosts, being infected through ingestion of mollusks or coming in\ndirect contact with their secretions.\nIn the identified cases, the probable source of infection was\ningestion of slugs. A 3rd case, under investigation, still hasn't had\na definitive epidemiologic association identified, not withstanding,\nthe literature does support the possibility of transmission of the\nhelminth through ingestion of vegetables and fruits that have been\ninfested with infectious larval forms of _A. cantonensis_ or through\nthe ingestion of other hosts of the helminth such as crabs and\nshrimp. These forms of transmission have been reported in eastern\n(Asian) countries where the disease is endemic. The occurrence of\nthis agent has not been reported in Brazil, suggesting a new\nintroduction of this species into the Brazilian territory.\nThe confirmation of the etiologic agent in both of the cases was made\nby polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of cerebrospinal fluid\n(CSF) from both patients, as well as through verification of\nreproduction of the agent in laboratory rats, in addition to the\nidentification of _A. cantonensis_ in slugs and conches and other\nmollusks collected around the household where the ingestion of the\ncited animals occurred.\nPathophysiology\n----------------\nThe infection occurs through the ingestion of infective larvae (L1)\npresent in the mollusks, by contact of the oral mucosa with\nsecretions of mollusks or maybe though fomites (contaminated\nobjects). The larvae, after having been ingested, enters the blood\nsystem, and, as a result of its tropism, is localized in the central\nnervous system (CNS) where it goes on to develop meningitis or infect\ncerebral tissue and cause encephalitis. In this way, through the\ninfectious process involving these different sites, the clinical\npicture of meningoencephalitis is produced. It is not known if the\nadult worm, due to an inability to migrate to the lungs, dies inside\nof the CNS or in another location.\nClinical picture\n-----------------\nIncubation period -- from one to 6 days after ingestion of the L1.\nSigns and Symptoms -- headache, nausea, nuchal rigidity, fever, rash,\nabdominal pain\nSpecific neurological signs -- can be absent or can evolve into\nparesthesias, hypotonia, and compromise of the 4th and 6th cranial\nnerves. It can lead to death, although this is rarely reported.\nLaboratory tests\n----------------\nIt is mandatory to collect CSF. The CSF normally has a leukocytosis\nwith eosinophilia reaching 10 percent that can persist for months.\nGlucose can be normal and for some time can be decreased. Sometimes\nthe larvae can be identified in the CSF at the time of the lumbar puncture.\nThere is usually an eosinophilia in the peripheral blood, concomitant\nwith the neurological picture. Serologic tests have not as yet been\nstandardized commercially.\nTherapy\n--------\nThe use of an anti-helminthic has not been demonstrated to be\neffective at any time during the course of the disease.\nTreatment of signs and symptoms during the course of the illness is\nrecommended to reduce the symptoms (headache and other signs of\nincreased intracranial pressure), as well as the use of analgesics\nand antiemetics.\nThe usual clinical course evolves over 2 months but in some cases can\nlast longer.\nDefinition of a suspected case: a patient of any age and sex, with a\nhistory of fever, headache nuchal rigidity, with a history of\ningestion or manipulation of landed mollusks in the preceding 1-15 days.\nDefinition of a confirmed case: a suspected case with a CSF\neosinophilia of 10 percent or a CSF positive for _A. cantonensis_.\nPrevention and control measures to be implemented in Espirito Santo State:\na) All suspected cases of eosinophilic meningitis should be reported\nimmediately to the Municipal and/or State Secretariat of Health (to\nthe Rapid Response Unit -- URR) and/or to the Center for Strategic\nInformation for Disease Surveillance of the Ministry health\n(CIEVS/SVS) through e-mail <notifica@saude.gov.br>;\nb) Seek immediate medical assistance at the primary signs and\nsymptoms of fever, accompanied by vomiting and nuchal rigidity;\nc) remove unnecessary materials by emptying the garbage adequately in\norder to reduce the rodent populations;\nd) avoid manual contact or ingestion of whatever species of landed\nmollusks, until there are studies of these fauna in the region and\none is able to identify the transmission risks;\ne) ingest fruits and vegetables only after adequate washing and use\nof sodium hypochlorite 2.5 percent disinfectant;\nf) mollusks and terrestrial and/or aquatic crustaceans should only be\ningested after adequate cooking;\ng) special attention should be paid to children, teaching them the\nrisks and keeping them in clean environments less hospitable to the\nmollusks (care should be taken with yards, pre-schools and daycare centers;\nThe Municipal and State Secretaries of Health should:\n1. Sensitize the health professionals and the teams that provide\nassistance to meningitis [patients] in the private and public\nhospitals about the risk of occurrence of the disease caused by _A.\ncantonensis_;\n2. implement a system that ensures collection of CSF from all cases\nwith signs and symptoms described above, that are compatible with a\nsuspect case;\n3. the chemocytologic examination of the CSF should include analysis\nof the cellular differential as well as a biochemical analysis;\n4. there should be collection of the CSF to be sent to LACEN (Center\nfor the Study and Control of Infectious Diseases), which will send\nthe specimen for PCR testing for the presence of _A. cantonensis_.\nThe specimens should be maintained and transported on dry ice or\nstored in a liquid nitrogen pipe.\n5. all suspected cases should be investigated by Epidemiologic\nSurveillance (VE), Environmental Health and VISAS (Sanitary\nMonitoring), with special attention to:\n- dietary habits (ingestion of raw mollusks or poorly cooked mollusks\nand/or crustaceans; types of naturally ingested foods such as fruits,\nvegetables and origin of these foods, for both the occurrence of\nmanipulation of the terrestrial and marine mollusks in the preceding 7 days;\n- completion of an environmental investigation around the household\nand peri-domicile of the suspected cases, with collection of\nterrestrial mollusks encountered in the locale (in keeping with the\norientation of CCZ (Center for Zoonoses Control), to identify the\nmollusks (conches and slugs) and implement rodent control in keeping\nwith the environmental characteristics.\nFor the rest of the State and Municipal Secretariats of Health:\nImplementation of prospective epidemiologic surveillance for\neosinophilic meningitis, doing a retrospective review of the past 6\nmonths, looking for compatible clinical pictures and the presence of\nCSF eosinophilia. If cases that fit the clinical picture for a\nsuspected case are identified, the CIE, VS should be notified within\n24 hours and all measures of investigation should be conducted as\nmentioned above.\n[Byline: Jose Ricardo Pio Marins, Gerson Pena]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is not necessarily due to _A. cantonensis_, as there are other\ncauses. Despite this, the presence of _Achatina fulica_ in Brazil,\nthe intermediary host of _A. cantonensis_ is of concern. - Mod. LJS]\n[More information on the lifecycle and diagnosis of _Angiostrongylis_\ncan be found at the CDC website\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dpd/parasites/angiostrongylus/default.htm>.\nIt should be noted that, in addition to an elevated eosinophil count\nin both spinal fluid and peripheral blood, the total IgE level in\nblood would be expected to be highly elevated. - Mod.EP]", "summary": "b) Seek immediate medical assistance at the primary signs and\nsymptoms of fever, accompanied by vomiting and nuchal rigidity;\nc) remove unnecessary materials by emptying the garbage adequately in\norder to reduce the rodent populations;\nd) avoid manual contact or ingestion of whatever species of landed\nmollusks, until there are studies of these fauna in the region and\none is able to identify the transmission risks;\ne) ingest fruits and vegetables only after adequate washing and use\nof sodium hypochlorite 2.5 percent disinfectant;\nf) mollusks and terrestrial and/or aquatic crustaceans should only be\ningested after adequate cooking;\ng) special attention should be paid to children, teaching them the\nrisks and keeping them in clean environments less hospitable to the\nmollusks (care should be taken with yards, pre-schools and daycare centers;\nThe Municipal and State Secretaries of Health should:\n1. all suspected cases should be investigated by Epidemiologic\nSurveillance (VE), Environmental Health and VISAS (Sanitary\nMonitoring), with special attention to:\n- dietary habits (ingestion of raw mollusks or poorly cooked mollusks\nand/or crustaceans; types of naturally ingested foods such as fruits,\nvegetables and origin of these foods, for both the occurrence of\nmanipulation of the terrestrial and marine mollusks in the preceding 7 days;\n- completion of an environmental investigation around the household\nand peri-domicile of the suspected cases, with collection of\nterrestrial mollusks encountered in the locale (in keeping with the\norientation of CCZ (Center for Zoonoses Control), to identify the\nmollusks (conches and slugs) and implement rodent control in keeping\nwith the environmental characteristics. Sensitize the health professionals and the teams that provide\nassistance to meningitis [patients] in the private and public\nhospitals about the risk of occurrence of the disease caused by _A.\ncantonensis_;\n2. implement a system that ensures collection of CSF from all cases\nwith signs and symptoms described above, that are compatible with a\nsuspect case;\n3. The confirmation of the etiologic agent in both of the cases was made\nby polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of cerebrospinal fluid\n(CSF) from both patients, as well as through verification of\nreproduction of the agent in laboratory rats, in addition to the\nidentification of _A. cantonensis_ in slugs and conches and other\nmollusks collected around the household where the ingestion of the\ncited animals occurred. A 3rd case, under investigation, still hasn't had\na definitive epidemiologic association identified, not withstanding,\nthe literature does support the possibility of transmission of the\nhelminth through ingestion of vegetables and fruits that have been\ninfested with infectious larval forms of _A. cantonensis_ or through\nthe ingestion of other hosts of the helminth such as crabs and\nshrimp. Prevention and control measures to be implemented in Espirito Santo State:\na) All suspected cases of eosinophilic meningitis should be reported\nimmediately to the Municipal and/or State Secretariat of Health (to\nthe Rapid Response Unit -- URR) and/or to the Center for Strategic\nInformation for Disease Surveillance of the Ministry health\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n If cases that fit the clinical picture for a\nsuspected case are identified, the CIE, VS should be notified within\n24 hours and all measures of investigation should be conducted as\nmentioned above.\n For the rest of the State and Municipal Secretariats of Health:\nImplementation of prospective epidemiologic surveillance for\neosinophilic meningitis, doing a retrospective review of the past 6\nmonths, looking for compatible clinical pictures and the presence of\nCSF eosinophilia. MPP, edited]\n<http://portal.saude.gov.br/portal/saude/visualizar_texto.cfm?idtxt=25832>\n\nIn the 2nd half of March 2007, the Secretary of Disease Surveillance\nof the Ministry of Health received a report from the State\nSecretariat of Health of Espirito Santo (ES) of 2 cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the city of Cariacica, ES. The infection occurs through the ingestion of infective larvae (L1)\npresent in the mollusks, by contact of the oral mucosa with\nsecretions of mollusks or maybe though fomites (contaminated\nobjects). The larvae, after having been ingested, enters the blood\nsystem, and, as a result of its tropism, is localized in the central\nnervous system (CNS) where it goes on to develop meningitis or infect\ncerebral tissue and cause encephalitis. Treatment of signs and symptoms during the course of the illness is\nrecommended to reduce the symptoms (headache and other signs of\nincreased intracranial pressure), as well as the use of analgesics\nand antiemetics. Among the\nhelminths, of special importance is the _Angiostrongylus\ncantonenesis_, a nematode that has the rat (urban and wild) as its\ndefinitive host. [Byline: Jose Ricardo Pio Marins, Gerson Pena]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Definition of a suspected case: a patient of any age and sex, with a\nhistory of fever, headache nuchal rigidity, with a history of\ningestion or manipulation of landed mollusks in the preceding 1-15 days. Eosinophilic meningitis is an infection of the central nervous system\ncaused mainly by helminths, but other infectious and non-infectious\nprocesses can be associated with this clinical picture. Humans are accidental\nhosts, being infected through ingestion of mollusks or coming in\ndirect contact with their secretions. Signs and Symptoms -- headache, nausea, nuchal rigidity, fever, rash,\nabdominal pain\n It should be noted that, in addition to an elevated eosinophil count\nin both spinal fluid and peripheral blood, the total IgE level in\nblood would be expected to be highly elevated. there should be collection of the CSF to be sent to LACEN (Center\nfor the Study and Control of Infectious Diseases), which will send\nthe specimen for PCR testing for the presence of _A. cantonensis_. In this way, through the\ninfectious process involving these different sites, the clinical\npicture of meningoencephalitis is produced. Specific neurological signs -- can be absent or can evolve into\nparesthesias, hypotonia, and compromise of the 4th and 6th cranial\nnerves. From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org, from ProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\nSource: Ministry of Health Brazil [Trans. from Portuguese by Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Cariacica", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "16143", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Ukraine (Vinnyts'ka)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=16143", "date": "2007-07-05 12:00:03", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - UKRAINE (VINNYTS'KA)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 27 Jun 2007\nSource: IA Gazeta po Ukraniski [in Russian, trans. Corr.ATS, edited]\n<http://gpu.ua/index.php?&id=170263>\n\nOn 28 Jun [2007], 20 school children from Khmelnik and the\nsurrounding villages of Blestka and Sokolovka (Vinnyts'ka region)\nwere hospitalized with a preliminary diagnosis of 'meningitis'.\nAccording to Aleksandr Jupanov, head of the Agency for Healthcare for\nthe Vinnyts'ka region, the children were admitted to the Khmelnik\nCentral Hospital with severe headache and nausea. Of the 20 cases, 2\nwere ranked as moderate, 17 as mild, and one was not confirmed by\nlaboratory diagnosis. The outbreak has been attributed preliminarily\nto swimming in local water bodies during hot weather.\nA special commission, which includes specialists from the\nsanitary-epidemiological service, departments of the Ministry of\nEmergencies, and local physicians, has been set up to investigate the\noutbreak. The situation is being evaluated. The Khmelnik regional\n[public health authority] has temporarily prohibited swimming\nactivities in local water bodies.\nMeningitis is an infectious disease with inflammation of the cerebral\nand medullar membranes, which can be caused by bacteria, viruses,\n_Chlamydia_, _Mycoplasma_, protozoa, or fungi. The infection can be\ntransmitted by contact and by airborne droplets.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report is not about meningococcal meningitis, as there is\npreliminary information about the connection with swimming. In\naddition, the condition of all the patients is moderate, whereas in\nthe case of meningococcal meningitis the severity of the cases would\nbe grave.\nThe outbreak is probably due to enterovirus, which can manifest also\nas serous meningitis. Serological tests would help to clarify the\ncause of disease. The restriction of swimming activities would also\nhelp, but the situation may get out of control because of the\npossibility of air droplet spread. - Corr.VM\nVinnyts'ka region (Vinnyts'ka oblast) can be located on the map of Ukraine at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/ukraine_adm93.jpg>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n ATS, edited]\n<http://gpu.ua/index.php?&id=170263>\n\nOn 28 Jun [2007], 20 school children from Khmelnik and the\nsurrounding villages of Blestka and Sokolovka (Vinnyts'ka region)\nwere hospitalized with a preliminary diagnosis of 'meningitis'. A special commission, which includes specialists from the\nsanitary-epidemiological service, departments of the Ministry of\nEmergencies, and local physicians, has been set up to investigate the\noutbreak. In\naddition, the condition of all the patients is moderate, whereas in\nthe case of meningococcal meningitis the severity of the cases would\nbe grave. \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org The restriction of swimming activities would also\nhelp, but the situation may get out of control because of the\npossibility of air droplet spread. Meningitis is an infectious disease with inflammation of the cerebral\nand medullar membranes, which can be caused by bacteria, viruses,\n_Chlamydia_, _Mycoplasma_, protozoa, or fungi. Of the 20 cases, 2\nwere ranked as moderate, 17 as mild, and one was not confirmed by\nlaboratory diagnosis. According to Aleksandr Jupanov, head of the Agency for Healthcare for\nthe Vinnyts'ka region, the children were admitted to the Khmelnik\nCentral Hospital with severe headache and nausea.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Blestka", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Mycoplasma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khmelnik", "country": "Belarus"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3306", "headline": "PRO> Meningitis, enterovirus - Italy (Piemonte) ex India (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3306", "date": "2006-10-07 00:00:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, ENTEROVIRUS - ITALY (PIEMONTE) EX INDIA (02)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 6 Oct 2006\nFrom: Pietro Caramello and Guido Calleri <malattieinfettive-a@asl3.to.it>\n\nThe enterovirus which affected 7 out of a group of 17 young scouts from\nItaly travelling to West Bengal, India, causing meningitis [see ProMED-mail\npost of 6 Sep 2006, entitled: 'Meningitis, enterovirus - Italy (Piemonte)\nex India 20060909.2563'] has been isolated from the stools of 6 of them and\nhas been identified as an echovirus. Typing was done with a pool of\nantisera (Chemicon, IFA), including subtypes 4, 6, 9, 11, 30, and 34;\nsubtyping is in progress.\nAll patients recovered with no sequelae, and were discharged after 4-8 days\nof treatment in hospital.\n--\nPietro Caramello and Guido Calleri\nAmedeo di Savoia Hospital\nInfectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine Units A and C\nC. Svizzera 164, 10149\nTorino, Italy\n<malattieinfettive-a@asl3.to.it>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Caramello and Calleri for providing this\nconfirmation that 6 of the 7 meningitis patients had contracted echovirus\ninfection during travel in west Bengal. These data, together with the data\nreported in Meningitis - Latvia (Rezekne & Daugavpi (02) 20061005.2850\nidentify echoviruses, 6, 9, 20 and 30 as the most likely cause of\nmeningitis in children and young adults in both Europe and Asia.\nInformation on the outcome of the subtyping of the echoviruses contracted\nin Asia would be welcomed. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Infectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine Units A and C\nC. Svizzera 164, 10149\nTorino, Italy\n<malattieinfettive-a@asl3.to.it>\n From: Pietro Caramello and Guido Calleri <malattieinfettive-a@asl3.to.it>\n\nThe enterovirus which affected 7 out of a group of 17 young scouts from\nItaly travelling to West Bengal, India, causing meningitis [see ProMED-mail\npost of 6 Sep 2006, entitled: 'Meningitis, enterovirus - Italy \nPietro Caramello and Guido Calleri\nAmedeo di Savoia Hospital\n [ProMED-mail thanks Drs Caramello and Calleri for providing this\nconfirmation that 6 of the 7 meningitis patients had contracted echovirus\ninfection during travel in west Bengal. Typing was done with a pool of\nantisera (Chemicon, IFA), including subtypes 4, 6, 9, 11, 30, and 34;\nsubtyping is in progress.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2006-09-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Calleri", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bengal", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3050", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - China (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3050", "date": "2006-10-01 00:00:00", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - CHINA (04)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat, 30 Sep 2006\nFrom: Lynda Bramham <lynda.bramham@masta.org\nSource: BBC Press search: Text of Xinhua report, 24 Sep 2006 [edited]\n\nBeijing has confirmed a new case of 'snail infection', bringing the\ntotal number of cases to 132. The 31-year-old man saw doctors at\nabout 8 city hospitals before finally being diagnosed with a type of\nangiostrongyliasis at Beijing Friendship Hospital on Friday.\nLike most of the other patients, he ate snails at the Shuguo Yanyi\nRestaurant, which serves Sichuan-style dishes, on 11 Jul and\ndeveloped symptoms of headache and fever on 27 Jul, said a doctor\nsurnamed Yin at the hospital. Yin said the 8 who were hospitalized\nat the Friendship Hospital were recovering well and would all be\ndischarged next week. The hospital is offering checkups every Monday,\nWednesday and Friday morning to ensure the patients' complete recovery.\nThe disease caused by parasites can affect the brain and spinal cord,\nand also lead to meningitis. The Friendship Hospital has diagnosed\n112 cases and admitted 71 patients since 24 Jun. No deaths have been reported.\nThe Amazonian snail culprits have been traced back to southern\nChina's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, according to the\ninvestigation by Beijing Health Bureau. Amazonian snails originated\nin South America and first came to China in the 1980s as a delicacy.\nThe first report of a person falling ill after eating the snails came\nfrom Guangzhou, capital city of the southern province of Guangdong.\nUntil recently, the big black snails were a hot-selling aquatic\nproduct in big Chinese cities like Beijing.\n--\nLynda Bramham\n<lynda.bramham@masta.org\n[In our last report from 26 Aug 2006, 87 people were reported to have\nbeen infected. The number has now increased to 132, and the outbreak\nmay not yet be under control. - Mod.EP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Like most of the other patients, he ate snails at the Shuguo Yanyi\nRestaurant, which serves Sichuan-style dishes, on 11 Jul and\ndeveloped symptoms of headache and fever on 27 Jul, said a doctor\nsurnamed Yin at the hospital. --\nLynda Bramham\n<lynda.bramham@masta.org\n The first report of a person falling ill after eating the snails came\nfrom Guangzhou, capital city of the southern province of Guangdong.\n The 31-year-old man saw doctors at\nabout 8 city hospitals before finally being diagnosed with a type of\nangiostrongyliasis at Beijing Friendship Hospital on Friday. Yin said the 8 who were hospitalized\nat the Friendship Hospital were recovering well and would all be\ndischarged next week. ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - CHINA (04)\n**********************************\n Source: BBC Press search: Text of Xinhua report, 24 Sep 2006 [edited]\n\nBeijing has confirmed a new case of 'snail infection', bringing the\ntotal number of cases to 132. Until recently, the big black snails were a hot-selling aquatic\nproduct in big Chinese cities like Beijing.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2006-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guangzhou", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "sichuan", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "15721", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis, Toscana virus - Portugal 2002-2005", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=15721", "date": "2007-07-02 23:00:04", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS, TOSCANA VIRUS - PORTUGAL 2002-2005\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 2 Jul 2007\nSource: Eurosurveillance monthly releases 2007,\nVolume 12 , Issue 6 June 2007 [edited]\n\nToscana virus meningitis in Portugal, 2002-2005\n-----------------------------------------------\nToscana virus infection is endemic in Italy but\nhas also been documented in other Mediterranean\ncountries. Our aim was to investigate the\noccurrence of Toscana virus (TOSV) meningitis in\nchildren and young adults in a metropolitan area\nin the north of Portugal. Cerebrospinal fluid\nsamples from 308 patients with the diagnosis of\nmeningitis and with negative bacterial culture\nwere tested for enteroviruses and herpesviruses\nby reverse transcription PCR. Those samples that\nproved negative for enterovirus and herpesviruses\nwere tested for Toscana virus with a commercial\nreverse transcription nested PCR assay. In total,\nwe investigated 106 samples, collected between\nMay and September during the 4-year period\nbetween 2002 and 2005 from patients younger than\n30 years old. Toscana virus was the cause of\nmeningitis in 6 (5.6 percent) of the cases, 3\nchildren and 3 young adults. All had a benign\ncourse and self-limited disease. Since a 1st case\nreport of TOSV infection 1985 and another in\n1996, both in foreign tourists, these 6 cases of\nToscana virus meningitis are, to our knowledge,\nthe 1st diagnosed in Portuguese inhabitants, and\nthey underline the need for more studies on the\nprevalence of this virus in Portugal.\nIntroduction\n-------------\nWith the improvement of diagnostic techniques\nsuch as PCR, it is now possible to rapidly\ndiagnose viral meningitis through identification\nof the pathogen [1]. In Portugal, enteroviruses\nare the most frequent cause of aseptic meningitis\nbut, despite thorough testing, a significant\nnumber of patients are discharged from hospital\nwithout an etiological diagnosis [2,3]. The\ninclusion of Toscana virus (TOSV) diagnosis in\nthe laboratory tests for enterovirus- and\nherpesvirus-negative samples was an attempt to\nimprove the knowledge about aseptic meningitis.\nViral meningitides, including TOSV meningitis,\nare non-notifiable diseases in Portugal and are\ncharacterised by non-specific symptoms.\nConsequently, their seroprevalence is unknown.\nTOSV belongs to a group of sandfly fever viruses\ntransmitted by the sandfly (genus _Phlebotomus_),\nand classified in the family _Bunyaviridae_,\ngenus _Phlebovirus_. Three sandfly fever viruses\nhave been identified in Mediterranean area:\nsandfly fever Naples virus, sandfly fever\nSicilian virus, and Toscana virus. The latter is\nendemic in central Italy and described as the\nmost frequent cause of aseptic meningitis in\nchildren in that region [4,5]. As a consequence\nof the life cycle of _Phlebotomus_, TOSV is more\nfrequent during summer, with a peak in August.\nThe most common presentation is an acute febrile\nillness or meningitis, and more rarely a\nmeningoencephalitis [5-7]. Most of the studies on\nTOSV have been done in central Italy, but the\noccurrence of TOSV in other countries, such as\nFrance, Spain, Slovenia, Greece, Cyprus, Turkey\nand Egypt, has also been reported recently [8].\nTOSV can be identified by culture of\ncerebrospinal fluid (CSF), a time-consuming\nmethod with low sensitivity, but very useful for\nvirus characterisation and genetic studies [8].\nImmunoenzymatic tests, (IgM by IFA or ELISA) are\nrapid and sensitive; however cross-reactivity can\noccur. Nowadays, reverse transcription (RT)-PCR\nis considered the method with the highest\nsensitivity and specificity for virus detection\n[8,9]. Many vectors implied in human diseases,\nincluding _Phlebotomus_, are present in Portugal\n[10]. The aim of this study was to investigate\nthe occurrence of TOSV meningitis in children and\nyoung adults in an urban area in the north of\nPortugal.\nMethods\n-------\nDuring the period 2002 to 2005, we have\ninvestigated the occurrence of TOSV in CSF\nsamples of aseptic meningitis patients. Aseptic\nmeningitis was defined by a CSF cytosis greater\nthan 6 leukocytes/ml and a negative bacterial\nculture. RNA was extracted from the samples with\nthe Qiamp viral RNA mini kit (Qiagen). Samples\nthat were PCR-negative for enterovirus and herpes\nvirus and that had been taken from patients\nyounger than 30 years and hospitalised between\nMay and September each year were tested for TOSV\nwith a nested RT-PCR assay purchased from\nAmplimedical SpA (Toscana, N prot Kit). Each run\nincluded a negative control (water) and a\npositive control (Toscana virus positive control,\nAmplimedical SpA). Some negative samples (n=26)\nwere tested with an in-house\ufffd nested RT-PCR\nprotocol with published outer and inner primers\n[11].\nResults\n-------\nOver the 4-year period (2002-2005), 308 patients\nwere admitted to the emergency department of our\nhospital with aseptic meningitis and hospitalised\nfor observation and study. They were analysed by\nRT-PCR for the presence of a number of viruses\nknown to cause meningitis (enterovirus, herpes\nsimplex virus (HSV), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV),\ncytomegalovirus (CMV), and West Nile virus)\nduring the acute phase of the disease. The\nresults are tabulated as follows:\nPCR / No. positive / No. negative\nEnterovirus / 110 / 178\nHerpes simplex virus / 20 / 178\nEpstein-Barr virus / 5 / 173\nCytomegalovirus / 3 / 175\nWest Nile virus / 0 / 15\nToscana virus / 6 / 100\nTotal meningitis cases 144 (47 percent)\nRT-PCR for enterovirus and herpes simplex virus\nwere done in an order determined by the patient's\nmental status at admission. CSF samples from\npatients with a normal level of consciousness or\nwith somnolence (Glasgow Coma Scale >=14) were\nanalysed 1st for enterovirus, and, if this was\nnegative, subsequently for HSV. Samples from\npatients with further impaired mental status\n(Glasgow Coma Scale <14) were 1st analysed for\nHSV, and then, if negative, for enterovirus.\nRT-PCR for CMV and EBV was performed only in\ncases with a negative result for HSV and\nenterovirus. RT-PCR for West Nile virus was done\nonly in 15 patients aged over 60 years without\netiologic diagnosis. It was negative in all of\nthem.\nFor this study, we chose 106 of those 308 samples\nto be tested for TOSV using the Amplimedical SpA\nnested RT-PCR assay. This included only samples\nfrom patients who had been admitted between May\nand September in the years from 2002 to 2005 and\nhad been negative for enterovirus, HSV, EBV and\nCMV when tested upon hospital admission. All\npatients were younger than 30 years of age (range\n2.5 months to 30 years). TOSV was detected in 6\n(5.6 percent) of those 106 samples. Three were\nchildren, one aged 4 years and 2 aged 8 years,\nand 3 were young adults, aged 16, 23 and 30\nyears. Three of the patients were male. All 6\npatients live in an urban area, and none of them\nhad a recent history of traveling abroad.\nAll cases had occurred between May and July, 2\ncases in 2002, 3 in 2003 and one in 2005.\nAdmission symptoms were fever, headache and\nvomiting and lasted between one and 5 days. On\nadmission, meningeal symptoms were present in all\npatients and somnolence in 3. Two of them had\nbrain-computed tomography that was normal. CSF\ncytosis ranged from 70 to 1,090 cells/ul, with\nnormal glucose and protein levels. The blood\nleukocyte count varied from 5.6 to 11.8x109/L,\nand C-reactive protein was normal in all\npatients. All underwent only supportive treatment\nwith antipyretics and intravenous fluids and had\na benign and self-limited disease. They were\ndischarged between 4-7 days after admission. 26\nof the 106 samples were examined only by an\nin-house\ufffd RT-PCR assay. The sensitivity of this\nassay was comparable to the commercial RT-PCR\nwhen tested using TOSV-positive clinical samples.\nAll 26 samples that were only tested by this\nmethod were negative.\nDiscussion\n----------\nIn the Mediterranean countries, especially Italy\nand Spain, the interest in TOSV has increased in\nrecent years [12-14]. PCR is the most frequent\nmethod used for TOSV diagnosis. It can be\ncomplemented by immuno-enzymatic tests, which are\nrapid and sensitive [8,11], or culture, which in\ncombination with PCR is useful for genetic\ncharacterisation of the virus. Most of the\nreported cases of TOSV infections occur\nthroughout the summertime in the central region\nof Italy, particularly in the Siena province, in\nchildren [4,5,9,15]. A study by Valassina et al.\n[5] describes the analysis of 277 meningitis\ncases that occurred in Tuscany between 1995 and\n1998. TOSV was identified as the cause for 58\npercent of the cases admitted in the period\nbetween June and September, and for 10 percent of\nthe cases admitted from May to October,\nreflecting the seasonality of the infection.\nOther studies investigate the seroprevalence of\nTOSV in humans in southern Europe [8]. More\nrecent reports have demonstrated the occurrence\nof TOSV in Spain, in the Granada and Madrid\nprovinces [8,16-18]. A study by Navarro et al.\nshows that this virus is responsible for 7\npercent of aseptic meningitis cases in Spain\n[16]. In another Spanish study using samples\ncollected between 1988 and 1996, TOSV was the\ncause of 8 percent of aseptic meningitis cases;\nthese authors analysed 1268 serum samples from\nadults and children for the presence of\nantibodies against TOSV, and found a prevalence\nof 26.2 percent [17].\nEchevarria et al. [18] identified TOSV as the\ncause of 8.6 percent of aseptic meningitis cases\nin the region of Madrid, where 5 percent of the\nhealthy population were shown to have had a past\ninfection. Another Spanish publication on the\nseroprevalence of TOSV in the community of\nMadrid, comparing 2 periods (1993 to 1994 and\n1999 to 2000) found past infections in 7.2\npercent and 5.7 percent, respectively. It further\nshowed that seroprevalence is age dependent, with\nthe antibody prevalence increasing with age [14].\nTwo TOSV cases have been identified in southern\nFrance, one of aseptic meningitis and the other\nof influenza-like illness [19,20]. In addition,\nseveral reports have been published on TOSV\ninfection in travelers returning from\nMediterranean countries [21-24].\nThe climate conditions in Portugal favor\n_Phlebotomus_ survival. Two infections with TOSV,\nacquired in Portugal, have been reported in the\npast. Both were in male tourists, one Swedish and\none German, returning from their holidays in\nPortugal in 1985 and in 1996, respectively [25,\n26]. One of them had documented meningitis.\nStudies on the occurrence of TOSV in Portugal\nhave so far not been done, and the 6 cases of\nTOSV meningitis reported here are the 1st cases\ndiagnosed in Portuguese inhabitants. Thus, in our\nopinion, the investigation of TOSV in summer\ncases of meningitis in Portugal should be\ncontinued in the future, as it is done in other\nMediterranean countries, even though the\nprevalence of TOSV appears to be lower in\nPortugal. Serological surveys are planned to\ndocument the prevalence of antibodies against\nTOSV in all age groups of the Portuguese\npopulation, in order to gain a clearer picture of\nthe occurrence of this form of viral meningitis.\nAuthors: L Santos <lursantos@net.sapo.pt>)1, J\nSimoes2, R Costa2, S Martins2, H Lecour3. 1.\nInfectious Disease Service, School of Medicine\nand Hospital S. Joao. Alameda Professor Hernani\nMonteiro, Porto, Portugal 2. Department of\nMicrobiology, Hospital S. Joao. Alameda Professor\nHernani Monteiro, Porto, Portugal 3. Institute of\nAnatomy, School of Medicine. Alameda Professor\nHernani Monteiro, Porto, Portugal.\nReferences\n----------\n(1) Hamilton SM, Jackson M, Abel D. Clinical\nutility of polymerase chain reaction testing for\nenterovirus meningitis. Ped Infect Dis.\n1999;18(6):533-8.\n(2) Santos L, Simoes J, Conde S, Costa R. Environ Health Perspect.\n2006;114(12):1950-6.\n(11) Schwarz TF, Jager G, Gilch S, Nitschko H.\nNested RT-PCR for detection of sandfly fever\nvirus, serotype Toscana, in clinical specimens,\nwith confirmation by nucleotide sequence\nanalysis. Res Virol. 1995;146:355-62.\n(12) Di Nicuolo G, Pagliano P, Battisti S,\nStarace M, Mininni V, Attanasio V, Faella FS.\nToscana virus central nervous system infections\nin southern Italy. J Clin Microbiol.\n2005;43(12):6186-8.\n(13) Sanbonmatsu-Gamez S, Perez-Ruiz M, Collao X,\nSanchez-Seco P, et al. Toscana virus in Spain.\nEmerg Infect Dis. 2005;11(11):1701-7. Available\nfrom:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol11no11/05-0851.htm>.\n(14) De Ory-Manchona F, Sanz-Moreno J,\nAranguez-Ruiz E y Ramirez-Fernandez R.\nSeroprevalencia edad dependiente frente al virus\nToscana en la Comunidad de Madrid: anos 1993-1994\ny 1999-2000. Enferm Infecc Microbiol Clin\n2007;25(3):187-9.\n(15) Valassina M, Cusi M; Valensin P. A\nMediterranean arbovirus: the Toscana virus. Scand J Infect.\n1991;23:451-7.\n(23) Dobler G, Treib J, Haass A, Frosner G,\nWoesner R, Schimrigk K. Toscana virus infection\nin German travellers returning from the\nMediterranean. J Travel\nMed. 2005;12:295-6.\n(25) Ehrnst A, Peters CJ, Niklasson B, Svedmyr A,\nHolmgren B. Neurovirulent Toscana virus (a\nsandfly fever virus) in a Swedish man after visit\nto Portugal. Lancet 1985;1:1212-3.\n(26) Schwartz TF, Jager G, Gilch S, Pauli C,\nEisenhut M, Nitschko H, et al. Travel-related\nvector-borne virus infections in Germany. Arch\nVirol Suppl. 1996;11:57-65.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[Toscana virus infection may be one of the\narboviruses extending its range into Europe as a\nconsequence of climatic change and may contribute\nincreasingly to viral meningitis in children and\nyoung adults in coming years. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Since a 1st case\nreport of TOSV infection 1985 and another in\n1996, both in foreign tourists, these 6 cases of\nToscana virus meningitis are, to our knowledge,\nthe 1st diagnosed in Portuguese inhabitants, and\nthey underline the need for more studies on the\nprevalence of this virus in Portugal. In another Spanish study using samples\ncollected between 1988 and 1996, TOSV was the\ncause of 8 percent of aseptic meningitis cases;\nthese authors analysed 1268 serum samples from\nadults and children for the presence of\nantibodies against TOSV, and found a prevalence\nof 26.2 percent [17]. Samples\nthat were PCR-negative for enterovirus and herpes\nvirus and that had been taken from patients\nyounger than 30 years and hospitalised between\nMay and September each year were tested for TOSV\nwith a nested RT-PCR assay purchased from\nAmplimedical SpA (Toscana, N prot Kit). They were analysed by\nRT-PCR for the presence of a number of viruses\nknown to cause meningitis (enterovirus, herpes\nsimplex virus (HSV), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV),\ncytomegalovirus (CMV), and West Nile virus)\nduring the acute phase of the disease. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The\ninclusion of Toscana virus (TOSV) diagnosis in\nthe laboratory tests for enterovirus- and\nherpesvirus-negative samples was an attempt to\nimprove the knowledge about aseptic meningitis. [Toscana virus infection may be one of the\narboviruses extending its range into Europe as a\nconsequence of climatic change and may contribute\nincreasingly to viral meningitis in children and\nyoung adults in coming years. [18] identified TOSV as the\ncause of 8.6 percent of aseptic meningitis cases\nin the region of Madrid, where 5 percent of the\nhealthy population were shown to have had a past\ninfection. Cerebrospinal fluid\nsamples from 308 patients with the diagnosis of\nmeningitis and with negative bacterial culture\nwere tested for enteroviruses and herpesviruses\nby reverse transcription PCR. This included only samples\nfrom patients who had been admitted between May\nand September in the years from 2002 to 2005 and\nhad been negative for enterovirus, HSV, EBV and\nCMV when tested upon hospital admission. TOSV was identified as the cause for 58\npercent of the cases admitted in the period\nbetween June and September, and for 10 percent of\nthe cases admitted from May to October,\nreflecting the seasonality of the infection. In Portugal, enteroviruses\nare the most frequent cause of aseptic meningitis\nbut, despite thorough testing, a significant\nnumber of patients are discharged from hospital\nwithout an etiological diagnosis [2,3]. In total,\nwe investigated 106 samples, collected between\nMay and September during the 4-year period\nbetween 2002 and 2005 from patients younger than\n30 years old. The aim of this study was to investigate\nthe occurrence of TOSV meningitis in children and\nyoung adults in an urban area in the north of\nPortugal.\n CSF samples from\npatients with a normal level of consciousness or\nwith somnolence (Glasgow Coma Scale >=14) were\nanalysed 1st for enterovirus, and, if this was\nnegative, subsequently for HSV. It can be\ncomplemented by immuno-enzymatic tests, which are\nrapid and sensitive [8,11], or culture, which in\ncombination with PCR is useful for genetic\ncharacterisation of the virus. Serological surveys are planned to\ndocument the prevalence of antibodies against\nTOSV in all age groups of the Portuguese\npopulation, in order to gain a clearer picture of\nthe occurrence of this form of viral meningitis. Another Spanish publication on the\nseroprevalence of TOSV in the community of\nMadrid, comparing 2 periods (1993 to 1994 and\n1999 to 2000) found past infections in 7.2\npercent and 5.7 percent, respectively. Thus, in our\nopinion, the investigation of TOSV in summer\ncases of meningitis in Portugal should be\ncontinued in the future, as it is done in other\n Most of the\nreported cases of TOSV infections occur\nthroughout the summertime in the central region\nof Italy, particularly in the Siena province, in\nchildren Most of the studies on\nTOSV have been done in central Italy, but the\noccurrence of TOSV in other countries, such as\nFrance, Spain, Slovenia, Greece, Cyprus, Turkey\nand Egypt, has also been reported recently [8]. Three sandfly fever viruses\nhave been identified in Mediterranean area:\nsandfly fever Naples virus, sandfly fever\nSicilian virus, and Toscana virus. Cytomegalovirus / 3 / 175\nWest Nile virus / 0 / 15\nToscana virus / 6 / 100\n (25) Ehrnst A, Peters CJ, Niklasson B, Svedmyr A,\nHolmgren B. Neurovirulent Toscana virus (a\nsandfly fever virus) in a Swedish man after visit\nto Portugal. Our aim was to investigate the\noccurrence of Toscana virus (TOSV) meningitis in\nchildren and young adults in a metropolitan area\nin the north of Portugal. Those samples that\nproved negative for enterovirus and herpesviruses\nwere tested for Toscana virus with a commercial\nreverse transcription nested PCR assay. Over the 4-year period (2002-2005), 308 patients\nwere admitted to the emergency department of our\nhospital with aseptic meningitis and hospitalised\nfor observation and study. Three were\nchildren, one aged 4 years and 2 aged 8 years,\nand 3 were young adults, aged 16, 23 and 30\nyears. Studies on the occurrence of TOSV in Portugal\nhave so far not been done, and the 6 cases of\nTOSV meningitis reported here are the 1st cases\ndiagnosed in Portuguese inhabitants. (14) De Ory-Manchona F, Sanz-Moreno J,\nAranguez-Ruiz E y Ramirez-Fernandez R.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "west nile virus"], "syndromes": ["influenza-like illness", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1996-03-26 00:00:00", "1985-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-09-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2004-04-01 20:06:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-05-26 00:00:00", "1268-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-08-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Sanchez", "country": "Dominican Republic"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Nice", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Slovenia", "country": "Slovenia"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "N", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Pauli C", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "Grenada"}, {"location": "Porto", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "diagnostico", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "Tuscany , Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Battisti S", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Bessaud M", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Siena", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Valassina", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3218", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Latvia (Rezekne & Daugavpils) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3218", "date": "2006-10-05 00:00:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - LATVIA (REZEKNE & DAUGAVPILS) (02)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 5 Oct 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@ppromedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly releases, Volume 11, Issue 10, Thu 5 Oct\n2006 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/061005.asp>\n\nSince August 2006, there has been a rapid increase in clinical cases of\naseptic meningitis due to enterovirus infection in several areas of eastern\nLatvia, including the region of Rezekne (consisting of the city and\ndistrict of Rezekne and the district of Ludza), and the region of\nDaugavpils (consisting of the city and district of Daugavpils and the\ndistrict of Kraslava). By 27 Sep 258 cases had been registered in the 2\nregions of Rezekne and Daugavpils. Enterovirus has been isolated from\nsamples taken from 54 patients from these regions. In Latvia, surveillance\nof aseptic meningitis is based on mandatory clinical notification.\nRezekne city and region: epidemiological and microbiological investigation\n---------------------------------------------------\nFrom 5 Aug to 27 Sep 2006, 105 cases of aseptic meningitis were registered\n(71 in Rezekne city, 21 in Rezekne district, and 13 in Ludza district). The\npatients included 89 children aged up to 18 years and 16 adults. The cases\nof aseptic meningitis in children were registered in 12 pre-school\nfacilities and in 13 schools in Rezekne city, Rezekne district and Ludza\ndistrict, and in a boarding school. To date, no cases have been severe and\nno sequelae have been reported in any of the patients.\nBy 27 Sep 2006, the national reference laboratory had isolated identical\nstrains of echovirus 30 from samples from 24 patients. Additionally,\nenteroviruses have been isolated from 11 patients, but the strains have not\nyet been serotyped.\nAn epidemiological investigation was launched by the Rezekne public health\nauthorities, and this determined that initial transmission was associated\nwith attending a sports centre in Rezekne, where several childrens' sports\nteams simultaneously use a common changing room. The changing room is very\nsmall and there was close contact between children. During the breaks, the\nchildren reported drinking non-potable water from a tap intended for\ncleaning the facilities. All the initial cases were associated with the\nsports centre. Secondary transmission to the initial patients' household\nand social contacts occurred. For the majority of subsequent cases it was\npossible to trace a link to an earlier case.\nDaugavpils city and district and Kraslava district: epidemiological and\nmicrobiological investigation\n----------------------------------------------------\nA rapid increase in number of cases of aseptic meningitis has been observed\nsince the beginning of September 2006. By 27 Sep 2006, 153 cases had been\nreported (104 in Daugavpils city, 38 in Daugavpils district, and 11 in\nKraslava district). Several cases reported in Kraslava are\nepidemiologically linked to the outbreak in Rezekne. Most of the patients\nare children. Cases have been registered in 12 pre-school facilities, 41\nschools, 4 vocational schools, one children's home and one university. All\nthe patients were admitted to hospital. By 27 Sep 2006, the microbiological\ninvestigation at the national reference laboratory had confirmed the\ncirculation of 3 serotypes of enterovirus: echovirus 6 (6 cases in August\n2006), and echovirus 20 (4 cases in August 2006) and echovirus 30 (4 cases\nin September 2006). Enterovirus has so far also been isolated from 5\npatients, but not yet serotyped. [The distribution of cases of aseptic\nmeningitis by age group, sex and location are tabulated in the original text.]\nDiscussion\n----------\nIn comparison with this year's numbers, in the period August to September\nin the previous 3 years, less than one case (average 0.7, range 0.3 to 1)\nwas registered per week in the affected regions. The national Public Health\nAgency is continuing to collect epidemiological data. The data [presented\nas a figure in the original ext] indicate a [dramatic] growth in number of\ncases of meningitis in the affected areas. In view of the rapid increase,\nthe seasonal character (summer-autumn) of enteroviral infections, and other\nfactors, more cases are expected. Importation and transmission of infection\nfrom and to other areas cannot be excluded.\nControl measures initiated by the national Public Health Agency\n---------------------------------------------------\nFrom the very beginning of the outbreak, the PHA and its branches in the\naffected areas have been working together to implement the following measures:\n(1) Detailed recommendations have been prepared and distributed to the\nresidents and educational establishments for the prevention of enteroviral\naseptic meningitis;\n(2) epidemiological monitoring of the morbidity of aseptic meningitides\n(daily reporting and analysis on the national level) was reinforced;\n(3) control measures in the foci of infection have been organised;\n(4) consultations and recommendations to the residents and institutions,\nincluding municipalities, boards of education, educational establishments\nand health care facilities, were provided;\n(5) control of drinking water quality, including virological control, has\nbeen carried out;\n(6) standard operational plans for other territories in case of an outbreak\nof aseptic meningitis have been developed.\nIn addition, the PHA branches in Rezekne and Daugavpils have suggested that\nthe following preventive measures be carried out by the municipality in all\nthe educational establishments:\n(1) To provide educational establishments with disposable cups for drinking\nwater;\n(2) to provide all the schools with soft soap and paper towels for handwashing;\n(3) to provide schools with disposable kitchenware when it is impossible to\nensure thermal treatment of dishes after washing;\n(4) It has also been recommended that the local authorities in the affected\nareas limit or cancel large social gatherings scheduled for late September\nand early October. Public health authorities have strengthened the\nepidemiological and virological surveillance of aseptic meningitis across\nthe whole country and will continue implementation of the measures\nmentioned above.\n[By J Perevoscikovs (<perevoscikovs@sva.lv>), I .Lucenko, R Nikiforova.\nDepartment of Epidemiological Surveillance of Infectious Diseases, State\nPublic Health Agency (Valsts a ent ra 'Sabiedr bas vesel bas a ent ra)].\nAcknowledgments:\nWe are grateful to Dr. Aleksandr Vasiljev and Dr. Marina Mandzgaladze from\nPHA Rezekne branch, Dr.Nonna Voloscuka and Dr.Inna Singarjova from PHA\nDaugavpils branch for their practical work conducting outbreak\ninvestigation and providing us with data, to Prof. Vaira Irisa Kalnina and\nDr. Violeta Mavcutko from PHA Virological laboratory for information about\nresults of investigations.\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The highlights of this comprehensive investigation are the tracing of the\norigin of the Rezekne city and region component of the outbreak to the\nconsumption by several disparate groups of children of non-potable water\nfrom a single source at a sports centre. The causative agent has been\nidentified as echovirus 30. The source of the Daugavpils city and district\nand Kraslava district has not been identified, but echovirus 6 and\nechovirus 20, in addition to echovirus 30, all known to be aseptic\nmeningitis-associated, have been isolated from patients.\nA map of Latvia locating Rezekne and Daugavpils, adjacent to the borders\nwith Russia and Belarus respectively, can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/latvia_rel98.jpg>.- Mod.CP]", "summary": "In addition, the PHA branches in Rezekne and Daugavpils have suggested that\nthe following preventive measures be carried out by the municipality in all\nthe educational establishments:\n(1) To provide educational establishments with disposable cups for drinking\nwater;\n(2) to provide all the schools with soft soap and paper towels for handwashing;\n(3) to provide schools with disposable kitchenware when it is impossible to\nensure thermal treatment of dishes after washing;\n(4) It has also been recommended that the local authorities in the affected\nareas limit or cancel large social gatherings scheduled for late September\nand early October. (daily reporting and analysis on the national level) was reinforced;\n(3) control measures in the foci of infection have been organised;\n(4) consultations and recommendations to the residents and institutions,\nincluding municipalities, boards of education, educational establishments\nand health care facilities, were provided;\n(5) control of drinking water quality, including virological control, has\nbeen carried out;\n(6) standard operational plans for other territories in case of an outbreak\nof aseptic meningitis have been developed. From the very beginning of the outbreak, the PHA and its branches in the\naffected areas have been working together to implement the following measures:\n(1) Detailed recommendations have been prepared and distributed to the\nresidents and educational establishments for the prevention of enteroviral\naseptic meningitis;\n(2) epidemiological monitoring of the morbidity of aseptic meningitides\n By 27 Sep 2006, the microbiological\ninvestigation at the national reference laboratory had confirmed the\ncirculation of 3 serotypes of enterovirus: echovirus 6 (6 cases in August\n2006), and echovirus 20 (4 cases in August 2006) and echovirus 30 (4 cases\nin September 2006). We are grateful to Dr. Aleksandr Vasiljev and Dr. Marina Mandzgaladze from\nPHA Rezekne branch, Dr.Nonna Voloscuka and Dr.Inna Singarjova from PHA\nDaugavpils branch for their practical work conducting outbreak\ninvestigation and providing us with data, to Prof. Vaira Irisa Kalnina and\nDr. Violeta Mavcutko from PHA Virological laboratory for information about\nresults of investigations. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Eurosurveillance weekly releases, Volume 11, Issue 10, Thu 5 Oct\n2006 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/061005.asp>\n\nSince August 2006, there has been a rapid increase in clinical cases of\naseptic meningitis due to enterovirus infection in several areas of eastern\n Public health authorities have strengthened the\nepidemiological and virological surveillance of aseptic meningitis across\nthe whole country and will continue implementation of the measures\nmentioned above.\n The source of the Daugavpils city and district\nand Kraslava district has not been identified, but echovirus 6 and\nechovirus 20, in addition to echovirus 30, all known to be aseptic\nmeningitis-associated, have been isolated from patients. [The highlights of this comprehensive investigation are the tracing of the\norigin of the Rezekne city and region component of the outbreak to the\nconsumption by several disparate groups of children of non-potable water\nfrom a single source at a sports centre. A map of Latvia locating Rezekne and Daugavpils, adjacent to the borders\nwith Russia and Belarus respectively, can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/latvia_rel98.jpg>.- Mod. \nDiscussion\n----------", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-08-26 00:00:00", "2006-09-26 00:00:00", "2006-09-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rezekne", "country": "Latvia"}, {"location": "Belarus", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Ludza district", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rezekne district", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Daugavpils city", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Daugavpils district", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "Latvia"}, {"location": "Rezekne city", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ludza", "country": "Latvia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2825", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Latvia (Rezekne & Daugavpils)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2825", "date": "2006-09-20 00:00:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - LATVIA (REZEKNE & DAUGAVPILS)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 20 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MediaCorp, Today online, Agence France Presse report [edited]\n<http://www.todayonline.com/articles/143730.asp>\n\n\nLatvia: Meningitis epidemic reported in east of country\n-----------------------------------------------\nHealth authorities in Latvia have said an outbreak of serous\nmeningitis -- acute meningitis accompanied by fluid accumulation in\nthe brain -- in the east of the Baltic state has reached epidemic\nproportions. [Serous meningitis is also known as viral or aseptic\nmeningitis. - Mod.CP]. '232 cases of serous meningitis have been\nregistered so far, and we can say that in Rezekne and Daugavpils\ncounties, it has reached the scale of an epidemic,' Public Health\nAgency spokeswoman Laura Bundule told Agence France Presse (AFP). As\nof Tue 19 Sep 2006, 124 cases of meningitis had been reported in\nRezekne county and 108 in Daugavpils county. Most have been hospitalized.\n\n'Serous meningitis is one of the mildest types of meningitis, but it\nis still a serious infection,' Bundule said. Symptoms of infection\nare high fever, severe headache, loss of appetite, and redness on the\nface and neck. The epidemic in eastern Latvia has affected mainly\nchildren and teenagers. 'Schools are still open but must apply\nsecurity measures, use disposable kitchenware and inform children\nabout the necessity to wash hands frequently,' Bundule said.\n\nAccording to the Latvian Public Health Agency, a large-scale outbreak\nof serous meningitis has also been registered in the region of\nKhabarovsk in eastern Russia, and in Serbia and Kosovo [see below]. A\nreport on Russia's Interfax news agency said that 419 people are\ncurrently being treated in hospitals in Khabarovsk for the disease.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Aseptic serous meningitis is likely to be a consequence of infection\nwith certain enteroviruses (predominantly echoviruses or\ncoxsackieviruses) and less frequently mumps virus in childhood, and\nherpes simplex virus in adults. Meningitis epidemics are common where\nthere are weaknesses in social infrastructure and lapses in personal\nhygiene. Illness in children may be severe but not is usually\nlife-threatening, and recovery is complete providing partial or\ncomplete immunity in adulthood.\n\nA map of Latvia locating Rezekne and Daugavpils, adjacent to the\nborders with Russia and Belarus respectively, can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/latvia_rel98.jpg>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 20 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org Health authorities in Latvia have said an outbreak of serous\nmeningitis -- acute meningitis accompanied by fluid accumulation in\nthe brain -- in the east of the Baltic state has reached epidemic\nproportions. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Aseptic serous meningitis is likely to be a consequence of infection\nwith certain enteroviruses (predominantly echoviruses or\ncoxsackieviruses) and less frequently mumps virus in childhood, and\nherpes simplex virus in adults. 232 cases of serous meningitis have been\nregistered so far, and we can say that in Rezekne and Daugavpils\ncounties, it has reached the scale of an epidemic,' Public Health\nAgency spokeswoman Laura Bundule told Agence France Presse According to the Latvian Public Health Agency, a large-scale outbreak\nof serous meningitis has also been registered in the region of\nKhabarovsk in eastern Russia, and in Serbia and Kosovo [see below]. As\nof Tue 19 Sep 2006, 124 cases of meningitis had been reported in\nRezekne county and 108 in Daugavpils county. Schools are still open but must apply\nsecurity measures, use disposable kitchenware and inform children\nabout the necessity to wash hands frequently,' Bundule said. Meningitis epidemics are common where\nthere are weaknesses in social infrastructure and lapses in personal\nhygiene.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Rezekne county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khabarovsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Serbia", "country": "Serbia"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "Kosovo"}, {"location": "Belarus", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Daugavpils county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "Latvia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2805", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Lativa (Rezekne & Daugavpils)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2805", "date": "2006-09-20 00:00:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - LATVIA (REZEKNE & DAUGAVPILS)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 20 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MediaCorp, Today online, Agence France Presse report [edited]\n<http://www.todayonline.com/articles/143730.asp>\n\n\nLatvia: Meningitis epidemic reported in east of country\n-----------------------------------------------\nHealth authorities in Latvia have said an outbreak of serous\nmeningitis -- acute meningitis accompanied by fluid accumulation in\nthe brain -- in the east of the Baltic state has reached epidemic\nproportions. [Serous meningitis is also known as viral or aseptic\nmeningitis. - Mod.CP]. '232 cases of serous meningitis have been\nregistered so far, and we can say that in Rezekne and Daugavpils\ncounties, it has reached the scale of an epidemic,' Public Health\nAgency spokeswoman Laura Bundule told Agence France Presse (AFP). As\nof Tue 19 Sep 2006, 124 cases of meningitis had been reported in\nRezekne county and 108 in Daugavpils county. Most have been hospitalized.\n\n'Serous meningitis is one of the mildest types of meningitis, but it\nis still a serious infection,' Bundule said. Symptoms of infection\nare high fever, severe headache, loss of appetite, and redness on the\nface and neck. The epidemic in eastern Latvia has affected mainly\nchildren and teenagers. 'Schools are still open but must apply\nsecurity measures, use disposable kitchenware and inform children\nabout the necessity to wash hands frequently,' Bundule said.\n\nAccording to the Latvian Public Health Agency, a large-scale outbreak\nof serous meningitis has also been registered in the region of\nKhabarovsk in eastern Russia, and in Serbia and Kosovo [see below]. A\nreport on Russia's Interfax news agency said that 419 people are\ncurrently being treated in hospitals in Khabarovsk for the disease.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Aseptic serous meningitis is likely to be a consequence of infection\nwith certain enteroviruses (predominantly echoviruses or\ncoxsackieviruses) and less frequently mumps virus in childhood, and\nherpes simplex virus in adults. Meningitis epidemics are common where\nthere are weaknesses in social infrastructure and lapses in personal\nhygiene. Illness in children may be severe but not is usually\nlife-threatening, and recovery is complete providing partial or\ncomplete immunity in adulthood.\n\nA map of Latvia locating Rezekne and Daugavpils, adjacent to the\nborders with Russia and Belarus respectively, can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/latvia_rel98.jpg>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 20 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org Health authorities in Latvia have said an outbreak of serous\nmeningitis -- acute meningitis accompanied by fluid accumulation in\nthe brain -- in the east of the Baltic state has reached epidemic\nproportions. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Aseptic serous meningitis is likely to be a consequence of infection\nwith certain enteroviruses (predominantly echoviruses or\ncoxsackieviruses) and less frequently mumps virus in childhood, and\nherpes simplex virus in adults. 232 cases of serous meningitis have been\nregistered so far, and we can say that in Rezekne and Daugavpils\ncounties, it has reached the scale of an epidemic,' Public Health\nAgency spokeswoman Laura Bundule told Agence France Presse According to the Latvian Public Health Agency, a large-scale outbreak\nof serous meningitis has also been registered in the region of\nKhabarovsk in eastern Russia, and in Serbia and Kosovo [see below].
