Meningitis epidemics are common where\nthere are weaknesses in social infrastructure and lapses in personal\nhygiene.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Khabarovsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Daugavpils county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rezekne county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "Latvia"}, {"location": "Serbia", "country": "Serbia"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "Kosovo"}, {"location": "Belarus", "country": "Belarus"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2687", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Serbia (Kosovo) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2687", "date": "2006-09-17 00:00:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - SERBIA (KOSOVO) (02)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 14 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly releases 2006, Volume 11 , Issue 9 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060914.asp#4>\n\nKosovo: Enteroviral Meningitis Outbreak: July-September 2006\n-----------------------------------------------\n(From the National Institute of Public Health, Pristina, Kosovo - UN\nAdministered Territory, Infectious Disease Clinic, Pristina, Kosovo -\nUN Administered Territory, Istituto Superiore di Sanita, Rome, Italy,\nWHO Reference Laboratory for Polio in the European Region, WHO\nOffice, Pristina, Kosovo - UN Administered Territory, and the WHO\nRegional Office for Europe, Copenhagen, Denmark <euroalert@euro.who.int>.\nFrom 1 Jul to 13 Sep 2006, 878 cases of acute neurological syndrome\nwere notified to the National Institute of Public Health, Pristina\nfrom 24 out of 30 municipalities of the UN administered territory of\nKosovo. The most affected municipalities are Malisheve (155 cases),\nMitrovice (112 cases), Gllogovc/Glogovac (109 cases),\nVushtrri/Vucitrn (100 cases), Skenderaj/Srbica (74 cases), Peje/Pec\n(71 cases), Prishtine/Pritina (68 cases), accounting for 78 percent\nof the reported cases. A total of 87 patients are currently in\nhospital at the Infectious Disease Clinic in Pristina. According to\nthe preliminary epidemiological analysis of 245 cases, 80 percent of\nthe cases were in people under 15 years of age, and 66 percent were in males.\n[Can anyone explain why a presumably waterborne infection would\npreferentially attack males & children? - Mod.JW]\nThis outbreak of acute neurological syndrome of possible viral origin\nwas reported to the World Health Organization Regional Office for\nEurope on 2 Aug 2006. On 15 Aug 2006, 28 samples (25 stool samples\nand 3 cerebrospinal fluid samples) from 27 patients were shipped for\nlaboratory testing to the WHO Reference Laboratory for Polio in the\nEuropean Region at the Istituto Superiore di Sanita (ISS), Rome,\nItaly. Enterovirus infection was detected by cell culture and\nconfirmed by serological and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests on\nat least 16 of the 28 samples currently being tested. Echovirus 2\nserotype was identified in 3 of the 16 samples. Further\ncharacterization tests on isolates are ongoing.\nControl measures\n----------------\nControl measures implemented by health authorities include: enhanced\nsurveillance, hospital screening and case management and awareness\ncampaigns to improve basic hygiene practices. The Ministry of Health\nand the Ministry of Education have developed a dedicated information\npackage for school children. The Institute of Public Health, Pristina\nis issuing daily information updates concerning the situation to the public.\nReferences\n----------\nWHO. 11 Aug 2006 - Acute neurological syndrome in Kosovo (UN\nAdministered Territory),\n<http://www.euro.who.int/surveillance/outbreaks/20060812_1>\nWHO. 18 Aug 2006 - Acute neurological syndrome in Kosovo (UN\nAdministered Territory) - Update 1,\n<http://www.euro.who.int/surveillance/outbreaks/20060818_1>\nWHO. 1 Sep 2006 - Enteroviral Meningitis in Kosovo (UN Administered\nTerritory) - Update 2,\n<http://www.euro.who.int/surveillance/outbreaks/20060901>_1>\nWHO. 8 Sep 2006 - Enteroviral Meningitis in Kosovo (UN Administered\nTerritory) - Update 3,\n<http://www.euro.who.int/surveillance/outbreaks/20060908_1>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The status of the Serbian province of Kosovo remains unresolved, and\nthe 1st report in this thread from a news agency source identified\nKosovo as a province of Serbia. This designation has been retained\nfor clarity, although Kosovo is designated now a UN administered Territory.\nThis outbreak is presumed to be an outbreak of aseptic (viral)\nmeningitis, since about 60 percent of Kosovo's population do not have\naccess to a mains water supply. A variety of enteroviruses have been\nassociated with outbreaks of aseptic meningitis, usually in\nassociation with fecal contamination of sources of drinking water.\nThis report positively identifies human echovirus 2 as the likely\nculprit in this outbreak, although so far only a minority of\npatients' samples have tested positive for this enterovirus.\nNo vaccines are available for prevention of aseptic meningitis, and\nthe best protection remains boiling of drinking water and water used\nin the preparation of food. In the longer term, improvements in the\nsupply of drinking water will be required to provide adequate\nprotection of the population of Kosovo.\nA map of the Serbian province/UN administered territory of Kosovo can\nbe accessed via\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/english/htmain.htm>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "WHO. 8 Sep 2006 - Enteroviral Meningitis in Kosovo (UN Administered\nTerritory) - Update 3,\n<http://www.euro.who.int/surveillance/outbreaks/20060908_1>\n--\nProMED-mail\n< (From the National Institute of Public Health, Pristina, Kosovo - UN\nAdministered Territory, Infectious Disease Clinic, Pristina, Kosovo -\nUN Administered Territory, Istituto Superiore di Sanita, Rome, Italy,\nWHO Reference Laboratory for Polio in the European Region, WHO\nOffice, Pristina, Kosovo - UN Administered Territory, and the WHO\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n On 15 Aug 2006, 28 samples (25 stool samples\nand 3 cerebrospinal fluid samples) from 27 patients were shipped for\nlaboratory testing to the WHO Reference Laboratory for Polio in the\nEuropean Region at the Istituto Superiore di Sanita (ISS), Rome,\nItaly. From 1 Jul to 13 Sep 2006, 878 cases of acute neurological syndrome\nwere notified to the National Institute of Public Health, Pristina\nfrom 24 out of 30 municipalities of the UN administered territory of\nKosovo. According to\nthe preliminary epidemiological analysis of 245 cases, 80 percent of\nthe cases were in people under 15 years of age, and 66 percent were in males.\n 11 Aug 2006 - Acute neurological syndrome in Kosovo (UN\nAdministered Territory),\n<http://www.euro.who.int/surveillance/outbreaks/20060812_1>\n ----------------\nControl measures implemented by health authorities include: enhanced\nsurveillance, hospital screening and case management and awareness\ncampaigns to improve basic hygiene practices. Mitrovice (112 cases), Gllogovc/Glogovac (109 cases),\nVushtrri/Vucitrn (100 cases), Skenderaj/Srbica (74 cases), Peje/Pec\n This outbreak of acute neurological syndrome of possible viral origin\nwas reported to the World Health Organization Regional Office for\nEurope on 2 Aug 2006. This outbreak is presumed to be an outbreak of aseptic (viral)\nmeningitis, since about 60 percent of Kosovo's population do not have\naccess to a mains water supply. This report positively identifies human echovirus 2 as the likely\nculprit in this outbreak, although so far only a minority of\npatients' samples have tested positive for this enterovirus. No vaccines are available for prevention of aseptic meningitis, and\nthe best protection remains boiling of drinking water and water used\nin the preparation of food. Enterovirus infection was detected by cell culture and\nconfirmed by serological and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests on\nat least 16 of the 28 samples currently being tested. A variety of enteroviruses have been\nassociated with outbreaks of aseptic meningitis, usually in\nassociation with fecal contamination of sources of drinking water. In the longer term, improvements in the\nsupply of drinking water will be required to provide adequate\nprotection of the population of Kosovo. [The status of the Serbian province of Kosovo remains unresolved, and\nthe 1st report in this thread from a news agency source identified\nKosovo as a province of Serbia. A map of the Serbian province/UN administered territory of Kosovo can\nbe accessed via\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/english/htmain.htm>. The Ministry of Health\nand the Ministry of Education have developed a dedicated information\npackage for school children. Update 2,\n<http://www.euro.who.int/surveillance/outbreaks/20060901>_1>\n Update 1,\n<http://www.euro.who.int/surveillance/outbreaks/20060818_1>\n References\n----------\nWHO. (71 cases), Prishtine/Pritina (68 cases), accounting for 78 percent\nof the reported cases. 18 Aug 2006 - Acute neurological syndrome in Kosovo (UN\nAdministered Territory) - 1 Sep 2006 - Enteroviral Meningitis in Kosovo (UN Administered\nTerritory) - Source: Eurosurveillance weekly releases 2006, Volume 11 , Issue 9 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060914.asp#4>\n\nKosovo:", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-08-15 00:00:00", "2006-08-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rome", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Pristina", "country": "Kosovo"}, {"location": "Copenhagen", "country": "Denmark"}, {"location": "Serbia", "country": "Serbia"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "Kosovo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2650", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk)(03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2650", "date": "2006-09-13 00:00:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (KHABAROVSK) (03)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 13 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Itar-Tass [edited]\n<http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=10787337&PageNum=0>\n\nTens of new meningitis cases registered daily in Russian region\n-----------------------------------------------\nAbout 20 new serous viral meningitis cases have been registered daily\nin the Khabarovsk Territory this week.\nThe regional government's press service told ITAR-TASS on Wednesday\n[13 Sep 2006] that the number of affected people had increased to\n1490 since the beginning of the disease outbreak. About 400 have been\nhospitalized with enterovirus meningitis. Specialists of the\nterritorial Health Department described the situation as tense. New\ncases have been registered in Komsomolsk-on-Amur and 3 adjacent areas.\nCauses of the virus spread are bathing in the Amur river and open\nreservoirs, contact and aerial infection transmission. Tests revealed\nenterovirus ECHO-6, hepatitis A virus and rotaviruses in water\nsamples from the Amur and in sewage.\nSanitarians say the viral meningitis rate had been declining as a\nresult of anti-epidemic measures.\nThere have been no cluster cases in children's day stay centers.\nLong-term observation has shown that outbreaks of serous viral\nmeningitis continue for 14 weeks. The morbidity situation is expected\nto return to normal in late September 2006. The school year has not\nbegun for 1st to 8th graders so far. Children under 14 years are\nforbidden to attend all mass functions to avoid exposure to crowds.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 11 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail-RUS Correspondent VM <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IA Regnum, 11 Sep 2006 [translated from Russian by Corresp.ARS, edited]\n<http://www.regnum.ru/news/702644.html>\n\nNew cases of serous-viral meningitis are registered in Khabarovsk Area\n-----------------------------------------------\n14 new cases of serous-viral meningitis have been registered in the\nKhabarovsk Region during the past few days, of which there were 7\ncases in Komsomolsk on Amur, and some cases in Khabarovsk and\nNanayskiy, Komsomolskiy, Solnechniy, Vaninskiy, and in the\nSovieto-Havanskiy regions. This information was given to IA Regnum by\nthe Agency of Rospotrebnadzor in the Khabarovsk Area. Currently, 434\npatients are in the hospitals of the Khabarovsk Area, including 411\ncases with confirmed diagnosis of serous-viral meningitis.\nSerous-viral meningitis has been diagnosed in 958 cases from 1 Jul\nto 10 Sep 2006.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This appears to be a continuation of a previously reported viral\nmeningitis outbreak. In the previous post, Mod.CP indicated that\nhuman echovirus 30 was also involved. See the copy of his previous\ncomments below. - Mod.TY]\n[Historically, echoviruses 6, 9, 11, 19, and 30 have been associated\nwith outbreaks of aseptic (serous) meningitis, accompanied by a rash\nin the case of echoviruses 6 and 9. Fortunately, recovery is usually\ncomplete within a few weeks, with risk of neurological complications\nonly in the very young.\nIn the current ICTV classification of viruses, ECHO-6 and ECHO-30 are\ndesignated Human echovirus 6 and Human echovirus 30 and ranked as\nserologically distinct members of the virus species _Human\nenterovirus B_. - Mod.CP]\n[Comment from PRO/RUS posting of article [2]: It is necessary to note\nagain that persons in affected areas should maintain preventive\nmeasures, including good hygiene, disinfection and cleaning of areas,\nwater boiling, avoidance of cinemas and play gardens, extended school\nvacations, quarantines etc. Unfortunately, there is no vaccine for\nenteroviral infection. - Corr.VM]", "summary": "-----------------------------------------------\n14 new cases of serous-viral meningitis have been registered in the\nKhabarovsk Region during the past few days, of which there were 7\ncases in Komsomolsk on Amur, and some cases in Khabarovsk and\nNanayskiy, Komsomolskiy, Solnechniy, Vaninskiy, and in the\nSovieto-Havanskiy regions. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Comment from PRO/RUS posting of article [2]: It is necessary to note\nagain that persons in affected areas should maintain preventive\nmeasures, including good hygiene, disinfection and cleaning of areas,\nwater boiling, avoidance of cinemas and play gardens, extended school\nvacations, quarantines etc. In the current ICTV classification of viruses, ECHO-6 and ECHO-30 are\ndesignated Human echovirus 6 and Human echovirus 30 and ranked as\nserologically distinct members of the virus species _Human\nenterovirus B_. - Mod. -----------------------------------------------\nAbout 20 new serous viral meningitis cases have been registered daily\nin the Khabarovsk Territory this week. ARS, edited]\n<http://www.regnum.ru/news/702644.html>\n\nNew cases of serous-viral meningitis are registered in Khabarovsk Area\n Serous-viral meningitis has been diagnosed in 958 cases from 1 Jul\nto 10 Sep 2006.\n [Historically, echoviruses 6, 9, 11, 19, and 30 have been associated\nwith outbreaks of aseptic (serous) meningitis, accompanied by a rash\nin the case of echoviruses 6 and 9. Currently, 434\npatients are in the hospitals of the Khabarovsk Area, including 411\ncases with confirmed diagnosis of serous-viral meningitis. Source: Itar-Tass [edited]\n<http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=10787337&PageNum=0>\n\nTens of new meningitis cases registered daily in Russian region\n Tests revealed\nenterovirus ECHO-6, hepatitis A virus and rotaviruses in water\nsamples from the Amur and in sewage. Fortunately, recovery is usually\ncomplete within a few weeks, with risk of neurological complications\nonly in the very young. --\nProMED-mail\n< \nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n Long-term observation has shown that outbreaks of serous viral\nmeningitis continue for 14 weeks. Sanitarians say the viral meningitis rate had been declining as a\nresult of anti-epidemic measures. [This appears to be a continuation of a previously reported viral\nmeningitis outbreak.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hepatitis a"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1490-03-26 00:00:00", "2006-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2011-06-09 19:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the", "country": "Anguilla"}, {"location": "the Khabarovsk Area", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khabarovsk", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2590", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, enterovirus - Italy (Piemonte) ex India", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2590", "date": "2006-09-09 00:00:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, ENTEROVIRUS - ITALY (PIEMONTE) EX INDIA\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 9 Sep 2006\nFrom: Pietro Caramello and Guido Calleri <malattieinfettive-a@asl3.to.it>\n\nItaly: Outbreak of Enteroviral Meningitis in a Group of Travellers to\nWest Bengal, India\n--------------------------------------------------\nA group of 17 Italian scouts, aged 17 to 31, went hiking in West\nBengal, India (Calcutta, Nadia and Murshidabad Districts) from 19 Aug\n2006 to 1 Sep 2006. One to 5 days after returning to Italy, 7 of them\npresented to our hospital with fever, headache and neck stiffness.\nCSF examination showed pleiocytosis in all patients ranging from 10\nto 1300/cells/mmc (lymphocytes in 6/7, prevalence of neutrophils in\nthe patients with 1300 cells/mmc).\nAn enterovirus was detected in CSF by PCR in 5/7 patients. Virus\ncultures are in progress on CSF, rectal and pharyngeal swabs. Serum\nsamples have been collected for antibody detection.\n--\nPietro Caramello and Guido Calleri\nAmedeo di Savoia Hospital\nInfectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine Units A and C\nC. Svizzera 164, 10149\nTorino, Italy\n<malattieinfettive-a@asl3.to.it>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Caramello and Calleri for highlighting this\nrisk for visitors to West Bengal. Further information on the precise\nidentity of the enterovirus(es) responsible for this outbreak of\nmeningitis would be appreciated, whenever available. Enterovirus\ninfections are common where there are deficiencies in public water\nsupply and sewage disposal. Certain enteroviruses such as human\nechovirus 6 and human echovirus 9 are more often associated with\nmeningitis. Fortunately viral meningitis usually resolves without\nlong-term disability.\nA map of the districts of West Bengal can be accessed at\n<http://mapsofindia.com/maps/westbengal/westbengal-district.htm>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Infectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine Units A and C\nC. Svizzera 164, 10149\nTorino, Italy\n<malattieinfettive-a@asl3.to.it>\n \nPietro Caramello and Guido Calleri\nAmedeo di Savoia Hospital\n CSF examination showed pleiocytosis in all patients ranging from 10\nto 1300/cells/mmc (lymphocytes in 6/7, prevalence of neutrophils in\nthe patients with 1300 cells/mmc). A group of 17 Italian scouts, aged 17 to 31, went hiking in West\nBengal, India (Calcutta, Nadia and Murshidabad Districts) from 19 Aug\n2006 to 1 Sep 2006. Certain enteroviruses such as human\nechovirus 6 and human echovirus 9 are more often associated with\nmeningitis. Further information on the precise\nidentity of the enterovirus(es) responsible for this outbreak of\nmeningitis would be appreciated, whenever available. Enterovirus\ninfections are common where there are deficiencies in public water\nsupply and sewage disposal.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Calleri", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4263", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - Spain (Madrid) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4263", "date": "2006-11-03 00:00:00", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - SPAIN (MADRID) (02)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 3 Nov 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release 2006, Vol 11, Issue 11 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/061103.asp#3>\n\nSpain: Increase in viral meningitis cases reported in the Autonomous\nRegion of Madrid, 2006\n----------------------------------------------------\nBetween 1 Jan and 16 Sep 2006, the Epidemiological Surveillance\nNetwork of the Autonomous Region of Madrid detected 446 cases of\nviral meningitis, an increase of 260 compared with the same period in\n2005. Viral and bacterial meningitis have been mandatorily notifiable\ndiseases in the Autonomous Region of Madrid since 1997. Clinical and\nepidemiological data are collected through a structured questionnaire\nfor every case. No changes in the reporting pattern have been\nobserved in recent years.\nThe cumulative incidence detected for the period was 7 cases per 100\n000 inhabitants (compared with 3/100 000 for the same period in\n2005). Three quarters of the cases were in children under 15 years of\nage, and 58 percent of all cases were male. The patients' ages ranged\nfrom 1 month to 73 years (median age = 5 years). The age group with\nthe highest incidence is 1-4 years (55 cases per 100 000), in\nchildren younger than 1 year (53 cases per 100 000) and in children\naged 5-9 years (46 cases per 100 000) (Figure. 1). Eleven per cent of\ncases were linked to other cases, particularly through household and\nschool contact. [These data are presented as a histogram in the text\nof the original report].\nNo sequelae have been reported in any of the patients, but 2 deaths\nhave been recorded. Both the patients who died had\nmeningoencephalitis, the cause of which was not identified.\nEnterovirus has so far been confirmed by serological or polymerase\nchain reaction (PCR) in samples from 49 patients (11 percent).\nStrains identified were mainly echovirus 30 (62 percent) and\nechovirus 6 (19 percent). Both of these serotypes are frequently\nreported in Spain.\nThis increase has also been observed in other regions of Spain. The\nnumber of cases of viral meningitis notified in 2006 in the\nAutonomous Region of Madrid has been greater than that observed\nannually from 2001 to 2005, but not as great as the outbreak due to\nechovirus 13 in 2000 [1]. Incidence in 2006 peaked in weeks 21-25\n(late spring), which is the usual pattern observed in this region. In\nthe original text these data are presented in the form of a figure\nplotting number of cases per week in 2006 against the minimum, median\nand maximum case numbers for the period 2001-2005.\nMany different viruses can cause aseptic meningitis, but\nenteroviruses are responsible for more than 80 percent of cases in\nwhich the cause is identified [2]. Enteroviruses are typically\ntransmitted through the faecal-oral or oral-oral routes and through\nrespiratory droplets and fomites. Outbreaks of enteroviruses have\noccurred frequently in a wide variety of places and years and\ncontinue to do so [3-14]. No specific prevention or control measures\nare available. Good hygiene is recommended: frequent and thorough\nhand washing (especially after changing babies' nappies),\ndisinfection of contaminated surfaces with household cleaners (such\nas diluted bleach solution), and avoidance of sharing utensils and\ndrinking containers [15].\nControl measures\n----------------\nMeasures implemented as a result of this detected increase have been\nenhanced surveillance (spreading of weekly epidemiological reports to\nthe Epidemiological Surveillance Network of the Region of Madrid),\nimprovement of diagnosis confirmation (recommendation of specimen\ncollection and transport to the Enteroviruses Reference Laboratory)\nand distribution of information leaflets on the main control measures\nrecommended to the schools affected.\n[By MA Gutierrez Rodriguez1 (<angeles.gutierrez@salud.madrid.org>), L\nGarcia Comas1, I Rodero Garduno1, C Garcia Fernandez1, M Ordobas\nGavin1, R Ramirez Fernandez1, on behalf of the Red de Vigilancia\nEpidemiologica de la Comunidad de Madrid (Epidemiological\nSurveillance Network of the Autonomous Region of Madrid). 1Instituto\nde Salud Publica de la Comunidad de Madrid, Madrid, Spain]\nReferences\n----------\n(1) Trallero G, Casas I, Avellon A, Perez C, Tenorio A, de la Loma A.\nFirst epidemia of aseptic meningitis due to echovirus type 13 among\nSpanish children. Epidemiol Infect 2003; 130:251-6.\n(2) AR Tunkel and WM Scheld. Meningitis aguda. En Enfermedades\nInfecciosas. Principios y practica. GL Mandell, JE Bennett y R Dolin.\n6th ed. Elsevier Espana, S.A. Madrid 2006.\n(3) National Institute of Public Health, Pristina, Kosovo - UN\nAdministered Territory, Infectious Disease Clinic, Pristina, Kosovo -\nUN Administered Territory, Istituto Superiore di Sanita, Rome, Italy,\nWHO Reference Laboratory for Polio in the European Region, WHO\nOffice, Pristina, Kosovo - UN Administered Territory, WHO Regional\nOffice for Europe, Copenhagen, Denmark. Enteroviral meningitis\noutbreak, Kosovo, July-September 2006. Euro Surveill\n2006;11(9):E060914.4. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060914.asp#4>\n(4) Kmetzsch CI, Balkie EMR, Monteiro A et al. Echovirus 13 aseptic\nmeningitis, Brazil. Emerging Infectious Diseases 2006; 12 (8):1289-91 (letter).\n(5) Antona D, Chomel J, Enterovirus Surveillance Laboratory Network.\nIncrease in viral meningitis cases reported in France, summer 2005.\nEuro Surveill 2005;10(9):E050908.1. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2005/050908.asp#1>\n(6) CDC. Outbreaks of aseptic meningitis associated with Echoviruses\n9 and 30 and preliminary Surveillance reports on Enterovirus\nactivity- United States, 2003. MMWR 2003; 52(32):761-4.\n(7) Noah N, Reid F. Recent increases in incidence of echoviruses 13\nand 30 around Europe. Eurosurveillance Weekly [1812-075X]. 2002 Feb\n14;2(7) 020214. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2002/020214.asp#4>\n(8) Hauri A, Letz A, Schimmelpfennig M, Schreier E, Twisselmann B.\nOutbreak of aseptic viral meningitis in Germany. Eurosurveillance\nWeekly [1812-075X]. 2001 Sep 13;9(37) 010913. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2001/010913.asp#2>\n(9) CDSC. Viral meningitis in England and Wales associated with an\nincrease of echovirus type 30. Commun Dis Rep Wkly 2001; 11(35).\n(10) Sarmiento L, Mas P, Goyenechea A et al. First epidemic of\nEchovirus 16 meningitis in Cuba. Emerging Infectious Diseases 2001; 7(5):887-9.\n(11) Twisselmann B. Cluster of cases of viral meningitis caused by\nechovirus type 13 in Germany . Eurosurveillance Weekly [1812-075X].\n2000 Oct 5;10(40) 001005. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2000/001005.asp#3>\n(12) CDSC. Echovirus 30 outbreak of aseptic\nmeningitis in Turkey. Pediatr Infect Dis J 2000; 19(5):490 (letter).\n(15) Melnick JL. Poliovirus and other enteroviruses. In Viral\nInfections of Humans. Epidemiology and Control. Ed. Alfred S. Evans\nand Richard A. Kaslow, fourth edition. New York 1997.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[These data show that the outbreak peaked between weeks 20 and 25 and\ndeclined to pre-outbreak levels by week 33. The outbreak in the\nMadrid region now appears to be over. Of the total cases, 81 percent\nwere confirmed as viral infections (echovirus 30 and echovirus 6).\nThe same serotypes were associated also with viral meningitis\noutbreaks in Latvia later in the summer -- see ProMED-mail post:\nMeningitis - Latvia (Rezekne & Daugavpils) (02) 20061005.2850. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "----------------\nMeasures implemented as a result of this detected increase have been\nenhanced surveillance (spreading of weekly epidemiological reports to\nthe Epidemiological Surveillance Network of the Region of Madrid),\nimprovement of diagnosis confirmation (recommendation of specimen\ncollection and transport to the Enteroviruses Reference Laboratory)\nand distribution of information leaflets on the main control measures\nrecommended to the schools affected.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n (3) National Institute of Public Health, Pristina, Kosovo - UN\nAdministered Territory, Infectious Disease Clinic, Pristina, Kosovo -\nUN Administered Territory, Istituto Superiore di Sanita, Rome, Italy,\nWHO Reference Laboratory for Polio in the European Region, WHO\nOffice, Pristina, Kosovo - UN Administered Territory, WHO Regional\nOffice for Europe, Copenhagen, Denmark. For the\nconvenience of readers, the corrected post is reproduced here,\nProMED-mail regrets this typographical error. - Mod.CP]\nDate: Fri 1 Sep 2006\nFrom: Lars Blad <lars.blad@gmail.com>\n\n[The following information has been provided by Lars Blad in response\nto Mod.NP's comment (see: ProMED-mail post 'Meningitis - Russia\n(Khabarovsk)' 20060830.2471, dated 30 Aug 2006) that no etiology for\nthe meningitis outbreak in Khabarovsk was available, although\nenterovirus infection is probably responsible.]\nI am able to assist on this issue. On the official website of the\nRussian Federation Federal Service for Surveillance in the Field of\nProtection of Consumer Rights and Human Welfare (Rospotrebnadzor)\n<http://www.rospotrebnadzor.ru/>,\na news release (in Russian) was posted on 29 Aug 2006 entitled: 'On\nthe epidemiological situation in the Khabarovsk territory,' wherein\nit is reported that 2 enteroviruses, ECHO-6 and ECHO-30, have been\nisolated from meningitis patients:\n<http://www.rospotrebnadzor.ru/info/pressreleases/?id=3D525>.\n--\nLars Blad\nInfectious Disease Specialist\nAssistant County Medical Officer for Communicable Disease Control\nCounty of Vasternorrland and Department of Communicable Diseases Control\nSundsvall Hospital\nSundsvall, Sweden\n<Lars.blad@gmail.com>\n[ProMED-mail welcomes the cooperation of Lars Blad in obtaining this\ninformation. Historically, echoviruses 6, 9, 11, 19, and 30 have been\nassociated with outbreaks of aseptic (serous) meningitis, accompanied\nby a rash in the case of echoviruses 6 and 9. Fortunately, recovery\nis usually complete within a few weeks, with risk of neurological\ncomplications only in the very young.\nIn the current ICTV classification of viruses, ECHO-6 and ECHO-30 are\ndesignated Human echovirus 6 and Human echovirus 30 and ranked as\nserologically distinct members of the virus species _Human\nenterovirus B_. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "On the official website of the\nRussian Federation Federal Service for Surveillance in the Field of\nProtection of Consumer Rights and Human Welfare (Rospotrebnadzor)\n<http://www.rospotrebnadzor.ru/>,\na news release (in Russian) was posted on 29 Aug 2006 entitled: 'On\nthe epidemiological situation in the Khabarovsk territory,' wherein\nit is reported that 2 enteroviruses, ECHO-6 and ECHO-30, have been\nisolated from meningitis patients:\n<http://www.rospotrebnadzor.ru/info/pressreleases/?id=3D525>.\n \nLars Blad\nInfectious Disease Specialist\nAssistant County Medical Officer for Communicable Disease Control\nCounty of Vasternorrland and Department of Communicable Diseases Control\nSundsvall Hospital\nSundsvall, Sweden\n<Lars.blad@gmail.com>\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n NP's comment (see: ProMED-mail post 'Meningitis - Russia\n(Khabarovsk)' 20060830.2471, dated 30 Aug 2006) that no etiology for\nthe meningitis outbreak in Khabarovsk was available, although\nenterovirus infection is probably responsible.] In the current ICTV classification of viruses, ECHO-6 and ECHO-30 are\ndesignated Human echovirus 6 and Human echovirus 30 and ranked as\nserologically distinct members of the virus species _Human\nenterovirus B_. - Mod. On the official web site of the Russian\nFederation Federal Service for Surveillance in the Field of Protection of\nConsumer Rights and Human Welfare (Rospotrebnadzor)\n<http://www.rospotrebnadzor.ru/> a news release (in Russian) was posted on\n29 Aug 2006 entitled: 'On the epidemiological situation in the Khabarovsk\nterritory', wherein it is reported that 2 enteroviruses, ECHO-6 and\nECHO-30, have been isolated from meningitis patients.\n(<http://www.rospotrebnadzor.ru/info/pressreleases/?id=3D525>).\n--\nLars Blad\nInfectious Disease Specialist\nAssistant County Medical Officer for Communicable Disease Control\nCounty of Vasternorrland\nand\nDepartment of Communicable Diseases Control\nSundsvall Hospital\nSundsvall, Sweden\n<Lars.blad@gmail.com>\n[ProMED-mail welcomes the cooperation of Lars Blad in obtaining this\ninformation. Historically, echoviruses 6, 9, 11, 19, and 30 have been\nassociated with outbreaks of septic (serous) meningitis, accompanied by a\nrash in the case of echoviruses 6 and 9. Fortunately, recovery is usually\ncomplete within a few weeks, with risk of neurological complications only\nin the very young.\nIn the current ICTV classification of viruses, ECHO-6 and ECHO-30 are\ndesignated Human echovirus 6 and Human echovirus 30 and ranked as\nserologically distinct members of the virus species _Human enterovirus B_.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "\nLars Blad\nInfectious Disease Specialist\nAssistant County Medical Officer for Communicable Disease Control\nCounty of Vasternorrland\nand\nDepartment of Communicable Diseases Control\nSundsvall Hospital\nSundsvall, Sweden\n<Lars.blad@gmail.com>\n On the official web site of the Russian\nFederation Federal Service for Surveillance in the Field of Protection of\nConsumer Rights and Human Welfare (Rospotrebnadzor)\n<http://www.rospotrebnadzor.ru/> a news release (in Russian) was posted on\n29 Aug 2006 entitled: 'On the epidemiological situation in the Khabarovsk\nterritory', wherein it is reported that 2 enteroviruses, ECHO-6 and\nECHO-30, have been isolated from meningitis patients.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n NP's comment (see: ProMED-mail post 'Meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk)'\n20060830.2471, dated 30 Aug 2006) that no etiology for the meningitis\noutbreak in Khabarovsk was available, although enterovirus infection is\nprobably responsible.] Historically, echoviruses 6, 9, 11, 19, and 30 have been\nassociated with outbreaks of septic (serous) meningitis, accompanied by a\nrash in the case of echoviruses 6 and 9. In the current ICTV classification of viruses, ECHO-6 and ECHO-30 are\ndesignated Human echovirus 6 and Human echovirus 30 and ranked as\nserologically distinct members of the virus species _Human enterovirus B_. Fortunately, recovery is usually\ncomplete within a few weeks, with risk of neurological complications only\nin the very young. [ProMED-mail welcomes the cooperation of Lars Blad in obtaining this\ninformation. [The following information has been provided by Lars Blad in response to\nMod. MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (KHABAROVSK) (02)\n Date: Fri 1 Sep 2006\n From: Lars Blad <lars.blad@gmail.com>\n **\n \n \n \n- Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-06-09 19:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khabarovsk", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2522", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2522", "date": "2006-08-30 00:00:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (KHABAROVSK)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Wed 30 Aug 2006\nFrom: Dan Silver <dgsilver@yahoo.com>\nSource: FSONNNLINE, Foshan Daily, Wed 30 Aug 2006 [translated from Chinese\nby Dan Silver, edited]\n<http://www.fsonline.com.cn/news/world.asp?id=5210700>\n\nRussia: Meningitis outbreak in Khabarovsk\n-----------------------------------------\nAccording to reports in the Russian press on Tue 29 Aug 2006, an outbreak\nof meningitis has occurred in the Russian Far East border region of\nKhabarovsk, with hundreds infected. In the 2 principal border cities of\nKhabarovsk and Komsomolsk-on-the-Amur, a total of over 700 people have been\ninfected, most of them children under 14 years of age. The local\nauthorities are considering whether to delay the start of the school year\nto prevent spread of the disease in schools. Local health care workers say\nmany of the children became infected by drinking unclean water. The virus\nwas then transmitted in the population through droplets of saliva.\n--\nDan Silver\n<dgsilver@yahoo.com>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 29 Aug 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail Russian Correspondent Vadim Melnik <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Russia-ru News Agency, Tue 29 Aug 2006 [translated by Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.regions.ru/news/health/2002695/>\n\nRussian Far East: outbreak of viral meningitis among children in Khabarovsk\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe start of the school year may be delayed in schools of the Khabarovsk\nArea as a result of an outbreak of viral meningitis. According to Vladimir\nOtt, head of administration at Rospotrebnadzor, the issue of a delayed\nstart of the school year will be considered on Wed 30 Aug 2006, taking into\naccount the epidemiological situation.\nMore than 800 cases of meningitis in children have been registered in the\narea since the end of June 2006. Usually, about a few hundred children are\ninfected in the region during the summer. The source of infection is\nusually the river Amur, where the microbiological and virological\nindicators are not favorable at this time of year. Children may have\ncontracted the infection when swimming in pools or by drinking unboiled tap\nwater. The infection may be spread subsequently by air-droplets.\nNo kindergarten, resort camps or other institutions for children in the\narea have been closed due to the outbreak. Teachers and doctors ensure that\nall precautions are taken to protect children from infection. Unsupervised\nchildren are at risk of infection as a rule. Most cases occurred in the\nKhabarovsk, Komsomolsk-on-Amur and Nanayskiy Regions.\nCurrently, there are about 150 children with a diagnosis of meningitis in\nthe infectious diseases units of pediatric hospitals in Khabarovsk. Since\nthe end of July 2006, there were 323 children with this diagnosis in\nKhabarovsk. Public health doctors have recommended the parents keep their\nchildren away from shows and cultural events. Prohibition of swimming in\nthe river Amur has been in force since the beginning of summer.\nViral meningitis is a seasonal infection in the area. Usually, transmission\nis most active in summer. Susceptibility is high in children below 14, as a\nrule. Outbreaks of viral meningitis occur cyclically.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although no etiology of meningitis is mentioned in this report,\nenterovirus infection is probably responsible. High morbidity of viral\nmeningitis in the neighboring Amur Region has also been observed, in which\ncase one of the routes of infection is considered to be fecal contamination\nof the waters of the Amur river. - Mod.NP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n --\nDan Silver\n<dgsilver@yahoo.com>\n******\n High morbidity of viral\nmeningitis in the neighboring Amur Region has also been observed, in which\ncase one of the routes of infection is considered to be fecal contamination\nof the waters of the Amur river. Source: FSONNNLINE, Foshan Daily, Wed 30 Aug 2006 [translated from Chinese\nby Dan Silver, edited]\n<http://www.fsonline.com.cn/news/world.asp?id=5210700>\n\nRussia: Meningitis outbreak in Khabarovsk\n According to Vladimir\nOtt, head of administration at Rospotrebnadzor, the issue of a delayed\nstart of the school year will be considered on Wed 30 Aug 2006, taking into\naccount the epidemiological situation. According to reports in the Russian press on Tue 29 Aug 2006, an outbreak\nof meningitis has occurred in the Russian Far East border region of\nKhabarovsk, with hundreds infected. AS, edited]\n<http://www.regions.ru/news/health/2002695/>\n\nRussian Far East: outbreak of viral meningitis among children in Khabarovsk\n Children may have\ncontracted the infection when swimming in pools or by drinking unboiled tap\nwater. In the 2 principal border cities of\nKhabarovsk and Komsomolsk-on-the-Amur, a total of over 700 people have been\ninfected, most of them children under 14 years of age. Since\nthe end of July 2006, there were 323 children with this diagnosis in\nKhabarovsk. The source of infection is\nusually the river Amur, where the microbiological and virological\nindicators are not favorable at this time of year. The local\nauthorities are considering whether to delay the start of the school year\nto prevent spread of the disease in schools. In the\nprevious report, 'fushouluo' was erroneously used to refer to the giant\nAfrican snail. Instead, it refers to the Amazonian snail, which is\ndistinctly smaller. This moderator apologizes for the mistake. Also,\nfushouluo lays bright pinkish, round, hard-shelled eggs that cling to the\nlower parts of aquatic plants, while the giant African snail lays beige\nhard-shelled eggs in a shallow pit on land.\nA map of Beijing can be accessed at:\n<http://archives.cnn.com/2000/ASIANOW/weather/08/24/asia.typhoon/map.china.beijing.jpg>.\n- Mod.RY]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Also,\nfushouluo lays bright pinkish, round, hard-shelled eggs that cling to the\nlower parts of aquatic plants, while the giant African snail lays beige\nhard-shelled eggs in a shallow pit on land. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n The number of people confirmed to have fallen ill after eating raw or\nhalf-cooked snails contaminated with parasites at a Beijing restaurant has\nrisen from 70 to 87, the Beijing Health Bureau reported yesterday. Qu Chuangang, spokesman for Shuguoyanyi Restaurant, which serves\nSichuan-style dishes, said it will assume responsibility for the incident\nand try to deal with the problems caused. The Kosovo National\nHealth Institute in Pristina said 123 new cases of meningitis were\nregistered over the past week, raising the number of people infected with\nthe disease to 553, Belgrade's Beta news agency reported on Wed 30 Aug 2006.\nDrinking water contaminated with waste is the main cause of meningitis\noutbreaks in the predominantly ethnic-Albanian province of Kosovo. Ilir\nBegolli, Director of the Health Institute, said the number of new cases has\nbeen decreasing but not at a satisfactory pace, the agency said. He said\nabout 90 patients stricken with meningitis are in Pristina's clinical center.\nThe epidemic, which is spreading mainly among children, is under control,\nand hospitals in Kosovo are well-equipped with doctors, equipment, and\nmedicine, Begolli said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This outbreak has still to be contained, suggesting that improvements in\nsocial infrastructure and the provision of clean drinking have yet to be\nachieved. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The Kosovo National\nHealth Institute in Pristina said 123 new cases of meningitis were\nregistered over the past week, raising the number of people infected with\nthe disease to 553, Belgrade's Beta news agency reported on Wed 30 Aug 2006. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n ---------------------------------------------\nPhysicians in the Serbian province of Kosovo have registered 553 cases of\nmeningitis since an epidemic began on 1 Jul 2006. Ilir\nBegolli, Director of the Health Institute, said the number of new cases has\nbeen decreasing but not at a satisfactory pace, the agency said. Source: United Press International, Wed 30 Aug 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/view.php?StoryID=20060830-082707-5028r>\n\nSerbia: meningitis outbreak in Kosovo spreads\n The epidemic, which is spreading mainly among children, is under control,\nand hospitals in Kosovo are well-equipped with doctors, equipment, and\nmedicine, Begolli said. [This outbreak has still to be contained, suggesting that improvements in\nsocial infrastructure and the provision of clean drinking have yet to be\nachieved. Drinking water contaminated with waste is the main cause of meningitis\noutbreaks in the predominantly ethnic-Albanian province of Kosovo. He said\nabout 90 patients stricken with meningitis are in Pristina's clinical center. Date: Wed 30 Aug 2006\n MENINGITIS - SERBIA (KOSOVO) (02)\n From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n \n-- **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Belgrade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pristina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ilir", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2060", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - Spain (Madrid)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2060", "date": "2006-08-01 00:00:00", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - SPAIN (MADRID)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 31 Jul 2005\nFrom: Pablo Nart <pablo.nart@terra.es>\nSource: El Pais, Madrid, Mon 31 Jul 2006 [translated by submitter; edited]\n<http://www.elpais.es/articulo/madrid/meningitis/virica/ha/causado/enero/411/casos/muertes/region/elpepiautmad/20060731elpmad_2/Tes/>\n\nThe incidence of viral meningitis has increased dramatically in the\n[Madrid] region in 2006. Since January it has afflicted 411 people, almost\n3 times more than the total for the same period in 2005. Eighty per cent of\nthe patients are under 15 years of age, and 2 have died.\nThe disease generally takes a benign form and cyclical epidemic outbreaks\noccur every 5-6 years There is neither a vaccine nor specific treatment.\nThe last [large outbreak] occurred in 2000 and affected 994 people. A\nreport of the Regional Department of Health reveals that the [current\noutbreak] is exhibiting great virulence, with an average of 25 cases per week.\nThe term meningitis embraces a wide range of viral and bacterial infectious\nagents which affect the membranes that cover the brain. The most serious\nform, against which there is a vaccine, is meningitis C, caused by a\nbacterium which can kill 15-25 per cent of patients, according to data from\nthe [Spanish (presumably. - Mod.SH)] Department of Health. More benign\nforms of meningitis are associated with viral infection. Viral meningitis\ncan be caused by more than 20 different viruses which can infect the\nmeninges, such as chickenpox virus and herpes simplex virus. The Department\nof Health has stated that the great majority of the cases of viral\nmeningitis take a mild course with no complications.\nIldefonso Hernandez, president of the Spanish Society of Epidemiology, said\nthat: 'Cyclical outbreaks of viral meningitis, like the present one, are\ncaused by enteroviruses, usually producing mild forms of disease.'\nEnteroviruses, like the other viruses that can cause meningitis, are\nwidespread and many people can be in contact with them without developing\nhealth problems. By causes that are not fully understood, every few years\n[such] viruses may undergo changes that enable them to reach and infect the\nmeninges.\n'Perhaps as in the case of the influenza viruses, an accumulation of small\ngenetic changes enables the virus to escape previously acquired [host]\nimmunity. After the 2000 outbreak, the incidence in the region declined to\nan average of between 200 to 300 annual cases, or about 4-5 cases a week.\n[In the present outbreak] by the end of February/beginning of March, there\nwas a sharp increase to 18 weekly cases, follow by a decrease in incidence\nto the more usual numbers. Subsequently, from the beginning of the last\nweek of May the [number] of cases of viral meningitis has [increased\nagain], reaching an average of 25 cases weekly, according to medical\nreports. (The most recent data are for the week 16-23 Jul 2006).\nThe viral meningitis outbreaks of 2000 and the present one follow similar\npatterns: mainly affecting younger people -- 81 per cent of the first 312\npatients were younger than 15 years, with an average of age of 5 years; 61\nper cent of patients are male. The symptoms of all the meningitis cases\ninclude fever, headache, and neck stiffness.\nEven in a mild case of viral meningitis physicians recommend a brief\nhospital stay, to allow exclusion of the more serious meningitis B or C by\nlaboratory diagnosis. If the meningitis is confirmed as viral, the patient\nis sent home with symptomatic treatment against the fever and the pains.\nVery rarely the disease lasts more than 10 or 15 days.\nTwo people have died in the present outbreak: males of 5 and 45 years,\naccording to the report of the Department of Health. A spokesman of the\ncouncil said that: 'Virus meningitis fatalities are usually patients who\npresented/displayed other ailments or that had impaired immune systems. It\nis very unusual for enteroviral meningitis to cause death.'\nThe disease is present in a dozen schools and nurseries. The Department of\nHealth has kept parents informed. 'It is important to [reassure] parents,\nwho are usually scared when they hear the word meningitis, and inform them\nthat the disease is mild, has a limited spread capacity, although there is\nno vaccine available.'\n--\nPablo Nart\n<pablo.nart@terra.es>\n[The identity of the enterovirus responsible for the increased incidence of\nmeningitis in the Madrid region is not stated. Further information would be\nwelcomed. Aseptic (viral) meningitis has often been associated with\nenterovirus 71, a virus currently responsible for a Malaysian (Sarawak)\noutbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease which can be responsible for an\nappreciable incidence of neurological disease in young children.\nIt is suggested in the above report that the cyclical pattern of viral\nmeningitis may represent an evasion of host population immunity by\nprogressive mutation of the virus. Alternatively it may be that the current\nheat wave and water shortages in Europe have facilitated the transmission\nof viruses, such as enterovirus 71, that are transmitted predominantly by a\nfecal-oral route. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The viral meningitis outbreaks of 2000 and the present one follow similar\npatterns: mainly affecting younger people -- 81 per cent of the first 312\npatients were younger than 15 years, with an average of age of 5 years; 61\nper cent of patients are male. Aseptic (viral) meningitis has often been associated with\nenterovirus 71, a virus currently responsible for a Malaysian (Sarawak)\noutbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease which can be responsible for an\nappreciable incidence of neurological disease in young children. Subsequently, from the beginning of the last\nweek of May the [number] of cases of viral meningitis has [increased\nagain], reaching an average of 25 cases weekly, according to medical\nreports. Ildefonso Hernandez, president of the Spanish Society of Epidemiology, said\nthat: 'Cyclical outbreaks of viral meningitis, like the present one, are\ncaused by enteroviruses, usually producing mild forms of disease.'\n The most serious\nform, against which there is a vaccine, is meningitis C, caused by a\nbacterium which can kill 15-25 per cent of patients, according to data from\nthe [Spanish (presumably. - Mod. It is important to [reassure] parents,\nwho are usually scared when they hear the word meningitis, and inform them\nthat the disease is mild, has a limited spread capacity, although there is\nno vaccine available.' Alternatively it may be that the current\nheat wave and water shortages in Europe have facilitated the transmission\nof viruses, such as enterovirus 71, that are transmitted predominantly by a\nfecal-oral route. \nPablo Nart\n<pablo.nart@terra.es>\n Even in a mild case of viral meningitis physicians recommend a brief\nhospital stay, to allow exclusion of the more serious meningitis B or C by\nlaboratory diagnosis. Viral meningitis\ncan be caused by more than 20 different viruses which can infect the\nmeninges, such as chickenpox virus and herpes simplex virus. It is suggested in the above report that the cyclical pattern of viral\nmeningitis may represent an evasion of host population immunity by\nprogressive mutation of the virus. The Department\nof Health has stated that the great majority of the cases of viral\nmeningitis take a mild course with no complications. After the 2000 outbreak, the incidence in the region declined to\nan average of between 200 to 300 annual cases, or about 4-5 cases a week.\n Source: El Pais, Madrid, Mon 31 Jul 2006 [translated by submitter; edited]\n<http://www.elpais.es/articulo/madrid/meningitis/virica/ha/causado/enero/411/casos/muertes/region/elpepiautmad/20060731elpmad_2/Tes/>\n\nThe incidence of viral meningitis has increased dramatically in the\n A spokesman of the\ncouncil said that: 'Virus meningitis fatalities are usually patients who\npresented/displayed other ailments or that had impaired immune systems. Enteroviruses, like the other viruses that can cause meningitis, are\nwidespread and many people can be in contact with them without developing\nhealth problems. [In the present outbreak] by the end of February/beginning of March, there\nwas a sharp increase to 18 weekly cases, follow by a decrease in incidence\nto the more usual numbers.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "1971-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2354", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Serbia (Kosovo)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2354", "date": "2006-08-19 00:00:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - SERBIA (KOSOVO)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 19 Aug 2006\nFrom: Pablo Nart <pablo.nart@terra.es>\nSource: Health News, United Press International report, Fri 18 Aug\n2006 [edited]\n<http://news.monstersandcritics.com/health/article_1191751.php/Kosovo_water_causes_meningitis_outreak>\n\nPhysicians in Serbia`s Kosovo province on Friday [18 Aug 2006]\nregistered 18 new cases of meningitis, raising the number of people\nstricken with the disease to 374. Ilir Begholi, Director of the\nKosovo Health Institute in Pristina, however, said the epidemic was\nunder control. Begholi said this was not the first time that Kosovo\nfaced a meningitis outbreak and added that his Institute had enough\ndoctors, equipment and medicine to deal with the disease, Belgrade's\nBeta news agency reported.\nDrinking water from village wells contaminated with waste is the most\nfrequent cause of meningitis outbreaks, Begholi said. Only about 40\npercent of Kosovo's 1.8 million population use water from the main\nwater systems. Begholi said the institute has undertaken emergency\nmeasures to prevent the spread of meningitis, which began early in July 2006.\n--\nPablo Nart\n<pablo.nart@terra.es>\n[This outbreak is presumed to be an outbreak of aseptic (viral)\nmeningitis since about 60 percent of Kosovo's population do not have\naccess to a main water supply. A variety of enteroviruses have been\nassociated with outbreaks of aseptic meningitis, usually in\nassociation with fecal contamination of sources of drinking water.\nThis report does not identify the particular virus or viruses\ninvolved. No vaccines are available for prevention of infection by\nviruses such as enterovirus 71 which have been associated frequently\nwith outbreaks of aseptic meningitis. The best protection is boiling\nof drinking water and water used in the preparation of food. In the\nlonger term improvements in the supply of drinking water will be\nrequired to provide adequate protection of the population of Kosovo.\nA map of the Serbian province of Kosovo can be accessed via\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/english/htmain.htm>. - Mod.CP]\n[see also\nViral meningitis - Spain (Madrid) 20060801.2128\n2005\n----\nSerous meningitis - Russia (Sverdlovsk) (02) 20051016.3022\nSerous meningitis, Russia (Sverdlovsk) 20051014.2992\nViral meningitis - France (02) 20050911.2692\nViral meningitis - France 20050910.2680\nViral meningitis - USA (UT) 20050724.2137\nViral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) (02) 20050724.2134\nViral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) 20050719.208\n2004\n----\nAseptic meningitis, school children - Russia (Ekaterinburg) 20041017.2820\nAseptic meningitis - Russia (Novosibirsk) (03) 20040828.2404\nAseptic meningitis - Russia (Novosibirsk) (02) 20040817.2277\nEchovirus 9, aseptic meningitis - USA (CT) 2003 20040814.2253\nEchovirus 30, aseptic meningitis - Puerto Rico 20040810.2211]\n........................cp/pg/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
