Viral meningitis - Spain (Madrid) 20060801.2128\n2005\n MENINGITIS - SERBIA (KOSOVO)\n****************************\n Ilir Begholi, Director of the\nKosovo Health Institute in Pristina, however, said the epidemic was\nunder control. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: 20050719.208\n2004\n---- Drinking water from village wells contaminated with waste is the most\nfrequent cause of meningitis outbreaks, Begholi said.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2006-07-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Khabarovsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Belgrade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Puerto Rico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Sverdlovsk", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2387", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - China (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2387", "date": "2006-08-22 00:00:00", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - CHINA (02)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 22 Aug 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Chinadaily.com.cn, 22 Aug 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2006-08/22/content_670398.htm>\n\nThe Beijing Bureau of Health said at a press conference yesterday that 70\npeople in Beijing have been diagnosed as suffering from Guangzhou\nAngiostrongylus meningitis.\nThe bureau said the meningitis outbreak had caused no deaths so far and 3\npatients had left hospital after treatment. But the bureau warned people\nnot to eat raw or half-cooked snails and gave a phone number, 65066969, for\nthe public to report anyone improperly cooked snails.\nGuo Zixia, an official with the Beijing municipal office of health\ninspection, said it would impose administrative punishment on Shuguo Yanyi\nRestaurant for improperly cooking the Amazonian snails, which caused the\noutbreak.\nThe office on Sunday issued an urgent notice prohibiting the sale of raw or\nhalf-cooked freshwater snails in the city's restaurants. The office also\nrequired restaurants to boil snails thoroughly before serving them to\ncustomers. It then inspected about 2000 restaurants, although it did not\nfind any selling raw or half-cooked snails.\nYin Quanxi, an official with the office, was quoted by the Beijing Daily\nMessenger as saying thoroughly boiled snails were safe to eat.\nYin said the office would improve the inspection of aquatic products, such\nas snails, fish, shrimps and crabs, by establishing a system of traceable\npurchases and sales so that food sources could be quickly identified.\nThe Beijing Friendship Hospital, specializing in treating the disease,\nyesterday launched a training course on the treatment of Guangzhou\nangiostrongylus meningitis. The course will train about 200 doctors working\nin the city's 3rd-class and 2nd-class hospitals.\nThe friendship hospital found the 1st case of meningitis on 24 Jun 2006\nwhen a 34-year-old man suffered from violent headache and nausea after\neating a dish of cold snail meat at the Shuguo Yanyi Restaurant. The snail\nmeat was from the Amazonian snail ['fushouluo' in Chinese], which is a host\nof _Angiostrongylus cantonesis_, a parasite that harms people's nervous system.\nYin Chenghong, an expert from the hospital, said people do not have to\npanic, as the disease is curable and will not result in major problems if\ntreated in a timely and proper fashion. Yin said the disease has an average\nlatency period of 10 days, during which time people can suffer from\nheadache, fever, vomiting and a stiff neck.\nMeanwhile, there have been no reports of illness related to Amazonian\nsnails so far in Guangzhou, capital of South China's Guangdong Province,\nthe local disease control and prevention office said yesterday.\n'The city saw disease cases related to the snail in the 1980s, but has not\nheard of any cases for more than a decade,' said Mao Xinwu, director of the\nfood and health department of Guangzhou Centre for Disease Control and\nPrevention. However, the city's health authorities have decided to launch a\none-week inspection campaign of freshwater seafood to raise awareness about\nsnail diseases.\nGuangzhou was one of the 1st Chinese cities to introduce Amazonian snails\nin the 1980s, as a delicacy. 'Sales of Amazonian snails have been affected\nin recent days,' said Guo Qinghong, a vendor at the Guangzhou Huangsha\nSeafood Market. 'It is because people are now afraid of diseases. Once we\nprove eating salad snails could harm health, we will issue an emergency\nnotice to the public not to eat them,' said Huang Hui, an official with the\nGuangzhou Health Bureau.\nAccording to Huang, trade of Amazonian snails has not been suspended in the\ncity.\n[Byline: Guan Xiaofeng in Beijing and Qiu Quanlin in Guangzhou (China Daily)]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is a nematode that lives as a parasite in a\nvariety of freshwater or land snails and slugs. The giant African snail, or\n'fushouluo,' its common Chinese name, and the Amazonian snail are often\nconsumed by humans due to their rich protein content. These snails are\nagricultural pests. Their preparation prior to cooking is not an easy job.\nThe parasites are abundant in the fluid of the soft tissues. Good hygiene\npractice is strongly recommended for food preparers, and the snail meat\nmust be well-cooked in order to kill the parasites before serving. Fresh\nsalad can be contaminated by small types of infected snails or slugs.\nAn outbreak of _Angiostrongylus_ meningitis was diagnosed in 12 out of 23\nyoung travelers returning from Jamaica to the USA in 2002 (see ref 1\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=PubMed&list_uids=11870244&dopt=Abstract>).\nThe symptoms, such as neck pain, nuchal rigidity, altered cutaneous\nsensations, photophobia or visual disturbances, and severe headache began a\nmedian of 11 days (range, 6 to 31 days) after their return to the United\nStates. Antibodies against an _A. cantonensis_-specific 31-kD antigen were\ndetected in convalescent-phase serum samples from 11 patients.\nSimilar outbreaks were reported from Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, among Thai\nlaborers between 1998 and 1999 (see refs 2 and 4). The main cause of the\ndisease was eating raw snails.\nAs also discussed in the previous ProMED-mail report (see below), there\nhave been several outbreaks in China between 1984 and 2003.\nAs stated in a 2005 letter to the CDC\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol11no10/04-1338.htm>, 'Angiostrongyliasis\nis an emerging foodborne public health problem in mainland China. Most\nclinicians are not familiar with this disease and little is known about the\nprevalence of _A. cantonensis_ in China. Thus, more studies should be\nconducted on the biology, epidemiology, and clinical characteristics of\nangiostrongyliasis, and more effective diagnostic methods and treatments\nfor _A. cantonensis_ should be developed.'\nReferences:\n1. Slom TJ, Cortese MM, Gerber SI, Jones RC, Holtz TH, Lopez AS, Zambrano\nCH, Sufit RL, Sakolvaree Y, Chaicumpa W, Herwaldt BL, Johnson S. An\noutbreak of eosinophilic meningitis caused by _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_\nin travelers returning from the Caribbean. N Engl J Med. 2002 Feb\n28;346(9):668-75.\n2. Hung-Chin Tsai, Yung-Ching Liu, Calvin M Kunin, et al. Eosinophilic\nmeningitis caused by _A. cantonensis: report of 17 cases. The Am J Med 111:\n109-114.\n3. Wen-Yuan Du, Jiunn_Wang Liao, Chia-Kwung Fan, and Kua-Eyre Su. Combined\ntreatment with interleukin-12 and mebendazole lessens the severity of\nexperimental eosinophilic meningitis caused by _A. cantonensis_ in ICR\nmice. Infection and Immunity, 2003, 71: 3947-53.\n4. Hung-Chin Tsai, Yung-Ching Liu, Calvin M Kunin, et al. Eosinophilic\nmeningitis caused by _A. cantonensis_ associated with eating raw snails:\ncorrelation of brain magnetic resonance imaging scans with clinical\nfindings. Am J Trop med Hyg, 2003, 68(3): 281-5.\n- Mod.RY]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Guo Zixia, an official with the Beijing municipal office of health\ninspection, said it would impose administrative punishment on Shuguo Yanyi\nRestaurant for improperly cooking the Amazonian snails, which caused the\noutbreak. The city saw disease cases related to the snail in the 1980s, but has not\nheard of any cases for more than a decade,' said Mao Xinwu, director of the\nfood and health department of Guangzhou Centre for Disease Control and\nPrevention. Once we\nprove eating salad snails could harm health, we will issue an emergency\nnotice to the public not to eat them,' said Huang Hui, an official with the\nGuangzhou Health Bureau. Eosinophilic\nmeningitis caused by _A. cantonensis_ associated with eating raw snails:\ncorrelation of brain magnetic resonance imaging scans with clinical\nfindings. Source: Chinadaily.com.cn, 22 Aug 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2006-08/22/content_670398.htm>\n\nThe Beijing Bureau of Health said at a press conference yesterday that 70\npeople in Beijing have been diagnosed as suffering from Guangzhou\n Slom TJ, Cortese MM, Gerber SI, Jones RC, Holtz TH, Lopez AS, Zambrano\nCH, Sufit RL, Sakolvaree Y, Chaicumpa W, Herwaldt BL, Johnson S. An\noutbreak of eosinophilic meningitis caused by _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_\nin travelers returning from the Caribbean. The symptoms, such as neck pain, nuchal rigidity, altered cutaneous\nsensations, photophobia or visual disturbances, and severe headache began a\nmedian of 11 days (range, 6 to 31 days) after their return to the United\nStates. Combined\ntreatment with interleukin-12 and mebendazole lessens the severity of\nexperimental eosinophilic meningitis caused by _A. cantonensis_ in ICR\nmice. Thus, more studies should be\nconducted on the biology, epidemiology, and clinical characteristics of\nangiostrongyliasis, and more effective diagnostic methods and treatments\nfor _A. cantonensis_ should be developed.' [Byline: Guan Xiaofeng in Beijing and Qiu Quanlin in Guangzhou (China Daily)]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< But the bureau warned people\nnot to eat raw or half-cooked snails and gave a phone number, 65066969, for\nthe public to report anyone improperly cooked snails. Yin said the office would improve the inspection of aquatic products, such\nas snails, fish, shrimps and crabs, by establishing a system of traceable\npurchases and sales so that food sources could be quickly identified. Meanwhile, there have been no reports of illness related to Amazonian\nsnails so far in Guangzhou, capital of South China's Guangdong Province,\nthe local disease control and prevention office said yesterday. The friendship hospital found the 1st case of meningitis on 24 Jun 2006\nwhen a 34-year-old man suffered from violent headache and nausea after\neating a dish of cold snail meat at the Shuguo Yanyi Restaurant. Yin said the disease has an average\nlatency period of 10 days, during which time people can suffer from\nheadache, fever, vomiting and a stiff neck. Sales of Amazonian snails have been affected\nin recent days,' said Guo Qinghong, a vendor at the Guangzhou Huangsha\nSeafood Market. ' The snail\nmeat was from the Amazonian snail ['fushouluo' in Chinese], which is a host\nof _Angiostrongylus cantonesis_, a parasite that harms people's nervous system. Yin Chenghong, an expert from the hospital, said people do not have to\npanic, as the disease is curable and will not result in major problems if\ntreated in a timely and proper fashion. The office also\nrequired restaurants to boil snails thoroughly before serving them to\ncustomers. However, the city's health authorities have decided to launch a\none-week inspection campaign of freshwater seafood to raise awareness about\nsnail diseases. The Beijing Friendship Hospital, specializing in treating the disease,\nyesterday launched a training course on the treatment of Guangzhou\nangiostrongylus meningitis. Good hygiene\npractice is strongly recommended for food preparers, and the snail meat\nmust be well-cooked in order to kill the parasites before serving. An outbreak of _Angiostrongylus_ meningitis was diagnosed in 12 out of 23\nyoung travelers returning from Jamaica to the USA in 2002 (see ref 1\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=PubMed&list_uids=11870244&dopt=Abstract>). According to Huang, trade of Amazonian snails has not been suspended in the\ncity.\n The giant African snail, or\n'fushouluo,' its common Chinese name, and the Amazonian snail are often\nconsumed by humans due to their rich protein content. Most\nclinicians are not familiar with this disease and little is known about the\nprevalence of _A. cantonensis_ in China. As stated in a 2005 letter to the CDC\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol11no10/04-1338.htm>, 'Angiostrongyliasis\nis an emerging foodborne public health problem in mainland China. The Am J Med 111:\n109-114.\n \nReferences:\n1. The office on Sunday issued an urgent notice prohibiting the sale of raw or\nhalf-cooked freshwater snails in the city's restaurants. The bureau said the meningitis outbreak had caused no deaths so far and 3\npatients had left hospital after treatment. It then inspected about 2000 restaurants, although it did not\nfind any selling raw or half-cooked snails. [_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is a nematode that lives as a parasite in a\nvariety of freshwater or land snails and slugs.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2006-06-24 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00", "0281-05-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jamaica", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangzhou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Kaohsiung", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Holtz TH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2393", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - China: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2393", "date": "2006-08-21 00:00:00", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS, - CHINA: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2006\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Alertnet [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/PEK219378.htm>\n\nSnails cause meningitis in Beijing\n-----------------------------------\nEating raw or half-raw snails has led to almost 40 people in Beijing\ncoming down with meningitis, state media said on Monday [21 Aug\n2006], and the same species is being blamed for destroying a huge\nswath of rice crops. Around half of the victims had eaten a dish made\nwith the Amazonian snails at a chain of Sichuan restaurants, the\nChina Daily said. 'The large, black snails are a hot-selling aquatic\nproduct in big Chinese cities like Beijing,' Xinhua news agency said,\nadding that those falling sick had been infected by parasitic eel worms.\nBut the problem does not end there. 'Amazonian snails ... are now\nbeing blamed for killing crops on more than 160,000 hectares' (617 sq\nmiles) in the southwestern autonomous region of Guangxi Zhuang, Xinhua said.\n'Farmers near 7 cities in Guangxi have reported an invasion of\nAmazonian snails in their paddy fields. Agricultural experts said\nrainy weather, brought by this summer's typhoons, created ideal\nconditions for the snails.'\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Aug 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: China Daily [edited]\n<http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2006-08/21/content_669160.htm>\n\nEating snails leads to meningitis in Beijing\n----------------\nAt least 50 people have been diagnosed as suffering from a\nparasite-caused meningitis after eating raw or half-raw snails at\nBeijing restaurants.\nIt is the first time the so-called Guangzhou angiostrongylus\nmeningitis has been found in Beijing, according to the Beijing\nMunicipal Health Bureau's website.\nIt has warned people not to eat raw seafood, which may carry\nparasites that threaten health.\nThe 1st case, involving a 34-year-old man, was found by the Beijing\nFriendship Hospital in June [2006].\nThe patient suffered from unbearable headaches and nausea after\neating a dish called cold snail meat in [a local] restaurant.\nThe snail meat was from Amazonian snails Fushouluo in Chinese a\npopular dish in Sichuan-style restaurants in Beijing\nDoctors took samples from the restaurant and found the parasite in 2\nof the snails.\nBy last Thursday [17 Aug 2006], 23 people had been found to suffer\nfrom the meningitis in the capital's hospitals, said the bureau.\nThey had all eaten cold or spicy snail meat, from Amazonian snails,\nat branches of the same restaurant.\nAccording to the bureau, 5 of the 23 were in a serious condition, 3\nhad left hospital, and 2 were seemingly self-cured. No deaths have\nbeen reported.\nAs it can take as long as a month after eating for symptoms to\nappear, some diners may not link their headache with the snails, and\ndoctors may not be able to find the real reason for the illness.\nAfter local media reported the news, the Beijing Friendship Hospital\nreceived more than 90 people over the weekend, all worried they might\nget the disease since they had eaten snail dishes in the past 2 months.\nThe hospital claimed 17 of them were suffering from meningitis. The\nyoungest patient was 13 years old, the Beijing Evening News reported yesterday.\nCurrently the [involved] restaurant is not selling the dish while\ndiners elsewhere are refusing to eat Amazonian snails.\nAccording to the bureau, other seafood may also contain parasites but\nthe Amazonian snail can host more than others.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It is not clear what 'parasitic eel worms' refers to.\n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is known to cause eosinophilic\nmeningitis. The posting contains no details at all on how the\ndiagnosis was supported and why a parasitic cause of the meningitis\nwas suspected. Food borne infections are important, and ProMED will\nbe happy to publish any further details. - Mod.EP]\n[A literature search on _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ in China\nrevealed it was 1st identified in 1984. Most of the references\navailable are in the Chinese literature. Ref 1 gives a nice overview\nof the problem with the conclusion that there is much more to be\nlearned about the epidemiology of the problem, but it does appear to\nbe an emerging disease on the Chinese mainland and is probably\ngrossly underreported/identified as a problem. In an outbreak in\nWenzhou (ref 3), the vehicle of transmission was ingestion of\nundercooked _Ampullaria gigas_ ('apple snails') in a restaurant in\nthe city. In the above outbreak, the type of snail mentioned is\n'Amazonian snails' and the Chinese name for the snail dish is given\n'Fushouluo'. More information on this outbreak would be very much appreciated.\n1: Chen XG, Li H, Lun ZR. Angiostrongyliasis, Mainland\nChina.[letter] Emerg Infect Dis. 2005 Oct;11(10):1645-7. Available\nat: <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/vol11no10/04-1338.htm>\n2: Lin JX, Li YS, Zhu K, Chen BJ, Cheng YZ, Lin JC, Cao Y, Chen\nRZ. [Epidemiological study on group infection of Angiostrongylus\ncantonensis in Changle City] Zhongguo Ji Sheng Chong Xue Yu Ji Sheng\nChong Bing Za Zhi. 2003;21(2):110-2.\n3: Xue DY, Ruan YZ, Lin BC, Zheng RY, Fang JQ, Zhao QX, Li MF, Pan\nCW. [Epidemiological investigation on an outbreak of\nangiostrongyliasis cantonensis in Wenzhou] Zhongguo Ji Sheng Chong\nXue Yu Ji Sheng Chong Bing Za Zhi. 2000;18(3):176-8.\n4: Liang HK. [Epidemiology of Angiostrongylus cantonensis in\nGuangzhou] Zhonghua Liu Xing Bing Xue Za Zhi. 1986 Feb;7(1):61-3.\n5: Ting B, Ho JZ, Chu TC, Luo YS. [A survey of Angiostrongylus\ncantonensis in Guangzhou] Ji Sheng Chong Xue Yu Ji Sheng Chong Bing\nZa Zhi. 1984;2(1):25-7.\n-Mod.MPP]\n..............ep/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Source: China Daily [edited]\n<http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2006-08/21/content_669160.htm>\n\nEating snails leads to meningitis in Beijing\n Source: Reuters Alertnet [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/PEK219378.htm>\n\nSnails cause meningitis in Beijing\n Agricultural experts said\nrainy weather, brought by this summer's typhoons, created ideal\nconditions for the snails.' It is the first time the so-called Guangzhou angiostrongylus\nmeningitis has been found in Beijing, according to the Beijing\nMunicipal Health Bureau's website. The posting contains no details at all on how the\ndiagnosis was supported and why a parasitic cause of the meningitis\nwas suspected. \n_Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ is known to cause eosinophilic\nmeningitis. According to the bureau, other seafood may also contain parasites but\nthe Amazonian snail can host more than others.\n ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS, - CHINA: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\n [Epidemiological investigation on an outbreak of\nangiostrongyliasis cantonensis in Wenzhou] Zhongguo Ji Sheng Chong\n [Epidemiological study on group infection of Angiostrongylus\ncantonensis in Changle City] Zhongguo Ji Sheng Chong Xue Yu Ji Sheng\n \nProMED-mail\n< [A survey of Angiostrongylus\ncantonensis in Guangzhou] Ji Sheng Chong Xue Yu Ji Sheng Chong Bing\n Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n By last Thursday [17 Aug 2006], 23 people had been found to suffer\nfrom the meningitis in the capital's hospitals, said the bureau. The patient suffered from unbearable headaches and nausea after\neating a dish called cold snail meat in [a local] restaurant.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1986-03-26 00:00:00", "1984-03-26 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-06-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Guangzhou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sichuan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangxi Zhuang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangxi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wenzhou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Changle City ] Zhongguo Ji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208795", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Serous meningitis, Russia (Sverdlovsk)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208795", "date": "2005-10-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "SEROUS MENINGITIS, RUSSIA (SVERDLOVSK)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\nThe Journal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\nDate: Thu 13 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail Russian\nCorrespondents<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Interfax.ru News Agency, Wed 12 Oct 2005\n[translated; edited]\n<http://www.interfax.ru/r/B/ural/289.html?menu=3&id_issue=11405404>\n\nAccording to the Sverdlovsk Regional Office of the Russian\n(Health) Protection Agency (Rospotrebnadzor], the number of\npeople in the Sverdlovsk region suffering from serous\n[viral?] meningitis at the present time has reached 48.\nResidents of Sverdlovsk have been admitted to hospital\nsuffering from viral meningitis over a period of 6 weeks.\nThe cause of the outbreak is [consumption of] unboiled\nwater.\nEpidemiologists have carried out an analysis of materials\nfrom Sverdlovsk and have discovered that those who have\nfallen ill have used unboiled water obtained from water\npipes from an [artesian] well. The cause of the outbreak has\nnot been made public yet.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Sverdlovsk region is located between the Central and\nNorthern Urals adjoining the Siberian plain. The total area\nis 194 000 square kilometers, and the population is 4.4\nmillion. Sverdlovsk is a city of 34 700 thousand\ninhabitants. - ProMED-mail Russian correspondents.\nSerous (or aseptic) meningitis is a term commonly used to\ndescribe non-bacterial (viral) meningitis. Serous meningitis\nis usually indicative of enteroviral infection, and the term\nviral meningitis is now the norm. However, in the absence of\nconfirmation of viral infection, the direct Russian\ntranslation is retained. Further information is awaited. -\nMod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Epidemiologists have carried out an analysis of materials\nfrom Sverdlovsk and have discovered that those who have\nfallen ill have used unboiled water obtained from water\npipes from an [artesian] well. According to the Sverdlovsk Regional Office of the Russian\n(Health) Protection Agency (Rospotrebnadzor], the number of\npeople in the Sverdlovsk region suffering from serous\n Serous meningitis\nis usually indicative of enteroviral infection, and the term\nviral meningitis is now the norm. However, in the absence of\nconfirmation of viral infection, the direct Russian\ntranslation is retained. The total area\nis 194 000 square kilometers, and the population is 4.4\nmillion. SEROUS MENINGITIS, RUSSIA (SVERDLOVSK)\n**************************************\n Source: Interfax.ru News Agency, Wed 12 Oct 2005\n[translated; edited]\n<http://www.interfax.ru/r/B/ural/289.html?menu=3&id_issue=11405404>\n\n --\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Sverdlovsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "RUSSIA", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208806", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Serous meningitis - Russia (Sverdlovsk) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208806", "date": "2005-10-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "SEROUS MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (SVERDLOVSK) (02)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail Russian Correspondents\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: API-Novosti, Fri 14 Oct 2005 [translated from\nRussian, edited]\n<http://www.apiural.ru/soc/?art=3D14190>\n\nRussia: meningitis outbreak in Severouralsk now attributed\nto echovirus 6\n-----------------------------------------------\nEpidemiologists of the Severouralsk Office of the Russian\n(Health) Protection Agency (Rospotrebnadzor) have identified\nthe pathogen responsible for the outbreak of serous\nmeningitis in the town of Severouralsk (Sverdlovsk region).\nContrary to earlier statements of health officials, it could\nnot be confirmed that the outbreak was a consequence of a\ndefective water supply. Testing of potable water supplies\ndid not detect any pathogen that might have been responsible\nfor the outbreak of serous meningitis. Analysis of patients'\nsamples, on the other hand, revealed the presence of an\nenterovirus -- human echovirus type 6 -- as the likely cause\nof the outbreak, an agent that could propagated by\ndroplet-transmission.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This outbreak has been confirmed now as viral meningitis by\ndetection of human echovirus type 6 in patients' samples. It\nis still possible, however, that the source of the outbreak\nwas contaminated water as originally suspected, with\nsubsequent propagation of the infection by droplet\ntransmission. Human echovirus type 6 is now classified as a\nmember of the _Human enterovirus B_ virus species, together\nwith the B group of human coxsackieviruses and another 33\nechovirus types. Echoviruses types 6, 9, 11, 19, and 30 have\nbeen associated with outbreaks of viral meningitis in the\npast. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Analysis of patients'\nsamples, on the other hand, revealed the presence of an\nenterovirus -- human echovirus type 6 -- as the likely cause\nof the outbreak, an agent that could propagated by\ndroplet-transmission. SEROUS MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (SVERDLOVSK) (02)\n From: ProMED-mail Russian Correspondents\n< Date: Sun 16 Oct 2005\n promed@promedmail.org>\n **\n \n \n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2011-06-09 19:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Severouralsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sverdlovsk", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208652", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - France (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208652", "date": "2005-09-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - FRANCE (02)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Clinical Virology\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/jocv>\nDate: Sat 10 Sep 2005\nFrom: Fabrice Simon <simon-f@wanadoo.fr>\n\nViral meningitis in adults in Marseille and south eastern France:\ninvolvement of enteroviruses and Toscana virus\n-----------------------------------------------\nI would like to add some information relating to the occurrence of viral\nmeningitis that has been observed in adults in the South of France,\nespecially in Marseille. As in numerous towns of France, most of the cases\nwe had to treat could be attributed to enterovirus infection (on the basis\nof positive PCR tests for enterovirus in cerebrospinal fluid).\nBut I would like to add that we also identified a few cases of severe\nlymphocytic meningitis during August 2005 that were due to autochthonous\nToscana virus infection (on the basis of seroconversion). All patients\nreported having stayed in the Marseille region, especially in the\nsurrounding towns below the hills.\nTo date, there are no published entomological data to explain the emergence\nof this arboviral infection in this area. This diagnosis should be\nconsidered particularly in the case of patients with lymphocytic meningitis\nor encephalitis when they have stayed or traveled in this part of\nsoutheastern France in summer, when headache is very painful and resistant\nto painkillers, or when the total number of lymphocytes is high (>100) in\ncerebrospinal fluid.\n--\nFabrice Simon, MD\nService des maladies infectieuses et tropicales\nHospital d'instruction des armes Laveran\nBP 50\n13998 Marseille armes - France\n[Toscana virus is a phlebovirus -- that is, it belongs to the genus\n_Phlebovvirus_ of the family _Bunyaviridae_ -- and is classified as a\nmember of the _Sandfly fever Naples virus_ species. These are viruses that\nare transmitted by sandflies (_Phlebotomus pernicious_). Toscana virus was\nisolated initially from sandflies in the Tuscany region of Italy and was\nsubsequently shown to be associated with cases of aseptic meningitis\noccurring during summer. Serological surveys have indicated that Toscana\nvirus infection is prevalent in other parts of southern Europe, although\nits clinical importance is unknown. Dr Simon's observations are\nparticularly relevant in this respect. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "This diagnosis should be\nconsidered particularly in the case of patients with lymphocytic meningitis\nor encephalitis when they have stayed or traveled in this part of\nsoutheastern France in summer, when headache is very painful and resistant\nto painkillers, or when the total number of lymphocytes is high (>100) in\ncerebrospinal fluid.\n \nFabrice Simon, MD\nService des maladies infectieuses et tropicales\nHospital d'instruction des armes Laveran\nBP 50\n13998 A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Toscana virus was\nisolated initially from sandflies in the Tuscany region of Italy and was\nsubsequently shown to be associated with cases of aseptic meningitis\noccurring during summer. As in numerous towns of France, most of the cases\nwe had to treat could be attributed to enterovirus infection (on the basis\nof positive PCR tests for enterovirus in cerebrospinal fluid). Serological surveys have indicated that Toscana\nvirus infection is prevalent in other parts of southern Europe, although\nits clinical importance is unknown. All patients\nreported having stayed in the Marseille region, especially in the\nsurrounding towns below the hills. Marseille armes - France\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-08-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Marseille", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Sandfly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Naples", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208642", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - France", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208642", "date": "2005-09-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - FRANCE\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nThe Clinical Journal of Virology\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/jocv>\nDate: Fri 9 Sep 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <prommed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly 2005 ; 10(9), Thu 8 Sep [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/index-02.asp>\n\nSince the end of May 2005, an increase in the number of viral meningitis\ncases has been observed, unevenly distributed throughout mainland France,\nwith the following regions affected the most: Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur\n(south east France), Ile de France (Paris and surrounding area),\nRhone-Alpes (south east France), Midi-Pyrenees (south west France), et\nHaute-Normandie (north west France) (1).\nInformation has been collected from virology laboratories participating in\nthe enterovirus surveillance network and, although biased, they do not\nindicate an epidemic on the scale of the 2000 outbreak [illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text]. However, the increase in case numbers is\ngreater than that seen in 2001-2004.\nNumbers peaked in week 27, and a decrease has been seen since then. [The\nenteroviruses] identified were mainly echovirus 30, coxsackievirus group B\ntype 5, and to a lesser extent, echoviruses 13 and 6. At the beginning of\nMay (week 18), 11 per cent of samples tested by ligase chain reaction (LCR)\nwere positive for enterovirus, and this reached 60 per cent in week 29\n(18-24 July).\nThe activity registered by the virology laboratories reflects only a small\npart of the admissions to hospital emergency departments for viral\nmeningitis, as not all patients are sampled for enterovirus testing. In\nIle-de-France, admissions are monitored in 23 emergency departments. Weekly\nadmissions from 1 May to 24 Jul 2005 (weekly 18 to 29) for viral\nmeningitis: cases increased until week 26, then decreased [illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text].\nA paper on the past 5 years of enterovirus surveillance in France will be\npublished in the Bulletin Epidemiologique Hebdomadaire in October 2005, and\na detailed report of the year 2005 is planned for publication in 2006\n(<http://www.invs.sante.fr/beh/default.htm>).\nIncreases in incidence of echoviruses 13 and 30 in Europe were last\nmentioned in Eurosurveillance in 2002 [2].\nReferences\n----------\n1. Institut de veille sanitaire. Epidemie de meningites virales en France.\nLe point au 1er aout 2005. 1 Aug 2005.\n<http://www.invs.sante.fr/presse/2005/le_point_sur/meningites_010805/index.html>\n2. Noah N, Reid F. Recent increases in incidence of echoviruses 13 and 30\naround Europe. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2002; 6(7): 14/02/2002.\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2002/020214.asp#4>\n[byline: Denise Antona1 (<d.antona@invs.sante.fr>) and Jean-Jacques\nChomel2, with the Enterovirus Surveillance Laboratory Network\n1 Institut de veille sanitaire, Saint-Maurice, France,\n2 Centre national de reference des Enterovirus, Lyon, France]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Viral meningitis in childhood can be associated with infection by certain\nenteroviruses or with mumps virus, whereas in adulthood other viruses such\nas herpes simplex type 2 may be involved. Headache, neck rigidity, fever\nand occasionally vomiting are indicative of viral meningitis. Illness\nusually resolves quickly without serious consequence. Viral meningitis is\nsometimes described as aseptic or lymphocytic meningitis due to the\npredominance of lymphocytes in the cerebrospinal fluid. The members of the\ngenus _Enterovirus_ (family _Picornaviridae_) associated with meningitis\ninclude various echoviruses, the polioviruses, and A and B type\ncoxsackieviruses. The predominance of echovirus 30 and coxsackievirus B 5\nin France in the current season may reflect the relative prevalence of\nthese enteroviruses in Northern Europe at the present time. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Eurosurveillance Weekly 2005 ; 10(9), Thu 8 Sep [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/index-02.asp>\n\nSince the end of May 2005, an increase in the number of viral meningitis\ncases has been observed, unevenly distributed throughout mainland France,\nwith the following regions affected the most: Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur\n 1 Institut de veille sanitaire, Saint-Maurice, France,\n2 Centre national de reference des Enterovirus, Lyon, France]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Weekly\nadmissions from 1 May to 24 Jul 2005 (weekly 18 to 29) for viral\nmeningitis: cases increased until week 26, then decreased [illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text]. At the beginning of\nMay (week 18), 11 per cent of samples tested by ligase chain reaction (LCR)\nwere positive for enterovirus, and this reached 60 per cent in week 29\n(18-24 July). A paper on the past 5 years of enterovirus surveillance in France will be\npublished in the Bulletin Epidemiologique Hebdomadaire in October 2005, and\na detailed report of the year 2005 is planned for publication in 2006\n(<http://www.invs.sante.fr/beh/default.htm>). Information has been collected from virology laboratories participating in\nthe enterovirus surveillance network and, although biased, they do not\nindicate an epidemic on the scale of the 2000 outbreak [illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text]. The members of the\ngenus _Enterovirus_ (family _Picornaviridae_) associated with meningitis\ninclude various echoviruses, the polioviruses, and A and B type\ncoxsackieviruses. The activity registered by the virology laboratories reflects only a small\npart of the admissions to hospital emergency departments for viral\nmeningitis, as not all patients are sampled for enterovirus testing. [Viral meningitis in childhood can be associated with infection by certain\nenteroviruses or with mumps virus, whereas in adulthood other viruses such\nas herpes simplex type 2 may be involved. [The\nenteroviruses] identified were mainly echovirus 30, coxsackievirus group B\ntype 5, and to a lesser extent, echoviruses 13 and 6. Viral meningitis is\nsometimes described as aseptic or lymphocytic meningitis due to the\npredominance of lymphocytes in the cerebrospinal fluid. The predominance of echovirus 30 and coxsackievirus B 5\nin France in the current season may reflect the relative prevalence of\nthese enteroviruses in Northern Europe at the present time. References\n----------\n1. \n<http://www.invs.sante.fr/presse/2005/le_point_sur/meningites_010805/index.html>\n2.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-08-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2005-07-24 00:00:00", "2018-07-24 00:00:00", "2021-05-26 00:00:00", "2002-02-14 00:00:00", "2021-05-01 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2005-10-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "France"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208335", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - USA (UT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208335", "date": "2005-07-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA (UTAH)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nHealth Information for International Travel 2005-2006\n<http://tinyurl.com/c228c>\nDate: Sat 23 Jul 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Salt Lake Tribune online, Fri 22 Jul 2005[edited]\n<http://www.sltrib.com/utah/ci_2881434>\n\nUSA: viral meningitis shows up at double the normal rate in Utah\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Salt Lake Valley Health Department has confirmed 13 cases of viral\nmeningitis between 1 and 19 Jul 2005. On average, the Health Department,\nwhich serves all of Salt Lake County, confirms an average of 5 cases during\nthe same time period. Viral meningitis is not as serious as bacterial\nmeningitis, which killed an East High School student earlier in 2005.\nMeningitis is an inflammation of the lining of the brain that can be caused\nby many organisms, including different types of viruses. Midsummer is the\npeak season for viral meningitis, said Pam Davenport, spokeswoman for the\nHealth Department.\n[Viral meningitis caused by enteroviruses] is believed to be transmitted\nthrough human contact with water, such as rivers, lakes, and wading pools.\n'It is often transmitted through fecal-oral [contact] when you get little\nkids in diapers in some of these water recreational places.'\nThe viruses that cause viral meningitis are 'very common during the summer\nand early fall, and many people are exposed to them,' said Dagmar Vitek,\nmedical officer for the Health Department. 'However, most infected persons\neither have no symptoms or develop only a cold or rash with low-grade\nfever. Only a small portion of infected persons actually develop meningitis.'\nViral meningitis is a common -- but rarely serious -- disease. The illness\nlasts from 7 to 10 days. Symptoms often include headache, fever,\nsensitivity to light, stiff or sore neck, and nausea and vomiting.\nEnteroviruses, the commonest cause of viral meningitis, are often spread\nthrough direct contact with respiratory secretions, such as saliva or\nmucus, from an infected person, according to Ilene Risk, an epidemiologist\nwith the Health Department. The virus can also be found in the stool of\ninfected people. In the summer, the high number of young children in\nfountains or wading pools is believed to increase the spread of viral\nmeningitis, Risk said. It is not as common in chlorinated swimming pools.\n[byline: Carey Hamilton]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The etiologic agents are predominantly enteroviruses, and less frequently\nmumps virus (transmitted by droplets and fomites), herpes simplex virus,\nand adenovirus.\nCases of enteroviral infection are commonest in summer months and in the\nfirst 10 years of life. Transmission of infection is predominantly by the\nfecal-oral route, or by ingestion of contaminated water, as is in the\noutbreak described above. Viral meningitis is likely in any situation where\nthere is gross contamination of environmental water and domestic water\nsupplies. There is no vaccine or specific treatment for viral meningitis in\nview of the heterogeneity of the causative agent. However, the prognosis\nfor enteroviral meningitis in particular and viral meningitis in general is\ngood and recovery is usually complete. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Enteroviruses, the commonest cause of viral meningitis, are often spread\nthrough direct contact with respiratory secretions, such as saliva or\nmucus, from an infected person, according to Ilene Risk, an epidemiologist\nwith the Health Department. [byline: Carey Hamilton]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nHealth Information for International Travel 2005-2006\n<http://tinyurl.com/c228c>\n However, the prognosis\nfor enteroviral meningitis in particular and viral meningitis in general is\ngood and recovery is usually complete. - Mod. In the summer, the high number of young children in\nfountains or wading pools is believed to increase the spread of viral\nmeningitis, Risk said. The viruses that cause viral meningitis are 'very common during the summer\nand early fall, and many people are exposed to them,' said Dagmar Vitek,\nmedical officer for the Health Department. ' Viral meningitis is likely in any situation where\nthere is gross contamination of environmental water and domestic water\nsupplies. \nThe Salt Lake Valley Health Department has confirmed 13 cases of viral\nmeningitis between 1 and 19 Jul 2005. VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA (UTAH)\n*****************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Salt Lake County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208303", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208303", "date": "2005-07-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (KHABAROVSK)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nHealth Information for International Travel 2005-2006\n<http://tinyurl.com/c228c>\nDate: Tue 19 Jul 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail Russian Correspondent Vadim Melnik <vamelnik@ua.fm>\nSource: Regions.ru News Agency, Mon 18 Jul 2005 [trans. Mod.NR; edited]\n<http://www.regions.ru/sepnewsarticle/news/id/1855044.html>\n\nRussia: aseptic (viral) meningitis outbreak in Komsomolsk-na-Amure\n------------------------------------------------------------------\n3 cases of aseptic (viral) meningitis have been notified in the city of\nKomsomolsk-na-Amure (Khabarovsk District). All 3 cases were children, aged\nfrom 2 to 9 years old, and were admitted to the city's Children's Hospital.\nIt was established that 2 of the infected children had swum in the Amur\nriver and that -- according to physicians -- is where they contracted the\nviral meningitis infection. Water samples were taken in the area of the\ncity beach. The results of microbiological tests revealed that water\nquality was far from satisfactory. Accordingly, epidemiologists have warned\nboth city inhabitants and visitors not to bathe in the river and to avoid\nswallowing water if they disregard this advice.\nPhysicians are also recommending that the population wash fruit and\nvegetables thoroughly and to drink only bottled or boiled water.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The city of Komsomolsk-na-Amure (Komsomolsk on the Amur) was estimated to\nhave a population of 315 000 in 1989. It is located on the Amur river in\nthe territory of Khabarovsk in the southern part of the Russian Far East.\nIt is a manufacturing centre producing steel, machinery, refined oil, and\nwood products. Tin mines are nearby. The city was founded (1932) by\nKomsomol (the Communist youth organization). - Mod.NR\nViral meningitis is sometimes referred to as aseptic, lymphocytic, or\nserous meningitis because of the predominance of lymphocytes in the\ncerebrospinal fluid. 1/2 to 3/4 of cases of meningitis are caused by\nviruses. The etiologic agents are predominantly enteroviruses, and less\nfrequently mumps virus (transmitted by droplets and fomites), herpes\nsimplex virus, and adenovirus.\nCases of enteroviral infection are commonest in summer months and in the\n1st 10 years of life. Transmission of infection is predominantly by the\nfecal-oral route, or by ingestion of contaminated water, as in the outbreak\ndescribed above. Viral meningitis is likely to occur in any situation where\nthere is gross contamination of environmental water and domestic water\nsupplies. The prognosis for viral meningitis is good and recovery is\nusually complete.\nFurther information on the outcome of this outbreak and confirmation of the\npresumptive diagnosis would be welcomed. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n NR\nViral meningitis is sometimes referred to as aseptic, lymphocytic, or\nserous meningitis because of the predominance of lymphocytes in the\ncerebrospinal fluid. Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nHealth Information for International Travel 2005-2006\n<http://tinyurl.com/c228c>\n It was established that 2 of the infected children had swum in the Amur\nriver and that -- according to physicians -- is where they contracted the\nviral meningitis infection. Viral meningitis is likely to occur in any situation where\nthere is gross contamination of environmental water and domestic water\nsupplies. \n3 cases of aseptic (viral) meningitis have been notified in the city of\nKomsomolsk-na-Amure (Khabarovsk District). NR; edited]\n<http://www.regions.ru/sepnewsarticle/news/id/1855044.html>\n\nRussia: aseptic (viral) meningitis outbreak in Komsomolsk-na-Amure\n------------------------------------------------------------------ Accordingly, epidemiologists have warned\nboth city inhabitants and visitors not to bathe in the river and to avoid\nswallowing water if they disregard this advice. Transmission of infection is predominantly by the\nfecal-oral route, or by ingestion of contaminated water, as in the outbreak\ndescribed above. Physicians are also recommending that the population wash fruit and\nvegetables thoroughly and to drink only bottled or boiled water.\n The etiologic agents are predominantly enteroviruses, and less\nfrequently mumps virus (transmitted by droplets and fomites), herpes\nsimplex virus, and adenovirus. VIRAL MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (KHABAROVSK)\n**************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1932-03-26 00:00:00", "1989-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Khabarovsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Komsomolsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206729", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Aseptic meningitis, school children - Russia (Ekaterinburg)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206729", "date": "2004-10-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "ASEPTIC MENINGITIS, SCHOOL CHILDREN - RUSSIA (EKATERINBURG)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 14 Oct 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Infectious and Parasitic Diseases News, Thu 14 Oct 2004\n[translated by Mod.NR, edited]\n<http://www.infectology.ru/news/news/calendar.asp?date=10/14/04>\n\nRussia: an outbreak of viral meningitis in Ekaterinburg\n-----------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of serous [now termed aseptic or viral] meningitis has\noccurred in a school in Ekaterinburg. According to the sanitary\nepidemiological surveillance center, there were 14 cases of serous\nmeningitis among schoolchildren attending school N 142, which is\nlocated in the village of Gorniy Chit near the city of Ekaterinburg.\nAccording to local physicians, the outbreak was suspected to be a\nconsequence of contamination of the [drinking] water supply, and this\nhas been confirmed now by laboratory testing of samples from the\nwater supply system. Sewage contamination of the water supply could\nhave exposed children to enteric virus infection. Those responsible\nfor maintenance of the water supply to the village of Gorniy Chit\nhave been dismissed, and the water system is now under the control of\nthe central authority. School N 142 is temporarily closed, and the\ninhabitants of the village have been asked not to drink tap water\nfrom the tap and to use bottled water instead.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report was received from Vadim Melnik, a ProMED-mail\ncorrespondent in Russia. Ekaterinburg (formerly known as Sverdlovsk)\nis located on the Asian side of the Ural Mountain range on the river\nIset. It is a major manufacturing center, and, with a population of\n1.3 million (2002), is Russia's 5th largest city. - Mod.NR]\n[Serous meningitis (otherwise known as aseptic, lymphocytic, or viral\nmeningitis) can be caused by many different enteric viruses, mumps\nvirus, herpes simplex virus (in adults), and, occasionally,\nadenovirus. In the majority of cases, especially where infection is\nwater-borne and associated with fecal contamination, viral meningitis\nis a consequence of infection by an enterovirus (usually one of the\nmany human echoviruses, human coxsackieviruses, or even poliovirus).\nInfection contracted in childhood usually resolves quickly with no\nsequelae. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n According to the sanitary\nepidemiological surveillance center, there were 14 cases of serous\nmeningitis among schoolchildren attending school N 142, which is\nlocated in the village of Gorniy Chit near the city of Ekaterinburg.\n In the majority of cases, especially where infection is\nwater-borne and associated with fecal contamination, viral meningitis\nis a consequence of infection by an enterovirus (usually one of the\nmany human echoviruses, human coxsackieviruses, or even poliovirus). According to local physicians, the outbreak was suspected to be a\nconsequence of contamination of the [drinking] water supply, and this\nhas been confirmed now by laboratory testing of samples from the\nwater supply system. [Serous meningitis (otherwise known as aseptic, lymphocytic, or viral\nmeningitis) can be caused by many different enteric viruses, mumps\nvirus, herpes simplex virus (in adults), and, occasionally,\nadenovirus. School N 142 is temporarily closed, and the\ninhabitants of the village have been asked not to drink tap water\nfrom the tap and to use bottled water instead.\n Those responsible\nfor maintenance of the water supply to the village of Gorniy Chit\nhave been dismissed, and the water system is now under the control of\nthe central authority. Natalia Pshenichnaya <crane@aaanet.ru>\nSource: Newsinfo.ru News Agency, Sat 23 Jul 2005 [trans. NP; edited]\n<http://www.newsinfo.ru/static/1224905.html>\n\nRussia: viral meningitis outbreak in Khabarovsk Region - update\n---------------------------------------------------------------\n17 children in the age range 7 to 12 years have been admitted to hospital\nwith viral meningitis [also known as serous or aseptic meningitis] in the\nKhabarovsk region. The first sick child was admitted to hospital about 2\nweeks ago [approx. 9 Jul 2005]. At present 9 cases of viral meningitis have\nbeen notified in Khabarovsk; 3 in Komsomolsk-na-Amure, 2 in Nanaian\ndistrict, and one each in the Khabarovskiy, Bikinskiy, and Nikolaevskiy\ndistricts.\nThe cause of the outbreak is thought to be bathing in local reservoirs, in\nparticular in the Amur River. According to local medical staff, none of the\nillnesses is life-threatening.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the previous ProMED-mail post the number of affected children on 19 Jul\n2005 was 3, all belonging to the city of Komsomolsk-na-Amure in the\nKhabarovsk region.\nThe Khabarovsk region is located in the far eastern part of Russia, bounded\nin the east by the Sea of Okhotsk and the Sea of Japan. In the south the\nKhabarovsk region borders the Heilongjiang province of China. In the south\nwest and the west it borders the Amur region, in the northwest and north\nwith the Republic of Sakha, and in north east with the Magadan region. The\nmountain ranges of Sykgote-Alin, Jzhugzhur, and Suntar-Khayat occupy the\ngreater part of the territory. The population is 1 436 000 (2003), and the\ncapital is Khabarovsk, with 583 000 inhabitants (2003). - Corresp.NP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \n17 children in the age range 7 to 12 years have been admitted to hospital\nwith viral meningitis [also known as serous or aseptic meningitis] in the\nKhabarovsk region. Date: Sat 23 Jul 2005\n Natalia Pshenichnaya <crane@aaanet.ru>\n promed@promedmail.org>\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Heilongjiang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khabarovsk Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jzhugzhur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khabarovsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Komsomolsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Sakha", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204912", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal, type A - Russia (02): (Moscow)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204912", "date": "2003-11-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL, TYPE A - RUSSIA (MOSCOW)\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sat, 15 Nov 2003 23:51:42 -0800 (PST)\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Regions.Ru (translated by Mod. NR) [edited]\n<http://www.regions.ru/newsheadlines/index.html?section=news&topic=health>\n\n10 children have died in Moscow from meningitis so far in 2003. Altogether,\n259 cases of meningitis were registered in Moscow, 129 of which are among\nchildren, according to the Chief Pediatrician of Moscow, Mr.Rumyanzev.\nAccording to him, the Sanitary Epidemiological Surveillance staff together\nwith physicians conducted investigations of the focus of\ninfection. Someone in each area was identified as a carrier of infection.\nDisease was registered in all suburbs of Moscow.\nVaccination is organized in Moscow, with obligatory vaccination of children\nunder 3 months to 9 years. Rumyanzev thinks that these measures will\nprevent an epidemic. According to formal signs, no epidemic has yet been\ndeclared in Moscow. The epidemic can be announced only when disease is\nregistered in more that 20 persons per 100 000 population. Currently the\nfigure is 3-3.5 per 100 000.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 14 Nov 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly Volume 7 Issue 46 13 Nov 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/031113.asp>\n\nMeningococcal meningitis increases in Moscow, associated with serogroup A:\nadvice to travelers\n------------------------------------\nThere has been a rise in the number of cases of meningococcal meningitis in\nMoscow. By the end of October 2003, there had been 268 cases (including 22\ndeaths) mostly in children, approximately twice the average number of cases\nreported (1). Unusually, many of the cases have been reported at the end\nof the summer and in early autumn; the usual seasonal increase occurs in\nFebruary and March. Meningococcal serogroup A has been identified in 90\npercent of the strains isolated. The city health authorities in Moscow have\ninitiated a mass vaccination campaign in order to prevent further cases\noccurring during the coming peak transmission season.\nCases of meningococcal serogroup A infection are rare in the European\nUnion, and it is uncommon even to have infections associated with travel to\nthose endemic areas where serogroup A is most frequent, such as the\nmeningitis belt in Africa, and therefore it is not anticipated that many\ncases will be imported from Russia into the EU.\nThe National Travel Health Network and Centre in England (NaTHNaC,\n<http://www.nathnac.org>) has issued guidance for English health\nprofessionals who may be advising travelers to Moscow (2), recommending\nthat meningococcal vaccine should be considered only for travelers to\nMoscow who will be teaching in schools, attending university or other\ncourses, frequenting crowded bars and clubs, or working in a medical setting.\nThe European Union Invasive Bacterial Infections Surveillance Network\n(EU-IBIS, <http://www.euibis.org/>) would be interested to know what\nguidance is being issued in other European countries; please email\ninformation to Sarah Handford (<sarah.handford@hpa.org.uk>).\n1. Meningitis, meningococcal type A - Russia (Moscow).in: ProMED-mail\n[online]. Boston US: International Society for Infectious Diseases, archive\nno. 20031029.2696, 29 Oct 2003.\n2. National Travel Health Network and Centre (NaTHNaC). Meningococcal\nmeningitis in Moscow. Clinical updates for health professionals. November 2003.\n(<http://www.nathnac.org/healthprofessionals/clinical/meningitis_moscow.html>)\n[accessed 11 Nov 2003]\n[Reported by: Jo Lawrence, Health Protection Agency Communicable Disease\nSurveillance Centre, and Sarah Handford, Scientific coordinator, European\nUnion Invasive Bacterial Infections Surveillance (EU-IBIS), Health\nProtection Agency Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre London, England]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "[Reported by: Jo Lawrence, Health Protection Agency Communicable Disease\nSurveillance Centre, and Sarah Handford, Scientific coordinator, European\nUnion Invasive Bacterial Infections Surveillance (EU-IBIS), Health\nProtection Agency Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre London, England]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org> Cases of meningococcal serogroup A infection are rare in the European\nUnion, and it is uncommon even to have infections associated with travel to\nthose endemic areas where serogroup A is most frequent, such as the\nmeningitis belt in Africa, and therefore it is not anticipated that many\ncases will be imported from Russia into the EU.\n The National Travel Health Network and Centre in England (NaTHNaC,\n<http://www.nathnac.org>) has issued guidance for English health\nprofessionals who may be advising travelers to Moscow (2), recommending\nthat meningococcal vaccine should be considered only for travelers to\nMoscow who will be teaching in schools, attending university or other\ncourses, frequenting crowded bars and clubs, or working in a medical setting. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Eurosurveillance Weekly Volume 7 Issue 46 13 Nov 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/031113.asp>\n\nMeningococcal meningitis increases in Moscow, associated with serogroup A:\nadvice to travelers\n The European Union Invasive Bacterial Infections Surveillance Network\n(EU-IBIS, <http://www.euibis.org/>) would be interested to know what\nguidance is being issued in other European countries; please email\ninformation to Sarah Handford (<sarah.handford@hpa.org.uk>). By the end of October 2003, there had been 268 cases (including 22\ndeaths) mostly in children, approximately twice the average number of cases\nreported (1). The city health authorities in Moscow have\ninitiated a mass vaccination campaign in order to prevent further cases\noccurring during the coming peak transmission season. Altogether,\n259 cases of meningitis were registered in Moscow, 129 of which are among\nchildren, according to the Chief Pediatrician of Moscow, Mr.Rumyanzev. Unusually, many of the cases have been reported at the end\nof the summer and in early autumn; the usual seasonal increase occurs in\nFebruary and March. According to him, the Sanitary Epidemiological Surveillance staff together\nwith physicians conducted investigations of the focus of\ninfection. Currently the\nfigure is 3-3.5 per 100 000.\n \n(<http://www.nathnac.org/healthprofessionals/clinical/meningitis_moscow.html>)\n Ru (translated by Mod.
