There has been a rise in the number of cases of meningococcal meningitis in\nMoscow.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-11-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Centre", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204868", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Russia (Mariy El): RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204868", "date": "2003-11-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (MARIY EL): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue, 11 Nov 2003 00:45:29 -0800 (PST)\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource MariNews 9 Nov 2003 [translated by Mod. Nilufar Rakhmanova] [edited]\n<http://www.marinews.ru/>\n\n25 people have gotten meningitis during the last 9 months [of 2003] in\nMariy El. This is twice the number of cases for the [same period of 2002].\nAccording to [the above-referenced website, cases of] meningitis mostly\ninvolve children, and this time 21 children have gotten meningitis. There\nwere 3 lethal cases.\nThe most effective preventive measure against meningitis is vaccination.\nHowever, according to the Mariy El Ministry of Public Health, no vaccine\nagainst meningitis is available in Mariy El. In Russia, vaccine is produced\nonly against one type of meningitis, which is not appropriate in Mariy El.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Republic of Mariy El is located in the middle part of the Volga\nValley. It is part of the Russia's Volga-Vyatka Economic region. Mariy El\noccupies a territory of 23 200 sq km, which is 0.13 percent of the total\narea of the Russian Federation. It has a population of 766 200. The\nadministrative center is Ioshkar-Ola, whose population totals 280 000 and\nis located approximately 400 miles southeast of Moscow.\nAlthough the report uses the word 'virus', the presence of fatalities and\npreventive vaccination strongly suggests that this is bacterial meningitis.\nProMED would like more information regarding the bacteriology of the cases.\nThe 3 major bacterial organisms involved in bacterial meningitis outside\nthe neonatal period are _Streptococcus pneumoniae_, _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_, (at least all the major capsular types except B) and\n_Haemophilus influenzae_. Pediatric vaccines are available in the west for\nall 3 with the pneumococcal and _H. influenzae_ products being conjugated\nto proteins. Conjugating polysaccharide capsules to a protein backbone\nimproves the immune response by allowing the vaccine to have efficacy in\nchildren less than 24 months old and, as a T-cell-dependent antigen,\nproduces immunologic memory. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue, 11 Nov 2003 00:45:29 -0800 (PST)\n The 3 major bacterial organisms involved in bacterial meningitis outside\nthe neonatal period are _Streptococcus pneumoniae_, _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_, (at least all the major capsular types except B) and\n_Haemophilus influenzae_. Conjugating polysaccharide capsules to a protein backbone\nimproves the immune response by allowing the vaccine to have efficacy in\nchildren less than 24 months old and, as a T-cell-dependent antigen,\nproduces immunologic memory. The\nadministrative center is Ioshkar-Ola, whose population totals 280 000 and\nis located approximately 400 miles southeast of Moscow.\n Nilufar Rakhmanova] [edited]\n<http://www.marinews.ru/>\n\n25 people have gotten meningitis during the last 9 months [of 2003] in\nMariy El. In Russia, vaccine is produced\nonly against one type of meningitis, which is not appropriate in Mariy El.\n Pediatric vaccines are available in the west for\nall 3 with the pneumococcal and _H. influenzae_ products being conjugated\nto proteins. Mariy El\noccupies a territory of 23 200 sq km, which is 0.13 percent of the total\narea of the Russian Federation. --\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mariy El", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204884", "headline": "PRO> Meningitis - Russia (Mariy El) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204884", "date": "2003-11-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (MARIY EL) (02)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue, 11 Nov 2003\nFrom: Ronald Gold <ronald.gold@sympatico.ca>\n\nVaccines exist for all 3 major pathogens causing bacterial meningitis, with\nconjugated vaccines being available for some. The conjugated vaccines are\nall effective in infants, children, and adults, with immunization starting\nat 2 months of age:\n_Streptococcus pneumoniae_: polysaccharides of 7 serotypes conjugated to\nCRM197 protein (Prevnar);\n_Haemophilus influenzae_ type b: PRP polysaccharide conjugated to either\ntetanus toxoid, CRM 197, diphtheria toxoid, or meningococcal outermembrane\nprotein;\nSerogroup C _Neisseria meningococcus_: serogroup C polysaccharide\nconjugated to tetanus toxoid or CRM197 protein. [This conjugated vaccine is\nnot available in the USA. - Mod.LL]\nPolysaccharide vaccines exist against pneumonoccus (23 serotypes) and\nmeningococcus (either bivalent A/C or tetravalent A/C/Y/W135).\nAlthough group A meningococcal vaccines are effective in infants starting\nat 2 months of age, the other polysaccharide vaccines are not sufficiently\nimmunogenic in infants less than 2 years of age.\nMost recent outbreaks of meningococcal disease in Western Europe have been\nassociated with serogroup C meningococcus.\n--\nRonald Gold, MD, MPH\nProfessor Emeritus of Pediatrics\nThe Hospital for Sick Children\nToronto, Ontario\n<ronald.gold@sympatico.ca>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Gold for his comments on the different types of vaccines\navailable for the major etiologies of bacterial meningitis. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "The conjugated vaccines are\nall effective in infants, children, and adults, with immunization starting\nat 2 months of age:\n_Streptococcus pneumoniae_: polysaccharides of 7 serotypes conjugated to\nCRM197 protein (Prevnar);\n_Haemophilus influenzae_ type b: PRP polysaccharide conjugated to either\ntetanus toxoid, CRM 197, diphtheria toxoid, or meningococcal outermembrane\nprotein;\nSerogroup C _Neisseria meningococcus_: serogroup C polysaccharide\nconjugated to tetanus toxoid or CRM197 protein. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue, 11 Nov 2003\n Although group A meningococcal vaccines are effective in infants starting\nat 2 months of age, the other polysaccharide vaccines are not sufficiently\nimmunogenic in infants less than 2 years of age. The Hospital for Sick Children\nToronto, Ontario\n<ronald.gold@sympatico.ca>\n \nRonald Gold, MD, MPH\nProfessor Emeritus of Pediatrics\n Polysaccharide vaccines exist against pneumonoccus (23 serotypes) and\nmeningococcus (either bivalent A/C or tetravalent A/C/Y/W135).\n Most recent outbreaks of meningococcal disease in Western Europe have been\nassociated with serogroup C meningococcus.\n From: Ronald Gold <ronald.gold@sympatico.ca>\n\nVaccines exist for all 3 major pathogens causing bacterial meningitis, with\nconjugated vaccines being available for some. [ProMED thanks Dr. Gold for his comments on the different types of vaccines\navailable for the major etiologies of bacterial meningitis. - Mod. [This conjugated vaccine is\nnot available in the USA. - Mod. MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (MARIY EL) (02)\n **\n LL]\n \n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204793", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal type A - Russia (Moscow)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204793", "date": "2003-10-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL TYPE A - RUSSIA (MOSCOW)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 28 Oct 2003\nFrom: Dr. Hans Berg <Hans.H.Berg@shell.com>\nIt has been conveyed to us that a rising number of meningococcal meningitis\nserogroup A cases is being reported in Moscow. Apparently, the Moscow City\nCentral Epidemiological Station has noted 25 cases between 1 Aug and 30 Sep\n2003, while from 1 to 20 Oct, 22 cases were diagnosed. Laboratory reports\nshow the meningococcal A strain as the cause of illness in 90 percent of\ncases.\n268 cases were reported during 2003 so far, which is a 150 percent increase\nover 2002. Local health authorities expect a further rise in the number of\ncases during the next 3 months due to the cold weather and are urging the\npopulation, especially children, to be vaccinated.\nCan anyone confirm the above statistics? Given the large denominator, do\nthese numbers actually warrant calling this an outbreak? Do we have\nhistoric epidemiological statistics on this in Gideon?\n--\nHans Berg MD\nSenior Health Adviser, Shell International B.V.\nThe Hague, The Netherlands\n<Hans.H.Berg@shell.com>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 17 Oct 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Moscow Times [edited]\n<http://www.themoscowtimes.com/stories/2003/10/17/013.html>\n\nCity to Vaccinate 400 000 Children for Meningitis\n-------------------------------------------------\nBacterial meningitis has killed 9 children in Moscow so far during the fall\nof 2003, and city health authorities have ordered a mass vaccination\ncampaign to try to prevent an outbreak of the disease. About 400 000\nchildren aged 1-1/2 to 8 years are to be vaccinated and the city has\nalready allocated the necessary funds, said Nikolai Filatov, head of the\ncity health inspectorate.\nSo far this year, 251 Muscovites, most of whom are children, have been hit\nby meningitis and 22 have died, including 9 children, Filatov said. The\nnumbers of cases and fatalities are only slightly higher than in previous\nyears, but many were registered at the end of the summer and in early fall,\nwhich are normally considered disease-free seasons, said Tatyana\nChernyshova, head of the meningitis laboratory at the Health Ministry's\nGabrichevsky Epidemiology and Microbiology Research Institute. The 9\nchildren all died in September 2003, she said.\nAdding to the worry, about 70 percent of the cases have been caused by type\nA bacteria, and it was type A bacteria that caused outbreaks of meningitis\nin Moscow in the 1980s. Chernyshova said her laboratory is trying to\ndetermine whether the current bacteria in the city are identical to the\nbacteria that caused the outbreaks 20 years ago.\n'There is no reason to panic yet, but we decided to be on the safe side and\nvaccinate before the seasonal increase in the number of cases,' Chernyshova\nsaid.\nChernyshova said children in Moscow will get shots of a Russian-made\nvaccine, which is almost 1/10 the cost of one manufactured in France. The\nHealth Ministry's stocks of the vaccine are sufficient, but in the case of\na major outbreak, health authorities might encounter trouble, since the\nRussian vaccine is produced in small quantities, she said.\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue, 29 Oct 2003\nFrom: Steve Berger <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: GideonOnline [edited]\n<http://www.GideonOnline.net>\n\nSome background on meningococcal disease in the Russian Federation\n---------------------------------------------------\nLarge epidemics of serogroup A meningococcal disease occurred in Moscow in\n1931 and 1940.\nIn 1968, a serogroup A epidemic was reported in Lipezk.\nAn outbreak of group A meningococcal meningitis (188 cases) was reported\nfrom Moscow during Jan to Apr 1996 -- primarily affecting the Vietnamese\ncommunity [see ProMED refs. below]. As a result, hundreds of thousands of\nMuscovites were immunized with A polysaccharide vaccine.\nYear / meningococcal disease - cases / fatal cases\n1966 / 491\n1967 / 532\n1968 / 656\n1969 / 2120\n1971 / 6716\n1972 / 13 326\n1973 / 21 353\n1974 / 16 956\n1975 / 15 290\n1976 / 15 677\n1977 / 15 712\n1978 / 6970\n1979 / 6694\n1980 / 8062 / 1214\n1981 / 10 375 / 1390\n1982 / 10 781 / 1345\n1983 / 12 446 / 1430\n1984 / 12 830 / 1717\n1985 / 12 054 / 1695\n1986 / 10 092 / 1335\n1987 / 9 009 / 1270\n1988 / 8430\n1989 / 7411\n1990 / 6615\n1991 / 5860\n1992 / 5167\n1995 / 3839 / 786\n1999 / 3777 (2.6 /100 000)\n2000 / 3925 (2.7 /100 000)\n--\nDr. Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Berg for his information and query regarding the current\nstate of meningococcal meningitis serogroup A in Moscow. The\nHealth Ministry's stocks of the vaccine are sufficient, but in the case of\na major outbreak, health authorities might encounter trouble, since the\nRussian vaccine is produced in small quantities, she said. The Hague, The Netherlands\n<Hans.H.Berg@shell.com>\n******\n \nDr. Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\n Apparently, the Moscow City\nCentral Epidemiological Station has noted 25 cases between 1 Aug and 30 Sep\n2003, while from 1 to 20 Oct, 22 cases were diagnosed. An outbreak of group A meningococcal meningitis (188 cases) was reported\nfrom Moscow during Jan to Apr 1996 -- primarily affecting the Vietnamese\ncommunity [see ProMED refs. below]. Local health authorities expect a further rise in the number of\ncases during the next 3 months due to the cold weather and are urging the\npopulation, especially children, to be vaccinated. Chernyshova said her laboratory is trying to\ndetermine whether the current bacteria in the city are identical to the\nbacteria that caused the outbreaks 20 years ago. \n268 cases were reported during 2003 so far, which is a 150 percent increase\nover 2002. Source: GideonOnline [edited]\n<http://www.GideonOnline.net>\n\nSome background on meningococcal disease in the Russian Federation\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1992-03-26 00:00:00", "1974-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-09-26 00:00:00", "1989-03-26 00:00:00", "1984-03-26 00:00:00", "1990-03-26 00:00:00", "1968-03-26 00:00:00", "1977-03-26 00:00:00", "1980-03-26 00:00:00", "1995-03-26 00:00:00", "1976-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "1975-03-26 00:00:00", "1971-03-26 00:00:00", "1973-03-26 00:00:00", "1966-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "1985-03-26 00:00:00", "1981-03-26 00:00:00", "1972-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tatyana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gideon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "the Hague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204567", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis update 2003 (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204567", "date": "2003-09-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS UPDATE 2003 (02)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Serous meningitis (Belarus, Minsk)\n[2] Serous meningitis (Russia, Stavropol)\n******\n[1]\nDate: Sat 6 Sep 2003\nFrom: Rakhmanova Nilufar <rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\nSource: ITAR-TASS, Wed 3 Sep 2003 [edited]\n<http://news.battery.ru/theme/health/?from_m=theme&from_t=health&from_n=2043538&newsId=1964570&lastId=1964570>\n\nBelarus: outbreak of serous meningitis in Minsk\n-----------------------------------------------\n495 cases of enterovirus infection have been registered so far in Minsk\n[the capital of Belarus]. According to the Belarus Republic Centre of\nHygiene, Epidemiology and Public Health about 90 of the people affected by\n'summer flu' are children. On average about 30 children are being admitted\nevery day to the children's hospital.\nIn many cases physicians diagnose serous meningitis, a consequence of\nenterovirus infection, which can be transferred through water and food\nproducts. Despite the increased incidence of enteroviral infection, and\nserous meningitis in particular, public officials are not considering it an\nepidemic . For prevention purposes, chlorination of drinking water has been\nundertaken and sanitary and epidemiologic control in food producing\nfactories is being increased.\n--\nNilufar Rakhmanova MD\nMaster of Public Health\nBoston University\nSchool of Public Health\n<rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 15 Sep 2003\nFrom: Rakhmanova Nilufar <rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\nSource: Infectious and Parasitological Diseases News, Mon 15 Sep 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.infectology.spb.ru/news/news/calendar.asp?date=09/15/03>\n\nRussia: serous meningitis cases in Stavropol reach 20\n-----------------------------------------------------\nThe number of people diagnosed with serous meningitis has increased to 20.\nAccording to the city of Stavropol Epidemiologic Surveillance Centre there\nare 3 adults among the 20 infected. The remainder are children aged 10 and\n11 years. Serous meningitis is an acute infectious diseases which [is\ntransmitted by the fecal oral route]. A person can become infected by\nswimming in lakes or rivers and accidentally swallowing water. Physicians\nare warning the public also to wash fruit and vegetables -- and their hands\n-- before eating. Tap water should be boiled during the course of the\noutbreak. Serous meningitis is a seasonal infection and is expected to\ndecrease soon.\n--\nNilufar Rakhmanova MD\nMaster of Public Health\nBoston University\nSchool of Public Health\n<rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\n[About half to three quarters of cases of meningitis are caused by viruses.\nThe etiologic agents are mainly enteroviruses (echoviruses, Coxsackie\nviruses, and poliovirus), and less frequently mumps virus (transmitted by\ndroplets and fomites), herpes simplex virus, and adenovirus. In some\ncountries viral meningitis may be associated with certain arboviruses.\nCases of human infection are commonest in summer months and in the first 10\nyears of life. The infection in Belarus and Russia described above appear\nto be transmitted by the fecal oral route and is likely to associated with\nenterovirus infection. The prognosis for viral meningitis is good and\nrecovery is usually complete. Viral meningitis is sometimes referred to as\naseptic, lymphocytic, or serous meningitis because of the predominance of\nlymphocytes in the cerebrospinal fluid. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "--\nNilufar Rakhmanova MD\nMaster of Public Health\nBoston University\nSchool of Public Health\n<rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\n --\nNilufar Rakhmanova MD\nMaster of Public Health\nBoston University\nSchool of Public Health\n<rakhmanovan@yahoo.com A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n In many cases physicians diagnose serous meningitis, a consequence of\nenterovirus infection, which can be transferred through water and food\nproducts. Viral meningitis is sometimes referred to as\naseptic, lymphocytic, or serous meningitis because of the predominance of\nlymphocytes in the cerebrospinal fluid. - Mod. VIRAL MENINGITIS UPDATE 2003 (02)\n*********************************\n In this update:\n[1] Serous meningitis (Belarus, Minsk)\n The etiologic agents are mainly enteroviruses (echoviruses, Coxsackie\nviruses, and poliovirus), and less frequently mumps virus (transmitted by\ndroplets and fomites), herpes simplex virus, and adenovirus. [2] Serous meningitis (Russia, Stavropol)\n******\n For prevention purposes, chlorination of drinking water has been\nundertaken and sanitary and epidemiologic control in food producing\nfactories is being increased.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-09-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Stavropol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belarus", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Minsk", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204684", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis update 2003 (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204684", "date": "2003-10-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS UPDATE 2003 (03)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Serous meningitis (Russia, Novodvinsk)\n[2] Serous meningitis (Russia, Moscow)\n******\n[1]\nDate: Tue 7 Oct 2003\nFrom: Nilufar Rakhmanova <rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\nSource: Regnum Information Agency, Mon 29 Sep 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.regnum.ru/allnews/161233.html>\n\nRussia: Outbreak of Meningitis Recorded in Novodvinsk\n(Arkangelsk)\n--------------------------------------------------\n18 cases of enteroviral infection were registered in Novodvinsk\nduring the period Wed 3 Sep to Mon 29 Sep 2003. 12 cases of\nserous meningitis were confirmed by serological analysis.\nAccording to Viktor Sosnizkiy of the Epidemiological Surveillance\nCenter, no fatal cases were registered.\nSosnizkiy explained that these were cases of serous meningitis\nand not purulent meningitis, which often has a fatal outcome.\nThe rise in infection can be explained by the disease's seasonal\ncharacter. We can talk about a meningitis outbreak only after 10\nregistered cases occur in the same district, whereas an epidemic is\n[declared] when the number of cases is 10 times greater. For\nexample, in the Sverdlovsk region, an epidemic was not declared\neven although 200 cases of meningitis were registered.\nMost of the infected are children. According to Sosnizkiy, the\nchildren probably contracted infection after swimming. The fact that\nthe epidemic occurred in September can be explained by the long\nincubation period of the illness. According to Sosnizkiy, enteroviral\ninfections [resulting in meningitis] are caused by coxsackieviruses\nor echoviruses.\nMeningitis morbidity has been sporadic during recent years. The\ndisease starts acutely, with high fever, severe headache, and\nfrequent vomiting not associated with food intake. Symptoms [of\nmeningitis] can be observed on the 2nd and 3rd day of the illness.\nPatients with this condition should be hospitalized and spinal\npuncture may be required [for diagnosis].\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 7 Oct 2003\nFrom: Rakhmanova Nilufar <rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\nSource: Mednovosti News online, Mon 6 Oct 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.mednovosti.ru/news/2003/10/06/meningitis/>\n\nRussia: Meningitis Epidemic Warning in Moscow\n---------------------------------------------\nPre-school and elementary school children in Moscow will be\nvaccinated because of the increase in meningitis cases, according\nto the Moscow Center for Sanitary Epidemiological Surveillance.\nAccording to an epidemiologist, there were 230 cases of meningitis\nin Moscow during the last 8 months. This is almost 2 times more\nthen average but is less then the epidemic threshold.\nThe steepest rise in (droplet-borne) disease is observed in\nautumn-winter, and if the necessary prevention measures are not\nundertaken, there is the threat of epidemic. Vaccination [is\nrecommended but not compulsory]. Obligatory vaccination is\nimplemented after 2 or more cases of meningitis occur in a\nkindergarten or elementary school. The final decision on\nvaccination will be made by local officials. If they decide not to\nvaccinate, parents can vaccinate their children for a fee of 500\nrubles.\n--\nNilufar Rakhmanova M.D.\nBoston University\nSchool of Public Health\n<rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\n[About 1/2 to 3/4 of cases of meningitis are caused by viruses. The\netiologic agents are predominantly enteroviruses (echoviruses,\ncoxsackieviruses, and poliovirus), and less frequently mumps virus\n(transmitted by droplets and fomites), herpes simplex virus, and\nadenovirus. In some countries viral meningitis may be associated\nwith certain arboviruses. Consequently there is no specific vaccine\napplicable to all cases of meningitis. It is presumed that in the\noutbreaks described above, poliomyelitis virus vaccine is being\nemployed, with the aim of inducing some degree of cross-protective\nimmunity.\nCases of enteroviral infection are commonest in summer months\nand in the first 10 years of life. Transmission of infection is\npredominantly by the fecal-oral route, likely the case in the\nenteroviral meningitis outbreaks described above. The prognosis\nfor viral meningitis is good and recovery is usually complete. Viral\nmeningitis is sometimes referred to as aseptic, lymphocytic, or\nserous meningitis because of the predominance of lymphocytes in\nthe cerebrospinal fluid.\nThe distinction between an outbreak and an epidemic is arbitrary,\nvarying according to situation, circumstance, and local usage. -\nMod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n ---------------------------------------------\nPre-school and elementary school children in Moscow will be\nvaccinated because of the increase in meningitis cases, according\nto the Moscow Center for Sanitary Epidemiological Surveillance.\n The\netiologic agents are predominantly enteroviruses (echoviruses,\ncoxsackieviruses, and poliovirus), and less frequently mumps virus\n(transmitted by droplets and fomites), herpes simplex virus, and\nadenovirus. \nNilufar Rakhmanova M.D.\nBoston University\nSchool of Public Health\n<rakhmanovan@yahoo.com Viral\nmeningitis is sometimes referred to as aseptic, lymphocytic, or\nserous meningitis because of the predominance of lymphocytes in\nthe cerebrospinal fluid. Health officials said most cases of the new virus are\nmild, but it can cause [aseptic] meningitis. The virus has hit hundreds of\npeople along the Front Range, said Dr. Ken Gershman, chief of the state's\ncommunicable disease program. He did not have a specific number because the\nstate is not tracking the virus.\n8 samples taken from patients were sent for analysis this week to the\nfederal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. Patients\nwith the suspected virus can suffer symptoms nearly identical to those\nafflicted with potentially deadly West Nile virus, including a rash. Other\nsymptoms include headache, muscle soreness and low-grade fever, all of\nwhich can be West Nile virus infection symptoms.\nDr. Adrienne LeBailly, director of the Larimer County health department, is\nworking with state officials and the CDC to identify the virus. She said it\nis probably transmitted by fecal matter, unlike mosquito-borne West Nile.\nIt also could be transmitted through respiratory secretions such as saliva\nor nasal mucus. The virus is not at this time considered a public health\nthreat, LeBailly said. Gershman said the number of non-West Nile\nvirus-associated meningitis cases is at a record level in Colorado. There\nwere 101 cases diagnosed in July 2003, the most the state has seen since at\nleast 1996, when a new tracking system was introduced. The previous high\nwas 68 in July 2001.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Aseptic (viral) meningitis is normally associated with enteroviral\ninfection. USA (Georgia) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204297", "date": "2003-08-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, VIRAL - USA (GEORGIA) (02)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 6 Aug 2003\nFrom: Keith Woeltje <kwoeltje@mail.mcg.edu>\n\nGeorgia: Echovirus 9 Associated with Current Viral Meningitis Outbreak\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe following information is an update on the posting on viral meningitis\nin North Georgia [see: Meningitis, viral - USA (Georgia) 20030805.1923].\nWe first detected the outbreak here in early April 2003, although in\nretrospect there had been some cases seen in late March. Echovirus 9 was\nisolated from numerous patients from cerebrospinal fluid .\n--\nKeith F. Woeltje, MD, PhD\nHospital Epidemiologist\nMedical College of Georgia\n<kwoeltje@mail.mcg.edu>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Dr. Woeltje for this additional\ninformation on the outbreak. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 6 Aug 2003\n --\nKeith F. That brings the tally of people known to be\naffected by the illness to 37. The outbreak began in mid-May.\nNorth Central District Health Department epidemiologist Donna Anderson says\nhealth authorities do not know what caused the outbreak, but anyone with\nsymptoms should call their doctor. Symptoms include fever, severe headache,\nstiff neck, sensitivity to bright lights, drowsiness or confusion, nausea\nand vomiting.\nViral meningitis involves inflammation of the tissues that cover the brain\nand spinal cord. It's less serious than bacterial meningitis, which has the\nsame symptoms. Health officials say frequent hand washing is the best\ndefense against viral meningitis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Viral or 'aseptic' memnigitis is usually associated with a variety of\nenteroviral infections. Recovery is normally complete within a few weeks,\nalthough there is a small risk of serious neurological damage in early\nlife. The hand-washing admonition suggests that enterovirus infection is\nsuspected. Aseptic meningitis may be associated also with mumps in\nchildren, an occasional feature of genital infection with herpes simplex\nvirus type 2 in adults, a consequence of exposure to small rodents carrying\nlymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, or arbovirus infection. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 25 Jun 2003\nFrom: 'Pablo Nart' <p.nart@vet.gla.ac.uk>\n Aseptic meningitis may be associated also with mumps in\nchildren, an occasional feature of genital infection with herpes simplex\nvirus type 2 in adults, a consequence of exposure to small rodents carrying\nlymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, or arbovirus infection. In recent weeks, health\nofficials have traveled to Umphang with vaccines, medical kits, and other\nmedicines to help stem the spread of the disease. Viral meningitis is much milder and less deadly\nthan bacterial meningitis. The viral version usually causes a short-lived\nflu-like sickness, but officials are concerned about it in 2003 because 300\ncases were reported between January and July, whereas in a typical year,\n175 cases are recorded in Georgia.\nRichard Quartarone of Georgia's Public Health Division says the outbreak\napparently started in Augusta but has spread to Gainesville and metro\nAtlanta. The health division put out a call to the media on Monday asking\nfor help in encouragement of hand-washing. Quartarone also cautioned people\nagainst sharing utensils or lip balm, especially during July and August,\nwhen viruses carried in the digestive system are typically at their peaks.\nState health workers are visiting day-care centers and schools to promote\nhand washing, which is considered the best prevention tool.\nSymptoms of viral meningitis include headache, fever, sore neck, and\nnausea. There's no cure, but sufferers are encouraged to see a doctor to\nmake sure they don't have bacterial meningitis, which can cause death by\ndamaging the lining around the brain and spinal cord.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Non-bacterial ('aseptic') meningitis is a frequent accompaniment of\nenteroviral infection. Many different enteroviruses have been associated\nwith aseptic meningitis. Recovery is normally complete within a few weeks,\nbut irritability and fatigue may persist. There is a low risk of serious\nneurological damage only during the first year of life. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 5 Aug 2003\n The viral version usually causes a short-lived\nflu-like sickness, but officials are concerned about it in 2003 because 300\ncases were reported between January and July, whereas in a typical year,\n175 cases are recorded in Georgia. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n There's no cure, but sufferers are encouraged to see a doctor to\nmake sure they don't have bacterial meningitis, which can cause death by\ndamaging the lining around the brain and spinal cord. REP. (NORTH KIVU)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 17:31:47 GMT+1\nFrom: Prudence Mitangala <mitangala.prudence@caramail.com>\nA meningitis outbreak started the 23 Sep 2002 in the Rwanguba Health zone,\nlocated at 80 km of Goma, in the Province of North Kivu, Democratic Republic\nof Congo. The epidemic thresholds was reached within 2 weeks. The outbreak\nis still confined in this health zone comprising 50 000 inhabitants. Until\nnow, a total of 109 patients and 22 deaths has been reported by the Health\nauthorities of Rwanguba (case fatality rate of 20.19%).\nThe etiological agent has been identified by the Provincial Public Health\nReference laboratory on 5 Oct 02. All strains isolated from cerebrospinal\nfluid samples of patients were identified as _Neisseria meningitidis_\nbelonging to serogroup A. The serotyping is actually done in Europe. The\nstrains are resistant to sulfonamides, but were susceptible to ampicillin,\nchloramphenicol, and ceftriaxone which are the first line drugs used for the\ntreatment of bacterial meningitis locally.\nFollowing the epidemiological and microbiological results, a late reactive\nimmunization campaign has now been started by the Provincial Health\nauthorities with the support of two NGO's: MSF-Holland and CEMUBAC-Belgium.\nThis situation underscores [the fact] that despite effective surveillance\nsystems and laboratory network, the delay between the beginning of the\nepidemic and mass vaccination is still [large] in the province of Nord-Kivu.\nIn regard to this situation, authorities should consider setting up a\nregional stock of vaccine to initiate reactive mass campaigns when outbreaks\noccur.\n--\nPrudence Mitangala Ndeba, MD\nHead of Provincial Epidemiological Unit\nProvince of North Kivu, DR Congo\n<mitangala.prudence@caramail.com>\n[ProMED thanks Dr Ndeba for this report from the field. Although serotype A\nis endemic in the meningitis belt of Africa, and not strictly an emerging\ndisease there, we encourage direct reporting of outbreaks. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "\nPrudence Mitangala Ndeba, MD\nHead of Provincial Epidemiological Unit\nProvince of North Kivu, DR Congo\n<mitangala.prudence@caramail.com>\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 17:31:47 The\nstrains are resistant to sulfonamides, but were susceptible to ampicillin,\nchloramphenicol, and ceftriaxone which are the first line drugs used for the\ntreatment of bacterial meningitis locally. This situation underscores [the fact] that despite effective surveillance\nsystems and laboratory network, the delay between the beginning of the\nepidemic and mass vaccination is still [large] in the province of Nord-Kivu. In regard to this situation, authorities should consider setting up a\nregional stock of vaccine to initiate reactive mass campaigns when outbreaks\noccur. A meningitis outbreak started the 23 Sep 2002 in the Rwanguba Health zone,\nlocated at 80 km of Goma, in the Province of North Kivu, Democratic Republic\nof Congo. All strains isolated from cerebrospinal\nfluid samples of patients were identified as _Neisseria meningitidis_\nbelonging to serogroup A. The serotyping is actually done in Europe. Until\nnow, a total of 109 patients and 22 deaths has been reported by the Health\nauthorities of Rwanguba (case fatality rate of 20.19%).", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2002-11-29 00:00:00", "2002-09-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North Kivu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Holland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202063", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, viral - Panama (Chiriqui)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202063", "date": "2002-06-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, VIRAL - PANAMA (CHIRIQUI)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 27 Jun 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Agencia EFE via COMTEX 26 Jun 2002 21:54 EST [edited]\n\nPanama declares meningitis epidemic along border with Costa Rica\n----------------------------------------------------\nPanamanian health authorities on Wednesday declared an epidemic of viral\nmeningitis in the province of Chiriqui, on the border with Costa Rica, where\n186 cases have been reported in the past 3 weeks. General health director\nEsteban Morales, flanked by epidemiologists, said that 237 cases of viral\nmeningitis had been recorded throughout the country in children under 15\nyears old.\nMorales told a news conference at a Panama City hospital that the Health\nMinistry was aware of only one case of bacterial meningitis. Health\nauthorities explained that viral meningitis is benign, while bacterial\nmeningitis is fatal in 15 percent of the cases, and results in lingering\nproblems in the brains of 40 percent of the patients. Most of the 20 or so\nchildren who are currently in hospital with viral meningitis are between one\nand 6 years old, Morales said.\nHe added that schools in the province of Chiriqui would remain closed to\navoid contagion, since there is no vaccine against the disease and the only\nway to prevent it is by practicing thorough personal hygiene.\nMorales said that viral meningitis is caused by an enterovirus that lodges\nin the intestinal wall, and he added that it spreads through oral contagion\nand poor hygienic practices. He described meningitis as an infection or\nswelling of the membrane that covers the brain and the spinal cord. Symptoms\nusually include severe headaches, vomiting, and neck pain and stiffness. A\nhealth official said that bacterial meningitis must be immediately treated\nwith specific antibiotics, but that there is no specific treatment for viral\nmeningitis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Viral meningitis is usually associated with enterovirus infection, in\nparticular, coxsackieviruses (A and B types) and some echoviruses. More\ninformation on this outbreak from official sources, including the type of\nvirus responsible, would be appreciated. - Mods.CP/MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A\nhealth official said that bacterial meningitis must be immediately treated\nwith specific antibiotics, but that there is no specific treatment for viral\nmeningitis.\n Health\nauthorities explained that viral meningitis is benign, while bacterial\nmeningitis is fatal in 15 percent of the cases, and results in lingering\nproblems in the brains of 40 percent of the patients. General health director\nEsteban Morales, flanked by epidemiologists, said that 237 cases of viral\nmeningitis had been recorded throughout the country in children under 15\nyears old. \nPanamanian health authorities on Wednesday declared an epidemic of viral\nmeningitis in the province of Chiriqui, on the border with Costa Rica, where\n186 cases have been reported in the past 3 weeks. Morales said that viral meningitis is caused by an enterovirus that lodges\nin the intestinal wall, and he added that it spreads through oral contagion\nand poor hygienic practices. Most of the 20 or so\nchildren who are currently in hospital with viral meningitis are between one\nand 6 years old, Morales said.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2002-06-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Panama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chiriqui", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Costa Rica", "country": "Costa Rica"}, {"location": "Panama City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204378", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis update 2003 (01)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204378", "date": "2003-08-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS UPDATE 2003 (01)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 15 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2003; 52(32): 761-4. Fri 15 Aug [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5232a1.htm>\n\nUnited States: outbreaks of aseptic meningitis associated with echoviruses\n9 and 30 and preliminary surveillance reports on enterovirus activity - 2003\n---------------------------\nAseptic or viral meningitis is the commonest type of meningitis and is\nassociated with an estimated 26 000 to 42 000 hospital admissions each year\nin the United States (1). Enteroviruses are the commonest cause of aseptic\nmeningitis (2). Echovirus 9 (E9) and echovirus 30 (E30) have been\nassociated frequently with outbreaks of aseptic meningitis (3,4,5).\nDuring March 2003, several state public health departments noted increased\nreports of aseptic meningitis and, as of 7 Aug 2003, 7 states (Arizona,\nCalifornia, Georgia, Idaho, Oregon, South Carolina, and Texas) had reported\noutbreaks associated with either E9 or E30. This report summarizes the\nepidemiologic features of the aseptic meningitis outbreaks in 5 states\n(Arizona, California, Georgia, Idaho, and South Carolina) and provides an\noverview of enterovirus activity in the US during the period 1 Jan to 7 Aug\n2003. Enteroviruses, E9 and E30 in particular, should be considered in the\ndifferential diagnosis of people with aseptic meningitis.\nAseptic meningitis is not a nationally notifiable disease, and no\nnationally accepted case definition exists for this condition (6).\nTherefore, cases of aseptic meningitis described in this report represent\nphysician diagnoses based on clinical presentation and laboratory findings.\nThe enterovirus surveillance data were obtained from reports to the\nNational Enterovirus Surveillance System (NESS), a passive voluntary\nsurveillance system based on reporting by state public health and private\nlaboratories of enterovirus detections by serotype and basic demographic\ninformation, specimen type, and date of collection.\nAseptic Meningitis Outbreaks\n----------------------------\nArizona:\n-------\nFrom 1 Jan to 7 Jul 2003, a total of 465 cases of aseptic meningitis\n(rate: 8.6 per 100 000 population) were reported to the Arizona Department\nof Health Services, compared with 104 cases (rate: 1.9) reported for the\nsame period in 2002. The highest rate during this period was reported in\nMaricopa County (rate: 12.7, compared with 2.7 during the same period in\n2002). As of 31 Jul 2003, the Arizona State Health Laboratory had reported\n62 enterovirus isolates, the majority (66 per cent) from cerebrospinal\nfluid (CSF) specimens. Of the 62 isolates, E30 accounted for 47 isolates\nand E9 for one isolate.\nCalifornia:\n----------\nAs of 5 Aug 2003, a total of 1753 cases of aseptic meningitis (rate: 8.0\nper 100 000 population) had been reported to the California Department of\nHealth Services (CDHS). During 1999 to 2003, the annual reported rate of\naseptic meningitis in California ranged from 4.5 to 7.3. Specimens from 148\npatients with aseptic meningitis were submitted to CDHS for diagnostic\ntesting from 24 counties throughout the state. Serum and CSF specimens from\nall patients were tested for enteroviruses and arboviruses (West Nile virus\n[WNV], St. Louis encephalitis virus, and western equine encephalitis virus)\nat CDHS. Of the 148 patients, 82 (55 per cent) had evidence of enterovirus\ninfection by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or culture; E30 was identified\nfrom 29 (85%) of the 82 culture-positive cases, and E9 was identified from\nfour (12%) cases.\nGeorgia:\n-------\nDuring March, an outbreak of aseptic meningitis associated with E9\ninfection began in Augusta, Georgia. During the period 10 Mar to 23 Jul\n2003, a total of 320 cases were reported from 50 of Georgia's 159 counties,\ncompared with 227 cases reported statewide during 2002. E9 has been\nisolated from CSF, throat swab, and/or rectal swab specimens of 24\npatients. Enteroviruses (untyped) were isolated from an additional 24 CSF\nspecimens, and 52 CSF specimens tested positive for enteroviruses by PCR.\nPatients commonly reported headache, fever, nausea or vomiting, stiff neck,\nand photophobia. As of 7 Aug 2003, the outbreak was ongoing.\nIdaho:\n-----\nFrom 2 May to 17 Jul 2003, an outbreak of viral meningitis occurred in\nnorth central Idaho, with 38 cases from 3 adjacent counties reported to the\nIdaho Division of Health, compared with 4 cases reported statewide during\nthe previous year. Of the 32 patients for whom clinical information was\navailable, 17 were hospitalized with clinical signs and symptoms consistent\nwith aseptic meningitis. E30 was isolated from 2 of 4 patients who\nunderwent virologic investigation. Two cases of aseptic meningitis reported\nsubsequently from the same area are under investigation by the North\nCentral District Health Department.\nSouth Carolina:\n--------------\nFrom 6 Apr to 31 Jul 2003, a total of 82 cases of viral meningitis were\nidentified by the Aiken County Health Department. The outbreak peaked in\nMay, when 38 cases were reported. E9 was isolated from CSF of 2 of these\npatients. At the same time, adjacent counties in Georgia also experienced\nan outbreak of aseptic meningitis associated with E9. In June, cases began\nto appear in multiple counties. The number of reports and CSF specimen\nsubmissions to the South Carolina State Laboratory continued to increase in\nJuly. As of 31 Jul 2003, a total of 130 cases of aseptic meningitis had\nbeen reported; E9 was isolated from 20 specimens (18 CSF and 2 throat\nwashings) from 8 different counties, and no other enteroviruses were\nidentified. Because viral meningitis is not a notifiable disease in South\nCarolina, comparative data are not available for previous years.\nEnterovirus surveillance data\n-----------------------------\nAs of 7 Aug 2003, NESS had received reports of 365 enterovirus detections\nin 25 states; source specimens for these isolates were collected from 5 Jan\nto 30 Jul 2003. The most commonly detected serotypes were E9 and E30, with\nE30 accounting for 132 (36 per cent) and E9 accounting for 108 (30 per\ncent) reports. E9 was isolated in 14 states, mainly in the East (for\nexample, Georgia, Florida, New Jersey, and South Carolina), and E30 was\nisolated in 10 states, mainly in the West (for example, Arizona,\nCalifornia, Colorado, and Texas). For both serotypes, CSF was the source\nspecimen in the majority of cases (72 [67 per cent] for E9 and 107 [81 per\ncent] for E30).\nOther enterovirus serotypes reported most frequently include coxsackievirus\nB1 (29 [8 per cent] of all reports), echovirus 7 (10 [3 per cent]),\ncoxsackievirus A9 (10 [3 per cent]), enterovirus 71 (nine [3 per cent]),\ncoxsackievirus B4 (12 [4 per cent]), and echovirus 5 (seven [2 per cent]).\n(Reported by: R Cheshier, Arizona Dept of Health Svcs. E Tu, C Glaser, MD,\nCalifornia Dept of Health Svcs. K Bryant, MPH, K Arnold, MD, Georgia Div of\nPublic Health. K Carter, DVM, Idaho Div of Health. E Brenner, MD, South\nCarolina Dept of Health and Environmental Control. SP Montgomery, DVM, Div\nof Vector-Borne Infectious Diseases; A LaMonte, MPH, N Khetsuriani, MD, M\nPallansch, PhD, Div of Viral and Rickettsial Diseases, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.)\nMMWR editorial note:\n-------------------\nAseptic meningitis is a central nervous system infection characterized by\nfever and meningeal symptoms with moderate, predominantly lymphocytic CSF\npleocytosis and the absence of bacterial pathogens in CSF. The disease\noccurs both sporadically and in outbreaks, and >90 per cent of cases with\nan identified cause are associated with enteroviruses (2). Many aseptic\nmeningitis outbreaks occurring during the current enterovirus season\nreflect high levels of E9 and E30 activity. In 2003, E9 has been involved\npredominantly in the outbreaks in the East, and E30 has been linked\nexclusively with outbreaks in the West.\nFrom 1970 to 2001, both E9 and E30 were among the 15 enteroviruses\nreported most commonly each year, accounting for 10.2 per cent and 8.2 per\ncent of all enterovirus isolates reported to CDC, respectively (CDC,\nunpublished data, 2003). However, these enteroviruses have been relatively\nquiescent in recent years; E9 has not been the predominant enterovirus\nisolated from clinical specimens since 1995, and E30 has not been\nwidespread since 1998 (7,8). This probably has resulted in an accumulation\nof cohorts of susceptible persons who have not been exposed previously to\nthese agents.\nThe increase in aseptic meningitis cases associated with high activity of\nE9 and E30 is consistent with the historic data; during the period 1988 to\n1999, peak years for viral meningitis hospitalizations in the United States\ncoincided with periods of high activity of either E9 or E30 (1).\nAlthough most cases of enterovirus infections are asymptomatic or result in\nmild febrile illnesses, aseptic meningitis is the main diagnosis reported\nwith the current E9 and E30 activity in the US because patients with\nmeningitis are more likely to be tested for enteroviruses than those with\nless severe manifestations. In a small proportion of cases, more severe,\nlife-threatening diseases (such as encephalitis, paralysis,\nmyopericarditis, and neonatal enteroviral sepsis) might occur.\nEnteroviruses typically demonstrate a marked seasonality in temperate\nclimates, with a typical enterovirus season in the United States occurring\nduring June to October (9). In 2003, the enterovirus season appears to have\nstarted early, with the first isolations of E9 reported in January (in\nLouisiana), the first outbreaks of E9-associated aseptic meningitis\nreported in March, and the first isolations of E30 reported in April (in\nArizona). WNV has the same seasonal pattern as enteroviruses, and is also\nassociated with neurologic signs and symptoms of aseptic meningitis.\nHowever, WNV-associated meningitis tends to occur among older people\n(median age: 46 years) (10), whereas children and young adults (median age:\n13 years) are at highest risk for enteroviral meningitis (1). The\ninvestigation of an aseptic meningitis outbreak in an area of high WNV\nepizootic activity in 2001 indicated that enteroviruses were the leading\ncause of aseptic meningitis in this area, and no evidence of WNV infection\nwas detected (10). For this reason, diagnostic testing of specimens from\nyounger patients with aseptic meningitis should include testing for\nenteroviruses, even during a documented WNV outbreak (10).\nEarly etiologic diagnosis of aseptic meningitis helps to avoid unnecessary\nantibiotic treatment and additional testing. Although virus culture is the\nstandard technique for enterovirus detection, it consumes time and\nresources and has limited clinical use. Molecular methods of enterovirus\ndetection (such as PCR and typing based on genomic sequences) are\nincreasingly becoming available. Serotype-specific PCR primers have been\ndeveloped by CDC for several enteroviruses, including E30 (5). These\nserotype-specific primers are useful for rapid differentiation of cases in\npatients infected with the outbreak strain from sporadic infections with\nother enteroviruses.\nAseptic meningitis is a benign, self-limiting illness, and severe illness\nand death are uncommon. The treatment is symptomatic and most patients\nrecover in about 1 week. Enteroviruses typically are spread person to\nperson through the fecal-oral or oral-oral routes and through respiratory\ndroplets and fomites. No specific prevention or control measures are\navailable for nonpolio enteroviruses including E9 and E30. Adherence to\ngood hygienic practices, such as frequent and thorough hand washing\n(especially after diaper changes), disinfection of contaminated surfaces by\nhousehold cleaners (such as diluted bleach solution), and avoidance of\nshared utensils and drinking containers, are recommended to help interrupt\ntransmission.\nReferences\n----------\n(1) Khetsuriani N, Quiroz E, Holman R, Anderson L. Viral\nmeningitis-associated hospitalizations in the United States, 1988-1999.\nNeuroepidemiology (in press).\n(2)Rotbart HA. Viral meningitis. Semin Neurol 2000; 20: 277-92.\n(3) Uysal G, \u00d6zkaya E, G\u00fcven A. Echovirus 30 outbreak of aseptic meningitis\nin Turkey. Pediatr Infect Dis J 2000; 19: 490.\n(4)CDC. Outbreak of aseptic meningitis---Whiteside County, Illinois, 1995.\nMMWR 1995; 46: 221-4.\n(5)CDC. Summary of notifiable diseases, United States, 1994. MMWR 1995; 43:\n1-8.\n(6) Kilpatrick DR, Quay J, Pallansch MA, Oberste MS. Type-specific\ndetection of echovirus 30 isolates using degenerate reverse transcriptase\nPCR primers. J Clin Microbiol 2001; 39: 1299-302.\n(7) CDC. Nonpolio enterovirus surveillance -- United States, 1993-1996.\nMMWR 1997; 46: 748-50.\n(8) CDC. Enterovirus surveillance -- United States, 1997-1999. MMWR 2000;\n49: 913-6.\n(9) Strikas RA, Anderson LJ, Parker RA. Temporal and geographic patterns of\nisolates of nonpolio enterovirus in the United States, 1970--1983. J Infect\nDis 1986; 153: 346-51.\n(10) Julian KG, Mullins JA, Olin A, et al. Aseptic meningitis epidemic\nduring West Nile virus avian epizootic. Emerg Infect Dis (in press).\n(Acknowledgments: The findings in this report are based on data contributed\nby W Zakowicz, C Levy, MS, K Komatsu, MPH, A Bernstein, MS, G Briggs, MS, L\nErhart, MPH, R Schofield, M Fink, MS, Arizona Dept of Health Svcs. W\nNix, S Oberste, PhD, Div of Viral and Rickettsial Diseases, National Center\nfor Infectious Diseases, CDC.)\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Although most cases of enterovirus infections are asymptomatic or result in\nmild febrile illnesses, aseptic meningitis is the main diagnosis reported\nwith the current E9 and E30 activity in the US because patients with\nmeningitis are more likely to be tested for enteroviruses than those with\nless severe manifestations. In 2003, the enterovirus season appears to have\nstarted early, with the first isolations of E9 reported in January (in\nLouisiana), the first outbreaks of E9-associated aseptic meningitis\nreported in March, and the first isolations of E30 reported in April (in\nArizona). The\ninvestigation of an aseptic meningitis outbreak in an area of high WNV\nepizootic activity in 2001 indicated that enteroviruses were the leading\ncause of aseptic meningitis in this area, and no evidence of WNV infection\nwas detected (10). The enterovirus surveillance data were obtained from reports to the\nNational Enterovirus Surveillance System (NESS), a passive voluntary\nsurveillance system based on reporting by state public health and private\nlaboratories of enterovirus detections by serotype and basic demographic\ninformation, specimen type, and date of collection. SP Montgomery, DVM, Div\nof Vector-Borne Infectious Diseases; A LaMonte, MPH, N Khetsuriani, MD, M\nPallansch, PhD, Div of Viral and Rickettsial Diseases, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.)\n From 1 Jan to 7 Jul 2003, a total of 465 cases of aseptic meningitis\n(rate: 8.6 per 100 000 population) were reported to the Arizona Department\nof Health Services, compared with 104 cases (rate: 1.9) reported for the\nsame period in 2002. The increase in aseptic meningitis cases associated with high activity of\nE9 and E30 is consistent with the historic data; during the period 1988 to\n1999, peak years for viral meningitis hospitalizations in the United States\ncoincided with periods of high activity of either E9 or E30 (1). From 2 May to 17 Jul 2003, an outbreak of viral meningitis occurred in\nnorth central Idaho, with 38 cases from 3 adjacent counties reported to the\nIdaho Division of Health, compared with 4 cases reported statewide during\nthe previous year. As of 31 Jul 2003, a total of 130 cases of aseptic meningitis had\nbeen reported; E9 was isolated from 20 specimens (18 CSF and 2 throat\nwashings) from 8 different counties, and no other enteroviruses were\nidentified. During March 2003, several state public health departments noted increased\nreports of aseptic meningitis and, as of 7 Aug 2003, 7 states (Arizona,\nCalifornia, Georgia, Idaho, Oregon, South Carolina, and Texas) had reported\noutbreaks associated with either E9 or E30. Fri 15 Aug [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5232a1.htm>\n\nUnited States: outbreaks of aseptic meningitis associated with echoviruses\n9 and 30 and preliminary surveillance reports on enterovirus activity - 2003\n \nAseptic or viral meningitis is the commonest type of meningitis and is\nassociated with an estimated 26 000 to 42 000 hospital admissions each year\nin the United States (1). From 1970 to 2001, both E9 and E30 were among the 15 enteroviruses\nreported most commonly each year, accounting for 10.2 per cent and 8.2 per\ncent of all enterovirus isolates reported to CDC, respectively (CDC,\nunpublished data, 2003). Of the 148 patients, 82 (55 per cent) had evidence of enterovirus\ninfection by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or culture; E30 was identified\nfrom 29 (85%) of the 82 culture-positive cases, and E9 was identified from\nfour (12%) cases. \nAseptic meningitis is a central nervous system infection characterized by\nfever and meningeal symptoms with moderate, predominantly lymphocytic CSF\npleocytosis and the absence of bacterial pathogens in CSF. These\nserotype-specific primers are useful for rapid differentiation of cases in\npatients infected with the outbreak strain from sporadic infections with\nother enteroviruses. However, these enteroviruses have been relatively\nquiescent in recent years; E9 has not been the predominant enterovirus\nisolated from clinical specimens since 1995, and E30 has not been\nwidespread since 1998 (7,8). In 2003, E9 has been involved\npredominantly in the outbreaks in the East, and E30 has been linked\nexclusively with outbreaks in the West.\n E9 was isolated in 14 states, mainly in the East (for\nexample, Georgia, Florida, New Jersey, and South Carolina), and E30 was\nisolated in 10 states, mainly in the West (for example, Arizona,\nCalifornia, Colorado, and Texas). Other enterovirus serotypes reported most frequently include coxsackievirus\nB1 (29 [8 per cent] of all reports), echovirus 7 (10 [3 per cent]),\ncoxsackievirus A9 (10 [3 per cent]), enterovirus 71 (nine As of 5 Aug 2003, a total of 1753 cases of aseptic meningitis (rate: 8.0\nper 100 000 population) had been reported to the California Department of\nHealth Services (CDHS). During the period 10 Mar to 23 Jul\n2003, a total of 320 cases were reported from 50 of Georgia's 159 counties,\ncompared with 227 cases reported statewide during 2002. For this reason, diagnostic testing of specimens from\nyounger patients with aseptic meningitis should include testing for\nenteroviruses, even during a documented WNV outbreak (10). Two cases of aseptic meningitis reported\nsubsequently from the same area are under investigation by the North\nCentral District Health Department. Many aseptic\nmeningitis outbreaks occurring during the current enterovirus season\nreflect high levels of E9 and E30 activity. As of 7 Aug 2003, NESS had received reports of 365 enterovirus detections\nin 25 states; source specimens for these isolates were collected from 5 Jan\nto 30 Jul 2003. Specimens from 148\npatients with aseptic meningitis were submitted to CDHS for diagnostic\ntesting from 24 counties throughout the state. As of 31 Jul 2003, the Arizona State Health Laboratory had reported\n62 enterovirus isolates, the majority (66 per cent) from cerebrospinal\nfluid (CSF) specimens. Of the 32 patients for whom clinical information was\navailable, 17 were hospitalized with clinical signs and symptoms consistent\nwith aseptic meningitis. WNV has the same seasonal pattern as enteroviruses, and is also\nassociated with neurologic signs and symptoms of aseptic meningitis.\n This report summarizes the\nepidemiologic features of the aseptic meningitis outbreaks in 5 states\n The disease\noccurs both sporadically and in outbreaks, and >90 per cent of cases with\nan identified cause are associated with enteroviruses (2). (Arizona, California, Georgia, Idaho, and South Carolina) and provides an\noverview of enterovirus activity in the US during the period 1 Jan to 7 Aug\n2003. "2002-10-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "FUNGAL MENINGITIS, CONTAMINATED DRUG - USA: ALERT\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 1 Oct 2002 11:40:52 -0400\nFrom: John P Maher <jmaher@chesco.org>\nSource: North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services [edited]\n\nPatients being notified that injected medication may have been contaminated\n--------------------------------------------------\nIn the past 2 months 3 patients treated at pain clinics in North Carolina\nhave developed meningitis due to a contaminated batch of the drug\nmethylprednisolone. One died. A fourth case is under investigation.\nMethylprednisolone is a corticosteroid administered by injection to treat\njoint pain [by decreasing inflammation - Mod.LL]. All 3 of the patients who\ndeveloped meningitis had received an injection of the drug in their spine\nbetween April and July 2002. A total of 3 North Carolina facilities\nreceived shipments of the contaminated drug: FirstHealth Moore Regional\nHospital Pain Clinic in Pinehurst, Wayne Memorial Hospital in Goldsboro,\nand Johnston Pain Management in Jacksonville. (The drug supply was not used\nat FH Moore Regional Hospital but was limited only to the hospital's pain\nclinic.) The 3 facilities are contacting all of their patients who may have\nbeen treated with the drug, either through spinal injection or injection\ninto a joint or trigger point area.\nPhysicians investigating the cases traced the cause of the infections to\nthe drug, which was provided by a single supplier in South Carolina. The\ndrug was contaminated with _Wangiella dermatitidis_, a fungus. An\ninvestigation is being conducted to determine how the drug became contaminated.\nThe drug was shipped to clinics and hospitals in 5 states, including North\nCarolina. The drug from that manufacturer is no longer being used; that\npharmacy has issued a recall on 17 Sep 2002 and no longer manufactures the\nproduct.\nPatients were injected with the recalled drug as recently as 12 Sep 2002.\nOne of the cases developed meningitis 10 weeks after the injection, so it\nis possible that new cases may subsequently develop.\nPatients who may have been infected through an injection into other parts\nof their body, such as their knee or other joint, may experience symptoms\nof a localized infection: pain, redness, a joint that is hot to the touch,\nswelling, or difficulty with movement of the joint. Patients of any of the\n3 facilities who are experiencing any of these symptoms, or who suspect\nthat they may be developing an infection, should immediately contact their\nprimary care physician, the pain clinic where they were treated, or the\nnearest hospital emergency department.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Wangiella is a dematiaceous, cosmopolitan fungus that inhabits the soil\nand plant material. Wangiella may cause various infections in humans. The\nonly species included in the genus Wangiella is _Wangiella dermatitidis_.\nThe taxonomic position of this species is not fully consistent. While some\nauthorities classify it in the genus Wangiella as _Wangiella dermatitidis_,\nothers prefer to classify it in the genus Exophiala as _Exophiala\ndermatitidis_. _Wangiella dermatitidis_ is an occasional causative agent of\nphaeohyphomycosis. Subcutaneous phaehypomycosis is the commonest clinical\npicture. The infection develops after traumatic implantation of the fungus\nthrough the skin. _Wangiella dermatitidis_ is a neurotropic fungus. Central\nnervous system infections have been reported. It may also cause keratitis,\notitis, pneumonia, and endocarditis. Disseminated infections may develop\nparticularly in immunocompromised patients. _Wangiella dermatitidis_ may\ncause bovine abortion and still birth. - Mod.TG\n_Wangiella dermatitidis_ has been associated with various human infections,\nusually related to traumatic or iatrogenic wounds. Infections have been\nassociated with such risks as peritoneal dialysis, intravenous catheters,\nand keratoplasty. The source of the contamination in this incident is as\nyet unknown. The cases of meningitis reported, given the delayed onset,\nwere probably related to spread to the subarachnoid space from a\nparameningeal occult infection with the organism. - Mod.LL]\n................ll/tg/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Patients who may have been infected through an injection into other parts\nof their body, such as their knee or other joint, may experience symptoms\nof a localized infection: pain, redness, a joint that is hot to the touch,\nswelling, or difficulty with movement of the joint. While some\nauthorities classify it in the genus Wangiella as _Wangiella dermatitidis_,\nothers prefer to classify it in the genus Exophiala as _Exophiala\ndermatitidis_. The 3 facilities are contacting all of their patients who may have\nbeen treated with the drug, either through spinal injection or injection\ninto a joint or trigger point area. All 3 of the patients who\ndeveloped meningitis had received an injection of the drug in their spine\nbetween April and July 2002. A total of 3 North Carolina facilities\nreceived shipments of the contaminated drug: FirstHealth Moore Regional\n The drug from that manufacturer is no longer being used; that\npharmacy has issued a recall on 17 Sep 2002 and no longer manufactures the\nproduct.
