The cases of meningitis reported, given the delayed onset,\nwere probably related to spread to the subarachnoid space from a\nparameningeal occult infection with the organism. (The drug supply was not used\nat FH Moore Regional Hospital but was limited only to the hospital's pain\nclinic.) FUNGAL MENINGITIS, CONTAMINATED DRUG - USA: ALERT\n*************************************************\n Infections have been\nassociated with such risks as peritoneal dialysis, intravenous catheters,\nand keratoplasty. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n --\nProMED-mail\n< Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: Physicians investigating the cases traced the cause of the infections to\nthe drug, which was provided by a single supplier in South Carolina. One of the cases developed meningitis 10 weeks after the injection, so it\nis possible that new cases may subsequently develop.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2002-09-17 00:00:00", "2002-10-01 00:00:00", "2002-09-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North \n Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Goldsboro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jacksonville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pinehurst", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203035", "headline": "PRO> Fungal meningitis, contaminated drug - USA (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203035", "date": "2002-12-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "FUNGAL MENINGITIS, CONTAMINATED DRUG - USA (03)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 12 Dec 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR 13 Dec 2002 51(49);1109-1112 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5149a1.htm>\n\n_Exophiala_ Infection from Contaminated Injectable Steroids Prepared\nby a Compounding Pharmacy - United States, July - November 2002\n----------------------------------------\nIn the USA, pharmacists compound medications to meet unique patient\ndrug requirements or to prepare drug products that are not available\ncommercially (1). In September 2002, the North Carolina Division of\nPublic Health (NCDPH) was notified of 2 cases of meningitis caused by\na rare fungus in patients who had received epidural injections at\noutpatient pain management clinics. This report describes 5 cases of\nfungal infection associated with contaminated drugs prepared at a\ncompounding pharmacy. Clinicians should consider improperly\ncompounded medications as a possible source of infection in patients\nafter epidural or intra-articular injections.\nCase Reports\nCase 1. On 5 Jul 2002, a woman aged 77 years with chronic low back\npain was admitted to hospital A in North Carolina with a 4-day\nhistory of progressive diffuse headache, fever, chills, and malaise\nwith subsequent development of vertigo, nausea, and vomiting. She was\nfebrile (100.4 F [38.0 C]) and had slight nuchal rigidity. Analysis\nof cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) was consistent with meningitis: 979\nwhite blood cells (WBC)/mm3 (normal: <10 WBC/mm3) with 63 percent\nneutrophils, protein of 134 mg/dL (normal: 15-45 mg/dL), and glucose\nof 38 mg/dL (normal: 40-80 mg/dL).\nThe patient showed no improvement on antibacterial drugs, and a\nfollow-up CSF analysis on 18 Jul 18 2002 revealed yeast-like elements\non microscopic examination. The patient was treated with amphotericin\nB and transferred to hospital B in North Carolina. On 24 Jul 2002, a\nfungus cultured from CSF was identified as _Exophiala (Wangiella)\ndermatitidis_. Amphotericin B was discontinued, and voriconazole and\nflucytosine were started. The patient's condition continued to\ndeteriorate, and she died 51 days after hospitalization.\nThe patient had been treated at pain management clinic A in North\nCarolina and had received lumbar epidural injections with\nmethylprednisolone acetate 100 and 35 days before hospital admission.\nThe injectable methylprednisolone had been prepared by compounding\npharmacy A in South Carolina.\nCase 2. On 14 Aug 2002, a woman aged 61 years who was being treated\nfor chronic low back pain at pain management clinic A was admitted to\nhospital A after CSF obtained during a myelogram was consistent with\nmeningitis (820 WBC/mm3 with 52 percent neutrophils, protein of 108\nmg/dL, and glucose of 57 mg/dL). The patient had a 3-5 day history of\nmild headache, subjective fever, chills, sweats, and mild neck\nstiffness. The patient had received lumbar epidural injections at\npain management clinic A 84 and 34 days before hospital admission.\nThe injections contained methylprednisolone acetate prepared by\ncompounding pharmacy A. CSF grew yeast, later identified as _E.\ndermatitidis_, 27 days after collection. The patient was begun on\nintravenous voriconazole and later switched to oral voriconazole; as\nof 5 Dec (70 days into therapy), her condition had improved.\nAdditional cases: Clinicians from hospital A notified NCDPH of the 2\ncases of _E. dermatitidis_ meningitis; 3 additional cases have been\nidentified.\nCase 3 occurred in a woman aged 71 years who had _E. dermatitidis_\nmeningitis. She was admitted to hospital B in North Carolina on 8 Jul\n2002 and had received epidural methylprednisolone acetate injections\nat pain management clinic B 82, 55, and 35 days before\nhospitalization.\nCase 4 occurred in a woman aged 65 years who had _E. dermatitidis_\nmeningitis. She was admitted to hospital C in North Carolina on 8 Oct\n2002 and had received epidural methylprednisolone acetate injections\nat pain management clinic A 116 days before hospitalization.\nCase 5 occurred in a woman aged 52 years who had _E. dermatitidis_\nsacroiliitis. She was admitted to hospital D in North Carolina on 4\nNov 2002 and had received intra-articular methylprednisolone acetate\ninjections at pain management clinic B 103 and 152 days before\nhospitalization.\nInvestigation of Compounding Pharmacy A\nCompounding pharmacy A was the source of the methylprednisolone\nacetate administered to all 5 patients with _Exophiala_ infections.\nThe pharmacy had been supplying the compounded product to hospitals\nand pain management clinics in 5 states after a proprietary form of\nmethylprednisolone acetate injectable suspension (Depo Medrol\u00c6,\nPharmacia Corp., Peapack, New Jersey) became difficult to obtain from\nthe manufacturer. An investigation of compounding pharmacy A by the\nSouth Carolina Board of Pharmacy (SCBP) found improper performance of\nan autoclave with no written procedures for autoclave operation, no\ntesting for sterility or appropriate checking of quality indicators,\nand inadequate clean-room practices as outlined in the American\nSociety of Health-System Pharmacists (ASHP) guidance for\npharmacy-prepared sterile products (2).\nMicrobiologic culture at CDC and the Food and Drug Administration\n(FDA) of unopened vials from 3 separate lots of injectable\nmethylprednisolone obtained from compounding pharmacy A yielded _E.\ndermatitidis_. On 27 Sep 2002, SCBP ordered the pharmacy to halt\nfurther sale of compounded drug products. Injectable drugs had been\ndistributed to physicians, hospitals, clinics, and consumers in 11\nstates (Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana,\nMassachusetts, Mississippi, New Hampshire, North Carolina, South\nCarolina, and Virginia). FDA inspection of the compounding facility\nrevealed that the firm failed to have adequate controls to ensure\nnecessary sterility, including the absence of appropriate testing for\npotency and sterility before distribution. On 15 Nov 2002, based on\nthe lack of assurance that the pharmacy's products were sterile, FDA\nannounced a nationwide alert about all injectable drug products\nprepared by the pharmacy.\nAll sites that received injectable methylprednisolone prepared by\ncompounding pharmacy A have been contacted and have returned all\nunused products for testing. Treating clinicians were informed of the\ninvestigation of the adulterated product. In 2 states, patients who\nmight have received the product were sent letters directing them to\nseek medical attention if they developed symptoms, and laboratories\nwere instructed to notify state officials if they isolated _E.\ndermatitidis_ from clinical specimens.\n[MMWR] Editorial Note:\nAs of 5 Dec 2002, 5 cases of _Exophiala_ infection associated with\ninjectable medication from compounding pharmacy A had occurred. Cases\noccurred up to 152 days following an injection.\nPharmacy compounding is the process of combining drug ingredients to\nprepare medications that are not commercially available or to alter\ncommercially available medications to meet specific patient needs\nsuch as dye-free or liquid formulations (3). The practice of\ncompounding has been reported to be increasing, with an estimated 43\n000 compounded medications prepared daily in the United States (4,5).\nPharmacists traditionally have prepared medications to fulfill\nindividual prescription requests or manipulated reasonable quantities\nof human drugs on receipt of a valid prescription for an individually\nidentified patient from a licensed practitioner. Some compounding is\nlegal under state laws, and, when appropriate, FDA can exercise its\nenforcement discretion regarding new drugs and certain other\nrequirements of the federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (6).\nOn-site investigation of compounding pharmacy A by state and federal\nregulators identified several instances of nonadherence to sterile\ntechnique. Microbiologic cultures at CDC and FDA of\nmethylprednisolone from unopened vials prepared by compounding\npharmacy A yielded isolates of _E. dermatitidis_. This fungus caused\nthe death from meningitis in one patient, sacroiliitis in another,\nand meningitis in 3 other patients who had received either epidural\nor intra-articular injections of methylprednisolone compounded at\npharmacy A. Other recent clusters of infections associated with\nproducts prepared by compounding pharmacies include _Serratia_\nmeningitis from epidural injections of betamethasone in California\n(Contra Costa Health Services, unpublished data, 2002) and\n_Chryseomonas_ meningitis from epidural injections of\nmethylprednisolone in Michigan (CDC, unpublished data, 2002). These\nmeningitis clusters all occurred among patients who received epidural\ninjections for chronic pain management.\n_E. dermatitidis_ is a neurotropic, dark pigment-forming fungus found\nin soil and is an uncommon cause of human illness (7). Limited data\nare available on treatment; however, in vitro data suggest that\namphotericin B, itraconazole, terbinafine, and voriconazole might be\neffective (8). Isolates from 4 of the 5 infected persons reported\nwere tested in vitro and were susceptible to voriconazole,\nitraconazole, and amphotericin B. Voriconazole was chosen for\ntreating the 5 persons reported because of in vitro susceptibility\nresults and availability of an oral form of the drug.\nClinicians or laboratorians diagnosing any cases of Exophiala should\ndetermine whether the patient had received injections of\nmethylprednisolone in the last year. Although the implicated product\nhas been recalled, clinicians should be aware that cases might still\noccur because of the possible long incubation period of the fungal\ninfection. Patients with possible injection-associated Exophiala\ninfections should be reported to their state health department and to\nCDC, telephone 800-893-0485; such information should be exchanged\nrapidly with other state and local health departments. Clinicians\nshould consider the possibility of contaminated medication as a\nsource of infection in patients after epidural or intra-articular\ninjections. Compounding pharmacies should ensure that pharmacy staff\nare trained appropriately and that proper sterile technique is\nfollowed in accordance with existing standards from ASHP (2) and the\nUnited States Pharmacopeia (<http://www.usp.org>). FDA has outlined\nspecific activities that help distinguish the role of compounding\npharmacies from that of pharmaceutical manufacturing (4).\nSome health-system pharmacists might not realize that they are\npurchasing injectables prepared through compounding (1). Purchasers\nof pharmaceuticals should determine whether supplies are provided\nfrom a compounding pharmacy that is licensed in their state and that\nfollows appropriate measures to ensure that injectable products are\nfree of contamination. In most states, compounding pharmacies are not\nrequired to report adverse events associated with their products to\nstate or federal agencies. Such reporting to FDA is required for\npharmaceutical manufacturing companies. Health-care professionals and\ncompounding pharmacies are urged to report contaminated compounded\ndrug products or adverse events associated with compounded drug\nproducts to their state boards of pharmacy and health departments. To\nhelp prevent further cases, practitioners also are encouraged to\nsubmit such reports to FDA's MedWatch program by telephone at\n1-800-332-1088 or at\n<http://www.fda.gov/medwatch/report.htm>.\nReferences\n1.Young D. Outsourced compounding can be problematic: community\npharmacies linked to contaminated injectables. Available at\n<http://www.ashp.org/public/pubs/ajhp/current/12a-news_oursourced.pdf>.\n2.American Society of Health-System Pharmacists. ASHP guidelines on\nquality assurance for pharmacy-prepared sterile products. Am J Health\nSys Pharm\n2000; 57:1150-69.\n3.International Academy of Compounding Pharmacists. About\ncompounding. Available at:\n<http://www.iacprx.org/about_compounding/index.html>.\n4.Smith LK. Regulatory and operational issues of founding a\ncompounding pharmacy. International Journal of Pharmaceutical\nCompounding 2002;6:434-7.\n5.Professional Compounding Centers of America. History of\ncompounding. Available at\n<http://www.pccarx.com/about_comp.asp>.\n6.U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Compliance policy guidance for\nFood and Drug Administration staff and industry. Section 460-200,\npharmacy compounding. Available at\n<http://www.fda.gov/ora/compliance_ref/cpg/cpgdrg/cpg460-200.html>.\n7.Matsumoto T, Matsuda T, McGinnis MR, Ajello L. Clinical and\nmycological spectra of Wangiella dermatitidis infections. Mycoses\n1993;36:145-55.\n8.Meletiadis J, Meis JF, de Hoog GS, Verweij PE. In vitro\nsusceptibilities of 11 clinical isolates of Exophiala species to six\nantifungal drugs. Mycoses 2000;43:309-12.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "This fungus caused\nthe death from meningitis in one patient, sacroiliitis in another,\nand meningitis in 3 other patients who had received either epidural\nor intra-articular injections of methylprednisolone compounded at\npharmacy A. In 2 states, patients who\nmight have received the product were sent letters directing them to\nseek medical attention if they developed symptoms, and laboratories\nwere instructed to notify state officials if they isolated _E.\ndermatitidis_ from clinical specimens.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n On 14 Aug 2002, a woman aged 61 years who was being treated\nfor chronic low back pain at pain management clinic A was admitted to\nhospital A after CSF obtained during a myelogram was consistent with\nmeningitis (820 WBC/mm3 with 52 percent neutrophils, protein of 108\nmg/dL, and glucose of 57 mg/dL). The pharmacy had been supplying the compounded product to hospitals\nand pain management clinics in 5 states after a proprietary form of\nmethylprednisolone acetate injectable suspension (Depo Medrol\u00c6,\nPharmacia Corp., Peapack, New Jersey) became difficult to obtain from\nthe manufacturer. Purchasers\nof pharmaceuticals should determine whether supplies are provided\nfrom a compounding pharmacy that is licensed in their state and that\nfollows appropriate measures to ensure that injectable products are\nfree of contamination. Isolates from 4 of the 5 infected persons reported\nwere tested in vitro and were susceptible to voriconazole,\nitraconazole, and amphotericin B. Voriconazole was chosen for\ntreating the 5 persons reported because of in vitro susceptibility\nresults and availability of an oral form of the drug. Analysis\nof cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) was consistent with meningitis: 979\nwhite blood cells (WBC)/mm3 (normal: <10 WBC/mm3) with 63 percent\nneutrophils, protein of 134 mg/dL (normal: 15-45 mg/dL), and glucose\nof 38 mg/dL (normal: 40-80 mg/dL). To\nhelp prevent further cases, practitioners also are encouraged to\nsubmit such reports to FDA's MedWatch program by telephone at\n1-800-332-1088 or at\n<http://www.fda.gov/medwatch/report.htm>. Injectable drugs had been\ndistributed to physicians, hospitals, clinics, and consumers in 11\nstates (Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana,\nMassachusetts, Mississippi, New Hampshire, North Carolina, South\nCarolina, and Virginia). Health-care professionals and\ncompounding pharmacies are urged to report contaminated compounded\ndrug products or adverse events associated with compounded drug\nproducts to their state boards of pharmacy and health departments. She was admitted to hospital B in North Carolina on 8 Jul\n2002 and had received epidural methylprednisolone acetate injections\nat pain management clinic B 82, 55, and 35 days before\nhospitalization. She was admitted to hospital D in North Carolina on 4\nNov 2002 and had received intra-articular methylprednisolone acetate\ninjections at pain management clinic B 103 and 152 days before\nhospitalization. On 15 Nov 2002, based on\nthe lack of assurance that the pharmacy's products were sterile, FDA\nannounced a nationwide alert about all injectable drug products\nprepared by the pharmacy. In September 2002, the North Carolina Division of\nPublic Health (NCDPH) was notified of 2 cases of meningitis caused by\na rare fungus in patients who had received epidural injections at\noutpatient pain management clinics. Dec 2002 51(49);1109-1112 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5149a1.htm>\n\n_Exophiala_ Infection from Contaminated Injectable Steroids Prepared\nby a Compounding Pharmacy - United States, July - November 2002\n Pharmacy compounding is the process of combining drug ingredients to\nprepare medications that are not commercially available or to alter\ncommercially available medications to meet specific patient needs\nsuch as dye-free or liquid formulations (3). On 5 Jul 2002, a woman aged 77 years with chronic low back\npain was admitted to hospital A in North Carolina with a 4-day\nhistory of progressive diffuse headache, fever, chills, and malaise\nwith subsequent development of vertigo, nausea, and vomiting. \nMicrobiologic culture at CDC and the Food and Drug Administration\n(FDA) of unopened vials from 3 separate lots of injectable\nmethylprednisolone obtained from compounding pharmacy Compounding pharmacies should ensure that pharmacy staff\nare trained appropriately and that proper sterile technique is\nfollowed in accordance with existing standards from ASHP (2) and the\nUnited States Pharmacopeia (<http://www.usp.org>). Some compounding is\nlegal under state laws, and, when appropriate, FDA can exercise its\nenforcement discretion regarding new drugs and certain other\nrequirements of the federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (6). Patients with possible injection-associated Exophiala\ninfections should be reported to their state health department and to\nCDC, telephone 800-893-0485; such information should be exchanged\nrapidly with other state and local health departments. Pharmacists traditionally have prepared medications to fulfill\nindividual prescription requests or manipulated reasonable quantities\nof human drugs on receipt of a valid prescription for an individually\nidentified patient from a licensed practitioner. Clinicians\nshould consider the possibility of contaminated medication as a\nsource of infection in patients after epidural or intra-articular\ninjections. FDA inspection of the compounding facility\nrevealed that the firm failed to have adequate controls to ensure\nnecessary sterility, including the absence of appropriate testing for\npotency and sterility before distribution. Although the implicated product\nhas been recalled, clinicians should be aware that cases might still\noccur because of the possible long incubation period of the fungal\ninfection. Limited data\nare available on treatment; however, in vitro data suggest that\namphotericin B, itraconazole, terbinafine, and voriconazole might be\neffective (8). She was admitted to hospital C in North Carolina on 8 Oct\n2002 and had received epidural methylprednisolone acetate injections\nat pain management clinic A 116 days before hospitalization. The injections contained methylprednisolone acetate prepared by\ncompounding pharmacy A. CSF grew yeast, later identified as _E.\ndermatitidis_, 27 days after collection. This report describes 5 cases of\nfungal infection associated with contaminated drugs prepared at a\ncompounding pharmacy. Additional cases: Clinicians from hospital A notified NCDPH of the 2\ncases of _E. dermatitidis_ meningitis; 3 additional cases have been\nidentified. The injectable methylprednisolone had been prepared by compounding\npharmacy A in South Carolina.\n In most states, compounding pharmacies are not\nrequired to report adverse events associated with their products to\nstate or federal agencies. Clinicians should consider improperly\ncompounded medications as a possible source of infection in patients\nafter epidural or intra-articular injections.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2002-09-27 00:00:00", "2002-11-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-08-14 00:00:00", "2002-12-26 00:00:00", "2002-12-05 00:00:00", "2055-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-07-24 00:00:00", "2002-07-05 00:00:00", "2002-09-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Peapack", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "South \n Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Exophiala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Louisiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mississippi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Hampshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kentucky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202880", "headline": "PRO> Fungal meningitis, contaminated drug - USA: alert (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202880", "date": "2002-11-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "FUNGAL MENINGITIS, CONTAMINATED DRUG - USA: ALERT (02)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 16 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AP Online 16 Nov 2002 09:36 EST (edited)\n\nFDA issues warning on injected drugs\n------------------------------------\nWASHINGTON (AP): Pain clinics and other health facilities should\nimmediately quit using all injectable drugs made by a South Carolina\npharmacy after one of that company's drugs was linked to deadly meningitis,\nthe [United States] government said on Friday, 15 Nov 2002.\nThe Food and Drug Administration () issued a nationwide alert warning\nhealth workers that injectable antibiotics, pain medications and hormones\nmade by Urgent Care Pharmacy of Spartanburg, SC, may be dangerous. Urgent\nCare recalled one of its injectable drugs, the synthetic corticosteroid\nmethylprednisolone, in September 2002 after it was linked to 4 cases of\nmeningitis caused by a rare fungus [_Wangiella dematitidis_ - Mod.LL]. One\nof the patients died.\nInjected drugs must be sterile, or they can cause deadly infections in\ntheir users. The FDA said its inspections found the Spartanburg pharmacy\nill-equipped to ensure sterility in any of the injected drugs it makes, and\nUrgent Care wasn't properly testing the drugs for sterility before shipping\nthem to pain clinics and other customers. Urgent Care refused to recall any\nother drugs, the FDA said. So the government told health workers on Friday\nto avoid using any of the following injected drugs made by Urgent Care:\nbaclofen, betamethasone, Bimix 30:1, clonidine, estradiol, hydromorphone,\nfentanyl, morphine, papaverine, Super Trimix, mesylate/prostaglandin, and\ntestosterone.\nThe FDA said the drugs were sold in Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana,\nKentucky, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Mississippi, New Hampshire, North\nCarolina, South Carolina, and Virginia. Also, the South Carolina pharmacy\nboard recently ordered a halt to further sales by Urgent Care, the FDA said.\nUrgent Care is not a pharmaceutical company. Pharmaceutical companies\nmanufacture injected drugs under conditions designed to guarantee\nsterility. Instead, Urgent Care 'compounded' drugs, brewing prescription\nmedicines to fit a doctor or clinic's special order instead of simply\ndispensing a drug made by a pharmaceutical company. Compounding is a common\npractice -- pharmacists routinely flavor medicines for children, for\nexample, or remove an allergy-causing ingredient from common drug brands.\nBut the FDA is investigating whether Urgent Care compounded drugs legally.\n******\n[2]\nDate November 15, 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA Talk Paper T02-44\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/ANSWERS/2002/ANS01171.html>\n\nNationwide alert on injectable drugs prepared by Urgent Care Pharmacy\n-------------------------------------------------------\nThe Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is announcing a nationwide alert\nconcerning all injectable drugs prepared by Urgent Care Pharmacy of\nSpartanburg, South Carolina, based on the lack of assurance that their\nproducts are sterile. Non-sterility of injectable products can represent a\nserious hazard to health that could lead to life-threatening injuries and\ndeath. FDA inspection of Urgent Care's facility revealed the firm failed to\nhave adequate controls to ensure necessary sterility, including the absence\nof appropriate testing for potency and sterility prior to distribution.\nOn September 16, 2002, Urgent Care recalled all lots of its injectable\nmethylprednisolone acetate based on reports of 4 patients who developed a\nrare fungal (wangiella) meningitis after use of their product. These\npatients were treated at 3 different North Carolina hospitals/clinics.\nSpinal fluid from all of these patients tested positive for a fungus\nconsistent with that found in the Urgent Care product analyzed by both the\nFDA and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). One patient later\ndied despite antifungal therapy.\nUrgent Care has refused to voluntarily recall any other injectable products\nthey prepared and refused to provide FDA with a complete list of products\nthey distributed. FDA is working to identify the recipients of these\nproducts so that the agency can directly alert them to the serious risks\ninvolved. FDA is continuing to work with CDC, along with officials from\nboth North Carolina and South Carolina, and will take whatever additional\naction is needed.\nIn the meantime, the South Carolina Board of Pharmacy has issued a Cease\nand Desist order to halt further sale of products from Urgent Care. At the\npresent time, based on limited information, FDA is aware that Urgent Care\nhas distributed the following injectable drugs to physicians, hospitals,\nclinics and consumers in Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky,\nLouisiana, Massachusetts, Mississippi, New Hampshire, North Carolina, South\nCarolina and Virginia:\nBaclofen\nBetamethasone\nBimix 30:1 (phentolamine mesylate/papaverine)\nClonidine\nEstradiol\nHydromorphone HCl\nFentanyl\nMethylprednisole acetate\nMorphine Sulfate/Bupivacaine\nPapaverine HCl\nSuper Trimix (papaverine HCl/phentolamine mesylate/prostaglandin)\nTestosterone cypionate\nTestosterone/Estradiol\nUrgent Care injectables are labeled as URGENT CARE PHARMACY 2500 WINCHESTER\nPLACE , STE. 106, SPARTANBURG, SC 29301, 800-692-8982. Consumers,\nphysicians, and health care workers are urged to examine their drug\nsupplies for any Urgent Care injectable products and immediately\ndiscontinue their use. Users should also notify FDA of any complaints or\nproblems associated with these products.\nThese reports may be made to MedWatch, the FDA's voluntary reporting\nprogram, by telephone at 1-800-FDA-1088 or online at\n<http://www.fda.gov/medwatch/how.htm>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "Clonidine\nEstradiol\nHydromorphone HCl\nFentanyl\nMethylprednisole acetate\nMorphine Sulfate/Bupivacaine\nPapaverine HCl\n At the\npresent time, based on limited information, FDA is aware that Urgent Care\nhas distributed the following injectable drugs to physicians, hospitals,\nclinics and consumers in Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky,\nLouisiana, Massachusetts, Mississippi, New Hampshire, North Carolina, South\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nWASHINGTON (AP): Pain clinics and other health facilities should\nimmediately quit using all injectable drugs made by a South Carolina\npharmacy after one of that company's drugs was linked to deadly meningitis,\nthe [United States] government said on Friday, 15 Nov 2002. \nThe Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is announcing a nationwide alert\nconcerning all injectable drugs prepared by Urgent Care Pharmacy of\nSpartanburg, South Carolina, based on the lack of assurance that their\nproducts are sterile. Carolina and Virginia:\nBaclofen\nBetamethasone\nBimix 30:1 (phentolamine mesylate/papaverine)\n The FDA said its inspections found the Spartanburg pharmacy\nill-equipped to ensure sterility in any of the injected drugs it makes, and\nUrgent Care wasn't properly testing the drugs for sterility before shipping\nthem to pain clinics and other customers. USA ex Jamaica", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200756", "date": "2001-10-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "EOSINOPHILIC MENINGITIS - USA EX JAMAICA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2201943", "headline": "PRO> Meningitis, viral - USA (Texas) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201943", "date": "2002-06-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, VIRAL - USA (TEXAS) (02)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 5 Jun 2002\nFrom: Dr. S. Shafran <sshafran@uah.ualberta.ca>\n\nRe: Intra-family Transmission\n-----------------------------\n[Re: Meningitis, viral - USA (Texas) 20020605.4410:\n>Dr. Robert Lozano, a Brownsville neurologist ... said. 'Usually, whole\nfamilies don't get it' <\nI disagree. We have experienced several enteroviral epidemics, and we always\nsaw several examples of transmission within families in epidemic years. This\nshould surely be expected with any pathogen with a fecal-oral transmission\npattern. (This comment assumes that the epidemic is due to enterovirus --\nand in fact makes it more likely -- although it is noted that the etiology\nhas not yet been established).\n--\nStephen D. Shafran, MD\nProfessor of Medicine\nDivision of Infectious Diseases\nUniversity of Alberta\n2E4.16 Walter C. Dominica 19970613.1245\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (02) 19970614.1250\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (03) 19970616.1263\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (04) 19970617.1276\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (05) 19970619.1306]\nDate: Thu, 28 Feb 2002 11:56:49 -0500\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: EID [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/vol8no3/01-0316.htm>\n\nEosinophilic meningitis in tourists - Jamaica\n------------------------------------------------\n[A recent study reported that] a 2000 outbreak in tourists visiting\nJamaica of eosinophilic meningitis [was] due to _Angiostrongylus\ncantonensis_ [and that the parasite was recently] found in rats and\nsnails on the island. Overall, 22 percent (24/109) of rats harboured\nadult worms, and 8 percent (4/48) of snails harboured _A.\ncantonensis_ larvae. This report is the first of enzootic _A.\ncantonensis_ infection in Jamaica, providing evidence that this\nparasite is likely to cause human cases of eosinophilic meningitis.\nThe paper describe how 12 persons in a group of 23 U.S. tourists who\nvisited Jamaica for a week developed eosinophilic meningitis within\n6-30 days (median 11) of returning home. Though 9 persons required\nhospitalisation, there were no deaths. There was serologic evidence\nof exposure to _A. cantonensis_ in 8 persons who had eaten salad at\nthe same restaurant, a common exposure that might account for all\ncases.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The study has been published in Emerging Infectious Diseases and\ndescribes the study of the animal reservoir of Angiostrongyliasis in\nJamaica. Eating uncooked snails, prawns, crabs or vegetables\ntransmits Angiostrongyliasis. The natural reservoir is rodents. -\nMod.EP]\n................................mpp/ep/mhj /pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Viral meningitis\nis a less severe form of meningitis than bacterial, which has a higher\nmortality rate and more severe symptoms. The viral form is rarely fatal\nfor people with normal immune systems, according to the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention.\n'It's an unusual amount that we're seeing at the hospital right now,'\nsaid Dr. Robert Lozano, a Brownsville neurologist. 'We're a little\nconcerned about it. I've been practicing here 10 years, and I have never\nseen a peak like this.' One of the unusual features of the cases is that\nthey involve 2 sets of family members, Lozano said. 'Usually, whole\nfamilies don't get it,' Lozano said. Lozano said the patients are expected\nto recover fully.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The diagnosis does not identify a specific virus as the etiologic agent.\nVarious enteroviruses have been associated with meningitis in the past,\nbut other viruses are not excluded. The early timing of this outbreak\n(enteroviruses tend to peak in their activity in the late summer and early\nfall in the USA) and the concern raised by the neurologist starts one to\nthink of some other alternative diagnoses. For example: Why does\nWest Nile virus spring into my mind (a left-field diagnosis)? (In the\nWNV outbreaks in Romania in recent years have presented as virla\nmeningitis -- see refs below. - Mod.JW) While WNV has not been\nreported in Texas as yet, it doesn't mean it hasn't managed to 'sneak in\nthe back door'. And there are other encephalitis viruses that have been\nactive in neighboring states (Eastern equine encephalitis and WNV\nhave been active in Louisiana). It's curious that there have been 'sets\nof family members' involved as well, because the 'usual suspects' do\nnot tend to cluster in families. More information on this outbreak\nwould be very much appreciated. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [edited]\n<http://www.austin360.com/statesman/editions/today/metro_state_13.ht\nml>\n\nSo far 5 patients at Valley Regional Medical Center have been\ndiagnosed with viral meningitis after they were admitted to the hospital\nlast week complaining of severe headaches and fever. The early timing of this outbreak\n(enteroviruses tend to peak in their activity in the late summer and early\nfall in the USA) and the concern raised by the neurologist starts one to\nthink of some other alternative diagnoses. Viral meningitis\nis a less severe form of meningitis than bacterial, which has a higher\nmortality rate and more severe symptoms. It's curious that there have been 'sets\nof family members' involved as well, because the 'usual suspects' do\nnot tend to cluster in families. (In the\nWNV outbreaks in Romania in recent years have presented as virla\nmeningitis -- see refs below. And there are other encephalitis viruses that have been\nactive in neighboring states (Eastern equine encephalitis and WNV\nhave been active in Louisiana). The viral form is rarely fatal\nfor people with normal immune systems, according to the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention. Adeel <aadeel@ksu.edu.sa>\nSource: Panafrican News Agency 20 Jan 2001 [edited]\n\n70 Cases of Meningitis Reported\n---------------------------------------\nThe Sudanese ministry of health has reported that 70 cases of\n[meningococcal] meningitis have been diagnosed in 4 of the country's\nstates.\nThe ministry's under-secretary Bashir Mukhtar said Saturday that the\ninfections were reported in the states of Gezira in central Sudan, Darfur\nin the West and Gedarif and the Red Sea states in the East. [These are all\nin the more desert 'north' as compared to the more tropical 'south' of the\ncountry. - Mod.JW].\n'We are very alarmed over the outbreak of meningitis during the winter\nseason. Meningitis is usually a summer disease in Sudan,' he said. 'We\nhave a strategic stock of meningitis vaccines to deal with the situation\nand control the disease,' Mukhtar said. He said vaccination campaigns\nwould be launched in areas where meningitis had broken out.\n--\nProf. Ahmed A. Canada (Alberta)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2199275", "date": "2001-01-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGOCOCCAL MENINGITIS - CANADA (ALBERTA)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2200612", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, viral - Germany", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200612", "date": "2001-09-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, VIRAL - GERMANY\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2199245", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Canada (Alberta): RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2199245", "date": "2001-01-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - CANADA (ALBERTA): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nDate: 12 Jan 2001\nSource: Edmunton Sun [edited]\n<http://www.canoe.ca/EdmontonNews/es.es-01-12-0003.html>\n\nHealth Canada Tags Edmonton Area the Meningitis Capital of the Nation\n-----------------------------------------------\nEdmonton is the meningitis capital of the nation, according to Health\nCanada. The Capital Health Region's 50 cases of meningitis since Dec 1999\n-- 3 fatal -- make an 'outbreak' for an urban area the size of Edmonton's,\nsaid Theresa Tam, medical epidemiologist for Health Canada.\n'Nationally the rate for meningitis is one per 100 000 people, so for a\ncity like Edmonton you would expect to see maybe 8 cases a year,' Tam\nsaid. '50 is a much higher than usual number. That is about 6 cases per\n100 000 people in a year when the national average was 0.7 per 100\n000. That isn't a cluster of the disease -- it's an outbreak.'\nLast November, Capital Health immunized 59 600 children and young adults\nwith meningitis vaccines to try to curb the disease. 'The campaign was\nbecause the numbers were so much higher than we would normally see,' Tam said.\nDr. Vinod Dhawan, chief of infectious diseases at the Martin Luther King\nJr. General Hospital in Los Angeles, said 6 meningitis cases per 100 000\npeople is cause for concern. 'That seems to be very high . . . we haven't\nseem numbers like that in a while,' Dhawan said.\nAlthough none of the Capital Health Region's cases were connected by a\nneighbourhood or school, the disease was being spread from person to person\nthroughout the region, Tam said. 'It was being spread around some way and\nit's not a bacterium that is spread easily.' In 1992 there were cluster\noutbreaks in Ottawa and Montreal that sparked vaccination campaigns, but\nthe numbers weren't as bad as in Edmonton over the last year, Tam added.\nDr. Gerry Predy, medical officer of health for the Capital Health Region,\nsays he hopes we've seen the last of the outbreak here. 'We had an unusual\nnumber of cases for many months and then the numbers dropped off in the\nsummer and picked right back up again,' Predy said. 'We are hoping to see\nthe end of it in the next few weeks.'\nTests done on Edmonton's meningitis cases show there was a unique strain of\nmeningitis being spread throughout the city, he said. 'The organism\ncirculating here was different than we have seen before. The subtle\ngenetic changes may have led to the situation we had last year.' Local\nmeningitis experts are conducting tests on the Edmonton strain of disease.\n'Meningitis is something we will never get rid of but hopefully the test\nresult will be of value fighting the disease.'\n[Byline: Kevin Connor]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail would like to receive more information on the outbreak. More\nepidemiologic information on the cases (age and vaccination history) and\nmore laboratory information on the strain of bacteria involved would be of\ninterest and help in interpreting the significance of this reported\noutbreak. - Mod.MPP]\n..........................mpp/pg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n More\nepidemiologic information on the cases (age and vaccination history) and\nmore laboratory information on the strain of bacteria involved would be of\ninterest and help in interpreting the significance of this reported\noutbreak. - Mod. \nDr. Vinod Dhawan, chief of infectious diseases at the Martin Luther King\nJr. General Hospital in Los Angeles, said 6 meningitis cases per 100 000\npeople is cause for concern. ' [Byline: Kevin Connor]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< The Capital Health Region's 50 cases of meningitis since Dec 1999\n-- 3 fatal -- make an 'outbreak' for an urban area the size of Edmonton's,\nsaid Theresa Tam, medical epidemiologist for Health Canada. Nationally the rate for meningitis is one per 100 000 people, so for a\ncity like Edmonton you would expect to see maybe 8 cases a year,' Tam\nsaid. That is about 6 cases per\n100 000 people in a year when the national average was 0.7 per 100\n000. Although none of the Capital Health Region's cases were connected by a\nneighbourhood or school, the disease was being spread from person to person\nthroughout the region, Tam said. ' We had an unusual\nnumber of cases for many months and then the numbers dropped off in the\nsummer and picked right back up again,' Predy said. ' In 1992 there were cluster\noutbreaks in Ottawa and Montreal that sparked vaccination campaigns, but\nthe numbers weren't as bad as in Edmonton over the last year, Tam added. Source: Edmunton Sun [edited]\n<http://www.canoe.ca/EdmontonNews/es.es-01-12-0003.html>\n\nHealth Canada Tags Edmonton Area the Meningitis Capital of the Nation\n MENINGITIS - CANADA (ALBERTA): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************\n \nEdmonton is the meningitis capital of the nation, according to Health\nCanada. Robertson <grobertson@rcn.com>\nSource: Nando Times, 22 Jul 2000 [edited]\n<http://www.nandotimes.com>\n\nMeningitis kills 13 newborns in Guatemala hospital\n--------------------------------------------------\nA meningitis outbreak at a hospital in Guatemala's second largest city has\nkilled 13 newborns and left 5 others seriously ill, officials said Saturday.\nThe infants died over the past week after officials detected the outbreak\nin the maternity ward at Quetzaltenango's largest public hospital. The 5\nothers were being treated with antibiotics and were expected to recover.\nMeningitis attacks the spine and brain. The germ enters the bloodstream\nthrough contact with the nose or throat discharges of an infected person.\nIf left untreated, it can kill a person within a few weeks. [Meningococcal\ndisease would be expected to have a more fulminant presentation than\nimplied by this description. - Mods.MPP/ES]\nOfficials think the disease was brought in by one of the mothers in the\nward in early July, the hospital's director of internal medicine, Rene\nAceituno, said.\nHospital staff moved all the newborns to a different area and believe the\noutbreak now is under control. Workers, wearing masks, removed sheets,\nclothing, furniture and ceiling tiles from the infected area Friday.\nThe outbreak has caused a panic in this largely Indian community some 125\nmiles southwest of Guatemala City. Local newspapers reported overcrowding\nin a half dozen other Quetzaltenango-area hospitals in the wake of the\noutbreak.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This and other articles were also submitted by ProMED-mail Moderator\nMarjorie Pollack, and by H. Greece (Thessaloniki)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2197135", "date": "2000-01-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, VIRAL? - GREECE (THESSALONIKI)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nDate: Fri, 14 Jan 2000 07:08:21 PST\nFrom: M. Cosgriff <mcosgriff@hotmail.com>\nSource: Athens News 14 Jan 2000 [edited]\n\nWoman dies mysterious death at Thessaloniki clinic, children hospitalised\n------------------------------------------\nThe husband and two children of a 30-year-old woman, who died at a\nThessaloniki clinic on Wednesday afternoon after being brought in with flu\nsymptoms, have been hospitalised as a precaution. Thessaloniki coroner\nDimitris Psaroulis has not yet determined the cause of death but believes\nit was brought on by a virus. 'I believe [the cause of death] is a viral\ninfection,' he said. 'I don't know where it originated from,' he added,\nnoting that he would have to wait for the laboratory test results to\nascertain the exact cause.\nReports stated yesterday that the woman was transferred to the Panagia\nclinic in Thessaloniki 3 days after developing flu symptoms. Efthymios\nSofianos, head of the\nambulance service (EKAV) in Thessaloniki, told reporters that when the\nhusband called them, his wife's symptoms had not caused them any particular\nconcern as they seemed to be associated with the common cold. 'He spoke of\na temperature and weakness then 3 days later told us she was also\nvomiting,' said Sofianos.\nWhen she arrived at Panagia, Aristidis Grammatikopoulos, the clinic's chief\nadministrator, said that the wife was unable to breathe. He said that she\nwas taken to intensive care but died 5 hours later. Her husband, 4-year-old\nson and 7-year-old daughter were hospitalised yesterday morning at the\nThessaloniki Hospital for Infectious Diseases after developing a high fever\nand headaches.\nPsaroulis is also investigating the deaths of another woman & a man who\nalso succumbed to a viral infection in Thessaloniki this week. He said that\nthe deaths could have been caused by meningitis though he did not exclude\nthe possibility of influenza.\nA 20-year-old man brought to hospital in Thessaloniki from the northern\nGreek town of Kozani was reported to have died from meningitis yesterday,\nwhile another 2 cases of this viral infection were reported on the Ionian\nisland of Corfu. A 16-year-old boy and 17-year-old girl diagnosed with the\ndisease were transferred to a Ioannina hospital and to Athens' Evangelismos\nhospital respectively, where doctors are hopeful they will recover.\nScores of individuals flocked to Sotiria hospital complaining of breathing\ndifficulties brought on by colds and viral infections. They were\nhospitalised but due to the increased demand on the facility, were forced\nto sleep in the hospital's corridors on camp beds.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n[In the midst of the current influenza epidemic in Greece some sudden\ndeaths from influenza are to be expected, but the medica authorities\napparently suspect these cases to be viral meningitis. Since it is not the\nmosquito season there, West Nile viral meningitis can be ruled out. - Mod.JW]\n.......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ' A 20-year-old man brought to hospital in Thessaloniki from the northern\nGreek town of Kozani was reported to have died from meningitis yesterday,\nwhile another 2 cases of this viral infection were reported on the Ionian\nisland of Corfu. Her husband, 4-year-old\nson and 7-year-old daughter were hospitalised yesterday morning at the\nThessaloniki Hospital for Infectious Diseases after developing a high fever\nand headaches. A 16-year-old boy and 17-year-old girl diagnosed with the\ndisease were transferred to a Ioannina hospital and to Athens' Evangelismos\nhospital respectively, where doctors are hopeful they will recover. The husband and two children of a 30-year-old woman, who died at a\nThessaloniki clinic on Wednesday afternoon after being brought in with flu\nsymptoms, have been hospitalised as a precaution. [In the midst of the current influenza epidemic in Greece some sudden\ndeaths from influenza are to be expected, but the medica authorities\napparently suspect these cases to be viral meningitis. He said that\nthe deaths could have been caused by meningitis though he did not exclude\nthe possibility of influenza. He spoke of\na temperature and weakness then 3 days later told us she was also\nvomiting,' said Sofianos. They were\nhospitalised but due to the increased demand on the facility, were forced\nto sleep in the hospital's corridors on camp beds. \nProMED-mail\ne-mail: 'I don't know where it originated from,' he added,\nnoting that he would have to wait for the laboratory test results to\nascertain the exact cause. As of 5 Jan 2000, 30 cases and 4 deaths had been\nreported (case-fatality rate, 13.3%).\nThe National Epidemiology Centre in Budapest has confirmed _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_ groups B and C.\nProtection and prevention measures include chemoprophylaxis of close\ncontacts with rifampicin and immunization (with bivalent A/C serogroup\nvaccine).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Note that there is no approved vaccine against group B - Mod.JW]\n............................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Hungary: alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2197092", "date": "2000-01-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - HUNGARY: ALERT\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nDate: Wed, 5 Jan 2000 20:09:13 -0700\nFrom: 'Rick Lehtinen' <lehtinenfamily@home.com>\nSource: Agence France Presse 4 Jan 2000 [edited]\n\nHungary Fears Meningitis Epidemic As Fourth Person Dies\n---------------------------------------------\nHungary is facing a meningitis epidemic after a fourth person died\nof the disease in Budapest, Hungarian medical authorities said\nTuesday.\nSince December, 32 people have been hospitalized with the killer\nillness, more than the average number for a whole year, said Ilona\nStraub, head of the national epidemology center.\n'On the basis of the number of people who are sick ... we can\nqualify it as an epidemic,' she said, adding that usually 20-40\npeople contract the disease each year.\nThe fatalities so far were a 50-year-old Budapest woman, a 4-year-\nold child in eastern Hungary and a teenager in the central town of\nKecskemet. The latest victim was a one-year-old child in Budapest.\nA 10-year-old girl in the eastern Debrecen was in critical condition\nTuesday, while a Budapest conscript hospitalized Sunday was in\n'satisfactory' condition, Straub said.\nThe outbreak started in army barracks in Szabadszallas and\nKecskemet, in central Hungary. Health authorities said they had\nsince vaccinated the entire force of 2600 troops.\nThey planned to vaccinate troops in barracks in Tapolca and\nSzombathely as soon as vaccines arrived in Hungary, chief army\ndoctor Laszlo Sved said.\n'This virus attacks young people who live in a closed community\nand are under increased physical pressure,' said doctor Ilona\nMolnar. Doctors have warned patients to seek early treatment as\nthis type of meningitis starts with symptoms of a common cold but\ncan be deadly within 24 hours if not treated.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail slipped up on this one. However, this\ndisease is not very rare and it is only possible to find out where the\nboy caught it after results of a test currently made at the National\nPublic Health Institute are known.\nThe boy was treated in the hospital for 10 days, and his illness had\na mild form, involving headache and fever. He received basically\nsymptomatic treatment.\nGyimesi added that the symptoms make it likely that the illness had\nbeen caused by an epidemic because bacterial meningitis usually\nhas more severe symptoms.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[It sounds, from the last sentence, as though the hospital did not\nattempt basic bacterial culture - Mod.JW]\n.................................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Sudanese authorities have closed off\nthree towns in western Sudan after meningitis killed 21 people, the\nofficial news agency said Thursday [7 Jan 1999].\nThe disease has infected 126 other people in the towns of\nel-Fasher, Kutum and Kebkabiya, about 500 miles west of the\ncapital, Khartoum, the Sudan News Agency said.\nThe North Darfur provincial authorities declared a state of\nemergency around the towns to contain the outbreak, closing schools\nand preventing traffic from leaving and entering the area, the\nagency said.\nThe Health Ministry has mobilized medical teams to care for\nthose inflected by the disease, which inflames the membranes of the\nbrain and the spinal cord.\nOutbreaks of meningitis occur occasionally in Sudan during the summer.\nIt is not known what has caused this outbreak during the winter.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Meningitis in the meningitis belt of Africa is seasonal & usually\ncaused by meningococcal infection. REP.\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Thu, 17 Dec 1998 04:01:54 +0000\nFrom: Pierre Bigras <pbigras@netrover.com>\n\nKAMPALA 15 Dec 1998 (AFP) Uganda on Tuesday [sic] warned its citizens\nliving along the border with the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) about a\nmeningitis outbreak that has killed 157 people in Burundi and the DRC.\nThe epidemic poses a serious threat to Ugandans living in areas bordering\non the DRC and on Rwanda, according to a statement released by health\nministry official Kihumuro Apuuli. 'There exists treatment and cure for the\ndisease by use of some commonly available drugs in health units,' the\nstatement said, adding that the health ministry was ready to take up the\nchallenge if the disease breaks out in the border districts.\n[As a comment I would add that because of the present conflict in the DRC\nthere is at the moment a heightened level of traffic between Uganda and the\nDRC, both in terms of troop movements and commercial trucking operations.\nThis could make for rapid spread of the disease both in Uganda and the DRC.\n- PB]\n--\nPierre Bigras\ne-mail: pbigras@netrover.com\n..................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (Iowa)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194066", "date": "1998-08-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "ASEPTIC MENINGITIS - USA (IOWA)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2194429", "headline": "PRO> Meningitis, meningococcal: surveillance - Australia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194429", "date": "1998-10-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL: SURVEILLANCE - AUSTRALIA\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Mon, 12 Oct 1998 10:06:16 -0700\nSource: CDI (Australia), Vol. 22 / No. 10, 1 Oct 1998\nVia: Dr. James Chin, CDPC-mail <jchin@cdpc.com>\n\nAnnual report of the Australian Meningococcal Surveillance Programme, 1997\n- The Australian Meningococcal Surveillance Programme. Commun Dis Itell\n1998;22:205-211.\nAbstract: The National _Neisseria_ Network (NNN) has undertaken\nmeningococcal isolate surveillance by means of a collaborative laboratory\nbased initiative since 1994. The phenotype (serogroup, serotype and\nserosubtype) and antibiotic susceptibility of 343 isolates of _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_ from invasive cases of meningococcal disease were determined\nin 1997. Ninety six percent of the invasive isolates were serogroup B or C.\nSerogroup B strains predominated in all States and Territories and were\nisolated from sporadic cases of invasive disease. Phenotypes B:4:P1.4 and\nB:15:P1.7 were prominent.\nSerogroup C isolates were most often encountered in New South Wales,\nespecially in adolescents and young adults, and in that State were nearly\nas numerous as serogroup B strains. C:2a:P1.5 was the most frequently\nencountered phenotype and C:2b:P1.2 strains were also distributed widely. A\nnumber of clusters of cases of serogroup C disease were noted, mainly with\nphenotype C:2a:P1.5. About three-quarters of all isolates showed decreased\nsusceptibility to the penicillin group of antibiotics (MIC 0.06 to 0.5\nmg/L). Three isolates showed reduced susceptibility to rifampicin and one\nwas chloramphenicol resistant.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (Rhode Island) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192852", "date": "1998-03-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (RHODE ISLAND) (05)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2192849", "headline": "PRO> Meningitis, meningococcal: venereal transmission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192849", "date": "1998-03-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL: VENEREAL TRANSMISSION\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Wed, 04 Mar 1998 12:07:48 -0800\nFrom: Paul Millikin <millikin@mtco.com>\n\nDogma has it that _Neisseria meningitidis_ inhabits the mouth and pharynx\nand somehow invades the blood stream and meninges from there. However,\n_Neisseria meningitis_ can also infect the urethra and uterine cervix, as\nshown\nby the references below.\nThere is documentation of its transfer from mouth to urethra via oral sex,\nso why not transfer from urethra to mouth via the same mechanism? I could\nfind no data on transfer from mouth to mouth, i.e. by kissing, but that seems\nat least theoretically possible. In other words, the evidence strongly\nsuggests that [meningococcal] meningitis may sometimes be acquired\nvenereally, from\nurethra to mouth to blood and meninges.\nConceivably that information might be useful to any physician who is faced\nwith a meningitis outbreak among young people, as on university campuses or\nin armed forces basic training centers. That's one situation where temporary\nabstinence might be a helpful control measure, provided the students or\nrecruits were made aware of it.\nIncidentally, correct identification of the organism in acute male urethritis\nmight occasionally save a marriage, when the organism is _N. meningitidis_\nfrom\nthe wife's throat rather than _N. gonorrheae_ from extracurricular sources.\nDoes anyone have any personal experience with such an outbreak?\nREFERENCES\nTI: Urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ in a London genitourinary\nmedicine clinic population.\nAU: Maini M, French P, Prince M, Bingham JS,\nSO: Int J STD AIDS 1992 Nov-Dec;3(6):423-5\n10 out of 5571 homosexual men.\n0 out of 8892 heterosexual men\n0 out of 15976 cervical cultures.\nTI: Urethritis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_: a case report.\nAU: Quarto M, Barbuti S, Germinario C, Vena GA, Foti C,\nSO: Eur J Epidemiol 1991 Nov;7(6):699-701\n1 case in a heterosexual male, acquired by fellatio\nTI: _Neisseria meningitidis_ in specimens from urogenital sites. Is increased\nawareness necessary?\nAU: Hagman M, Forslin L, Moi H, Danielsson D,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1991 Oct-Dec;18(4):228-32\n1 man, 2 women, all heterosexual. 1 woman had acute salpingitis\nTI: Urogenital infection due to meningococcus in men and women.\nAU: Conde-Glez CJ, Calderon E,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1991 Apr-Jun;18(2):72-5\n5 heterosexual men, 1 homosexual. 3 prostitutes with acute cervicitis\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ [letter; comment]\nAU: Shanmugaratnam K, Pattman RS,\nCM: Comment on: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nTI: Meningococcal urethritis.\nAU: Faigel HC,\nSO: J Adolesc Health Care 1990 Jul;11(4):355-7\n1 heterosexual male. Urethritis acquired by fellatio\nTI: Urethritis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ group B: a case\nreport.\nAU: Hartmann AA, Elsner P,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1988 Jul-Sep;15(3):150-1\n1 heterosexual man. Onset 5 days after casual fellatio by a female\nTI: [Isolation of _Neisseria meningitidis_ from the urethra and cervix]\nAU: Bohler-Sommeregger K, Poitschek C, Furnsinn G, Schuller-Petrovic S,\nHirschl A,\nSO: Wien Klin Wochenschr 1987 Jan 9;99(1):25-7\nReview and discussion\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ [letter; comment]\nAU: Shanmugaratnam K, Pattman RS,\nCM: Comment on: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ group A acquired\nby oro-genital contact: case report [letter]\nAU: Hay PE, Murphy SM, Chinn RJ,\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Aug;65(4):285-6\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ group A acquired\nby orogenital contact: case report [see comments]\nAU: Wilson AP, Wolff J, Atia W,\nCM: Comment in: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nCM: Comment in: Genitourin Med 1990 Aug;66(4):305-6\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nTI: Isolation of _Neisseria meningitidis_ from anogenital sites in\nadolescents: clinical implications.\nAU: Jaffe LR, Stavis JA,\nSO: J Adolesc Health Care 1983 Sep;4(3):171-3\nTI: Isolation of _N. meningitidis_ from patients in a gonorrhea screen\nprogram: a four-year survey in New York City.\nAU: Faur YC, Wilson ME, May PS,\nSO: Am J Public Health 1981 Jan;71(1):53-8\n964 strains from GU tract or anal canal over 4 years\nTI: Prevalence and site-pathogen studies of _Neisseria meningitidis_\nand _N. gonorrhoeae_ in homosexual men.\nAU: Janda WM, Bohnoff M, Morello JA, Lerner SA,\nSO: JAMA 1980 Nov 7;244(18):2060-4\n6 urethral and 16 anal positive cultures in 815 homosexual men\n--\nPaul D. Millikin, MD\ne-mail: millikin@mtco.com\n[While venereal transmission has been shown to occur, oropharyngeal\ntransmission between two people in that sort of close contact is likely to\nbe the primary route - Mod.JW]\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1992-03-26 00:00:00", "1983-03-26 00:00:00", "5571-03-26 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00", "1988-03-26 00:00:00", "1991-03-26 "unknown"}, {"location": "Hay PE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2193321", "headline": "PRO/AH> Angiostrongyliasis & eosinophilic meningitis", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2193321", "date": "1998-05-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLIASIS AND EOSINOPHILIC MENINGITIS\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Thu, 30 Apr 1998 17:15:41 -0000\nFrom: World Health Organisation <whosma@SAMOA.NET>\nVia: Pacific Public Health Surveillance Network <PACNET@LISTSERV.SPC.ORG.NC>\n\nLast Tuesday it was quoted in the Samoan Observer, by a pathologist, that\nthree cases of suspected eosinophilic meningitis [had been detected].\nEosinophilic meningitis is transmitted by the nematode (lungworm of rats)\n_Angiostrongylus_ (_Parastrongylus_) _cantonensis_ a which has several\nintermediate hosts including snails.\nA local non-government official is trying to promote consumption of the\nGiant African Snail by humans in an attempt to turn this pest into a\nvaluable factor.\nCan anybody give specific information about:\n1) the hosts of _Angiostrongylus_ (specific snails or any mollusk?)\n2) the risks of infection of humans by lungworms as a result of snail\ncollection and the consumption of cooked snails.\n3) any other diseases transmitted by collecting or eating cooked Giant\nAfrican Snails.\n--\nPamela Messervy\nOfficer In Charge\nOffice of the WHO Representative\nP.O. Box 77\nApia\nSamoa\ne-mail: whosma@samoa.net\n[2]\n[Steve Berger <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>, Tel Aviv Medical Center, responded:\nThe GIDEON software program identifies snail or slug species as reservoirs\nfor at least 20 human-infecting trematodes; and vehicle (e.g., ingestion)\nfor only three: eosinophilic meningitis, Abdominal angiostrongyliasis\n(found in Latin America) and Echinostomiasis (found in Latin America and\nAsia). The following background data on angiostrongyliasis were extracted\nfrom GIDEON:\n_Angiostrongylus_ (_Parastrongylus_) _cantonensis_ was first identified in\nrats in Canton, China in 1933; in humans in Taiwan in 1944. Epidemics\noccurred in Ponape (East Carolina Islands) during 1944 to 1948, and the\nparasite was widely disseminated by the African land snail (_Achatina\nfulica_).\nInfection of rats is now found throughout the Indopacific basin,\nMadagascar, Cuba, Egypt, Puerto Rico, New Orleans and Cuba. Following World\nWar II, the parasite was introduced and spread from southeast Asia into the\nPacific, through Micronesia, Australia, Micronesia and Polynesia. Cases\nwere first identified in the Philippines, Saipan, New Caledonia, Rarotonga\nand Tahiti during the 1950's. During the 1960's, the disease was reported\nfrom Vietnam, Thailand, Cambodia, Java, Sarawak, Guam and Hawaii.\n_Angiostrongylus_ (_Parastrongylus_) _cantonensis_ is found in rats, prawns\nand frogs and transmitted to man through ingestion of snails, slugs, prawns\nor lettuce. Following an incubation period of approximately 2 weeks\n(range 5 to 35 days) the patient may develop an eosinophilic meningitis\n(generally self-limited) in which fever is absent or low grade in most\ncases. Cranial nerve involvement (II, VI and VII) may ensue. Therapy may\ninclude mebendazole 100 mg BID X 5d, and corticosteroids for severe disease.\nAdditional country-specific notes:\nAustralia: Sporadic cases have been reported in Queensland. Seropositivity\nis common among aboriginals [proper term: 'kooris'].\nCook Islands: Thirty cases were reported from Rarotonga during 1965 to 1967.\nFrench Polynesia: Approximately 1,000 cases were reported for Tahiti, and\n67 for Raiatea during 1957 to 1964.\nGuam: Five cases were reported in 1965.\nNew Caledonia: 243 cases were reported during 1951 to 1964.\nPapua New Guinea: Seropositivity rates of 17% are found in East New\nBritain; and 12% of rats in Port Moresby are infested.\nTrust Territory Pacific Isl.: Cases are reported from Truk, Ponape, Saipan\nand the Marshall Islands.\nVanuatu: A single case has been reported from Espiritu Santo.\n--\nSteve Berger\nDirector, Geographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\ne-mail: mberger@post.tau.ac.il\n[3]\nDate: Wed, 6 May 1998 12:15:59 +1000\nFrom: Bureau of Environmental Health <jtag@GTEPACIFICA.NET>\nVia: Pacific Public Health Surveillance Network <PACNET@LISTSERV.SPC.ORG.NC>\n\nDuring the Japanese occupation of the Northern Islands prior to World War\nII, the Japanese raised the giant African snail for human consumption. The\nsnails were raised in special pens with screen floors where the snail\ndroppings are not allowed to be either consume by the snails or just to\nco-mingle. The significance of this practice is unknown to [me]. However,\nafter the war, the consumption of the giant African snails totally ceased\nfor the islanders and for those Japanese who decided to stay back in the\nislands.\n--\nBureau of Environmental Health\ne-mail: jtag@GTEPACIFICA.NET\n[String cut. - Mod.CHC]\n...................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "CHC]\n...................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Box 77\n However,\nafter the war, the consumption of the giant African snails totally ceased\nfor the islanders and for those Japanese who decided to stay back in the\nislands.\n The\nsnails were raised in special pens with screen floors where the snail\ndroppings are not allowed to be either consume by the snails or just to\nco-mingle. The following background data on angiostrongyliasis were extracted\nfrom GIDEON:\n_Angiostrongylus_ (_Parastrongylus_) _cantonensis_ was first identified in\nrats in Canton, China in 1933; in humans in Taiwan in 1944. Epidemics\noccurred in Ponape (East Carolina Islands) during 1944 to 1948, and the\nparasite was widely disseminated by the African land snail (_Achatina\nfulica_). --\nBureau of Environmental Health\ne-mail: jtag@GTEPACIFICA.NET\n Apia\nSamoa\ne-mail: whosma@samoa.net\n Angiostrongylus_ (_Parastrongylus_) _cantonensis_ is found in rats, prawns\nand frogs and transmitted to man through ingestion of snails, slugs, prawns\nor lettuce. (range 5 to 35 days) the patient may develop an eosinophilic meningitis\n(generally self-limited) in which fever is absent or low grade in most\ncases. A local non-government official is trying to promote consumption of the\nGiant African Snail by humans in an attempt to turn this pest into a\nvaluable factor. 3) any other diseases transmitted by collecting or eating cooked Giant\nAfrican Snails.\n : Cases are reported from Truk, Ponape, Saipan\nand the Marshall Islands.\n Tel Aviv Medical Center\ne-mail: mberger@post.tau.ac.il\n Cases\nwere first identified in the Philippines, Saipan, New Caledonia, Rarotonga\nand Tahiti during the 1950's. Following World\nWar II, the parasite was introduced and spread from southeast Asia into the\nPacific, through Micronesia, Australia, Micronesia and Polynesia. There are several cases in the county of Rottal/Inn\nthat is near the Austrian border and about 150 km east from Munich. One\n16-year-old boy died on Friday. Six pupils are in hospital. The authorities\nclosed all schools and kindergartens and told the parents to keep their\nchildren inside the houses. Today, an expert task-force from the\nRobert-Koch-Institute in Berlin has arrived. The source of the infection is\nunknown.\n--\nMarc Siegert\ne-mail: marcs@t-online.de\n[Another subscriber, Gregor Lichtfuss <gregor@lfa4.lfa.mw.tu-muenchen.de>\nhas reported that there have been 2 fatalities in this outbreak. Robertson <grobertson@erols.com>\nSource: News reports\n\nRhode Island health officials are reported to have initiated a program to\nvaccinate up to 250,000 persons between the ages of 2 and 22 years against\nmeningococcal meningitis. Dr. Patricia Nolan, Director of Health for Rhode\nIsland issued the unusual vaccination recommendation in response to 11\ncases of bacterial meningitis that have occurred this year, with 3\nfatalities. The 3 fatalities were geographically dispersed and apparently\nepidemiologically unrelated. Despite the unusual recommendation for\nwidespread vaccination, Dr. Nolan is quoted as saying 'this is not an\noutbreak.'\nMassachusetts health official, Dr. Bela Matyas, is quoted as disagreeing\nwith the Rhode Island response saying, 'what they are doing is dangerous,\nnot only because there may not be enough vaccine available for intended\nuses, but because it has created alarm that has crossed over to residents\nof Connecticut and Massachusetts.' Massachusetts has reported 12 cases of\nbacterial meningitis this year with 2 fatalities. Last year, Massachusetts\nhad seen 26 cases with 6 fatalities by this time.\nNancy Rosenstein of the CDC's Meningitis Program is reported to have said\nthat the Rhode Island response is 'reasonable' but that 'there's no reason\nto panic in Rhode Island or Massachusetts.'\nA spokesperson for Pasteur Merieux Connaught, the vaccine producer has\nindicated that production has been increased in response to the demand, and\nthat it is probable that the demand can be met.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Based upon the information reported by news media, the response of Rhode\nIsland health officials seems to me to be a bit extreme. ProMED-mail would\nappreciate comments from CDC or other officials concerning the reports in\nthe media, and their views of the scientific/ medical basis for a response\nof this magnitude to the meningococcal meningitis cases reported in Rhode\nIsland. Laboratory data indicating strain relatedness, or lack thereof,\nfor meningococcal isolates from the 11 Rhode Island cases would also be\nuseful in assessing the situation. - Mod.ES]\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
