A ProMED-mail post\nDate: Sun, 1 Mar 1998 08:36:47 -0500\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1998-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rhode \n Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Rhode Island", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192722", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, viral - Israel & Palestine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192722", "date": "1998-02-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, VIRAL - ISRAEL & PALESTINE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Sun, 8 Feb 1998 13:38:17 +0200 (IST)\nFrom: Dr. Lester M. Shulman <cvlsheba@netvision.net.il>\n\nThe [following] text is from an abstract submitted and accepted for\npresentation at the Annual meeting of the Israeli Microbiological Society.\nThe work was done by R. Handsher(1), E. Mendelson(1), E. Anis(2), B.\nAbramovitz(1), I. Silberstein(1), M. Neuman(1) and L. Shulman(1) at (1) the\nCentral Virology Laboratory, Public Health Laboratories, Ministry of\nHealth, Chaim Sheba Medical Center, Tel-Hashome and (2) The Department of\nEpidemiology, Public Health Services, Ministry of Health, Jerusalem.\n\nASEPTIC MENINGITIS DUE TO ECHOVIRUS TYPE 4 IN ISRAEL AND THE PALESTINIAN\nAUTHORITY IN 1997\n\nAn outbreak of aseptic meningitis, due to Echo 4 occurred in Israel and the\nPalestinian Authority between April and October 1997. Echo 4 has not been\nisolated in Israel since 1980. Specimens were sent from all parts of Israel\nand from Gaza and Hebron. 145 isolates (61% of all isolates) were\nidentified as Echo 4 by neutralization with specific antibodies and/or by\nimmunofluorescence with monoclonal antibodies. However, WHO standard\nantibody pools failed to identify the isolates. 13.4% of the isolates were\nother enteroviruses and the remaining 25.6% are still untyped. 11% of the\nEcho 4 isolates were from infants (<1yr); 15% from 1-4 yr old; 54% from\nschool age children (5-17 yrs); and 20% from adults. 64.2% were from males\nand 35.8% were from females. Molecular analysis was performed by sequencing\nof a 435 bp fragment from the 5' non-coding region which was amplified by\nRT-PCR using common primers. The sequences of 25 of 28 isolates from all\ngeographical regions and throughout the time course of the outbreak were\nrelated (>95% homology). The remaining 3 isolates were <95% homologous to\nthese and to each other. Interestingly, the sequence of the 5' non coding\nregion of the Echo 4 isolates was more closely related to a previously\npublished Echo 6 sequence rather than Echo 4 sequence. Our data suggest\nthat the virus was apparently a new variant of Echo 4, a fact which\nfacilitated its massive circulation in the community.\n--\nDr. Lester M. Shulman\nHead, Division of Molecular and Environmental Virology\nCentral Virology Laboratory\nSheba Medical Center\nTel Hashomer, Israel\nPhone (972-3)-530-2341\nFax (972-3)-530-2457\ne-mail: cvlsheba@netvision.net.il\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Handsher(1), E. Mendelson(1), E. Anis(2), B.\nAbramovitz(1), I. Silberstein(1), M. Neuman(1) and L. Shulman(1) at (1) the\nCentral Virology Laboratory, Public Health Laboratories, Ministry of\nHealth, Chaim Sheba Medical Center, Tel-Hashome and (2) Interestingly, the sequence of the 5' non coding\nregion of the Echo 4 isolates was more closely related to a previously\npublished Echo 6 sequence rather than Echo 4 sequence. 11% of the\nEcho 4 isolates were from infants (<1yr); 15% from 1-4 yr old; 54% from\nschool age children (5-17 yrs); and 20% from adults. 145 isolates (61% of all isolates) were\nidentified as Echo 4 by neutralization with specific antibodies and/or by\nimmunofluorescence with monoclonal antibodies. \n\nASEPTIC MENINGITIS DUE TO ECHOVIRUS TYPE 4 IN ISRAEL AND THE PALESTINIAN\nAUTHORITY IN 1997\n\nAn outbreak of aseptic meningitis, due to Echo 4 occurred in Israel and the\nPalestinian Authority between April and October 1997. The sequences of 25 of 28 isolates from all\ngeographical regions and throughout the time course of the outbreak were\nrelated (>95% homology). Molecular analysis was performed by sequencing\nof a 435 bp fragment from the 5' non-coding region which was amplified by\nRT-PCR using common primers. Vaccines, diagnostic kits and media for\npreserving isolates during transport have been shipped to Harare.\n Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to:", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-09-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bulawayo city", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2191937", "headline": "PRO> Meningitis, meningococcal, imported - Canada", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2191937", "date": "1997-09-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL, IMPORTED - CANADA\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Thu, 25 Sep 1997 03:08:39 -0700\nFrom: James Chin, MD, MPH <jchin@cdpc.com>\nSource: Canada Communicable Disease Report - Vol . 23 No. 18 (September 15,\n1997) via CDPC-mail\n\nNEISSERIA MENINGITIDIS SEROGROUP A IN ONTARIO\nEpidemics of meningococcal meningitis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup A virtually disappeared from industrialized nations after World\nWar II. Since 1990, the Laboratory Centre for Disease Control (LCDC) in\nOttawa has confirmed five cases of _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A in Canada,\nwith no laboratory-confirmed cases in the past 3 years. In Ontario, _N.\nmeningitidis_ serogroup A has not been confirmed since 1990. In early\n1997, we identified _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A isolated from a case of\nmeningitis in the greater Toronto area. A 30-year-old male returning to\nCanada in January 1997 from the northern state of Punjab, India, became ill\nwith symptoms of a high fever and headache during the flight back to\nToronto. The patient was admitted to hospital where cultures of both blood\nand cerebrospinal fluid were positive for _N. meningitidis_...\nDiscussion: Meningococcal disease is a serious public-health concern\nworldwide. In Europe and North America, the annual incidence of\nmeningococcal disease is one to three per 100,000 population and epidemics\nhave virtually disappeared, except for limited outbreaks and clusters of\ncases. In developing countries and specific areas such as the 'meningitis\nbelt' of sub-Saharan African, epidemics of meningococcal disease occur\napproximately every 8 to 10 years and can affect 1% of the population. The\nannual incidence of disease is about 10 to 50 cases per 100,000 in these\nhyper-epidemic areas, and can rise to more than 500 cases per 100,000\nduring epidemics. In the early 1980s, serogroup A:4:P1.9/clone III-1\ncaused epidemics in China and Nepal before spreading to the north of India\nin 1985. In the summer of 1987, the same strain of _N. meningitidis_ was\ncarried by Muslim pilgrims from southern Asia to Mecca and Medina, Saudi\nArabia, resulting in 7,000 cases. The relatively small number of cases\nassociated with this epidemic that were detected in Europe and North\nAmerica were linked to pilgrims returning home. Continued spread of this\nstrain to Africa following the return of Muslim pilgrims to\n'meningitis-belt' countries has continued into 1996. In Ontario, the\nmajority of cases of meningococcal disease are due to _N. meningitidis_\nserogroups B, C, Y, and occasionally W135. We have described an isolated\ncase in Ontario of meningococcal disease associated with the same strain of\n_N. meningitidis_ A:4P1.9/clone III-1 that has been linked to the major\noutbreaks in Africa, China, Nepal, the Middle East, and North India.\nAlthough only sporadic cases of _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A may occur in\nCanada, laboratory staff dealing with such specimens should be aware of the\npossible occurrence of _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A, particularly in\npatients with a recent travel history to pandemic or epidemic regions.\n--\nJames Chin, MD, MPH\nCDCP-mail\ne-mail: jchin@cdpc.com\n....................................................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n Although only sporadic cases of _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A may occur in\nCanada, laboratory staff dealing with such specimens should be aware of the\npossible occurrence of _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A, particularly in\npatients with a recent travel history to pandemic or epidemic regions.\n We have described an isolated\ncase in Ontario of meningococcal disease associated with the same strain of\n_N. meningitidis_ A:4P1.9/clone III-1 that has been linked to the major\noutbreaks in Africa, China, Nepal, the Middle East, and North India.\n The\nannual incidence of disease is about 10 to 50 cases per 100,000 in these\nhyper-epidemic areas, and can rise to more than 500 cases per 100,000\nduring epidemics. In Europe and North America, the annual incidence of\nmeningococcal disease is one to three per 100,000 population and epidemics\nhave virtually disappeared, except for limited outbreaks and clusters of\ncases. James Chin, MD, MPH\nCDCP-mail\ne-mail: jchin@cdpc.com\n.................................................................... A 30-year-old male returning to\nCanada in January 1997 from the northern state of Punjab, India, became ill\nwith symptoms of a high fever and headache during the flight back to\nToronto. Since 1990, the Laboratory Centre for Disease Control (LCDC) in\nOttawa has confirmed five cases of _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A in Canada,\nwith no laboratory-confirmed cases in the past 3 years. In developing countries and specific areas such as the 'meningitis\nbelt' of sub-Saharan African, epidemics of meningococcal disease occur\napproximately every 8 to 10 years and can affect 1% of the population. In early\n1997, we identified _N. meningitidis_ serogroup A isolated from a case of\nmeningitis in the greater Toronto area. (September 15,\n1997) via CDPC-mail\n\nNEISSERIA MENINGITIDIS SEROGROUP A IN ONTARIO\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1990-03-26 00:00:00", "1997-01-26 00:00:00", "1997-09-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-26 00:00:00", "1985-03-26 00:00:00", "1997-09-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Punjab", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mecca", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Medina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2191791", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Meningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2191791", "date": "1997-09-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (03)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "MENINGITIS - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (03)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2191492", "headline": "PRO> Meningitis, meningococcal - New Zealand (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2191492", "date": "1997-07-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NEW ZEALAND (06)\n********************************************\nDate: Thu, 24 Jul 1997 21:10:00 +1300\nFrom: Michael Baker <michael.baker@esr.cri.nz>\n[see\nMeningitis, meningococcal - New Zealand 970708101517\nMeningitis, meningococcal - New Zealand (02) 970708204915\nMeningitis, meningococcal - New Zealand (03) 970711122620\nMeningitis, meningococcal - New Zealand (04) 970711141631\nMeningitis, meningococcal - New Zealand (05) 970712114529]\nThis report is in response to several recent ProMED-mail items that have\ncommented on meningococcal disease in New Zealand.\nNew Zealand is now in its sixth year of a meningococcal disease epidemic\nwhich began in mid-1991. The background incidence of meningococcal disease\nwas about 50 cases a year in 1989-90 (1.5 per 100,000). Rates have increased\nsteadily since then with 473 cases in 1996, a rate of 14.0 per 100,000.\nDisease incidence increased by a further 27% during the first 6 months of\n1997. Most cases (73% in 1996) occur in the winter and spring months.\nAs expected, highest rates are in the young (142.0 per 100,000 in those\nunder one year of age, 72.9 for those 1-4 years). There are also marked\nethnic differences in incidence with Maori having rates that were 1.5 times\nhigher than Europeans in 1996, and Pacific Islands people having rates that\nwere 5.3 times higher. This disease is particularly concentrated in young\nPacific Island children (570.7 cases per 100,000 for Pacific Island children\nunder one year of age). The case fatality rate has been about 5.0% for a\nnumber of years.\nSerogroup B accounted for 77.6% (215/277) of isolates obtained in 1996, with\nserogroup C accounting for most of the rest (18.8% or 52/277). One\nserosubtype (P1.4) has become dominant among the serogroup B cases,\naccounting for 87.4% (188/215) in 1996. A serogroup B vaccine which\neffectively targets this antigen (P1.4) could have a major role in\ncontrolling this epidemic.\nMonthly updates on meningococcal disease incidence are published in the New\nZealand Public Health Report, which can be accessed on the New Zealand\nMinistry of Health's Web site <http://www.moh.govt.nz/pubs_on.htm>\n---\nMichael Baker, Public Health Physician\nESR, Box 50348, Porirua, New Zealand\nTEL: (64 4) 2370 149\nFAX: (64 4) 237 2370\ne-mail: <michael.baker@esr.cri.nz>\nSue Walker, Scientist\nESR, Box 50348, Porirua, New Zealand\nTEL: (64 4) 2370 149\nFAX: (64 4) 237 2370\ne-mail: <sue.walker@esr.cri.nz>\n[Thanks to both of you for this marvelous summary. -- Mod CHC]\n............................................................................\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Norwegian\nfield trial reduced the incidence of group B disease among school children by\nonly 53% (Lancet 1991;338:1093). Results were somewhat better in Chile and\nCuba. However, the outer membrane protein vaccine is serotype specific so\nthat its utility in New Zealand would depend on the serotype responsible for\ndisease there.\n[It is stated to be type B, see: 970708204915 - Mod.JW]\n---\nRonald Gold, MD\n46 Waverley Rd.\nToronto, ON M4L 3T1\nTEL: (416) 691-4952\nFAX: (416) 693-4227\nemail: <rongold@netcom.ca>\n.........................................................................chc\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The health authorities issued an\nurgent warning to treat any case of fever with rash as potentially\nmeningitis. Symptoms of meningitis include fever, stiff neck, headache,\nrash and vomiting.\nThis follows press reports of:\n- one case of 'meningitis,' unspecified whether bacterial or viral, in\nCanterbury the week ending 7 March 1997,\n- the death of a New Zealand decathlon athlete from the disease on 17 March\n1997, and the recovery of another young athlete admitted the day before that,\n- a case in a female university student admitted to Wellington Hospital in\nthe first week of April 1997,\n- a case in 10-year-old New Plymouth boy admitted to Taranaki Base Hospital\nin early\nApril 1997\n- two cases of meningococcal meningitis in Southland, Invercargill, the\nweek of 6 June 1997. One, a 2-year-old boy, died but it was not clear\nwhether meningitis was the cause of death.\nIn 1996, 37 people in Christchurch were reported to have suffered from the\ndisease, a large increase from 22 the year before. The rate of\nmeningococcal meningitis in New Zealand appears to be much higher than in\nother developed countries, and 7 times the rate in Australia.\n.................................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The health authorities issued an\nurgent warning to treat any case of fever with rash as potentially\nmeningitis. The rate of\nmeningococcal meningitis in New Zealand appears to be much higher than in\nother developed countries, and 7 times the rate in Australia. There is some possibility of a spenoidal sinusitis, based on a\nreview of MRI films taken earlier this month on the patient who had been seen\nmultiple times for evaluation of gradually progressing headache. The MRI had\ninitially been read as negative by our radiologist, who reexamined the films\nin light of the patient's deterioration. The patient was admitted on\nSaturday with obtundation, responding only to painful stimuli, but with\nspontaneous movements, so spontaneous that the patient was too disruptive to\nbe maintained on the general medicine ward and was transferred to the ICU\n(Japanese hospital).\nSo far, no further cases have been identified, although there has been the\nusual panic (we are a small base.)\n---\nCapt Philip Gould\ne-mail: <GOULDPH@35MDG.Misawa.af.mil>\n[Can any of our Japanese subscribers answer this question? The number of deaths reported in Niger\nwas 206 [sic] and the number of cases reported in Rwanda was 10.\nThe revised text follows:\nMeningitis in West Africa\n-------------------------\nAs at 11 April, a total of 41 699 cases of meningitis with\n4498 deaths had been reported in Africa. These were mainly\nfrom countries in West Africa where epidemics have continued\nto occur.\nBurkina Faso with 16 775 cases and 1953 deaths\naccounted for 40% of the cases reported this year,\nGhana with 13 063 and 1191 deaths for 31% and\nMali with 6 119 cases and 587 deaths for 15%.\nCases were also reported in:\nBenin (273 cases, 47 deaths),\nGambia (856 cases, 119 deaths),\nNiger (1813 cases, 208 [sic] deaths), *******\nRwanda (10 cases, 4 deaths), *******\nSenegal (13 cases, 4 deaths), and\nTogo (2619 cases, 360 deaths).\n\nGambia, Ghana and Togo were less affected during the 1996\nepidemics when Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger and Nigeria reported\nwidespread outbreaks. Burkina Faso reported 42 129 cases, Mali\n7254 and Niger 16 145 cases in 1996.\nNigeria, which reported 77 089 cases in 1996, has not yet reported cases\nduring 1997.\n..........................................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A programme\nof mass chemoprophylaxis and vaccination was implemented on 29 November and\nthe outbreak was declared over on 9 December. The final report of the\noutbreak control team was referred to the PHLS Meningococcus Working Group,\nwhich was asked to consider whether guidance on the management of university\nand college outbreaks published in January 1997 needed to be revised or\nexpanded following the investigation of the outbreak in Cardiff. The Working\nGroup has advised that there is no need to modify this recent guidance. In\nparticular no change is recommended to guidance on the management of cases\nseparated by four or more weeks. The current guidance states: 'if cases are\nseparated by more than four weeks or the denominator population is large =96\nfor example in university clusters without links between cases =96 seek=\nadvice\non further action.'\n\nApril 7, 1997 -CDR Review -UK - Vol 7 No. 4 (April 4, 1997)=20\nChanging patterns of case ascertainment and trends in meningococcal disease\nin England and Wales; Ramsay M, et al:\nSummary: We have reviewed data on meningococcal disease routinely collected\nin England and Wales from 1989 to 1995 to illustrate and explain changing\npatterns and guide future surveillance. Statutory notifications of\nmeningococcal meningitis and epticaemia, laboratory confirmed infections,\nand death registrations coded as eningococcal disease were analysed in terms\nof their numbers, the age of cases, season of the report, and (if available)\nsite of isolation, serogroup, and serotype. Case fatality rates were\nestimated for clinically diagnosed and culture confirmed cases.\nThe number of cases notified each year, in particular those notified as\nsepticaemia, rose significantly over the period (p<0.0001) but there was no\nnet change in the number of culture confirmed cases. Case fatality rates\nestimated from routine data fell, most markedly for cases notified as\nsepticaemia, but the true case fatality rate of culture confirmed cases did\nnot change between 1993 and 1995. These data suggest that reporting practice\nchanged between 1989 and 1995 and that the ascertainment of clinically\ndiagnosed disease improved, particularly for meningococcal septicaemia. Late\nin 1995, reports from all data sources increased and the age distribution of\nboth notified and laboratory confirmed cases changed. These changes were\naccompanied by an increase in the proportion of infections due to Neisseria\nmeningitidis of serogroup c and a significant increase in serotype c2a\ninfections (p<0.0001).=20\nContinuing efforts to reconcile data from several sources will be needed to\nensure that routine data can be interpreted accurately to provide evidence\nfor the development of future vaccination policy and to monitor vaccination\nprogrammes. In addition, the role of non-culture diagnosis will be crucial\nin enhancing sveillance based on clinical diagnoses.\n...........................................mhj\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. The current guidance states: 'if cases are\nseparated by more than four weeks or the denominator population is large =96\nfor example in university clusters without links between cases =96 seek=\nadvice\non further action.'\n\nApril 7, 1997 -CDR Review -UK - Vol 7 No. 4 (April 4, 1997)=20\n ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n Statutory notifications of\nmeningococcal meningitis and epticaemia, laboratory confirmed infections,\nand death registrations coded as eningococcal disease were analysed in terms\nof their numbers, the age of cases, season of the report, and (if available)\nsite of isolation, serogroup, and serotype. The final report of the\noutbreak control team was referred to the PHLS Meningococcus Working Group,\nwhich was asked to consider whether guidance on the management of university\nand college outbreaks published in January 1997 needed to be revised or\nexpanded following the investigation of the outbreak in Cardiff. These changes were\naccompanied by an increase in the proportion of infections due to Neisseria\nmeningitidis of serogroup c and a significant increase in serotype c2a\ninfections (p<0.0001).=20\n Case fatality rates\nestimated from routine data fell, most markedly for cases notified as\nsepticaemia, but the true case fatality rate of culture confirmed cases did\nnot change between 1993 and 1995. Continuing efforts to reconcile data from several sources will be needed to\nensure that routine data can be interpreted accurately to provide evidence\nfor the development of future vaccination policy and to monitor vaccination\nprogrammes. The number of cases notified each year, in particular those notified as\nsepticaemia, rose significantly over the period (p<0.0001) but there was no\nnet change in the number of culture confirmed cases. Late\nin 1995, reports from all data sources increased and the age distribution of\nboth notified and laboratory confirmed cases changed. These data suggest that reporting practice\nchanged between 1989 and 1995 and that the ascertainment of clinically\ndiagnosed disease improved, particularly for meningococcal septicaemia. Summary: We have reviewed data on meningococcal disease routinely collected\nin England and Wales from 1989 to 1995 to illustrate and explain changing\npatterns and guide future surveillance.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-04-07 00:00:00", "2021-12-09 00:00:00", "2021-11-29 00:00:00", "2021-04-04 00:00:00", "1997-01-26 00:00:00", "1995-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2190402", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - West Africa", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190402", "date": "1997-03-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - WEST AFRICA\n=======================================\nDate: Fri, 21 Mar 1997 10:28:55 -0800\nFrom: CDPC-mail (Jim Chin) <jchin@cdpc.com>\n[see\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso, Ghana, Togo 970314153752\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Ghana (02) 970307153821\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Togo (04) 970210130250\nMeningitis, meningococcal? - Burkina Faso 970131144055\nMeningitis, meningococcal? - Ghana, Mali 970131144049\nMeningitis, meningococcal? - Togo 970124154411\nMeningitis, meningococcal? - Togo (02) 970127153534\nMeningitis, meningococcal? - Togo (03) 970131144054]\n\n>From WHO's Outbreak Page (March 21, 1997)\nGhana:\nThe number of cases [of meningitis] has more than doubled since 22 February\nand was 3,757 with 411 deaths (Case Fatality Rate 11%) by 13 March. The\noutbreaks were first reported in Bawku East and Bolgatanga Districts in the\nUpper East Region and East Mamprusi District in the Northern Region. They\nhave since spread to several other districts including Bawku West and\nKassena-Nankan Districts in the Upper East Region and Gushegu-Karaga, Tamale,\nWest Mamprusi and Yendi Districts in the Northern Region. The total\npopulation in districts where the weekly attack rate exceeds 5 cases per\n100,00 population is 1,771,539 and the population under 30 years of age in\nthese districts is approximately 1,240,000. The Ministry of Health is basing\nits control strategy on health education, case management and vaccination\nactivities. A task force has been created to coordinate reporting and the\nsupport to the affected regions. External support has been obtained to\npurchase vaccine, injection material and drugs.\nOther countries in west Africa:\nThe number of cases of epidemic meningitis reported in Burkina Faso more than\ndoubled during the past month. As at 20 March 10,000 cases had been reported\nof which 1,200 were fatal (CFR 12%). The latest cumulative figures from\nother countries are: Chad (28 February): 38 cases, 6 deaths (CFR 16%); Gambia\n(19 March): 151 cases, 17 deaths (CFR 11%); Mali (11 March): 1,549 cases, 160\ndeaths (CFR 10%) and Togo (19 March),: 2,380 cases, 329 deaths (CFR 14%).\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n..........................................................................chc\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The latest cumulative figures from\nother countries are: Chad (28 February): 38 cases, 6 deaths (CFR 16%); The number of cases of epidemic meningitis reported in Burkina Faso more than\ndoubled during the past month.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-02-28 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-02-22 00:00:00", "1997-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "West Mamprusi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gambia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2190508", "headline": "PRO/AH> BSE & meningitis and Hemophilus vaccine bans - Italy (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190508", "date": "1997-04-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "BSE & MENINGITIS AND HEMOPHILUS VACCINE BANS - ITALY (02)\n=========================================================\n[see\nBSE & meningitis and Hemophilus vaccine bans - Italy 970129223423]\n[We received the following communication from Professor Urbano. MHJ}\nDate: Tue, 01 Apr 1997 19:00:25 +0200\nFrom: Pasquale Urbano <micro@CESIT1.UNIFI.IT>\nSubject: BSE & meningitis and Hemophilus vaccine bans - Italy\nI enclose a paper by Prof. Bartolozzi, due to be published in a widely\ncirculated Journal for pediatricians (Medico e Bambino). The paper comments\non the hasty decision for our health authorities to ban some vaccine lots,\non account of the remote and theoretical risk of BSE transmission. The point\nis that the national vaccination efforts, and for Hib in particular, have\nsuffered from the ban, and from the ensuing media fuss.\n---\nProf. Pasquale Urbano\nIstituto di Microbiologia\nViale Morgagni 48 - 50126 Firenze\nTel. +39 55 411081; fax +39 55 4223895\nE-mail: micro@unifi.it\nhttp://urbano.micromed.unifi.it\n[Professor Ottolenghi kindly prepared the following abstract of the\nBartolozzi paper. MHJ]\nDate: Sat, 5 Apr 1997 13:33:48 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: ottolenghi.1@osu.edu (Abramo Ottolenghi)\nIn an article to be published in the Italian pediatric journal 'Medico e\nBambino' Professor Bartolozzi comments on the ban recently enacted by the\nItalian Ministy of Health on two Hib conjugated vaccines prepared with\norganisms cultured on Brain Heart Infusion (BHI), a culture medium prepared\nwith neural tissue from animals.\nThe ban apparently follows a recommendation by the EC that companies\nproducing vaccines abandon such media. The vaccines in question are\nBiocine-Kiron's Vaxem-Hib which had been previously recalled voluntarily by\nthe firm, and Hib-titer produced by Cyanamid-Praxis Lederle. The ban does\nnot affect ACT-Hib produced by Merieux-Pasteur which is produced without\nusing BHI. The ban also affects Mempovax Kiron's meningococcal vaccine. The\narticle points out that the publicity surrounding the ban has created a\nreluctance to vaccinate agaianst other diseases.\nThe basis for the ban is a fear that BSE might be transmitted via BHI. After\na detailed discussion of BSE and prions, the article points out that since\n1991 care was taken that the materials used for the production of vaccines\ncame from animals from the U.S. and Australia and thus considered to be free\nof the BSE-causing agent. It further points out that in January 1997 the\nEuropean Agency for the Evaluation of Medicinal Products had concluded that\nthe procedures used in the production of the vaccines were such that there\nwas no risk of transmitting BSE.\nThe article reports that Italy is the only country where the vaccines have\nbeen banned, and points to the fact that USFDA has not banned them. The ban\nwas reported in English by K. McKenzie in BMJ 314:397 1997.\n--\nAbramo Ottolenghi\nProfessor Emeritus\nDept. Medical Microbiology and Immunology\nOhio State University College of Medicine\nColumbus, Ohio 43210 U.S.A.\nPhone 614-292-5773\nFax 614-292-9805\n[With thanks to our two good Professors. MHJ]\n................................................mhj\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. After\na detailed discussion of BSE and prions, the article points out that since\n1991 care was taken that the materials used for the production of vaccines\ncame from animals from the U.S. and Australia and thus considered to be free\nof the BSE-causing agent. ---\nProf. Pasquale Urbano\nIstituto di Microbiologia\nViale Morgagni 48 - 50126 Firenze\n It further points out that in January 1997 the\nEuropean Agency for the Evaluation of Medicinal Products had concluded that\nthe procedures used in the production of the vaccines were such that there\nwas no risk of transmitting BSE. The paper comments\non the hasty decision for our health authorities to ban some vaccine lots,\non account of the remote and theoretical risk of BSE transmission. The\narticle points out that the publicity surrounding the ban has created a\nreluctance to vaccinate agaianst other diseases. The point\nis that the national vaccination efforts, and for Hib in particular, have\nsuffered from the ban, and from the ensuing media fuss. The ban does\nnot affect ACT-Hib produced by Merieux-Pasteur which is produced without\nusing BHI. The vaccines in question are\nBiocine-Kiron's Vaxem-Hib which had been previously recalled voluntarily by\nthe firm, and Hib-titer produced by Cyanamid-Praxis Lederle. Most (95%) of\nthe cases in Ghana have been reported in Upper East Region (6 364\ncases, 497 deaths) and Northern Region (1 867 cases, 281 deaths).\n\nCases have also been detected in Ashanti, Brong Ahafo and Upper West\nRegions.\n..........................................................jw\n\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. From: ProMED-mail <<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n\nEMC disease news - 27 March 1997\n\nMeningitis in West Africa\n\nAs at 23 March 1997, a total of 24 798 cases with 2 933 deaths from\nepidemic meningitis had been reported in Benin, Burkina Faso, Gambia,\nGhana, Mali, Niger, and Togo. There have been two cases\nof _E.sakazakii_ septicaemia in 1997 and eight in 1996, all in adults and but\none aged over 65. From 1986 to date we have received 42 reports of\nsepticaemia, of which only three were before 1991. PHLS\n[Public Health Laboratory Service]\nreports no infant cases of septicaemia or meningitis in 1997 in England &\nWales. Local investigations in Ayrshire & Arran are underway.\n_E.sakazakii_ was designated a distinct species in 1980 and has been\nassociated with a rare but severe meningitis (mortality of 40-80%)\nassociated with contaminated dried infant formula in two USA outbreaks. This\nspecies appears to be highly thermoresistant in comparison with other\nEnterobacteraciae.\nReferences:\n-----------\nClark NC, Hill BC et al. Epidemiologic typing of Enterobacter sakazakii in\ntwo neonatal nosocomial outbreaks. Diag Microbiol & Inf Dis 1990; 13: 467-72\nNazarowec-White M, Farber JM. Thermal resistance of Enterobacter sakazakii\nin reconstituted dried infant formula. Lett Appl Microbiol 1997; 24: 9-13\n--\nNorman MacDonald\n<norman@scieh.tcom.co.uk>\n...............................................................jw\n\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. MENINGITIS, ENTEROBACTER SAKAZAKII - SCOTLAND (KILMARNOCK)\n==========================================================\n Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: This\nspecies appears to be highly thermoresistant in comparison with other\nEnterobacteraciae. References:\n-----------\nClark NC, Hill BC et al.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1986-03-26 00:00:00", "1990-03-26 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00", "2065-03-26 00:00:00", "1991-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "1980-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-09-13 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2190357", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso, Ghana, Togo", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190357", "date": "1997-03-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BURKINA FASO, GHANA, TOGO\n=====================================================\nDate: Fri, 14 Mar 1997 11:57:07 -0800\nFrom: 'Dr. James Chin' <jchin@cdpc.com>\n\nSource: CDPC E-mail Service - March 14, 1997\nMarch 14, 1997 - WER [WHO Weekly Epidemiological Record] - Vol 72/ No. 11\nMeningitis in Africa Epidemic situation, January - March 1997:\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nThree countries (Togo, Ghana and Burkina Faso) have reached the epidemic\nthreshold since the beginning of the 1997 meningitis season in early\nNovember 1996.\nTogo was the first country to report an increased number of meningitis\ncases in the Savanes Region neighbouring Burkina Faso. The first\ncases were reported in late December 1996 and the epidemic threshold was\nreached on 5 January 1997 in Tone District. Mass immunization activities\nhave covered 159 000 persons (100% of the population) in the Tandjouare\nand Oti areas neighbouring Tone District. In other areas, efforts are\nbeing made to convince the population still reluctant towards\nvaccination.\nBurkina Faso: The epidemic threshold has been reached in 5 districts\nsince the second week of 1997. The weekly reported number of cases\ncontinued to increase; the epidemic has extended to more than 10\ndistricts and continues to spread. Intensive vaccination campaigns are\nunder way, as well as social mobilization to convince more people to be\nvaccinated in the affected areas.\nGhana: Cases have been reported from northern Ghana since the beginning\nof November 1996. The threshold was reached during the last week of\nJanuary. Since then, the epidemic has continued to spread. The weekly\nattack rates are over 15 per 100 000 population in 6 districts in the\nUpper East and Northern Regions. The population at greatest risk is\nestimated at more than 1.7 million. The national crisis committee\nmonitors the epidemic situation and determines the needs. Intensive\nvaccination campaigns are in progress. Other countries [in the region]\nhave reported sporadic cases. National health authorities have been re-\nquested to reinforce disease surveillance and initiate vaccination\nactivities as soon as the epidemic threshold is reached.\n(Based on: A report from the WHO Regional Office for Africa.)\nWER Editorial Note: An international Appeal has been launched by WHO\njointly with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent\nSocieties, Medecins sans Frontieres and UNICEF to raise funds for the\ncontrol of meningitis in Africa in the 1997 epidemic season. The funds\nare being used to purchase vaccine, treatment drugs and autodestruct\ninjection material. Requests for vaccine are evaluated according to\ncriteria set by an International Coordinating Group, to ensure that\noptimal use is made of the vaccine currently available.\n.............................................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": ".............................................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n \nWER Editorial Note: An international Appeal has been launched by WHO\njointly with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent\nSocieties, Medecins sans Frontieres and UNICEF to raise funds for the\ncontrol of meningitis in Africa in the 1997 epidemic season. Requests for vaccine are evaluated according to\ncriteria set by an International Coordinating Group, to ensure that\noptimal use is made of the vaccine currently available.\n The first\ncases were reported in late December 1996 and the epidemic threshold was\nreached on 5 January 1997 in Tone District. Three countries (Togo, Ghana and Burkina Faso) have reached the epidemic\nthreshold since the beginning of the 1997 meningitis season in early\n National health authorities have been re-\nquested to reinforce disease surveillance and initiate vaccination\nactivities as soon as the epidemic threshold is reached. The weekly reported number of cases\ncontinued to increase; the epidemic has extended to more than 10\ndistricts and continues to spread. Mass immunization activities\nhave covered 159 000 persons (100% of the population) in the Tandjouare\nand Oti areas neighbouring Tone District. The weekly\nattack rates are over 15 per 100 000 population in 6 districts in the\nUpper East and Northern Regions. Intensive vaccination campaigns are\nunder way, as well as social mobilization to convince more people to be\nvaccinated in the affected areas. In other areas, efforts are\nbeing made to convince the population still reluctant towards\nvaccination. The funds\nare being used to purchase vaccine, treatment drugs and autodestruct\ninjection material. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BURKINA FASO, GHANA, TOGO\n=====================================================\n The epidemic threshold has been reached in 5 districts\nsince the second week of 1997.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-01-05 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00", "1996-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2190308", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Ghana (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190308", "date": "1997-03-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - GHANA (02)\n======================================\nDate: Thu, 06 Mar 97 16:30:37 CET\nFrom: EMC disease news <estevesk@who.ch>\n[see\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 970131144055\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Ghana, Mali 970131144049\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Togo 970124154411\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Togo (02) 970127153534\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Togo (03) 970131144054\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Togo (04) 970210130250]\n>From November 1996 to 22 February 1997, 1659 cases of cerebrospinal\nmeningitis with 281 deaths (Case-fatality rate 17%) were reported, most of\nwhich (70%) occurred in February 1997. The outbreak started in East Mamprusi\ndistrict and Bawku East and then spread to four other districts in Upper West\nRegion. The population at greatest risk is estimated at around 1.7 million\nbut the entire population at risk in the Upper East and Northern Regions is\nclose to 3 million. Reports indicate that the number of cases is increasing\nrapidly in other districts of the Upper East, Northern, Upper West and Brong\nAhafo Regions. The total population exposed in these Regions is near 5.5\nmillion. The Ministry of Health has mobilized funds to purchase at least\n3,395,000 doses of vaccines with needles and syringes.\n\nOutbreaks have also been reported in Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger and Togo,\ncontinuing the epidemic cycle which started in West Africa in 1996. The\npresence of serogroup A _Neisseria meningitidis_ has been confirmed.\n\nThe appeal launched by WHO, UNICEF, Medecins sans Frontiere, Federation of\nRed Cross, and Red Crescent Societies on 7 February resulted in pledges\nexceeding US$ 3 million for the response to the threat of epidemic meningitis\nin Africa. The appeal is being relaunched on 7 March to reach the goal of\nUS$ 6.3 million needed to secure the purchase and distribution of vaccine,\ndrugs for treatment and injection material.\nEND OF MESSAGE\nNOTE: Starting January 1997, outbreak news entered on EMC's home page on the\nWorld Wide Web (site http://www.who.ch/programmes/emc), will also be\ndistributed to all subscribers to the e-mail list 'Table of Contents of the\nWeekly Epidemiological Record'.\n\nIf you wish to continue to receive these news bulletins by e-mail, please\nsubscribe by sending an e-mail message to: <majordomo@who.ch> and type:\nsubscribe wer-reh\nas the only text in the message field.\n\nPlease note that this dedicated e-mail service will be discontinued at the\nend of March.\n\nNews on disease outbreaks received in the WHO's Division of Emerging and other\nCommunicable Diseases (EMC), are posted on EMC's home page on World Wide Web\n(http://www.who.ch/programmes/emc/news.htm).\n\n---\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n..........................................................................chc\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Jon Hinkle <hinklc@mail.health.state.mo.us>\n[see\nMeningococcal meningitis: RFI 970304174525]\nAs one of those `state health department' types referred to, I want to echo\nCharlie's comment. [Which was, 'Certainly these occurrences should be taken\nseriously but one would assume that such outbreaks are reported to local and\nstate public health authorities and that they are investigated and treated\n(the episode as well as the individuals). When you hear of such occurrences\nor even rumors of such occurrences, rather than contact ProMED-mail, contact\nyour state or local health department, university health center, or other\nappropriate organizations.' -- Mod CHC]\nIndeed, meningococcal disease does occur sporadically in school-aged kids,\nfrom elementary on up and unfortunately, it occasionally (to often) results\nin a death. This is guaranteed to stir the worst fears in the population in\ngeneral and parents in particular. It doesn't help that the media often use\nsuch a tragedy to sell more newspapers.\nThe local and state health departments have (too much) experience in dealing\nwith this situation, and we have developed good methods to identify and\nprophylax the folks who need it. If we get good reporting, we can get\nprophylaxis started within 24 hours of the report.\nThe bottom line is that Charlie's advice to contact the Public Health\ndepartment in your area is right on. They should have the knowledge and the\nresources to provide good information and advice in such cases.\n---\nC. Jon Hinkle\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2190285", "headline": "PRO> Meningococcal meningitis, reporting (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190285", "date": "1997-03-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGOCOCCAL MENINGITIS, REPORTING (03)\n========================================\nDate: Wed, 05 Mar 1997 12:55:29 -0800\nFrom: Kenneth Dardick <kdardick@neca.com>\n[see\nMeningococcal meningitis: RFI 970304174525]\nMeningococcal disease is quite common in both closed (i.e., college and\nmilitary) and open (the community at large) settings, but always seems to\ntake the press and public by storm. For example, here in Connecticut there\nare, on average, 20 cases a year, year in year out. [Not a significant\ncommunity threat] from a public health point of view, certainly a big deal to\nthe affected patient. Yet, each case is the subject of its own 'headline'\nnews piece. The usual routine with isolated cases is to administer rifampin\n'prophylaxis' to all those living/sleeping in close quarters with the\nidentified case. This does not apply to co-workers, other students or other\n'friends'.\nWhat is news, however, are clusters of cases. So, a few years ago when we\nhad three cases in 24 hours at the University of Connecticut, and all three\nlived in different dorms and had no personal or other association with the\nothers, we became quite alarmed that we might be sitting on the tip of an\noutbreak-iceberg. This had happened the year before at the University of\nIllinois with a few deaths. Given the facts (3 cases, no known contact) we\nmounted a massive vaccination program and vaccinated about 12,000 students in\na three-day period (in the middle of exams and Mother's Day!). The outbreak\nended and we have had only an occasional isolated case since then.\nHope this helps.\n---\nKenneth R. Dardick, MD FACP DTM&H\nDirector of Health, Mansfield, Connecticut\nConnecticut Travel Medicine\ne-mail: <kdardick@neca.com>\n[This unique perspective and information is appreciated. -- Mod CHC]\n.............................................................................\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. No only that, but\nelimination of these strains was durable. I'll have to look up the times in\nthe data but it was surprising. I think that the role of chemoprophylaxis (or\nthe lack of it) in populations is largely a matter of conjecture. It is true\nthat when there is no germ there is no meningitis and than certain\nantibiotics can get rid of carriage. When carriage rates are up around 30%\nantibiotics might have a role for Group B strains. The current\nrecommendations in textbooks and from the CDC et al are based on secondary\nattack rates in small groups. They are conservative and justified based on\nwhat we know about these settings. It is difficult to go beyond these data\nin a positive or negative way and be on firm ground.\n--\nJBL McClain\ne-mail: T10B9@aol.com\n[Because PROMED-EDR is for reports of disease outbreaks or emergency measures,\nin order to maintain the selectivity of EDR any further discussion on this\ntopic will now be switched to the 'regular' PROMED list after this\nposting. Subscribers are cordially invited to continue the discussion there.\n-- Mod. MENINGOCOCCAL MENINGITIS: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n=================================================\n Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: -- Mod CHC]\n.............................................................................\n [ProMED-mail receives many such messages regarding isolated cases or small-\ncluster outbreaks of meningococcal meningitis in various locations.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Blacksburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia Beach", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2188142", "headline": "PROMED: Meningitis, meningococcal, group C, 1992 - US: Possible risk factors", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2188142", "date": "1996-03-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "Date: Tues 19 Mar 1996\nFrom: Dorothy Preslar <dpreslar@fas.org>\nex news services\n\nMENINGOCOCCAL MENINGITIS: REPORT ON 1992 SEROGROUP C OUTBREAK, US\n=================================================================\n[From press reports]\nA study by researchers at the NCID (Natl Center for Infectious\nDiseases, CDC) and the University of Illinois on the 1992\noutbreak of serogroup C meningococcal meningitis that killed three\nuniversity students has raised a question on the role smoking,\ndrinking and dense crowds may have in spreading the disease.\nThe study makes these points: All 3 victims were regulars at a particular\ncampus bar. Employees and other patrons were found to be 20 to 40 times\nmore likely to catch the disease or carry the bacteria, which is usually a\nharmless bacteria carried in the nose and throat. The connection between\nthe outbreak and the social habits of the people studied was unexpected.\nMore research is needed to confirm the implication that the consumption of\nalcohol and smoking may have the effect of causing bacteria in the nose to\ncolonize, perhaps invading the body more deeply, and kill within 24 hours.\nHowever, the leader of the study (Peter Imrey) has been quoted saying that\npublic health officials dealing with future outbreaks of meningococcal\ndisease in otherwise healthy persons, young adults in particular, may want\nto consider patterns of alcohol consumption and bar patronage.\n--\nDorothy B. Preslar\nWashington ProMED Officer/AHEAD Coordinator\nFederation of American Scientists\n307 Massachusetts Ave. NE, Washington, DC 20002, USA\ne-mail: dpreslar@fas.org\nhttp://www.fas.org/pub/gen/fas/promed/\n...............................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n However, the leader of the study (Peter Imrey) has been quoted saying that\npublic health officials dealing with future outbreaks of meningococcal\ndisease in otherwise healthy persons, young adults in particular, may want\nto consider patterns of alcohol consumption and bar patronage.\n A study by researchers at the NCID (Natl Center for Infectious\nDiseases, CDC) and the University of Illinois on the 1992\noutbreak of serogroup C meningococcal meningitis that killed three\nuniversity students has raised a question on the role smoking,\ndrinking and dense crowds may have in spreading the disease. \n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. \nDorothy B. Preslar\nWashington ProMED Officer/AHEAD Coordinator\nFederation of American Scientists\n307 Massachusetts Ave. More research is needed to confirm the implication that the consumption of\nalcohol and smoking may have the effect of causing bacteria in the nose to\ncolonize, perhaps invading the body more deeply, and kill within 24 hours.\n From: Dorothy Preslar <dpreslar@fas.org>\nex news services\n\nMENINGOCOCCAL MENINGITIS: REPORT ON 1992 SEROGROUP C OUTBREAK, US\n=================================================================\n Employees and other patrons were found to be 20 to 40 times\nmore likely to catch the disease or carry the bacteria, which is usually a\nharmless bacteria carried in the nose and throat. e-mail: dpreslar@fas.org\nhttp://www.fas.org/pub/gen/fas/promed/\n...............................................................................", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1996-03-26 00:00:00", "1992-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2188152", "headline": "PROMED: Meningitis, meningococcal - US: Poss. risk factors (2)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2188152", "date": "1996-03-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "From: David O. Matson, MD <MATSON@PICARD.EVMS.EDU\nCenter for Pediatric Research\nDate: Wed 20 Mar 1996\n\nMENINGOCOCCAL MENINGITIS: 1992 SEROGROUP C OUTBREAK, US (2)\n===========================================================\n[Referring to the original account, posted 19 March, reporting that\nfrequenting certain bars and smoking were associated with acquiring\nthe infection:]\nThis seems to be an example of co-factors without causality. In the\nparticular instance of the cases in Illinois, crowding, smoking, and\ndrinking went together because the students crowded in a place where\nsmoking and drinking were common. Smoking, drinking, and crowding\nin this outbreak cannot be separated from each other epidemiologically.\nTo confirm whether smoking as an important risk factor, one must\ninvestigate outbreaks where smoking is common, but crowding and drinking are\nnot. To confirm drinking as a risk factor, one must find situations\nwhere drinking was an independent predictor of risk. Such situations\nare not easy to find and this highlights the weaknesses of outbreak\ninvestigations. Ralph Feigin did a nice investigation of an outbreak in\na school where smoking and drinking were not an issue. The factor most\npredictive of being a secondary case was the nose-to-nose distance of\nthe child in his desk from an index case. Especially for infections\nwith respiratory spread, crowding is a key factor.\n--\nDavid O. Matson, M.D., Ph.D.\nCenter for Pediatric Research\nNorfolk, Virginia\ne-mail: MATSON@PICARD.EVMS.EDU\n[Via: Dorothy B. The death toll in Nigeria rose to\n3,386, an increase of more than 700 in a week, the UN agency said. In Niger, 4,808 people are\ninfected, with 503 deaths so far.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-04-01 00:00:00", "1996-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2188122", "headline": "PROMED-EDR: Meningitis, control (2)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2188122", "date": "1996-03-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, CONTROL (2)\n=======================\n[This posting collects two replies to the original item on\nthis subject.]\n[1]\nFrom: Patrick S Moore <psm9@columbia.edu>\nDate: Fri, 15 Mar 1996 12:18:22 -0500 (EST)\nChemoprophylaxis recommendations differ between developing and developed\ncountries. Chemoprophylaxis is effective in reducing secondary cases in\nepidemiologically well-defined and limited situations in developed\ncountries (e.g. household contacts, day-care contacts, persons with\ndirect oral contact from kissing, mouth-to-mouth resuscitation).\nGenerally, for these very limited settings, prophylaxis is given after an\ninitial case in the US. This does not apply to general medical personnel\n(i.e. emergency room personnel) without intimate respiratory contact.\nIn developing countries with ongoing epidemics, as is currently occurring\nin West and Central Africa, chemoprophylaxis a limited role and generally\nis not a useful public health intervention. The reason is that carriage\nof epidemic strains is common under these circumstances and reinfection\nor infection after chemoprophylaxis frequently occurs. Widespread\nprophylaxis will only hope to increase drug-resistance rates for a\nvariety of infections and also increase drug-related toxicity.\nFor group A and C epidemics in developing countries, rapid mass\nvaccination is required to reduce attack rates.\nThe vaccine has a limited duration of protection but short-term, high\nefficacy rates in children and adults (even down to 1 year\nof age) can be expected from the polysaccharide vaccine. Threshold\nrates are being evaluated to discriminate\nepidemic from endemic disease to guide vaccination programs (a rate\ngreater than 15 cases/100,000/week averaged over a two week period is\nthe standard). However, in the case where a clear epidemic is ongoing in\na region (as is the case for Chad, Nigeria and Burkina Faso), then\nvaccination should be instituted immediately in any near-by\npopulation in which new cases are starting to appear regardless of the\nincidence rate.\nIs the current West African pandemic known to be due to the group III-1\nclonal complex or is it a new clone(s)?\n--\nPatrick S. Moore, M.D., MPH\nColumbia University, School of Public Health, New York, NY\ne-mail: psm9@columbia.edu\n.................................................................\n\n[2]\nFrom: 'Jon Rosenberg M.D. C' <HW1.JROSENBE@HW1.CAHWNET.GOV>\nDate: 15 Mar 1996 09:20:09 PST\nThat same CDR Review contains a report of a secondary case of meningococcal\ndisease occurring in a day nursery contact 16 days after apparently receiving\nrifampin prophylaxis, in spite of a survey indicating 55/57 children and 10/10\nstaff were 'thought to have complied fully with treatment.' The case is\ndescribed as supporting the withdrawal of recommendations to give antibiotics\nto nursery contacts of a case, who were felt to be a greater risk of serious\nadverse drug reactions than of meningococcal disease. Canadian Guidelines for\nControl of Meningococcal Disease (Canada Communicable Disease report Vol 20-3,\n15 February 1994) continue to define child care and/or nursery school contacts\nas close contacts meriting prophylaxis following a single case. I understand\nthat the U.S. CDC is currently working on guidelines. I doubt that there is\nsufficient data from child care/nursery school cases currently to make a clear\nchoice between these two recommendations. I have observed that parental and\ncommunity anxiety need to be taken into consideration, and that these are\nfrequently driven by the outcome of the index case.\n--\nJon Rosenberg M.D.\nState of California, Div. Comm. Dis. Cont.\n2151 Berkeley Way, Berkeley CA 94704\nTel.: +1(510) 540-3233 Fax +1(510) 540-2570\ne-mail: jrosenbe@hw1.cahwnet.gov\n..............................................................\n..............................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Threshold\nrates are being evaluated to discriminate\nepidemic from endemic disease to guide vaccination programs (a rate\ngreater than 15 cases/100,000/week averaged over a two week period is\nthe standard). \n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. \nPatrick S. Moore, M.D., MPH\nColumbia University, School of Public Health, New York, NY\ne-mail: psm9@columbia.edu\n................................................................. Canadian Guidelines for\nControl of Meningococcal Disease (Canada Communicable Disease report Vol 20-3,\n15 February 1994) continue to define child care and/or nursery school contacts\nas close contacts meriting prophylaxis following a single case. Chemoprophylaxis is effective in reducing secondary cases in\nepidemiologically well-defined and limited situations in developed\ncountries (e.g. household contacts, day-care contacts, persons with\ndirect oral contact from kissing, mouth-to-mouth resuscitation). That same CDR Review contains a report of a secondary case of meningococcal\ndisease occurring in a day nursery contact 16 days after apparently receiving\nrifampin prophylaxis, in spite of a survey indicating 55/57 children and 10/10\nstaff were 'thought to have complied fully with treatment.' The case is\ndescribed as supporting the withdrawal of recommendations to give antibiotics\nto nursery contacts of a case, who were felt to be a greater risk of serious\nadverse drug reactions than of meningococcal disease. Tel.: +1(510) 540-3233 Fax +1(510) 540-2570\ne-mail: jrosenbe@hw1.cahwnet.gov\n..............................................................\n.............................................................................. In developing countries with ongoing epidemics, as is currently occurring\nin West and Central Africa, chemoprophylaxis a limited role and generally\nis not a useful public health intervention. The vaccine has a limited duration of protection but short-term, high\nefficacy rates in children and adults (even down to 1 year\nof age) can be expected from the polysaccharide vaccine. I doubt that there is\nsufficient data from child care/nursery school cases currently to make a clear\nchoice between these two recommendations. Widespread\nprophylaxis will only hope to increase drug-resistance rates for a\nvariety of infections and also increase drug-related toxicity. I have observed that parental and\ncommunity anxiety need to be taken into consideration, and that these are\nfrequently driven by the outcome of the index case. The reason is that carriage\nof epidemic strains is common under these circumstances and reinfection\nor infection after chemoprophylaxis frequently occurs. Is the current West African pandemic known to be due to the group III-1\nclonal complex or is it a new clone(s)?\n Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to:", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1996-03-26 00:00:00", "1994-02-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "M.D.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Central Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2188118", "headline": "PROMED-EDR: Meningitis - Nigeria (6)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2188118", "date": "1996-03-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - NIGERIA (6)\n========================\nDate: 14 Mar 96 19:16:41 EST\nFrom: Peter.A.Rogers@Dartmouth.EDU (Peter A Rogers)\nMeningitis in northern Nigeria\nI am an advisory member of a committee of expatriate Nigerians and\nfriends of Nigeria, who have recently organized a fund drive to help\nfight the current meningitis epidemic in the northern part of the\ncountry.\nWhile CSM is acknowledged to be a perennial dry-season problem in\nthis region, many see in the scale of this year's affliction a\nreflection of the military government's absolute dysfunction.\nThe Nigeria Meningitis Appeal Fund began just over two weeks ago on\none of the main Nigeria newsgroups on the Internet, under the\ncommitted inspiration of O. Kasirim Nguwe of Boston University. Since\nits inception, the appeal has raised nearly $2000.00 from dozens of\nnetters in the US and UK.\nIt is my understanding that Medecins Sans Frontiers has been the main\nhealth NGO on the ground in and around Kano over the past several weeks.\nI would like get confirmation about this and additional information as\nto what other NGOs (Nigerian and non-Nigerian) are involved. We would\nlike to contact such organizations to determine immediate medical needs\nof the vaccination campaign.\nThanks,\nPeter A. Rogers\nDept of History\nDartmouth College\nHanover, NH\n[Moderator - Martin Hugh-Jones]\n..........................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Rogers\n Dept of History\nDartmouth College\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2188117", "headline": "PROMED-EDR: Meningitis, control", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2188117", "date": "1996-03-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, CONTROL\n===================\nDate: Thu, 14 Mar 1996 14:39:48 +1000 (EST)\nFrom: 'Dr. Ossama El-Saadi' <o.elsaadi@portal.qut.edu.au>\nIn the CDR Review, Vol 5 Review No 13 pages R189-193 'Control of\nmeningococcal disease: guidance for consultants in communicable\ndisease control.' Under recommendations for management of clusters,\nthat in absence of good evidence to guide best practice,\n'chemoprophylaxis should be offered to all children and staff if\ntwo or more cases of the same strain occur within four weeks in\nthe same play group, nursery, or primary school....' The practice\nin Australia is to offer chemoprophylaxis if one case does occur.\nAny views or comments?\nOssama El-Saadi\nEpidemiologist\nZonal Population Health Unit\nQueensland\nEmail : o.elsaadi@portal.qut.edu.au\nFax: 61 7 3256 3522\n................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Total reported cases are 8,252. The\ncountry's director of preventive medicine, it is reported, said that the\nepidemic is continuing even though 1.3 million people have been vaccinated\nand despite public information campaigns. A new vaccination effort has\nbegun, using 200,000 doses on hand and 400,000 doses now in transit..\nThis report brings the number of reported deaths from meningitis in West\nAfrica to almost 3500 -- 722 in Burkina Faso, over 200 in Niger and 2,550 in\nnorthern Nigeria.\n--\nDorothy B. Genetik\nDate: Tue, 30 Jan 1996 10:11:12 MET +0100\n\nMENINGITIS AND MENINGOCOCCAL DISEASE - FLORIDA, USA (8)\n=======================================================\nThere have been a couple of comments to this topic relating clonal\nrelationships of meningococci. In fact, there are well-establised clonal\nschemes based on MLEE [multilocus enzyme electrophoresis] with defined\nreference strains available on request for both serogroup A meningococci\n(Infect. Immun. 60: 5267-5282, 1992) and serogroup C meningococci\n(JID 167: 1320-1329, 1993). A similar minimal set\nof reference strains has also been developed for serogroup B\nmeningococci (Molec. Microbiol. in press). Tight clonal relationships\nwithin meningococci are also readily demonstrated using pulsed-field\ngel electrophoresis (J. gen. Microbiol., 138:523-531, 1992) or\nRAPD ['random amplified polymorphic DNA', a method for DNA\nfingerprinting] (J. Infect. Dis., 169:1384-1389, 1994).\nHowever, the latter methods have not yet been integrated\ninto global typing schemes which readily allow comparisons between\ndifferent laboratories.\n--\nMark Achtman\nMax-Planck-Institut fuer molekulare Genetik,\nD-14195 Berlin Germany\ne-mail: achtman@MPIMG-Berlin-Dahlem.MPG.DE\nPhone (+49) 30 8413 1262\nFax (+49) 30 8413 1387 (or 1385)\n.............................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. There have been a couple of comments to this topic relating clonal\nrelationships of meningococci.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1385-03-26 00:00:00", "1996-01-30 00:00:00", "1993-03-26 00:00:00", "1994-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2187835", "headline": "PROMED: Meningitis, meningococcal - Florida USA (5)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2187835", "date": "1996-01-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "From: david.watson@utmb.edu\nDate: Wed, 24 Jan 1996 17:34:17 -0500 (CDT)\n\nMENINGITIS & MENINGOCOCCAL DISEASE - FLORIDA, USA (5)\n=====================================================\nThis really is intriguing. In bacterial disease outbreaks examined to date\nby molecular methods, it has been the case that molecular typing (by PCR)\nessentially confirms what phenotypic markers already suggest. Namely, that\nwithin a given outbreak all isolates are the same clone (i.e. genotype).\nRecently, isolates of Streptococcus pneumoniae (one of the most common of\nbacterial pathogens and one of the more virulent) have been shown to have\napparently switched serotypes (the extracellular polysaccharide capsule\ncovering the bacterium) while otherwise maintaining the same clonal identity\nas determined by molecular methods (the genes encoding the polysaccharide\ncapsule comprise an operon or cassette). One could therefore imagine a\nvirulent N. meningitidis clone with the capacity for (for want of a better\nway to put it) 'hyperswitchability' of extracellular polysaccharide capsular\nserotype. A straightforward molecular typing method, such as REP/ERIC PCR\n[method using conserved repeat sequences in the genome] or\nRAPD [random amplified polymorphic DNA] PCR, or possibly\nmultilocus enzyme electrophoresis (MLEE), would tell\nyou right away whether the isolates are of the same clone. Please keep us\nupdated both on the outbreak and on any attempts to genotype the isolates.\n--\nDavid A. Watson, Ph.D., Asst Prof of Microbiology & Immunology\nDepartment of Microbiology & Immunology\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston, TX 77555-1019\nph. 409-747-0952 fax 409-772-5065\ne-mail: david.watson@utmb.edu\n..............................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator).
