Date: Wed, 24 Jan 1996 17:34:17 -0500 (CDT)\n\nMENINGITIS & MENINGOCOCCAL DISEASE - FLORIDA, USA (5)\n=====================================================\n Please keep us\nupdated both on the outbreak and on any attempts to genotype the isolates.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1996-01-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2188068", "headline": "PROMED-EDR: Meningitis - Nigeria (5)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2188068", "date": "1996-03-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "From: estevesk@who.ch\nDate: Wed, 06 Mar 96 15:57:54 CET\n\nMENINGITIS - NIGERIA (5)\n========================\nSubject: Communicable disease news - 7 March 1996\nDisease outbreaks reported\n\n7 March\nMeningococcal meningitis\nNigeria: As at 4 March, 15 733 cases with 2 411 deaths had been\nreported in 12 States: Adamawa, Bauchi, Benue, Cross River, Kano,\nKaduna, Katsina, Kebbi, Kwara, Niger, Sokoto, and Taraba. Most cases\nwere from Bauchi (4 399 cases/802 deaths), Kebbi (2 812/429), Kano (2\n475/419), Sokoto (1 687/246) and Katsina (1 590/419). Cases began to\nbe reported in January and the numbers reported increased markedly in\nFebruary. The Ministry of Health in collaboration with WHO, UNICEF\nand NGOs, including MSF, France have dispatched medical teams to the\naffected states to assist in the evaluation and control of the\noutbreaks. Over 8 million doses of vaccine, antibiotics and infusion\nfluids have been distributed to the affected States and the Federal\nMinistry of Health has ordered an additional 10 million doses of the\nvaccine. Immunization is planned for the populations in all urban\nareas in these states. For Kano State, MSF has provided drugs and\nequipment to a value of US$ 1.9 million. The Federal Ministry of\nHealth reports that the concerted efforts have helped bring the\noutbreaks under control and there is no cause for alarm.\n......................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Preliminary data for 1994 are 974 cases\nand for 1995, 1106 notified by 28 December 1995. In 1995, 40% of\nthe cases were in children under 5 and 16% of the cases died. Most\ncases (90%) in 1995 were from the metropolitan area and about half\nfrom Rio de Janeiro [the city; the remaining 10% of cases must have been\nfrom Rio de Janeiro State - Mod.JW].\nTypes B and C have increased during this period, and in 1995 when 48% of\ncases were serotyped, 42% [of those typed] were type B and\n57% type C. Ampicillin and penicillin has been recommended for\ntreatment of cases, rifampicin for prophylaxis in close contacts.\nSeveral vaccination campaigns have been conducted in the state. In\nDecember 1994 - February 1995, 63% of children in age groups from 6\nmonths to 13 years and over 80% in age groups between 1 and 9 years\nreceived the vaccine. The vaccination campaign was resumed in\nNovember 1995 targeting the age groups 14-29 years.\n............................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Case fatality rates ranged from 2.5%\nto 30% in the different States. The cases were reported in Adamawa,\nBauchi, Kano, Kaduna, Katsina, Kebbi, Kwara, Niger, Sokoto and Taraba\nStates. Deaths from meningitis had also been registered in Cross\nRiver. Most cases were reported in Bauchi (2 504 cases, 461 deaths),\nKaduna (2 000 cases, 50 deaths), and Katsina (1 590 cases, 297\ndeaths). Preliminary laboratory investigations of 5 cases have\nidentified Neisseria meningitidis serogroup A in 3 cases and serogroup\nB in 1. Samples are being further investigated. The Ministry of\nHealth has sent teams to the affected areas and experts from WHO,\nUNICEF and MSF have joined the teams in their support to control\nactivities.\nThe epidemic in Bauchi State may have started in early January\n1996. By 24 February almost all administrative areas had been\naffected, and 5 of them severely and one LGA, Itas-Gadu reporting an\nincidence rate of 369.8 per 100 000. Case fatality rates have ranged\nfrom 6.5% to 33.9% with many areas reporting high mortality rates The\nnumber of cases reported in Bauchi State in the first 2 months of 1996\nwas far greater than the number of cases reported annually in previous\nyears. Mass immunization has started with 250 000 doses issued by the\nFederal Ministry of Health, the State Ministry of Health and local\ngovernment services have order additional 380 000 doses of vaccine.\nThe State Ministry of Health has started a campaign to inform the\ngeneral public about the outbreak.\nIn Kano State, 12 LGS have reported cases of cerebrospinal\nmeningitis with incidence rates ranging from 14 to 309 cases per 100\n000 population. Rates above 300 were reported in and 2 LGS, Bagwai\nand Dawakin Tofa. Up to 24 February, over 300 000 doses of vaccine\nhad been distributed among school children, armed forces and prison\ninmates. Patients were treated with penicillin and chloramphenicol.\n\n.........................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Hopkins <RYH8@WONDER.EM.CDC.GOV>\nDate: Fri, 26 Jan 96 15:54:00 EST\n\nMENINGOCOCCAL INFECTION (GROUP C) - FLORIDA, USA (6)\n====================================================\n[For previous postings, see:\nEarlier report: promed archive.960119\nAdditional discussion: promed archive.960124 & archive.960125\nReports & discussion - Texas, USA: promed archive.960121 & archive.960123]\nThe Florida State Health Office, the Okaloosa County Public Health Unit, the\nUS Air Force, the Okaloosa County Public Schools and local EMS units are\ncooperating in a campaign to provide multivalent meningococcal polysaccharide\nvaccine to approximately 5000 children residing in one area Fort Walton Beach,\nFlorida.\nThere have been seven confirmed cases of Neisseria meningitidis invasive\ndisease since the first of the year. Two have been group B, one group Y, and\nfour group C. An additional possible case is under investigation. Two of the\ngroup C cases were in children in the same elementary school, with onset dates\ntwo days apart.\nThe target group is children two years of age through 8th grade, living in\nFort Walton Beach south of Cinco Bayou and Gap Creek, and west from Brooks\nBridge to Hurlbut Field. The majority of children in this area are US Air\nForce dependents.\nOn Saturday clinics will provide vaccine for preschool children; vaccine will\nbe provided for school-age children through the schools starting on Monday.\nAfter next Friday proof of immunization will be required for school\nattendance.\nInformation is available through the Okaloosa CPHU at 904-833-9244 or through\nthe state epidemiology office at 904-488-2905.\n--\nRichard S. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail.", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "1996-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Gap Creek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FLORIDA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Walton Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MSPH", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2187817", "headline": "PROMED: Meningitis, meningococcal - Florida USA (3)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2187817", "date": "1996-01-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "From: 'Mark Achtman' <Mark@Novell-MPIMG1.RZ-Berlin.MPG.DE>\nOrganization: Max Planck Inst. fuer mol. Genetik\nDate: Thu, 25 Jan 1996 12:53:58 MET +0100\n\nMENINGITIS & INVASIVE MENINGOCOCCAL INFECTION - FLORIDA, USA (3)\n================================================================\nIn a recent publication of mine (Trends in Microbiology,\n3:186-192, 1995; reprints available), I summarized data\ncompatible with meningococcal outbreaks being\nassociated with outbreaks of a second, unrecognized\nimmunomodulating microorganism. I also speculated on epidemic\nspread and increases in frequency of carriage rate also being\ndependent on an unrecognized microorganism, which\nmight differ from the one responsible for immunomodulation.\nUnder circumstances where the bacteria present in the carrier\npopulation are clonally homogeneous, or where they are rapidly\nspreading and colonizing numerous individuals, meningococci\nisolated from disease outbreaks will be clonally\nhomogeneous. Under conditions where the carrier bacteria\ncontain several clones capable of causing invasive disease,\ndisease outbreaks will be clonally heterogeneous. Examples\nof major epidemics which are clonally homogeneous as\nwell as other which were clonally heterogeneous exist.\nA general summary of the global epidemiology of epidemic\ndisease may also be found in a different recent\npublication of mine (Meningococcal disease, edited by\nK. Cartwright, John Wiley, 1995, pp. 159-175; the book\nis a wonderful compendium of review articles;\nreprints of my article are also available).\n--\nMark Achtman\nMax-Planck-Institut fuer molekulare Genetik,\nD-14195 Berlin Germany\nE-mail: achtman@MPIMG-Berlin-Dahlem.MPG.DE\nPhone (+49) 30 8413 1262\nFax (+49) 30 8413 1387 (or 1385)\n...........................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Taylor' <JTAYLOR@DISCON.TDH.STATE.TX.US>\nOrganization: Texas Department of Health\nDate: Tue, 23 Jan 1996 11:20:01 -0600 (CST)\n\nMENINGITIS & MENINGOCOCCAL INFECTION - TEXAS, USA (2)\n=====================================================\nThere have been recent discussions on meningococcal disease activity,\nspecifically the activity in the state of Florida, and a request for\ninformation on meningococcal disease activity in the state of Texas.\nThe preliminary number of invasive meningococcal disease cases\nreported in Texas in 1995 is 256. Below lists the number of cases\nand incidence rate for each year since 1982. Historical data for\nmeningococcal disease in Texas shows a cyclic trend of increasing\nnumber of cases every 10-12 years. Typically, incidence rates in\nchildren are higher compared with adults. In 1994, the rate per\n100,000 children under one year of age was 11.0; in 1-4 year olds,\n3.9; in 5-9 year olds, 2.3; in 10-14 year olds, 1.0. Rates for age\ngroups over 15 years of age are usually 1.0 or less. A high\npercentage (57%) of cases occurred in the winter months of January,\nFebruary, March, Novermber, and December.\nIn 1994, 149 Neisseria meningitidis isolates were serotyped at the\nTexas Department of Health laboratory. Sixty percent were group C;\n28% were group B; 9% were group Y; and 3% were group W135.\nRecent community-wide outbreaks with Group C have occurred in counties\nin East and North Texas. These outbreaks have lasted several months.\nIncreased activity in Gregg County (106,000 population) in East\nTexas occurred from March 1994 through October 1995. A total of 28\ncases occurred primarily in children and adults less than 29 years of\nage. From March 1994 through October 1995 over 30,000 county\nresidents received meningococcal vaccine.\nInvasive meningococcal disease cases in Texas by year.\nYear Number Rate/100,000\n1995 256 1.4 preliminary\n1994 237 1.3\n1993 157 0.9\n1992 111 0.6\n1991 100 0.6\n1990 93 0.5\n1989 93 0.5\n1988 98 0.6\n1987 126 0.7\n1986 138 0.8\n1985 132 0.8\n1984 180 1.2\n1983 188 1.2\n1982 238 1.6\n--\nJeffery P. Hopkins, MD, MSPH\nState Epidemiologist, HSDE\n904-488-2905\nryh8@wonder.em.cdc.gov\nNeisseria meningitidis disease in Okaloosa County.\nOkaloosa County has had at least 5 confirmed cases of invasive meningococcal\ndisease since Dec 30. All have been in children and all are recovering. Two\nof the children were siblings with simultaneous onset. Two others are\nunrelated children at Eglin AFB [Air Force Base]. The Okaloosa CPHU [County\nPublic Health Unit?] is taking vigorous, well-targeted preventive action\nwith close contacts of cases.\nIsolates so far have been of three different serogroups. Aside\nfrom the two siblings, none of the other cases have been epi-linked. The\nvariety of serogroups is extremely important in confirming that the cases are\nnot connected. Why cases of several different serogroups would appear\nsimultaneously is not understood. Co-infection with another agent, such as\ninfluenza virus, is a possible explanation.\n--\nRichard S. Hopkins, MD, MSPH\nState Epidemiologist, HSDE\nTel.: +(1) 904-488-2905\ne-mail: ryh8@wonder.em.cdc.gov\n\n[The UK recently reported several cases of invasive meningococcal disease.\nDo any subscribers believe they are seeing more cases of invasive\ndisease than they would normally expect, based on historical data? - Mod.]\n............................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Hypotheses to explain the Okaloosa situation would be welcome.\n--\nRichard Hopkins, MD, MSPH\nState epidemiologist, Florida State Health Office\nTel.: +1-904-922-2203\ne-mail: ryh8@wonder.em.cdc.gov\n...........................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
